Sonat's Houston-based subsidiary, Sonat Offshore Drilling, will take delivery from the South Korean builder beginning in 1986. The company said the rigs would be able to drill through more than 20,000 feet of rock in water 3,000 feet deep.

title: FILM:'NOT FOR PUBLICATION,' A COMEDY
description: ''NOT FOR PUBLICATION'' is the new comedy by Paul Bartel, the almost recklessly independent film maker whose ''Eating Raoul'' gave a whole new meaning to the term ''gourmet cooking.'' Like B-movies of the 1930's and 40's, ''Not for Publication'' tears the lid off the whole rotten world of crooked politics and sleazy journalism while demonstrating how one good young woman, who possesses pluck and a certain taste for sleaziness herself, can set things to right.

title: TV-Olympics Squabble

''We really regret we have to come up with a decision,'' he said, ''because whatever we decide will hurt somebody.''

'THE THREE WISHES OF BILLY GRIER'
description: TELEVISION movies make no secret of the fact that they are unusually partial to diseases of both the social and physical sort, but ''The Three Wishes of Billy Grier,'' on ABC tonight at 8, does stretch things a bit in its search for inspirational fodder. Billy, it seems, has a rare metabolism ailment that will prematurely age him from 15 into an elderly man in the span of a single year. How rare? you may well ask. A preface carefully notes: ''This story is fiction. There exists a rare disease affecting the young who age in a short life span and die. This picture imagines such a life.'' Later on, a doctor in the film will explain that ''the disorder is extremely rare.'' Give the production a brownie point for honesty.

title: India Without Indira Gandhi It very nearly happened in Brighton two weeks ago, in Rome and in Washington three years before. This time, in New Delhi, assassins claimed a world leader, Indira Gandhi, and forced a new crisis for India's democracy. The Prime Minister's immense authority was chiefly personal, and she leaves no real successor.
description: Her death is the more grievous because so much more was invested in her than in even a Pope, an American President or British Prime Minister: the task of holding India together and free.

title: Florida Gains Delay
description: James H. McComas , president of Mississippi State University, has granted a request by Marshall Criser, president of the University of Florida, to postpone a meeting of the Southeastern Conference executive committee that had been called for Monday to decide whether Florida's football team should be banned from bowl games this season and barred from qualifying for the S.E.C. championship. A series of recruiting and other violations has already led the National Collegiate Athletic Association to impose sanctions, including a ban on bowl appearances. Now the school has until Wednesday to appeal the N.C.A.A. sanctions, which would automatically postpone to January - after the bowl games - any N.C.A.A. sanctions.

title: Harry J. Chaloner Dies at 110; Oldest Veteran in the Nation
description: Harry J. Chaloner, America's oldest veteran, died Tuesday at Bay Pines Veterans Administration Medical Center. He was 110 years old.

title: Endangered Bats Spur Army To Reconsider Training Plan
description: Two endangered species of bats that hibernate each year in a cave in rural central Tennessee have forced the Army to reconsider plans to use the deserted tract of land as a training center.

title: RETRACING THE ANALYSIS
description: Margaret Thatcher escaped and Indira Gandhi was cut down; Ronald Reagan lived and Anwar Sadat died; the Pope survived and a pro-Solidarity Polish priest was secretly murdered. Every world leader is the target of some madman, or nationalist group, or religious fanatic, or other world leader willing to employ terrorists.

title: Times Official Is Promoted
description: The New York Times has named Russell T. Lewis a senior vice president.

title: FOLD-UP FURNITURE: VERSATILE DESIGNS
description: COLLAPSIBLE furniture, a necessity for those who live in small spaces, is no longer a stepchild of the design world. Manufacturers are now turning out pieces that are both comfortable and good-looking.

title: CONFLICT OF FUNCTION IS AT CORE OF STATE MENTAL-HEALTH SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $6.8 million on the retirement of debt and a tax credit. c-Net loss.

title: KASPAROV AND KARPOV DRAW AGAIN
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov drew the 20th game of their world chess championship match today, the 11th consecutive draw.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Road to Hollywood Is All Downhill
description: Hollywood was never far from where Bill Johnson grew up. Just a short ride on the freeway and there they were, all the stars you could see while walking down Hollywood Boulevard. Johnson showed the world last February that he is very good at getting down a snowy hill from the start to the finish, and he has proved just as resourceful in his trip from Van Nuys to Hollywood. He just went via the slopes of Sarajevo.

title: Halloween Mischief
description: When students at A. Philip Randolph High School started throwing eggs yesterday, Officer Catherine A. Kenny called for help.

title: YIDDISH MUSICAL IN CZARIST RUSSIA
description: DEPENDING on which reference work one consults, Abraham Goldfaden is either the father or the grandfather of the Yiddish theater.

title: SOFTWARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEITHER SILENCE NOR SHAME FOR THE BEIRUT DEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $648,000, or 17 cents a share, on the sale of a subsidiary. Share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 4.

title: Yields on 6-Month C.D.'s Continue to Fall
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell drastically for the second consecutive week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. For the week ended yesterday, The Monitor's national index on six- month C.D.'s slid to 10.55 percent, from 10.78 percent, while the index on the money market accounts declined to 9.56 percent, from 9.67 percent.

title: IS THERE THE WILL?
description: JERUSALEM The inflation rate is 800 percent a

title: CHURCH SAYS CIVIL RIGHTS IN CHILE ARE ERODING
description: Roman Catholic Church officials say that the Government's tactics against protesters this week illustrate what they assert has been a significant new erosion of human rights and civil liberties.

title: N.C.A.A. Role Is Clarified OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 31
description: Judge Juan Burciaga,

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Brooks Fashion Stores Inc., a women's retail store operator, said stockholders had approved a leveraged buyout, making the company a unit of BR investors, a closely held concern whose shareholders include former officers of Brooks Dylex Ltd.

title: 10 Killed as a Nighttime Fire Sweeps Manila Tourist Hotel
description: Ten people were killed when fire swept the seventh floor of a tourist hotel early today, authorities reported.

title: AIR ONE'S MYSTERIOUS 'ANGEL'
description: Air One, a nine-plane airline based in St. Louis, was staring at bankruptcy two weeks ago. It needed money quickly, just to pay the fuel bill to keep its planes aloft.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 1, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MEDICAL GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMONG INDIANS FAR FROM HOME, JOYFUL CELEBRATIONS CONTRAST WITH SHOCK AND GRIEF
description: American Sikh leaders voiced deep concern about possible Hindu retaliation for the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi yesterday, but many ordinary Sikhs jubilantly celebrated the killing by handing out candy.

title: THE MAN WHO PUT NEO IN NEOLIBERAL
description: Charles A. Peters, known to his friends as ''the godfather of neoliberalism,'' is convinced that the ideas espoused by his movement are being avidly accepted by many Americans. But he wonders whether they are aware of the movement's name, which even he feels is pretentious.

title: SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Net income.

title: PHILIPS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIAS SUIT SETTLED BY LOAN COMPANY
description: The Household Finance Corporation, one of the nation's largest consumer finance companies, agreed today to give equal consideration to loan applicants who were unmarried or female or on public assistance.

title: NATIONAL COMPREHENSIVE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $365,000. c-Year-ago results are not available because the company went public in August.

title: MAYS, J.W. INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $390,000, or 18 cents a share. c-Net loss. Results for the 1984 fiscal year include income of $1,834,005 from the settlement of pre-Chapter 11 liabilities, litigation, and claims and controversies, a gain of $1,488,938 on the sale of property in Massapequa, and expenses amounting to $721,089 resulting from store closings and Chapter 11 administration costs. Results for the 1983 year include expenses amounting to $853,931 resulting from store closings and Chapter 11 administration costs. The company was discharged from Chapter 11 in the current fiscal year, on Feb. 14, 1984.

title: GRIEF AND ANGER OF NEW DELHI CROWD
description: At the medical institute where Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was taken after she was shot this morning, tens of thousands of people, including Members of Parliament, Cabinet ministers and top police officials, had gathered.

title: FISCHER & PORTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,014,000 from the sale of certain property. c-Net loss.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results for the latest year include the operations of Food World Inc. from April 2, the date of its acquisition.

title: CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operaions of $522,000 for the quarter and $365,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $68,000 for the quarter and $1,515,000 for the 9 months.

title: TAX MAN DECIDES TO SACK THE JETS
description: Many of the Jets were rudely reminded of the New England Patriots today when they opened their mail and found that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts was demanding back taxes from them.

title: GANDHI, SLAIN, IS SUCCEEDED BY SON; KILLING LAID TO 2 SIKH BODYGUARDS; ARMY ALERTED TO BAR SECT VIOLENCE
description: Rajiv Gandhi, who was chosen today to become India's new Prime Minister after the assassination of his mother, Indira, was propelled into public life after his younger, more politically ambitious brother, Sanjay, died in a stunt plane crash in 1980. At the time, Sanjay was regarded as his mother's likely successor and, after Mrs. Gandhi, the most powerful politician in the country. Sanjay's death left a vacuum that Mrs. Gandhi and her followers urged Rajiv to fill.

title: HINDU FUNERAL TRADITIONS The Hindu belief in reincarnation provides the basis for its funeral rituals. Though these practices differ somewhat among social and economic groups, there is a common core of tradition.
description: For married Hindus, men and women alike, cremation is the normal procedure for disposing of the body. There is no specific time element involved, but in most cases the rite takes place within a day of the death.

title: TOFU TIME INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $18,148. Sales for the latest year include $1,483,450 in sales recorded in the fourth quarter.

title: Court Bar to Operation Of Atom Plant Lifted
description: The United State Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today lifted its seven-week-old injunction blocking the commercial operation of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant in California.

title: INDIA'S DEMOCRATIC SYSTEM
description: India is a democratic republic. Its Constitution, which took effect Jan. 26, 1950, was strongly influenced by India's former British rulers in its adoption of a parliamentary legislature.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMSTOCK GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect the issuance of 1 million common shares on Oct. 19.

title: Doctors' Emotions
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:The recent Hers columns written by Perri Klass have been most enjoyable and bring back memories. Her description of her colleagues' disapproval over seeking help from a senior physician (Sept. 27) was, however, disturbing.

title: BRIDGE: U.S. OPEN TEAM AT OLYMPIAD GAINS, AND WOMEN REBOUND
description: The United States open team advanced but the women's team lost ground when play resumed in the World Team Olympiad this afternoon.

title: Catholic Slain in Belfast
description: Masked gunmen shot and killed a 40- year-old Catholic man, Harry Muldoon, in Belfast, Northern Ireland, today in what the police there said they believed was a sectarian murder. Protestant loyalists said the victim drove an unlicensed taxi in the Catholic Falls Road area.

title: William Brokaw, 54, Investment Executive
description: William Vail Brokaw, the founder and president of the Brokaw Capital Management Company, died Sunday at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, Mass., after suffering a heart attack while traveling. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTHVIEW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A BANK THAT BANKS ON CONSERVATIVE DOLLARS
description: Last year a new bank opened in a sleek, new downtown building on K Street. Officials of the venture, the Palmer National Bank, talked about reaching high-technology customers, entrepreneurs and an ''upscale market.''

title: NBC TO DEPICT SLAYING OF GREEN BERET'S FAMILY
description: ''Fatal Vision,'' an NBC television miniseries based on the case of a Green Beret doctor who was convicted in 1979 of killing his pregnant wife and two young daughters, will go on the air as scheduled Nov. 18 and 19 despite requests from Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald's lawyers that the program be delayed.

title: P & F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $73,000.

title: Clubs Sue City On Anti-Bias Law
description: A group of private clubs has sued New York City to stop enforcement of a new law barring discrimination by certain clubs in the city.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses. c-Including a gain of $2.8 million, or 47 cents a share, associated with the sale and disposal of certain assets.

title: MONDALE, IN HOLIDAY PLEA, WARNS OF TRICK OR TREAT BY REPUBLICANS
description: Walter F. Mondale, spending the final days of his campaign pleading for the votes of wavering Democrats and the middle class, today told warmly responding crowds that the the re-election of President Reagan would be marked by economic and social injustice.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $951,000, or 14 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: 600,000 Said to Join Strike in Ecuador
description: Ecuador's United Labor Front staged a 24-hour general strike today in its first challenge to the 10-week-old conservative Government, crippling industrial belts in cities around the country, unionists said.

title:
ASSASSINATION IN INDIA: ANXIETY IN WASHINGTON;
WORLD POLITICAL AND RELIGIOUS LEADERS ARE UNANIMOUS IN GRIEF AND OUTRAGE
description: Political and religious leaders in all parts of the world today fiercely condemned the assassination of Indira Gandhi and, with a rare unanimity that cut across all ideological boundaries, praised her as a champion of her people.

title: BRITISH ARE SAID TO SEEK U.S. ANTITRUST FINE CURB
description: Sources close to talks between American and British antitrust and aviation officials - scheduled to resume today in London - say the British are trying to persuade the Americans to introduce legislation in Congress that would make it impossible for a private party to collect triple damages in an antitrust action against a foreign entity.

title: 'Personal Loss' for Galbraith
description: John Kenneth Galbraith, a former American Ambassador to India, said today that he felt a ''personal loss'' at the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India. ''My first reaction is one of personal loss,'' said Mr. Galbraith, who met and became friends with Mrs. Gandhi in 1956 before she was elected Prime Minister.

title: NBC Poll Finds Reagan In Lead by 58% to 34% By The Associated PressPresident Reagan holds a lead of 24 percentage points over Walter F. Mondale among 1,538 likely voters, according to an NBC News poll released Tuesday.
description: The poll, conducted by telephone from Friday to Sunday, found that 58 percent of those questioned said they supported Mr. Reagan and Vice President Bush and 34 percent backed Mr. Mondale and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro. The findings were similar to an NBC News poll taken Oct. 14-16 in which the Republicans led the Democrats by 60 percent to 35 percent.

title: HODGES RELEASED
description: While the Yankees retained one of their newer players, Marty Bystrom, by reaching agreement on a new contract, the Mets let their senior-most player go yesterday.

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: PEGGY LYMAN TROUPE PERFORMS
description: SINCE 1973, Peggy Lyman has been a leading soloist with Martha Graham's Company. She has also managed to keep creatively busy when the Graham Company is not performing by offering solo programs of dances by various choreographers. Recently, she began choreographing her own dances and she has organized her own little troupe, the Peggy Lyman Dance Company, which appeared Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater in works by Miss Lyman and three other choreographers.

title: FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SEPTEMBER FACTORY ORDERS FELL
description: New orders to factories for manufactured goods tumbled 1.8 percent in September, the second monthly decline in a row, the Government reported today.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARETS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 15
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,757,000 for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks and a gain of $2,743,000 for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks on the termination of a pension plan. c-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $392,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. d-Including a tax credit of $120,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Michigan Hospital Bond Issue Set
description: The Michigan State Hospital Finance Authority is offering $48 million of bonds on behalf of the Henry Ford Hospital with a maximum yield of about 10.56 percent for bonds due in 2008. For shorter maturities, bonds were offered with yields ranging from 6.25 percent in 1985 to 10 percent in 1997.

title: EAST-WEST DOCTORS' GROUP WINS PEACE PRIZE
description: An organization founded by two physicians, one Soviet, the other American, has been awarded a United Nations peace prize here.

title: WOMAN FACES JAIL IN A LEGAL DISPUTE
description: A stenographer who lost her court battle to provide low-cost legal services must begin serving a 30-day jail term Nov. 15 for practicing law without a license, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $203.7 million gain from the sale of the company's U.S. unit.

title: Appeals Court Backs Award In a 'Wrongful Birth' Lawsuit
description: A Federal appeals court Tuesday upheld damages of $338,000 to a couple and their retarded children in a suit alleging ''wrongful birth'' against the Government over treatment at a military hospital.

title: TOUGH FOES FOR OLYMPIANS IN PRO DEBUT
description: ''You'll get your chance.''

title: Article 051261 -- No Title
description: Dr. Yuet Wai Kan of the University of California at San Francisco, an expert on sickle cell anemia and other disorders of human blood, yesterday was named winner of the $100,000 Lita Annenberg Hazen Award for excellence in clinical research.

title: ; WE NEED GARDENS TO GIVE A ROOM A VIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: NAKASONE NAMES NEW CABINET IN TOKYO
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone named his new government today, leaving in place top economic and foreign affairs ministers. At the same time, he gave several key Cabinet posts to followers of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rally Ends as Dow Falls 9.93
description: The stock market retreated yesterday in slower trading, giving up much of its gains from the one-day rally Tuesday. The main casualties were some of the technology issues.

title: U.S. RIDERS' DEFEAT STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: An embarrassing loss brought an even more embarrassing controversy spilling forth from the United States Equestrian Team at the National Horse Show last night.

title: Pricing Issue Seen As Threat to Group
description: In retaining the $3-a-barrel difference between the official prices for heavy and light crude oil, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has left unresolved a problem that will undermine its effort to shore up prices, oil industry analysts said yesterday.

title: And Now the Nooze
description: In its final days the Mondale campaign is showing a looser sense of

title: AFTER U.S.F.L., A JOB ON GIANTS
description: The trivia test of the week might well be to identify the only two players from the United States Football League, other than two kickers, who are now regulars in the National Football League.

title: GOODYEAR CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WEST BANK SCHOOL CLOSED BY ISRAELIS
description: The Israeli military authorities today ordered a West Bank university shut down until Monday after three days of intermittent campus rioting.

title: INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a writeoff of 14 cents a share for the company's investment in the ETSI Coal-Slurry Pipeline Project, which was terminated July 31, for the quarter and 9 months.

U.S.F.L. Stars Get New Home
description: The Philadelphia Stars, champions of the United States Football League, will play their home games in the University of Maryland's Byrd Stadium in College Park in the spring of 1985.

title: GIANT YELLOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kean Opposes Coalport Project
description: Governor Kean has informed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that he is opposed to a proposal under study by the authority to locate a coalport on the Hudson River in Bayonne. In a letter released today, the Governor urged the authority to end the project and remove it from the agency's agenda.

title: GIBSON-HOMANS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANAHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Oct. 23 about television coverage of the second Presidential debate cited the wrong candidate in quoting an assessment by the NBC News correspondent Roger Mudd. He said he believed the outcome ''was a slight edge for Mondale.''

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1984 Assassination in India Indira Gandhi was fatally shot at her home in New Delhi by two men identified by police officials as Sikh members of the Prime Minister's personal bodyguard. Officials said the longtime Indian leader was killed by at least eight bullets fired at close range from a submachine gun and a pistol. (Page A1, Columns 1-6.) Anti-Sikh violence rocked New Delhi and at least seven other Indian cities after the assassination of Prime Minister Gandhi. Army troops were deployed in Calcutta and many other cities to curb the wave of street attacks. The entire army was placed on alert. (A18:1-2.)

title: MTV NETWORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes provisions for income taxes of $3,146,000 for the quarter and $7,665,000 for the 9 months. For a part of the quarter and 9 months, however, the company was a partnership between American Express Co. and Warner Communications Inc. and as such, was not subject to taxes. c-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was a partnership between American Express and Warner Communications for part of the duration of the year-ago periods. Net income figures are pro forma as the company went public on Aug. 10, 1984. MTV Networks was incorporated in February 1984.

title: VOTER ROLLS SOAR 11.6 PERCENT TO RECORD HIGH IN CONNECTICUT
description: Spurred by the Presidential election and registration drives by both major parties, Connecticut's voter rolls increased 11.6 percent this year, a record, the state announced today.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $19,900,000 related to the closing of the company's San Diego tuna cannery.

title: Eddie Murphy Signs Contract at Paramount
description: Eddie Murphy, the star of two recent Paramount box office successes, ''48 Hours'' and ''Trading Places,'' has signed a new exclusive contract with that studio.

title: The Candidates Today
description: Walter F. Mondale comes from Buffalo to Manhattan

title: Budd Returns Home
description: Zola Budd has decided not to compete in international track meets for her adopted country of Britain and will remain in South Africa, where she was born. That's what The Daily Mail of London reported yesterday, saying the 18-year-old Miss Budd had made the decision against the advice of her father, her coach and South African sports authorities.

title: Beleaguered Coach
description: Foge Fazio , the Pitt football coach, has a contract through the 1988 season, but with the Panthers' record at a dismal 1-6-1 after the team was voted the No. 3 team in the nation in preseason polls, his days at Pitt could be numbered. That seemed to be the case, anyway, after Ed Bozik , Pitt's athletic director, told his weekly news conference that Pitt's problems were ''serious,'' and that the ''administration and coaching staff intend to do something about it at the appropriate time.'' Asked whether Fazio would be back next year, Bozik said it would be ''inappropriate'' to answer.

title: Jury Picked in Suit Over Time Article
description: A jury was selected yesterday for the trial of a libel suit that Israel's former Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, filed against Time magazine.

title: Charter Units To Be Bought
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will acquire the troubled Charter Company's insurance subsidiaries for $52 million in cash and a contingent payment of up to $39 million five years from the date of the sale, the companies said.

title: Swedish Rate Decline
description: Sweden's major banks said today that they had reduced the interest rate they pay on special accounts held by corporate customers by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 11 percent. An official of Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken said the move was a reaction to last week's decline in Treasury bill rates.

title: MOCHARY LISTS INVESTMENTS OF AT LEAST $1.4 MILLION
description: In the early 1970's, when Mary V. Mochary began her career as a lawyer, she also began a string of investments, some with her brother, I. Michael Kasser, in real estate, logging, baseball and television. Her properties have proved to be productive.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results do not include net gains of $77,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $155,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months. Corrected from yesterday's editions

title: 43 Are Reported Killed In Argentine Crash
description: Forty-three people were reported killed and 22 injured today when a train slammed into a commuter bus at a suburban railroad crossing.

title: Namibia Rebel Deaths Listed
description: -West Africa, Oct. 31 (Reuters) - South African-led troops shot and killed 17 black nationalist guerrillas in the last two weeks, the senior military officer in this territory, also known as Namibia, said today. Maj. Gen. George Meiring, the commander, told reporters six of them were killed in Kavango in the north of the territory, but he gave no other details.

title: MCLEAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Digital Introduces A Minicomputer
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced its long-awaited VAX 8600, a minicomputer that the company hopes will enable it to retain its leadership in the hotly contested field of scientific and engineering computing. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., said the new machine is its fastest, capable of processing about 4.2 million instructions a second, compared with the VAX 780's capability of one million instructions a second.

title: REBEL ASSERTS C.I.A. PLEDGED HELP IN WAR AGAINST SANDINISTAS
description: A senior director of the largest Nicaraguan rebel force says the Central Intelligence Agency recruited him to serve as a director two years ago and told him, ''We are going to help you change the Government in Managua and do it within a year.''

title: SHOREHAM IS AN ISSUE IN CLOSE HOUSE RACE ON L.I.
description: Assemblyman George J. Hochbreuckner, an opponent of the Shoreham nuclear plant, said today that the plant was ''the single most important issue'' in his race to represent the First Congressional District.

title: Waste Concern Is Said To Agree to Pay Fines
description: The Government and Waste Management Inc. have reached an ''agreement in principle'' under which the concern will pay $1.05 million in fines for alleged civil violations at its Alabama toxic waste disposal site, Federal sources said today.

title: CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $211,642 for the quarter and $221,642 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $46,101 for the quarter and $63,660 for the 9 months, extraordinary credits of $2,354 for the quarter and $306,641 for the 9 months and income $108,000 for the quarter and 9 months from a refund from an insurance policy.

title: TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE ON OPEC'S MEETING
description: Following is the text of a communique issued today in English by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries after the meeting at which its oil ministers agreed on a formula to reduce production:

CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid on Aug. 31, 1984.

title: DOCTORS' EMOTIONS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:The article by Perri Klass (Oct. 4) sounds a familiar, if discordant, chord to me. I write from the bias of a hospice physician where care and comfort for patients is the objective and cure is no longer the goal.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL PARES NET LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, helped by nonoperating factors, narrowed its third-quarter deficit to $17.4 million, from $42.9 million a year before, the company said yesterday.

title: DISPUTE HEADS CURRICULUM IN CHICAGO
description: It is not reading and writing but lawsuits and labor negotiations that occupy center stage in the Chicago public school system these days.

title: Roger E. Ortmayer Is Dead; A Leader of Church Council
description: The Rev. Roger E. Ortmayer, former executive director of the Department of Church and Culture of the National Council of Churches, died Oct. 22 of a heart attack at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 69 years old.

title: PENN VIRGINIA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes securities gains resulting from the distribution, as dividends, of a small portion of Penn Virginia's investment in Norfolk Southern Corp. of $1,100,000 for the quarter and $3,400,000 for the 9 months.

title: CALENDAR: CHRYSANTHEMUMS AND DOLLS
description: Kiku-Ka Ten: An Exhibition of Japanese Chrysanthemums, New York

title: JEFFERSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment gains of $28,857 for the quarter and $60,534 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $82,897 for the quarter and $168,224 for the 9 months. The per share results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct. 8, 1984.

title: HEALTH CARE & RETIREMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EUROPE'S PLACE IN NATO
description: A year ago some of the West European members of NATO, rattled by the problem of winning public opinion to the deployment in Europe of new American nuclear missiles, began talking about a way to put a more visible European stamp on Western security policy. The discussion fell under the catchword ''Europeanization,'' and it largely involved a plan to revivify the Western Europe Union, a little-used intergovernmental defense policy agency.

title: GENENTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CUTTING BACK THE GROWTH OF SUMMER
description: THE rush is on to complete garden chores by the end of the growing season. One task, often overlooked, is pruning. Many trees and shrubs can be trimmed safely now with little risk of damage. But there are some plants that should not be touched until late spring lest their blooms be cut off.

title: Magazine Entrepreneur Starts CFO Magazine
description: Neil R. Goldhirsh, brother of Bernard Goldhirsh - who created Inc. the successful magazine for managers of medium-size companies, is coming out with a magazine of his own. To be called CFO (for chief financial officer), it will be sent free to 200,000 such people in companies in the same revenue range as the Inc. clientele.

title: GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include sales and income of Lese Aluminum Co., acquired April 1, 1984 and a change in the tax provision due to benefits of investment tax credits from new products in 1984.

GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Warns Citizens Not to Travel to India
description: The State Department urged Americans today to postpone travel to India until the political situation there becomes more settled after the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF ITIALIAN JUDGE'S REPORT ON SHOOTING OF THE POPE
description: Following are key sections of Judge Ilario Martella's report, filed today, on the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, as translated by The New York Times from the Italian:

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: GENERAL HOME reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: E.E.C.-Japan Trade Talks
description: The European Economic Community and Japan today ended three days of ''extremely positive'' talks resolving to redress their trade imbalance. Although the imbalance is slowly changing in favor of the Common Market community, a European spokesman said ''problems still exist'' and Common Market officials pressed for easing Japanese import restrictions.

Welcoming
description: What should a Democratic candidate do when President Reagan invades his area to make the Presidential coattails available to Republicans? A leading strategist, Representative Tony Coelho of California, advises Democrats in such positions not to duck. The better tactic is to welcome the enemy but first to place pointed local issues in the grassroots like punji sticks, to tear the coattails.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Tuesday about a parody of The New York Post incorrectly described the role of its publishers - Telepictures Publications Inc. and Robert Vare - in an earlier newspaper parody, Off The Wall Street Journal. Mr. Vare was an editor of the first issue of Off The Wall Street Journal, in 1982. Telepictures had no connection with it.

ALL THE RIGHT MOVES FOR CLIPPERS?
description: The two gymnasiums on the sprawling, sun-splashed campus of Loyola Marymount University here are separated by only a few yards. The building to the north is a small, windowless place with no bleachers. It is used primarily by the weeknight hackers who wander in from time to time, or the bulky-chested weight lifters who want to work up a sweat after pumping iron in the tiny room just off the court.

title: OPERA:'MEDEE' PAIRED WITH 'MEDEA' IN LYONS
description: The venturesome Opera de Lyon has a particularly exciting two-day double bill playing just now. From Oct. 22-23 until Nov. 8-9, there are six double performances, the first night being a fully- staged version of Marc-Antoine Charpentier's lyric tragedy of 1693, ''Medee.'' The second night of each pair consists of the first performances of a new opera called ''Medea'' by Robert Wilson, the American avant-garde playwright, stage director and designer, and Gavin Bryars, the experimental British composer.

title: The Sikhs
description: Origins Sikhism was founded in Punjab in the late 15th century by a guru, or religious teacher, named Nanak. The name Sikh is derived from the Hindi word meaning disciple, and Sikhs regard themselves as disciples of 10 gurus. The first, Guru Nanak, taught a monotheistic creed that blended elements of Islam and Hinduism. He was opposed to the hierarchical Hindu caste system, the Brahmin priestly monopoly over religious matters, idolatory and much ritual.

title: PRIVATE HEXUM SERVICE
description: A funeral service for Jon-Erik Hexum, who accidentally shot himself in the head on the set of his new television series, will be private, a spokesman for the Westwood Village Mortuary said today. The 26-year-old actor shot himself in the temple with a prop gun loaded with blanks Oct. 12 in a break in the taping of his CBS series ''Cover Up'' at 20th Century Fox studios. He lapsed into a coma immediately and was pronounced dead six days later.

description: The Rockwell International Corporation received a $1.9 billion Air Force contract for continued advanced buying of parts for B-1B bomber air frames, the Defense Department said.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS FOR RAW GOODS OFF 0.7%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products as they enter the marketing pipeline declined seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, but still averaged 3 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: DR. RALPH MANNING CROWLEY, PSYCHOANALYST, IS DEAD AT 78
description: Dr. Ralph Manning Crowley, a psychiatrist who was a former president of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis, died Tuesday at St. Luke's- Roosevelt Hospital Center after suffering a heart attack a week ago. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mrs. Reagan's Southern Trip Will End Her Solo Campaign
description: Nancy Reagan will wind up a solo political campaign trip with visits to Kentucky, Georgia, Louisiana and Mississippi on Friday and Saturday.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New York Bond Sales Benefit From Insurance

title: POLICE AND VICTIM'S DAUGHTER CLASH ON SHOOTING

Keefe Cato, a right-hander who saw limited action with the Cincinnati Reds, was traded to the San Diego Padres for another minor league pitcher, Darren Burroughs .

title: Noah Objects

title: STORING VCR CASSETTES
description: WHAT does a video cassette have in common with an 18th-century edition of Boswell's ''Life of Johnson''? They look similar on a bookshelf when the cassette is stored in a new dustproof case from Leathersmith of London. Designed to look like old leather books, the Classic Video Library was introduced in Europe last year and has recently become available in this country. The case, made of imitation leather, comes in black, brown, red or green with gold filigree. Individual cases sell for $4.95, a set of five for $24.75. For an extra $1.75 a case the company will stamp the title of the cassette in gold on the spine. The Classic Video Library can be found at T. Anthony, Bloomingdale's, B. Altman and Lord & Taylor.

title: GETTY TRUST SETS UP GRANT FOR THE ARTS
description: The J. Paul Getty Trust, whose $2 billion endowment is paying for the establishment of an arts complex in Los Angeles and for several visual arts scholarship and education projects, has established a program that could provide up to $15 million a year in grants to arts institutions around the world, according to trust officials.

title: Trying Out Again
description: Jeffrey Crompton, a hugely oversized center from the University of North Carolina, has played professional basketball in several leagues since 1978. He was with Denver, Portland, Milwaukee, San Antonio and Cleveland of the National Basketball Association.

title: PILOT DECLINES TO TESTIFY ON FLIGHT 007
description: A Korean Air Lines pilot who had been expected to cast some light on a fellow pilot's off- course flight into Soviet airspace more than a year ago has resigned from the company and will therefore not give a deposition, an airline lawyer said today.

title: SOVIET PRESS HINTS AT A BIGGER PLOT
description: The Soviet Union sent messages of condolence to Indian leaders today over the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, while Soviet press accounts suggested her assassination was part of a broader conspiracy, with possible support from abroad.

title: Vetoed Hope for the Young With one stroke of his powerful pen, President Reagan has given life to a meaningless bill to please the elderly and with another he has killed a genuinely constructive program to help young people.
description: The gesture to old folks guaranteed a 3 percent cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits next year if the Consumer Price Index didn't trigger it automatically. In fact, the C.P.I. rose 3.5 percent, requiring a benefit increase of that amount.

title: NOLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HERS
description: ''YOU want to help sick people?'' asks my friend rhetorically. ''You want to care for people in pain? Become a nurse.'' We are both medical students. We are both in the middle of a clinical clerkship on the medical wards of the hospital. What she means is, the nurses spend time with the patients. They get to know them, they meet their families, they tend to their immediate and sometimes desperate needs. They offer comfort, encouragement, explanations. The doctors, with the medical students in tow, show up briefly on morning rounds, returning only if the patient is seriously ill, or in need of some procedure or other. When patients leave the hospital, it is the nurses to whom they send thank-you notes, or chocolates, or flowers.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: ALL kinds of objects that can be classified and have lost their usefulness become, in our time, ''collectibles.'' Acquired uselessness seems to be their single necessary attribute. Victims of obsolescence fill the 20th-century equivalents of the 19th-century curio cabinets without which our grandparents' parlors were not completely furnished. Now plastics have become collectibles, and if you care to know why and how, a current book, ''Plastics: Common Objects, Classic Designs'' by Sylvia Katz (Harry N. Abrams, $25), will tell you everything a neophyte needs to know and more.

title: BOOM IN LUXURY CAR IMPORTS
description: For almost two decades, European car makers have nibbled away at the highly profitable American luxury car market with hardly any response from the Big Three.

title: U.S. Sues Arkansas On Aid to Voters at Polls
description: The Justice Department has filed a civil suit to require Arkansas to comply with a new provision of the Voting Rights Act allowing voters who need assistance to choose their own helpers.

SANHAI JUKU AT CITY CENTER
description: A midget laughs mysteriously. A peacock wanders about the stage. Fish-men slither, stalk, parade and throw themselves on the ground, then stand stock still. Heads are shaved and nearly nude bodies are coated with flour. Raw rice is gobbled from the floor. The scene is unlikely, but New York audiences haven't been at all fazed by the peculiarities of Sankai Juku, the Japanese experimentalist theater-dance company that's playing at City Center through Sunday.

title: BABY FAE CONTINUES TO THRIVE AFTER 6 DAYS WITH BABOON'S HEART
description: Baby Fae continued to thrive today, six days after she received a baboon heart. Doctors representing the Loma Linda University Medical Center said that if her body rejected the heart and she needed a second heart transplant they would first seek a human heart before choosing another baboon.

description: IT doesn't matter whether you're thrilled to

title: STAGE:ANTHONY HEALD IN 'FOREIGNER'
description: ANTHONY HEALD is American, but, in a few seasons, he has become one of the New York theater's funniest and most stylish English character actors. The secret of Mr. Heald's success is not simply his ability to mimic accents. His comic portraits are meticulously detailed in every way - so much so that they leave an impression far larger than the size of his roles might indicate. Theatergoers may not remember Mr. Heald's name or face, but they don't quickly forget his performances as Gunner in the Roundabout's 1981 ''Misalliance,'' as the accident-prone schoolteacher in ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' or as the Welsh pedant, Fluellen, in last summer's Central Park ''Henry V.''

title: POP/JAZZ
description: MICHELE BROURMAN, a singer and composer whose inspired musical arrangements and choice of material have brightened two major cabaret debuts in New York recently, exemplifies a versatile new breed of pop musician. Moving in the worlds of Broadway, rock- and-roll and cabaret, Miss Brourman, who has accompanied performers as dissimilar as Bob Dylan and Bernadette Peters, has been helping a number of Los Angeles-based singer-actors expand their horizons. And tonight and tomorrow, at Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street, Miss Brourman, who accompanied Dixie Carter in her two-week engagement there, is having her own showcase.

title: O'NEILL TO OFFER 225 BOTTLED WATER
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today announced that the state would begin supplying bottled water Nov. 15 to 225 homes, most of them in north-central Connecticut, where wells have been contaminated by pesticides.

title: KOCH IS SEEKING WAY TO OVERSEE ELECTION BOARD
description: Mayor Koch, citing ''gross incompetence'' at the New York City Board of Elections, proposed yesterday that the board be restructured to give him more control over it.

title: A HEAD OF VIDEOTEX AT KNIGHT-RIDER
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers, which earlier this week announced a staff cut at its Viewtron videotex service, said yesterday that it had named Reid Ashe to the new positions of chairman and chief executive of the subsidiary that runs the videotex service.

title: No Headline
description: A lot has been going wrong lately for RKO General, the big broadcasting, bottling and film production subsidiary of Gencorp Inc. Even WOR- TV, the company's New York television station, did not come through with the revenue surge executives had considered certain from broadcasting the New York Mets' baseball games last summer.

title: Charter Loses $14.4 Million
description: The troubled Charter Company yesterday reported a loss of $14.4 million for the third quarter, in contrast to net income of $33 million, or $1.39, in the similar period of 1983.

title: IN DAYTON, THE ECONOMY SEEMS TO BE MAJOR ISSUE
description: Bruce Neller, a 29-year-old salesman in an automobile parts store, says he will vote for President Reagan next week, and he is blunt about his reasons.

title: Keeping Ill Workers in Ignorance
description: Thou shalt not kill - but needst not strive Officiously to keep alive.

title: Raymark-Echlin
description: The Raymark Corporation said it had a tentative agreement to sell its brake systems business to Echlin Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Joan Collins Stars In 'America's Vixen'
description: ''Everyone at every supermarket counter sees you right next to the sugarless gum, and you know how many people chew gum!'' a fawning executive gushes to Cartier Rand, the temperamental star of the hit television series ''Storm Watch.'' Any similarities between the Cartier Rand, who is nicknamed ''America's Vixen,'' and Joan Collins, who plays the role with her typical lip-smacking sense of mischief, are definitely intentional.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: The Navy awarded the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a unit of the Lockheed

title: AUCTIONS
description: FOR months, the photography world has been pondering the effects on collectors, dealers and institutions of several major developments. Among these are the J. Paul Getty Museum's entry into the field, the deaths of Ansel Adams and Brassai, the publication of Patricia Bosworth's biography of Diane Arbus and the exhibition of Irving Penn's works at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Ogilvy Buys Interest In a Dublin Agency
description: Ogilvy & Mather International celebrated the first day of the Celtic new year yesterday by announcing it will be acquiring a controlling interest in Dublin's Wilson Hartnell Group, which already shares two of Ogilvy's good clients, General Foods and American Express.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
A Touch of France
description: Paris came to City College for a

title: BEHIND JEWS' POLITICAL PRINCIPLES
description: In America, as elsewhere, the comfortable and the rich usually vote their pocketbooks. A notable exception to this rule has been the Jews who, despite their striking economic and social rise in the last generation, have continued to vote with ''have-nots.'' I believe that this year will be no exception, despite the blandishments of Jews on the right.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERSTATE BANK PLANS APPROVED
description: In what could be an important step toward interstate banking, the Comptroller of the Currency gave 13 bank holding companies permission today to operate 29 limited-service banking offices beyond their home states.

title: TERA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DR. RICHARD B. POMEROY
description: Dr. Richard Bruce Pomeroy, director of dental services at the Judson Health Center in Manhattan from 1948 to 1966, died at the White Plains Medical Center on Oct. 24.

title: Hughes in Korean Deal
description: Hughes Helicopters Inc. has reached an agreement with Korean Air to import Korean-made parts for Hughes-designed helicopters beginning in 1985.

title: Addenda
description: * The Wall Street Journal is increasing its advertising rates 9.5 percent, starting Jan. 2.

title: Ailing Bank's Auditor Out
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and the Continental Illinois Corporation, the bank's holding company, said today that they would replace their accounting firm, Ernst & Whinney. The troubled Chicago- based bank, which received a $4.5 billion Federal rescue package, said that effective Jan. 1, Price Waterhouse would become its principal outside auditor.

title: 'CAFE CON LECHE': A BIT OF HOME BREW
description: Gloria Gonzalez was born in New York to a Cuban mother and a Spanish father and grew up mostly among Puerto Ricans in East Harlem and the Bronx. She has been writing ever since she could remember, with a dozen years of professional credits as the author of English-language theatrical and television plays and novels. Yet ''Cafe con Leche'' is the first play she has ever done that is really close to home, and it is currently sending Spanish-speaking audiences into fits of laughter at the intimate Gramercy Arts Theater at 138 East 27th Street.

title: ALGERIA 'QUAKE-PROOFS' AN OFTEN-RUINED TOWN
description: -CHELIFF, Algeria - Nobody knows for sure how many times this north Algerian town has been knocked down by earthquakes. But if those who have just rebuilt it again are right, it will not be knocked down any more.

description: A 29-year-old transient was held in $100,000 bond today on arson charges stemming from a blaze that caused $1 million in damages to the Boardwalk on Oct. 15.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Home Products Corp. has promoted Richard Bogash to chairman of its Wyeth Laboratories division, and Dr. Bernard Canavan to president of the division. In addition, Mr. Bogash will assume the post of vice president, development, at American Home Products.

title: SANDINISTAS EXCHANGE PRISONERS WITH REBEL GROUP FOR FIRST TIME
description: For the first time since the civil war began three years ago, the Government this week exchanged prisoners with a rebel group.

title: ATV SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 6 months include $6,874,000 in service revenue realized in the first quarter from the service business sold to First Data Resources on July 3.

title: U.S. DECLINES TO TAKE MIDEAST MEDIATOR ROLE
description: The special United States envoy to the Middle East met with Israeli leaders today to discuss a request that Washington mediate between Israel and Syria while Israel and Lebanon negotiate directly.

title: MAN TERMED AN UNDERBOSS OF CRIME 'FAMILY' IS SEIZED
description: A man identified by law enforcement officials as the underboss of the Gambino crime ''family'' was charged with tax evasion in a Federal indictment unsealed yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Report, Report, Report, Report
description: New York City's economy may or

title: Cyanide Pills Voted Down
description: Students at the University of Colorado voted Thursday against having the university look into the possibility of stockpiling cyanide capsules for use in the event of a nuclear war. About 20 percent of the 20,000 students took part, said John Guldaman, chief assistant election commissioner for the university's student government, with 2,332 opposing the idea and 1,689 favoring it.

title: Alfred M. Hunt Dies; Retired Alcoa Officer
description: Alfred M. Hunt, who retired May 1 as secretary and vice president of the Aluminum Company of America, died Wednesday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: ART: EVOKING THE WORLD OF SOME GREAT PAINTERS
description: ROBERT SIVARD has a specialty all his own. He takes a great painter from the past (or at any rate a famous one), and he paints that painter's environment. He puts in the work (and plenty of it, most deftly counterfeited), but he also suggests the mode of life, some of the known friendships and the postal address. Then he rounds it all off with a portrait of the painter. All this is done on a very small scale. Sometimes it derives from a famous photograph, but Sivard rarely fails to bring something personal to his mimicries.

REAGAN, ON A FINAL SWING, URGES HIS BACKERS TO VOTE
description: President Reagan today began the final push of his re-election campaign by seeking support for Republican Congressional candidates, warning against complacency, jousting with hecklers and telling noisy crowds that America would ''never go back'' to its days of decline.

description: b-Includes a gain of $31,100,000 on the reversal of reserves established for the disposition of aircraft.

description: The Soviet press today intensified insinuations that the United States was somehow linked to the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: U.S. Navy to Hold Exercises With 5 Nations in Caribbean
description: The United States Navy will hold exercises with the coast guards of five eastern Caribbean nations next Tuesday, the United States Embassy in Barbados said today.

title: EXPECT A FARCE
description: On Sunday, while the United States public endures the final phase of the 1984 political campaign, Nicaraguans will go to the polls for the election they were promised five years ago after their revolution against Anastasio Somoza Debayle. Regrettably, the election will be a farce.

title: A.T.&T. Improves Phone Connecting
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, seeking to enhance its position in the highly competitive business telephone equipment market, announced enhancements to its flagship product in that market, the System 85 private branch exchange. Private branch exchanges, or P.B.X.'s, connect all the telephones within an office building or company.

title: 'WAKE UP' TO TERROR, SHULTZ SAYS ON WAY TO INDIA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, speaking shortly before he flew to India to attend the funeral of Indira Gandhi, said yesterday that her assassination was further evidence that ''we in the United States have to wake up'' to the threat of international terrorism.

title: TODAY Boxing
description: Mark Medal, champion, vs. Carlos Santos, International Boxing Federation's junior-middleweight title bout, 15 rounds, at the Felt Forum; first preliminary, 8 P.M. Medal, in his first defense of the crown, will be on familiar ground.

title: TAX-REDUCTION PLANS UP FOR VOTE IN 4 STATES
description: The taxpayer revolt is still alive, at least in California, Michigan, Oregon and Nevada, where voters have a chance next Tuesday to approve anti- tax measures reminiscent of California's Proposition 13 in 1978 and Massachusetts' Proposition 2 1/2 two years later.

title: FULL HOUSE IN BAHAMAS: TOURISTS AND A TEMPEST
description: Ismael Nun, general manager of the new Cable Beach Casino, is sitting behind his desk. Croupiers at the gaming tables wear tuxedos, but Mr. Nun is dressed less formally, in green sunglasses, black jeans and a black shirt, wide open at the chest.

description: The trial of 19 people accused in the slaying last year of former Prime Minister Maurice Bishop resumed briefly today with one of the defendants vowing to continue a hunger strike until she is assigned a lawyer.

title: EX-ENVOYS OFF TO FUNERAL
description: The United States delegation to the funeral of Indira Gandhi will be led by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and include Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, and three former ambassadors to India, the White House announced today.

description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include a gain of $564,000 from a change in tax law. Share earnings have been adjusted for 3 percent stock dividends in December 1983 and May 1984.

title: AFTER THEATER AND TV, ANNIE ROSS SINGS AGAIN
description: FOR most American jazz fans, Annie Ross disappeared more than 20 years ago when she left the popular jazz singing trio Lambert, Hendricks and Ross. In four years with the innovative group, she became a model for a new breed of jazz singers who could sing rapid- fire, tongue-tangling words set to instrumental solos and, in ensembles, vocalize the parts of high trumpets with precision and clarity.

Hey, Big Spender
description: Conventional wisdom in the capital, rarely in short supply, holds that the Federal Government is a big hirer but not a big spender hereabouts. No longer true, according to the Greater Washington Research Center, which says Federal contracts awarded in the Washington metropolitan area in the fiscal year 1983 reached $6.7 billion, approaching the Federal payroll for the same area of $11.8 billion in calendar year 1982.

title: Coast Thrift Unit Mortgage Bonds
description: The Far West Savings and Loan Association, a thrift institution in Newport Beach, Calif., with assets of $1.6 billion, yesterday became the first thrift unit to issue collateralized mortgage obligations, a kind of mortgage-backed security.

description: b-Includes a gain of $466,000 from LIFO inventory liquidations.

description: The Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday cut the price it pays for West Texas-New Mexico Intermediate crude oil by $1 a barrel.

title: STEPHEN E. HRITZ
description: Stephen E. Hritz, a copy editor on the metropolitan desk of The New York Times since 1971, died yesterday at Middlesex General-University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J., following a stroke. Mr. Hritz, who had been ill since last May, was 62 years old and lived in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: Auto Strikes In Britain
description: Thousands of automobile workers went on strike today, halting production of luxury Jaguar cars and Austin Rover models.

title: Persistent Problem
description: Stanley Wilson , the Cincinnati Bengal running back who had already missed part of the season while undergoing treatment for a drug problem, was suspended yesterday after a urinalysis taken last week disclosed that he had been using drugs again, the club announced. Pete Rozelle , the National Football League commissioner, ordered Wilson to undergo chemical evaluation and submit to any recommended treatment before applying for reinstatement.

title: Marcel Moyse, Flutist,A Founder of Marlboro
description: The flutist Marcel Moyse, a founder of the Marlboro School of Music and an influential teacher, died Thursday at his home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 95. Mr. Moyse often said he was inspired by opera singers to try to give the flute the resources of the human voice.

title: GRAND PLANS FOR 'TEMPLE' ON WALL STREET
description: To its admirers, the Federal Hall National Memorial is the Parthenon of New York. But somebody got the topography wrong.

description: Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, has assets of between $1 million and $1.7 million, according to financial disclosures filed with the secretary of the Senate.

title: Singing the Blues
description: The Chicago blues singer Koko Taylor will perform tomorrow at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. at Tramps (777-5077), 125 East 15th Street. There is an $8 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1984 International Army troops entered 9 Indian cities including New Delhi to quell a nationwide wave of lynchings and arson that began soon after the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. Soldiers were ordered to shoot rioters on sight in the capital and five other cities. Unofficial tallies indicated more than 150 people have been killed and 1,000 injured since Wednesday. (Page A1, Columns 3-6.) India's new Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, the slain's leader's son, and 15 oppositon party leaders issued a joint appeal for an end to the anti-Sikh violence. (A16:1-2.)

title: CHESS:DRAWS PUZZLING
description: It is indeed difficult to know what Anatoly Karpov, the 33-year-old world chess champion, and his challenger, 21-year-old Gary Kasparov, have in mind in their title match in Moscow. Are they interested in setting records for consecutive draws or in finishing the contest?

title: CRACKDOWN ON QUESTIONABLE QUALITY OF THE GOODS
description: More than 25 years ago the Defense Department adopted a policy of withholding payments to companies that produced faulty arms or equipment. But only recently has that policy been put into effect. Asked why, a Pentagon spokesman said, ''I don't know.''

FILM:MAKING 'VOLCANO'
description: WHEN documentaries record the making of important feature films, they rarely capture anything to rival the features themselves. Les Blank's ''Burden of Dreams,'' about the making of Werner Herzog's ''Fitzcarraldo,'' is a fascinating exception, since it shows a side of Mr. Herzog that his own work reveals less directly, and since Mr. Herzog's behind-the-scenes exertions were at least on a par with those of his film's fanatical hero.

title: Holmgren Suspended
description: Paul Holmgren , the frequently penalized wing of the Minnesota North Stars, was given a 10-game suspension by the National Hockey League yesterday for spearing Torrie Robertson of the Hartford Whalers in the face. The blow, in a game last Saturday, caused a gash that required six stitches to close. In ordering the suspension, Brian O'Neill , the league's executive vice president, said videotape made clear that the attack ''was vicious and could not be categorized as a reflex action.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; City Bond Sale's Size To Rise to $400 Million
description: New York City officials confirmed yesterday plans to increase the size of the next bond offering to $400 million from $250 million at the last sale. After meeting with representatives of major securities firms, city officials were not sure if the offering would be moved up to next week or held during the week of Nov. 12.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday, with a report in New York Day by Day about a New York University fund drive, misidentified the person at the left. He was Larry A. Silverstein, an organizer of the drive.

ABOARD QE2, DARKNESS, COLD CUTS AND NO WATER
description: Passengers aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 told yesterday of spending some stress-filled hours at sea as a power failure idled the ship in the Atlantic Ocean, darkened cabins and shut off water supplies.

title: Lucas and Sun Agree
description: Maurice Lucas , a free-agent forward, has reached a contract agreement with the Phoenix Suns, according to General Manager Jerry Colangelo , who said last night that Lucas and his agent, Bill Pollak , would arrive in Phoenix tomorrow from New Jersey ''to conclude contract negotiations.''

title: EDUARDDO DE FILIPPO, AUTHOR OF PLAYS ON NEAPOLITAN LIFE
description: Eduardo De Filippo, one of Italy's foremost playwrights, died on Thursday in Rome. He was 84 years old. The Naples-born author of more than 50 plays, which were performed all over Europe and in the United States, was famous for his boisterous, bittersweet comedies of Italian family life and especially of Neapolitan society during and after World War II.

title: BRIDGE:U.S. SQUADS HOLD 2D PLACE IN WORLD TEAM OLYMPIAD
description: Both United States teams were well-placed in the World Team Olympiad here today.

title: A VIRTUOSO COLLECTION OF NEW YORK RECITALS
description: EVERY so often there is a heated argument about the location of the music capital of the world. Some British critics claim London as the venue. New York critics laugh at that claim. It is true that London has more symphony orchestras than New York. But London, the New Yorkers point out, has nowhere near the amount of music that, day in and day out, East Side, West Side and all around the town, New York presents.

title: RATES FALL
description: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the nation's money supply declined an unexpectedly large $2.5 billion in the week ended Oct. 25, reinforcing market expectations that the central bank would ease monetary policy and that interest rates would fall further.

title: RJ FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: A rare life-sized stone statue from the eighth century is included in a major display on the humanist image of Buddha, on view through February at the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway, in the Crown Heights sections.

Inquiry on Lee Party
description: Calling a state investigation into a party in his honor last Saturday night in Newark ''petty and childish, the work of small minds,'' Robert Lee , acting chairman of the New Jersey State Athletic Commission, denied yesterday that any of the proceeds from the $15-a-plate affair had gone to him. But the State Attorney General's office and the Commission on Ethical Standards are both looking into the possibility that money was being raised to defend Lee against pending civil charges that he solicited funds from boxing industry officials for the International Boxing Federation, a sanctioning body he also heads.

title: LEADERS OF OPPOSITION BACK APPEAL FOR END TO VIOLENCE
description: Opposition leaders joined tonight with Rajiv Gandhi, India's new Prime Minister, in an appeal for an end to the anti-Sikh violence that has spread through the country since Mr. Gandhi's mother was shot to death by assassins.

title: Court Ruling May Stay Coast Death Sentences
description: In a decision that may mean new trials for 21 prisoners condemned to die, the California Supreme Court ruled today that jurors should not be told that a murderer sentenced to life without parole could be made eligible for parole by the Governor.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Wary beginners can learn to ski close to home this weekend, in the Park Avenue Armory at 67th Street. Lessons will be offered on a synthetic snow slope during the New York Ski and Travel Show, which is open 4 to 11 P.M. today, 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. tomorrow and 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Sunday. There will also be lessons in cross-country skiing on an indoor track, and a play will be performed on skis. Phil Mahre, Bill Johnson and Jean-Claude Killy, all Olympic gold medalists, will answer questions, and so will representatives of ski resorts and equipment. Admission: $5. Information: 242-6582. title: Public Image at Beacon
description: Public Image Ltd., the funk and rock band led by John Lydon, will perform tonight at 8 P.M. at the Beacon Theater (874-1717), Broadway at 74th Street. Tickets are $13.50 and $14.50.

title: 2 Brooklyn Men Seized in Burglary
description: Two Brooklyn men have been arrested and charged with the burglary of a food warehouse in Brooklyn on Sept. 26, the police said yesterday.

description: The nation's money market mutual funds again reported record asset growth for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

The reformulated products, Diet Pepsi, Diet Pepsi Free and Pepsi Light, will be available in some markets this month and be available nationwide by Jan. 1.

description: Reversing course once again, stock prices rallied yesterday, aided by a drop in interest rates in the bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.71 points, to 1,217.09, all but erasing Wednesday's 9.93-point decline.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING RISES 1.1%
description: Spending on new construction in September rose 1.1 percent from August, the best increase in four months, the Commerce Department said today. The rise was propelled by gains in office buildings, apartments and shopping centers.

description: A dusk-to-dawn curfew was in effect tonight after racial violence on Halloween left nine people injured, one of whom was critically beaten, officials said.

description: A majority of homeless men and women in New York State cannot find or afford housing and their primary reason for homelessness is poverty, according to a report released yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: Incumbent Senators Lead Foes in Funds
description: The 29 senators seeking re-election have raised two and a half times as much money as their opponents and have spent nearly $2 million each by mid-October, and most still have bulging war chests, an analysis of campaign spending reports showed today.

Works by Alban Berg

title: SHARING THE WEIGHT
description: With metal braces on both of his knees and a harness on his left shoulder, Dave Langevin says, he weighs ''around 250 pounds'' when he skates for the Islanders. But the supports are not the heaviest weight Dave Langevin has been carrying.

title: State Gets Back Into the Ring
description: John Branca, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, which regulates boxing in this state, has been telling anyone who will listen that the Empire State, unlike the World Boxing Council, still recognizes Marvelous Marvin Hagler as world middleweight champion. Branca also says New York recognizes Larry Holmes as heavyweight champion and Michael Spinks as the light-heavyweight titleholder.

title: IN NEW DELHI, MOURNERS AND MARIGOLDS
description: Thousands of mourners filed by the body of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today today at what was once her father's house, a quarter of a mile from the bungalow complex where she was assassinated on Wednesday.

description: As he worked to coordinate the staging for the television cameras in advance of President Reagan's rally here today, Gary Foster, an agent for the Reagan re-election campaign, took a moment to reflect on the opposition and on the changed appearance of Walter F. Mondale's campaign.

title: Prognosis Better
description: John Stearns has declared for free agency, and two days ago, the Mets released Ron Hodges. With those catchers gone, the chances for Clint Hurdle to play at Shea Stadium next season with a mask, chest protector and shin guards seem to have greatly improved.

description: Recent talks between the United States and Nicaragua have failed to narrow major differences between them, according to officials of both countries.

title: TWO MOODS IN DETROIT: ONE DOWN, ONE UPBEAT
description: James Spivey used to spend his days guiding a heavy welding gun that stitched together the fresh steel bodies of Ford automobiles rolling down an assembly line. He earned more than $700 a week, owned two cars and lived in a house in the affluent suburb of Grosse Pointe Park.

description: Pass Rush Key for Jets

title: BATTLE LINES ARE DRAWN BY PENTAGON FOOTBALL FANS
description: Visitors to the Pentagon on Friday can expect to find the Army, the Navy and the Air Force on a combat footing. By Saturday, a major mobilization will be under way.

title: Newspaper Sold
description: Park Communications Inc. said it had acquired The Evening News of Jeffersonville, Ind., and its companion weekly, The Clark County Journal. The Evening News, a daily newspaper since 1872, has a circulation of more than 18,000.

title: Ailing John Henry May Miss Breeders'
description: John Henry yesterday was found to have suffered a strained ligament that will probably keep him out of next Saturday's Breeders' Cup Turf, a race for which his owner reluctantly paid a nonrefundable $133,000 entry fee last Tuesday.

title: Nuggets 129, Bulls 113
description: Calvin Natt scored 11 of his game-high 31 points in the first five minutes of the fourth quarter as Denver (2-1) snapped Chicago's two-game winning streak.

description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest periods include operations of the former Bendix Automation Group which became part of Cross & Trecker on April 19.

title: SISTER COLUMBA KAVANAGH, 54, OFFICIAL OF SACRED HEART ORDER
description: Sister Columba Kavanagh, former provincial director of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, died of cancer Monday at the Marymount Roman Catholic Convent in Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 54 years old.

title: Pills for Birth Control Are Recalled by Searle
description: The pharmaceutical manufacturer G. D. Searle is recalling more than a million birth control pills because low-strength counterfeit versions, which may not prevent pregnancy, have been distributed, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: The Daughter of Stalin Reported Back in Soviet
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, who defected 17 years ago, has returned to Moscow, the headmaster of her daughter's British school said today. The report could not be confirmed.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: -tie crowd at the French Consulate the other evening and said, ''I really don't go out often. I get too comfortable sitting at home and you cannot do that or you will begin to lose people. You must go out.'' The prospect that the dancer was in any danger of becoming a social recluse was certainly not evident at the dinner, where he was guest of honor along with Andre Lariquie, president of the Paris Opera at the event to organize the American Friends of the Paris Opera and Ballet.

title: ART:PECHSTEIN EXHIBITION
description: GERMAN expressionism is heavily with us. This year there have been New York gallery exhibitions devoted to Paula Modersohn-Becker and the Blue Four. A major exhibition, at the Guggenheim Museum, told the story of Kandinsky's Bauhaus years. There have been news articles involving large numbers of Paul Klees and Lyonel Feiningers. And it has been a year of traveling exhibitions on Max Beckmann, German Expressionist sculpture and the Buchheim collection. While the attention has been understandable - given the interest in recent German painting and in the current forms of Expressionism - as usual, the bandwagon effect has managed to transform a genuine interest into a glut.

title: IMPROVED M.I.S.L. SET FOR NEW SEASON
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League, bolstered by the addition of the Cosmos and three other teams from the North American Soccer League and the retention of its commissioner, will start the most ambitious campaign in its seven-year history tonight.

title: John Paul Is 'Weighed Down' By Recent Killings in World
description: Pope John Paul II said in an All Saints' Day sermon today that his heart is ''weighed down'' at the thought of recent bloodshed throughout the world.

title: STEWART BRAND: A NEW 'CATALOG' AND ALL'S WELL
description: The gale from the north forced sheets of cold rain against the houseboats moored at E Dock in Waldo Point Harbor, and set them swaying. A smile lit up Stewart Brand's wayworn face as he turned his attention to the water music on the decks of his tugboat, the Mirene. ''I like to be aware of the weather,'' he said.

description: ''This madness must stop.'' - Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and 15 opposition leaders. (A1:6.)

title: SURGE IN JOBS REPORTED IN ALL 5 CITY BOROUGHS
description: Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx have joined an economic recovery in New York City that until last year was limited largely to Manhattan, according to a Federal report released yesterday.

title: Philadelphia Operation Ends With 46 Arrests
description: Investigators recovered nearly $2.2 million in stolen property and charged 46 people, including three sailors, as a result of a covert operation designed to catch thieves at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, United States Attorney Edward Dennis Jr. said today.

title: CAPITOL AIR PRESIDENCY IS FILLED AFTER VACANCY
description: John H. Jackson has been named president of Capitol Air Inc., the financially troubled carrier, effective immediately.

title: BOTH PARTIES FOCUSING ON NORTH JERSEY
description: In the final days of the Presidential race in New Jersey, both the Republican and Democratic campaigns are focusing on the Democratic strongholds in the northern part of the state.

title: SOLIDARITY ACTIVISTS CALL WORK STOPPAGE IN MEMORY OF PRIEST
description: A group of Solidarity leaders in the northern port of Gdansk called today for a one-hour work stoppage next week in memory of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the outspoken pro-Solidarity priest who was abducted and slain, apparently by Government security men.

description: Mortgage rates fell in October, marking the third straight month of decline, with fixed-rate mortgages dropping to the lowest point since May, the Government said today.

description: A new generation of Democratic Party fund raisers is emerging this year, providing fresh sources of money and energy but leaving behind some slightly bruised egos and untapped resources.
