title: LaRouche Jury Gives $3 Million to NBC-TV
description: A Federal District Court jury today awarded NBC $3 million in damages against the campaign organization of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and rejected Mr. LaRouche's $150 million defamation suit against the television network.

title: WHEN CONDOMINIUM FINDS SALES RESISTANCE ON L.I.
description: The art of real estate marketing is being put through its paces at a luxury condominium project in this affluent Nassau County community east of Kennedy International Airport.

title: SYRIA BACKS ISRAEL-LEBANON TALKS BUT REFUSES TO OFFER GUARANTEES
description: Syria said today that it welcomed the announcement that talks would begin next week between Israel and Lebanon on an Israeli troop withdrawal. But it ruled out, for what it said was a final time, a longstanding Israeli request that Syria guarantee the security of Israel's northern border.

title: Driver Sentenced In Fatal Shooting
description: An investment broker convicted of killing a passenger in a car that damaged the Ferrari he was driving was sentenced yesterday to serve 15 years to life.

description: of 32 Illinois bankers today

title: Herbert E. Marks, 82, Dies; A PoLM
description: Herbert E. Marks, who was president of one of the leading publishers of Latin American music for 26 years, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: ARMY SEEKS EXPANSION OF CHEMICAL WARFARE UNIT
description: The Army is seeking funds to work with large quantities of lethal biological sprays as part of a planned $250 million expansion of chemical and biological warfare research at the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah.

title: 1984 Nobel Laureate's Books Hard to Find
description: Within hours after Jaroslav Seifert was named winner of the 1984 Nobel Prize for Literature, a number of bookstores around the country received telephone calls inquiring about books by the Czechoslovak poet. Almost none had any, since the only one listed in Books in Print, the standard reference source for booksellers, is ''The Casting of Bells,'' translated by Tom O'Grady and Paul Jagasich, and published by The Spirit That Moves Us Press in Iowa City, Iowa.

title: 3 African Nations to Get $45.1 Million in Food Aid
description: President Reagan approved $45.1 million in emergency food assistance to the drought-ravaged African nations of Kenya, Mozambique and Mali today, the White House announced.

title: E.P.A. ORDERED TESTS AT SITES OF SUSPECTED TOXIC SEEPAGE
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday directed the operator of a Niagara Falls disposal site to sink a series of new monitoring wells in an effort to determine whether three toxic waste dumps are leaking.

Coach Joe Paterno seems to have been cloned.

title: MORE FANCY LODGINGS FOR THE WEARY
description: Just when it seemed the boom in luxury hotels was easing off, Washington is engulfed in a new wave of construction of elegant hostelries oriented to the type of patron apt to arrive in a chauffeured Bentley or Rolls-Royce.

title: MOODY'S REVIEWS CAR MAKER RATING
description: Debt ratings for the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are being reviewed for possible upgrading, analysts at Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Yes to New York's Propositions New Yorkers will be asked Tuesday to vote on two amendments to the state Constitution. We urge yes votes on both.
description: Proposition One would permit the Legislature to change the length of terms for sheriffs and clerks in counties outside New York City from three years to four. That would permit voting for these offices to coincide with other local and state elections, and avoid off-year inattention.

title: Dartmouth Reporter Will Not Face Action
description: Dartmouth College has decided not to pursue disciplinary action against a student reporter who secretly tape-recorded a meeting of a homosexual students' group and published excerpts of it last spring.

title: CASEY'S LETTER ON NICARAGUA MANUAL
description: Following is a letter from William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, to members of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees. The letter, dated Oct. 25, was obtained today from a member of Congress.

title: PRINCESS ANNE CUTS TRIP SHORT
description: Princess Anne will cut short a tour of India because security officials there are concerned about her safety, Buckingham Palace announced today.

title: Lawsuit of Symphony Completed by Actress
description: Lawyers for the actress Vanessa Redgrave completed their case today in Federal District Court in the breach-of-contract and civil rights suit against the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

description: The Interpublic Group of Companies will be losing a vice chairman and Reno will be getting a new high roller on Dec. 31 when Peter H. Dailey, an agency founder and former Ambassador to Ireland, leaves behind all of his former business pursuits, including a board seat at Walt Disney Productions, to be chairman of Enniskerry Financial Ltd., a privately held Nevada investment banking firm of which he is a principal owner.

title: Killing Called Spontaneous
description: Ujagar Singh Bawa, general secretary of the Sikh Association of America, who teaches economics at Bloomsburg State College in Pennsylvania, said here today that the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India by two of her guards could have been a spontaneous ''act of personal revenge.'' He said that ''Sikhs have never perpetrated or condoned acts of terrorism or assassinations and this act of two individuals was completely unorchestrated and unrehearsed.''

title: Choices for New York Courts
description: Some day, New York's Legislature will reform judicial selection. For now, candidates reach the ballot by persuading party leaders to put them there and are elected by voters who know little about them. Our recommendations are based on candidate interviews and findings by the City Bar Association and Citizens Union.

title: MEXICO TRIMS OIL EXPORTS BY 6.6%
description: Mexico will reduce oil exports by 100,000 barrels a day during November, the country's top energy officials announced today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: 3 States Sued by U.S. On Absentee Time Limit
description: The Justice Department sued Alabama, Montana and Wisconsin on Wednesday, seeking more time for overseas voters to mail in absentee ballots.

title: Task Force Set Up In Synagogue Fire
description: A task force of 20 detectives and fire marshals was set up yesterday to investigate a fire early Wednesday that virtually destroyed a synagogue and Hebrew school in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

description: A New York-based Sikh group appealed to India's Government today to halt the violence being directed at Sikhs since the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Market Place ; Arco as Proxy For Oil Stocks
description: Money managers, individuals and securities analysts spend endless hours trying to fathom the potentials and pitfalls of energy stocks. But Joseph A. Feshbach, chief technical analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, has discovered a quick way for assessing investment opportunities in the oils.

title: ART:BRONZE SCULPTURES OF RENOIR AND GUINO
description: RENOIR dallied with sculpture early in his career, but the bronzes for which he is famous were not modeled until just before his death in 1919, at the age of 78. Nudes, mainly, they are as recognizably the master's work as his canvases - the models and poses are the same, the surfaces even evoke his brushwork as it was in the late years. At the same time, the figures - Aphrodites all, even when posing as washerwomen - are very like Maillol's, having similar proportions and the same heavy, tubular limbs.

description: The General Assembly approved a resolution today calling on Britain and Argentina to resume negotiations over the Falkland Islands.

title: Plain Dealer Pact Approved
description: Employees of The Plain Dealer, the city's only daily newspaper, approved a 37- month contract Wednesday four hours before a strike. Seven unions representing 1,500 people, including reporters, truck drivers and press operators, accepted a $105 raise over 37 months, covering wages and benefits. The employees had been working without a contract since Sept. 30.

title: WHAT AN AROUSED MAYOR CAN AND CANNOT DO
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TO PASS UP TV ROLE FOR NOW
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, granted permission by a Federal judge Wednesday to re-enter the football-telecast business - this time as a competitor - reaffirmed yesterday that it had no immediate desire to do so.

title: FILM:DOCUMENTARY ON SANDINISTAS
description: ''NICARAGUA: NO PASARAN'' is a love letter to a revolution. It looks on the Sandinistas and finds them good. It is possible this is so; it is possible their struggle is just. But it seems unlikely that they bear no responsibility at all for their relationship with Washington, or that the United States, as always, is the source of all Nicaraguan problems. The documentary, which opens today at Film Forum 2, is entitled to a point of view, but it abuses the privilege.

description: A mysterious disease has killed five whooping cranes out of the 39-bird breeding flock maintained at the Patuxent, Md., research center of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, the service said Wednesday.

title: U.S. Seeks New Rules On Disposing of EDB
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, which earlier this year, banned the agricultural use of ethylene dibromide, known as EDB, now wants to impose tighter restraints on the disposal of EDB wastes from the production of gasoline additives and other chemicals.

DEMOCRATS DELIVER A LARGE TURNOUT
description: The traditional garment center rally yesterday was almost as important for Governor Cuomo and the Mondale-Ferraro campaign in the state as next Tuesday's election. The New Yorkers could assure a big rally, but not necessarily an election victory.

title: A VIEW OF GUY BURGESS IN MOSCOW
description: TELEVISION has developed a virtual monopoly on the short story requiring no more than an hour. A superb example of it can be found tonight at 9 on Channel 13's Great Performances series. The dramatization of an amusing and perhaps unsettling anecdote, ''An Englishman Abroad,'' starring Alan Bates and Coral Browne, was directed for the BBC by John Schlesinger, whose film credits include ''Darling,'' ''Midnight Cowboy'' and ''Sunday, Bloody Sunday.''

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHERE publishers go, restaurateurs are sure to follow. Such is the case with Cafe du Parc, a handsome new establishment at 106 East 19th Street, which hopes to cash in on the literary profession's devotion to the midday repast. Many publishing houses have fled midtown rents in recent years and relocated in the Gramercy Park area, and a number of chefs have grabbed their pans and trotted right behind them. The next time you head down to this neighborhood to ink a quarter-million-dollar book contract, or just happen to find yourself strolling near the park at mealtime, Cafe du Parc is worth considering.

title: A Show of Magic
description: The history of magic, from ancient Egypt to the Broadway stage, is the subject of the exhibition ''Magic: Past and Present,'' in the main gallery of the New York Public Library's General Library and Museum for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $14,000. c-Net loss after income from discontinued operations of $38,000.

title: U.S. Seeks More Data On Rolm-I.B.M. Deal
description: The Justice Department yesterday requested more information about the proposed acquisition of the Rolm Corporation by the International Business Machines Corporation, a move that could delay the $1.25 billion acquisition.

title: WARD SHIFTS PROCEDURE IN DISARMING DERANGED
description: Three days after a police officer fatally shot a 66-year-old woman who was believed to be deranged, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday ordered a major revision in rules for disarming emotionally disturbed people.

title: Grumman Income Flat; General Dynamics Up
description: The Grumman Corporation reported flat earnings for the third quarter, while General Dynamics posted record profits.

title: THOUSANDS CROWD GARMENT DISTRICT TO CHEER MONDALE
description: With confetti drifting around him and tens of thousands of supporters jammed into the blocks below, Walter F. Mondale yesterday told an exuberant rally in New York City's garment district that he would be elected President on Tuesday.

title: AN ENVIRONMENT DIVIDED BY A BORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: DE KOONING WORK SOLD
description: Willem de Kooning's ''Two Women,'' a 1953 oil on paper laid down on canvas, last night became the most expensive post-World War II artwork ever auctioned, a fact that reportedly did not impress the artist when he was told.

title: Cardiff-Conwed
description: The Cardiff Equities Corporation said it intends to make a cash tender offer of $21.50 a share for all of the shares outstanding of the Conwed Corporation.

title: ROBERTSON, H.H. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STORES IN CITY, SUBURBS POST DECLINES
description: Sales by New York City's seven largest retailers slipped 1.5 percent in October from the same month a year ago, a spot check found yesterday. The decline, the first in two and a half years, followed three months of slow business.

title: Penobscot Indians
description: The Penobscot Indian nation and Shape Inc., a maker of video and audio cassettes, will become partners in a $2.5 million manufacturing concern on Indian Island here.

title: THE REGION ; SUSPECT IN SLAYINGS FACES NEW COUNTS
description: A suspect in the deaths of six Connecticut women was charged today with attempted murder, kidnapping and sexual assault by North Carolina authorities, the state police reported.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT'S a slice of Maine on lower Third Avenue.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,580,000 for the quarter and $1,700,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $670,000 for the quarter and $1,410,000 for the 9 months.

title: Accord Reached On Bus Traffic
description: This village and Liberty Lines reached an agreement today over the amount of bus traffic on Bronxville's main thoroughfare, Pondfield Road.

title: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes securities gains resulting from the distribution, as dividends, of a small portion of Penn Virginia's investment in Norfolk Southern Corp. of $1,100,000 for the quarter and $3,400,000 for the 9 months.

title: Kaiser Trims Unit
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell most of its fertilizer division, Kaiser Agricultural Chemicals, to a new company to be formed by the Sullivan & Proops investment firm of Chicago, and the divisional president, John Gutknecht, and vice president, Charlie Seaton. Terms were not disclosed. The sale will include about 100 fertilizer retail outlets, or Farmarkets, and associated facilities in the Middle West and Southeast.

title: Surplus Spurs Dispute
description: To anyone wondering how the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee was able to pile up a staggering $150 million profit after predicting a surplus of no more than $15 million, one answer has been provided by some former committee employees, municipal officials and private contractors. In an article by The Los Angeles Times, they are quoted as saying that the committee built the surplus by deceiving them about its true financial prospects and persuading them to accept smaller salaries and more stringent contracts than they otherwise would have.

title: ELECTRONIC MEMORIES & MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months reflect a pretax provision of $1.8 million consisting primarily of anticipated losses on several long- term contracts designated in British pounds which was made to recognize the decline in the sales value of the contracts due to the decrease in the value of the pound relative to the dollar.

title: Hearst's New Publisher For Science Digest
description: Gerald Godfrey Hotchkiss, Gerry to the smart set, is joining Hearst Magazines as publisher of Science Digest, a post being vacated by Thomas P. Losee Jr., who is moving to a similar seat at Architectural Digest.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAND-INS ASSISTING MONDALE EFFORT IN CONNECTICUT
description: The final days of the Presidential campaign in Connecticut are drawing appearances by the Vice Presidential candidates as well as stand-ins for the Democratic ticket.

title:
AS NICARAGUANS PREPARE TO VOTE;
SUCCESS UNDERCUT
description: A fatal combination of United States intransigence and conflicts within the Sandinista leadership have turned the Nicaraguan elections, scheduled for Sunday, into a travesty of what they might have been. This was a unique opportunity for a third world revolution to gain legitimacy in the eyes of the world. Instead, the Sandinistas have seen their electoral experiment crumble.

title: Accountant Is Acquitted
description: Warren Essner, formerly a senior partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company, has been acquitted by a New York State court jury of charges that he criminally gave false information about Drysdale Government Securities Inc. shortly before it filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: HUNTINGDON RESEARCH CENRE PLC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article Oct. 20 about the New Alliance Party and its Presidential candidate, Dennis Serrette, incorrectly described its headquarters. It is a large Manhattan apartment housing 13 offices.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a capital loss of $10,428. c-After capital gains of $43,145 for the quarter and $289,945 for the 9 months. d-After a capital gain of $354,844.

title: Outspoken Coach
description: If you're wondering why William Hudnut , the Mayor of Indianapolis, didn't ask Bobby Knight to go along when he flew to Mexico City to stump for Indianapolis as the site of the 1987 Pan American Games, Knight may have offered a clue at an Indianapolis news conference. ''I don't even think we should be in the Pan American Games,'' said Knight, Indiana University's basketball coach, who also guided this country's Olympians last summer.

title: COURT-MARTIAL DISCLOSURE HEATS UP A CAMPAIGN IN CALIFORNIA
description: The Republican candidate in a high-visibility State Assembly race here suffered a large embarrassment over the recent disclosure that he had been court-martialed in the Air Force in 1967 for drug abuse. But those who have come to his defense in his race against Tom Hayden include Gov. George Deukmejian.

title: GUARDS QUELL CUBAN INMATES
description: The authorities fired tear gas into cellblocks at the Federal penitentiary here tonight after about 500 Cuban prisoners set fires and created disturbances, demanding their freedom.

title: AN ARTIST OF THE FISH MARKET MAKES IT HER GALLERY AS WELL
description: Vinnie the Unloader, as he is known to co-workers at the Fulton Fish Market, walked into a gallery called Art in the Afternoon (fish in the morning), regarded a colorful array of paintings hung from fishing lines, and pronounced the one-woman show a success. ''I've bought $1,800 worth of her paintings,'' he said, pointing to the artist, Naima Rauam. ''I'm partial to the Brooklyn Bridge.''

title: C.I.A. CHIEF DEFENDS MANUAL FOR NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, has written a letter to members of Congress defending a C.I.A. manual for Nicaraguan rebels that advocates kidnapping and assassinating Nicaraguan Government officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1984
description: The Economy

title: RISE IN VOTER TURNOUT IS SEEN
description: A private nonpartisan research agency predicted today that about 55 percent of eligible voters would cast ballots in Tuesday's Presidential election, reversing a 20- year decline in voter turnout.

title: Continental Has Profit
description: The Pan Am Corporation, parent of Pan American World Airways, yesterday reported a 92.7 percent plunge in net income for the important third quarter.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''ELBOWING THE SEDUCER,'' one of the year's funniest and most talked- about first novels, is headed for the screen. T. Gertler's book about a young writer trying to find her way in New York's literary community and eventually having the last laugh on an editor and a critic who take advantage of her na"ivete, has been optioned by David Picker. A former president of United Artists and Paramount, now an independent producer, Mr. Picker has asked Miss Gertler to write the screenplay for a film to be directed by Nessa Hyams.

title: BOB GRANT IS GOING TO WABC-AM
description: Bob Grant, a controversial radio interviewer who has worked on New York radio since 1970 and currently has a popular program on WMCA- AM, will be switching to WABC-AM on Nov. 15, it was announced yesterday.

title: KennethO.WilsonDiesat87; Ex-Chief of Newark Academy
description: Kenneth O. Wilson, a former headmaster of the Newark Academy, died last Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 87 years old and had lived in Binghamton, N.Y.

description: The Libertarian Party's effort to get its Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates on the Connecticut ballot has been rejected by the State Supreme Court.

title: 4 Policemen in Chile Killed in Bombing
description: Four riot policemen were killed and 12 wounded today when a bomb destroyed their bus in the most serious of recent bombings directed at the Government of President Augusto Pinochet, police said.

title: BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

HINTS IF LONLINESS AND DASHED HOPES
description: If I ever defect back to Moscow - no one should be surprised,'' Svetlana Alliluyeva wrote to an acquaintance in New York last Sept. 4. ''What I had confronted in this so-called Free World, was enough to kill the ideology and enthusiasm of even a strong man. I am NO strong man, and I have no 'Nerves of Steel.' Maybe you have those.''

description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly yesterday, losing a small part of the gains made earlier in the week.

title: 'THE PROFESSOR' IS KEEPING LYMAN PLACE ALIVE
description: Hetty Fox would like to take this opportunity to remind residents of Lyman Place that they will be solely responsible for hot dogs, potato salad and such at the next block party. The block party will no longer be held jointly with residents of the next block because of the disappearance of that block. Thank you.

title: SANCTIONS SOUGHT AGAINST JAPANESE WHALERS
description: Conservation groups announced today that they would sue to force the Reagan Administration to impose sanctions on Japan if the Japanese violate an international ban on catching sperm whales.

Suspect in Bomb Threat
description: A woman has been charged with making a bomb threat against President Reagan while he visited Boston Thursday, the police say.

title: Reagan Sweeping Victor In Student-Parent Vote
description: President Reagan swept to victory Thursday, with almost 60 percent of the votes, as more than 1.6 million parents and students participated in the National Student-Parent Mock Election, five days before Election Day.

title: Conoco and Citgo To Pay Less for Oil
description: Conoco Inc. and the Citgo Petroleum Corporation, following the lead of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, yesterday cut the price they will pay for a barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude oil to $28.50. This common variety of oil, which accounts for about 10 percent of United States petroleum, is a benchmark by which other varieties are often priced.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1984 International The estimated death toll in India reached 500 as the violence ignited by the assassination of Indira Gandhi spread. About half the deaths were reported in the metropolitan area of New Delhi, the capital, where Mrs. Gandhi's funeral and cremation will take place today. Representatives of more than 100 countries will attend. (Page 1, Column 6.) The bodies of slain Sikhs have been arriving from the countryside at Delhi Railway Station. The deputy stationmaster said he had been told by witnesses that some of the Sikhs had been murdered by gangs who boarded the trains. Other victims, he said, were apparently killed or wounded first, then thrown into passing train carriages. On the eve of Indira's Gandhi's funeral, at least 40 bodies had arrived at the station, officials said. (1:3.)

title: TAPES FOR VICTIMIZED WOMEN

Cuts at Disney
description: Walt Disney Productions said it was eliminating 95 jobs at its Burbank studio, or about 5 percent of the stdio's 1,800 workers. Erwin Okun, a Disney vice president, said most of the positions were in the Walt Disney Pictures unit, which has about 1,000 employees. Some jobs in general and studio services, live action and post- production were being eliminated as a result of a productivity study completed in August, Mr. Okun said.

title: FURTHER CUTS IN HUMAN SERVICES

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31

title: U.S. and Britain Tied at 2-2 in Cup
description: The United States and Britain each won one match and were tied, 2-2, after tonight's play in the Wightman Cup women's tennis competition, a four- of-seven series. Jo Durie, the No. 1 British player, defeated Barbara Potter, 6-3, 7-6, winning the tiebreaker, 10-8. In the second match, the American captain, Chris Evert Lloyd, teamed with Alycia Moulton to beat Virginia Wade and Amanda Brown, 6-2, 6-2.

title: L.I. Infant Dies In Apartment Fire
description: A 1-year-old girl was killed and her mother was critically injured in a fire in an apartment house caused by a child playing with matches Thursday night, fire officials said.

title: UNCLE HAROLD'S ELECTION VIEWS
description: A few nights ago, my Uncle Harold called to talk about the election.

title: Ring on Ropes
description: Randy Gordon grew up reading Ring, fantasizing that one day he might write for the boxing magazine. Five years ago, his dream came true, and a year ago he was named editor.

description: Tony Dorsett, the Cowboy running back, left for Pennsylvania today after learning that his

title: ISRAEL REACHES ACCORD TO HELP CUT INFLATION
description: The Israeli Government today initialed a three- month agreement with representatives of the Histadrut labor union and leading manufacturers that could help to bring a sharp reduction in the country's 800 percent inflation rate.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE OF NEW HAMPHIRE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PAPP'S NEW 'BOHEME' MIGHT SURPRISE PUCCINI
description: I said, 'Opera? What do you want to do opera for?' '' Linda Ronstadt, the pop singer, recalls. ''I'd only ever seen one opera in my whole life, and that was 'Amahl and the Night Visitors.' I'd never heard 'La Boh eme.' ''

title: Jury Is Selected In Matthews Trial
description: The selection of 12 jurors and 6 alternates was completed today in the Federal extortion trial of former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City.

title: 3-MONTH MUSEUM SHOW FEATURES BRITISH TV
description: Lord Thomson, the head of the British Independent Broadcasting Authority, and Brian Cowgill, the managing director of Thames Television, drank coffee and considered television yesterday as they prepared for the seminar that would kick off the Museum of Broadcasting's three- month tribute to Thames, the biggest producer of television in Britain.

title: YANKEE OIL & GAS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There was an after-tax gain of $650,000 affecting both third quarter and 9-month earnings as a result of changes in tax laws.

title: Transactions
description: Promoter announced cancellation of next year's race because of scheduling problems. BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Hired Ken Berry, former major-league outfielder, as the minor-league hitting instructor.

title: SUSPECT IS ARRESTED
description: A Bronx teen-ager was shot and killed Thursday afternoon in front of a high school on the Upper West Side, and a suspect was being arrested yesterday, the police said.

title: A Bid for Early
description: Early California Industries Inc. said it had received notice that the ECI Acquiring Company will make a $10-a-share tender offer for any and all Early California shares.

title: SANTOS BEATS MEDAL TO TAKE I.B.F. TITLE
description: Carlos Santos did not run last night. He boxed, he slugged, he jabbed, he countered, he hit low, he bit. He did everything but cash a big pay check in scoring a surprising and convincing 15-round decision over Mark Medal to capture the International Boxing Federation's version of the junior middleweight title at the Felt Forum.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: MUSIC: HIROSHIMA MEMORIES
description: A haunting musical work that recalls the bombing of Hiroshima was given its first New York performance by the Inoue Ensemble at Goodman House on Tuesday night. The composer, Ken Niikura, is Japanese, and this work - though cast in a Western idiom - is very Japanese in its economy of gesture and detail.

title: AGENCIES STEP UP RELIEF FOR ETHIOPIA
description: As a major airlift began yesterday to send food to the drought-stricken northern regions of Ethiopia, a consortium of four relief agencies said they had developed a plan to distribute 200,000 tons of food in the East African nation over the next year.

description: Phyllis Miller Green and Joseph Anthony Walker 3d were married yesterday by Judge David Saxe of the Civil Court of the City of New York in his chambers.

description: Results reflect the consolidation of U.S. Equity & Mortgage Trust, an 86.5 percent-owned subsidiary.

title: A FAREWELL FOR A TRAIN AND AN ERA
description: The last diesel train on the Upper Harlem Line made its final run today, its passage evoking both relief and a sense of regret in commuters.

title: MENOTTI PLANS '86 PREMIERE IN CAPITAL
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, looking ahead to 1986, ''a fateful year for me because I will be 75 years old,'' is intent on completing an opera on the life of Goya by then. And he has chosen Washington and the Washington Opera for its premiere.

title: No Retreat From Seoul
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch , the president of the International Olympic Committee, said the 1988 Summer Games would be in Seoul, South Korea, despite fears of another Soviet-led boycott. The Soviet and other Eastern European nations that do not have diplomatic relations with South Korea and want the site changed have a sympathizer in an Italian I.O.C. member, Franco Carraro, who is leading a campaign to move the Games to a ''more neutral'' country.

title: DIAGNOSTIC RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TWO HISTORIANS OF PHOTOGRAPHY WIN AN AWARD
description: When Helmut Gernsheim and Beaumont Newhall, the two foremost historians of photography in the English language, first met in London during World War II they were two young men with a common interest in photography. On Thursday night, 40 years and several dozen books later, they met again in the Roosevelt Hotel in New York to be honored for their achievements in the presence of a group of distinguished photography collectors, curators, critics and dealers from the United States, Canada and Europe.

title:
Patents;
New Way To Detect Eye Tumor
description: WASHINGTONA new procedure for diagnosing tumors of the eye - having the patient look into a pair of radiation detectors - was patented this week for the Department of Energy. About 3,500 new cases of eye tumors are discovered each year in the United States.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES IN THE CITY DESPITE ECONOMIC IMPROVEMENTS
description: Unemployment in New York City rose last month to 9.7 percent as more people entered the labor force to look for jobs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The rate was 8.8 percent in September.

Identifying Currency And Tracing Thefts
description: Milton F. Allen, who operates the Scented Money Deterrency Company in Atlanta, was granted a patent this week for various ways of identifying paper currency and tracing thefts. His company now treats bills for banks by attaching glass vials that release odorous fluid.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17.

title: BUSH ASSERTS 'IDIOTS' LACK UNDERSTANDING OF AMERICA'S PRIDE
description: Vice President Bush told a rally in New Jersey today that there were a lot of ''idiots'' who did not understand that pride and patriotism had been restored in America as a result of President Reagan's policies.

title: Punter in Red
description: The Jets have the same game plan whether Pat Ryan or Ken O'Brien is the quarterback. But Chuck Ramsey, the Jets' punter, is wearing red these days - the color shirt a quarterback wears in practice - as the team's No. 3 quarterback.

title: Russell Staying Put
description: Bill Russell , who has been a member of the Los Angeles Dodgers for 16 years, has agreed to remain with the Dodgers rather than go through the free-agent draft Thursday.

title: FIRST WOMAN IS EXECUTED IN U.S. SINCE 1962
description: A moment after she uttered a a final apology for ''all the hurt I have caused,'' Margie Velma Barfield was executed here this morning for murder, the first woman to be put to death in the United States in 22 years.

title: Peking Leader Says Military Isn't Changing Fast Enough
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, complained in reports published today that despite his military policies, the armed forces remained plagued by aging generals, narrow-minded thinking, incompetence and overstaffing.

title: Cement Truck Crash Kills 6
description: A cement truck slammed into a small car, then veered into a recreational vehicle, killing six people today on a road near Interstate 35.

description: Visiting China seems to be increasingly popular with American sports figures.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review of paintings by Erastus Salisbury Field in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect address for the Museum of American Folk Art. It is 125 West 55th Street.

title: Bankrupt Airline To Stay Grounded
description: Plans to put American International Airways, a bankrupt discount carrier, back in the air in the next two months have apparently been scrapped because investors have been unable to agree on the best method, A.I.A.'s trustee said. The airline had expected to be flying again from Philadelphia to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., by Nov. 15, and from Detroit to Florida by Dec. 1.

title: A POLISH GENERAL IS TIED TO DEATH OF WARSAW PRIEST
description: The Government announced today that two more Interior Ministry security officers had been ordered detained and a general suspended in connection with the abduction and slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest.

title: FEW GAINS IN SALVADOR ARMY DRIVE
description: A major two-week-old effort by Salvadoran Army units to drive leftist rebels from their strongholds north of this garrison town in Morazan Province appears to be winding down with few decisive gains for the army.

description: b-Net income. Year-ago results are restated to reflect revenues and costs of two recently acquired subsidiaries, Systems Practice and Avera Corp.

title: INDIA INVESTIGATES PLOT POSSIBILITIES
description: Government investigators have reportedly begun to interrogate a man identified as the surviving assassin of Indira Gandhi and are said to be studying possible links between Sikhs in the security forces and Sikh extremists based inside and outside India.

title: 360o Music Experience
description: The drummer Beaver Harris and his group 360o Music Experience, with David Ware on saxophone and Brian Smith on bass, will perform tonight at 10:30 P.M. at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street (505-5660). Tickets are $8 (or Theater Development Fund voucher plus $2; $6 for students and the elderly).

title: Mafia Informer Faces Extradition to U.S.
description: The Italian authorities decided today to send a key Mafia informer to the United States to face drug-related charges, the ANSA news agency reported.

title: Wien Air Halts Its Operations
description: Wien Air Alaska Inc. said it plans to suspend all scheduled flight operations for 25 days beginning Nov. 17 to restructure its scheduled operations.

title: PENTAGON PRESSING ITS PROGRAM FOR HOMELESS
description: The Defense Department said Thursday it was pressing its program to turn 600 military facilities into shelters for the homeless, and the Department of Health and Human Services urged an advocate for the indigent who is protesting Administration policies to end his 49-day hunger strike.

title: Suspect in Killings Pleads Not Guilty
description: A 25-year-old man accused of killing six teen-age girls and young women in southeastern Connecticut pleaded not guilty today to two counts of capital felony in two of the slayings.

title: MONDALE ATTRACTS BIG CROWD TO HIS RALLY IN BOSTON
description: Chanting ''Four more days,'' tens of thousands of people welcomed Walter F. Mondale to Boston today and heard the Democratic nominee attack President Reagan's foreign and domestic policies as dangerous and without ''caring or compassion.''

title: Jockey on the Move
description: Steve Cauthen , the peripatetic rider who became the first American in 71 years to win the British jockeys' championship, picked up his trophy in England yesterday and announced plans to extend his international range. title: THE POLISH RIDDLES
description: ''There are many riddles in the case,'' said Jerzy Urban, the Polish Government's chief spokesman, as he discussed the investigation into the slaying of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko. Essentially, the specifics of the case as it has emerged are that on Oct. 19, as the 37-year-old pro-Solidarity cleric was returning to Warsaw after preaching at a church in Bydgosz, the car he was riding in was stopped by three men in a second car. The priest's friend and driver, Waldemar Chrostowski, was said to have later told the police that he was blindfolded, gagged, handcuffed and pushed into the car. He said he heard the priest say, ''Gentlemen, what are you doing?'' This was followed by a thud and the sound of weight being thrown into the trunk. Mr. Chrostowski said he managed to pry up the door latch and rolled out of the moving car, escaping into the night. According to Government sources, the abductors sent a ransom note to church officials. Shortly thereafter, investigators focused attention on Gregorz Piotrrowski, a captain in the Interior Ministry department that is reportedly charged with monitoring the activities of priests. The captain had reportedly forged an entry in a log book in his official car. Traces of the priest's hair were found in the trunk, and the captain was detained with two associates in the ministry's security services, Lieut. Wlademar Chmielewski and Lieut. Leszek Pekala. Questioning of the suspects led investigators to a reservoir near Wloclawek, where the priest's body was discovered by divers last Tuesday.

title: To Get at Guns in Schools Between classes at New York City's DeWitt Clinton High School recently, a 15-year-old girl was grazed by a bullet. The 16-year-old boy who accidentally fired the shot while showing off his gun to a friend now faces criminal charges. But the case raises a larger question: Why can't the Board of Education keep guns out of the schools?

title: A KIND WORD FOR NOVEMBER
description: Most months need no defense. We like them for what they are. November is different. More than any other month, except perhaps February, it requires advocacy. Poets often scorn it. Thomas Moore called it a ''solemn month (amid) gathering gloom.'' Bayard Taylor epitomized it as ''the croak of a crow, on the desolate tree top.'' It has, wrote Thomas Hood, ''no nobility, no warmth, no cheerfulness.'' Plain folk tend to resent it, underrate it, or, at best, tolerate it.

title: What Velma Wore Margie Velma Barfield, who died by lethal injection early yesterday morning, chose pink cotton pajamas for the event. Her last meal consisted of Cheez Doodles and a Coke. We know these details about Mrs. Barfield's wardrobe and diet, as we know them about the 28 men who've shared her fate in the eight years since the death penalty was restored, because the entertainment value of an execution is still very high.

title: ARE CROWDS AND ART A HAPPY MIX?
description: People are really very perverse. There is on Manhattan Island, north of 52d Street and all the way up to Fort Tryon Park, as dense and as various a concentration of great art on a permanent basis as can be found anywhere in the world. Inch by inch, and gamut by gamut, there is no capital city of which we need be envious, though there are many that we long to visit. And our situation gets better year by year. New buildings go up, new collections come in, individual masterpieces arrive almost by stealth.

title: Coach Reprimanded
description: After an investigation by a special committee at Memphis State, Rey Dempsey, the football coach, and three unnamed assistants have been reprimanded for violating state education policy on religious activities. They were cited for having had an unnamed former football professional speak to the players on a religious topic and for having permitted religious activities at a summer football camp. The committee, formed after the American Civil Liberties Union had filed a list of complaints, found that most of the charges were groundless, including accusations that starting assignments had been made on the basis of players' religious beliefs; that athletic scholarships had been withdrawn because prospects were not Christians, and that one coach had told players they couldn't play on his team unless they played on ''God's team.''

title: BAN ON SEAPLANES URGED ON EAST END

title: ORGAN TRANSPLANTS GROW IN NUMBERS AND SUCCESS
description: Thirty years after a Harvard team of physicians removed a healthy kidney from a man and transferred it to his twin brother, doctors continue to conduct dramatic and controversial experiments in human transplants. Removing the heart of a living baboon and implanting it into an infant named Baby Fae in California nine days ago is the latest breakthrough. In recent years, doctors have transplanted the lungs, heart-and-lung combinations, the small intestine, and even a uterus, among other organs. But behind the risky work on the scientific frontiers, something at least as remarkable is taking place in the medical mainstream. The number of transplants of hearts, livers, kidneys, corneas and other organs has been growing rapidly in the past few years, and the operation is becoming a standard medical procedure in desperate cases.60,000 KidneysExperts at the National Center for Health Services Research estimate that more than 60,000 kidneys have been transplanted in the world in the past two decades. The center counts roughly 5,300 bone marrow transplants worldwide, and it says that doctors have also transplanted more than 700 livers and 400 pancreases and roughly 800 hearts. Heart transplants, which made headlines in the 1960's but proved so ineffective that most medical centers stopped performing them, have returned to favor. Early this year, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, one of the heart transplant pioneers, resumed the operation after a 14-year layoff. ''We're at the low end of an upward swing'' in organ transplants, says Kenneth Goodman, executive director of the American Council on Transplantation, a private group that seeks to increase the supply of available human organs.

title: UPTOWN SANTA
description: It was December, I was 10 years old, and my mother, my brother and I were visiting Aunt Frances. We had come to Harlem before, always in summer, always by Trailways, always leaving my father at home, content with Boston's South End. New York, he said, was full of hoodlums. This time we had come for the funeral of a woman from Mother's hometown, Kingston, Jamaica. Mother always took us to funerals; they offered friends a chance to meet, to speak of past lives and future hopes. Truth to tell, my brother - five years my junior - and I attended with curious delight: We'd listen intently to the minister and to grown-ups talking later of those who had ''gone on.'' But in New York we were restless. The mourners were strangers, the talk strangers' talk. Our mother cut short her socializing and led us out to 125th Street.

title: TIME BURNISHES BARBER'S 'ANTONY AND CLEOPATRA'
description: Samuel Barber, who died in 1981 at the age of 70, lived long enough to see the beginnings of an academic vindication of his musical vision. Barber never lacked public appreciation; after Copland and Bernstein, he must stand as the most popular American composer of midcentury. But, during most of the composer's life, it was fashionable within certain musical circles to dismiss him as a sentimental reactionary who could never come to terms with the latest Modernist innovations, and should therefore suffer the consequences. Barber's insistence on a tonal framework for the majority of his compositions; his refusal to treat composition as historical process; his commitment to direct, lyrical, unabashedly emotional musical

description: DEBATES REVEAL the living language. The carefully phrased answers suggested in briefing books cannot all be committed to memory; in actual debate, the prompting devices are stripped away, and the words that tumble off the screen are often made up in the speaker's head.

title: CASINO BARGAIN Although
description: Frank Lentino and former Atlantic City Mayor Michael J. Matthews stand accused of being partners in crime, Mr. Matthews will be facing the jury alone.

title: PUERTO RICO:A DREAM DIVIDED
description: William Stockton is assistant to the executive editor of The Times.

title: IN SHORT
description: This is ''The Wizard of Oz'' written as a boy's adventure, with spacey adumbrations on the theme of good and evil and their symmetry in the universe. Jack Sawyer is the boy, his scarecrow is an old black man named Speedy Parker, his cowardly lion is a cheerful werewolf and the Tin Woodman is his human but ultra-rational cousin Richard. The yellow brick road may be U.S. 40, while Oz is a quaint country known as the Territories, to which Jack learns to travel far more easily than by tornado over a rainbow. The talisman, the object off his quest, is the Wizard. Unlike the Wizard, the little crystal ball is not a fraud but ''the axle of all possible worlds'' with which Jack's mother, a former Sandra Dee-type actress known as the ''Queen of the B's,'' and her ''twinner,'' the Queen of the Territories, will be able to rise from their deathbeds. There is no Toto, but to make up for that there are two wicked witches. Stephen King and Peter Straub must have had fun with their collaboration, not least by making digs at other authors. The evil evangelist is named Sunlight Gardener, the worst man in the hellish town of Oatley is Smokey Updike, and Jack starts out at a creepy hotel in New Hampshire. There are quantities of blood and of worms crawling out of things, and of each character's verbal tag tacked to every utterance - ''Yeah-bob,'' ''Right here and now,'' ''God pound his nails,'' ''Can you gimme hallelujah,'' - until you could hum them in your sleep.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Sociological Candor

title: MORAL MAJORITY AND ITS ALLIES EXPECT HARVEST OF VOTES FOR CONSERVATIVES
description: Moral Majority, the fundamentalist Christian lobby that sprang upon the national scene in 1980 but came to maturity this year, is confidently awaiting a harvest of votes for its causes and candidates on Tuesday.

title: A LIVELY RENAISSANCE FOR SCULPTURE IN BRONZE
description: As with just about everything else that was exiled from the defiant and resolute late modernist years, bronze is back. The material that gave us the Charioteer of Delphi, the doors of Hildesheim Cathedral, Ghiberti's doors to the Baptistery of Florence, Donatello's ''David'' and Rodin's ''Balzac'' was certainly not going to melt away just because the esthetic and ethical imperatives of one art historical moment deemed it unworthy. Not only has bronze come back, but ''Six in Bronze,'' an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum through Jan. 6, suggests that it is generating sculptural possibilities that did not exist before.

title: Harboring People
description: With New York City housing 6,500 homeless people in 18 shelters and no end to the problem in sight, Mayor Koch said in April that he was considering using mothballed war ships and idle ferryboats as shelters. He stressed that he was ''very serious'' about the idea.

title: FRANK TO A FAULT As a diplomat,
description: Samuel W. Lewis seemed to slip a little out of character last week during a speech in Tel Aviv. Mr. Lewis, the American Ambassador to Israel, said the timing of President Reagan's 1982 Middle East peace plan was ''abysmal'' and that its outcome was ''so far, nil.''

title: Study Says Active Men Get Less Colon Cancer
description: Men with active jobs are less likely to develop cancer of the colon than those with more sedentary jobs, a study of 2,950 colon cancer patients shows.

title: A RARE ACHIEVEMENT
description: The composed problem, in bridge as in chess, is remote from practical play. Few enthusiasts care to make the effort to solve a double- dummy situation which they know will be challenging and complex. On the rare occasions on which such deals occur in practice there is virtually no chance that the declarer will find the double-dummy solution, which is likely to escape altogether unless the post-mortem is conducted with great vigor and perception.

title: HOSPITAL FOR RICH NOW AIDS EAST SIDE
description: Doctors Hospital, once the medical preserve of the rich and famous on the Upper East Side, is becoming a highly visable community hospital serving Yorkville's large elderly population and its growing influx of young professionals.

title: No Headline
description: Wine is made all over the world, but wine excitement is made in New York. When a Bordeaux Rothschild wants to sell his wine, he doesn't go to Paris; he comes to Manhattan. When Italy decides it is time to create a great modern showcase for its wines, does it build in Rome? Or Milan? No, the Italian Wine Center is at Park Avenue and 59th Street. And where would Beaujolais nouveau be today if New York had not made a fad of it a dozen years ago?

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNALZ HISTORIANS as well as law-enforcement officials are assessing last week's Halloween activities. Traditionally, on Halloween Eve - widely known as ''Mischief Night'' - pranksters armed with soap and eggs sally forth, bent on leaving their marks on car, store and garage windows, as well as on occasional pedestrians or even on other pranksters.
description: In recent years, many municipalities in the state's 21 counties have adopted curfews aimed at clearing the streets of would-be tricksters. However, such curfews - most begin at 9-P.M. - are being viewed by the state's chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union as a violation of a person's right to walk the street without harassment. Deborah Karpatkin , a lawyer with the Newark- based A.C.L.U., said that curfews held ''practically all minors accountable'' for offenses committed by a few. She stressed that, although the A.C.L.U. did not object to laws that guarded against vandalism and mischievous activity by minors, curfews were unfair, particularly in communities where the law applied to all citizens.

title: LITTLE CORNER'S OF TOKYO'S PAST
description: For a city with only a smattering of buildings over 30 years old, Tokyo manages in a quite uncanny way to present its history in its modern face. Otemachi, Marunouchi, Hibiya - those areas that constitute the hub of the modern city - belonged in feudal days to the military classes. Now they are the preserve of the modern business baronies. Not far to the north, Asakusa, Ueno and Yushima belonged for the main part to the townspeople and priests. And so, one may say, with historical license, they do today.

title: TABLETOP TALENTS
description: JOHN LORING, DESIGN DIRECTOR OF TIFFANY & Company, collects flatware, china and crystal as children collect building blocks. In fact, he calls his stash of accouterments toys for the table. David F. Sanders Jr., owner of D. F. Sanders & Company, the housewares emporium, has amassed a tabletop wardrobe filled with many of the great modern classics. And Peri Wolfman and her husband, Charles Gold, of the store Wolfman- Gold & Good Company create elegant table settings using items that are both opulent and edible. Such theatrics are a challenge to tabletop manufacturers, making them invent a bevy of new merchandise each season. This fall, their latest designs will be on display at the New York Tabletop and Accessories Show, which opens Saturday and runs through Nov. 16. This event, held twice a year in the manufacturers' showrooms, enables buyers for department and specialty stores to shop for new spring merchandise.

title: MONDALE AIDE HAS TAKEN ODYSSEY OF VIEWS

title: ORVIETO: MARVEL OF THE MIDDLE AGES
description: The plateau that time forgot: There can be few more alluring notions, and Orvieto, perched above a green, wine-growing valley in central Italy, fulfills it perfectly. The city, on its tall, sheer cliffs, is still almost as hard to reach as it was in the 12th and 13th centuries when, in a series of wars with its neighbors, its site served a strategic purpose. Much later, in our own day, the same lofty site precluded the building of railroad tracks (the station is down in the valley), superhighways, shopping centers and other similar blessings of the modern age. So the city has remained much as it was in the late Middle Ages, when it became part of the Pontifical States. Yet this seeming permanence is threatened: The passage of time and the vibrations of traffic have undermined the city, and the soft stone of the cliff on which it stands has begun to disintegrate. Although precautionary measures have been planned, the work has yet to begin.

title: Strong Dollar Forces ThaisInto Devaluation of the Baht
description: The recent rise of the United States dollar has forced Thailand to devalue and float its currency, the baht, Finance Minister Sommai Hoontrakul said today.

title: IS PAPANDREOU ROCKING THE NATO BOAT?
description: Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou last month became the first Western chief of government to visit Poland since martial law was imposed in 1981. That in itself was enough to upset his allies, but the Socialist leader - a former American citizen, wartime Navy sailor and University of California economics professor - went farther. He denounced Western esteem for the Solidarity labor union, contending it was motivated by the desire to ''destabilize'' the Soviet camp at Washington's behest. Mr. Papandreou also praised Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader who crushed the liberalization, as a socialist patriot. And he dismissed Solidarity as a onetime ''progressive'' movement that had become ''negative and dangerous.''

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO KEEP HOUSE PLANTS HEALTHY
description: ABOUT this time of year house plant problems begin to appear, especially with those plants that were furloughed outdoors for the summer. The causes of these problems merit attention if the plants are to survive and flourish.

title: CROSSING SWORDS OVER THE CROSSROADDS
description: Whatever else it may have been, the Board of Estimate's recent hearing on the huge Times Square rebuilding plan was a display of power. The arguments for and against it had been heard before, of course. Mayor Koch has described it as the greatest project since the Pyramids; a slightly more modest assessment from a state official compares it to the Parthenon. But the fact that the Mayor personally presided over the board for the first time in five years, and Governor Cuomo became the first governor in at least a generation to enter its chambers, underscored the importance of the project to each.

According to The Orlando Sentinel, the 49-year-old Corso, who took over at Northern Michigan last January after 10 years at Indiana, worked out a tentative agreement with Renegade officials in a week of negotiations, and an announcement is expected tomorrow.

title:
TRAVEL ADVISORY: EGYPTIAN JOURNEY, CHRISTMAS BIRD COUNT;
Biblical Tours
description: Turkish officials are busy dusting off their biblical past in an effort to attract more foreign tourists. Travelers on traditional Holy Land tours are reminded that the Book of Revelations' Seven Churches of Asia Minor - Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia and Laodicea are in western Turkey. And tourists with a particular interest in the roles played by the disciples of Jesus will also remember that Paul, who was born in Tarsus (the modern Turkish city bears the same name), traveled widely throughout Turkey and the eastern Mediterranean in his missionary work.

title: A PASSAGE THROUGH INDIA
description: The best travel experiences are the unexpected ones. At the time, we cursed our travel agent for not knowing that ''air-conditioned'' was the top class on Indian railroads, ''first'' being akin to cattle-car accommodations. Today, a decade later, those 17 hours we spent on that train are richer in retrospect than the caves of Ajanta and Ellora we had just come from or the Taj Mahal to which we were headed.

title: THE WORLD LEADERS AT THE GANDHI FUNERAL
description: Following are the officials who were designated to represent their countries and international organizations at the funeral today of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. The list is based on information from the governments and organizations and the Indian Foreign Ministry.

description: Barbara Johnson is a professor of French and comparative literature at Harvard. She is the author of ''The Critical Difference'' and the forthcoming ''Critical Transitions.'' DICKINSON

title: Lisa Ann Roberts Weds a Physician
description: Lisa Ann Roberts, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Walter Roberts of New York, and Dr. William Todd Pordy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Pordy of New York, were married yesterday in Manhattan. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: BESIDE NEW DELHI RIVER, 2 SCENES OF MOURNING
description: The sluggish Jumna River cuts through the northeastern corner of the Union Territory of Delhi, leaving the prosperous and the not-so-prosperous to the west of its flat banks and the very poor to the east in slums that are known officially as ''unauthorized regularized colonies.''

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: ''Echoes of Vienna's Heritage'' resound loudly in Paul Hofmann's nostalgic essay (Travel, Aug. 12).

title: EX-IMMIGRANT, BACK ON ISLAND, LEFT A LEGACY
description: RENDEZVOUS BAY, ANGUILLA THE decision to return to his birthplace here was not an easy one for Jeremiah Gumbs. He had accumulated much over 46 years in and around Edison, N.J. Not material things, but memories - and a legacy of sorts.

description: THE work of George J. Ivers, an East Windsor artist, will be traveling through Latin America, Australia, New Zealand, Japan and the United States to help poor children.

description: Richard Smith Beal, a political analyst, pollster and expert in survey research for the National Security Council at the White House, died Friday after a long illness. He was 38 years old.

description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met here tonight with the Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai A. Tikhonov, and later said they had had ''a good meeting.''

description: ABOUT this time of year house plant problems begin to appear, especially with those plants that were furloughed outdoors for the summer. The causes of these problems merit attention if the plants are to survive and flourish.

title: THE RECITAL
description: Alana looked as if she had been on the street for at least a decade when she appeared one night at Emmaus House, a community of homeless men and women in a Harlem brownstone. She was a tiny figure swathed in layers of jackets, coats and scarves. A turban concealed her red hair. Two overstuffed shopping bags held what appeared to be the rest of her worldly goods. With dignity she announced herself as a great jazz pianist who had toured with such masters as Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong. There was not an empty room at Emmaus; Father David Kirk, the Eastern Rite Catholic priest who presides with grace and kindness over the shelter, gave her a bed in the chapel.

title: ARAB-AMERICANS TAKE AN INCREASED POLITICAL ROLE

title:
THE WORLD;
SVETLANA GOES BACK

Miss Alliluyeva, the daughter of Joseph Stalin, has returned to Moscow and her Soviet citizenship has been restored, the press agency Tass reported last week.

title: RITES FOR WOMAN POLICE KILLED
description: More than 100 people filled a Bronx funeral home yesterday to mourn Eleanor Bumpurs, the 66-year-old woman who was fatally shot by the police while resisting eviction from her apartment in the Sedgwick Houses in the Bronx.

title: Torborg Drops Out
description: Jeff Torborg, who had been the leading candidate to fill the Seattle Mariners' managerial vacancy, is no longer in the running because the Mariners can no longer talk to him about the job. Torborg, who has four years left on a seven-year contract as a Yankee coach, learned Friday that George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, had withdrawn permission two weeks ago for the Mariners to talk to Torborg.

title: REPUBLICANS GET MILITARY ABSENTEE VOTER LIST
description: Through the Freedom of Information Act and a Pentagon computer, the National Republican Senatorial Committee, with the help of President Reagan's campaign committee, recently obtained the names and office addresses of 1.4 million military personnel who requested absentee ballots this year.

title: 12TH DRAW IN A ROW AT CHESS CHAMPIONSHIP
description: The parade of draws in the world championship chess match in Moscow between the titleholder, 33-year-old Anatoly Karpov, and 21-year-old Gary Kasparov continues on. When the players agreed to a draw on the 31st move of the 21st game of the series on Friday, they were registering the 12th draw in a row, extending the record for consecutive draws in world championship play. Karpov leads the series 4 to 0, but one now wonders whether he will ever score the two more victories needed to win the match; draws do not count. This 21st game was a pretty much uneventful performance by both players. True, Kasparov expedited his development with a little gambit, but Karpov refused it to resume business as usual, and neither side ever got the upper hand. The same Queen's Gambit Declined variation as in the 19th game made its appearance, but this time Kasparov, probably fearing some prepared analysis by Karpov's team, eschewed his earlier sharp 7 . . . N-B3 in favor of 7 . . . PxP. This allowed Karpov to advance 8 P-K4 without hindrance, but Kasparov was equally free to strike back at the white center buildup with 8 . . . P-B4. The champion did not try to seize the gambit pawn offered by 12 . . . O-O!, since 13 QxP, B-N5! will recover the material with a good game. Thus, 14 O-O, BxN; 15 PxB, B-B5 threatens 16 . . . Q-R5! as well as 16 . . . NxP. After the exchange of queens with 13 . . . QxQ; 14 BxQ, the resulting ending was quite even: White had the better centralized piece placement, but his KP was slightly fragile and Black had the bishop-pair.

title: LEARNING TO RELAX TO EASE THE PAIN
description: HENRY HOPPE will never forget his blinding headaches. They came like armies in the night. The pain would sneak along his shoulder blades and slowly creep up his neck before reaching his head. By then it was too late for Mr. Hoppe to defend himself. The pain would explode in his head.

title: REAGAN NOW SAYS MANUEL WAS MISTRANSLATED
description: President Reagan, commenting on a Central Intelligence Agency manual for Nicaraguan rebels that describes how to undermine the Government, said today that there was ''nothing in that manual that talked assassination at all.''

title: SOUND AND SILENCE IN FILM
description: Walter Kerr raises a number of interesting points about sound and silence in film. His analysis of scenes from various American films is good, but for some reason he neglects foreign directors.

title: SPOTTING AND TRACKING TO PRECEDE AERIAL WOLF HUNTING IN ALASKA
description: Hunting of wolves from the air is authorized to begin Sunday over portions of Alaska's interior, but any flying done this weekend will be only for spotting, according to a state wildlife official.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
PORTRAITS THAT INFORM THROUGH AMBIGUITY
description: At first glance, no two bodies of work could be less like one another than Francesco Scavullo's fashion magazine portraits at Light Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, through Dec. 1, and Nicholas Nixon's pictures of old people in nursing homes at Pace/MacGill Gallery, 11 East 57th Street, through Nov. 24. Scavullo's celebrities, dramatically posed, lighted and cropped to catch the eye, are presented in large prints, including one floor-to-ceiling blowup. Nixon's 8-by-10-inch contact prints are no larger than is usual nowadays in museum and gallery exhibitions, and his otherwise unknown old people, photographed apparently unposed in the settings of their everyday lives, are shown in a neutral light that seems to do no more (or perhaps I should say no less) than reveal them as they actually are. Scavullo seems to have created out of public figures a flamboyant world of his own imagination. Nixon seems to have retreated so far from his obscure subjects that their pictures seem to be taken by camera and chemistry alone, without any interpretation by the photographer.

title: CHICAGO OPERA ON TRACK
description: ''Our policy is to engage the best casts in the world. I've been here from the start; I don't know any other way.'' The speaker was Ardis Krainik, former bit-part singer, former secretary, long-time behind-the-scenes assistant, current general manager of the Chicago Lyric Opera, the company that is now celebrating its 30th anniversary by putting on ''Eugene Onegin,'' ''Carmen,'' ''Arabella'' and four others with what, on the basis of name recognition, you might call the best casts in the world.

title: I & T ; NEW ALARM AND DALKON SHIELD
description: When the Dalkon Shield was introduced in the early 1970's, it was heralded as a trouble-free, reliable means of birth control, a symbol of greater freedom for women. Later, however, amid claims that the intrauterine device caused sterility, spontaneous abortion, pelvic infections and even death, it became symbolic of the danger that a faulty product can pose to consumers.

County restaurants serving special meals on Nov. 22 and listing more than a token bottle of Zinfandel include The Horse and Hound Inn (Spring Street, South Salem, 763-3108) and Pratt's Inn (Route 118, Yorktown, 962-4090). description: Mr. and Mrs. Rocco Martusciello of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Iris Martusciello, to Edward J. Vorwerk, a son of Patricia Dobbs and E. Casey Vorwerk, both of New Canaan, Conn. The wedding is to be in January.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
A MOTHER'S SON
description: A SLIGHTLY GARISH model of a wooden gondola, from Venice, now graces the top of the steamer trunk that serves as a coffee table in my apartment living room. I received the gondola from my mother in 1967, when I was 11. It was one of the trophies she brought back from her first trip abroad, and it became my favorite toy for several years. It vanished in the early 1970's, shortly after my parents moved across the country.

title: Susan Alderton Is Bride of S. A. Crane
description: Susan Edith Alderton, a daughter of Squadron Leader and Mrs. Ronald H. Alderton of Ramsey, England, was married there yesterday to Stephen Andrew Crane, the son of Mrs. Andrew J. Crane of New York and the late Mr. Crane. The Rev. Brian Jones performed the ceremony at St. Thomas a Becket Church.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS SAID TO EXECUTE 9
description: On the night of July 22 leftist guerrillas entered this small village and abducted seven of its leading residents. Three weeks ago the rebels returned, several villagers say, and announced that the men had been executed for political reasons.

title: WORLD LEADERS BACK REAGAN FOR HIS FOREIGN POLICY
description: Government leaders and diplomats in Western Europe, most of Latin America, the Middle East and Asia are quietly expressing hopes for President Reagan's re-election, according to interviews with foreign officials here and abroad.

title: ON HOME TURF After pondering her future in international athletics,
description: Zola Budd last week took herself out of the running. The track star, who switched her citizenship from South African to British to compete in last summer's Olympics, announced that South Africa would again be her home.

title: CONNECTICUT PLAN WOULD AID GIFTED
description: Gifted students in Connecticut public schools would receive special academic and artistic programs by the 1988-89 school year under a proposal being drafted for the State Board of Education.

description: Janet Leigh's autobiography, ''There Really

title: A RETROSPECTIVE ON TEACHING HIGH SCHOOL IN THE EARY 1950's
description: SINCE my retirement from teaching, I often look back to the early years of my career, 1950-1954. A great war had been won; the world had been saved from tyranny.

title: GOING THROUGH THE MOTIONS IN NICARAGUA
description: Most everyone in Nicaragua is confident of what will happen in today's election: The ruling Sandinista Front will win easily, and its leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, will be elected President. It is after the voting that things become confused.

title: Paper Says Slain Author Wrote of Rift in Taiwan
description: A Chinese- American writer killed in California last month was about to publish two books on conflicts in the Taiwanese Government, the official China Daily said today.

title: THEATER: SHAKESPEARE'S CYMBELINE' IS PRESENTED
description: As Shakespeare's harshest critic, Shaw dismissed the play as ''silly old 'Cymbeline', '' while excluding the character of Imogen from his devastating charge. She is one of Shakespeare's glorious heroines, the total embodiment of her assumed name, Fidele - a woman who is faithful through the thick of betrayal and bloody revenge.

title: YALE STRIKE TOUCHES MANY CHORDS IN CITY
description: THE cash register hardly stopped ringing at Claire's Corner Copia on Chapel Street in New Haven. But Claire Criscuolo, the restaurant's owner, was not celebrating.

title: IANNONE STARS FOR EASTCHESTER
description: Mike Iannone found the end zone in a variety of ways yesterday - scoring on a kick return, a run, a catch and a fumble recovery - as Eastchester upset Rye, 28-13, and gained a share of the Conference B-II South championship.

title:
THE WORLD;
A LONG PULLOUT BY ISRAEL FROM LEBANON
description: Israel's unity Government came to power in July agreed on the need to withdraw from Lebanon as soon as possible. But amid preparations for talks that start tomorrow, it was clear that leaving would be much harder than entering and occupying.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN

title: A 'Disservice' to Irving Berlin?

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: EXILED IN PARADISE: German Refugee Artists and Intellectuals in America, from the 1930s to the Present, by Anthony Heilbut. (Beacon, $12.95.) Writing in these pages last year, Stanley Kauffmann called the migration of European intellectuals and artists to America during the Hitler era ''the largest transfusion of talents from one culture to another in Western history.'' Anthony Heilbut's ''Exiled in Paradise'' is devoted to those men and women, from Hannah Arendt and Bertolt Brecht to Kurt Weill and Stefan Zweig, what they came from and their experiences here. Mr. Kauffmann praised Mr. Heilbut's ''passionate concern. If he picked up a heavy load which sometimes makes him spill a bit or stumble, he marches on with fervor.'' A MAN AND TWO WOMEN, by Doris Lessing. (Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) These are stories, set in England and South Africa, dealing with sexual and romantic involvements. Our reviewer, Stanley Kauffmann, taking note of Doris Lessing's ''The Golden Notebook'' which came out in 1962, a year before ''A Man and Two Women,'' said, ''Most of these 19 stories are the work of the author she has already shown herself to be - a mature and valuable artist, adventurous in the mysteries of daily life, thoughtful, passionate, true.''

description: JAZZ SMORGASBORD

title: Dr. Christine Ann Fusillo Bride of Realty Executive
description: Dr. Christine Ann Fusillo, assistant director of pediatrics at the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital, and Robert Vincent O'Boyle, regional director of Mast Properties, a real-estate management company in Orange, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Christopher Turczany performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: MUSIC: PORTLAND QUARTET PLAYS BLOCH
description: It is now 25 years since the death of Ernest Bloch. To commemorate the composer's death - and, more importantly, to celebrate his life and achievements - Suzanne Bloch, a distinguished artist in her own right, has sponsored a complete cycle of her father's string quartets at Alice Tully Hall. The series, featuring the Portland String Quartet, began Wednesday night, with performances of the first and third quartets, and will conclude next Wednesday, with the remaining three.

title: TIME RUNS OUT FOR CONVICTED MURDERERS
description: It had been 22 years since a woman was executed in a United States prison. But on Friday in North Carolina, Margie Velma Barfield, a convicted murderer, was strapped to a hospital gurney and intravenously fed a lethal dose of muscle relaxer.

title: Future Events
description: Benefits for Many BY ROBERT E. TOMASSON

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: CANCER patients who are able to return to work after their treatment often face a new adversary: job discrimination.

title: Connecticut Woman Receives New Heart
description: A 52- year-old woman today was given the heart of a man who had been killed in an automobile accident, doctors at Yale-New Haven Hospital said. It was the first heart transplant in Connecticut.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY SHULTZ ON U.S.-INDIAN LINKS
description: Following is the text of a statement given to reporters today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz after he met with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi:

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The right to live and the right to die came into debate at the Chamber Music Society's concert Friday night. The program at Alice Tully Hall had, as a whole, the kind of mix and range we have come to expect from this series, with pieces by Haydn, Perle, Chausson and Faure. But the evening really centered on six songs by Alban Berg - three of which the composer wanted us to hear, three of which he wished to take with him to his grave.

title: Miss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Ziegler of Bainbridge Island, Wash., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ziegler's daughter, Mary Elizabeth Laidlaw, to Jonathan Franklin, the son of Sir Michael and Lady Franklin of Barnet, England. An April wedding is planned.

title: A Home for Cambodia's Children
description: Pain and joy characterized my reaction to Gail Sheehy's moving and remarkable article, ''A Home for Cambodia's Children'' (Sept. 23). It is painful to witness the extent of man's potential for evil. But, with all the accounts of life under the Khmer Rouge, what emerges is hope - hope in man, in his ability to do good, in his ability to pick up destroyed pieces and to rebuild. HIEM THONG

title: 2d Quake Rocks Wyoming
description: The second moderate earthquake to hit Wyoming in two weeks rattled the Lander area early today, awakening people and causing some minor damage but no injuries. John Minsch, of the United States Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said the quake occurred at 2:30 A.M. and registered 5 on the open-ended Richter scale, milder than the 5.5 quake that struck the state on Oct. 18. Today's quake was centered about 25 miles southwest of Lander in southwest Wyoming.

title: Deborah Reilly Marries
description: Deborah Ann Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Reilly of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kenneth J. Hanniford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth G. Hanniford of New City, N.Y. The Rev. Rudolph Eisler performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Data Bank; November 4, 1984
REPORT CONTENDS POLITICS UNDERMINED WASTE UNIT
description: Three Long Island towns squandered $8.15 million on planning a garbage- conversion plant that never got built because political considerations outweighed merit in many decisions, the State Commission of Investigation has charged.

title: PHILIP GLASS ZEROES IN ON OPERA AS THEATER
description: At one point last summer, it looked as if New York was going to see three major operatic productions by Philip Glass within a six- month span: those portions of Robert Wilson's epic ''Civil Wars'' with music by Mr. Glass at the Metropolitan Opera House in July, the New York premiere of Mr. Glass's ''Akhnaten'' in November at the City Opera and a revival of the Glass-Wilson ''Einstein on the Beach'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in December.

title: RESEARCH LINKS GENETIC TRAIT TO RISK OF DOWN'S SYNDROME
description: Researchers have identified a genetic abnormality that sharply increases parents' risk of having a child with Down's syndrome, a discovery that could prevent as many as 30 percent of such births.

title: OPEC MOVES TO ADAPT IN A WORLD THAT USES LESS OIL
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last week patched its leaky boat and prepared to weather the latest storm of price cuts and dissension. By reducing oil output by 8.6 percent to 16 million barrels a day, OPEC hoped to tighten supplies, stiffen prices and bring maverick members into line.

Weeks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shelton Weeks of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.
