description: If nothing else, Manhattan Dance Theater was enterprising. A new ballet company directed by Colleen Heffernan and Bridgett Lambertini, it offered four ambitious works Monday night at the Y.W.C.A. of the City of New York at 610 Lexington Avenue. And it managed to get as many as 15 dancers onto a stage so small as to seem scarcely suitable for a puppet show.

Smith of Lancaster, Pa. A spring wedding is planned.

title: PICKING THE LOW-INFLATION WINNERS
description: Most money managers are convinced that the disinflation of the past few years is here to stay for a while. Consequently, many of them will continue portfolio strategies designed to take advantage of such an environment.

BUSINESS FORUM;
THE LESS BUSINESS IS TAXED, THE BETTER
description: Up to now, the debate over whether corporations bear too small a portion of the national tax burden has not been very edifying. This is because those critics who argue that corporate taxes should be increased ignore two fundamental facts:

title: Miss Mullen To Be Bride In February
description: Charlotte Victoria Mullen and Benjamin Joseph Sullivan Jr. plan to be married Feb. 16, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Welch Mullen of New York, have announced.

title: SOUND ; UNUSUAL TONEARMS ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LP MUSIC
description: Among the estimated 83 million turntables spinning out music in the United States, about 200,000 are laser-digital CD players. Considering that these devices have been on the market for only a short time, this is quite a sizable figure, attesting to the deserved success of the new technology. Even so, these digital devices are outnumbered 415:1 by conventional phonographs, and this ratio supports predictions that regular LP's and regular turntables will dominate the phonographic scene for years to come.

title: OPEC CUTS QUOTA, BUT TO WHAT AVAIL?
description: Oil Quotas. The OPEC nations considered their agreement to reduce daily output to be a sign of solidarity in the face of falling prices. But oil analysts note that the reduction, ranging from no cut by Nigeria and Iraq to 14.3 percent by Kuwait, will be difficult to enforce, since so many of the nations are already above their quotas. Indeed, most analysts believe that the 1.5-billion-barrel-a-day reduction would simply bring OPEC down to its original production levels, with little effect on prices.

title: UNITED TELECOM GAMBLES ON FIBER OPTICS
description: WESTWOOD, Kan.

title: CRIME
description: The eighth in the Lovejoy series of Jonathan Gash - it started in 1977 with ''The Judas Pair'' - is FIREFLY GADROON (St. Martin's, $11.95). Lovejoy is an antiques dealer, a genius in his way, and also a thoroughly unscrupulous operator. Call him the Jacques Villon of the antiques world. ''Firefly Gadroon'' is less baroque in plot than some of its immediate predecessors. Indeed, it is downright orthodox. One of Lovejoy's friends, an old and great silversmith who was teaching him how to make a reverse gadroon, is murdered. Lovejoy knows who was responsible and takes revenge into his own hands.

GARDENING;
HOW TO KEEP HOUSE PLANTSHEALTHY
description: ABOUT this time of year house plant problems begin to appear, especially with those plants that were furloughed outdoors for the summer. The causes of these problems merit attention if the plants are to survive and flourish.

title: TOUR OF CITY PROVIDES INSIGHTS ON URBAN RENEWAL
description: An 85-mile tour of 22 New York City neighborhoods provided glimpses of efforts to restore blighted communities for a group of visitors engaged in financing urban renewal in other cities.

title: A VILLAGE SQUARE
description: The village square, long a symbol of the marketplace in small-town America, is being replicated in a new shopping and office mall now in the last stage of construction in Middlesex Township, N.J. A clock tower, fountain and benches will complete the traditional motif of Towne Center at Hidden Lake, as it will be called.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
TIME TO GET TOUGHER ON WRITING
description: COLLEGE English teachers, like their colleagues in other disciplines, are given to complaining about being faced with roomfuls of students who can't write very well and who are waiting for us to show them the road to literacy. But teaching these youngsters is not the problem - it's our job. The problem is teaching those who can't write very well but don't know it.

title: AMERICAN JEWS REDISCOVER ORTHODOXY
description: When Natalie Gittelson speaks of Orthodoxy's ''no- compromise mentality,'' she misses the point.

title: TEACHER LEAVES MARK BEFORE AND AFTER DEATH
description: David Higbee spent almost all of his waking hours during the past 25 years teaching and coaching at an elementary school in this suburb of Philadelphia. And, when he knew he was going to die, he added one final contribution - a $200,000 scholarship fund.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES;
description: The Republican Party, bidding to assure a friendly Congress in a hoped-for second Reagan Administration, has raised $225.4 million in the past 22 months, Federal Election Commission figures showed today.

title:
ART;
THOUGHT-DIRECTING IMAGES
description: BABS KENT paints rather evocative abstract images that look like stringy unraveling masses floating through space. What seems significant is the way the work directs our thoughts toward the ''substance'' of things, and makes us wonder if indeed we are not dealing with some allegorical reference to all worldly matter.

title: S. CAROLINA RALLIES TO STAY UNBEATEN
description: Thomas Dendy ran for two touchdowns, including a 6-yarder with 50 seconds to play, to help South Carolina (8-0) escape with a 35-28 victory over North Carolina State today.

title: AMERICAN JEWS REDISCOVER ORTHODOXY
description: No one who is concerned for the meaningful survival of Judaism can be anything but happy about the new surge of strength in American Orthdox Judaism, especially when it means Torah (study) and Mitzvot (deeds in harmony with the will of God). The burgeoning success of Orthodoxy was, on the whole, very well reported by Natalie Gittelson.

title: SALVADOR REBEL CHIEF SEES SLOW PROGRESS IN TALKS
description: A Salvadoran rebel leader said this week that peace talks held in the town of La Palma last month represented the best prospect for ending the civil war in El Salvador since it began more than four years ago. But the leader, Ruben Zamora, said he did not expect any quick breakthroughs.

title: Dr. Michael Ira Cohen To Wed Amy B. Kates
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Kates of Great Neck, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Amy Beth Kates to Dr. Michael Ira Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cohen of Brooklyn.

title: Election Agency Told To Act on Complaint
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Federal Election Commission to act within 30 days on a Democratic Congressman's two-year-old complaint against two conservative North Carolina political groups linked to Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican.

title: THE PUZZLE OF CHILD ACTORS
description: Hunter Carson has a cat named Einstein. ''Do you know why I call him Einstein?'' asks the 8-year-old boy, his sleepy blue eyes opening just slightly. ''Because he's very dumb,'' he answers, slapping the table, delighted with his cleverness.

description: Health officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say there is a growing awareness of the need to come to grips with the profound moral, ethical and legal considerations involved in life-and-death decisions affecting patients.

title: Convict Rights
description: A Missouri convict serving 23 years for rape and kidnapping sued the state, charging that its director of prisons and two subordinates had violated his civil rights in the state penitentiary by beating him in 1980, when the director was warden. In May, a Federal District Court jury awarded $90,000 in damages to the inmate, Ronald Parton.

description: HAVING successfully curbed the abuse of infant formula in underdeveloped countries, some medical professionals are now trying to slow its use here as well, and Dr. Roy Brown, a Paterson pediatrician, is in the forefront of a campaign that will begin this week in New York City.

'I can't go anywhere and talk about food wthout being asked 'How many calories is that?' or 'How much salt is in that?'' says the vice president of marketing at the Campbell Soup Company. 'This has become a way of life and a way of thinking among consumers.'

Voters there, and in a handful of other communities around the country, will cast Presidential ballots electronically, pressing buttons on what amounts to a souped-up personal computer.

title: DROUGHT SPREADS DEATH ACROSS AFRICA
description: In at least three countries of Africa, men, women and children are dying of hunger. In many others, malnutrition is widespread, and the threat of famine looms. And in other countries of the continent, drought has made grossly insufficient harvests a certainty.

Belanger, who also intercepted a Passaic pass in the end zone in the third quarter, booted a 32-yard field goal for a 3-0 lead in the first period. Mike Henry threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to John Hanle in the second quarter and Belanger ran 24 yards to a touchdown in the last period.

title: Sound and Silence In Film
description: While Walter Kerr sees rightly that the movies rarely convey emotional nuance through visuals these days, the procedures of broad visual storytelling are by no means lost (''In Praise of Silence in Film,'' Sept. 30). Stanley Kubrick's 1971 film ''A Clockwork Orange'' requires only its two musical cues (''Ode to Joy'' and ''Singin' in the Rain'') to be completely understood; the dialogue is an overlay for a purely visual tale.

He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PLANNING FOR FINANCIAL AID IN OLD AGE
description: Growing old. The onset of senility. And before long, the courts appoint someone to handle an elderly person's finances. Indeed, with growing frequency the old are losing control of their assets and estates to strangers because they do not plan ahead. Moreover, demographic trends indicate that record numbers of elderly people will need to have their finances managed for them in the coming years.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: ''Winter: Love It or Leave It,'' the second volume of The Sophisticated Traveler Series, has been published by Villard Books.

title: Wendi Weill To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Wendi Fern Weill to Matthew Ian Seiden has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Weill of Westfield, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hank Seiden of New York.

title: MARINO: SO GOOD SO SOON
description: HE is not afraid to fail. That trait is what Dan Marino's father is proudest of in his son, the wunderkind quarterback of the Miami Dolphins.

title: A YOUNG CHEF'S 3-STAR IMAGINATION
description: WHEN it comes to Le Coq Hardi, getting older means getting better. This small, sophisticated country French restaurant in Ridgefield opened two years ago to three-star acclaim. But when its chef left, anxious patrons wondered what would happen next.

title: NEW YORK VOTING FOR LEGISLATURE
description: All 211 seats in the New York Legislature will be filled in Tuesday's election, but serious contests have developed for only about 30 of the seats.

title: NEW GLIMPSES INTO THE PAST
description: Michael Norman is a reporter on the Metropolitan staff of The Times. We are flying north in the early morning haze, going upriver to Albany in search of the past. Manhattan's past. We need to know the past to know the present; but, in the way of all voyeurs, we are also simply curious. We crave details - the daily scandals and disappointments, the quarrels over land and love, the petty, the ordinary, the source, unalloyed and accessible. You see, we are looking for patterns, links, the long, reassuring nexus.

title: WHERE REAGAN AND MONDALE STAND ON KEY ISSUES Ronald Reagan FOREIGN AFFAIRS Arms Control
description: Opposes a nuclear freeze as unverifiable and likely to undercut incentives for Soviet Union to negotiate arms reductions. Supports a continuing military buildup to permit United States to negotiate from position of strength. In strategic arms limitation talks, would reduce number and capaciy of ballistic missile warheads and restrict bombers and cruise missiles to levels below those of SALT II. Favors a comprehensive, verifiable worldwide ban on chemical weapons, but in its absence would build up chemical weapons arsenal. Space WeaponsHas begun a ''strategic defense initiative'' to develop a defense against ballistic missiles. Proposes sharing the technology with the Soviet Union. Military Spending

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on traveling by ferry from Vancouver Island to Alaska (''Along the Gold Rush Trail,'' Oct. 21), the starting point of the boat trip was misstated. The ferry departs from Port Hardy, on the northern tip of the island.

title: HOSPITAL PANELS CONSIDER KEY ETHICS ISSUES
description: Quietly and without fanfare, hundreds of American hospitals are organizing internal ethics committees that are coming to play crucial roles in life- and-death decisions for thousands of patients.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
TIMELESS VERMONT TOYS
description: Though applauded for its ski slopes, maple syrup, Cheddar cheese and fall foliage, Vermont has never received equally widespread fame for its toy manufacturers. Yet in the Green Mountain hamlet of Montgomery, six miles from the Canadian border in the heart of Vermont's hard maple, white ash and yellow birch woodlands, hundreds of thousands of well-designed wood toys are made each year.

title: Miss Mix to Wed Scott C. Newquist
description: Announcement has been made by Mary Ellen Mix of Bedminster, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and Earl B. Mix Jr. of Basking Ridge, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Aileen Katherine Mix, to Scott Crawford Newquist, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester J. Newquist of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: STILL LIFE WITH SHOVEL
description: Le Anne Schreiber, former deputy editor of The New York Times Book Review, lives and writes in upstate New York. DIGS

title: EATING ROUND THE CLOCK
description: Of all the all-night spots in Manhattan, the most unfailingly democratic are the three Market Diners, all just a short spin from the Hudson River and its tunnels. They are stainless steel anachronisms you would expect to see on Route 66, with wraparound parking lots, gum-snapping waitresses and single-digit meals right our of the prewar years. All night long, everyone from bone-weary cabbies to exuberant young punkers and fashionably preened partygoers stop by for a jolt of 40-weight java and a wedge of glutinous pie. The good-natured if jaded staff probably would not look up from their check pads if Queen Elizabeth II slid into a booth and ordered a B.L.T. 'Whole wheat, rye or white, ma'am?'

title: BECKMANN REMEMBEREDZ
description: WHILE we have been lamenting the fact that the Max Beckmann retrospective exhibition on view through Nov. 4 at the St. Louis Museum will not be seen in New York City, we should be aware that the 100th anniversary of his birth will not go uncommemorated on the Island. The small but broad survey of his paintings and graphics on display at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor offers at least a taste - more satisfying than a banquet of many other artists' work - of the achievement of this giant among 20th-century painters.

title: CLAM CHOWDERS
description: OVER THE years, we have often been asked about the origin of the word chowder, which has a distinctly American ring. Surprisingly enough, the word is believed to be of French origin. It is said to derive from the French word for cauldron,

title: THE MOOD HAS CHANGED: ALONG WITH MUCH ELSE
description: WASHINGTON THE

title: Kim Susan Hirsh Betrothed
description: The engagement of Kim Susan Hirsh to Mark Widmann, a medical student at Yale University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hirsh of Springfield, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Warren Widmann of Morristown, N.J. A March wedding is planned. Miss Hirsh graduated from the Newark Academy and Brown University. Mr. Widmann is an alumnus of the academy and Duke University.

title: No Headline
description: With effective offense in the first quarter and strong defense in the last, Akeem Olajuwon and Ralph Sampson of the Rockets proved too intimidating for the Knicks tonight.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Antiques View column on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect date for an auction of Galle glass designs at Christie's in Geneva. It is next Sunday.

title: DANCE: STREICHER TROUPE
description: Perhaps Robert Streicher has missed his calling. He thinks of himself as a dancer and choreographer but he is really a stage director at heart.

title: OF ONE BLOOD, TWO MEN
description: BROTHERS AND KEEPERS

title: FINDING LOWER-INCOME HOUSING 'NEED' IN NEW JERSEY
description: AN arcane numbers game is emerging in

title: AIRPORT IN DENVER UNDERGOES GROWING PAINS
description: When Stapleton International Airport opened as Denver Municipal Airport 55 years ago, it was out in the sticks.

title: JERSEY OFFICIALS CALL CHEATING RARE IN CASINOS
description: Despite the discovery of a purported $580,000 swindle using marked cards, New Jersey gambling authorities said this week that they believed cheating in Atlantic City casinos to be rare.

title: STERN OF ABANDONED TANKER SINKS OFF COAST OF CALIFORNIA
description: An abandoned oil tanker, heavily damaged by fire and a series of explosions three days ago, broke in two about 25 miles off the coast of California today, with one section sinking and the other still afloat amid two giant oil slicks.

title: VOLUNTEERS HELP YOUTHS FIGHT LONELINESS IN RIKERS JAIL
description: Carl Ebanks has spent most of his life in institutions. He is 17 years old, and when he recently spent eight months at a Rikers Island jail, not a single visitor crossed the narrow bridge from Astoria, Queens, to see him.

title: Thatcher Assails Sikh For British Broadcast
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher condemned the Sikh separatist movement today and said her Government had wanted to prosecute its leader in Britain.

title: American Jews Rediscover Orthodoxy
description: Natalie Gittelson effectively makes the case for Jewish Orthodoxy, quoting many ''exhilarated'' Orthodox Jews as testimony (''American Jews Rediscover Orthodoxy,'' Sept. 30).

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
MUSINGS AT THE OCEAN'S EDGE
description: MOVING, moving, the ocean has much to teach me. Stretching and stretching, spreading itself worldwide, it sprawls to reach my toes, covering all of them without discrimination.

title: Anne Woodward And J. F. Boucher AWiR
description: Anne Cary Woodward, a corporate lending officer for the North American division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Freeman Boucher, an associate at the Jordan Company, an investment partnership in New York. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: Hearing Aid Dealers' Slogan Is Judged to Be Misleading
description: A Government board has canceled the trademark of the National Hearing Aid Society, a group of hearing aid dealers, ruling that it was deceptive for the members to call themselves ''Certified Hearing Aid Audiologists.''

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 FOR A SONG
description: With some 300 songs ''on the shelf'' and only one, ''It's Honeymooner Time,'' recorded and selling, to the tune of 4,000 copies, Jesse Goldberg of Syosset, a lawyer who would rather be a songwriter, has his sights set on tonight's Songwriting Contest sponsored by the Babylon Citizens Council on the Arts. He won last year's event with ''Legends in Their Own Rhymes'' (it's back on the shelf) and he hopes that the judges will be favorably disposed toward his current entries. Mr. Goldberg and other finalists (there were more than 35 songs submitted) will perform their works at 8 P.M. at the Lindenhurst Junior High School on Wellwood Avenue. Spectators can pay $3, or $2 for the elderly, to find out who walks off with the five cash prizes. IN FULL COLOR

title: BOSTON UNIVERSITY STOPS HOLY CROSS
description: The tailback Paul Lewis ran for 145 yards and a touchdown to help Boston University deal Holy Cross (7-1) its first loss in 18 regular-season Division I-AA games today, 16-12.

title: TOPICS
description: I sit alone a lot these evenings, in a room illuminated by an electrified kerosene lamp that belonged to my grandmother. Sometimes I knit or sew, but mostly I write about the good old days when I was growing up. The days when I spent my lunch hour listening to Helen Trent and Our Gal Sunday on the radio while my mother prepared a hot lunch for me. The days before fast-food chains, shopping malls, giant flea markets. The days before cable television.

title: SHERRILL HASN'T ENDED THE AGGIE JOKES
description: GIVEN the circumstances, there really wasn't much that Jackie Sherrill said he could have done differently. He was the cover boy of college football coaches in 1982, one of the best and the brightest, the one Texas A&M had enticed from the University of Pittsburgh at great expense to help it achieve its manifest destiny on the football field.

title: WHAT THE HOLES MEAN
description: The condition of a stamp or other philatelic item, is perhaps the most important factor affecting its desirability. But there are so many exceptions to ''philatelic rules.'' One is the belief that stamps should be perfect. This has led to a whole area of collecting: that is ''perfins'' stamps with perforated initials punched in them.

title: NATURE CONTINUES MT. ST. HELENS COMEBACK
description: Nature is engaged in a remarkable comeback from the 1980 volcanic eruption of Mount St. Helens here.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A COUNTRY THANKSGIVING
description: SERGEANTSVILLE FOR THE last 11 years, this picturesque Hunterdon County community has thrown open historic and more-modern doors for a weekend ''elegant house tour'' to celebrate ''Thanksgiving in the Country.''

title: Lucie Curtiss Becomes the Bride of Gordon Hard
description: Lucie E. Curtiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Curtiss 2d of Sheffield, Mass., was married yesterday to Gordon Hard, a son of Mrs. William Hard Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Hard. Canon Robert S. S. Whitman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Blantyre, an inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: CITY TORN BY RIOTS LOOKS AT PLAN TO CONVERT PLANT
description: In the aftermath of three days of rioting this summer in a Hispanic part of this town, a plan to open a high-technology plant here is being hailed by company and government officials as a solution to economic and social problems.

title: Political Wing of I.R.A. Holds Meeting in Dublin
description: Leaders of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, Sinn Fein, assembled in Dublin under heavy security today for their annual two-day convention.

title: Suspect in 2 Break-Ins At Abrams Home Held
description: A man accused of robbing the summer home of State Attorney General Robert Abrams twice last week was arrested on Thursday and is being held in the Dutchess County jail, the state police said yesterday.

title: A BANNER YEAR FOR ENLISTMENTS
description: Hard times prompt job-hungry young people to volunteer for the military; in good times, when nonmilitary work is presumably plentiful, more are inclined to remain civilians. Such has been the pattern since the demise of the draft in 1973.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Movement Research, Inc. describes itself simply as ''dedicated to serving the dance community in the New York City environs.'' Its work is largely behind the scenes and hard to define, but its programs are at least informative and sometimes controversial. Sunday night, for instance, Jane Comfort and Ishmael Houston-Jones, two noted dance experimentalists, will participate in the Studies Project, a continuing discussion- performance series at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center.

title: DR. CLARK LECTURES ON RACE RELATIONS
description: THE class is Sociology 125 at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, entitled ''Perspectives in American Culture.'' The 33 students are predominantly foreign, with a sprinkling of Americans. They are studying this country, its culture and its institutions through readings and a series of lectures given by Mercy College faculty members and outside speakers. The subjects include religion and American culture, the poor and homeless in America and the contributions of various ethnic groups.

title: ISRAELIS ARREST SOLDIER, 18, IN ROCKET ATTACK ON BUS
description: The police said today that they had arrested an 18- year-old soldier from a crack army unit on suspicion of firing a rocket at an Arab bus in Jerusalem last week.

title: Barbara R. Biben Becomes a Bride
description: Nathan S. Ancell, chairman and chief executive officer of the Ethan Allen furniture company, and Barbara Rubinstein Biben, director of public service for the Gannett Rochester Newspapers, were married yesterday at the Waldorf Astoria. Rabbi Stanley Schacter officiated.

title: 24-Hour Trading
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Hayes Bride Of Dr. S. C. Updegrov e
description: Kathleen M. Hayes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hayes of Port Washington, L.I., and Dr. Stephen C. Updegrove, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Updegrove of Easton, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Sandercock performed the Protestant ceremony in the Dwight Chapel at Yale University.

title: POLY PREP STREAK ENDED AT 16 GAMES
description: Phil Foglietta, the Poly Prep coach, had an open date on the schedule for yesterday, so 10 days ago he contacted Susan Wagner, a Public Schools Athletic League team on Staten Island, to fill the gap. Wagner said it would play Poly if it lost to Curtis last Saturday.

title: UNITED STORIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunisia
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE LOOPHOLES DISTORT INCENTIVES
description: Why is the Federal Government racking up record budget deficits while most Americans believe - and rightly so - that they are paying more in taxes than ever before?

title: OBSTACLE COURSE FOR THE AGED
description: David Haward Bain is the author of ''Sitting in Darkness'' and ''Aftershocks,'' about the postwar traumas of a Vietnamese refugee family and an American veteran, KATE QUINTON'S DAYS

title: Renee Petrofes Weds Gerald McNamara Jr.
description: Renee K. Petrofes and Gerald C. McNamara Jr., both associates in the security sales department at Goldman, Sachs & Company, were married yesterday at the Metropolitan Club. The Rev. Peter Jenkins, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW ACT RESTRICTS ATOMIC TEST SUITS
description: A measure that slipped through Congress virtually unnoticed in September apparently makes it impossible for veterans and their relatives to win lawsuits seeking compensation for cancers allegedly caused by atomic weapon tests.

title: AMERICAN JEWS REDISCOVER ORTHODOXY
description: Women are half the moving force behind the re-emergence of Orthodox Judaism, but only three were mentioned in an article about more than a dozen men. Natalie Gittelson seems to imply that ''Jew'' equals ''Jewish man'' and ''Jewish woman'' signifies ''Jewish wife.''

title: REAGAN BEATS THE PRESS
description: WASHINGTON Among the losers in this Presidential election campaign you will

title:
DINING OUT;
RUSTIC CHARM IN SPRING VALLEY
description: TUCKED among wooded acres beside a duck pond, La Capannina is full of rustic charm. Reflecting its surroundings, this 18th-century farmhouse has an unpretentious, comfortable air. Next to the bar, a tray bearing a side of smoked salmon marks the entrance to the dining room lined in dark rough wood. Red curtains and table skirts add a cheery note. The food is decent without being fussy, its heartiness providing a good foil for the cellar's fine stock of wine.

title: HOW CAN FUTURE DEBATES BE IMPROVED?
description: The Presidential and Vice Presidential debates are behind us; the election is almost here. What part the debates play in Tuesday's voting will never be fully established, even though they seem to have been the climactic events of the political year. In their wakes, meanwhile, each of the debates left smaller debates: Why did Ronald Reagan do so poorly in his first encounter with Walter F. Mondale? Was George Bush a chauvinist when he met Geraldine Ferraro? How could Mr. Reagan have won his second debate if all that he did was to tie? These were not great questions, in part because the debates did not have great formats. In theory, the candidates used the debates to crystallize their positions; in fact, few positions emerged.

title: AUTHOR TELLS TALES OF STATE'S PAST
description: THE Dark Lady of New Gate, one of Connecticut's hundreds of legends, was supposed to have helped a prisoner escape. It now seems likely the only person she helped out of a jam was the jailer.

title: Doug Williams Balks
description: The Oklahoma Outlaws and the Arizona Wranglers have all but completed their merger, and the only remaining hurdle is to decide which players will remain with the merged team in Phoenix and which will be put in a pool for disbursement to other United States Football League teams. One player involved said that could prove to be an expensive hurdle.

title: INIDA'S INSIDE THREAT
description: The assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi by Sikh members of her own security entourage dramatically symbolizes that the real threat to Indian democracy and security lies not from outside India's borders, as Mrs. Gandhi often claimed, but from within - from the innumerable divisions created by caste, language, religion and regional faction.

title: Some Still Suffer From '81 Strike
description: DURING the players' strike in 1981, Ray Grebey, the owners' chief labor negotiator, would appear at news conferences following bargaining sessions and recite what became, to his listeners, a comical refrain. Referring to the number of players he thought would be affected by the owners' proposal for free- agent compensation, Grebey would say, ''We now have a strike for the negotiating rights of eight players.'' Or seven players or four players, whatever the count happened to be that particular day. The whole time, of course, Grebey ignored the domino effect the plan could have on the rest of the players.

title: AAT CIGARETTE STAND, INDIAN VS. TAX LAW
description: ALL his life, Jonathan Smith has dreamed of owning a business. A Shinnecock Indian, he has sought to preserve the right of self-determination that he says is very much a part of the tradition of his people. Owning and operating a business, he thought, would be a natural extension of that right.

title: Miss Greenberg Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Greenberg of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Faith Greenberg, to Martin J. Pitiger, the son of Mrs. Bernard Pelavin of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Nathan Pitiger.

title:
MEN'S STYLE;
A CROWNING TOUCH
description: I HAVE ALWAYS LIKED HATS, ALways felt undressed without one. During the last two decades, however, my affinity for headgear seemed a decidedly eccentric predilection. As New York's pre-eminent hatter, Burton Berinsky of Jay Lord Hatters, observes: ''Up until five years ago, almost nobody wore hats. There were some exceptions, of course. Certain people who went to Yale in 1952 wore them, as did a few diehard traditionalists, but that was about it.''

title: TEACHING YOUTHS 'STREET SMARTS'
description: The best way to keep your children safe in the city, Grace Hechinger says, is to talk to them.

title: RALLY BY RAMIREZ DETHRONES ROSARIO
description: Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico, almost out on his feet in the second round, fought back today to dethrone Edwin Rosario of Puerto Rico and earn the World Boxing Council lightweight title when the referee stopped the fight in the fourth round.

title: Cynthia Coggeshall Is to Marry Dec. 22
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bayard Coggeshall of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Coggeshall to Richard Ten Broeck Trask, a son of Mrs. John Jacquelin Trask of New York and the late Mr. Trask. The wedding is to take place on Dec. 22.

title: Annette E. Quick WedsK.T.Norris
description: Annette Elizabeth Quick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Quick of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Thomas Norris, a son of Cora Wright of Lexington, Ky., and the late Cal Norris. The Rev. John B. Quick, the bride's uncle, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel, assisted by the Rev. George White.

title: TRUFFAUT: THE MAN WAS REVEALED THROUGH HIS ART
description: In ''Bed and Board'' (''Domicile Conjugal,'' 1970), Francois Truffaut's third feature in his extraordinary series of semiautobiographical comedies about the life and times of Antine Doinel, there's a funny and rather nasty moment when Antoine (Jean-Pierre Leaud) turns on his wife, Christine (Claude Jade), who has been gently suggesting that they get a telephone. When bored, Christine explains, they could always ring up their friends.

title: Recession Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE THAN CANDIDATES ARE ON THE BALLOT
description: VOTERS will have not only a choice of Presidential, Congressional and county-office candidates on Tuesday, but also will be able to say ''Yes'' or ''No'' to six referendum questions, including authorizing $150 million in additional spending.

title: PROMISES, PROMISES
description: IN GROPING FOR

title: A MOTHER INTRODUCES THE CITY
description: Joyce Maynard is the author of the novel ''Baby Love.''

title: A NEW ERA OPENS FOR CAMP SMITH
description: NATIONAL Guard Staff Sergeant Juan Cosme gazed into the darkness and it was impenetrable. Coming from somewhere off in the distance, however, was the sound of rumbling machinery and clanking metal.

title: STAGE: YALE REP OFFERS 'HENRY IV, PART ONE'
description: The Yale Repertory Theater serves two principal, complementary purposes. As the producer of such plays as August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' and works by Athol Fugard, the company is one of our major regional theaters. At the same time it is an affiliate of the Yale Graduate School of Drama. As directed by Lloyd Richards, each institution nurtures the other; students have an opportunity to observe and to take part in productions in various capacities as actors and designers.

title: SUBURB OF DETROIT EYES NAME CHANGE
description: Residents of this Detroit suburb will decide Tuesday whether to change its name to Erin Heights. Proponents of the move say it will improve the city's civic image and property values by differentiating it from Detroit. The Motor City, they say, is known for its slums and crime.

title:
DANCE VIEW;
GARCIA LORCA INSPIRED A VIVID DANCE SPECTACLE
description: One way of keeping up with the international dance scene - armchair-travel style - is to tune in on cable television's Arts & Entertainment Network. Also known to some as Hearst/ ABC-RCTV, it has often provided the first public airing in the United States of dance programs and productions filmed abroad. These have ranged from several full-length works with Britain's Royal Ballet to Pina Bausch's ''Rite of Spring,'' which was telecast here a few years before Miss Bausch's company from West Germany made its controversial debut here last summer. There have also been American dance programs produced in association with the Hearst/ABC group in the past. Two premieres, ''Moses Pendleton Presents Moses Pendleton'' and ''Swan Lake, Minnesota'' were reviewed at length in this column and were among the most interesting dance programs seen anywhere on television.

title: LETTERS
description: -OP BIAS RULING PROVOKES IRONY

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TOKYO
description: CLYDE HABERMAN is the Tokyo bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: Engineers Free Stuck Bridge
description: The Army Corps of Engineers raised a stuck railroad bridge Friday and allowed 19 ships stranded for two days to pass through the Soo Locks, officials said. The bridge jammed Wednesday night, forcing ships passing between Lakes Superior and Huron to wait and trains to be rerouted. The Corps estimated the cost of the delay to be $1,115,000.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1984 Indira Gandhi's body was cremated in New Delhi in a traditional Hindu funeral ceremony witnessed by tens of thousands of people, including nearly 100 foreign leaders and dignitaries. Rajiv Gandhi, Mrs. Gandhi's 40-year-old son and her successor as Prime Minister of India, lit the cremation pyre, bringing to a symbolic end the drama that began when his mother was shot to death Wednesday by two men identified as Sikh members of her bodyguard. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: KREMLIN LETS FACTORIES REACH OUT TO THE EAST BLOC
description: The Soviet Union, in a move aimed at closer economic contacts with its allies, has authorized factories to establish ''direct links'' with their counterparts in other Communist countries.

title: TUNISIA
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. EXAMINES ROOTS OF THE FOOD CRISIS IN AFRICA
description: The General Assembly has begun a debate that seeks to look beyond the food crisis in Africa, with emphasis on the economic and social problems that have contributed to the situation.

title:
DINING OUT;
ENTICING THE PALATE IN HOBOKEN
description: A DECADE ago, it would have been impossible to find a restaurant that served quail- stuffed fois gras or even fresh asparagus out of season. Now, however, thanks to the many innovative chefs who have chosen to open restaurants in New Jersey, we are becoming used to ordering wonders such as these.

title: PRIEST'S MURDER DRAWS POLES TOGETHER
description: The murder of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko has linked Poland's three often contentious elements - the Roman Catholic Church, the Solidarity movement and the Government - in a frail tactical alliance.

title: MAD FOR MANHATTAN
description: qsf9952wqcc17.6,5,8.5,10wqif.8wqef

title: GIRL BEATS RULE TO JOIN BOYS' TEAM
description: WHEN Angie Gibbons moved to Clinton from Kingsport, Tenn., with her family in July, she left behind both a host of friends and a starting berth on the high school girls' varsity soccer team, which she had led in scoring as a freshman last season.

title: LOVE'S MAGIC SPELL IS IN TROUBLE
description: Poor Sidney Pollack. Poor Robert Redford. Not too long ago I read in the daily newspapers that Mr. Pollack, the film director, and Mr. Redford, the film actor, would very much like to do a picture together. Not just any old picture. A romantic picture, a love story. The only thing that's been holding them up is the fact that you can't do a love story today. As Mr. Pollack has pointed out, there's no longer any obstacle, any barrier, any impediment or social taboo for the lovers to overcome. Except incest. And if there's nothing to prevent passion from having all its rites

title: Sp"atzle
description: To the Editor: Many thanks for your illuminating article on sp"atzle (Travel, Sept. 23). I have sent it on with red-penciled underlines and comments to my brother.

title: STUDENTS-CONSERVATIVE, FERAFUL
description: Republican analysts say young voters are leaning toward President Reagan because they believe the nation is heading in the ''right'' rather than the ''wrong'' direction. Mr. Reagan's pollster, Richard Wirthlin, thinks today's youth ''have not had disillusioning events in their lives.'' None of this rings true to me.

title: U.S. Seeks to Protect Woodpecker on Oil Site
description: The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service has gone to court to protect the endangered red-cockaded woodpecker on a wildlife refuge where a petroleum company intends to begin drilling natural gas wells next week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We bid farewell to you solemnly and with dignity and hope for a just social peace in our country.

title: FORAYS FOR FUNGI BRING MUSHROOM FANS TOGETHER
description: S COTT STOLESON of Trumbull is one of almost 300 state residents who get together a few times each year for one reason - the love of mushrooms.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO KEEP HOUSE PLANTSHEALTHY
description: ABOUT this time of year house plant problems begin to appear, especially with those plants that were furloughed outdoors for the summer. The causes of these problems merit attention if the plants are to survive and flourish.

title: DAY-CARE OPTIONS EXPLORED
description: CORPORATE and county government representatives gathered at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown last week to discuss options for day care during a conference that offered both a national and a local perspective on the issue.

title: SOME HINDUS PROTECTED SIKHS
description: Indian news reports today told of instances in which Hindus protected or hid Sikhs from homicidal mobs that began attacking Sikhs in the aftermath of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's assassination.

title: GUARDIAN ANGELS HELD IN PROTEST PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 3 (AP) - Curtis Sliwa, founder of the Guardian Angels, was arrested today with five fellow demonstrators protesting the treatment of some homeless people by Rajneeshpuram, a city-commune led by a guru.
description: The six protesters, all members of the crime-fighting group, were arrested on trespassing charges after they handcuffed themselves to the entrance of the Hotel Rajneesh here and refused to leave despite warnings from the hotel manager and the police.

title: DANCE: FOLKLORICO FILIPINO
description: There have been gaudier and more lavish folk-dance performances in New York. But there have been few with the charming simplicity and freshness of the program by Folklorico Filipino on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, where the company is performing through tonight.

title: Melissa Jan Kahn Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kahn of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Jan Kahn, to Michael Feinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Feinstein of Syosset, L.I. Miss Kahn, a lawyer with Skadden, Arps, Slater, Meagher & Flom in New York, graduated from Cornell University and the Georgetown University Law Center. Her fiance, an alumnus of Duke University, is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University.

title: SQUATTERS RECEIVE LONG-SOUGHT LAND
description: Dozens of squatters who illegally built homes on Federal land years ago in this onetime silver boomtown have settled a 27-year squabble with the Government. They can stay here and own their land.

title: A SMART LAY-AWAY PLAN
description: HERE TODAY, GONE tomorrow. Such is the fickleness of fashion. Flat shoes are a case in point. Several years ago, they were impossible to find.

title: WIGHTMAN CUP TO U.S.
description: Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Jo Durie today, 7-6, 6-1, and clinched the United States' sixth straight triumph over Britain in the Wightman Cup women's tennis series.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: UTOPIA IN THE OUTER BOROUGHS
description: Paul Goldberger is the Pulitzer Prize- winning architecture critic of The New York Times.

title: WHAT THE PSYCHIATRIST SAW
description: Central Park South was frozen still at 4 degrees on Christmas morning last year as a Yale psychiatrist named Seymour Handler walked out of the St. Moritz Hotel into the blinding sunlight. He squinted up and down the avenue. Nothing was moving but steam from the manholes, a couple of masked madmen in blue Nikes, and a woman in furs leading a Schnauzer in a red sweater that said ''Noel.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: the Night of the Broken Glass - was the Nov. 9, 1938, night in Germany when the Nazis began their systematic campaign to terrorize the Jews with the breaking of windows in synagogues and shops throughout the country.

title: EAT, DRINK, AND BE MERRY
description: Nora Ephron recently completed a screenplay of her novel, ''Heartburn.''

title: GRANTS TO BENEFIT TRANSIT IN JERSEY
description: The award of $135 million in Federal grants for public-transit improvements in New Jersey was announced this week.

title: FERRARO SAYS SHE SENSES SURPRISE VOTE BY WOMEN
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro says she senses that a hidden vote, by women who are not telling their husbands, their friends or poll takers that they intend to vote for her, will emerge on Election Day.

title: PLANS FOR RALLIES SHOW DIFFERENT CAMPAIGN STYLES
description: At lunchtime Wednesday, office workers taking the sun on City Hall Plaza paused to gawk as the carefully constructed rally that was to greet President Reagan at noon the next day began to take shape.

title: CONERT TO MARK BIRTHDAY OF NEW ROCHELLE COMPOSER
description: WHAT better birthday present can a composer have than a program of her music? ''None,'' says New Rochelle's Ruth Schonthal, whose 60th birthday is being marked this evening at 8 o'clock with a special concert at the Westchester Conservatory of Music in White Plains. ''It's a very exciting occasion, and I'm really looking forward to it.''

title: PANELS TO EXPLORE SOCIALIST LEGACY
description: PRINCETON WHILE pollsters and prophets look to the effects of Tuesday's election, a major conference at Princeton University this week will focus on the politics of another era: the impact of the Socialist Party and Norman Thomas, its leading figure from 1928 until his death in 1968.

title: Lebanese Druse Chief Voices Suspicion of National Army
description: Walid Jumblat, the Lebanese Druse leader, says that in the event of an Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon, several conditions will have to be met before he would agree to the deployment of Lebanese Army soldiers in the vacated area.

title: GRESCHNER INJURED IN RANGER VICTORY
description: Their great defenseman was back doing great things like diving in front of a vacant net to prevent a goal, and driving back the opposition with emphatic checks. But Barry Beck alone could not prevent the Rangers' game against the Penguins tonight from becoming one haphazard offensive spree after another.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''I Pagliacci,'' Ruggero Leoncavallo's musical tale of a clown with a broken heart, will come to television Friday night at 9 as part of the ''Great Performances'' series on Channel 13. Franco Zeffirelli, who directed this production for Teatro alla Scala in Milan, has updated the action to Depression- era Southern Italy.

title: CANDIDATES FOCUS ON CLOSEST STATES IN FINAL WEEKEND
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale hopscotched through some of the more closely contested states yesterday as Mr. Mondale struggled to cut into the strong overall lead that Mr. Reagan appeared to hold three days before the election.

title: GREBSTEIN ASSESES CHANGES AT COLLEGE
description: IN 1982, a year after Sheldon N.

title: OF CARS, WOODCHUCKS AND BEING BELLOW'S BOSWELL
description: Mark Harris, the author of ''Saul Bellow: Drumlin Woodchuck,'' teaches English at Arizona State University. His latest novel is ''Lying in Bed.'' LOVE those pink slips in my box telling me someone's been seeking me. So-and-so Telephoned - and then the options: Wants To See You, Please Call, Will Call Again, Urgent. I do as I'm asked, open to possibilities. Make an offer, that's my motto. I don't want people to think I'm aloof.

title: Walesa Offers Condolences
description: Lech Walesa visited the Indian Embassy today to offer condolences over the assassination of Indira Gandhi. The Nobel Peace Prize winner wrote in the embassy's condolence book, ''Deeply startled by the barbaric act of terror, in feeling of real brotherhood and solidarity, I join with the nation of Mahatma Gandhi and pray for peace and unity in your country.''

title: School Weapons
description: After the second slaying in six months at Samuel J. Tilden High School in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, officials began meeting in April with students and parents to seek ways of preventing violence. Student possession of knives and guns was reported to be widespread, and 100 students signed a petition asking for a metal detector at the door.

title: THEY MAKE BONES TALK
description: Katherine Bouton writes frequently about archeology. DISCLOSING THE PAST

title:
LEISURE;
DESERT CURIOSITIES ARE FUN TO COLLECT AND GROW AT HOME
description: Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island.

title: DVID BOWIE PONDERS HIS NEWFOUND POPULARITY
description: For a decade now, David Bowie has been a star. His records are played automatically by radio stations and scrutinized by critics, and he has had more than a dozen hit singles. Tour after tour, he has sold out the world's largest auditoriums. In the 1980's, he emerged - for better or worse - as the primary influence on scores of young American and British rock singers, who copied his haircuts, wardrobe, vocal phrasing and air of deeply committed irony. Right now, no doubt, imitations of Mr. Bowie's latest album, ''Tonight,'' are in the works.

title: Katherine Anne McInerney Wed to Hans Morris
description: The marriage of Katherine Anne McInerney, an assistant vice president in the money-market finance division of PaineWebber Inc. in New York, to John Churchill Morris, a second vice president in the public finance division at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert McChesney performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: The Nobel Prize and Dreiser
description: To the Editor:

title: TAMPA FACES BITTER RACE FOR STATE ATTORNEY
description: A popular district attorney whose office is under Federal investigation is facing his first campaign challenge in 16 years from a former prosecutor of organized crime.

title: 9PM TO 5AM
description: Maureen Dowd is a reporter on the Metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

title: AMERICAN CATHOLICS:A TIME FOR CHALLENGE
description: Elaine Sciolino is a reporter for The New York Times. When she FOUND out she was pregnant, the woman was overwhelmed. Separated from her husband and raising her 10-year-old son alone on a Post Office salary, she had no prospects for remarriage and felt she could not support another child. She was Roman Catholic, and she feared God would not forgive her if she had an abortion. Nevertheless, she felt she had no other alternative.

title: PEPSICO BRANCHING
description: Twenty-five miles north of its corporate home in Purchase, N.Y., Pepsico, the soft- drink conglomerate whose products now range from snack foods to sporting goods, is building a new headquarters for its worldwide beverage operations. The building is going up on a 212-acre wooded spread next to the Croton Reservoir in Somers between Interstate 684 and Route 35.

title: ; LETTERS; LESSON FROM THE EMBASSY TAKEOVER IN IRAN
description: To the Editor:

title: ; LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: A WORD ON THE OUTLOOK OF U.N. SITE UNIT

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN LOWER MANHATTAN
description: DURING the business day, 650,000 people work in Lower Manhattan and 100,000 more come as tourists. Billions of dollars change hands in the square mile of granite skyscrapers and narrow streets that is the site of the original New York.

title: GALLE'S GLASS MASTERPIECES COMMAND NEW ATTENTION
description: This may well be the year of Emile Galle, the French Art Nouveau designer whose glass ranks among the finest ever produced. This year, more Americans than ever before viewed the turn-of-the-century innovator's masterpieces. Between late April and late October about 350,000 visitors to the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N. Y., viewed 40 such works in ''Emile Galle: Dreams Into Glass,'' the most select exhibition ever held outside France of Galle's work.

title: BISHOP CRITICIZES MIXING OF CHURCH AND STATE
description: Bishop Paul Moore Jr., the head of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, says that the nation has profited from recent discussion of the role of religion in politics, but that he believes the ''soul of America'' has gone wrong.

title: REGION'S TOP CONGRESEMEN CAN TAKE IT EASY TUESDAY
description: While perhaps a dozen close contests for the House of Representatives in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have drawn attention, most of the region's real Congressional powers seem likely to coast quietly back into office this week. Representatives Peter W. Rodino Jr. of Newark, Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens and a dozen other senior members of the region's delegation are expected to continue to wield influence in Washington. Does their power make re-election all but certain? Or has their popularity in their districts earned them the seniority needed to win power in Congress? ''A mixture of both, I guess,'' Mr. Rangel said. Other politicians and political experts agree, saying that while it is difficult to separate cause and effect, there is little doubt that both create the conditions for Congressional authority. As Democratic chairmen of committees and subcommittees in the Democratically controlled House, power brokers often decide the fate of legislation. They are courted by lobbyists and political action committees eager to contribute even to re- election campaigns that are contests in name only. A chairman's power and resources, including patronage, can scare off potential opponents. Party leaders have even been known to acknowledge - behind the scenes, to be sure - that a committee chairman from an opposing party can do more for a district and its local politicians than a freshman representative from one's own party. Senior representatives are seldom subject to election-day jitters. Mr. Rodino, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, routinely gets 85 percent of the vote. Mr. Rangel, the fourth-ranking member of the Ways and Means Committee, does even better.

title: ST. PATRICK'S SETS THE STAGE FOR CHRISTMAS
description: Anna Quindlen is deputy metropolitan editor of The New York Times. From 1981 to 1983 she wrote the column About New York.

title: ELECTION DRAWS MANY U.S. OBSERVERS
description: A large contingent of invited observers from the United States and other countries is lending an element of credibility to an electoral process that has been criticized here and abroad.

title: A HOME FOR CAMBODIA'S CHILDREN
description: I am a student at Harvard College, and last spring I took a course that dealt with the phenomenon of genocide. People are most familiar with the Holocaust in Nazi Germany, but what happened in Cambodia is no less frightening and appalling.

title: ADAMS ADVANCES OVER CLINTON, 18-6
description: It wasn't as smooth a beginning as he would have liked. But, as Coach Angelo Palumbo told his John Adams team yesterday following their 18-6 quarterfinal victory over DeWitt Clinton, at this point in the season results, not form, are important.

title: THEATER: A REVIVAL OF 'BELLS'
description: Betty Comden and Adolph Green wrote 'Bells Are Ringing' in 1956 as a showcase for their old colleague in The Revuers, Judy Holliday, giving her a role in whichshe could show off her personal facets as a comedienne that had contributed to the success of that memorable short-lived group. In this musical, she was a nettlesome telephone operator at an answering service who becomes anonymously involved in the affairs of the service's clients in ways that put her in situations that might have skits from The Revuers' repertory.

title: Farmer Gets 5 Years In Feud With Hunters
description: George Yant, who chased deer hunters off his farm with a gun a year ago, was sentenced Friday to five years in prison,

title: CONSTRUCTION CURB IN WESTBURY BACKED
description: Construction Curb In Westbury Backed

title: Comings and Goings
description: For the game against the Jets today, the Miami Dolphins have activated Kim Bokamper, their right defensive end who had missed five games with an ankle injury. He is likely to be used on passing situations. . . . Harold Weston Jr., the Madison Square Garden matchmaker, says that he has signed Hector (Macho) Camacho, the undefeated former W.B.C. junior-lightweight champion, to a two-bout contract and that Camacho, idle since May, will fight Juan Ramon Cruz Jan. 19 in Puerto Rico or Montreal. . . . Dave Bergman, the Detroit first baseman who is used primarily for defense, has signed a three-year contract with the Tigers with an option year. No financial terms were announced. . . . Ro berto Bettega, the Italian soccer star who has been playing for the Toronto Blizzard, suffered a broken rib and a fracture near an eyebrow in an auto crash on the Turin-Milan superhighway, and is expected be sidelined two months. . . . Soo Hwan Hong of South Korea, a former world bantamweight champion who has been working as a taxi driver in Anchorage, Alaska, has been charged with multiple counts of selling cocaine.

title: Shakers
description: To the Editor: I was very pleased to see the articles ''Where Shaker Sim

title: MARINERS ROUT COAST GUARD
description: Frank Azzarita threw three touchdown passes and ran for a fourth as the Merchant Marine Academy strengthened its chances of an invitation to the Division III playoffs by stopping the Coast Guard Academy, 41-0, yesterday at Kings Point, L.I. Azzarita, a freshman, completed 6 of 10 passes for 119 yards. Todd Wendorf, who kicked 4 extra points, set a school single-season record with 26. Hofstra 27, Hobart 22 - The undefeated Flying Dutchmen (9-0) continued toward the Division III playoffs as Tom McLaughlin threw a scoring pass and ran for a score. He completed 13 of 21 passes for 181 yards.

title: 'The Story of an Involvement'
description: In the winter of 1976, for reasons he could never fully fathom, Graham Greene received an invitation from Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera to visit Panama. By his own admission, he knew little about Panama and still less about its ruler, but the idea evoked childhood fantasies about the gold-grabbing exploits in the region of Sir Francis Drake and Sir Henry Morgan, and it mobilized the writer's instinct for adventure. He accepted the invitation without hesitation.

title: QUESTIONS IN TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: CIVITAS'S PLAN FOR 96th STREET CORRIDOR
description: ''THE 96th Street corridor, running from the green space of Central Park to the blue space of the river, has too long lain like a divisive ditch athwart the fabric of the community,'' said August Heckscher in releasing a report that recommends a variety of zoning, landscaping and traffic changes for the area.

title: V.A. STAFF BRACES FOR CUTBACK
description: NEWARK THE Veterans Administration regional office here is bracing for budget cuts that will eliminate 19 employees. The cuts, averaging 3 to 6 percent, have been ordered at the national level.

title: Poll in Minnesota Shows A Neck and Neck Race
description: In Minnesota, Walter F. Mondale's home state, two polls published Saturday showed the race was a virtual tossup, with one survey giving a narrow lead to the Democrat and the other a slight edge to President Reagan.

title: Man Charged With 3 Deaths
description: An 18-year-old was arrested today in the shooting deaths of twin 2-year-old boys and their baby sitter. Arnold Ruebke Jr. was charged in the deaths of James and Andrew Vogelsang and their baby sitter, Tammey Mooney, 18, who disappeared from the twins' rural Arlington home Monday, and their bodies were discovered Thursday night in dense brush about 10 miles west of the home.

title: RAJIV GANDHI'S POST SECURE, FOR NOW
description: Although Rajiv Gandhi occupies the center stage of Indian politics today, waiting in the wings are influential politicians, some of whom have made no secret that they covet his position.

title: EGYPTIAN COURT SAYS AUTHORITIES TORTURED SUSPECTS
description: Egypt's Supreme Court has accused the security forces of having tortured more than half of the 281 Moslem fundamentalists whose protracted trial on charges of sedition and murder ended a month ago.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS DONE
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 31 to Nov. 3 with 2,875 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 2,075 indicated they were registered to vote.

title: GIANT DEFENSE STYMIES COWBOYS
description: One week after they upset the Washington Redskins, the Giants upset the Dallas Cowboys, 19-7, today. The victory, with the St. Louis Cardinals' 16-13 loss to the Los Angeles Rams, left the Giants, Cardinals and Cowboys tied for the division lead.

title: Hermann Baumann In French Horn Recital
description: Any evening given over to the French horn - that most dangerous and unpredictable of instruments - is as much an adventure as a musical event. Hermann Baumann, who played at the 92d Street Y Saturday night, minimized our anxieties with his strong technique and made some nice music as well.

title: Gore Disavows Impact Of Corporation Gift
description: Albert Gore Jr. said Saturday that he was still a critic of General Dynamics, even though his Senate campaign accepted a donation from the company political action committee.

title: QUIET REVOLUTION ON THE FARM
description: Wayne Frederick, a burly corn grower in this farm community where Herbert Hoover was born, is in the vanguard of an unsung but growing movement that is changing millenia-old agricultural techniques.

title: INDIANAPOLIS SYMPHONY SETTLES INTO NEW HOME
description: More and more American orchestras are doing it the simple way, and the latest to join the growing band is the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Instead of building its own home, paying $30 million and up, it has taken over an old movie theater, renovated it at cost of just under $7 million, and moved in a few weeks ago, on Oct. 12.

title: Horses' Night Out
description: Today Pasha, Pulaski, Farrell and Shadow are back at their posts, be they in Central Park or central Harlem or even the area around Madison Square Garden. But Saturday night, they were inside the Garden, performing in the New York City Mounted Police Musical Ride at the National Horse Show.

title: Robert Rifkind Wed To Stephanie Barron
description: Stephanie Barron, curator of 20th- century art at the Los Angeles County Museum, and Robert Gore Rifkind, the managing partner of the law firm of Rifkind, Sterling & Levin in New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., were married yesterday. Rabbi Max Vorspan performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Beverly Hills.

title: POP: GIL SCOTT-HERON
description: Words like ''resistance,'' ''jeopardize,'' ''irony'' and ''Constitution'' don't show up too often in pop songs. For more than a decade, however, Gil Scott-Heron has been writing songs about issues that try hard not to oversimplify, and he uses whatever vocabulary he needs.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 5, 1984: MONDAY Baldor ElectricJefferson-PilotBankamerica CorpLockheed CorpCarpenter TechMinn Mng MfgCincinnati BellStone ContainerGeneral Motors

title: Futures ; Liquidity In Farm Options
description: Since the latest batch of options on farm futures were hatched last week on a half-dozen exchanges, many traders and brokers are wondering whether they will soar like the phenomenally successful Treasury bond, stock index and gold options, or fade like sub-index options.

title: Armed Indian Escorts Are Ordered for Trains
description: The railway authorities in India have been ordered to put armed escorts on trains to prevent further violence by mobs who have been attacking passengers.

title: STAGE: 'LOYALTOWN,' BY PETER ROSE
description: Peter Rose grew up in Far Rockaway and he describes his life there in ''Loyaltown, U.S.A.,'' which he presented Saturday night at Performance Space 122. His solo performance combined monologues and dramatically appropriate movement with guitar music by Noah Shapiro and was sometimes witty and at other times gently melancholy in tone.

title: THE USE OF VIDEO CLIPS IN WESTMORELAND TRIAL
description: When the jury in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit against CBS first heard the voice of George Crile in Federal District Court in Manhattan, it wasn't from the witness stand, but from videotape played by the general's attorney.

title: Police Put Trucks at Capitol
description: The Capitol police placed seven heavy-duty trucks outside the United States Capitol building Friday night as part of a trial program to improve security around Federal buildings. A police spokesman said this move was not a reaction to any particular threat of an attack, but that such a program for dealing with terrorist actions has been ''considered for some time.''

title: Los Angeles Police Net Suspected Drug Dealers
description: In a four-day crackdown aimed at halting a recent rash of gang-related crime, police officers here have broken down doors and crashed through windows to net nearly 700 suspected drug dealers.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Redskins vs. Atlanta Falcons , at Washington. The Atlanta coach, Dan Henning, who used to be an assistant with the Redskins, goes against his former boss, Joe Gibbs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the last two or three months, we lost control of our business, and it was no joke.

title: FASTING WINS CONCESSIONS ON SHELTER FOR HOMELESS
description: The Reagan Administration agreed today to renovate an 800-bed shelter for homeless people here, and a local activist who was protesting the Administration's policies toward the homeless ended his 51-day fast.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Oct. 16 about a lawsuit brought by the Chase Manhattan Bank against Arthur Andersen & Company misstated the legal status of a former officer of the Drysdale Securities Corporation. Peter J. Wasserman, its former president, was not charged with any criminal wrongdoing.

title: Rescuers Search for Victims Of Fire in an Egyptian Village
description: Rescue forces searched today for additional victims of a fire that destroyed nearly 500 mud houses and killed at least 52 people in a Nile Delta village Friday.

title: REAGAN, ON THE STUMP, IN RAPPORT WITH FANS
description: The mild weather that marked his re-election campaign all fall gave way this week to harbingers of winter as President Reagan finally put in his first long days on the stump.

title: Pact Is Extended For Jersey Faculty
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University faculty members agreed yesterday to a two-and-a-half-month contract extension, postponing a strike deadline set for today.

title: LEBANON DELAYS TALKS WITH ISRAELIS
description: Lebanon announced today that talks with Israel on arrangements for an Israeli troop withdrawal had been postponed at Beirut's request until later in the week.

title: French Nuclear Device Is Exploded in Pacific
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, Nov. 5 (Reuters) - France has detonated another underground nuclear explosion at its Mururoa Atoll testing ground in the Pacific, New Zealand scientists reported today.

title: F.B.I. ARRESTS 4 FUGITIVES IN OHIO IN 1981 SLAYING OF JERSEY TROOPER
description: Federal agents in Ohio yesterday arrested four long-sought fugitives in the slaying of a New Jersey state trooper nearly three years ago. A fifth person accused of harboring them also was seized.

title: COURT HAS KEPT FAITH ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Marlene VerPlanck Sings at Freddy's
description: Marlene VerPlanck, who used to be the voice of Campbell's Soup, has a sweet soprano not unlike Linda Ronstadt's. Miss VerPlanck, who ended a weeklong engagement at Freddy's Supper Club on Saturday, came to pop from the world of jingles and backup vocalizing.

title: CARDS BEATEN BY RAMS
description: Eric Dickerson ran for 207 yards on 20 carries, and Mike Lansford kicked field goals of 27 and 32 yards in the second half, giving the Los Angeles Rams a 16-13 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.
