title: RECITAL: SALVATORE ACCARDO
description: Italy - a land of natural singers and charismatic conductors

title: Braniff Picks Agency As Ayer Replacement
description: A week ago Braniff Inc., the troubled airline. and N. W. Ayer, its ad agency, mutually agreed to split because the relationship would no longer be economically feasible for either of them. On Friday the Dallas- based carrier said it had appointed Saunders, Lubinski & White in its home town to handle the business, which has shrunk, like the airline itself. The new ad budget is $4 million.

title: PUNK-ROCK: PUBLIC IMAGE
description: John Lydon of Public Image Ltd. has worked out a way to embody that contradiction in terms, a professional punk- rocker. He has kept his obnoxious persona, but he no longer sabotages his music in order to bait the audience.

title: MAKING MARK ON POLITICS, 'BABY BOOMERS' APPEAR TO RALLY AROUND REAGAN
description: Pollsters and political scientists have been watching Dick Merrick and his generation for years.

title: The Cup Runneth Over
description: It has been five years since Jim O'Neal figured out what was wrong with golf, or ''Scottish golf,'' as he has taken to calling the game that has given him so much grief.

title: Norwegian Aluminum OSLO, Nov. 4, (Reuters) -
description: Two Norwegian aluminum producers said they were cutting

title: Soviet Press Predicts Victory for Reagan
description: Soviet newspapers today predicted re-election for President Reagan and said the influence of big corporations makes Americans vote in ''elections without choice,'' as one newspaper headlined its article.

title: HOW OUR PERCEPTION OF PEOPLE IS ALTERED BY THE AGE FACTOR
description: Offer to introduce a friend to a member of the opposite sex and the first question likely to arise is, ''How old is he?'' or ''How old is she.'' Not, says Victoria Secunda, author of a new book on the influences of age, ''Did he (or she) go to college, does he have a sense of humor, is he kind, does he like movies?'' These qualities might be more sound predictors of a potential friendship than a birthdate.

title: FURY SLACKEN, AND NEW DELHI REVIVES
description: Sikh refugees huddled at makeshift camps today said the killings that followed Indira Gandhi's assassination were condoned or abetted by the police.

title: PAY FIGHTS EMBROIL BRITISH CAR MAKERS
description: Until recently, Jaguar P.L.C. could do no wrong in the British Government's eyes. Under the leadership of John Egan, its aggressive and energetic chairman, the luxury-car maker regained a squandered reputation for quality, turned from large losses to dazzling profits, and moved from state ownership to private control in a popular $362 million share sale this summer.

title: BRONCOS DEFEAT PATRIOTS BY 26-19
description: The safety Dennis Smith recovered a fumble by Mosi Tatupu with 1 minute 45 seconds to play today and ran 64 yards for a touchdown, giving the Denver Broncos (9-1) a 26-19 victory over the New England Patriots (6-4).

title: 7 AFGHAN REBELS ARE FLOWN TO U.S. FOR CARE
description: Seven seriously injured Afghan rebels, whose wounds could not be treated in Pakistan, were flown to the United States yesterday by an American relief organization for treatment at a hospital in Richmond, Va.

title: ELECTIONS IN NICARAGUA: THE PARTIES AND THE CANDIDATES
description: Seven parties

title: THE NICARAGUAN VOTE
description: The election in Nicaragua today is likely to heighten tensions between Washington and Managua and make it more difficult to develop a peace plan for Central America, according to Reagan Administration officials and Latin American diplomats. The problem, they say, is that the United States and Nicaragua view the election so differently. They agree on only one point: the election will have a major impact on political developments in the region.

title: DANCE: BY STUART PIMSLER, ANTIWAR WORK, 'SENTRY'
description: Stuart Pimsler works with a limited movement vocabulary, a lot of ideas, and a stage presence reminiscent of Woody Allen's film personna. The mix was not always a productive one in the dances presented by Stuart Pimsler Dance & Theater on Saturday at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. But in ''Sentry'' Mr. Pimsler has a work that must stand as one of the most powerful antiwar dances that have been seen in a long time.

title: SANDINISTAS HOLD THEIR FIRST ELECTIONS
description: Nicaragua held a national election today, the first since the Sandinistas took power five years ago after an insurrection.

title: PURCHASERS: SLOWDOWN TO CONTINUE
description: The economy remained virtually at a standstill in October, and is likely to remain at this plateau through the remainder of the year, the National Association of Purchasing Management concluded yesterday in its most recent report.

title: Buskin & Batteau At the Bottom Line
description: By writing and performing songs that scrutinize the pop life from a droll, older-but-wiser point of view, the duo of Buskin & Batteau are breathing new life into the unfashionable genre of the folk-pop singer- songwriter.

title: NOMINATION PLAN IS COMPLEX
description: The Breeders' Cup got its name not just because it was the brainchild of the horse breeding industry but because that group puts up the majority of the money for the $10 million in purses for next Saturday's seven races and the $10 million that was scheduled to be given away in premium awards for the top finishers in other major races during the year.

title: Ogilvy Wins Coast Job
description: The Los Angeles office of Ogilvy & Mather has beaten out 10 other West Coast agencies for the $12 million account of the California Federal Savings and Loan Association and its corporate parent, Calfed Inc. The advertising had been handled in-house.

title: BEARS SMOTHER RAIDERS, 17-6
description: Walter Payton rushed for 111 yards and two first-half touchdowns and the Chicago defense forced five turnovers and recorded nine sacks today in sparking the Bears (7-3) to a 17-6 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders (7-3).

title: Washington Bows
description: Pat McLaughlin rushed for 266 yards on 28 carries yesterday to help McBurney (5-3) defeat George Washington, 26-20, in a Public Schools Athletic League game.

title: U.S. Transport Plane Arrives in Ethiopia
description: A chartered United States transport plane flew into Addis Ababa today. It was the first American aircraft to join the airlift of food and supplies to six million Ethiopian famine victims.

title: Washington Watch ; A Pocketbook Vote Predictor
description: WASHINGTON

title: WIEST AND LANGELLA PLAY COMPLEX ROLES IN 'FALL'
description: When actors move audiences in ''After the Fall,'' the achievement has not come cheaply. The play is one of the most daring and troublesome in the Arthur Miller canon, a tale of a lawyer's failures at love, of his pain and self-pity, told through a mosaic of scenes. It is compelling to some, confounding to others.

title: Topics ; Less Drink, More Discretion
description: Higher Stakes

title: ON THE LAST WEEKEND OF CAMPAIGN, POLITICIANS STUMP, DEBATE AND RALLY
description: On flatbed trucks, at festive rallies, in sharp debate and through relentless television advertising, candidates made last-minute appeals to voters yesterday throughout the New York metropolitan area.

title: ROLE OF NBC COMEDIES
description: NBC threw a Halloween party recently for the cast and crew of ''Silver Spoons'' and ''Punky Brewster,'' two NBC television series that are currently languishing near the bottom of the Nielsen ratings. Why NBC lavished $20,000 on food, frivolity, ghouls, games and huge ghost balloons in honor of 14-year-old Ricky Schroder, the star of ''Silver Spoons,'' and 8-year-old Soleil Moon Frye, the star of ''Punky Brewster,'' says a great deal about the subtleties of television ratings.

title: L.I. Train Kills Army Private, 18
description: An 18-year-old Army private was struck and killed by an eastbound Long Island Rail Road train early today.

title: IRISH REBEL DEFENDS BRIGHTON BOMBING
description: The leader of Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing, declared today that the bombing last month at the British Conservative Party conference was ''a blow for democracy.''

title: CHANGES AT NEW YORKER ASSESSED BY TOP EDITOR
description: William Shawn, the editor of The New Yorker, said yesterday that the appointment of two co-managing editors indicated no immediate changes in his role at the magazine. However, he added, the two may eventually succeed him, as co-editors.

title: EMOTIONAL PAIN AND A BULLET DOOM EX-FOOTBALL STAR
description: PHILADELPHIAA shout from below her window awakened Charlotte Smith. She had been sleeping in the bedroom of her second-floor apartment at 131 North 15th Street, a three-story red-brick building, in Center City here early Friday morning, Oct. 26.

title: BOTH SIDES SPEND IN ABORTION FIGHT
description: In the competition for influence on one of the most volatile issues in this campaign year, groups opposing abortion have been more vociferous than ever.

title: LABOR, EMPLOYERS FEAR FRINGE-BENEFIT TAXATION
description: The tax-exempt status of employee benefits has long been considered safe. But in the search for ways to raise new revenues and ''reform'' the tax system, some members of Congress and the Administration have set their sights on them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1984

title: CHARCOAL VENTURE IN TROUBLE
description: At the time, it seemed like the perfect marriage between a Western entrepreneur and a developing nation.

title: Vigil of Hope
description: Seven weeks after he collapsed on the sidelines after being tackled in a game against Oregon in Eugene, Ed Reinhardt Jr., a 19-year-old Colorado tight end, remains in a coma, according to officials of the University of Colorado Medical Center in Denver, but the young man's small, fifth-floor room in the hospital's surgical intensive-care unit has become a center of hope and inspiration. It is decorated by pennants, posters and photographs sent by fellow football players and other well-wishers from across the country, and has become a focal point for hospital professionals.

title: Iran Marks Embassy Seizure
description: Several thousand people demonstrated outside the former United States Embassy today, the fifth anniversary of the day it was seized by Iranian militants. Witnesses said the crowd was noticeably smaller than in previous years and that much attention was given to another anniversary, that of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's expulsion by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi 20 years ago today.

title: POLICE IN JAPAN: BADGES HAVE LOST THEIR SPARKLE
description: A few years back, an American political scientist who had studied police behavior here wrote that Japan was ''heaven for a cop.''

title: Bahamas Takes Custody Of 180 Haitian Refugees
description: Bahamian officials today took custody of 180 Haitian refugees who were intercepted by the United States Coast Guard when their 40-foot sailboat ran aground while trying to reach Florida.

title: NEW BENEFITS LAW PROVOKES DISPUTE
description: A law newly enacted in an effort to end three years of bitter disputes over the Social Security disability program has spawned more conflict.

title: 1,000 HELP SYNAGOGUE UNDO HATE
description: As a crowd huddled under leaden skies, Rabbi Ira J. Rothstein began scrubbing - slowly, then more vigorously - to erase the swastikas and other anti-Semitic graffiti from a wall of the Beth Shalom Synagogue.

title: HORSEMEN BETTING ON SPORT'S FUTURE
description: On Saturday afternoon at Hollywood Park, just down the road from Los Angeles International Airport, about 75 thoroughbreds will compete in seven new races called the Breeders' Cup that will take less than 13 minutes to run. What happens in those 13 minutes, and how many people care about the results, could well shape the future of thoroughbred racing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of incorrect information from the Associated Press, a caption Friday with articles about the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India misidentified the type of artillery piece upon which her body was being borne. It was a British-made weapon.

title: SLUGGISHNESS SEEN IN QUARTERLY PROFITS
description: Corporate earnings growth slowed noticeably in the third quarter, reflecting the distinct decline in the pace of economic expansion from the first half of the year.

title: ; 'AS IF THEY WERE JUST PEOPLE LIKE OURSELVES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics ; LESS DRINK, MORE DISCRETION True ConfessionsMaybe it was because Geraldine Ferraro just wanted to show that charges that were ''enough to make a grown man cry,'' as Phil Donahue put it, didn't have the same effect on a grown woman. But in declining to say whether she cried after reading a newspaper story about her mother, she breathed life into an almost-defunct virtue. Discretion. What a temptation it is for Americans to 'fess up! A Vice Presidential candidate of several campaigns back, anxious that we should be informed, admitted that he had ''half a hemorrhoid.'' Asked to muse about what she'd do if her young daughter were having an affair, a former First Lady did so - for millions of television viewers. Asked if she'd abort a pregnancy that resulted from rape, another First Lady said '' I don't know.'' That's the same answer, for that matter, that Mrs. Ferraro gives.
description: Topics like these are hardly in the national interest, but, faced with a direct question, there's many a public figure who, in the name of candor, has opted for gratuitous confession.

title: EASING BY THE FED EXPECTED
description: This week's meeting of Federal Reserve officials in charge of monetary policy comes amid widespread speculation in the credit markets that the Fed will opt for a more generous money policy that would promote lower interest rates and help stimulate a flagging economy.

title: U.S. Judge Denies Stay To a Condemned Slayer
description: Timothy Palmes, one of two convicted murderers scheduled to die Wednesday in Florida's electric chair, was denied a stay of execution tonight by Judge Howell Melton of Federal District Court.

title: THRONG IN CENTRAL PARK MOURNS LOST LEADER
description: More than 2,000 Indians and Indian- Americans living in the New York area gathered in Central Park yesterday, amid heavy police protection, in a memorial service for Indira Gandhi that brought calls for unity and an end to the bloodshed that has engulfed India since the Prime Minister's assassination last week.

title: Shades of Lincoln
description: Illusionists of the Evergreen Painting Studios will be swarming up

title: ISRAELI DEFENDS ATTACK ON ARABS
description: An Israeli soldier arrested on charges of firing a rocket at an Arab bus told a judge today that he hoped the court ''would understand'' his action, in which an Arab youth was killed and 10 other passengers were wounded.

title: CRIME AND PUNISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTE SET ON HOMOSEXUAL COMMUNITY
description: Voters in an urban enclave between Los Angeles and Beverly Hills are to decide Tuesday whether to establish what some of its residents call a ''Camelot'' for homosexuals.

title: HELPING HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS' CHILDREN
description: ''SOMEHOW there was always an awareness that my parents were different than other people,'' says a young woman at the start of ''Breaking the Silence: The Generation After the Holocaust,'' a documentary film about how children of survivors of the Holocaust learn to improve their self-images and their relationships with parents.

title: LOOKING FOR AN EXIT
description: JERUSALEM ''We are through with delusions in Lebanon.'' In those words Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin signifies a profound Israeli change of policy. The new national unity Government has totally abandoned the far-reaching political goals of Israel's Lebanese war.

title: FLIGHT OF DEALERS ENDS ERA OF AUTOMOBILE ROW
description: Manhattan's Automobile Row is rolling toward extinction.

title: World Debt Gains Cited
description: Impressive progress has been recorded by a number of major debtor countries in the last two years, according to economists at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: DANCE: ROYAL BALLET OF WINNIPEG PERFORMS
description: The Royal Winnipeg Ballet of Canada is a sunny and likeable company of attractive dancers with clean, crisp technical skills. And it presented a pleasant evening's entertainment on Friday at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx. But it needs - as does many another company today - some choreography.

title: Norway Finds Big Oil Field OSLO, Nov. 4 (Reuters) - A
description: new oil field off Norway's central coast is the nation's most

title: SUNS SIGN LUCAS AMID TRADE TALK
description: The free-agent forward Maurice Lucas signed a one-year contract with the Phoenix Suns early today amid speculation that the team might try to trade him.

title: Officer Named to Head Mellon Trust Operation
description: Donald A. McMullen Jr. has been named senior vice president and head of the trust and investment department of Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. The appointment is effective immediately.

title: Addenda
description: * The New York Times is increasing its advertising rates an average of 8.5 percent as of Jan. 1.

title: BRUINS TROUNCE ISLANDERS BY 6-2
description: Road warriors for so long, with a better-than-.500 record in eight of the last nine seasons, the Islanders now find themselves road weary. They lost for the third consecutive time on the road tonight, vastly outplayed in the 6-2 loss to the Bruins at Boston Garden, suffering their fifth setback in six games away from home this season.

title: RECITAL: POGORELICH PERFORMS
description: Anyone who came to Ivo Pogorelich's Carnegie Hall recital Saturday expecting shocks and thrills must have gone home disappointed. There were a few eccentricities in the young Yugoslav's playing, but none of them was particularly outrageous, and they seemed not so much bold and poetic as random and listless.

title: EX-PALERMO MAYOR ARRESTED
description: A former Mayor of Palermo, Sicily, has been arrested on charges of having links with the Mafia and of illegally exporting capital, the police said today.

title: PRIEST REPORTED TO HAVE BEEN BEATEN
description: A pro- Solidarity priest was beaten, gagged and tied up before he was thrown into a reservoir, sources who attended his autopsy said today.

title: 2,000 Minks Freed In Britain
description: Animal rights campaigners freed 2,000 minks today from a fur farm near this north England village, the police said.

title: IN FINAL DAYS, EACH RIVAL GOES INTO FOE'S AREA
description: President Reagan made a last- minute foray into Walter F. Mondale's home state yesterday to try to include Minnesota in what his campaign strategists predict could be a coast-to- coast victory for the President in Tuesday's election.

title: TALK OF NEW VOTING RULES STIRS FEAR IN BRAZIL
description: Brazil's departing military Government is studying possible changes in the rules for indirect presidential elections next January, and some politicians and commentators fear that the aim is to frustrate an opposition victory.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EAGLE AGAINST THE SUN. By Ronald

title: 500 Are Detained by Nepal
description: About 500 people were detained today for taking part in a meeting organized by the outlawed Nepali Congress Party in Bharatpur, sources in the party said. More than 150 were still being held late today, the sources said. All political parties are banned in Nepal.

title: WONDERWORKS' AND 'BRAINGAMES'
description: Devising programs for younger audiences can be a tricky and frustrating business. An example of what works nicely is the current public- television series ''Wonderworks,'' which, tonight at 8 on WNET/13, begins a two-part adaptation of Virginia Hamilton's story ''The House of Dies Drear.'' An example of what can go wrong is ''Braingames,'' an animation game show making its debut on Home Box Office, the pay-cable channel, this evening at 7 P.M.

title: ALCORN STATE TRIUMPHS, 42-28
description: Perry Qualls got five touchdowns, including the go-ahead one with 1 minute 51 seconds to play, in Alcorn State's 42-28 victory over Mississippi Valley State in a showdown of Southwestern Athletic Conference unbeaten teams today.

title: SPURS EDGE KNICKS IN DOUBLE OVERTIME
description: Big men have been plaguing the Knicks ever since they began their road trip last Tuesday night against the Utah Jazz. It was no different tonight.

title: 'AS IF THEY WERE JUST PEOPLE LIKE OURSELVES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Films on Germany
description: Seven German films will be shown in a week-long series, ''The Third Reich in the Films of the Federal Republic of Germany,'' which opens at 8 P.M. on Nov. 12 at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. Wolf Donner, film critic, will speak on ''Coming to Terms With Our Past,'' and Part II of ''Our Hitler,'' by Hans J"urgen Syberberg, will be shown. Free tickets will be distributed at 7 P.M. Information: Goethe House, 744-8310, 744-8989.

title: FOUR WOMEN PLAN PROJECT IN EGYPT
description: Four American women have formed an all-female expedition to begin searching in Egypt in January for ruins including the remains of a 70-foot-tall statue of the Pharaoh Amenhotep III, who reigned from 1417 B.C. to 1379 B.C. and was the grandfather of Tutankhamen.

title: NOVA-PARK'S EMBATTLED HOTEL
description: Five years ago, when Nova-Park A.G., a Swiss hotel company known for developing luxury hotels, announced plans to renovate the stately Gotham Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, the project seemed destined to be a glittering success.

title: ST. FRANCIS PREP GAINS IN PLAYOFFS
description: St. Francis Prep, the defending Catholic High Schools' Football League champion, scored a 24-7 victory over Mount St. Michael yesterday in the playoff quarterfinals.

title: Index Draws Dissent
description: Matters of a few tenths of a percentage point have a great bearing on how the Government and private economists see the economy evolving, particularly on the eves of national elections. Take, for example, the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators. It is used to forecast the onset of recessions and recoveries.

title: A Folk Music Concert At Alice Tully Hall
description: Led by the Leonard M. Davis, some two dozen balalaika and domra players performed a program of Eastern European folk music at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday. For rustic folk instruments, the three-stringed, triangular balalaika and its older pear-shaped cousin, the domra, yield unusually delicate timbres.

title: Syrian Vice President Meets With U.S. Aide
description: Vice President Abdel Halim Khaddam conferred here today with the American Assistant Secretary of State, Richard W. Murphy, the Syrian press agency reported.

title: Helicopter Crashes Off China
description: Two Americans and three Chinese are believed dead after their helicopter crashed in the South China Sea on Thursday, industry sources said today. The official New China News Agency reported that the Chinese helicopter had been chartered by an American company prospecting for crude oil, and that a search was under way in the South China Sea.

title: WHAT REAGAN HAS DONE FOR MEDICARE...
description: To the Editor:

title: MCENROE IS FINED $2,100
description: John McEnroe was fined $2,100 for three displays of temper today during a victory over Anders Jarryd in the semifinals of the $315,000 Stockholm Open tennis tournament.

title: U.S. MAY ALTER MONEY TO THWART COUNTERFEITS
description: The Treasury Department, worried that a forthcoming generation of copying machines could be used to counterfeit money, is seeking to change the design of American currency.

title: FOR FOUNDING FATHERS, A SECULAR SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SLAUGHTER ON 29th STREET There are secret passageways, power failures and lots of disguises. In fact, nobody, it seems, is who he or she appears to be in ''The Musical Comedy Murders of 1940,'' a spoof of mystery films by John Bishop that will be read, script in hand, tonight at 8 at the Little Church Around the Corner, 1 East 29th Street.

title: DOCTOR SAYS SUSPECT IN GANDHI SHOOTING ISN'T 'OUT OF DANGER'
description: A doctor supervising the treatment of one of the purported assassins of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that the man was ''not yet out of danger or fit to make a statement'' to the police.

title: U.S. to End Ban on Knitting
description: The Labor Department will permanently lift the on-again, off-again ban on knitting at home for pay, Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, announced today after conferring with officials in Washington.

title: Payment To Venezuela
description: The World Bank has agreed to repay five years ahead of schedule about $252 million of a loan that the bank obtained from Venezuela in 1974, a World Bank spokesman said.

title: WHERE 'TEMPORARY' HAS LASTED 13 YEARS
description: Almost 13 years after the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals was created to adjudicate cases arising from the Nixon Administration's wage-price control program, and more than a decade after these controls were removed, this vestige of a failed policy is as busy as ever.

title: S.L. HABER, RELIEF AIDE,DIES
description: Samuel L. Haber, who directed efforts to resettle tens of thousands of uprooted Jews from postwar Europe to Israel, died Saturday while visiting his son's family in Akron, Ohio. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giant-Jet Fantasia
description: In the end, the Jets finally crumpled, losing to the

title: PRESIDENT REGRETS BOMBING COMMENT
description: President Reagan said today that he should not have joked into an open microphone about ordering the bombing of the Soviet Union. But he insisted the news media should not have broadcast his remark and risked ''an incident.''

title: EGYPTIAN IS FOCUS OF WORK
description: ''Akhnaten'' is Philip Glass's third opera, following his ''Einstein on the Beach'' and ''Satyagraha.'' Although they were conceived separately, Mr. Glass now regards them as a trilogy based on the lives of three great men: King Akhnaten, Einstein and Gandhi.

title: Hockey by the Book
description: Ever get to wondering, say, who won the Stanley Cup in 1919? Or how many games the Devils won in their longest winning streak? Or who the Rangers play in their last home game before the 1985 All-Star break? Or how many penalty minutes Pierre Larouche served two seasons ago? Or when Maurice Richard scored his 500th goal? Or how much Mike Bossy weighs? Or what Al Arbour looked like in his Maple Leaf uniform?

title: 4 Runbacks Set a Record
description: Three defensive backs for the Seattle Seahawks - Dave Brown, Keith Simpson and Ken Easley - put themselves into the National Football League record book today in the 45-0 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Marjorie Munsterberg Becomes Bride
description: Marjorie Munsterberg, a teaching fellow in the humanities at Columbia University, and Charles Douglas Gregor, a computer systems analyst for the Reserve Fund, were married yesterday at Columbia's Faculty House. Rabbi Herschel Cohen performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Jacob Kret.

title: MONDALE SPRINTS TO THE FINISH LINE
description: As his long quest for the Presidency draws to a close and the autumn air turns ever cooler, Walter F. Mondale is gathering his friends and supporters about him in multitudes and holding his head high.

title: John Henry Out, His Trainer Says
description: John Henry, who had been a doubtful starter since Thursday, will miss the Breeders' Cup race Saturday and will not race again this year, according to his trainer, Ron McAnally.

title: A Travel Ad Specialist, Just Like Doug, Is Back
description: First came the big white box tied in red ribbon that, when opened, revealed a khaki Army officer's cap with a visor splattered with gold ''scrambled eggs.'' The card said merely, ''I.''

title: REAGAN CAMPAIGN MAKES LAST-MINUTE STOP IN MONDALE'S TURF
description: With the glee of brigands, the Reagan campaign touched down in its rival's home state this morning so President Reagan might personally seek to sway some final, resistant votes from Walter F. Mondale.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Oct. 26 incorrectly described a transaction involving the International Paper Company. It is buying the Durham containerboard mill in Riegelsville, Pa., from Durham Mills Inc.

title: VIOLENCE INCREASES AGAINST ABORTION CLINICS IN '84
description: Violence against abortion clinics and centers that provide information on birth control appears to be increasing, according to law-enforcement officials and family planning experts.

title: COMPUTER STRUGGLE AT CONVERGENT
description: A rash of troublesome news from Convergent Technologies Inc. has prompted conjecture that the computer maker's financial health has worsened since midyear. Analysts said the company's fate could be decided in the next few weeks as it fights parts shortages, lower-than-expected profit margins and increasing competition for its powerful desktop computer, called the Ngen.

title: MUSIC
description: Choral Society Presents Beethoven's 'Mass in D'

title: John D. Beals Jr. Dies at 88; A Partner in City Law Firms
description: John D. Beals Jr., a lawyer in New York City for 60 years, died Saturday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has named Thomas C. Wajnert president of its new ATT Credit Corp. subsidiary.

title: Facets
description: Frank Loesser, the composer, is

title: Alfred W. Crown, 73, A Producer of Movies
description: Alfred W. Crown, a motion-picture producer whose films included ''Moby Dick,'' died of pneumonia Saturday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Susan C. Wolff Weds Jonathan Holtz in Rye
description: Susan C. Wolff and Jonathan J. Holtz were married yesterday at the Rye Town (N.Y.) Hilton. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony.

title: Accounts
description: * New York City Board of Education has reassigned its recruiting account to Walter F. Cameron Advertising, Jericho, L.I.

title: AT JAI-ALAI'S LATE SHOW
description: Only 100 spectators were left when the championship match began Friday night. The players took the court, waving their wicker cestas at the backs of patrons heading into the post-midnight stillness of Milford, Conn. There was no trifecta, no perfecta, no quinella, merely win betting on the championship match - hardly enough incentive for most jai-alai patrons to stay.

title: Article 060132 -- No Title
description: The Treasury will start a major $17.5 billion note and bond financing today with a three-year note auction, followed on Wednesday by 10-year notes and on Thursday with 30-year bonds.

title: Splitting Bears
description: The news may come too late to

title: Carl Ally, 60, to Retire; Shop Adds 2 Accounts
description: Carl Ally, 60 years old, will be retiring at the end of the year from Ally & Gargano, the agency he helped found 22 years ago and helped take public last year.

title: TV'S ELECTION DAMAGE
description: In a healthy display of bipartisan statemanship, President Reagan and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale have individually and voluntarily agreed to refrain from claiming victory or conceding defeat in the election until all the polls are closed.

title: BRITISH RIDERS EARN HONORS
description: The British completed their stunning sweep of the international equestrian honors at the 101st National Horse Show yesterday, taking the team championship away from the United States Equestrian Team for the first time since 1973, and winning the leading international rider award as well.

title: BEIRUT HOSTAGES' FAMILIES SPEAK OUT
description: On separate occasions last spring, three Americans - a journalist, a diplomat and a minister - were kidnapped off the sidewalks of Beirut by gunmen.

title: Bridge:American Teams Progress Toward Olympiad Playoffs
description: Both United States teams progressed steadily at the World Team Olympiad here this afternoon and seemed sure to advance to playoffs beginning Wednesday.

title: OUTDOORS: SPECIAL HUNT PRESERVE
description: BRIGHTON, Ill.

title: NEW THREAT OF RAID ON AMERICANS REPORTED IN A LEBANESE BROADCAST
description: A group that has taken responsibility for most of the terrorist attacks against American installations in the Middle East has threatened to hit United States institutions in the region within two days, the Christian radio station Voice of Lebanon said today.

title: STALIN DAUGHTER SAID TO VISIT MOSCOW FRIENDS AND FAMILY
description: Two days after an announcement that she had returned to the Soviet Union after 17 years abroad, Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, has not been seen in public.

title: Ellis Larkins Plays Piano at Hanratty's
description: After six years using Carnegie Tavern as his New York base, Ellis Larkins has joined the company of pianists who come and go at Hanratty's, Second Avenue at 92d Street.

title: INDIA'S 2 NEWS AGENCIES
description: Over the last five days, Indian readers have relied greatly on two independent news agencies for reports on Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's assassination and the mass violence that engulfed much of New Delhi and other parts of this sprawling nation.

title: ...AND COULD DO TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMIC FREEZE STARTS AS ISRAEL FIGHTS INFLATION
description: The Israeli Cabinet today formally approved the package deal with labor unions and leading industrialists that will hold down wages and freeze prices in Israel for the next three months.

title: PENTAGON PLANS TO EXTEND SECRECY RESTRICTIONS ON TECHNICAL DATA
description: The Defense Department plans to expand its secrecy rules in an effort to prevent technical information from being passed to the Soviet Union or other potential adversaries, according to Pentagon officials.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1984 International Sikh refugees in New Delhi described the mass slayings of Sikhs that followed Indira Gandhi's assassination, calling them a mixture of class and political warfare condoned or abetted by the police. The killings, which wiped out entire Sikh neighborhoods in the Delhi area, have generated enormous refugee problems. (Page A1, Column 2.) New Delhi was back in business after four days of silent empty streets, deserted by fearful people. The irrepressible life of the city began to reassert itself with a temporary lifting of the curfew imposed in the last several violent days. (A1:1.)

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: For how many years did Vice President Bush play college baseball and how good a player was he?

title: Official Dies After Game
description: A Suffolk County football official suffered cardiac arrest during a high school game at Islip Saturday and died later at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore.

title: The Volcker Question
description: When Paul Volcker was nominated by President Reagan in mid-1983 for a second four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, he told the Senate that he might not serve out the full four years. That remark sometimes has been taken to mean that Mr. Volcker said he would resign next year, after the Presidential inauguration.

title: INDIA RELAXES CURFEWS AS VIOLENCE EBBS
description: The violence that gripped New Delhi and the rest of the country after the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi seemed to have abated today.

title: South Africa's Foreign Chief Begins a 3-Day Visit to Israel
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, arrived in Israel tonight on a three-day private visit that newspapers here have described as an embarrassment.

title: MONDALE, IN SUMMATION, EVOKES DR. KING'S GOAL
description: A weary but buoyant Walter F. Mondale, nearing the end of his quest for the Presidency, said today that the nation faced a ''crucial moment in American history'' that pitted the values of ''decency'' and ''compassion'' against the ''vicious'' social policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 5, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Essie Woltman Is Married
description: Essie H. Woltman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Woltman of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Martin J. Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerald Greenberg of Bennington, Vt., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Perry Rank performed the ceremony at Temple Shomrei Emunah in Montclair, N.J. Mrs. Greenberg is a registered nurse at St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark. Her husband is a senior resident in internal medicine at the University Hospital College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark.

title: AT SIKH SHRINE, WORRY AND DEEP ANGER
description: In this holiest of Sikh cities, the prayers this morning at the holiest of Sikh shrines, the Golden Temple, were for peace and brotherhood, as they are every day of the year.

title: People
description: * Lou Mazzulli has been named a senior vice president at Lewis Advertising, Baltimore.

title: Lee Rubin, Executive, Wed to Wendy Greene
description: Wendy Greene, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Greene of New York, and Lee Alan Rubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Rubin of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., were married yesterday.

title: Market Place ; A Caution Flag for Rail Issues
description: The nation's railroads have

title: Air Mail, With a Vengeance
description: An envelope bearing a colorful

title: NOBODY'S PERFECT
description: WASHINGTON Before it is too late, let us root out the sources of voter ennui.

title: Play Award Finalists
description: Four finalists have been announced in the 1985 National Play Award competition sponsored by the National Repertory Theater Foundation of Los Angeles. They are Dennis J. Reardon of Middleburgh, N. Y.; Jan Henson Dow of Danbury, Conn.; David Kranes, former Long Wharf Theater playwright-in-residence, and Don Nigro of Malvern, Ohio. The winner, to be named next spring, will receive $7,500 in cash and production money.

title: INNUENDO GOES ON DISPITE SOVIET PREMIER'S DENIAL
description: The Communist Party daily Pravda repeated assertions today that ''external forces'' - by implication the United States - were involved in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: 6 Yugoslav Dissidents Go on Trial Today
description: Six dissident intellectuals go on trial Monday in a case Western diplomats say may define new limits on the behavior of internal critics in post-Tito Yugoslavia.

title: Like a Loose Garment
description: There are so many lawyers in

title: Baby Fae Is Eating Well 9 Days After Transplant
description: Baby Fae, the infant who received the heart of a baboon nine days ago, has been weaned from a special solution of sugar, salts and water to full-strength baby formula and is kicking, yawning and stretching ''just like any other baby,'' a hospital official said today.

title: THE CANDIDATES AND PROPOSITIONS IN NEW YORK STATE ELECTIONS
description: Following is a list of candidates appearing on ballots in the New York metropolitan area in tomorrow's election. Incumbent candidates are marked with an asterisk (*). Unopposed candidates are marked (U). The abbreviations are: D - Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, L - Liberal, I - Independent, RTL - Right to Life, FL - Free Libertarian, C - Communist, NA - New Alliance, SW - Socialist Worker, WW - Workers World, RP - Rate Payers Against Lilco Party, IP - Independence Party, IV - Independent Vote Party, IN - Independent Neighbors Party, Nuclear Freeze Party, TL- There Is Life After Lilco Party, ST - Sewer Tax Opposition Party, NT - Neighborhood Taxpayers Party, SQ - South Queens Community Alliance Party, PA - People Against Crime Party, SI - Statewide Independent Party, V - Veterans Party and FP - First Party Independent.

title: GIANT DEFENSE STYMIES COWBOYS;JETS BEATEN AS DOLPHINS WIN 10TH; MARINO LEADS 31-17 VICTORY
description: The undefeated Dolphins were shocked into victory against the Jets today, after trailing twice in a game for the first time this season.

title: OF CRIME, EQUAL RIGHTS AND A MENTAL HOSPITAL
description: When Raymond L. S. Patriarca, the reputed boss of the New England crime syndicate, died on July 11, the speculation about who would succeed him was intense. The Federal Bureau of Investigation appeared to provide an answer recently, but its conclusions are now in dispute.

title: Emily Halpern, Harpist, Wed to Peter B. Gormley
description: Emily Margaret Halpern, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham L. Halpern of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Bernard Gormley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gormley of Dublin. Justice Arnold L. Fein of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Eaton Corporation received a $308 million Air Force contract for expanded advance procurement of defensive avionics parts for the B-1B bomber, the Defense Department said. It said the Air Force also gave the Boeing Company contracts totaling $145.6 million for expanded advance procurement for B-1B bomber offensive avionics. In addition, the Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronics Company, a subsidiary of the North American Philips Corporation, received $124.9 million in Navy contracts for sonobuoys, the department said.

title: Two Gang Members Arrested In Alexander Family Killings
description: Two gang members accused of shooting to death four relatives of the former football star Kermit Alexander were held today in connection with the Aug. 31 killings.

title: PIERCING THOUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: MANUEL CONTINUES HIS BIG-PLAY ROLE
description: In a five- minute span late in the third quarter and early in the fourth, Lionel Manuel made two key catches today in the Giants' 19-7 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Elsinore Finance Corp. , is offering $115 million principal amount of 15 1/2 percent senior mortgage bonds due 1999, through Drexel Burham Lambert Inc.

title: At the West End Cafe, Eddie Chamblee Group
description: Eddie Chamblee's background in the musical world where rhythm and blues, big bands (Lionel Hampton) and the highly personalized blues singing of Dinah Washington converge has given him a style as a saxophonist that draws on all three elements. Last weekend at the West End Cafe, Broadway at 113th Street, his urgent playing was teamed in a quintet with the polished trombone work of Benny Powell, one of the stars of Count Basie's band in the 1950's and 60's.

title: FURY SLACKENS, AND NEW DELHI REVIVES
description: Cheddi, a beggar from Bihar state, came out of hiding at Delhi Railway Station early this morning and headed, tin cup in hand, for the center of town.

title: Connections
description: Politics can be a family affair.

title: TWO PARTIES PRESS CONGRESS CONTESTS IN VOTE TOMORROW
description: With an advertising blitz in the campaign finale, Republican leaders are pressing to convert President Reagan's broad personal popularity into a Congressional sweep.

title: STAGE: BURKIE,' STORY OF A PHILADELPHIA PLUMBER
description: At its heart, Bruce Graham's ''Burkie'' is a family play written to formula. In this domestic drama, a widowed Philadelphia plumber (Eddie Jones) is dying and his two grown children are trying to come to terms with him, their childhood and their own limitations. The play, first presented at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, opened last night at the Hudson Guild Theater in a production directed by Lynn M. Thomson.

title: CITY OPERA: 'AKHNATEN' BY GLASS
description: ''Akhnaten,'' the Philip Glass work that the New York City Opera presented last night in its New York premiere, is not a work whose music asks to be listened to seriously. Despite the publicity that Mr. Glass's works have received, his operas to date add up to little more than pageants with backgrounds of continually repeated, barely varied sound patterns. They stand to music as the sentence ''See Spot run'' stands to literature. As a pageant, then, ''Akhnaten'' must depend largely on the imagination of its production. By all reports, it benefited from brilliant staging earlier this year in its world premiere in Stuttgart, West Germany, and enjoyed a triumph there.

title: Advertising; Ginger Ale Given Push By Y.&R.
description: ''WE equate a cola,'' said William Appelman, sneering with sibilant scorn, ''with soppy, sentimental, sweet stuff.''

title: FLUTIE & CO. STILL IN RUNNING
description: Boston College, with Doug Flutie, is not out of the running for a major bowl bid despite the 37-30 loss to Penn State, its second of the season, according to the executive director of the Sugar Bowl.

title: ASSESSING ELEANOR ROOSEVELT AS A FEMINIST
description: ''Women are different from men, their physical functions are different, and the future of the race depends upon their ability to produce healthy children.'' - Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: A NEW COAL-BURNING PLANT OFFERS A GLIMPSE OF A NONNUCLEAR FUTURE
description: While two nuclear power plants in New York State struggle toward completion more than a decade late and about 1,000 percent over budget, a new coal-powered electric plant has opened here two and a half weeks early and $70 million under the cost projected four years ago.

title: WHY TRUST THE POLLS?
description: When the election is over, someone will owe the public an explanation about why the margin between Walter F. Mondale and Ronald Reagan in the five or six major public opinion polls varied so widely, when everybody was supposed to be measuring the same thing, using the same scientific methods, with the same margin of error of 4 percent.

title: ELECTION TOMORROW
description: Tomorrow is Election Day. Following are schedules of events: Polls - In New York, open 6 A.M. to 9

title: FERRARO SAYS REAGAN WOULD RAISE TAXES
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro today accused Ronald Reagan of ''peddling phony statistics about our tax plan'' while harboring his own ''secret plan to raise taxes.''

title: South African Mine Rescue
description: Eight missing black miners were found alive Saturday and today after a gold mine fire a mile and a half underground killed eight other miners, a company spokesman said. The fire was at the Buffelsfontein mine, 100 miles southwest of Johannesburg.

title: Politicians on Tour
description: Three dozen young public and

title: TO CZAR OR NOT TO CZAR
description: There is an iron law of bureaucracy that goes as follows: If the formal decision- making system is not working the President's presumed will, create an informal one to work around the obstacles; failing that, make personnel changes to remove the obstacles; and if unwilling to do that, add some new faces to the team to change the power balance and get things moving.

title: 3M Fills Top Post At Major Division
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has named Allen F. Jacobson president of its domestic operations, which last year accounted for two-thirds of the company's $7 billion in sales.

title: Businesses Lobbying on Fees
description: The Equal Access to Justice Act sounds like just the sort of thing the Reagan Administration, with its emphasis on trimming Government interference in business, would support.

title: The Candidates Today
description: Walter F. Mondale has scheduled broadcast interviews

title: 2 Prison Escapees Arrested in Jersey
description: Two convicted armed robbers who escaped from the Bordentown Youth Correctional Institution in August have been apprehended in Camden County.

title: Mixed Media
description: Fred W. Friendly has written five

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Cipher Data Products Inc., a San Diego-based designer and maker of magnetic tape peripherals, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire closely held Spectra Logic Corp. of Mountainview, Calif., for an undisclosed number of shares of Cipher's common stock.

title: A CRACK IN ROADWAY SUPPORT DELAYS LINCOLN TUNNEL TRAFFIC
description: Drivers heading west through the Lincoln Tunnel were delayed more than an hour yesterday after authorities found a crack in a support beam of an elevated highway in New Jersey and closed the roadway that connects the tunnel with the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Osborne's New Venture Is Software Publishing
description: Adam Osborne, the British-born writer and scientist who founded the Osborne Computer Corporation in 1980 only to see it file for bankruptcy three years later, has a new venture.

title: VIGILANTE PATROLS ARE FORMED TO SAFEGUARD NEIGHBORHOODS
description: A common sight in the capital these last few nights has been groups of residents armed with field hockey sticks, bamboo staves, iron bars and even rocks, patrolling their neighborhoods to protect them from looting mobs.

title: ARMS CURB STUDY HELD UP TILL VOTE
description: The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency has withheld making public a study of antisatellite arms control issues pending the election.

title: DRAMATIC VERMONT CLASH IS THE TIGHTEST OF 13 RACES FOR GOVERNOR
description: Vermont's Attorney General, John J. Easton Jr., stood in a cherry picker 50 feet above a scenic back road in Randolph, Vt., stringing electric lines with a crew. It was the 25th and final daylong job in the ''working with Vermont'' phase of his campaign for Governor, which took him to farms and factories, schools and health centers.

title: CASHEN SAYS METS MAY PASS IN DRAFT
description: When Frank Cashen attends the free-agent draft Thursday, he may utter only two words, and they won't be ''Rick Sutcliffe.'' The Mets' general manager indicated yesterday that he might say, ''Pass, pass,'' which was precisely what he said at the draft a year ago.

title: At the Opera
description: There is discord at the Washington Opera over the use of translations that now flash above the stage at the Kennedy Center. The translations run in English while the opera characters sing in another language.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Thursday with an article about the 63d Street subway between Manhattan and Queens misidentified a nearly completed station. It was the Roosevelt Island station.

title: 'Sit Me Down'
description: The National Basketball Association season is young, but Reggie Theus of the Kings and World B. Free of the Cavaliers are already at odds with their new coaches. Theus regards the style of Jack McKinney, coach of the Kings, as too conservative, and says: ''I want to feel like you can make a mistake without it being a cardinal sin.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment gains of $216,000 for the quarter and $1,449,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $152,000 for the quarter and $2,616,000 for the 9 months.

title: DEMOCRATS GAIN IN BUSINESS PAC FUNDS
description: Business interests are putting up about half the money going into today's Congressional elections, but Democrats appear to be getting almost as much as Republicans.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the consolidation of a previously unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: JOURNEYMAN GLAD TO BE HOME
description: BOSTON Dave Silk is back home, and the turns in his hockey career are beginning to appear more and more like a circle. He was 12 years old when Bobby Orr's goal gave Boston the Stanley Cup in 1970, and now, after a professional career that was once in jeopardy, he is wearing the same ''B'' on his chest.

title: BANKERS OPPOSE LAWS ON MONEY LAUNDERING
description: Leading bankers have expressed opposition to a Presidential commission's recommendations for Federal laws to block money laundering, citing a fear that the laws would intrude on the privacy of customers. Banking organizations also oppose any mandatory self-regulation along the lines adopted by bankers in other countries.

title: AT SHOWS, TAILORED DAYS AND GLAMOROUS EVENINGS
description: Glamorous evening clothes and tailored clothes are disparate fashion areas that have come off quite well so far in the spring New York showings.

title: MCENROE REMAINS ELIGIBLE FOR DAVIS
description: John McEnroe decided tonight not to appeal a 42-day suspension from competitive tennis he received Sunday after surpassing a yearly limit on fines. The decision came shortly after he had beaten Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, to win the $315,000 Stockholm Open for the third time.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a reversal of $224,800 in deferred income tax resulting from new tax legislation regarding domestic international sales corporations. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in June.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: REPORT SUGGESTS A RESHAPING OF NATIONAL COUNCIL OF CHURCHES
description: A top panel of the National Council of Churches has proposed a plan to make the council more attentive to the views of member churches and vest more power in its highest governing body, both moves that could diminish the role of the council's staff.

title: Nathan Bienstock, 86, Agent for Journalists
description: Nathan Bienstock, an agent and manager for newspaper, radio and television journalists, among others, died in his sleep Saturday at his home in the Westwood section of Los Angeles. He was 86 years old.

title: Greschner Out 3 Weeks The Rangers learned yesterday that Ron Greschner's separated
description: left shoulder, which had been expected to keep him out of action for only

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $395,000 for the quarter and $1,230,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $245,000 for the quarter and $620,000 for the 9 months.

title: MANILA TRIBUNAL ACCUSES GENERAL
description: Government prosecutors today ordered Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the Chief of Staff of the Philippine armed forces, and 25 other people to answer the accusations of a board of inquiry that they were involved in the 1983 assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Recent Insurer-Broker Mergers
description: The acquisition of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is only one of a series of recent insurer-brokerage mergers. In the last three years or so, several such marriages have taken place, including these:

title: CONSUMER BANKING AT CHASE GETS CHIEF
description: Arthur F. Ryan has been named head of consumer bank operations at the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: Aqueduct Fires Under Inquiry
description: Investigators for the New York Racing Association are looking into several fires that occurred Sunday night in the barn area at Aqueduct. Damage to the barns was slight, but 25 horses had to be relocated, and one, Roman Cuff, trained by Peter Ferriola and stabled in Barn 3, suffered some minor burns to his chest, hindquarters and tail.

title: Judge Keeps 11 Bands From Rally for Reagan
description: A Federal district judge issued a restraining order that stopped hundreds of students from playing in 11 high school bands at President Reagan's rally at the State Capitol today.

title: A MORNING AFTER AWAITS STUDENTS FOR REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT-TERM RATES DROP SHARPLY
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday amid rampant speculation by traders and economists that the Federal Reserve had moved to ease monetary policy and encourage lower interest rates.

title: Trial of 6 Dissidents Recessed in Belgrade
description: A trial of six dissidents charged with conspiring to overthrow the Government was recessed today for 24 hours after a defendant objected to a ruling by the presiding judge.

title: ON 'NOVA,' INDIAN NOMADS OF ECUADOR
description: ''NOMADS of the Rain Forest'' is an enthralling look at a Stone Age culture. It is also, one suspects, a mildly romantic look, but no matter. It is enthralling all the same. The documentary, part of the public- television series ''Nova,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: BIG TURNOUT EXPECTED IN NEW YORK, JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT VOTING
description: Election officials prepared yesterday for what could be a near record turnout in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today.

title: photo of William Donaldson, Dan Lufkin and Richard Jenrette; DONALDSON, LUFKIN LONG A MAVERICK
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a brokerage firm known for its maverick trend-setting ways, said yesterday that it would do what many of its Wall Street rivals have done over the last 10 years: merge.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations for major or closely contested races. Polls are open in New York from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. and in Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENT Walter Mondale Geraldine Ferraro (D,L) NEW YORK CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS

title: A Garden Match Of Camacho-Cruz
description: For (Macho) Camacho, embroiled in a contract dispute with his manager, Billy Giles, and thus inactive since last May, finally heeded the advice of friends and signed for a fight with Madison Square Garden as the promoter. Now friends are wondering whether the undefeated former World Boxing Council junior- lightweight champion should have waited for some managerial advice.

title: A PROJECT FOR THE GIFTED, A KNACK FOR FALLING SHORT
description: In the last two years nearly every member of Congress, several Cabinet members and President Reagan have endorsed a group whose aim is to get business involved in the education of gifted students.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28

title: CITY OPERA: 'AKHNATEN,' STORY OF EGYPTIAN RULER
description: ''AKHNATEN,'' the Philip Glass work that the New York City Opera presented Sunday night in its New York premiere, is not a work whose music asks to be listened to seriously. Despite the publicity that Mr. Glass's works have received, his operas to date add up to little more than pageants with backgrounds of continually repeated, barely varied sound patterns. They stand to music as the sentence ''See Spot run'' stands to literature. As a pageant, then, ''Akhnaten'' must depend largely on the imagination of its production. By all reports, it benefited from brilliant staging earlier this year in its world premiere in Stuttgart, West Germany, and enjoyed a triumph there.

title: Sir William Duncan, 61, Dies; Chief Officer of Rolls-Royce
description: Sir William Duncan, chairman and chief executive of Rolls-Royce Ltd., died yesterday at his home in London. He was 61 years old.

title: GRINNING, FIST CLENCHED, MONDALE ENDS CAMPAIGN
description: Walter F. Mondale ended his long campaign for the Presidency today with his fist held high, his face showing a grin and his voice rising.

title: College to Remove Tainted Air Ducts
description: Westchester County has ordered the air ducts removed from part of the science building at Westchester Community College in Valhalla to remove all asbestos from the building.

title: NEW BOOK CRITICIZES U.S. EFFORT TO RESCUE JEWS
description: Long-standing assertions that the United States and Britain extended only token assistance to the Jewish victims of Nazism in World War II have been documented and amplified in a book 15 years in preparation by an authority on the Holocaust.

title: A NEW WORK BY PHILIP GLASS
description: ''Akhnaten'' is Philip Glass's third opera, following his ''Einstein on the Beach'' and ''Satyagraha.'' Although they were conceived separately, Mr. Glass now regards them as a trilogy based on the lives of three great men: King Akhnaten, Einstein and Gandhi.

title: EQUITABLE LIFE WILL PURCHASE SECURITIES FIRM
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that it would purchase Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a leading Wall Street securities firm. The acquisition continues the blending of the stock brokerage, banking and insurance industries as these businesses seek their niches in a deregulated marketplace.

title: NEW DEMOCRATIC HOME & UNITY CO.
description: The sleekly handsome building, just three blocks from the Capitol, has 42,000 square feet of floor space, offices for 200 workers, television production facilities and a computer center. Not counting the technical equipment, the brand-new structure cost $6.6 million.

title: DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE BOOKS GET BETTER ON NONTECHNICAL TOPICS
description: COMPUTER books are entering a new era, one that allows for books that are a pleasure to read in and of themselves. There is certainly no dearth of supertechnical texts of interest to a specialized audience, and volumes on machine language, computer graphics and artificial intelligence abound. Yet in the midst of the deluge there are occasional new releases that are not only informative but, as editors put it, ''a good read.''

description: The small band of armed men walking on a provincial road north of Manila recently was a rag-tag bunch, a Western diplomat recalled.

Pantry Pride
description: Philip Devon, the former chairman of the Devon Stores Corporation, which is now a subsidiary of Pantry Pride Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that because of the ''inadequate'' performance of Pantry Pride's directors, he intends to seek the ouster of the present board by means of a proxy fight. Mr. Devon resigned from the board last Friday. Pantry Pride is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. According to the filing, Mr. Devon holds 10.4 percent of the shares outstanding.

description: Saying that levels of dioxin high enough to threaten human health had been found at the Dow Chemical Company plant in Midland, Mich., the Environmental Protection Agency has drafted an order to require the company to seal over the contaminated soil.

description: Joe Theismann passed for one touchdown and ran for another, and John Riggins scored twice as the Washington Redskins beat the Atlanta Falcons, 27-14, tonight.

title: On the Campaign Trail
description: The latest, and perhaps last, issue of a jocular daily journal

title: RETURN TO INDIA: ASHES AND MEMORIES
description: For a visitor who witnessed the cremation of the slain Mohandas K. Gandhi here nearly four decades ago, the similarities of the funeral Saturday of another Indian leader who had also fallen victim to religious and political passions left an eerie feeling.

title: Shadow Over the Election
description: By 8 o'clock tonight, the polls will have closed in states with 334 of the 538 electoral votes. Not many minutes later, all three television networks could well cast a shadow over the 1984 election. If the voters behave the way surveys suggest, the word will trumpet forth: ''According to our projections, President Reagan has already won more than the 270 electoral votes necessary for re-election.''

title: MOLLY PRICE
description: Molly Price, the author of ''The Iris Book,'' generally considered to be the definitive work on the subject, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. She was 81 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.

title: REAGAN RETURNS TO COAST FOR LAST RE-ELECTION PLEA
description: President Reagan finished his plea for re-election today with a fond return to see home- state voters and a televised appeal to the nation to ''go forward with an America of momentum'' rather than ''back to an America of malaise.''

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: b-Net loss.

title: Constantin A. Stavropoulos;On the U.N. Staff for 30 Years
description: Constantin A. Stavropoulos, a former Undersecretary General of the Legal Service office, died of a heart attack today after a long illness.

title: Attire and Research
description: On Saturday, some users of the Performing Arts Research Center at the New York Public Library's Lincoln Center branch chose to leave because they weren't dressed right, at least by library standards.

title: STRONG HOLIDAY SALES FORECAST
description: From the traditional point of view, the Christmas shopping season is a key economic indicator, providing insight into the overall health of the nation's retailing business. But at least one retailing analyst, Jerome H. Buff, first vice president of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, holds a different view. He feels that the Christmas season, though crucial in its sales impact, is not dependent of what went before or will come afterward, and that too much long-range significance can easily be read into it.

title: U.S. ENDS BAN ON HOME KNITTING FOR SALE
description: The Labor Department today declared that home knitters who turned out mittens and ski caps for sale were no longer outlaws. But it said they must register with the Government so that minimum wage and child labor laws could be enforced.

title: U.S. INDUSTRY WARY ON JAPANESE BILL
description: American industry representatives are expressing concern that a draft bill ostensibly meant to liberalize Japan's telecommunications industry may actually all but close the door to United States products.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NO MERGER FOR UNITED AND ALLIED
description: The United Technologies Corporation said today that it had been approached repeatedly over the last year by Edward L. Hennessy, its former president and now chairman of the Allied Corporation, suggesting a merger of the two companies.

title: 3 PHOTOGRAPHERS ATTACKED IN INDIA
description: Three photographers working for foreign news organizations were attacked and beaten today as about 60 policemen watched and did nothing, the photographers and witnesses said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Edwin Bailey , a starting offensive lineman for the Seattle Seahawks, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his knee and will miss two games. . . . Jim Bush , the longtime track coach at U.C.L.A., has been named running coach by the Los Angeles Dodgers. . . . Villanova University announced that Gary Massey, a senior basketball guard at St. Raymond High in the Bronx, has made a verbal agreement to attend Villanova in September 1985. Massey was the fourth-highest scorer in the Catholic High School Athletic Association last year, averaging 23 points.

title: FOREIGN UNDERSTUDIES IN CUP
description: A major reason why the Breeders' Cup is offering $10 million in purses is that all those strong American dollars were supposed to attract the best horses from around the world. Indeed, more than a quarter of the 73 horses expected to run in the seven rich cup races at Hollywood Park here Saturday have done most of their racing in Europe. But they appear more of an embarrassment than a credit to their homelands.

title: DISINFECTION OF SEWAGE IS ORDERED YEAR-ROUND
description: In an attempt to reopen what were once some of the most prized shellfish beds in North America, an agency that monitors sewage discharges in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut has ordered many communities in the region to increase their levels of treatment.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
ELITE COLLEGES TRAIN TEACHERS
description: THE more Ted Spieth thought about his career choice, the more convinced he became that he would like to teach in a public school. So, now a college senior, he finished his student teaching last week and will be certified to teach when he graduates in June.

title: RAJIV GANDHI FACES BIG FOREIGN POLICY TASK
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, faced with the task of securing his own political position while bringing domestic stability to the country, has also inherited some formidable foreign policy problems.

title: HONDA DEALERS SIGN WITH NEEDHAM HARPER
description: Needham Harper Worldwide's New York office has been tapped to do advertising for the Tri-State Honda Dealers of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware and also for the Greater Pittsburgh Honda Dealers.

description: Nov. 6, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Robbers Get Million in Gems
description: Two men who posed as diamond salesmen held up a jewelry concern in the diamond district in mid-Manhattan yesterday and escaped with between $1.4 million and $1.7 million in gems, the police said.

title: TRAFFIC STILL CLOGGED BY REPAIRS, BUT OFFICIALS REVISE PLANS AND OFFER HOPE
description: As traffic officials struggle with a growing wave of highway reconstruction, Manhattan is a joyless isle for those who must drive into its business districts every day.

title: Dixville Notch Votes For Reagan, 29 to 1
description: Thirty voters in this isolated White Mountain hamlet cast the nation's first ballots early today and voted almost unanimously to re-elect President Reagan.

title: Harold Donohue Dies; Was Member of House
description: Harold D. Donohue, a Democrat who served 14 terms in the House of Representatives, died Sunday at the age of 83.

title: ETHIOPIA'S FISTULA HOSPITAL OFFERS HOPE TO DESPERATE WOMEN
description: ADDIS ABABA, ETHIOPIA ONE woman crawled on her hands and knees from a village 10 miles away to get here. Another came from an isolated village in the province Gojam, lying in the aisle of a bus for three days on a makeshift stretcher.

title: CANCER GENES DESCRIBED AS HAVING JEKYLL AND HYDE ROLE

title: CHESS MATCH: A DRAW AGAIN
description: The 22d game of the world chess championship match ended in a draw today after Gary Kasparov, the challenger, made his 20th move.

title: Undecided on '88
description: The president of the Soviet Olympic Committee, Marat Gramov, said in a newspaper report in Mexico that his country had not yet made a decision whether to attend the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea. In the newspaper La Jornada of Mexico City, where the General Assembly of National Olympic Committees is scheduled to meet today to explore ways to avert future Olympic boycotts, Gramov was quoted as saying: ''It is not true that the Soviet Union will say it is not going to Seoul.

title: MIDWEST ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

An Explanation For Fiery Object EDINBURG, Texas, Nov. 5 (UPI) - A fiery object that streaked across the Texas sky, accompanied by an explosive sound, was probably a meteor, a scientist said today. Ed LeMaster, physicial sciences professor at Edinburg University, said one or more fragments from a meteor shower may have come down in the area.
description: The object was reported by dozens of people Sunday night who later jammed law enforcement switchboards.

title: Conductor Loses Job Over Ride
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that it had dismissed a subway conductor who took 80 passengers on an unscheduled ride when they refused to get off a train being taken out of service.

title: New Levitz Offer To Be Disclosed
description: Trading in the stock of the Levitz Furniture Corporation was halted today on the New York Stock Exchange pending an announcement of an offer to buy the company in a leveraged buyout. Robert M. Elliott, chairman of Levitz, said a private group, the members of which he did not identify, planned to present the offer to the company's directors Tuesday.

title: THUNANDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1984
description: International Offices, banks and stores reopened in New Delhi for the first time since the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi last Wednesday. Commuters, shoppers and tourists crowded the streets and traffic moved normally. (Page A1, Col. 2.) Ten South African blacks died as hundreds of thousands of workers and students boycotted jobs and schools in an anti-Government protest. Police officers used rubber bullets, buckshot and tear gas against the demonstrators in black townships around Johannesburg and Pretoria. (A1:1.)

title: SIKHS BEGIN TO REAPPEAR IN PUBLIC
description: Offices, banks and most stores reopened in the capital today for the first time since the assassination last Wednesday of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company Consolidated said yesterday that William H. Dougherty, formerly vice chairman of the Southeast Banking Corporation in Miami, had been named vice chairman and chief financial officer. The appointment is effective Nov. 15.

title: 4-VEHICLE COLLISION KILLS 1 AND HURTS 41
description: A Union County man was killed and 41 people, most of them students, were injured today when a car pulled in front of a school bus and triggered a four-vehicle collision, authorities said.

Swiss Bank Plans Bid For London Brokerage

title: AMERICAN FIRST CORP (OKLAHOMA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Philippine Debt Accord
description: The Philippine Government and a bankers group have agreed on a plan to restructure the nation's repayment of $5.8 billion in foreign debt and to extend nearly $4 billion in new loans and trade facilities, officials announced today. The governor of the Philippines central bank, Jose B. Fernandez Jr., said the bank group, headed by Manufacturers Hanover Bank of New York, had recommended that the Philippines' 483 creditor banks approve the plan. It calls for rescheduling payment of $5.8 billion of the Philippines' $26 billion foreign debt over 10 years, with no principal due in the first five years.

title: Playoff Toll Call
description: Paul Hardin, the president of Drew University in Madison, N.J., is upset over an administrative error that kept Drew's women's field hockey team out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III championship tournament.

title: French in Guadeloupe Hold 7 Haiti Dissidents
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Nov. 5 (Reuters) - Seven Haitians opposed to President Jean-Claude Duvalier were detained Friday aboard a boat with arms and ammunition, the French police said today.

description: Stock prices rose sharply in slower trading yesterday, buoyed by investors' optimism that interest rates will decline.

title: 2 Sides of George Bush
description: Vice President Bush has done and said much in the campaign to give the lie to intimations that he is a foppish ''preppy'' with snobbish values and attitudes. He has talked tough, even vulgar, at times, to efface such an image.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Washington Watch column in Business Day yesterday misstated the outcome of the 1968 election. The Republican Party regained the White House.

title: ALL-OUT SEASON FOR HUSKIES
description: The Washington Huskies have a simple explanation for how they've managed to stay ranked No. 1 in the nation in the news-agency college football polls for the last four weeks.

title: POLL EXPERTS ATTRIBUTE DISPARITIES TO DIFFERENCES IN METHODS
description: The various public opinion polls agree that President Reagan is in a position to be re-elected by a large margin Tuesday, but they differ substantially on the size of the gap.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INCOME SECURIIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rising Popularity Of Bond Warrants
description: Anticipation of lower interest rates and rising bond prices is strong enough so that many new financings in the Eurodollar bond market are being offered with warrants that give investors the option of buying fixed- rate bonds at a specified price in the future. Investors are attracted to low- cost warrants because their price would rise sharply if interest rates declined.

title: ADS BY ASPIRIN GROUP CRITICIZED
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that televised announcements discounting a possible link between aspirin and the childhood illness Reye's Syndrome were ''misleading'' and ''potentially dangerous.''

description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of Direct Marketing Agency Inc., which was acquired during the latest quarter and Caribiner Inc. and Ventura Associates Inc. which was acquired during the first quarter. These were accounted for as a purchase.

title: BAD OLD ELECTION DAYS
description: Desp ite President Reagan's large apparent lead, there are bound to be close state and local races today, so it is important that the counts be honest and accurate. That has not always been the case. In New York City, elections in recent years have been without serious incident, but it has been otherwise. I worked for years at the polls in various capacities and recall incidents of fraud and violence - in one case, a poll-watcher was killed.

title: JURT HEARS DEPOSITION FROM EX-AIDE IN CBS TRIAL
description: A. FARBER

title: BUSH ASKS TEXANS FOR '4 MORE YEARS'
description: Vice President Bush, confining his last day of campaigning to his adopted state, today re-emphasized his overall themes of pride, prosperity and peace.

title: A Tycoon With a New Bank
description: If a judge's bench, a professor's classroom, city hall and the ballot box represent kinds of power, the small, dimly lighted back office at the Chapman Printing Company is another. There, suited, tied and chewing Red Man tobacco, sits Marshall T. Reynolds, this economically depressed town's self- made tycoon.

title: Florida Given New Appeal Date
description: The University of Florida reported today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association had extended the deadline for the school to decide whether to appeal a three-year probation dealt its football program because of various rules violations.

description: Dow Jones & Company and a group of four investors have offered $112 million for the stock of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, a large communications organization, according to Michael G. Gartner, the Register and Tribune's president and one of the prospective investors.

title: European Studies
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones is broadening his education. He is leaving for Europe today to study programs that prepare students for jobs.

title: ISLAND'S FORMULA FOR CHANGE: PART POLITICS, PART TOLERANCE AND PART TV
description: Change is in the air in San Juan.
