title: A Saudi Jet Is Hijacked To Iran With 127 Aboard
description: A Saudi jetliner was hijacked early today on a London-to-Riyadh flight and taken to Iran with 113 passengers and 14 crew members aboard, the Saudi state radio reported.

title: LESSONS OF THE U.S.S. IOWA
description: The U.S.S. Iowa was expecting a tranquil mooring when it opened itself to the public in Brooklyn last month. Instead, the old World War II battleship, which has been taken out of mothballs and retrofitted so that it can carry nuclear weapons, has been rocked with attacks that it is a ''holocaust machine,'' exposing New York to a nuclear accident similar to the one threatening the globe. Whatever the substance of such protestors' fears - in fact, the Navy has neither confirmed nor denied that the ship is carrying nuclear weapons - this is a sadly telling incident, a symbol of all too many Americans' view of our military and civilian leaders and indeed of the nation itself.

title: EISENHOWER WARNED ON MILITARY SPENDING
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Dance Company
description: Antonio Gades, the Spanish dancer and choreographer, will perform at the New York City Center with his company in a three-week season beginning Jan. 29. Mr. Gades is former director of the National Ballet of Spain. His program will include the New York premiere of ''Carmen,'' with Cristina Hoyos.

title: MCA'S NET DECLINES BY 23.2%
description: Two entertainment companies reported quarterly earnings yesterday. MCA Inc., said its profit in the third quarter fell 23.2 percent as revenues edged up 1.5 percent.

title: HELIX CIRCUITS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUBLISHER IS OBJECT OF G.&.W. BID
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it would make a $70- a-share tender offer for all the outstanding common stock of Prentice- Hall Inc., its first big acquisition attempt after two years of divestitures.

title: CONFUSION SURROUNDS BABY FAE
description: The saving grace is that Baby Fae is still alive. Her new heart has now beaten more than two million times, and with every new beat the thriving infant makes history as the longest surviving human recipient of a transplanted animal heart.

title: 5 HIGH SIKH PRIESTS STRUGGLE WITH A NEW POLITICAL ROLE AND A DISPUTE OVER IT
description: In days gone by, whenever the head priests of this country's five major Sikh temples met at the Golden Temple here, they would mainly discuss theology.

title: Laos Says It Has Closed Its Re-education Camps
description: An American professor said here today that he had been told in Laos that ''re-education camps'' set up after 1975 had been dismantled.

title: Symphony Official Tells Of Canceling Redgrave
description: Canceling Vanessa Redgrave's 1982 appearances with the Boston Symphony Orchestra was harder than allowing her to perform, an orchestra executive testified today at the trial of the actress's $5 million suit against the organization.

title: FILM ADAPTATIONS DRAWING CRITICISM
description: It's been a bountiful period for movies made from books, but relations between the film makers and the authors or their admirers remain as testy as ever. Among the works that have made it to the screen in recent months, in some form, are Malcolm Lowry's ''Under the Volcano,'' Henry James's ''The Bostonians,'' Marcel Proust's ''Swann's Way,'' Bernard Malamud's ''The Natural'' and John Le Carre's ''The Little Drummer Girl.'' In every case, some critics have found that they failed to do justice to the original work.

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WHY EQUITABLE WANTS BROKER
description: In its bid for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is seeking a company that may offer it business advantages down the road.

title: WELFARE AGENCY CALLS GIRL'S CASE POORLY HANDLED
description: The Human Resources Administration said yesterday that improper handling by the agency contributed to a case in which a malnourished 7-year- old girl, left alone in a Queens apartment, was not rescued until she telephoned an operator for help last week.

title: JETS EYEING HOLMES
description: The Giants are not yet a Super Bowl team. So far they are not even a playoff team. They are merely a team with a 6-4 record, tied for their division lead and playing well.

title: Politics of the Past
description: An old-fashioned political parade

title: A CHANGE IN CHILE
description: Until the resignation of his Cabinet in Santiago today, it appeared that President Augusto Pinochet could ignore the persistent calls for talks that have been coming from the opposition parties and the Roman Catholic Church. But Interior Minister Sergio Onofre Jarpa's decision to resign could make General Pinochet reconsider his hard-line stance. If he does not give Mr. Jarpa a freer hand in dealing with the opposition and keep him in the Cabinet, some officials believe that the former diplomat and conservative politician could decide to join the opposition.

title: RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After a loss of $4,535,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $499,000 for the quarter and 1,926,000 for the year. The company said results for the latest quarter are after a charge of $14,770,000, after taxes, from the closing of a textile manufacturing plant in Ware Shoals, South Carolina.

title: NEW YORK'S HARVEST DRAWS A STREAM OF MIGRANT LABOR
description: For the last 7 of her 28 years, Geraldine Alexander has been a migrant farm worker. During the winter and spring, she has picked oranges in the South. In the fall, she comes north to New York to pick apples for $125 to $150 a week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This Cabinet crisis reflects the crisis of a Government that has nothing to offer the country except the President's will to stay in power under a Constitution that the majority of Chileans do not accept.'' - Ricardo Lagos, president of Democratic Alliance, a Chilean opposition group. (A1:4.)

title: SOUTH AFRICA, ON 'PRIVATE VISIT,' MEETS WITH SHAMIR IN JERUSALEM
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, met today with Yitzhak Shamir, his Israeli counterpart, as part of what Israeli officials described as a ''private visit.''

title: DEMOCRATS FEAR BLACK APATHY BUT HOPE FOR RUSH TO THE POLLS
description: Four years ago, President Reagan won this state by 11,000 votes. He was the victor in Arkansas by a mere 5,000 votes, and in Alabama he beat Jimmy Carter by 17,400 votes.

title: 358 U.S. Observers Going To 4 States' Voting Sites
description: Attorney General William French Smith has ordered 358 Federal observers stationed at polling places in Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi and North Carolina to avert racial discrimination.

title: Texas Eastern To Sell Unit HOUSTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said it would sell its Transwestern Pipeline Company

title: SPACE SALVAGE: LOST SATELLITES ARE THE PRIZE
description: TWO little satellites that went astray out in the vastness of space, written off as lost by owners but never entirely abandoned by resourceful engineers and hopeful insurors, await rescue by American astronauts who are set to embark Wednesday on the first space salvage mission.

title: MAYOR APPOINTS NEW FINANCE CHIEF
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named Paul A. Crotty the city's Finance Commissioner.

title: NETWORKS PREPARE FOR RATINGS BATTLE
description: The November ratings sweeps period, the first important determinant of advertising rates for local stations, indicates the predicament into which ABC - now in the No. 3 position for the first time in many years - has been thrown by NBC's recent surge of strength.

title: ABC News Shifts Policy On Early Projections
description: ABC News announced yesterday that it would refrain in its election night broadcasts from ''characterizing'' probable winners before the polls close in a given state.

title: TOUCH OF NEW YORK
description: John Sloan and John Marin were artists who lived and worked in the New York of the early 1900's and loved the city. They could conjure up pictures of New York that would make you wonder if they were thinking of the same place - but that is also typical New York, the infinite views of an infinitely changing place.

description: GREAT numbers of black and Hispanic candidates for teaching licenses are being eliminated as most states introduce competency tests. Bernard R. Gifford, dean of the Graduate School of Education at the University of California at Berkeley, calls the high failure rate among minority groups ''horrifying'' and ''unacceptable.'' At the same time, he emphatically rejects any lowering of standards for minorities.

title: Tunisian Leader in Hospital
description: Habib Bourguiba, the 81-year-old President of Tunisia, was admitted to the cardiology department of a Tunis hospital today, his office announced. His doctors said he was admitted for ''surveillance'' and ''appropriate treatment.'' Mr. Bourguiba has led Tunisia since independence in 1956.

title: 7 Arrested in Clashes As Plane Plant Is Struck
description: Police officers and firefighters used fire hoses to stop strikers from throwing bottles hours after 6,400 workers struck the Fort Worth division of the General Dynamics Corporation today.

description: Basketball Knicks vs. Mavericks , at Dallas. With Bill Cartwright still recovering from injury, the Knicks have been beaten badly up front throughout their road trip.

title: OCT.21-31 CAR SALES INCREASED 3.3%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 3.3 percent in the Oct. 21-31 period from the comparable period a year before, despite strikes against the General Motors Corporation's Canadian plants that held down G.M. sales. The daily combined selling rate of 27,184 reported by the six domestic auto companies today was the highest in the late October period since 1979.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS SHIFT IN PARTY LOYALTY IN ELECTION TODAY
description: With months of campaigning at an end, the nation's voters choose today between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale in an election that is also being watched as a test of long-term trends in party loyalty and Congressional power.

description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: Tribute to Rodgers
description: A tribute to the composer Richard Rodgers, featuring manuscripts, sheet music, costumes and other items, will begin on Nov. 20 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, Broadway and 65th Street. Over 150 items from private and public collections will be on view through Feb. 2. Exhibition hours are Monday and Thursday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, noon to 6 P.M. and Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: AARON RENTS OF ATLANTA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHIEF OF FRONTIER HOLDINGS RESIGNS
description: Glen L. Ryland, chairman, chief executive officer and president of Frontier Holdings Inc. and its subsidiary, Frontier Airlines, resigned all his positions at both companies yesterday, ending a career that began in 1971.

title: Thanks, America
description: Grand Duke Jean, the constitutional monarch of Luxembourg since 1964, will make his first official visit to this country Nov. 11- 19. Luxembourg's Ambassador to the United States, Paul Peters, said 1984 was chosen for the visit because this year Luxembourg is celebrating the 40th anniversary of its two World War II liberations, both by the United States Army.

title: POLISH DISSIDENTS ASK JARUZELSKI TO RESIGN OVER SLAYING OF PRIEST
description: A group of Polish dissidents said today that recent official criticism of the activities of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a pro-Solidarity priest, had created ''the basis and the climate'' for his slaying.

title: Taiwan Store Fire Kills 2
description: A fire in a department store on the lower floors of a building in Taichung killed 2 people, injured 28 and forced 260 to the 12th story roof, where 5 helicopters shuttled them to safety, the police said. They said 3 people were missing and feared dead. A gas leak was thought to have caused the fire.

title: DO DRIVES NEED CLEANING?
description: HOW often should diskette drives be cleaned? A survey of manufacturers, computer dealers and service technicians yielded conflicting suggestions.

title: SANDINISTA CLAIMS BIG ELECTION VICTORY
description: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the presidential candidate of the governing Sandinista National Liberation Front, claimed today that he and his party had won an overwhelming victory in the first elections here in 10 years.

description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation questioned in 1972 whether the offices of the Democratic National Commmittee were actually bugged by the Watergate burglars, according to Justice Department documents and a new book on the case.

title: DECEMBER SHUTTLE FLIGHT POSTPONED

But later, when the freshness and shine have worn off, it takes special effort to keep productions from turning to fool's gold. The Metropolitan Opera's ''Barbiere di Siviglia,'' which had its first performance of the season last evening, showed a need of polishing here and there but it had the necessary glitter most of the time.

Ferraro last night ended her three-month effort to become the first woman to be elected Vice President, telling students that her candidacy showed that Americans ''should be able to reach as far as our dreams will take us.''

Treatment for Plager
description: Barclay Plager, the assistant coach of the St. Louis Blues, will undergo radiation treatment and chemotherapy for a brain tumor, according to team doctors. Physicians say the 43-year-old Plager will be treated over the next six weeks as an outpatient at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis.

title: West Germany Elects Speaker of Parliament
description: Philipp Jenninger, an adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, was elected the Speaker of Parliament today to replace Rainer Barzel, who resigned in a scandal.

description: Secretary of State Geroge P. Shultz will attend the autumn meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Foreign Ministers in Brussels on Dec. 13 and 14, the State Department announced today.

title: Financing Needed In Riegel Buyout
description: The Riegel Textile Corporation said an investor group, including its chairman, R.E. Coleman, and other management members, had been unable so far to secure commitments for all the financing required in its proposed acquisition of Riegel. The company said the group continues to seek financing.

title: UNESCO REPORTED TO MOVE AWAY FROM ISSUE OF LICENSING REPORTERS
description: A longtime critic of the communications policies of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said yesterday that the agency's Director General had sent him a statement of Unesco policy that represents a ''significant shift'' away from involvement with the issue of licensing journalists.

title: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP ; NEW CASE COULD CLARIFY RULES ON CAR SEARCHES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to try once again to clarify one of the most confused areas of constitutional laws: the extent to which the police may search an automobile without a warrant.

title: Bonds Are Priced On Port Authority
description: A $100 million bond issue of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was tentatively priced at 100 with a coupon of 9 percent through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Bethlehem Steel Corporation misstated its ranking in the industry. It is the third-largest producer.

description: ''Shanti,'' said the khaki-turbaned Sikh police sergeant, who sat on a rough wooden bench surveying knots of his co-religionists, barefoot and subdued, entering the golden-domed Bangla Sahib temple for prayer. ''Peace.''

title: IN BIRDS, NICE LEGS GET WHISTLES
description: THE color of a bird's legs may influence its mating behavior. Nancy Burley, a University of Illinois ornithologist who was studying the mating behavior of zebra finches, tagged a group of finches that had been individually marked with different colored leg bands and then released them into an aviary.

title: HIGH COURT BARS N.F.L. CONTROL OF FRANCHISE SHIFTS
description: The National Football League today lost its legal battle for the right to prevent member teams from moving from city to city.

description: A Federal bankruptcy judge refused to issue a temporary restraining order preventing Braniff Inc. from operating 10 of its jets in a joint service agreement with Northeastern International Airlines.

description: To appreciate what E. L. Doctorow is up to in his sixth and latest work of fiction, ''Lives of the Poets: Six Stories and a Novella,'' you have to judge not the separate pieces in the book, but their relationship and the process of their unfolding.

The share earnings a year ago were restated for Oct. 31, 1983, 1-for-2 reverse stock split.

title: DEFENSES HURT KING BUT DON'T STOP HIM
description: Bernard King is ailing. A hip is bruised, his fingers are jammed, the right ankle is sore and a knee is strained.

Charges Reinstated
description: A judge today reinstated all charges against the five defendants in the ''Twilight Zone'' movie accident, including two counts of involuntary manslaughter based on child endangering against the director John Landis. The charges stemmed from the deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children during the shooting of a helicopter crash scene in the film ''Twilight Zone - The Movie.''

title: McKay Quits as Coach
description: John McKay, the only coach in the nine-year history of the Buccaneers, announced in Tampa that he would resign at the end of the season. At a news conference attended by Hugh Culverhouse, the Bucs' owner, McKay said that he was ''sorry I couldn't get the job done, but we tried.''

title: THERESA SALDANA PLAYS HERSELF AS VICTIM ON NBC
description: Next week on an NBC television movie Theresa Saldana - who played Robert DeNiro's sister in ''Raging Bull'' - will portray a woman who responds to a vicious knife assault by founding a support group for victims of violent crime. In this instance the plot will be based on actual events that befell Miss Saldana.

title: Ex-Philadelphia Officer Changes Plea to Guilty
description: A former Philadelphia police officer changed his plea to guilty today as jury selection began in the trial of five fellow officers on extortion charges.

description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, said today that the United States and its allies bore full responsibility for a world situation that he said could cause alarm.

title: Pact for Skelgas
description: Texaco Inc. said it had entered into a definitive agreement to sell Skelgas Inc. to Synergy Group Inc. of Farmingdale, L.I. Terms were not disclosed. Texaco said the sale was another step in its plan to sell selected assets of the Getty Oil Company, which it acquired earlier this year. Skelgas markets propane in 16 states.

title: Council Won't Review Hospital's Zoning Plea
description: The White Plains Common Council tonight voted, 7 to 0, not to consider or review an application by New York Hospital to rezone 180 acres of the hospital's land for a $500 million development of offices, stores and apartments.

description: Despite a nationwide landslide for President Reagan, Lieut. Gov. John F. Kerry, a liberal Democrat, defeated Raymond Shamie, a conservative Republican businessman, today for the Senate seat vacated by Paul E. Tsongas.

description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday broke with a tradition that may go as far back as the 1792 Presidential contest, when George Washington ran unopposed for re-election, by remaining open - and booming - on the day of a Presidential election.

description: The Thai Army sent reinforcements today to push out Vietnamese soldiers who overran a border post inside Thailand, army officers said.

title: FIVE LEGISLATORS IN BID TO DELAY TIME SQ. PLAN
description: Five elected officials and the head of the Clinton community board have called on the Board of Estimate to postpone the vote scheduled tomorrow on the Times Square redevelopment plan.

title: Nets Activating King
description: Albert King, the Nets' forward who has been on the injured list since the start of the regular season because of a sprained back, will be in uniform tonight when New Jersey faces the Washington Bullets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Nets said, however, that King won't be activated until sometime this morning, after the latest tests are conducted on Darryl Dawkins, the team's starting center.

title: ABC SHOULD PAY MORE, PATERNO SAYS
description: Joe Paterno, Penn State'shead coach, says the College Football Association deserves much more than the $12 million it is getting from ABC Sports for television rights to the association's games this season. And, in support of his argument, Paterno points to the profit that the network made last summer from the Los Angeles Olympics.

description: Richard Frem, 37 years old, of 4745

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Marietta Executive Seeks NASA Pact
description: Martin Marietta Aerospace, a subsidiary of the military contractor, said yesterday that it had formed a seven-company team to compete for major elements of the National Aeronautic and Space Administration's upcoming space station program. The unit said that the team would be led by James W. McCown, a vice president and space station manager for Martin Marietta.

title: Chief's Crown Fails to Persuade Critics;  Faces Test in Breeders' Cup
description: Wayne Lukas and Woody Stephens are the leading trainers in the country this year and have handled more good young horses than anyone else in the sport over the last few years. Lukas has sent out the last two favorites for the Kentucky Derby, and Stephens's horses have won the last three Belmont Stakes.

title: 2 PLEAD INNOCENT IN DEATHS ON SET
description: Two film makers pleaded innocent today to revived manslaughter charges in the deaths of actor Vic Morrow and two children during filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' in 1982.

ECONOMY THE KEY ISSUE
description: For all the careful orchestration of campaign rallies and political commercials, the televised debates, the partisan clashes over fine points of foreign and military policy, it was the economy that set the basic pattern for President Reagan's stunning re- election sweep yesterday and that fueled Republican gains in Congress.

title: JACK HABER, 45, FORMER EDITOR OF MEN'S FASHION MAGAZINES
description: Jack Haber, former editor in chief of Gentleman's Quarterly, died Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INFILTRATION ASSESSMENTS DEFENDED AT CBS TRIAL
description: A military intelligence officer testified yesterday that, contrary to statements made by CBS in a 1982 documentary, North Vietnamese infiltration into South Vietnam in 1967 was not understated by Gen. William C. Westmoreland's command.

title: Credit Market Mostly Quiet
description: While the Government securities market was closed on Election Day, activity in other sectors of the credit markets was listless, with no significant changes in interest rates.

title: Catholics and the No-Bias Pledge The nation's largest Catholic diocese, embracing Brooklyn and Queens, has affirmed that there is no conflict between its faith and a promise not to discriminate against homosexual job applicants. That is noteworthy because Archbishop John O'Connor of the neighboring New York archdiocese has so aggressively taken the opposite view.
description: The issue arose because Mayor Koch, by executive order, required agencies with which the city contracts for social services to pledge that they would not discriminate in hiring for those programs. Archbishop O'Connor, while denying any actual discrimination, insists that the pledge amounts to church ''approval'' of homosexuality, which he feels theologically unable to give. To avoid loss of the contracts, he challenged the Mayor's right to issue such an order and won a state court ruling that anti-bias rules require legislative action, not a mere executive order.

title: COKE, PEPSI TO USE MORE CORN SYRUP
description: Pepsico Inc. and the Coca-Cola Company, the two giants of the soft- drink industry, said in separate announcements yesterday that they would significantly increase the use of a corn-based sweetener in their regular and caffeine-free cola drinks in the United States.

title: Mediator Reopens Talks In Strike in Fort Worth
description: A Federal mediator called company and union representatives back to the bargaining table Tuesday, while for the second day the police were called to quell violence on the picket line at the General Dynamics plant.

description: AS a dancer, Dan Wagoner resembles a graceful teddy bear. As a choreographer, he has yet to recognize the plumb line in any single body. In short, he is a master of quirky invention, of the odd shape, the unexpected movement.

title: West German Inflation
description: West Germany's cost of living climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in October from September and 2.1 percent from the year before, the Government's statistics office said today. The index had 12-month increases of 1.7 percent in August and 1.5 percent in September, indicating a slight acceleration of inflation in the latest month, the agency said.

title: GUNMEN HUNTED NEAR BUFFALO
description: State troopers, a tracking dog and a helicopter searching for three men who held four employees at a supermarket in Eden, N.Y., early yesterday morning.

title: Man Who Sued to Get Off Respirator Is Dead
description: William F. Bartling, a salesman whose legal fight to force his hospital to disconnect a life-sustaining respirator drew national attention died this afternoon. He was 70 years old.

title: Motorola Files Trade Complaint
description: Motorola Inc. said it had filed a petition with the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission asking that anti-dumping action be taken against Japanese manufacturers selling cellular car telephones in the United States. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., said the Japanese companies were severely injuring the domestic cellular industry and that millions of dollars in sales and profits had already been lost.

title: Ex-Police Minister in Soviet Is Stripped of General's Rank
description: Nikolai S. Shchelokov, the Interior Minister who was dismissed in June 1983 in a campaign against corruption, has been stripped of his military rank as a general, the press agency Tass said today.

title: MET OPERA: 'IL BARBIERE,' WITH HAMARI IN DEBUT
description: WHEN opera productions are new, they ought to gleam like gold and sometimes do. But later, when the freshness and shine have worn off, it takes special effort to keep productions from turning to fool's gold. The Metropolitan Opera's ''Barbiere di Siviglia,'' which had its first performance of the season on Monday evening, showed a need of polishing here and there but it had the necessary glitter most of the time.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The New York Times/CBS News exit poll is based on questionnaires completed by 3,258 voters as they left polling places in 190 randomly selected precincts in all parts of the United States.

title: Diablo Canyon Nuclear Plant Is Gearing Up To Full Power
description: Half of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant was gearing up to full power today, and operators said it could be generating electricity as soon as Wednesday.

title: Hostages on Saudi Plane Tackle Hijackers in Iran

title: COOKWARE FROM ITALY
description: WHEN it comes to innovative design in cookware, the Italians have led the field in recent years. Some of the most handsome and efficient pots, pans and machines of all sorts have been coming out of Italy - and with the strong dollar versus the lira, prices have been relatively low.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation's newest personal computer, the PC-AT, has gotten off to a strong start and is already in short supply.

title: NICARAGUA SAID TO GET SOVIET ATTACK COPTERS
description: Nicaragua has received a number of Soviet-built attack helicopters in recent days, a senior Administration official said Tuesday night. He said the White House viewed their delivery as a ''very serious development.''

title: MUSIC: MAHLER'S FIFTH, LONDON PHILHARMONIC
description: THE 1984 American tour of the London Philharmonic Orchestra marks its first visit here in eight years, and its first since Klaus Tennstedt took over as music director last year. The second of the orchestra's two Carnegie Hall concerts Monday night - the first, on Sunday, was devoted to a conventional Beethoven-Brahms bill - was dominated by Mahler's massive Symphony No. 5, with Schubert's ''Unfinished'' Symphony as the curtain-raiser.

title: RECITAL: LUCY SHELTON
description: THE future of the song recital, if it is to have one, lies largely in the hands of a few young singers like Lucy Shelton who go on exploring unfamiliar music, exploring behind the words and notes of familiar music, and caring about the individual dramatic life of each short song.

description: The trial of six Yugoslav dissidents charged with counterrevolutionary activities reconvened briefly today before it was recessed for two days to allow a newly appointed defense lawyer to prepare his case.

title: KLEIN'S SPRING LOOK: FLUID AND FLATTERING
description: CALVIN KLEIN rarely makes grandiose claims about his contribution to fashion. When asked about his work, he often says he makes the kind of clothes he likes and hopes women would like to wear. After showing his spring collection yesterday morning, he went a little further. He didn't want to get political, he said, referring to Election Day, but he said he believed ''we are moving into conservatism.''

title: CHALLENGER LEADS PUERTO RICO RACE
description: A former Governor, Rafael Hernandez Colon, tonight took a commanding lead over the incumbent in the commonwealth's bitterly contested gubernatorial election.

title: CRABLE SEEMS OUT FOR SEASON
description: Bob Crable, the Jets' middle linebacker, is scheduled to undergo arthroscopic surgery today on his left knee, and will then be moved to the team's injured reserve list, probably for the remainder of the season.

title: SUPPLIER BECOMES RETAILER
description: When a longtime supplier opens its own store in direct competition with the retailers it serves, a rather delicate situation can develop.

title: RAJIV GANDHI IS SAID TO HAVE ALSO BEEN A TARGET
description: The surviving Sikh accused of killing Indira Gandhi has told investigators that he was also to have killed Rajiv Gandhi, now Prime Minister, if he had been with his mother on the morning of the assassination, The Statesman, one of India's most respected newspapers, reported today.

description: The three major commercial networks declared Ronald Reagan the winner of this year's Presidential election last night while voters were still casting their ballots in nearly half the states around the country.

description: The parents of Baby Fae are accepting bids from publications willing to pay for the story of the world's longest-living recipient of an animal heart transplant.

description: In a game that heightened a collegiate soccer rivalry that is developing into the strongest in the metropolitan area, Columbia defeated Long Island University, 3-2, in overtime at Baker Field yesterday.

title: NEW WEAPONS USED IN DRIVE ON CORRUPTION
description: The bribing of New York City inspectors - a problem the authorities call pervasive - has become the target of new law enforcement strategies that some officials say offer hope of changing long-entrenched patterns of corruption.

title: Red Wings 4, Canadiens 2
description: Ron Duguay and Ivan Boldirev scored power-play goals and the goaltender Corrado Micalef turned aside 22 shots in pacing the Detroit triumph. Duguay converted Kelly Kisio's centering pass midway through the second period for his ninth goal of the season and a 3-0 lead.

title: A CHEF'S OWN TOUCH IN AUSTRIAN CUISINE
description: ONE of Austria's most highly praised chefs is Karl Eschlb"ock, the proprietor of his family's hotel and restaurant, the Hotel Eschlb"ock in Mondsee, a sailing and mountain-climbing resort outside Salzburg. His skills have been compared with those of Paul Bocuse in France and Fredy Girardet in Switzerland; his clientele have names like Getty, Niarchos and von Karajan; his dishes bear an undeniable hallmark of creativity and inventiveness.

title: And Still Champion Who's your choice, a New York Times/CBS News Poll asked last January, Reagan or Mondale? The President came out ahead by 16 points. Yesterday, all America answered the same question and the answer, after endless months of campaign, was nearly the same.
description: It's possible, in other words, that everything that happened in between was just a digression. The voters, it appears, made up their minds about Ronald Reagan a long time ago. They like him and trust him - and the Democrats could do nothing to change their minds. So this genial man, who has built a brilliant political career out of being underestimated, has won a smashing re-election, and with it the congratulations and respect of all Americans.

title: RAJIV GANDHI AND SIKHS MEET AND HE OFFERS REASSURANCES
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi met today with a delegation of prominent Sikhs and told them the Sikh people should not be condemned for the assassination of his mother, Indira Gandhi, by ''two misguided individuals.''

title: CELEBRATING CAPITALISM
description: The report of the Lay Commission on Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy is a strong celebration of the capitalist system and the individual entrepreneur, not the government, as the true benefactors of the poor and jobless. The committee, headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, with Michael Novak, a writer and theologian based at the American Enterprise Institute, as co-chairman and the report's prime author, apparently believed that the forthcoming pastoral letter of Roman Catholic bishops would put too little stress on the creative role of capitalists and too much emphasis on the role of the state.

description: Josephine Morris, 79 years old, collapsed in a voting booth here today and apparently died of a heart attack despite efforts by paramedics to revive her, officials said. A. James Manchin, the Secretary of State, who was nearby, ruled that the woman's partly completed ballot could be counted. ''She made the supreme sacrifice in the true spirit of the American patriot'' by going to vote despite a heart condition, Mr. Manchin said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1984 The 1984 Elections Ronald Wilson Reagan won a second term as President in an election that Republican leaders hailed as a sweeping personal triumph and a mandate for his policies. The three commercial networks declared Ronald Reagan the winner of the Presidential election while voters were still casting ballots in nearly half the 50 states. (A21:4-6.)

title: Johnson Layoffs

title: EVEN THE MOST ELEGANT FOODS ARE AVAILABLE BY MAIL
description: THE speed with which packages fly across the country and around the world has put even the most perishable foods within almost everyone's reach. It is no longer possible to complain that exotic ingredients and elegant ready-to-eat foods are unavailable because the only specialty shop in town has nothing more esoteric than Brie. Mail-order foods are especially useful now, with the holiday season almost upon us and time for shopping at a premium.

title: HELMS BEATS HUNT TO STAY IN SENATE
description: Senator Jesse Helms easily won election to a third term tonight over Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. after a tough and expensive campaign. Mr. Helms, a Republican, accepted victory at 11:10 P.M., telling his supporters, ''You have sent a signal throughout the world that North Carolina is a God-fearing, conservative state.'' The campaign was the most expensive Senate race in United States history and one of the most mean-spirited in the nation this year. Hunt. Since spring, polls had showed the race to be a dead heat, and Mr. Helms clearly benefited from President Reagan's easy victory in the state. The President captured more than 60 percent of the North Carolina vote.

title: Nobody Won in Nicaragua
description: Only the naive believe that Sunday's election in Nicaragua was democratic or legitimizing proof of the Sandinistas' popularity. The result was ordained when opposition parties tamely accepted terms that barred them from power. This plebiscite will not end the struggle for pluralism in Nicaragua. But neither can it serve as justification for recent American policy.

description: The police said today that they did not have enough evidence to book the man a newspaper reporter said took him on a harrowing nightlong ride while threatening to ''blow his head off.''

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1984 Markets Stocks soared to their best levels since they began climbing in early August, lifted in part by market expectations of lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 14.91 points, to 1,244.15, after climbing 12 points Monday. Volume was 101.3 million shares, surprisingly high since many banks and businesses were closed for Election Day. (Page D1.) The Election Day trading broke a tradition that may go as far back as 1792, when George Washington ran unopposed. But some traders opposed the change. (D12.) The dollar advanced broadly in a quiet session as traders awaited the election results. Gold fell $2.50 in New York, to $345. (D20.) Grain and soybean futures posted a modest recovery. (D20.)

title: NEGOTIATIONS BREAK OFF IN STRIKE AGAINST 11 NURSING HOMES IN CITY

title: Downgraded at L.S.U.
description: Dale Brown , the Louisiana State basketball coach, has demoted three of his top players to the bottom of the roster because they failed to meet academic requirements. The players are Jerry Reynolds and Derrick Taylor , both all-Southeastern Conference selections last season, and Damon Vance . ''All three of these young men have proven they are more than capable of succeeding academically,'' said Brown.

title: ONE KILLED IN CRASH ON MAJOR DEEGAN
description: A woman was killed and nine people, including a police officer, were injured yesterday when a tractor-trailor hit a retaining wall on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx and set off a chain of crashes involving 11 cars.

title: Dun in Deal For Cook Unit By The Associated Press The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said it had agreed in
description: principle to acquire Thomas

title: BIG TURNOUT AND CONFUSION AT VOTING PLACES IN THE CITY
description: Tens of thousands of voters were forced to use paper ballots in New York City yesterday as exasperated election inspectors were unable to locate voting cards filed in the last few weeks.

title: REDGRAVE FIGHTS BLACKLISTING, ACTRESS'S LAWYER TELLS COURT
description: A lawyer for Vanessa Redgrave said today that the actress was leading a fight against blacklisting by suing the Boston Symphony Orchestra for canceling a concert series featuring her.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $155,000 for the quarter and $286,000 for the 9 months, income of $33,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, and a gain of $288,000 for the 9 months from the sale of assets of an Alaska unit.

title: AN EASY-TO-GROW BULB FOR ALL SEASONS
description: THE best thing about an amaryllis bulb is that it is eager to bloom. It is the perfect choice for people who think they can't grow anything. Some bulbs even come preplanted and the flower performance is almost automatic.

title: More Money Set For First Graders
description: City school officials said yesterday that they would appropriate more money to the 30 community school districts to help reduce the number of students in first-grade classes.

title: Turner Cable Subscribers
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. announced yesterday that it had ''incorrectly'' inflated the number of initial subscribers to the Cable Music Channel, its 24-hour music video channel that began broadcasting on Oct. 26.

title: RESULTSOF CONNECTICUT RACES
description: Abbreviatons in the following table are: D-Democrat, R-Republican, C-Conservative, L-Liberal, RTL-Right to Life. U denotes an unopposed candidate. An asterisk (*) denotes an incumbent and a dagger (+) less than a 99 percent return.

title: Chrysler Overtime
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had put six of its seven United States assembly plants on overtime as its car and truck sales rose nationwide, particularly in Texas, during October. Chrysler said its truck sales in Texas last month rose 72 percent, to 1,927 units, and car sales increased 44 percent, to 2,256. Nationwide, sales of cars and trucks were up 15 percent.

title: VOTER TURNOUT UP SLIGHTLY, REVERSING TREND
description: When all the ballots are counted, voter turnout in Tuesday's election will be up slightly, reversing a 20-year trend of declining participation in Presidential elections, an analyst said today.

title: Vacation of Sorts
description: John McEnroe's 21-day suspension may be costing him many thousands of dollars in earnings, but, according to his doubles partner, Peter Fleming, the enforced layoff is just what McEnroe needed. ''Let's face it, he's bought three weeks off,'' said Fleming, who sees fatigue in the face of a grueling schedule as the reason for the Stockholm outburst last weekend that led to the suspension.

title: O'Hare Airport Issue Is Priced
description: A $308.9 million bond issue of the Chicago O'Hare International Airport was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of about 10.55 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: West German Steel
description: West German production of crude steel climbed 3 percent in October and September, to 3.56 million metric tons, the Federal Statistics Office said today. In the first 10 months of 1984, production reached 33.21 million tons, up 11.3 percent from the period last year.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $181,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $58,000 for the quarter and $148,000 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months results reflect losses related to certain terminated and redefined product lines of Instron's British subsidiary, which reduced net income by $1,659,000, or 81 cents a share.

title: U.S. WARNS SOVIET IT WON'T TOLERATE MIG'S IN NICARAGUA
description: The United States, concerned that a Soviet freighter that has reached Nicaragua might be carrying advanced fighter aircraft, warned Moscow on Tuesday that it would not tolerate the delivery of such planes, the State Department said today.

title: Sea Storm Threat Abating
description: Tropical Storm Klaus was near hurricane strength today, but forecasters said it would remain at sea. ''It's moving away from Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands area, moving out to sea,'' said Hal Gerrish, a spokesman for the National Hurricane Center.

title: Czech Fire Kills 26, Hurts 2
description: A fire killed 26 residents of a home for the disabled in the town of Medenec in northwestern Czechoslovakia, the Communist Party newspaper Rude Pravo reported today. Two people were injured in the blaze, which struck ''at the end of last week during the night,'' Rude Pravo said.

title: STATE ASSURANCE FAILS TO THWART RUN ON A BANK
description: Waving blue bank passbooks and reacting to a rumor that a Chinatown bank was in financial trouble, hundreds of depositors yesterday waited for hours in long lines to withdraw their money from the bank.

title: BLIGHTED ATLANTA AREA MAY GET $1 BILLION LIFT
description: A $1 billion development being pursued here would bring office towers and living units to 20 square blocks of blighted downtown land.

title: Typhoon Toll Reaches 300
description: The death toll from the typhoon that swept through the central Philippines this week, has mounted to more than 300 after nearly 100 more bodies were found, disaster officials said today.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Q.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Ideas and Trends section of The Week in Review on Sunday misstated the position of the A. H. Robins Company on intrauterine birth control devices. Robins, which manufactures the Dalkon Shield, is urging women still using that device to have it removed because ''continued use may pose a serious personal health hazard.'' But the company has formally taken no position about the use of any other brand of intrauterine device.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline on Sunday with an article about the Veterans Administration misidentified the hospital criticized in a report to the agency. It was the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Hospital in Montrose, N.Y., unrelated to Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.

title: Peking Judge Chosen For World Court
description: A Chinese judge was named to the World Court today, becoming the first representative of the Peking Government on the court since the nation was admitted to the United Nations.

title: Thinking of Achievement
description: One man and 12 women will receive

title: Tom Hayden Appears to Win 2d California Assembly Term
description: Assemblyman Tom Hayden appeared today to be on his way to victory, but a write-in campaign was delaying the vote count in his bid for a second term in the California Legislature.

title: AFTER SYNAGOGUE FIRES, BENSONHURST TRIES TO RETAIN CALM
description: The morning after a fire destroyed the synagogue that housed his yeshiva in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Rabbi Yaakov Mosbacher received offers from other Bensonhurst schools, synagogues and even churches for classroom space.

title: Cleric Barred by Chile; 3 Foes of Regime Held
description: The Government today banned a leader of the Roman Catholic Church from returning to Chile, and arrested 21 people, including at least three opposition leaders.

title: THE POST-ELECTION WISH LIST
description: Business leaders were strong supporters of President Reagan's re- election bid and have been quick to cheer his overwhelming victory. But these corporate chieftains are also voicing concern that Mr. Reagan has yet to tackle the problem he promised to solve four years ago.

title: A FEW SHIFTS IN THE FACE OF AMERICAN POLITICS
description: Albert Gore Jr. Albert Gore Jr., has won the right to take the Senate seat being vacated by a Tennessee institution, Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader. As a four-term Democratic member of the House, Mr. Gore has represented the Sixth District, which has sent several national party leaders to Washington, including his father, Senator Albert Gore Sr. Representative Gore, a Harvard graduate who attended Vanderbilt School of Religion and Vanderbilt Law School, is a Vietnam War veteran. He has worked hard in Congress on such matters as toxic-waste cleanup, which is a major concern in customarily Republican East Tennessee, and arms control. In the latter area, he agreed to support the MX missile in exchange for shifts in the Reagan Administration's bargaining position in strategic arms talks.

title: MUSIC: FRANK FOSTER'S BAND AT THE VILLAGE VANGUARD
description: SINCE Frank Foster left Count Basie's saxophone section in 1964, after 11 years as one of the Basie bands more distinctive soloists and arrangers, he has maintained a big band that has survived despite his involvement in a variety of other musical projects. Mr. Foster has always been able to call his band together on relatively short notice when playing opportunities appeared. On Monday evening it was at the Village Vanguard, substituting for the Mel Lewis Band.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for 3-for-2 stock splits on Nov. 30, 1983 and Aug. 20, 1984.

title: HERS
description: MY journal from last summer when I worked in the hospital: history sheets meant for patients' records covered instead with disjointed fragments in my most minuscule cramped handwriting. My journal, surrounded by the stern hospital injunctions printed on history sheets: ''Enter name and unit number on both sides of Every sheet.'' ''Please do not waste space.'' My journal, written in lectures and conferences, a page of diary hidden beneath a page of conscientious lecture notes - a habit I developed in high school. My journal: endless complaints of fatigue (''worst night in a while, home after no sleep on call and then baby up from 2 to 3 A.M.''). Analysis of depression (''The sad truth is, I really want to be doing something I'm good at, and I am just not good at this''). Resolutions (''I have to (1) get more efficient about writing up patients, (2) stop eating potato chips in the middle of the night on call''). Quotes and anecdotes, attempts to record the flavor of the place so I would be able to recall it (''People dying with the TV on, Mr. P. with lung cancer, L.A. Olympics in background, swimming races''). And above all, a steady sense of stress, stress so constant and unyielding that I sometimes have trouble recognizing my own familiar voice in my journal.

title: Cautious Coaches
description: Georgetown University, the defending national basketball champion, will repeat as the conference champion this season, with St. John's finishing a close second, according to the results of a vote by the Big East coaches. But during the conference's media day yesterday, John Thompson, the Georgetown coach, and Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, outdid themselves trying to downplay the poll.

title: REV. PASQUALE J. ZACCARA, 75, EX-OFFICIAL OF MISSION SOCIETY
description: The Rev. Pasquale J. Zaccara, a Presbyterian minister and former deputy executive director of the New York Mission Society, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Tequesta, Fla.

title: P.S.C.'S NUCLEAR-PLANT CAP GRANTS UTILITIES A HUGE LOOPHOLE
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERS SHOW SATURN ROCKET CHIEF WAS CALLED 'ARDENT NAZI' BY U.S.
description: Arthur Rudolph, the developer of the Saturn V moon rocket and manager of a German rocket factory where slave laborers were worked to death during World War II, was originally described by American military authorities as an ''ardent Nazi'' but the assessment was later reversed, long-secret documents show.

title: HIGH COURT GETS VIEWS ON SABBATH DAYS OFF
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a state can require all private employers to give religiously observant employees a day off each week for the sabbath.

title: Callers Help Pentagon To Waste Not Millions
description: The Defense Department says its ''hot line'' for reporting abuses in military spending has saved $3.5 million in two years.

description: b-Including tax credits of $1,213,000 for the quarter and $3,070,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $783,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the termination of a pension plan. c-Net losses.

title: Jacobs Group Has 11.3% of Avco
description: An investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, Minneapois businessman, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had nearly doubled its holdings in the Avco Corporation. The group said it currently holds 2,633,500, or 11.3 percent, of Avco's shares outstanding.

title: Orioles in a Tie
description: The touring Baltimore Orioles slammed four home runs but had to rally to salvage a 5-5 tie today against a combined team of the Hiroshima Toyo Carp and the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants. The homers were by Jim Traber, who got two; Gary Roenicke and Eddie Murray. The game, played in a light drizzle before 16,000 spectators, was called after nine innings.

title: BILTRITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect a net charge against earnings of $8,034,000 for the cost of closing a footwear products factory in Chelsea, Mass.

title: PUTTING A WAX FINISH ON FURNITURE OF PINE
description: Does raw wood take kindly to the most simple, and one of the oldest, finishes - the wax treatment? Oak has been taken care of this way throughout the centuries, but oak is hard and dense. What of the softer pine?

title: PLAINTIFF IS DEAD, BUT SUIT GOES ON
description: Just 23 hours after the death of William F. Bartling, who suffered from five usually fatal diseases, his lawyer walked into a courtroom here today to argue that the 70-year-old former dental supply salesman should have been allowed to die sooner.

title: BERKLEY, W.R. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $958,000 for the quarter and $1,038,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a loss of $577,000 from underwriting losses from discontinued product lines and realized investment gains of $1,310,000. d-Net income after a loss of $1,262,000 from underwriting losses from discontinued product lines and realized investment gains of $3,433,000.

title: NEW YORK MARINE & GENERAL INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a realized investment gain of $507 for the quarter and a realized investment loss of $82,414 for the 9 months. c-After a realized investment gain of $1,251,000 for the quarter and a realized investment loss of $25,642 for the 9 months.

title: SYMPHONY: MUTI CONDUCTS THE PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA
description: RICCARDO MUTI chose a peculiar program with which to open the Philadelphia Orchestra's New York season at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. It consisted of Salieri's ''Follia di Spagna'' Variations, Bach's Violin Concertos in A minor and E major and Prokofiev's Symphony No. 3.

title: CONTROL DATA MAY SELL CREDIT UNIT
description: The Control Data Corporation, the troubled Minneapolis computer maker, said yesterday that it might sell the Commercial Credit Company, its financial services subsidiary.

title: SOVIET CONGRATULATORY MESSAGE TO REAGAN LOOKS TO BETTER RELATIONS
description: The Soviet Union sent a message of congratulations today to President Reagan on his re-election, stressing the hope that relations will improve in coming years.

title: Neapolitans March for Jobs
description: About 100 unemployed residents of Naples marched on the town hall today, protesting what they called local politicians' inertia on job programs. Dozens of shop windows and parked cars were damaged, the police said, and about 50 men were detained in scuffles between policemen and demonstrators.

title: THE BALLOTING IN NEW YORK FOR HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
FUJI CITES BIG LOSS BY TRADER
description: Fuji Bank said yesterday that it had lost about $48 million through unauthorized foreign exchange trading by its chief currency trader in New York.

title: COLLEGE TEACHER IS FATALLY SHOT IN LIQUOR STORE
description: A part-time college professor was fatally shot Tuesday night during what appeared to be an attempt to rob a liquor store that he owned and operated in the East Bronx, the police said.

title: President Leaves Storage Technology
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Naim S. Aweida, had resigned those positions.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30

description: THE emotional television sales

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Commerzbank A.G. of Frankfurt has named Kurt Richolt and Axel Freiherr von Ruedorfeer managing directors.

title: PENTAGON RESTRICTS DISCLOSURE OF DATA
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has signed a directive intended to prevent the public disclosure of technical information with military or space applications that the Pentagon considers could be useful to the Soviet Union, the Defense Department reported today. The directive applies to information that until now has been available to the public.

title: THE RESULTS OF THE BALLOTING FOR NEW YORK STATE SENATE
ECI Hits a Snag; May End Tender
description: Early California Industries said the ECI Acquiring Company had failed to buy 51.2 percent of Early California's stock held by certain shareholders and, as a result, those stockholders will not extend an earlier committment to sell their shares.

title: DANCE: BRAZILIAN, KOREAN CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: DANCES by choreographers from Brazil and Korea opened the Third World Theater Arts Festival on Tuesday night at La Mama Annex. The festival, which continues through Sunday, has been organized by the Third World Institute of Theater Arts Studies and the International League of Folk Arts for Communication and Education under the direction of Cecile Guidote Alvarez.

title: BUSH SAYS IT'S TIME TO 'REPRESENT ALL'
description: Vice President Bush, ending what he called the ''long and grueling'' campaign, said today that what he would like to do now ''is to make a contribution to bringing this country together.''

title: Oh, Sure
description: Campaign footnote: Walter F. Mondale got a lot of laughs when he said, scores of times, that he was applying to President Reagan the words of Will Rogers: ''It's not what he doesn't know that bothers me, it's what he knows for sure that just ain't so.'' Extensive research could not determine who actually said that first.

title: PAUL ENGLE'S WORDLY PEN
description: ''I didn't get into writing,'' said Paul Engle. ''Writing got into me.''

title: Ford Makes Offer to Workers Threatening Strike in Canada
description: The Ford Motor Company made an offer to its Canadian workers today in the face of a strike deadline of noon Friday.

title: RANGERS PACED BY RUOTSALAINEN
description: It might have been the prettiest scoring play of the year and it left two Washington Capitals on their elbows watching. The goal was the first one last night for the Rangers and it started them on their way to a 4-3 victory over Washington at the Garden.

title: G.O.P. IS FILLING ASSEMBLY POSTS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Connecticut Republicans jubilant over Tuesday's election results, which ended a decade of Democratic control, moved quickly today to organize the state's General Assembly and confront the Democratic administration of Gov. William A. O'Neill in the legislative session beginning Jan. 9.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. After a Western swing of five games and five losses, the Knicks return home to face Michael Jordan, the rookie billed as the National Basketball Association's next Dr. J. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1:15 A.M., tape.

title: Chairman's Daughter Gets Post
description: William H. Millard, the wealthy chairman of the Computerland Corporation, announced yesterday that his 26-year-old daughter, Barbara J. Millard, had been named president and chief operating officer of the corporation, succeeding him in those posts. He will remain chairman and chief executive.

title: STATE DEPT. IN A DITHER OVER HELMS
description: The State Department has no embassy in Raleigh, N.C., but it was more interested today in the post-election political scene in North Carolina than in most of the reports it was receiving from its nearly 200 missions overseas.

title: A DECADE OF IMAGES IN LIFE MAGAZINE EXHIBITION
description: Picasso is drawing a minotaur in the air with a flashlight, Harry Truman is playing the piano and Roger Bannister is finishing the four- minute mile. Joe Louis is caught with his hands down, and Marilyn Monroe with her skirt up. There are bullfighters, whirlybirds, gamblers, teen- agers and a great deal of war.

title: Books: Classic Sinatra
description: SINATRA. An American Classic. By John

title: Nova Scotian Tories Gain Big Victory
description: Premier John Buchanan of Nova Scotia led his Progressive Conservatives to an overwhelming third consecutive victory Tuesday in Nova Scotia's elections.

title: Saga Ends Talks On Sale of Unit
description: The Saga Corporation said it had terminated talks on the proposed sale of its Straw Hat Pizza division to Bullwinkle's Inc., because Bullwinkle's had been unable to secure the necessary financing.

title: IN NEW YORK CITY, JOBS ARE ON THE RISE AND GROWTH IS NOT ALL IN MANHATTAN
description: It is perhaps conventional wisdom that the economic strength of New York City can be measured in the size of Manhattan's skyline, that what is good for Wall Street, Broadway and Madison Avenue is good for New York as a whole.

title: Touches of Class
description: If some Met fans think Ron Darling adds a touch of class to the team because he is from Yale, consider the Ivy flavor the Mets could have in a few years. They have three other players from Ivy League schools who have played well in their farm system.

title: Portrait of the Electorate
description: 1984 data based on interviews with 8,696 voters leaving polling places around the nation on Tuesday, 1980 data based on interviews with 15,201 voter leaving polling places around the nation. Those who did not answer or said they had no opinion are not shown. Neither are groups from whom the samples available were too small. Family income categories in 1980: under $10,000, $10,000-14,999, $15,000-24,999, $25,000-49,999 and $50,000 and over.

title: Chess Game Postponed Because of Holiday
description: The 22d game of the world chess championship match was not played today because of the holiday celebrating the 67th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: TANDY OFFERS NEW COMPUTERS
description: The Tandy Corporation, seeking to bolster its shrinking presence in the personal computer market, today will introduce an inexpensive computer compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Baker International Corp., Orange, Calif., said its Magna Corp. unit had agreed to purchase the Di-Chem operations of Dresser Industries of Dallas. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Test Planned in Kidnapping
description: The police, investigating a reporter's charge that he was kidnapped and threatened, said today that they would give a polygraph test to a man questioned about the incident and also might ask the reporter to take one. Lieut. Dan Cooke, a police spokesman, said Timothy Carlson, a reporter for The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, and Dennis Higgins, the man Mr. Carlson said abducted him, offered ''different versions of what happened.'' No one has been arrested in the incident, which occurred Monday night.

title: No Headline
description: A Miracle Man in Chile Chile's President, Augusto Pinochet, seems to be fashioning the political miracle that eluded his elected predecessors: uniting Chileans from left to right in favor of basic political change. Unfortunately for General Pinochet, the first change they seek is the end of his military dictatorship.

title: HOW THE CANDIDATES DIVIDED THE VOTES
description: President Reagan won the votes of 66 percent of whites, 62 percent of retired people and 60 percent of first-time voters, while 90 percent of blacks, 68 percent of the unemployed and 70 percent of the liberals backed Walter F. Mondale.

title: WHO DID IN THE DEMOCRATS?
description: Now that the long-predicted debacle has occurred, there will be a natural tendency for Democrats to try to identify those responsible. Some will say that blame- fixing is destructive. But this is a fine time for finger-pointing. Now that the Democrats have lost four of the last five Presidential elections, fixing blame is a necessary first step in arresting the decline of the party. Here are my four nominees for those most responsible for the latest defeat.

description: As part of an early retirement program intended to streamline operations at the European American Bank, Nicholas A. Sica, the bank's 63- year-old president, announced that he would leave at the end of the year.

title: STARVING ETHIOPIANS MUST BE RESCUED
description: The famine in Ethiopia is a tragedy on a scale so huge that few people can conceive it. The conditions are so severe that they demand magnanimous and continuing responses from governments that possess the required food.

''It's a tough thing that I took on an incumbent who had been elected four times before and that was a great obstacle,'' she said Tuesday after losing to Representative Thomas R. Carper, a Democrat who had served as the state treasurer. He won a second House term with 141,472 votes, or 58 percent, to Mrs. du Pont's 100,142, or 42 percent. She is the wife of Gov. The Monitor's national index on money market aaccounts fell to 9.49 percent, from 9.56 percent, as the index of six- month C.D.'s slipped to 10.28 percent, from 10.55 percent.

description: A pistol seized after the arrest of five reputed radicals in Ohio was the weapon used to kill a New Jersey state trooper in December 1981, authorities said today.

DEMOCRATS HOLD THE LINE IN CONTESTS FOR GOVERNOR
description: Madeleine M. Kunin won the governorship of Vermont in Tuesday's election as Democratic gubernatorial candidates around the country held the line against Republicans who appeared to benefit only slightly from President Reagan's landslide victory.

description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a request by the Schiavone Construction Company that an ''independent counsel'' be named to investigate its charge that a Government witness perjured himself in a 1982 investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: SUBTLE AND ELEGANT DETAIL FROM BEENE
description: AT a time when inventiveness and imagination seem to have been banished from the fashion lexicon, it is somewhat startling to view a Geoffrey Beene collection that aims valiantly and, for the most part, successfully to extend the boundaries of fashion.

title: Man Charged in 4 Slayings
description: Horace Edwin Burns, 20 years old, was charged Tuesday with murdering four members of the family of Kermit Alexander, the former professional football player. Police Chief Daryl Gates said the killers had the right house number but the wrong street. Tiequon Cox, 18, was arrested earlier in the case.

title: Boston Cab Driver Accused Of Attacking Reagan Backer
description: A cab driver has been accused of firing two shots at a campaign worker for President Reagan, then yelling, ''Reagan's next!'' outside the Republican headquarters downtown, the police say.

title: 'YOU AIN'T SEEN NOTHING YET'
description: BOSTON It is going to be a different country.

title: GIANTS FAVOR HELMET RADIOS
description: The wave, something new in professional football this year, may be the instrument that brings something new next year: transistor-radio equipment in the players' helmets for transmitting and receiving signals.

title: PARTY LOOKS INWARD FOR WAYS TO REGAIN MAJORITY
description: Democratic Party leaders began yesterday what they foresee as a long and agonizing appraisal of how they can renew their appeal to the white majority in Presidential elections and still hold the allegiance of minorities, the poor and others who seek Federal assistance.

title: THEATER: 'ANONYMOUS,' ON CATHOLICS IN FUTURE
description: ''ANONYMOUS,'' a musical at the AMAS Repertory Theatre, is concerned with dissension in the Catholic Church in the 21st century that leads to the removal of the Vatican to New York, where the Empire State Building becomes Vatican City, and the subsequent elevation of a black pope.

title: A Season for Giant Fans
description: Ted Siebold is not yet aware that

title: LEADERS IN THE NEW YORK WEIGH REAGAN'S TRIUMPH IN STATE
description: A total of 6.6 million New Yorkers voted in Tuesday's Presidential election, an increase over the 1980 turnout but far fewer than the more than 7 million who went to the polls in the 1950's and 1960's and in 1972.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Florida Killer's Plea
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today to stay the execution of Timothy Charles Palmes, who is scheduled to die Thursday in Florida's electric chair for the murder of a furniture store owner.

title: JAZZ: BETTY CARTER, SINGER, AT THE BLUE NOTE
description: MOST jazz singers who take broad liberties with the material they sing want either to underscore the lyrics at the expense of musical cohesiveness or to use the music as a foundation for abstract tonal flights. Betty Carter, who is performing with a trio at the Blue Note, through Sunday, does both at once.

title: JETS LOOK TO MCNEIL TO CONTROL THE BALL
description: Because the secondary is so battered, with three of the four starters sidelined, the Jets are likely to be obsessed with keeping possession as long as possible Sunday against the Indianapolis Colts to avoid pitting the depleted defense against them.

title: Australian Films At the Guggenheim
description: An Australian film festival, featuring full-length commercial releases and short experimental works, will run over the next two weekends at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street.

title: PRESIDENTIAL RESULTS BY COUNTY
description: The votes for some minor-party candidates will not be available until the official canvastes are completed.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Former 'Hillbilly' Loses
description: Nancy Kulp, the zany bank secretary of ''The Beverly Hillbillies'' on television in the 1960's, lost her bid to unseat Representative Bud Shuster. A former co- star, the actor Buddy Ebsen, who played the millionaire Jed Clampett on the show, said in political radio commercials that he had ''dropped her a note to say, 'Hey Nancy, I love you dearly but you're too liberal for me - I've got to go with Bud Shuster.' '' Mr. Shuster won 117,203 votes Tuesday in central Pennsylvania's Ninth District, while the Democratic challenger drew 59,449.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORPPer to Sept 30 reports earnings for 1984
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $112,000 for the quarter and $1,135,000 for the 9 months. c-After a realized investment loss of $70,000 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $2,486,000 for the 9 months.

title: INDIA, STILL UNEASY, ALERTS SOME TROOPS
description: The army rushed reinforcements to New Delhi and Punjab State today in anticipation of possible renewed violence Thursday, the anniversary of the birth of the man who founded the Sikh religion.

title: Arkansas Housing Mortgage Bonds
description: The Arkansas Housing Development Agency is offering $150 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield on interest-bearing bonds of 10.59 percent for bonds due in 2006, according to tentative prices announced by Paine Webber Inc., the lead underwriter. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's.

title: TRAIN TAKES ART AND ARTISTS TO TOWNS OVER TEXAS
description: A bright red train pulled into town here in the heart of deepest East Texas the other day, carrying not cattle and not lumber, but culture.

description: Waived Ellis Valentine, outfielder. Assigned Angel Moreno, Jay Kibbe and Bill Mooneyham, pitchers, and Pat Keedy, infielder, to Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League.

title: DECORATIVE TILING: TAKING THE BOLD APPROACH

title: Article 069303 -- No Title
description: SURROUNDED by a battalion of people hanging pictures, polishing floors, moving furniture and arranging flowers, Mayor Koch was preparing for the official unveiling yesterday of the renovation of Gracie Mansion. ''This is the second most famous house in the country,'' the Mayor said of the mansion's $5.5 million renovation, which included a structural overhaul, new furnishings and a cosmetic face lift of the 1799 house and the Susan E. Wagner Wing, built in 1966.

title: DILEMMA OF VOTER POLLS: SUSPENSE OR KNOWLEDGE
description: After years as a foreign correspondent, away from American politics and the technological revolution, the ABC News anchor Peter Jennings encountered what might be termed projection shock on the night of the New Hampshire primary.

description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Dow Jones & Company misstated the company's stake in The Press-Enterprise, a newspaper in Riverside, Calif. It is 21.5 percent.

title: DAVID LEAVITT, A WRITER TO WATCH
description: When David Leavitt speaks of ''my generation,'' he means people who are about his age. All of 23. In his view, it's neither a lost generation nor an involved one. He describes himself and his friends as members of a ''skeptical, mournful'' generation.

title: Heart Patient Runs In a 24-Hour Race
description: As the seventh hour of the Sri Chinmoy 24-hour road race ended yesterday, Yiannis Kouros of Greece, the winner of a six-day race in July at Randalls Island, had covered 63 miles - a pace that would break the world record by 45 miles.

description: Before he became known as Bonecrusher, when he was just plain James Smith, ''a country boy'' from Magnolia, N.C., the unlikely challenger for boxing's supreme title said, ''I didn't have time for fairy tales.''

The 30- year-old Dawson is currently on a rehabilitation program to strengthen the muscles in his left knee, which was already tender from a childhood injury before a bone spur formed early last season and severely hampered his production.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1984 After the Voting After winning the biggest electoral vote total in the nation's history, President Reagan said he regarded his victory as an endorsement of his economic policies and as an opportunity to press for a breakthrough in arms control talks with Moscow. In final returns, Mr. Reagan won 59 percent of the popular vote and carried every state except Minnesota. The President's total of 525 electoral votes exceeded the 523 won by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1936. (Page A1, Col. 6.)

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: A $400 million issue of New York City general obligation bonds, the largest such sale by the city since 1974, was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The issue has a maximum yield of 11 percent for 10 7/8 percent bonds due in 2014, which were offered at a price of 98.9, or $989 per $1,000 bond.

description: A score of the neon advertising signs above Times Square were turned off for half an hour yesterday evening in protest of aspects of the planned Times Square redevelopment.

title: REACTION ABROAD IS LARGELY POSITIVE
description: Foreign politicians and political commentators, almost all of whom had expected President Reagan's re-election, largely welcomed it today as a portent of continuity, but many of them also said the time had come for bolder action in Washington.

title: THE DIFFERING NETWORK MOODS ON ELECTION NIGHT
description: HOW does television, which thrives on drama, cover a Presidential election when (a) everyone knows who is going to win, (b) it is necessary to pretend no one really knows, and (c) interpretation must be supplied, even if there is not much to interpret? On Tuesday night, the networks answered the question, each in its own separate way.

description: Cigarette smoking, a well-known contributor to heart attacks, also causes a rare but lethal disease that weakens the heart's pumping power, researchers report.

Those numbers bespeak a mammoth workload for the Board of Elections because, as Tuesday showed, it lacks both the staff and the equipment to handle its task. With a mayoral election just months away, there's no time to lose to shape things up.

description: Although the Edmonton Oilers, last season's Stanley Cup champions, are riding a 13-game unbeaten streak and have vastly improved their defense, Doug Carpenter, the Devils' coach, thinks his club will be able to dent it Thursday night at Byrne Meadowlands.

title: COMBATING ILLS OF LATE SHIFTS
description: DETROIT EXPENSIVE machinery is much more efficiently employed when it is operated for more than eight hours a day, which is why many factories run double shifts or more. Some facilities, such as nuclear power plants, oil refineries and glass plants, are typically kept running around the clock for months.

title: JUDGE AIDS CLAIMS ON ASBESTOS
description: In a major victory for those with asbestos-related diseases, a Federal judge in Chicago ruled yesterday that 17,000 asbestos-related claims against UNR Industries - an asbestos maker that filed for reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws - could not be heard in bankruptcy court, but would have to be tried by district courts.

description: Nov. 5, 1980, was a bleak day for poll takers. Ronald Reagan had won a landslide victory over President Carter the day before, and the pollsters were on the hot seat trying to explain why their final pre-election surveys had said the race was close, perhaps with Mr. Carter even ahead.

title: NEW ROLE FOR NILSSON AT MASTER CLASS
description: ''Horseback riding is good,'' the famous Valkyrie suggested, ''if your family has a horse. Some families don't. But ride a bicycle uphill, in the lowest gear. The next day, where it hurts, there is your breath support.''

description: Although his Democratic opponent refused to concede defeat, Joseph J. DioGuardi, the Republican-Conservative candidate, today celebrated what appeared to be a victory in the 20th Congressional District in Westchester County.

On Saturday, the orchestra came across the river to Carnegie Hall for the afternoon.

''It's a tough thing that I took on an incumbent who had been elected four times before and that was a great obstacle,'' she said Tuesday after losing to Representative Thomas R. Carper, a Democrat who had served as the state treasurer. He won a second House term with 141,472 votes, or 58 percent, to Mrs. du Pont's 100,142, or 42 percent. She is the wife of Gov. description: Voters rejected sweeping, conservative-backed proposals to cut taxes in California, Michigan and Nevada Tuesday, indicating that the taxpayers' revolt that began in California six years ago may have run its course for now.

description: A witness at the Westmoreland-CBS libel trial said yesterday that the Vietcong's self-defense forces were ''little more than a motley crew'' and recalled for the jury a patrol he had joined in the rice paddies of South Vietnam's Mekong River delta in October 1967.

title: NIGERIA PLANS TO KEEP OIL OUTPUT OVER QUOTA
description: Nigeria will maintain its over-quota pace of oil production for the foreseeable future regardless of cuts other OPEC members have made, according to Nigeria's oil minister, Tam David- West.

description: Unimed Inc. said it had been notified that the Food and Drug Administration had said it would not approve Marinol, the company's new drug.
