description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported a 45 percent increase in its third-quarter profit.

title: THE POLITICS OF POPULARITY
description: President Reagan's landslide election victory was more than an endorsement of certain policies or a defeat of a ragged Democratic army. Many experts feel it was an enormous personal triumph establishing Mr. Reagan as the most powerful political phenomenon in decades. Exactly 20 years ago, in his capacity as a show business personality, Mr. Reagan outlined a startling conservative vision of America on the eve of what was to be Senator Barry Goldwater's overwhelming loss to President Johnson.

title: Prentice-Hall Sets Statement
description: Prentice-Hall Inc., which has received a $70-a-share takeover bid by Gulf and Western Industries, will issue a formal statement on the offer today, insiders said last night. The statement will follow a meeting of Prentice-Hall directors.

title: Denmark's Trade Gap
description: Denmark's balance of payments deficit widened to 2.5 billion kroner, or about $237 million, in the third quarter from 1 billion kroner a year earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said today. The balance of payments measures international transactions in merchandise trade, services and transfer payments like investments.

title: 'Dial-a-Porn' Curbs Rejected
description: The Federal Communications Commission must find another way to restrict ''dial- a-porn'' simulated telephone sex calls after a Federal appellate court unanimously declared rules limiting them to nighttime hours unconstitutional.

title: PARTY LABELS SURPASSED BY REAGAN AND BRADLEY

title: G.O.P. ADDS TO TOTAL IN HOUSE, BUT DEMOCRATS RETAIN CONTROL

Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $987,611 for the quarter and $2,032,389 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $493,335 for the quarter and $2,698,873 for the 9 months.

title: PUERTO RICO'S GOVERNOR LOSES
description: Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo conceded defeat early this morning to former Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon, whose Popular Democratic Party took commanding control of the Legislature and wrested control of at least six cities and towns from the Governor's New Progressive Party.

title: CITY BOARD OF EDUCATION REFUSING TO SUBMIT TO BACKGROUND CHECKS
description: The Board of Education has reneged on its agreement to have top officials - including the Chancellor and the board members - submit to background checks, the City Investigation Commissioner said yesterday.

title: MORLEY GETS ART AWARD
description: The painter Malcolm Morley, a British-born artist who has lived in the United States since 1958, won a $12,500 award Tuesday given by the Friends of the Tate Gallery in London for ''the person who has made the greatest contribution to art in Britain in the previous 12 months.''

title: ASTRONOMCAL PRICE OF 'STAR WARS' DEFENSE SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW NEW STADIUM WILL PAY ITS WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PRAIRIE FIRE
description: WASHINGTON Was the Reagan sweep primarily a personal victory of a popular leader in prosperous times, like Ike's re-election in 1956?

title: South Africa Accused Of Detaining 1,000
description: A human-rights group here said today that the South African police had detained more than 1,000 people since Jan. 1, a figure described as the highest ''for many years.''

title: CORNELL TEACHER IN HOTEL FIELD
description: Vance A. Christian, a food consultant who taught at the Cornell School of Hotel Administration, died Monday at the Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 55 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.75-12.00N.A. Not available because of Election Day holiday ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REAGAN FACES DIFFICULT TASK IN LEADING DIVIDED CONGRESS
description: Despite his overwhelming electoral victory Tuesday, President Reagan faces a much more complicated task in leading a divided Government in his second term than when he entered the White House four years ago.

title: Pentagon Spokesman Gets Reporter as Aide
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger announced today that Fred S. Hoffman, longtime Pentagon correspondent for The Associated Press, would become Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs on Tuesday.

title: AN ACTOR WITH SOMETHING EXTRA
description: THERE are moments in ''The Killing Fields,'' as there are in ''Places in the Heart,'' when John Malkovich nearly walks off with the show. Mr. Malkovich's roles in these, his first two films after ''True West'' and ''Death of a Salesman'' on the stage, are relatively small. But they are substantial enough to establish him as the best thing to happen to screen acting in a long while. In ''Places in the Heart,'' that makes him one member of a very fine ensemble cast, albeit the one who is outstanding; in ''The Killing Fields,'' Mr. Malkovich's presence is something more.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY 3 MILE ISLAND WAS NEAR MELTDOWN
description: The nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island came closer to melt-down than was previously believed, according to research commissioned by the United States Department of Energy.

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN, TAKING 49 STATES AND 59% OF VOTE, VOWS TO STRESS ARMS TALKS AND ECONOMY
description: In the aftermath of his overwhelming defeat, Walter F. Mondale said quietly today that he was ending his long political career and would return to Washington to work as a lawyer.

title: 2-SEAT GAIN BUOYS SENATE DEMOCRATS
description: Democratic leaders in the Senate predicted yesterday that their party's gain of two Senate seats, reducing the Republican margin to 53 to 47, would pose legislative problems for President Reagan, enhance the influence of moderate Republicans and place the Democrats within striking distance of capturing the Senate in 1986.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $1,329,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 9 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $2,182,000 for the quarter and $7,797,000 for the 9 months.

title: Amnesty International Accuses Chad of Killings
description: Amnesty International today accused Government soldiers in Chad of carrying out hundreds of summary executions and random killings in the past two months.

title: Alexander & Baldwin Fight
description: Harry Weinberg, the largest shareholder of Alexander & Baldwin Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that he intends to wage a proxy contest to oust the directors of the company, a Honolulu-based transportation, sugar and real estate concern.

title: 40 Die in Colombian Floods
description: At least 40 people have died in Colombia's worst floods in a decade, and as more rivers overflowed their banks today the authorities warned that the rains could continue into next month.

title: Fralic Could Play A Defensive Role
description: If the National Football League season continues on its present course, either the Houston Oilers or the Buffalo Bills will win the right to pick first in the 1985 college draft. Neither team has won a game after 10 weeks.

title: EXPERTS TO AID WILDLIFE ON ISLES SOAKED BY OIL
description: Wildlife experts have been dispatched to help birds and seals affected by oil that has washed ashore in the Farallone Islands since a tanker's stern sank after an explosion Oct. 31, the authorities said today.

title: PLIGHT OF PARENTS WITH AN INFANT IN INTENSIVE CARE
description: LAST June, Margot Hammond awoke from an emergency Caesarean section to learn that her newborn daughter, Kaitlin, had been placed in the hospital's intensive-care nursery.

title: COMMUNITY GARDEN ON A CITY ROOFTOP
description: SATURDAY was one of the first crisp days of autumn, and some of the members of the Lotus Garden were not about to let it pass. ''It's real digging weather,'' said Laurie Hawkins, a singer and one of 16 gardeners who turned out. Dig they did, in their garden on the second-story roof of a parking garage on the Upper West Side. Spring bulbs - narcissus, allium, tulips and hyacinths - were planted in holes peppered throughout the 7,000- square-foot space.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $5,000 for the quarter and $40,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Veterans' Day came a week early here. The official celebration will still take place on Sunday, but last weekend veterans from World War II and Korea did something for the veterans of Vietnam. Those who were gathered in a cold wind on the green in front of Borough Hall are not likely to forget it soon.

title: Deutsche Bank In British Deal LONDON, Nov. 7 -
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest commercial

title: ARGUMENTS GIVEN IN EX-ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR'S TRIAL
description: The United States Attorney for New Jersey said today that former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City would convict himself of extortion and bribery by ''his words alone.''

title: ANTHONY GEARY STARS IN ABC MOVIE
description: ANTHONY GEARY and Gloria Monty are collaborating again. In case you didn't know, he has been playing Luke for several years in the soap opera ''General Hospital,'' which she produces. Now, Miss Monty is the executive producer of a television movie called ''The Impostor,'' which can be seen at 8 on ABC this evening with Mr. Geary playing the lead role of an irrepressible con man. He has said of Miss Monty: ''If she said to me, 'I want you to jump out of this airplane,' I'd say, 'With or without a parachute?' I mean that, because you cannot be a creative person in a vacuum.'' Fortunately, ''The Impostor'' does not require him to jump out of an airplane.

title: IF THE SUN CO. WERE A TARGET
description: THE Sun Company, one of the nation's major

title: Still on the Mend
description: Though three weeks away from tennis may be enough to restore McEnroe to top mental and physical form, three months off has not been enough for Andrea Jaeger. The 19-year-old star, who cited shoulder and elbow injuries when she dropped out of the tour, said it may be March before she resumes training.

title: KING ANGERS ASHE ON SOUTH AFRICA DEAL
description: Don King, one of the charter signatories when Artists and Athletes Against Apartheid was formed two years ago, has embarrassed the group by sending a heavyweight championship bout to Bophuthatswana, Arthur Ashe, one of the group's co-chairmen, said today.

title: ITALIANS TO PRESS FOR CITIBANK TRIAL
description: A Milan prosecutor plans a new effort to bring to trial 11 present and former Citibank employees on charges that they violated Italian foreign exchange regulations, despite some speculation that he would give up the four-year- old case.

title: Dominican Loan Talks
description: A new round of negotiations is under way here between the Government and the International Monetary Fund on a $240 million loan.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $750,000.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 20
COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of approximately $2.5 million for the quarter and year from a change in tax rules and a gain of $4.2 million for the year from a joint venture. c-Including a gain of $1.3 million from the sale of a unit.

title: Imprisoned State Legislator Easily Elected to an 8th Term
description: Representative Tommy Burnett, serving a prison term for failing to file income tax returns, has easily won re-election to an eighth term in the State Legislature, but it is unclear if he can take office.

title: POLISH SPOKESMAN GIVES ACCOUNT OF SLAYING
description: The three security officers charged with killing the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko were said today to have been stopped by highway patrolmen who routinely checked credentials as the pro-Solidarity priest lay in the trunk of the car.

title: D'Arcy Man Joins J. Walter Thompson
description: Timothy Arnold, who formerly ran the Budweiser account at D'Arcy MacManus Masius, has joined the New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Company as a senior vice preident, management director.

title: TURBULENT WINDS PROMPT DELAY OF SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: The launching of the space shuttle Discovery was postponed today because of turbulent high-altitude winds. The flight, the first space salvage mission, was rescheduled for Thursday.

title: Libertarian Gets Alaska Seat
description: After an absence of two years, the Libertarian Party is once again represented in the Alaska Legislature. Andre Marrou upset the incumbent, Milo Fritz, a Republican.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,465,000 for the quarter and $2,000,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: Folk Art Scratched From Breeders' Cup
description: Sixty-nine horses were entered today to run for $10 million in the seven inaugural Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park here Saturday, but Folk Art was not among them. The daughter of Nijinsky, who had been the favorite to win the $1 million Juvenile Fillies race and an Eclipse Award as the best 2-year-old filly in the country, was found to be suffering from a strained ligament this morning.

title: Onetime Nun in Rhode Island Elected as Attorney General
description: Arlene Violet, a Roman Catholic who quit the Sisters of Mercy religious order to run for Attorney General, has unseated the three-term incumbent, Dennis J. Roberts 2d.

title: DeLorean Appeals for Funds In Newspaper Advertisement
description: John Z. DeLorean asked in a newspaper advertisement today for donations of $5 to $100 to pay for legal fees incurred during his successful two-year fight against drug-trafficking charges.

title: Thinking of Spring
description: While the leaves are just falling

title: Utah Agency Issue Offered
description: The Utah Housing Finance Agency is offering $150 million of single- family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10 5/8 percent for bonds due in 2008, according to tentative prices announced by Kidder, Peabody & Company, the lead underwriter.

title: Last Mondale Flight Evokes Washington
description: Walter F. Mondale's last flight aboard his campaign plane ended today with a pass over the Washington Monument and George Washington's home.

title: Power on at Coast Reactor
description: Nuclear technicians fired up a low- level atomic reaction at the Diablo Canyon power plant today but scaled back predictions that power would be produced sometime this week.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 6
description: b-Net losses.

title: 56 FREE AGENTS AVAILABLE IN DRAFT TODAY
description: Rick Sutcliffe and Bruce Sutter are free agents for the first time, and they figure to emerge from today's draft with the most lucrative contracts that will be given to any of the 56 available players. Oscar Gamble, Derrel Thomas and Miguel Dilone are free agents for the third time, and they hope simply to emerge from the draft with jobs.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Hubert Birkenmeier, the Cosmos' goalkeeper, has been named assistant coach for the Major Indoor Soccer League team, the club president, Giorgio Chinaglia, announced yesterday. . . . The California Angels have asked waivers on the outfielder Ellis Valentine for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Valentine, 30 years old, missed the 1984 season with a bruised left heel.

title: MGM/UA Off Despite Hits
description: Despite its best year ever at the movies, the MGM/UA Entertainment Company reported today that its earnings fell 80.9 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Aug. 31, and were down 17.2 percent for the full year. The conglomerate's movie unit had highly successful films such as ''Yentl.''

title: NAVY DEFENDS ITS METHODS IN FIGHTING DRUG ABUSE
description: While the nuclear attack submarine Boston was in Newport News shipyard two years ago, Michael J. Yox Jr. heard his number come up.

title: 125 Children Missing As Indian Bridge Falls
description: About 125 schoolchildren were missing today after a rope bridge collapsed over a swollen stream in a mountain region of the southern state of Kerala, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: TREASURY PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell sharply yesterday as securities dealers discovered that investor demand was waning in the face of the rapid rise in prices and decline in yields in the last two months.

title: Utility Debt Appeal Set
description: The United States Supreme Court will be asked to review court rulings in Washington State that freed utilities from having to pay their debts to the Washington Public Power Supply System, officials of the Chemical Bank said today.

title: Bridge:U.S. Trails in Quarterfinal Of World Team Olympiad
description: The United States open team trailed Austria by 11 international match points, 55-66, at the midpoint of World Team Olympiad quarterfinals here this afternoon. The young and talented Austrian team is giving the best performance for its country since 1937 when a Viennese sextet won the world title.

title: Dorsey in Move To Halt Investors
description: The Dorsey Corporation said it had asked in Federal District Court for a preliminary injunction to restrain a group of investors from acquiring more of its common shares.

title: SKETCHES OF ASTRONAUTS ON MOON
description: Anna L. Fisher

title: 'CHORUS LINE' DIRECTOR SEEKS TO BUY SHARE OF THEATER
description: Michael Bennett, the director of ''A Chorus Line'' and other shows, said yesterday that he was negotiating to buy a share of the Mark Hellinger Theater from the Nederlander Organization.

title: AGENT TELLS OF CONFRONTING MATTHEWS
description: An agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today about how he confronted Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City outside a restaurant last December to tell him he was the target of a two-year undercover investigation into corruption in his office.

title: Sparkman Energy
description: The Sparkman Energy Corporation said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter as a result of a ruling by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: BID FOR HELP SOON ON TAXES WEIGHED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration may seek early, bipartisan help from Congress to shape a simpler tax code, an official said today.

title: OHIO SUSPECTS TIED TO 10 BOMB BLASTS
description: The F.B.I. says it has evidence linking five people arrested this week in connection with the slaying of a New Jersey state trooper to 10 bombings in the New York metropolitan area.

title: HOUSE MAKEUP APPARENT DESPITE DISPUTED RACES
description: Several House races in Tuesday's elections remained in doubt yesterday, but Democrats emerged as apparent winners in contests in Illinois and Indiana. And Senator Walter D. Huddleston, Democrat of Kentucky, an apparent loser in a close race, asked election officials to recheck their ballot count.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Plea in Burglary At State Mansion
description: An Albany man who was charged with buglarizing the state's Executive Mansion while Governor Cuomo and his family slept pleaded guilty today to criminal trespass, a misdemeanor.

title: Children's Theater Head Gets Year in Sex Case
description: John Clark Donahue, the founder and former artistic director of the Children's Theater Company, was sentenced today to a year in jail and 15 years' probation for having sexual relations with three boys who were students at the theater.

title: GUANTRONIX reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $66,000 for the quarter and $105,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $140,000.

description: From deep within the Department of Labor comes word that

SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THERE'S PLENTY OF LIFE AFTER REINSTATEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP G.O.P. TARGET HAS DEMOCRAT TROUBLES, TOO
description: One of the Republican Party's top targets this election year was Representative James R. Jones, the chairman of the House Budget Committee. The Republicans missed the mark, however, as Mr. Jones won re-election by about 11,000 votes.

title: PASTERNAK'S SPIRIT IS EVICTED FROM HIS OLD DACHA
description: The big wooden house with its castle- like turret stands empty now. Only bare floors and faded wallpaper can be glimpsed through the newspapers taped to the windows, except for one room where a grand piano lies on its side, its damaged strings to the window.

title: A FEDERAL INSURANCE PLAN FOR IMMUNIZATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY STARTING $6 MILLION EFFORT TO IMPROVE NEIHBORHOOD PARKS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city was undertaking its most serious commitment in half a century to spruce up neighborhood parks.

title: 3-MONTH TRADE GAP A RECORD
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit set a quarterly record of $33.3 billion in July, August and September, the Commerce Department said today. Imports jumped 9.9 percent; exports rose only seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Former Official Admits Military Contract Fraud
description: Chester Eugene Adamsky, a former executive for a Massachusetts military contractor, has pleaded guilty to Federal charges that he took $237,000 in bribes to grant subcontracts to other companies and to overlook fraud.

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $228,000 for the quarter and $545,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $32,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 9 months.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: Garland L. Thompson is new at The Philadelphia Tribune, but his voice could be that of the crusading editor who founded the thrice-weekly newspaper here 100 years ago.

title: PENTAGON IN DISPUTE OVER AID ABROAD
description: The Defense Department has been seeking to expand its humanitarian assistance in such areas as Central America and Ethiopia, but has been opposed by the State Department, according to an internal Pentagon report.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arco Loses Alaska Plea ANCHORAGE, Nov. 8 (AP)
description: Alaska's North Slope Borough has rejected a request

title: U.S. BEGINS INQUIRY INTO EMPLOYEE ACTS AT NUCLEAR AGENCY
description: The Department of Justice has begun a Federal grand jury investigation of Nuclear Regulatory Commission employees, Nunzio J. Palladino, the commission's chairman, told Congress today.

title: NICARAGUAN SAYS SOVIET SHIP CARRIED ONE OR TWO MILITARY COPTERS
description: A senior Nicaraguan official said today that a Soviet ship that docked at the Pacific port of Corinto Wednesday was carrying one or two helicopters for the Nicaraguan Army.

title: STAGE: 'IN CELEBRATION' BY DAVID STOREY OPENS
description: '' WHAT do you do with this feeling of disfigurement?'' asks a son in David Storey's play, ''In Celebration.'' The disfigurement to which the young man refers is that which parents can inflict, however innocently, upon their children. The question may be an eternal one - as eternal as Ibsenesque family dramas like ''In Celebration'' - but it is not asked or answered rhetorically by Mr. Storey. Though it takes a while to get there, his play leaves us with bruising images of adult children gasping to escape the crippling psychological stranglehold of Mom and Dad.

title: FULL CHAD PULLOUT REPORTED NEAR
description: France and Libya are about to complete withdrawal of the troops they sent to Chad to back opposing factions in the 20-year-old civil war, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today.

title: Idle Talk of City Wages
description: Although New York's contracts with most of its employees expired last spring, negotiations between the unions and City Hall have been fitfully slow. The two sides are stuck with a demand for a 9 percent annual wage increase and an offer of 2 percent, leaving Mayor Koch to ask the Board of Collective Bargaining to make a declaration of impasse and to move to arbitration.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; President Is Named By Phelps Dodge
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation announced yesterday that it had named G. Robert Durham president, chief operating officer and a director of the company. The appointments are effective Jan. 1.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARCHIVES SOURCE FOR 'GOLDEN LAND'
description: Before World War II, downtown Second Avenue was a kind of Yiddish Broadway. Every night more than a dozen theaters filled up with Jewish immigrants, who came to see operettas that reflected their own experiences as sweatshop workers, union maids and schleppers.

title: '85 Bonn Summit Talks
description: The annual economic summit conference of the major industrialized democracies will be held in Bonn next May, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today. The leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and West Germany will participate.

title: AN 80TH BIRTHDAY PARTY (3 IN FACT) ON JANE STREET
description: Jane Street stretches for five blocks in Greenwich Village from Greenwich Avenue to West Street and the Hudson River. There are trees, handsome Federal-style houses and a high-rise or two. It was named, according to the New-York Historical Society, for a Mr. Jaynes who lived there in the 1700's. But beginning this evening, a giant banner, along with a large assortment of Happy 80th Birthday greetings placed in a great many of the residence and shop windows, will proudly proclaim the fact that all weekend long Jane Street will, unofficially, be Chuck Verral Street.

title: C.I.A. VIETNAM ANALYST
description: George A. Carver Jr., who appeared yesterday as a witness in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS, was the chief Central Intelligence Agency analyst of the Vietnam War. Though he testified in behalf of the general, he had sometimes clashed with him during the war and oversaw studies that suggested the war was unwinnable.

title: SUCCESS STORY WITH A $120,000 CELLO CODA
description: EVERYTHING seems to be working out right for Carter Brey, the 30-year-old cellist who will play Dvorak's beloved concerto with the American Symphony Orchestra on Sunday. He has racked up impressive competition victories, made debuts with several major orchestras, garnered rave reviews wherever he has played, won the enthusiastic support of Rostropovich and, most recently, bought a cello.

title: New Saxophone Music
description: The composer and saxophonist Richard Landry will play new music for tenor saxophone tomorrow at 8 P.M. as part of the Next Wave festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, near the Atlantic Avenue IRT station. He will be joined by the percussionist David van Tieghem for part of the concert. Tickets are $15, and the number for information is (718) 636-4100.

description: What with all the CBS promotion for its miniseries ''Ellis Island,'' one might well be put off at tuning in ''Ellis Island: The Odyssey of a Dream,'' tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. on Channel 2. This would be a pity because, despite all portents that might point to a quick job of ransacking the files for old film, it is a half-hour of television that manages to catch a heartstring along the way.

description: The Philippine Supreme Court ordered the release today of a detained journalist who reported last year that the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was a high-level military conspiracy. A civilian panel said last month that it had found evidence of such a conpiracy.

title: Leroy Jenkins and Sting
description: The jazz violinist Leroy Jenkins and his electrified band, Sting, will perform tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street; 247-7800. Tickets are $10.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: VANESSA REDGRAVE'S SUIT AGAINST BOSTON SYMPHONY GOES TO FEDERAL JURY
description: A Federal jury began deliberations today in Vanessa Redgrave's breach of contract suit against the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The actress's suit has divided Boston's artistic community and raised troublesome issues about freedom of speech and art.

STUDIED ARCHITECTURE OF BRAIN
description: Dr. Norman Geschwind, professor of neurology at Harvard Medical School and an authority on the brain, died Sunday of a heart attack at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 58 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Jet Crashes in Germany
description: A British jet fighter crashed today in Bavaria, barely missing a convent. Two crewmen ejected and were hospitalized with minor injuries, the police said.

title: Vendo Official Returns To Fill Operating Post
description: The Vendo Company, the vending machine and electronic component manufacturer that has been in and out of financial difficulties for much of the last decade, said yesterday that it had named Joe R. Town, a former executive at the company, as president and chief operating officer.

title: Lincoln Savings Commercial Paper
description: Lincoln Savings and Loan Association announced plans yesterday to sell up to $500 million of commercial paper through a special-purpose subsidiary called the Lincoln Funding Corporation. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets will sell the paper.

title: SIX PUBLICATIONS BANNED IN CHILE
description: The Government today suspended publication of six opposition magazines, severely restricted radio, television and newspaper reports and banned all political meetings.

title: U.S. Steel Plans To Close Plant
description: Slumping demand for iron ore will force the United States Steel Corporation to close its Minntac taconite plant in Mountain Iron next week, idling about 1,800 workers, union officials said. Employees have been told that the plant would close on Nov. 17, said James Daniels, president of United Steelworkers Local 1938.

Revenues for the latest quarter and 6 months include a gain of $132,000 from the sale of certain property.

title: Or, N.M.A.H.S.T.C.
description: With any luck at all, this should be the final report on renaming the catch-all museum of the Smithsonian Institution situated on the Mall. When it first opened 20 years ago, the spacious modern display hall was called the Museum of History and Technology, on the theory that everything in its wide-ranging collections would qualify as one or the other.

title: MUSIC: JOHN KAIZAN NEPTUNE
description: JOHN KAIZAN NEPTUNE, an American who now lives in Japan, has developed remarkable technique on the shakuhachi, a five-holed bamboo flute. He intends to create a fusion of Eastern music and jazz, but Wednesday at the Japan Society, his dexterity was more impressive than his hybrid music.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: DOVE'S PAINTINGS AND OTHER 'EXTRACTIONS'
description: THOUGH he was America's first exhibited ''abstract'' artist, Arthur Dove (1880- 1946) didn't much care for the term. He preferred to call his work ''extraction,'' by which he meant drawing out the ''essence'' from the forms and elements of the visible world, painting not a wind-swept landscape, but - as he put it - the ''weight'' of the wind itself; not a foghorn, but the bass vibrations of its sound.

title: A MYOPIC APPROACH TO MARIJUANA
description: For better or for worse, marijuana has become as American as apple pie and computers. It is now the nation's second largest cash crop, according to the House Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control - more important than wheat or soybeans and second only to corn. This state of affairs is directly traceable to Government policy.

title: Europe's Steel Deadline
description: The Common Market is under pressure to extend its Dec. 31 deadline for ending government subsidies to steel producers, a spokesman said today. Some of the 10 member nations want more time ''to cope with the problems of restructuring,'' he said. Industry ministers will discuss the issue in Brussels on Nov. 22.

title: MANY ABLE TO AVOID GUN'S LAW MANDATORY TERM
description: The man charged with shooting his lawyer yesterday outside a Queens courtroom while on trial on a weapons charge is one of the 10,000 people indicted each year under New York State's strict gun control law.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Operating loss.

title: Let Them Eat Skippy!
description: Democratic opportunities for revenge were not frequent on election night, but some existed for the resourceful.

title: Polish Leader to Pay Visit to Hungary Today
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, is to pay a one-day visit to Hungary on Friday.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROYAL DUTCH PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARTIST OF THE SPORTING LIFE
description: New Yorkers have an excellent opportunity this month to see the work of Brooklyn-born Ogden M. Pleissner, one of this country's most highly respected sporting artists.

title: WAR'S CHILDREN RELIVE PAIN IN TOUR FOR PEACE
description: Twenty-six young people from abroad whose families have been wrenched apart by war arrived in New York City this week to begin telling America's children of life growing up in the shadow of destruction.

title: Valentin Sokolov Dies at 58; A Soviet Dissident and Poet
description: Valentin Sokolov, a Soviet dissident who was a poet and writer, died earlier this month in a Soviet psychiatric clinic, the International Society for Human Rights reported today.

title: EDUCATION SECRETARY TO QUIT REAGAN CABINET NEXT MONTH
description: Education Secretary T .H. Bell announced today that he was resigning from President Reagan's Cabinet, saying he had witnessed the start of ''a real renaissance of American education.''

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEVRIES GETS U.S. APPROVAL FOR ARTIFICIAL HEART IMPLANT
description: Dr. William C. DeVries received Federal approval today to perform the second implant of an artificial heart. He first performed the operation in 1982 on Dr. Barney Clark.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reagan Halting Radio Talks
description: President Reagan will discontinue his weekly radio speeches, at least through the rest of this year, a White House aide said today. ''It just makes sense to discontinue until we have the budget and the program to talk about,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, a deputy White House press secretary.

title: PORT AUTHORITY MAKES PLANS FOR YONKERS INDUSTRIAL PARK
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday extended its economic development activities into Westchester County for the first time, with the approval of a plan for development of an industrial park in Yonkers.

title: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: BRONZES BY WOMEN AT BERRY-HILL GALLERIES
description: THE Brearley School is marking its centennial with an exhibition of small bronzes at the Berry-Hill Galleries, 743 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street. Appropriately for a girls' school, the 11 sculptors involved are women, and all were born within 15 years of the academy's founding. This means that they were pursuing their vocations during the sculpture boom that began after the Civil War, reached a peak in 1893 in both the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago and the founding of the National Sculpture Society and continued well into the 1920's.

title: Conwed Rejection
description: The Conwed Corporation said its board had rejected an unsolicited $21.50- a-share tender offer from the Cardiff Equities Corporation, a unit of the Leucadia National Corporation.

title: Tentative Pact Averts Canadian Ford Strike
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company of Canada reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract today, 19 hours before a deadline that would have sent 14,200 workers on strike at nine plants.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mariners to Decide
description: The Mariners will select Chuck Cottier , the team's interim skipper after the dismissal of Del Crandall in September, to continue in the manager's job, according to The Seattle Times, which said that a news conference to announce the appointment was scheduled for today. Asked for confirmation, a spokesman for the team said that he knew nothing of the appointment.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $395,000 for the quarter and $723,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $154,000 for the quarter and $318,000 for the 6 months.

title: YEAR'S TOP AUCTION HOUSE SHOWS
description: THIS weekend you can see Impressionist and modern art works by a veritable who's who of painters and sculptors of the last century as the city's two top auction houses prepare for the season's biggest week of art auctions. The works, ranging from Corot to Picasso, from Renoir to Leger, are valued at more than $60 million.

title: MANY AT EVERS GETTING U.S. AID FOUND INELIGIBLE
description: An audit by the City University of New York has found that almost a third of a sample of students receiving Federal aid at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn are ineligible.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIALS CALLED PLEASED BY REAGAN'S ELECTION VICTORY
description: Israeli officials say that they welcome President Reagan's re-election. They say they do not expect him, as a second-term President, to try to press Israel into accepting American ideas for a Middle East peace.

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,334,000.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Kansas City Kings, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. The Nets, fresh from a rousing victory Wednesday night over Washington, close out a home stand before embarking on a trip that will keep them away from New Jersey for two weeks.

title: Data Access Plan
description: Data Access Systems Inc. said it had completed its plan of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from securities transactions of $14,162,000 for the quarter and $605,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from securities transactions of $1,793,000 for the quarter and $8,778,000 for the 9 months.

title: GOOD NEWS ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: Events - at home, not abroad - have made me optimistic about America's potential for playing a more useful, constructive, humane and effective role in the world.

title: Fearless Puncher
description: Dwight Williams, a 26-year-old plumber from Syracuse who learned to box in prison, will have the dubious pleasure of being the first professional opponent for Mark Breland when the Olympic champion begins to fight for money, not medals, on Thursday at Madison Square Garden.

title: SHULTZ INDICATES SOVIET HAS DENIED SHIPPING FIGHTERS
description: The Soviet Union has told the United States that it has not shipped any advanced fighter planes to Nicaragua, Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated today.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEMORIAL FOR ALFRED CROWN
description: A memorial meeting for Alfred Crown, a film and theatrical producer who died Saturday at the age of 73, will be held Nov. 19 at 5:30 P.M. at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Arrangements for a service at a different time and place have been canceled.

title: OILERS WIN WITH :06 LEFT, EQUAL BEST N.H.L. START
description: The Edmonton Oilers remained unbeaten for a record-tying 14th game tonight when Jarri Kurri scored his second goal of the night with six seconds left to beat the Devils, 3-2.

title: Black & Decker
description: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company said it would close its plant in Allentown, Pa., which employs 850 people, in early 1986. The plant, bought last spring by the Maryland- based home equipment company, makes toaster ovens and related products. It was acquired by Black & Decker as part of the purchase of the General Electric Company's housewares business.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: WHEN veterans of the 1937 Paris Exhibition get together, they remember the celebrated standoff between the German and the Soviet pavilions. They remember Picasso's ''Guernica.'' Along with these portents of bad times to come, they also remember the enormous mural, about 30 feet high and almost 200 feet wide, that Raoul Dufy had produced in short order on a subject that would have daunted many a more pretentious painter - the history of electricity.

title: PRO SQUASH IS TAKING ITS COURT ON THE ROAD
description: Professional squash racquets players, accustomed to appearing before tiny crowds in cozy club settings, think they have just the thing to bring out more fans and pick up more prize money on their travels: a court that will travel along with them.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAW SIGNED MAKING JERSEY 2D STATE WITH SEAT-BELT RULE
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today making New Jersey the second state to require the wearing of seat belts in passenger cars.

description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. AIDES BROADEN WARNINGS TO NICARAGUA
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials, recalling the Monroe Doctrine, today broadened the assertion that United States security interests in the Western Hemisphere would be seriously threatened by the delivery of high-performance combat planes to Nicaragua.

title: HORNBECK OFFSHORE SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $623,000 from the recovery of an allowance for possible losses. c-Includes a gain of $1,168,000 from the sale of land.

title: MUSIC: VIOLA CONCERT AT THE Y
description: KIM KASHKASHIAN'S concert at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night offered older pieces transcribed for the viola and music by more recent composers, many of whom have discovered and embraced the instrument's special timbral patina.

title: Harmonic Choir
description: David Hykes and the Harmonic Choir, a group whose members use Tibetan and Mongolian vocal techniques that enable each one to sing multiple tones simultaneously, will perform tonight and tomorrow at 8 at the Cathetral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Tickets are $10 and $12, and the number for more information is 662-2133; tickets are also available from Ticketron outlets and through Teletron, 947-5850.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 6
HICKAM, DOW B. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TO BE HONORED BY CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION
description: Floyd Abrams, lawyer and lecturer,

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. For the year-ago 9 months, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Occidental to Sell Geothermal Unit
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in a move to concentrate on its main lines of business, said today it will sell its geothermal energy unit to the Kuwaiti-owned Santa Fe International Corporation for $350 million.

title: Bethlehem Mines
description: More than 900 coal miners will be out of work Friday when a mine and two repair shops in the Bethlehem Mines Corporation's Cambria division shut down, company officials said. Mine 33 and the Conemaugh and Mine 32 repair shops will close indefinitely, Art Roth, a company spokesman, said.

title: PUBLISHING: FITZGERALD-FULLER AFFAIR RECOUNTED
description: JAMES R. MELLOW'S new book about F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, ''Invented Lives,'' describes a brief love affair between the 23-year-old Fitzgerald and 27-year-old Rosalinde Fuller, an English actress who may have been the inspiration for Fitzgerald's bold chorus girl in ''Head and Shoulders.''

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DeLorean Plea for Aid Said to Bring Many Calls
description: John Z. DeLorean's unusual public appeal for money to pay legal expenses has brought calls from people across the nation offering to help the former automobile maker, a DeLorean spokesman said today.

title: COUNCIL PANEL VOTES MEASURE ON TAX BREAKS
description: A compromise bill that would restrict tax exemptions for developers of luxury housing in most of Manhattan unless they provided low- and moderate-income units was approved by a City Council committee yesterday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: FOLLOWING is a sampling of restaurants that will serve turkey dinners on Thanksgiving, as well as other special dishes. All prices are for individual prix fixe meals.

title: VOICEMAIL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After non-operating expenses from a settlement with the company's former president, Thomas J. Zimmerman, and a reserve for the anticipated costs of subleasing the company's Los Angeles office amounting to $54,849 for the quarter and $55,381 for the 9 months.

title: Debate on Israel
description: The future of Israel will be debated by Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the Jewish Defense League, and Alan M. Dershowitz, a lawyer and Harvard law professor, on Sunday at 7 P.M. at the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, 3700 Henry Hudson Parkway in the Bronx. Admission is $5. Information: 796-4730.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income which is after a tax credit of $1,754,000 for the 9 months from a previously reported settlement of a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: A Regional Push for Pontiac
description: Soon after David Deutsch & Associates won the account in June of the New York, New Jersey and Fairfield County Pontiac Dealers Association, Donald Deutsch, vice president, creative director and son, sat at a conference table with some of his troops trying to brainstorm a way of tying in with Pontiac's continuing national ''We'll excite you'' campaign.

title: ARGENTINE DEBT: SOME IS FAULTED
description: Federal bank regulators have classified some loans to Argentina as ''substandard,'' a step that might increase bank resistance to granting fresh credits and delay final approval of an International Monetary Fund program of emergency financial aid, Federal officials reported today.

title: THAI DEVALUATION CREATING TENSIONS
description: Tensions between Thailand's civilian Government and the commander of the country's armed forces erupted into an open confrontation today over the Government's decision to devalue the national currency.

title: JO SULLIVAN PERFORMING THE SONGS OF LOESSER
description: -woman revue ''I Hear Music . . . of Frank Loesser and Friends'' at the Ballroom Theater is the chance to rediscover the kind of golden lyric soprano that is a vanishing breed among theatrical voices. Thoroughly trained in the light opera tradition, Miss Sullivan got her big Broadway break in 1956 when Frank Loesser, her husband-to-be, chose her for the plum role of the mail-order bride Rosabella in his very operatic musical ''The Most Happy Fella.'' ''I Hear Music'' is filled with soaringly sweet melodies, not only by Frank Loesser but also by such spiritual ''friends'' of the singer as Victor Herbert, Giacomo Puccini, Vernon Duke and Jerome Kern.

title: MORAL TEST IN ETHIOPIA
description: ROME In addition to its problems of politics, logistics and money, the disastrous famine in Ethiopia presents a moral problem for people who aren't hungry.

title: FADED STAR KEEPS CHASING A DREAM
description: To those who believe that the Kentucky Derby is a dead-serious ritual whose roll of winners is etched in immortality, the big gray horse in Barn 70 at Hollywood Park is an embarrassment and a disgrace.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $26,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations and tax credits of $839,000 for the quarter and $1,017,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $9,803,000 for the quarter and $12,468,000 for the 9 months.

title: New Pact for Dantley
description: The Utah Jazz announced that Adrian Dantley , the star forward who led the National Basketball Association in scoring last season, had ended his holdout by agreeing to a three- year extension of his contract and that he was expected to be in uniform for tonight's game against the Golden State Warriors. No financial terms were disclosed.

title: Trooper Cleared In Beating at Fair
description: A State Supreme Court justice here today cleared a state police sergeant of all five assault charges stemming from injuries to a Syracuse man seized at the State Fair last year.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BONN AIDE DENIES TAKING MONEY
description: West Germany's Foreign Minister denied today that he ever took cash from the Flick industrial group or helped it in obtaining tax favors.

title: C.I.A. AIDE IN SAIGON SAYS DATA WAS 'ENORMOUS'
description: The former chief of Vietnamese Affairs for the Central Intelligence Agency testified yesterday that Gen. William C. Westmoreland's command was so generous with information on enemy troop strength that many intelligence analysts complained it was ''too much for their in-baskets.''

title: Dunlop Holdings Picks A New Top Executive
description: Sir Michael Edwardes, the man credited with saving the British car maker BL Ltd. from collapse, was named chairman and chief executive officer of troubled Dunlop Holdings yesterday as part of a sweeping change in the company's board of directors and management.

title: SHARON'S LIBEL SUIT WILL GO TO TRIAL
description: A Federal judge yesterday refused to dismiss the libel suit that Israel's former Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, filed against Time magazine.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: For the latest third quarter preferred dividend requirements exceeded operating earnings and net income.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include nonrecurring items that increased net income by $4,000,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: CUOMO NAMES A BACKER STATE'S COMMERCE CHIEF
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday named John C. Michaelson, an investment banker and longtime campaign supporter, to be Commerce Commissioner and the state's Director of Economic Development. The latter is a new post created by Mr. Cuomo.

title: SUPERTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income which includes tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $460,000 for the 6 months.

PHONE LINE RATE BID REJECTED
description: The Federal Communications Commission today ordered local telephone companies to scale back their proposed increases in access charges that long- distance companies pay for private lines used by businesses and government agencies.

title: SCREEN: 'NIGHTMARE'
description: IN ''A Nightmare on Elm

title: Report From Phoenix
description: Leonard Tose was in Phoenix yesterday amid reports that he was trying to sell the Philadelphia Eagles to interests who would move them to that city. But Ed Wisneski , a team spokesman, denied that the reports were accurate and said that neither Tose nor his daughter, Susan Fletcher , the club vice president and legal counsel, would comment on them.

title: A Thank-You Note
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro's mother, Antonetta, telephoned Mondale-Ferraro headquarters at 369 Lexington Avenue yesterday, where Trudy Mason was packing up the press office.

title: SOONER STATE FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JON CRYER IN 'NO SMALL AFFAIR'
description: THE schoolboy precocity of its teen-age hero - the kind of boy who can come home to find a stranger in the family apartment and introduce himself as ''Charles Cummings, in case you're wondering whose mother you had your way with'' - gives ''No Small Affair'' a brittle but definite charm. And Jon Cryer, who plays Charles, makes him a toothy, good-humored adolescent with style. The film is supposed to center on Charles's affair with a glamorous would-be rock singer, Laura Victor (Demi Moore), who at 23 is the older woman in his life. But Charles is more appealing than either Laura or her music, and it's Charles who keeps the movie lively.

AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: VIETNAM WAR VETERANS ASSEMBLE FOR CEREMONY
description: Thousands of Vietnam-era veterans began assembling here today for a weekend of remembering the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Viveca Lindfors Play
description: ''Anna,'' a one-woman play written by and starring Viveca Lindfors, will begin performances Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Writers Theater, 133 Second Avenue, off St. Marks Place and East Ninth Street.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The project was scrapped, the insurance money collected and the cast dispersed to other projects. But William Sackheim, the film's producer, still had hopes for the material. So the screenplay, which had been written by Craig Bolotin, was rewritten by Charles Bolt and Terence Mulcahy. The completed film, which stars Jon Cryer and Demi Moore and was directed by Jerry Schatzberg, has more humor than the first version and a leading lady who's a rock singer in her 20's.

title: Grumman Planes
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation received three Navy contracts totaling $65.6 million for nine E-2C aircraft, the Defense Department said. Work on the contracts is expected to be completed by February 1987, it said.

title: TIMES TO PRINT IN OHIO
description: The New York Times, citing continued growth, said it would begin printing its national edition next spring at the plant of The Lorain (Ohio) Journal.

LED VOLUNTEER UNIT ON SMALL BUSINESS
description: Sidney Kushin, former director of New York City's Executive Volunteer Corps, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

description: b-Net income.

OBJECT RECOGNITION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CBS NO. 1 IN RATINGS ON VOTING
description: CBS News, showing strength in areas not monitored in the nine-city sample Nielsen ratings Tuesday night, won the national election night contest among the three networks by a comfortable margin.

title: Debt
description: * BMC Industries said it had received a commitment from a group of lenders led by Prudential Insurance Co. of America for the sale of $30 million of convertible subordinated debentures.

title: WE CAN STILL STOP CREEPING POLLOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Messengers
description: The drummer Art Blakey and his current Jazz Messengers will play hard bop tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street; 242-1785. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is an $8 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: MARY McFADDEN designed a new gown for the Statue of Liberty, a column of the tiny pleats that are her trademark. Ellen Burstyn gave a group of chairs to the City Council to sit on ''when contemplating the Broadway theaters.'' David Bowie created the ''official New York City haircut,'' a flight of steps ascending, through a silver- blond wig, the back of the Statue of Liberty's head. Joanne Woodward designed a new form of mass transportation for the city, a silver ballet slipper on a monorail. Andy Warhol signed sheriffs' badges and ''I Love New York'' mugs and ashtrays for the Convention and Visitors Bureau.

title: Dow Seeking More Of Morton-Thiokol
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would request authorization from the Federal Government to increase its stake in Morton- Thiokol Inc. to 15 percent. But Dow continued to say that it was interested only in an investment, not a takeover.

title: General Foods: A New Look
description: Say bye-bye to that cute little box containing a ''G'' and an ''F'' and a few colored dots. It served bravely as the General Foods trademark for 22 years.

title: THE NEW REALITY
description: Exit polls confirmed what any

title: Dining Out Guide: Upper East Side Elegant
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AN AMERICAN PLACE, 969 Lexington Avenue, at 71st Street (517-7660) -

title: ST. LOUIS OFFICIAL AND FIVE OTHERS INDICTED IN A CABLE TV EXTORTION
description: A Federal grand jury indicted the president of the St. Louis Board of Aldermen and five other people today on charges of extortion.

title: LESS DRAMATIC REMEDY FOR BABY FAE CASES
description: To the Editor:

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 6
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $32,200 for the 12 weeks and $700,800 for the 40 weeks. c-Including income of $1,245,800 from discontinued operations.

title: INSTIUTE RUSK FOUNDED NAMED FOR HIM AT LAST
description: At last they are hanging Dr. Howard A. Rusk's shingle on the hospital he founded and ran for more than 30 years.

title: Foote, Cone Profits
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications yesterday released its third- quarter financial results. They showed that the company had net income of $4.7 million, or $1.30 a share, a 62.1 percent increase from the $2.9 million, or 88 cents a share, earned in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues for the quarter increased 16.8 percent, to $68.2 million, from $58.4 million.

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; First Zero Coupon Bond Backed by Mortgages
description: The Franklin Savings Association, a privately held savings and loan based in Ottawa, Kan., plans to sell the first issue of zero coupon mortgage-backed bonds, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Convictions Are Upheld
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit Wednesday upheld the convictions of Yorie Kahl, Scott Paul and David Broer on charges stemming from their part in the case of a fugitive, Gordon Kahl. They were arrested after two United States marshals were killed in a shootout with Mr. Kahl, a tax protester, in February 1983 outside Medina, N.D. The marshals were trying to arrest him for violating probation on a charge of failing to file income tax forms.

title:
WORKING PROFILE:Michael H. Robinson;
SPIDER MAN AT HELM OF NATION'S ARK
description: Each weekday morning at 6:30, while many bipeds in this city are groping for a first cup of coffee, Dr. Michael H. Robinson enters the gates of his Washington fief, sometimes to a fanfare of trumpeting elephants and the basso songs of the lions.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE IS LAUNCHED ON SATELLITE SALVAGE FLIGHT
description: The space shuttle Discovery rocketed into orbit today on a planned eight-day mission to launch two new communications satellites and retrieve two stray ones in the first space salvage operation.

title: UNIONISTS REASSESS MONDALE SUPPORT
description: Union leaders, wincing from the defeat of a Democratic Presidential ticket they had backed with maximum energy, today sought consolation in the fact that they had turned out substantial majorities of their own membership for Walter F. Mondale.

title: ELECTION RESULTS TROUBLING BLACKS
description: Black voters and politicians are looking hard for a silver lining in the Reagan landslide, but they are disappointed by key races lost and fearful about the effect of four more years of programs and policies they consider inimical to blacks.

title: OSHA Regulation on Noise Thrown Out by Federal Court
description: A Federal appeals court today threw out a temporary Federal regulation designed to reduce hearing loss caused by noise in the work place.

title: UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICAIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Revenue figures for 1984 include gains from the disposal of properties of $1,040,000 for the quarter and $1,750,000 for the year. Revenue figures for 1983 include gains from the disposal of property of $7,000 for the quarter and $3,850,000 for the year. Revenues for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of the company's wholly owned subsidiary, United Artists Cablesystems Corp., on a fully consolidated basis. In the year-ago quarter, the subsidiary's operations were reported using the equity method which included it's 49 percent share of the earnings of Rogers UA Cablesystems Inc., a predecessor company to United Artists Cablesystems.

title: 25 U.S. WARSHIPS IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: The United States Navy has 25 warships, including the newly renovated battleship Iowa, on maneuvers in the Caribbean, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Howard C. Davidson; Ex-Air Force General
description: Maj. Gen. Howard Calhoun Davidson of the Air Force, a World War I pilot and commander of the Tenth Air Force in the China-Burma-India theater in World War II, died Wednesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Hospital in Washington. He was 94 years old.

title: Sonmor Returns
description: Bill Mahoney , the scholarly coach who guided the Minnesota North Stars to a division championship last season, was dismissed yesterday after the team's record had fallen to 3-8-2 with a loss to Buffalo on Wednesday night. He was immediately replaced by Glen Sonmor , who quit as North Star coach in January 1983 after a bar-room fight with a fan and who had recently been serving as a scout for the team.

title: CARE PLUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No comparative year-ago results are available because the company began operations in December 1983.

title: 2 DAYS AFTER ELECTION, COAST MAYOR IS ON TRIAL
description: Jury selection began today in Mayor Roger Hedgecock's trial on charges of conspiracy and perjury, two days after another jury, the San Diego voters, re-elected him to a new term by a wide margin.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $600 MILLION
description: After two days of tempestuous activity, with sharply falling prices and rising bond yields, Treasury note and bond prices turned up late yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced a $600 million decline in the nation's basic money supply.

title: BOOK SAYS LINDBERGH REPORTED ON GERMANS
description: Charles A. Lindbergh, who was criticized by fellow Americans for his red- carpet treatment by the Nazis before World War II, made detailed reports to Washington describing German air power, a recently published book says.

title: All-Male Clubs Get A Reprieve at Harvard
description: Harvard University's elite all-male social clubs, which have resisted accepting women members for nearly 200 years, have been given a one-month extension before facing possible sanctions for discrimination.

title: By the Book
description: The problems of high school athletes preparing to enter college have been of increasing concern to coaches, administrators and academic counselors over the last several years. They have been aware that many athletes are poorly prepared for college work, don't understand academic demands they must meet and often fail to earn a degree.

description: The armed forces can favor Congressmen with rides on aircraft carriers or sleek military jets. The National Science Foundation can escort them to the South Pole. Big corporations can take them to hunting lodges and sports magnates can give them box seats at important games.

title: THE MEDIUM AND MONDALE
description: Walter F. Mondale and television have each been a part of American public life for more than 35 years, but it was not until Wednesday, when the number of viewing households had reached almost 84 million and his own defeat in the Presidential election was just hours behind him, that Mr. Mondale seemed to discover an elemental political truth. A reporter had asked him what the lessons were for someone in his position four years from now.

Portugal Won't Accept Rumanian Archbishop
description: Portugal refused a residence permit today for a Rumanian Orthodox Archbishop who was deported from the United States in August after being accused of concealing war crimes.

description: The city's Board of Estimate early this morning unanimously approved a nearly $2 billion plan to rebuild Times Square.

title: 3 Bronx Youths Held in Stabbings
description: Three Bronx teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with stabbing three other youths during a fight Halloween night in a housing project in the Bronx, the police said.

title: LAUREN SCORES FOR AMERICAN SPORTSWEAR
description: Ralph Lauren's spring clothes are clean, uncomplicated and understated. They aren't the least bit gimmicky. They make no attempt to change the world. They simply look comfortable to wear and stylish in a nonaggressive way. The show Wednesday night was another triumph for traditional American sportswear.

description: A stunning last-ditch upset removed one American team from contention here at the World Team Olympiad Wednesday night, but the other is advancing toward a title.

title: Yanks Select Top Free-Agent Pitchers
description: The Mets were one of three teams that selected no one in baseball's ninth free-agent draft yesterday. The Yankees were one of six teams that wound up with negotiating rights to both Rick Sutcliffe and Bruce Sutter, who are certain to be the most expensive of the 56 players in the draft. It remained uncertain, though, how seriously the Yankees would pursue the two pitchers, Sutcliffe the starter and Sutter the reliever.

title: BABY FAE'S MOTHER ASKS PRIVACY AND REPEATS SUPPORT OF SURGERY
description: The still anonymous mother of Baby Fae, the infant who received the heart of a baboon, expressed some of the pressure she and her husband have been feeling in a statement released at a news conference today.

description: Some time ago, Larry Holmes asked his wife, Diane, about the large jar of coins he discovered in the kitchen of their mansion in Easton, Pa.

Comings and Goings
description: In a remarkable turnabout, Coach Dennis Green of the Northwestern football team, who had reportedly been on the verge of being dropped last week, was rewarded yesterday with a new three-year contract. The accord followed 10 days of meetings between Green, who had one year remaining on a five-year contract, and Athletic Director Doug Single . . . . Jimmy Connors has accumulated enough tour points to join John McEnroe , becoming the second player to qualify for the Volvo Masters tennis tournament, to be played at Madison Square Garden in January. . . . Fran Polsfoot , a Denver Bronco assistant coach, will re-enter a hospital Monday for treatment of a brain tumor that doctors had thought was in remission.

title: The Crates of Nicaragua When the facts are murky, and crated, deduce as best you can. The suddenly public suspicion that Nicaragua is receiving advanced Soviet warplanes has evoked an interesting response from the Sandinista Government. In one breath its spokesmen proclaim the right to buy MIG's. In the next they insist they have no MIG's, that none are en route and that none have been ordered.
description: If this denial is a lie, it will be known soon enough. For the moment it is good to have a response that at least tacitly, and no doubt fearfully, concedes that Nicaragua's arms purchases, especially from the Soviet Union, are a matter of intense - and we would add legitimate - concern to other American nations.

title: Few Followers of Guru Vote
description: Only 239 of 7,000 disciples of an Indian guru and homeless people living at his commune voted Tuesday, failing to carry out a threatened attempt to takeover a rural county government. But a spokesman for Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the guru, indicated the commune might challenge election results.

title: JOURNALISTS QUESTION EMBARGO ON CAMPAIGN NEWS
description: A special issue of Newsweek magazine, published yesterday, features what is described as confidential information on the Presidential campaigns gathered for the past year on the understanding that it would not be published until after the election. The agreement prompted a worried response from some journalists who say it raises thorny ethical questions.

title: FILM: 'PARIS TEXAS,' WRITTEN BY SAM SHEPARD

title: ARGENTINA DEBT SPLITS U.S. BANKS

This could make an accord more difficult to achieve, as well as more onerous for the giant money center banks that are already heavily involved in Latin America.

The Ultimate Junket NASA has invited Senator Jake Garn, the chief arbiter of its funds on the Senate Appropriations Committee, to go for a ride on the space shuttle. There've been enough astronauts sent to the Senate, so what's wrong with sending a Senator into space?
description: Exactly that. It was their careers as astronauts that gave Jack Schmitt and John Glenn entree to the Senate. If being shot into space can make a novice more electable to Congress, it will surely boost an incumbent politician into a third term and beyond. Senator Garn, a 52-year-old Utah Republican, must stand for re-election in 1986.

title: MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESTAURANTS
description: MANY New Yorkers remember the old Polo Lounge in the Westbury Hotel as a genteel East Side watering hole where dispirited businessmen - the kind of characters who inhabit John Cheever stories - would stop for a few martinis and an encouraging word before catching the 7:08 to Darien. A three-year renovation of the building, under new ownership, has transformed what is now called The Polo into perhaps the best hotel dining room in the city - and one of the better French restaurants overall.

Princeton Reissuing 'History of the Sikhs'
description: In the wake of Indira Gandhi's assassination by Sikh members of her security guard, Princeton University Press is reissuing in paperback early next month its two-volume ''History of the Sikhs'' by Khushwant Singh, himself a Sikh, a novelist and once a close adviser to Mrs. Gandhi. The book was originally published in hard cover by Princeton in 1963 and 1965, but it went out of print in 1978. The first volume covers Sikhism from the birth of its founder in 1469 to 1839; the second continues the history to the death of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in 1964.

title: Pantry Pride Lawsuit
description: Pantry Pride Inc., the supermarket chain based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said yesterday that it had filed suit against Patrick J. Rooney, an investment banker, and his firm, Rooney, Pace Inc., along with Stuart Perlman, a Florida investor, charging violations of Federal securities law. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, charges that the defendants bought large amounts of stock covertly and unlawfully in an effort to win control of the company. It seeks to prohibit the defendants from voting their shares and to require them to divest themselves of all unlawfully acquired shares.

Canada Taking Steps To Cut Budget Deficit
description: Canada's Minister of Finance told Parliament tonight that the nation's economy is in worse shape than even his newly elected Progressive Conservative Party suspected, and he announced urgent measures to cut next year's projected Federal deficit by $3.2 billion, to $26.5 billion, in United States dollars.

title: LEBANESE MEET WITH THE ISRAELIS ABOUT A PULLOUT
description: Israeli and Lebanese Army officers began talks here today on conditions for an Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon.

Mulloy, at 71, Serving It Up
description: Gardnar Mulloy still has plenty of competitive energy left as he nears his 71st birthday on Nov. 22. Mulloy, the tennis director at the Boca Grove Plantantion, near his home in Miami, plays the game in earnest every day.

title: Friday BROOKLYN'S PUBLISHERS
description: When people talk about New York publishers, they usually mean those in Manhattan. To let everybody know that publishers also thrive in another borough, a Brooklyn Book Fair will be held from noon to 4:30 today and 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday in Prospect Park's Picnic House off Prospect Park West and Fifth Street. About 20 Brooklyn publishers will be represented, including Kitchen Table: Woman of Color Press; the Brooklyn (College Alumni) Literary Review; Confrontation, a literary magazine, and Somrie Press, publisher of books and broadsides. Music, including jazz and rock, will be performed, and poetry will be read each day at noon and 3:30. PREHISTORIC SOCIETY

The company said its Duval Corporation unit would withdraw from the mining of base metals, precious metals and potash and sell or otherwise dispose of properties related to these activities.

title: Winter Hours at Zoo
description: Winter hours and rates are now in effect at the Bronx Zoo, Fordham Road and the Bronx River Parkway. The zoo is open daily, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., through March, and admission is $1.25 (50 cents for those under 12). Information: 367-1010.

title: Merie Earle, Actress, Dies;Maude Gormley on 'Waltons'
description: Merie Earle, who played Maude Gormley on ''The Waltons'' television series and appeared in many feature films and TV commercials, died Sunday of uremic poisoning, according to her agent.

title: OUTLOOK FOR TAX REFORM
description: Throughout the election campaign, President Reagan stoutly maintained that the way to reduce the huge Federal budget deficits was through economic growth and reduced spending.Higher taxes, he said, would be accepted only as ''a last resort.'' Yet it is quite likely that millions of Americans would indeed find their taxes raised, some quite substantially, as a result of almost any version of the sweeping tax revision plan that has been advanced in Congress or the one likely to be proposed by the Reagan Administration after it receives recommendations from the Treasury next month.

title: OFFENSIVE LINE LETTING DOWN COWBOYS
description: In the last 19 seasons, the Dallas Cowboys have failed to make the playoffs only once, in 1974, when they finished in third place in the National Conference's Eastern Division at 8-6, behind the Washington Redskins and the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: S.E.C. Backs Mutual Fund
description: A divided Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to permit the Vanguard Group of investment companies of Valley Forge, Pa., to market a mutual fund that intends to invest all of its investors' dollars in other Vanguard funds.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL CHOOSES LEADERR WHO SUPPORTS ITS SOCIAL ACTIVISM
description: The National Council of Churches, which has come under attack for some of its programs of social activism, got a new leader today who endorses those programs but says they must be firmly rooted in Christian belief.

title: SECOND ISLANDER HURT AT PRACTICE
description: For the second consecutive day, the Islanders' practice proved as rough and as perilous as one of their games. Bob Bourne, skating in a routine drill, was knocked unconscious by a steaming Stefan Persson shot and required 21 stitches to close a gash in his scalp.

title: ART: JULIAN SCHNABEL THE CARNIVAL MAN
description: JULIAN SCHNABEL is the carnival man of contemporary art. There is hardly an image in his first show at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, through Dec. 1, that is not easily imaginable in a Mardi Gras celebration, either inching its way through throngs of people on a float or paraded on the outstretched and fanatical arms of devotees. Largely because Schnabel's paintings share with religious carnivals a mixture of devotional imagery, popular culture, bad taste, large scale, theatrical flair and frenzied expression, his exhibitions become themselves mini-carni- vals, festive and even rapturous for those who share Schnabel's sense of occasion, irritating and inflated for most of those who don't.

title: The Losers Lunch
description: On the whole, however, key operatives of the losing effort to make Walter F. Mondale President seem to have recovered their bearings. James A. Johnson, the campaign manager; Michael S. Berman, director of scheduling and advance, and John Sasso, who managed the Vice-Presidential campaign of Geraldine A. Ferraro, were observed relaxing over lunch at The Palm yesterday for what they said, in chorus, was the first time in months.

description: A burglar fell six stories to his death yesterday when a sheet tore as he was using it to lower himself into a Brooklyn apartment building, the police said.

MCDONALD'S DISPUTE ON COAST
description: McDonald's paid $4.7 million last week to Charles Griffis, a black franchise operator with four inner-city restaurants in Los Angeles. Mr. Griffis's lawyers say the money is in settlement of Mr. Griffis's charges of race discrimination.

title: Canada Is Requested To Annex Minnesota
description: A Minneapolis carpenter, depressed that President Reagan won re-election carrying 49 of the 50 states, has urged Canada to annex Minnesota, the only state won by Walter F. Mondale.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PROTESTERS' OFFICES RAIDED
description: The security police raided the offices of protest organizations and a black labor union federation here today, detaining at least six suspected leaders of a two- day work boycott that occurred this week.

title: FRUSTRATION OVER AIRLINE SLOTS
description: Samuel C. Clark 3d says he has run out of patience. Since April, Mr. Clark, staff vice president of government and industry affairs for Air Atlanta, has sat in on more than 20 meetings of the panel in charge of allocating additional slots at New York's busy La Guardia Airport.

title: PITFALLS IN TRYING A NEW FIELD
description: -Hubbell Inc., publisher of the leading directory of lawyers, decided to get into the business of placing lawyers last year, it was the first major change in the operations of the 117-year-old family company.
