E.P.A. TIGHTENING SMOKESTACK RULES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed new restrictions on the use of tall smokestacks by power plants and factories as a means of complying with the Clean Air Act. Sulfur dioxide and other emissions from these smokestakes have been identified as a source of the precipitation called acid rain.

title: First Round of the School Debate How sick is New York City's school system? Donna Shalala, the President of Hunter College, calls it a ''rotten barrel'' that needs ''fundamental, systemic reform.'' Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff concedes there are problems, but stresses ''very real and significant improvements'' over the last few years.
description: Who's right? On balance, we say Dr. Shalala. Public education in New York may finally be recovering from budget cutbacks and a stormy decentralization, as Mr. Brezenoff points out. But the system's health still requires some fundamental changes.

title: Consumers Power Tells Of Inquiry by S.E.C.
description: The Consumers Power Company, the financially troubled Michigan utility, said yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission for ''possible violations of the Federal securities laws.''

title: Swiss Inflation Is 3.1%
description: The cost of living in Switzerland rose six-tenths of 1 percent in October from September and 3.1 percent from 12 months before, the Government said today.

title: No Headline
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1984 International Moscow has assured Washington that it has not shipped any advanced fighter planes to Nicaragua, Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated. At the same time, Mr. Shultz, in an interview, said he planned to be directly involved with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in managing Soviet-American relations, including arms-control talks. (Page A1, Col. 6.) A Soviet ship that docked at the Nicaraguan port of Corinto Wednesday was carrying one or two helicopters for Nicaragua's army, according to a senior Sandinista official. He denied that any advanced planes were on the vessel or aboard any other ship heading for Nicaragua. (A10:1.)

description: b-Including a gain of $9.7 million from a state income tax refund and rate adjustment.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $17,900,000 from the sale of Canadian operations and a gain of $4,600,000 from the sale of certain non-oil and gas assets.

title: SEEKS OTHERS
description: Directors of Prentice-Hall Inc., the publishing house, yesterday unanimously rejected a $700 million takeover bid by Gulf and Western Industries as ''inadequate'' and placed the company on the auction block ''to seek a more favorable offer.''

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income figures for the year-ago quarter and 9 months are after the pro forma effect of business combination in 1983.

title: No Headline
description: Play About Incest

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $264,000 from a change in federal tax law.

title: THE REGION;
description: Governor Kean today signed legislation allocating $2.1 million to provide temporary housing this winter to the state's homeless and people facing eviction.

title: CLIENT IS HELD
description: A man on trial for attempted burglary and weapons charges shot and critically wounded his lawyer yesterday in front of the State Supreme Court building in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

title: Banking Pact Challenge
description: The Justice Department filed a brief today urging the Supreme Court not to hear a challenge by Citicorp and other big banks to the so-called New England Compact.

title: Struck Plane Maker Keeping Up Production
description: No quick settlement is expected in the strike by 6,400 aerospace workers seeking pay raises at a General Dynamics plant, a union spokesman says.

title: INDIAN MOSLEMS FEAR MOBS MIGHT PICK THEM NEXT
description: Many Moslems in this southern Indian city say they fear that widespread attacks against Sikhs in the aftermath of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's assassination are an indication of a larger problem. They say this is the inability of the Hindu-dominated Government to rein in effectively the right-wing Hindu groups that are openly challenging Moslems and other minorities in many parts of India.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giants Taste the Other Side
description: After one-sided upsets over Washington and Dallas, it has not escaped Harry Carson and George Martin that some pro football players have had more fun than they have. They have experienced too many new weeks, dragging themselves back into the Giant locker room, ''like a tomb, everybody's back against the wall,'' as Martin puts it.

title: Old Pop-Up Books
description: A historical display of life-size and miniature pop-up books is on view through March 15 at the Manhattan Laboratory Museum, 314 West 54th Street.

title: FLORIDA EXECUTES SLAYER OF FURNITURE STORE OWNER
description: Timothy Palmes was electrocuted today for murdering a furniture store owner who had refused him a job.

title: All-Star Jazz Quartet
description: The alto saxophonist Sonny Fortune is leading an all-star quartet - Ron Carter on bass, Kenny Barron on piano and Al Foster on drums - through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street; 255-4037. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Internorth Sells Stake in Bucyrus
description: Internorth Inc. said it had agreed to sell 4,083,038 common shares of the Bucyrus-Erie Company to Bucyrus- Erie for $13.875 each, or $56.6 million.

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fire Destroys Coast Project
description: A fire destroyed an unfinished luxury condominium project Thursday night, forcing evacuation of surrounding buildings and causing an estimated $15 million in damage, the authorities said. There were no reports of injuries in the fire.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $831,000 and a tax credit of $327,000.

title: Thanks, But No Thanks
description: Several owners in the United States Football League, dissatisfied with Commissioner Chet Simmons , are known to have been looking around for a replacement, and Al Davis says he is one of the people they've been looking at. ''I've been talked to about the possibility of being commissioner of the league from time to time,'' Davis, the managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, told Howard Cosell in an interview to be televised by ABC today on ''SportsBeat.'' Would he ever consider unloading his club and accepting the job? ''No, Howard,'' Davis said, ''I love the Los Angeles Raiders.''

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring after-tax gain of $700,000 related to the sale of investment securities. c-Includes a nonrecurring after-tax gain of $1.7 million related to the sale of a restaurant lease, net of certain charges, and the sale of certain investment securities.

title: Cottier at the Helm
description: The appointment had been expected, and yesterday the Seattle Mariners made it official: Chuck Cottier , who became interim manager when Del Crandall was let go in September, has been chosen to continue guiding the club next year. ''We looked at every viable candidate,'' said Chuck Armstrong , the Mariners' president, ''and, after we boiled it down, we decided that Chuck was our man for 1985 and hopefully beyond.''

title: SOVIET HAS QUERIES ON ARMS PROPOSAL
description: The Soviet Union has sought clarification of President Reagan's proposal for wide-ranging ''umbrella'' talks on arms control, the State Department said today.

title: CHIEF CONSOLIDATED MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $1,200,000 of reserves for contingent liabilities. Revenue figures for 1984 include gains from the sale of hotels of $4,534,000 for the quarter and $5,186,000 for the 9 months.

title: The Old and the New
description: In 1882, when Mrs. John Gihon's

title: ROTHMANS OF PALL MALL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRODUCER PRICES DOWN IN OCTOBER FOR THIRD MONTH
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, measuring industrial price changes that may influence what consumers pay later, fell by two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Labor Department reported today. It was the third successive monthly decline.

title: EX-C.I.A. AIDE CITES WESTMORELAND'S HELP ON TROOP FIGURES
description: The former chief of Vietnamese affairs for the Central Intelligence Agency testified yesterday that he believed for a few days in 1967 that Gen. William C. Westmoreland had imposed a ceiling of 300,000 on reports of the size of enemy forces in South Vietnam, perhaps to avoid criticism by the press.

title: OILERS BREAK RECORD
description: Jari Kurri scored three goals and Wayne Gretzky had two goals and four assists as the Edmonton Oilers defeated the Washington Capitals, 8-5, tonight and set a National Hockey League record of 15 consecutive unbeaten games at the start of a season.

title: THOSE RISING BANK CHARGES
description: REBECCA TERKIN, a New York sales representative, was very annoyed recently when her bank announced that it was raising the fees on its consumer accounts.

title: INTEREST RATES DECLINE AGAIN
description: Interest rates fell again yesterday, and the question being asked in the credit markets was not whether rates would keeping dropping but how quickly and to what extent.

title: Rebels Said to Kill 9 Turks
description: Five women and four children were killed in eastern Turkey when Kurdish guerrillas bombed two houses, martial- law authorities said today. An official statement said the attack took place Thursday night at the village of Karagecit near the town of Eruh. Security forces said they killed one of the guerrillas.

title: Subway Cleaners To Get New Rules
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reached an agreement with its largest union on assigning work to subway-car cleaners, M.T.A. officials announced yesterday.

title: Sheriff Is Rebuffed In Move to Arrest Cleric
description: A dismissed minister who leads unemployed steelworkers was ordered arrested in his church today for contempt of court, but his supporters turned away the sheriff, who said, ''I'm not going to kick in the door of a church.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A personality sketch on Thursday of Madeleine M. Kunin, the Governor- elect of Vermont, described the historical precedents incorrectly. She is the fourth woman elected to such a post in her own right. Three other women have succeeded their husbands as governors.

title: GROUP INCREASES STAKE IN ALEXANDER'S TO 35.6%
description: Alexander's Inc., one of the New York area's largest retailers, announced yesterday that an investment group including Interstate Properties and Robert M. Bass of Fort Worth and interests related to him had increased its stake in the company to 35.6 percent, from 27.8 percent.

title: REAGAN SIGNS MEASURE TIGHTENING RULES FOR DISPOSAL OF TOXIC WASTE
description: President Reagan today signed a major piece of environmental legislation that tightens Federal standards for the disposal of toxic wastes and extends controls to small companies.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses on the disposal of the company's beverage segment of $1,977,000 for the quarter and $3,877,000 for the year, a gain from the operations of the segment of $46,000 for the quarter, and a loss from the operations of the segment of $416,000 for the year. c-Includes gains from the operations of the company's discontinued beverage segment of $628,000 for the quarter and $3,811,000 for the year.

title: HEAD OF H.R.A. FAULTS ACTIONS IN EVICTION CASE
description: The head of the city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday that his agency had failed to intervene quickly enough to help a woman, described by officials as emotionally disturbed, before she was fatally shot by the police in an eviction dispute.

title: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition in April 1984.

title: COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Major Accounting Merger Backed
description: Price Waterhouse & Company and Deloitte Haskins & Sells won clearance from the Justice Department's antitrust division today to proceed with their proposed merger, which would produce the largest accounting firm in the nation.

title: FOR TRAINING, COACHING, CLASSES
description: Following are some of the centers in the New York area that give gymnastics instruction. Large, fully equipped centers for serious training and competition are usually found outside of Manhattan, where the rent is lower.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL GROUP BACKS A REORGANIZATION PROPOSAL
description: The governing board of the National Council of Churches today approved a reorganization plan intended to give smaller churches a larger voice in council management, particularly with regard to spending.

title: FIRSTGULF BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SALVADORAN REBELS ATTACK TOWN BUT ARE REPULSED
description: In their first major attack in six months, leftist guerrillas fought their way into this central Salvadoran town today, before being driven back by army paratroopers in heavy fighting.

title: BROADWAY FIRST: 'CATS' DOES ROCK VIDEO TURN
description: The Longacre Theater, empty recently, became the scene yesterday of a new hybrid in the media lexicon: the Broadway rock video. ''Cats,'' the hit musical seemingly playing now and forever at the Winter Garden Theater, reorchestrated and restaged one of its show-stopping numbers, ''The Rum Tum Tugger,'' and turned it into the first known case of a rock video taken from a Broadway musical.

title: U.S. OFFICERS PLAY DOWN MOVES IN NICARAGUA
description: United States military officers said today that the recent arrival of Soviet helicopter gunships in Nicaragua would add only a limited military capacity to the armed forces of that nation and that the additional capacity would be more defensive than offensive.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S.F.L. Helping Players Find Jobs
description: Once the United States Football League is certain that the planned consolidation of six teams into three can be completed, league executives plan to hold a dispersal draft to help some of the excess players find jobs with other teams.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $290,000 for the quarter and $320,000 for the 9 months.

title: 3 KLANSMEN GUILTY IN RACIAL BEATINGS
description: A Federal jury today convicted three Ku Klux Klan members of civil rights violations in what prosecutors called racially motivated beatings in western Georgia in 1982 and 1983.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VOLUNTEER CORPS BEGINS AIDING CITY
description: Their basic training ended, 56 teen- agers put on crisp, new gray-and-red uniforms yesterday and began transplanting trees and building picnic tables and benches in Roy Wilkins Southern Queens Park in St. Albans.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Terry Reason , a senior swingman for Marquette University's basketball team and the No. 3 scorer in California high school history, has been dismissed from the squad by Coach Rick Majerus , for reasons that were not disclosed. . . . Ron Flockhart , who played two seasons with the Philadelphia Flyers before being traded to the Pittsburgh Penguins last season, has been traded again, this time to the Montreal Canadiens in exchange for another center, John Chabot .

description: b-Including a tax credit of $222,000. c-Net income.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Scott & Fetzer Ends Kelso Talks
description: An offer by Kelso & Company to acquire the Scott & Fetzer Company expired, and Scott & Fetzer said its board and its financial adviser, the First Boston Corporation, had been exploring other acquisition proposals. Kelso, which had proposed to acquire Scott & Fetzer for $61 a share, or about $435 million, said it was disappointed that Scott & Fetzer's board had not supported the proposal.

title: LETTER: ON INTERSTATE BANKING
description: THE SMALL INSTITUTIONS WOULD SUFFER

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: QUESTION FOR THE HOUSE: WHO WON?
description: The battle of the ballot box is over, but already another partisan fracas has broken out in Washington. Both parties are vying to define the answer to the question of who really won the election in the House of Representatives.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Washington yesterday about Veterans' Day observances incorrectly described Robert A. Sniffen, chairman of the National Vietnam Veterans Network. Mr. Sniffen, a Navy enlisted man from 1960 to 1962, did not serve in combat.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Official Arrives in Cairo
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy arrived today for talks with Egyptian leaders after a three-day visit to Iraq, Egyptian officials said. He is expected to meet with President Hosni Mubarak and other senior officials.

title: HIM TARZAN, ME JANE.
description: While watching a Tarzan movie, I fell in love. Tarzan isn't the type I usually go for. He's nothing like a Columbia man. Never having taken Lit. or Art Hum., he probably couldn't discuss the relationship between self- identity and self-negation in ''Crime and Punishment,'' or speculate on whether the painter Balthus actually was a pedophile or simply used pedophilia to appeal to the voyeuristic tendencies in his audience. He probably wouldn't be much help in deciding on a cheap, but dry, white wine and wouldn't know a dialectic from a dinosaur, but Tarzan has other things going for him.

title: U.S. Replies on Marc Rich
description: The United States, after nearly four months of delay, has replied to a Swiss offer for help in the United States tax evasion case against Marc Rich, the fugitive commodities trader, the Government said today.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
CHALLENGE TO MEESE EXPECTED
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, who was largely responsible for holding up the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General, intends to continue his opposition, Senate sources said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a technical error, an article on the Washington Talk page in some editions on Thursday about Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, omitted a line. The passage should have said that Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, would replace Representative Clarence D. Long, Democrat of Maryland, as chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GANDHI'S ASHES PLACED AT FAMILY ESTATE
description: In a solemn ceremony today, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi placed an urn containing his slain mother's ashes under a tree on the Nehru family estate in northern India.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results for the year-ago quarter do not include the operations of Derotchild Knitwear Inc. and Fabric Tree Inc., which were acquired prior to Sept. 30, 1983.

title: Media Exposure
description: When DePauw and Wabash, a pair of Division III rivals in Indiana, play for the 75th consecutive time today, viewers over the Satellite Program Network's 520 cable systems should see a lot of Rich Bonaccorsi. Not only will the viewers see Bonaccorsi on the field, they will see him at halftime as well.

title: THE UNWANTED WAIFS OF 45TH AVE. IN QUEENS
description: When out-of-town guests visit, a Long Island City, Queens, resident says, he always shows them the sights of his typical New York neighborhood: the deli, the subway stop, the view down the street of the gleaming Chrysler Building, and ''this,'' he tells them proudly, ''this is our neighborhood abandoned car.''

title: Producers Pay $800 In 'Alone Together' Case
description: The producers of the Broadway play ''Alone Together,'' who were accused by the Department of Consumer Affairs of quoting a review out of context in an advertisement, have paid $800 in a settlement of the case.

title: Texas Jury Indicts Five In Nursing Home Case
description: A grand jury indicted a nursing home corporation, its president and four employees on murder charges today in the 1978 deaths of two patients at a Texas City facility.

title: G.M. SETS LAYOFFS
description: The General Motors Corporation said that on Monday it would indefinitely lay off 70 production workers at its Delco Products division plant in suburban Kettering. A G.M. spokesman, Jerry Robbins, said the layoffs were the result of inventory adjustments made necessary by strikes by the United Automobile Workers in the United States and Canada. Mr. Robbins said the layoffs do not reflect auto sales, which have been strong. But he said the inventory at Delco was still backed up, even though the division had 960 of its 3,200 employees on layoff during the Canadian strike.

title: Home of Black Family In Chicago Is Attacked
description: The Federal Burea of Investigation today joined the investigation of a five-hour attack on the apartment of a black family who moved into an all-white enclave, but the tenant said he would not to return to the neighborhood.

title: SEOUL GAMES WIN BACKING OF SOVIET
description: The International Olympic Committee received a document today in which more than 150 nations, including the Soviet Union, committed themselves to attending the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1984 Tax Reform Act resulted in a reduction of $577,000 in taxes on qualified earnings of the company's domestic international sales corporation for the latest 9 months.

title: VIADUCT OPENED ON RIVERSIDE DR. TWO DAYS LATE
description: Two lanes of a major Riverside Drive viaduct were opened to traffic yesterday evening, two days after many motorists were misled by a public announcement that it was ready for use.

title: OFF PUERTO RICO, A 'NORMAL' EXERCISE
description: F-14 Tomcat fighter jets thundered low over the smooth green hills of Puerto Rico today and headed eastward toward an unseen fleet of ships far out to sea.

title: S.E.C. Cites Jake Butcher
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Jake Butcher, whose Tennessee banking empire collapsed in 1982, with violating the antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: STATUE COMPLETES VIETNAM MEMORIAL
description: A bronze statue of three wary, weary American servicemen was unveiled today by veterans who said they hoped to dispel the ''myth'' that survivors of the Vietnam war were outcasts in their homeland.

title: TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: PUBLISHER OF TIMES CITES CONCERN FOR PRESS IN SECOND REAGAN TERM
description: The press has reason for concern about its First Amendment rights and access to government information under the second Reagan Administration, the publisher of The New York Times said tonight.

title: THE DANCE: NEW WORK BY CRATTY
description: Bill Cratty and Risa Steinberg, who are performing through Sunday afternoon at Riverside Church with the Bill Cratty Dance Theater, are exceptionally good dancers - they are thrilling to watch.

title: Hurricane Heads Out to Sea
description: Hurricane Klaus headed toward the open sea today with winds of 75 miles an hour while residents of northeastern Caribbean islands cleaned up millions of dollars in damage. The season's fourth hurricane raked the Virgin Islands and other islands in the region for three days.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income.

title: POLITICAL HINTS FROM CITY HALL
description: Woven together, several seemingly disparate episodes in city government over the last few weeks produce a tapestry that may spell out Mayor Koch's strategy for re-election.

title: Suit Over a Tower In TriBeCa Killed
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a suit that would have blocked construction of a $300 million computer and operatons center by Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc., the financial services company, in lower Manhattan.

title: EARLY MUSIC: THE KUIJKEN QUARTET
description: The three Belgian Kuijken brothers count among the most distinguished of all present-day early-music specialists. They have long since branched out into conducting and other far-reaching ways of propagating authentic Baroque style. But they are each masters of a different set of instruments, so their occasional reunions for concerts and tours become genuine occasions.

Bogged Down Over Sentencing ''Flat'' sentencing is advertised as a simple, painless remedy for the ailments of criminal justice. New York State's Legislature bought the idea last year, and Congress bought it as part of the new Federal crime package.
description: The advertisements, however, are often exaggerated. A New York commission set up to design the state's program is struggling with the technical problems and has become deeply divided. Unless it surmounts the conflict, flat sentencing would be better abandoned.

title: HIGHER DISEASE RISK IN YOUNGER CHILDREN LINKED TO DAY CARE
description: Children 5 years old and younger who attend day- care centers are almost twice as likely as those who stay home to contract a bacterial disease that is the leading cause of meningitis and epiglottitis in children, according to a new study.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Kansas City Kings, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. How much worse can things get for the Knicks? Losers in six of their first seven games, they learned yesterday that Bill Cartwright, who has yet to play this season, would not be back for weeks. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1:15 A.M., tape. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:20 P.M.) Football

title: SCHOOLS SHOULD BE RUN FOR CHILDREN, NOT PARENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LOBLAW COMPANIES LTD reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 16
description: b-After tax credits of $2,673,000 for the quarter and $6,255,000 for the 40 weeks. c-After tax credits of $2,230,000 for the quarter and $5,786,000 for the 40 weeks. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: THE MYSTERY OF THE ALTERED BEST SELLER
description: Politics and publishing are mysterious businesses. English readers of Jeffrey Archer's recently published best seller ''First Among Equals'' were treated to a tale of the lives of four Englishmen in line to become Prime Minister in the near future in the reign of King Charles. One, a Social Democrat named Duncan Fraser, has largely disappeared from the American version of the book, appearing briefly under another name in the crowd at the House of Commons.

title: ROOF OVER THE L.I.E.
description: To the Editor:

title: Midland-Guardian And PSFS in Pact
description: The PSFS Credit Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the manufactured housing financing operations from the Midland-Guardian Company and the Midland-Guardian Investment Company for about $70 million.

title: THEUS SPARKS KINGS
description: At the Nets' expense, Reggie Theus found a way to thrive in the Kansas City Kings' system tonight. After three quarters of playing no role in a contest that leaned to the Nets, Theus fell into his old part as the sly savior.

title: Hotel Venture Set
description: The Brock Hotel Corporation said it had signed a letter of agreement with the Americana Hotels Corporation that includes an understanding in principle for the companies to form a company made up of most of their hotel properties.

title: 117 Said to Die of Starvation In Remote Area of Indonesia
description: At least 117 people have died of starvation in a remote district of West Irian province, the daily newspaper Sinar Harapan said today.

title: SOTHEBY'S PLANS 3 AUCTIONS OF JUDAICA
description: Sotheby's, in what it said was the largest sale of its kind, will auction $5 million in rare Hebrew books, manuscripts and artworks in three successive sales in early December, the company announced yesterday.

title: Kodak Dividends
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said its board had raised the quarterly dividend to 80 cents a share, from 75 cents, and declared an extra dividend of 55 cents a share, the same amount it paid at the end of the last two years. The board also voted an annual wage dividend of $249.9 million for about 85,000 eligible United States employees. That dividend will be paid March 15.

title: Tornado Hits Missouri Town, Killing One With 20 Injured
description: A tornado struck a crowded shopping center here tonight, killing one person and injuring at least 20 others, the authorities said.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Activist Recovers From Fast
description: Mitch Snyder, the community activist who undertook a 51-day protest fast in behalf of the homeless, was released from Howard University hospital today. ''He's gained 20 pounds in the hospital,'' said a spokesman for the Community for Creative Nonviolence, Mr. Snyder's group. Mr. Snyder had lost 60 pounds. He ended his fast Sunday after President Reagan agreed to renovate a Federal building operated as a shelter for the homeless by the group.

title: Floridians Can Buy Florida Citrus Again
description: Fresh Florida citrus, denied to residents of the state for almost two months, went on sale again today in stores, markets and roadside stands.

title: BOWL HOPES PINNED ON UPSETS
description: Scouts from only two bowl games - the Gator and the Florida Citrus - will be at Giants Stadium today when West Virginia and Rutgers meet at 12:20 P.M. And they'll be there to see West Virginia, not Rutgers.

title: 3 House Races Are Undecided
description: Three days after the general election, candidates in three Congressional districts were still waiting today for an official declaration of a winner.

description: b-Including tax credits from loss carry forwards of $317,000 for the quarter and $636,000 for the year and a tax credit of $923,000 for the quarter and year.

title: A Snorkeler's Tale
description: When the landslide re-election victory for Bill Bradley as United States Senator from New Jersey was apparent last Tuesday evening, one of the television commentators discussed the Senator's style.

title: Collin Walcott, a Co-Founder Of 'World Music' Ensemble
description: Collin Walcott, a founding member of the ''world music'' ensemble Oregon, died Thursday in a hospital in Magdeburg, East Germany, after a car crash. He was 39 years old. Mr. Walcott, who played the sitar and tabla in the group, was one of the few Western musicians to incorporate this type of instrument into an ensemble.

title: WEST GERMANY IS DEMANDING RUMANIA RECALL 5 DIPLOMATS
description: The West German Government demanded today that Rumania recall five diplomats.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., a Pittsburgh-based maker of industrial and consumer products, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Alloy Rods Inc. unit to a group of private investors. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Sale of Unilever Unit
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British side of the joint British-Dutch household goods and foods company, said today that it had agreed to sell most of its Unilever Computer Services division to Electronic Data Services of Dallas. Terms were not disclosed, but Unilever said the deal would not affect a significant portion of its total assets. Electronic Data recently was acquired by the General Motors Corporation.

title: UPSTATE OFFICE WORKERS GAIN A LANDMARK PACT
description: Workers at the Syracuse office of the Equitable Life Assurance Society have agreed to a labor contract - the first in the company's history - that the union says has implications for unions and office workers nationwide.

description: b-Net income.

title: JURY ORDERS SYMPHONY TO PAY ACTRESS $100,000
description: A Federal jury today awarded the actress Vanessa Redgrave $100,000 in damages from the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which had canceled her 1982 scheduled performance as narrator in Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex.''

title: SCOUTING ; Sibling Rivalry
description: For the first time in an organized hockey game, Alain Lemieux of the St. Louis Blues got a chance to play against his younger and more famous brother, Mario, on Thursday night at Pittsburgh. Mario, who was the first selection in the entry draft by the Penguins after scoring 133 goals and 282 points for he Laval Voisins of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League, is 18, four years younger than Alain.

title: GASTRONOMES' FAVORITE FUEL IS ONLY A PRICKLY PLAGUE TO RANCHERS IN TEXAS
description: Cooking on mesquite may be the latest culinary fad in New York and California, and John Copeland, a rancher near here, would be happy to ship every bit of the woody trees that infest his 25,000-acre ranch to gastronomes.

title: FINDING PROJECT DIRECTOR NEXT STEP FOR TIMES SQ.
description: Having won unanimous Board of Estimate approval for the Times Square redevelopment plan early yesterday, city and state officials committed themselves to naming a full-time director for the project by the end of the month.

title: WORLD POPULATION GROWTH THREATENS OUR NATIONAL SECURITY

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,712,000 for the quarter and $3,872,000 for the 9 months. Storage Technology filed for protection against creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on Oct. 31.

title: NEW YORK TO CURB COASTAL BUILDING
description: Losing its battle against coastal erosion, New York State is putting regulations into effect that will prevent shore-front homes from being rebuilt if they are destroyed by storms.

description: PRINCE ALBERT. A Biography. By Robert Rhodes James. 299 pages. Alfred

title: 'Cozying Up' to Reagan Aided Some Foes, Republican Says
description: Many Democrats re-elected to the House did it by ''cozying up to President Reagan,'' and the President will remind voters of this should his second- term programs run into trouble there, a top Republican spokesman said today.

title: Judge Upholds a Test For Massachusetts Police
description: A Federal district judge today refused to stop a state police qualifying examination, rejecting arguments by the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that the test would perpetuate age discrimination.

title: FED EASED POLICY IN SEPTEMBER
description: The Federal Reserve reported today that it ''eased appreciably'' its grip on the nation's money supply in September but that a majority of its policy makers declined to ease even further in October.

title: DEMOCRATS VOICE FUTURE CONCERN
description: Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic Party chairman, asserted today that in future Presidential elections the party should balance its ticket regionally and reach out for independent and blue-collar voters with a message of economic growth and opportunity.

title: GYMNASTICS FOR CHILDREN: DEMAND IS RISING
description: Gymnastics has a new glamour for children after the unexpected triumphs of the United States gymnastics teams at the Summer Olympics. This fall enrollments have shot up in gymnastics schools all over the country, and the New York metropolitan area is no exception.

title: A.I.D. CHIEF TELLS OF AGONY OF AFRICAN FAMINE
description: Somber and horrified after a visit to drought- stricken Ethiopia, M. Peter McPherson, administrator of the Agency for International Development, said today that he had ''never seen anything like'' the famine that is devastating northern Ethiopia.

title: HARVEST FIGHTING SINCE JULY BREAKS OUT IN BEIRUT
description: The worst outbreak of fighting since last July erupted here late Thursday and continued into today.

description: Mesquite may be nothing more than a pesky bush to ranchers in the Southwest. But to the new breed of American cooks its wood is a valuable commodity for which they are willing to pay about $1 a pound.

description: There are so many myths about turkeys that it is difficult to separate fact from fiction. And people who ought to know better help to perpetuate the myths.

French Rocket Is Launched
description: A French Ariane rocket booster carrying two communications satellites stacked atop each other was launched today by the 11-nation European Space Agency. The second of the agency's Ariane-3 launchers, the 11th in the Ariane program, carried a MARECS B-2 maritime communications satellite and an American G.T.E. Spacenet F-2 telecommunications satellite on the way to 22,300-mile-high orbits shortly after liftoff, agency officials said.

title: ISRAEL PREVENTS 5 FROM TESTIFYING FOR TIME IN LIBEL SUIT BY SHARON
description: The Government today barred five prominent Israelis from appearing at the Manhattan trial of former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon's $50 million libel suit against Time magazine. Five other Israelis whom Time lawyers had sought to question were cleared to testify.

title: FOR GHANAIAN TRIP TO ETERNITY: A CANOE, A LIZARD
description: In this West African nation, as elsewhere, there are people who know how to make an art of living. But this ramshackle roadside town 10 miles northeast of the Ghanaian capital of Accra is home to a very different group of craftsmen: custom coffin makers.

title: MAN FREED AFTER GRAND JURY TESTIMONY ABOUT SON
description: A state judge freed a man today who had served nearly two months in jail for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating murder charges against his teen-age son.

title: CHINATOWN BAND AIDE, CITED AT CRIME HEARING, QUITS POST
description: The vice chairman of a Chinatown bank who was identified by witnesses at a Federal hearing as an organized- crime figure yesterday announced his resignation as a bank official.

title: In the Fast Lane
description: Willy T. Ribbs, one of the few black auto racing drivers in history, was introduced to Larry Holmes in the heavyweight champion's suite at Las Vegas, Nev., where he was relaxing before last night's fight against James (Bonecrusher) Smith.

RANGERS RALLY FROM 4-0 DEFICIT

Stanford Narrowing Choices For Presidential Library Site
description: Stanford University trustees are expected to decide Dec. 11 on which of three sites to recommend to the White House for the proposed Ronald Reagan Presidential library.

title: COUPLE WITH CHILD TOLD TO MOVE
description: A Florida judge ruled today that a couple must move out of their home of seven years in a section of a housing development restricted to adults because their 15-month-old daughter violates a no-child restriction in their deed.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A BAD YEAR FOR PUSHCARTS
description: Soon after midnight, hours before any office worker or tourist thought of breakfast, much less lunch, a hundred or so trucks lumbered through the city streets to deliver their cargo - 600,000 hot dogs, 750,000 rolls, cartons of mustard, relish, onions - one day's eating for New Yorkers from the ever-present pushcart.

title: Chess Game Postponed At Kasparov's Request
description: Gary Kasparov has taken his third postponement in the world chess championship match, chess officials said today.

title: NEDERLANDER IS OFFERED HOTEL THEATER RIGHTS
description: The Nederlander Organization has won the right to negotatiate a lease to operate the theater in the Marriott Marquis Hotel. The Nederlander group - currently the second-largest theater owners on Broadway - signed a letter of agreement authorizing the negotiations with the Times Square Hotel Company, which is building the hotel on Broadway between 45th and 46th streets.

Bird, who also had seven rebounds and three assists, went over the 40-point mark for the sixth time in his career before he squared off against Erving.

description: Larry Holmes said he beat James (Bonecrusher) Smith with one good hand tonight. But the victory, a 12th-round knockout in the cold desert night, was certainly not the anticipated mismatch.

description: A large cloud of toxic fumes escaped from a chemical plant in Linden, N.J., yesterday but dispersed after about an hour, authorities said. There were no reports of injuries.

description: William Kapelman, a former Assemblyman and State Supreme Court Justice, died of leukemia yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Knicks' Cartwright Suffers New Injury;  Center Out 6 to 8 Weeks
description: Just as the Knicks were counting the days to Bill Cartwright's return yesterday, the 7-foot-1-inch center suffered a fracture to the bone that connects the little toe to the left foot and will be out for another six to eight weeks. The injury occurred before practice at Upsala College in East Orange, N.J.

title: 3 S.I. Schools in Semifinals
description: New York City's public and Catholic high school football playoffs resume this weekend with three sets of semifinals, two of which have a Staten Island flavor. Three of the 12 teams - Port Richmond, New Dorp and Monsignor Farrell - are from Staten Island.

C.I.A. AIDE IS SAID TO URGE PUNISHING MANUAL'S AUTHORS
description: The inspector general of the Central Intelligence Agency has called for the punishment of several agency officials for their roles in preparing a C.I.A. manual instructing Nicaraguan rebels in guerrilla warfare, Congressional and intelligence officials said today. The manual advises rebels to kidnap and ''neutralize'' Nicaraguan Government officials, a term interpreted by many within the United States intelligence community and by the Nicaraguan rebel leaders to mean assassinate.

description: A happy group of Polish players, beneficiaries of a last-board Austrian disaster in Thursday night's semifinal, clashed this afternoon with France, the defending champions, in the World Team Olympiad final. After 16 deals, Poland led by the substantial margin of 46 international match points, 65-19.

PICKING A TEACHER
description: In gymnastics an experienced instructor can mean the difference between fun and serious injury, the experts say. While there are now no mandatory certification requirements for instructors, the United States Gymnastics Federation, the official governing body of the sport, plans to begin a certification program next fall.

title: INSTITUTIONS FORCE STOCK FEES DOWN
description: Big institutions, a dominant factor in stock trading, are forcing down the commissions they pay to securities firms. The drop has sparked fears of another blow to Wall Street profits, and could ultimately lead to a further restructuring of the industry.

title: MANAGUAN HELD UNLIKELY TO GET ADVANCED JETS
description: There is little prospect that Nicaragua will receive advanced jet aircraft anytime soon, in the view of most foreign diplomats and independent military analysts here.

title: THE THEATER: 'LOSING IT'
description: Jon Klein's ''Losing It,'' a good old boy comedy that opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse, is as rusty as it is rustic. As Arch, Cutty and The Kid chug-a-lug beer in the backyard of a shack near Nashville, swapping stories about their problems with women, we realize that we have been here before - in, among other plays, James McLure's immeasurably funnier ''Lone Star.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A personality sketch on Thursday of Terry L. Bruce, who was elected to the House of Representatives from Illinois's 19th Congressional District, misstated his State Senate voting record. He voted in committee against a call for a constitutional convention to consider a balanced-budget amendment to the United States Constitution, but not against the proposed amendment itself.

title: KIM C. ROGAL
description: Kim C. Rogal, an associate editor of Newsweek who wrote cover stories on a wide range of international issues, died apparently of a heart attack Wednesday after swimming. He was 32 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PO FOLKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Truck Parts Plant Sold
description: Walker Deutschland G.m.b.H., a unit of Tenneco Inc., said today that it had sold its truck parts factory in Mannheim to newly formed Moco Fahrzeugteile G.m.b.H. Terms were not disclosed. The Mannheim plant, which employs about 190 people, produces exhaust pipes, air vents, oil pans and belt pulleys.

title: 107 Reported Arrested In Raids in Chile
description: The police arrested 107 people today in raids on private homes and two labor unions, according to Government and church sources.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Lockheed Corporation's Lockheed Missiles and Space Company received a $207.4 million Navy contract for missile processing and support services, the Defense Department said. In additon, it said the Ashland Petroleum Company had received a $136.8 million contract for jet fuel production from the Defense Logistics Agency.

title: The Christmas Countdown
description: It's less than two weeks to Thanksgiving, and already there is Christmas news:

title: ELECTROLUX OF SWEDEN TRIES BIG LEAP TO EXPAND
description: In its 1983 annual report, published last May, the Swedish appliance maker Electrolux said that it hoped to build a strong position in several more countries during the next few years, probably through acquiring companies.

title: Military Secrets That Aren't When everything is stamped ''secret,'' confidence in the censor's judgment ebbs, and leaks inevitably flow. The best way to keep secrets is to keep their number small, a lesson American Governments keep having to relearn. Here they go again.
description: Besides the usual category of secrets, the Defense Department has invented a new category of semi-secrets to hoard scientific and technical information that previously could be made public. The new category seems designed more to avoid embarrassment, about overpriced spare parts and undera chieving weapons, than to deny information to the Russians, the ostensible purpose.

title: Farewell to Marathons
description: Waldemar Cierpinski of East Germany, who in 1980 became the second runner to win two successive Olympic marathons, has retired from competition, at age 34.

title: MATTHEWS KEPT BRIBE PAYMENT, AGENT TESTIFIES
description: An F.B.I. agent pulled an envelope stuffed with 70 $100 bills from his pocket today and testified that he had watched Michael J. Matthews, then Mayor of Atlantic City, retrieve it from his bedroom closet before dawn last Dec. 7 and hand it to other agents.

title: A.T.&.T. SEEKS FLEXIBLE RATE OF RETURN
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest supplier of long-distance service, proposed today that the Federal Communications Commission increase to 14.2 percent, from 12.75 percent, the company's allowed rate of return on interstate services.

description: The Beatrice Companies said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Brillion Iron Works to the Robins Group for $32.5 million.

title: Dorsett to Play
description: Although it has been a trying week for Tony Dorsett , the Dallas running back, he intends to play tomorrow when the Cowboys visit St. Louis for the important intradivision game against the Cardinals. Dorsett's father, West, died Thursday in Aliquippa, Pa., several days after suffering a stroke. A spokesman for the Cowboys said that Dorsett would play tomorrow and then attend the funeral, scheduled for Monday. . . . One Cowboy who will not play is Bob Breunig , the veteran middle linebacker who has been suffering from severe back spasms for much of the season and whose resulting subpar play has made him an object of boos from a number of Cowboy fans.

title: Oil From Damaged Ship Kills Birds on Coast
description: Thousands of gallons of black and yellow oil from a tanker that was damaged by explosions Oct. 31 washed ashore today, staining two beaches at Point Reyes, killing 50 sea birds and threatening thousands more, the Coast Guard said.

title: INTELSTAT: TIME OF UNCERTAINTY
description: On a hillside facing Connecticut Avenue four miles from the White House, construction workers are building one of the most visually striking projects to grace the city's changing skyline. It is a $50 million headquarters for Intelsat, the organization of 109 governments that runs the only worldwide satellite communications system.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: William Beasley Harris Dies
description: William Beasley Harris, the husband of Patricia Roberts Harris, a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, died Tuesday at Walter Reed Army Hospital after suffering a stroke. Mr. Harris, who was 70 years old, was an administrative law judge with the Federal Power Commission. Previously he was a lawyer and also taught at Howard University law school.

title: FOUNDED ART LIBRARY IN 1920
description: Helen Clay Frick, a former trustee of the Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue and founder of the Frick Art Reference Library, died yesterday at her home in Pittsburgh. She was 96 years old.

title: THE STRIKE THAT WAS LOW AND OUTSIDE
description: Tiny and insignificant reminders often provoke floods of memory. I have just read a little notice tucked away on the sports pages: ''Babe Pinelli, longtime major league umpire, died Monday at age 89 at a convalescent home near San Francisco.''

title: 3d Manila Hotel Blaze In 16 Days Takes 7 Lives
description: The nation's third fatal hotel fire in 16 days killed seven people in Manila today and injured 13, the police said. Manila's Mayor was quoted as saying that terrorists might be responsible.

title: Storage Technology
description: The Storage Technology Corporation reported a third-quarter loss of $64.7 million, compared with a loss of $5.2 million in the third quarter last year. The company, which filed for protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Code earlier this month, had revenues of $145.5 million for the quarter, up 20.8 percent from revenues of $120.4 million for the third quarter last year. The maker of data storage devices for large computers had been one of the more spectacular success stories of the computer industry with annual sales at one time of $1 billion, but it faltered as competition grew more intense.

description: A thin slice of fiberglass, a tiny strip of sheet metal and a syringe of painkiller today insured that Slew o' Gold will be able to finish his career by bidding for the richest prize in the history of horse racing.

description: The Labor Department is intensifying efforts to find work for war veterans, Acting Labor Secretary Ford B. Ford announced today.

description: Edper Investments Ltd., which is controlled by Peter and Edward Bronfman of Toronto, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Scott Paper Company's common stock to 12,036,167 shares, or 25 percent of the total outstanding. Edper said it bought an additional 650,000 shares on Oct. 31 in an open market transaction through Brascan U.S.A. Inc., an indirect subsidiary. Scott, based in Philadelphia, closed at $32.875, down 37.5 cents, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson announced today that hereafter he would devote most of his energies to the Rainbow Coalition, a new political organization that will be based in Washington, but would continue to hold the title of president of Operation PUSH, the civil rights organization he founded 13 years ago.

title: The Subway Tries Teamwork New York's subway system classifies 1,400 of its employees as car inspectors capable of making routine repairs they find to be necessary. Properly deployed, motivated and supervised, they should be able to keep 6,200 subway cars running satisfactorily. For years, however, they have not been properly deployed, motivated or supervised.
description: With Mayor Koch's help, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its union have now agreed to try a new approach. The effort deserves praise and close scrutiny.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES OMEGA 7 LEADER TO LIFE IN PRISON
description: A life sentence and an additional 35 years in prison were imposed yesterday on Eduardo Arocena, a Cuban exile convicted of murder and terrorist bombings as the head of an anti-Castro group called Omega 7.

title: YANKEE DRAFT PICKS BLUR RIGHETTI STATUS
description: Unlike the last few years, when players were puzzled over their positions with the Yankees, there will be no confusion next season, George Steinbrenner said yesterday. ''I've told my guys I want everybody to know their role next year,'' the owner said.

title: Lotus Software for Apple Expected
description: The Lotus Development Corporation is expected to announce on Monday a business-oriented software package for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh personal computer. The move would likely add momentum to Macintosh sales, especially to businesses, analysts said.

description: One of the many delightful things we do in New York is eat cuisine. I recommend it to everybody.

title: Zimbabwe Rebels Slay A State Senator
description: Rebels assassinated a state senator from the ruling party today, setting off riots that left one person dead and 180 wounded, the Government said.

A DIRECTORY FOR A VARIETY OF SERVICES
description: SEVERAL organizations provide counseling, lists of schools and other services for learning- disabled students. State education departments also publish listings, and high school counselors and private therapists also usually have information.

title: Catherine Elliott To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Elliott Jr. of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Story Elliott to Patrick J. Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford W. Mitchell of Doylestown, Pa., and Ogunquit, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER AND 50 CONCERNS MEET ON SECURITY
description: Westchester County officials met here today with executives of 50 corporations to discuss ways to make the businesses less vulnerable to acts of terrorism.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1984 Lebanon suspended talks with Israel over the the withdrawal of troops in southern Lebanon, and took the action under fierce pressure from Islamic fundamentalists. The Lebanese said the reason for the suspension was the Israeli arrest of 13 Shiite Moslem officials in the Amal militia, which has been in the forefront of the armed resistance to the Israeli occupation. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title:
THE LEARNING DISABLED;
MANY COLLEGES NOW OFFER L.D. PROGRAMS
description: -disabled students, will open in Putney, Vt., next September on the site of defunct Windham College. The school, according to its president, James Olivier, will take 150 students ''with average to above-average I.Q.'s, who don't have a primary emotional problem and who are diagnosed as being dyslexic or as having a specific learning disability.''

title: RATCHFORD ASSESES LOSS TO ROWLAND
description: ON Wednesday morning United States Representative William R. Ratchford perused the morning papers and studied the figures that showed he was the only incumbent Congressman in Connecticut who lost a re-election bid in voting the day before.

title: A HOT AUCTION FOR PRENTICE-HALL
description: After four months of fruitless overtures, Gulf and Western Industries has decided to let its money do the talking in a bid to take over Prentice- Hall Inc., the nation's largest producer of college textbooks. Gulf and Western says it wants to merge Prentice-Hall with Simon and Schuster into ''a major force in virtually every segment of the book publishing business.''

title: MATCHUPS DECIDED
description: Eighteen head coaches met at a Wantagh cafe last evening and decided, mathematically, which teams in each conference would advance to the Nassau County playoffs that begin next Saturday.

title: MUSIC: ORCHESTRA FROM LILLE, FRANCE
description: The Orchestre National de Lille, which appeared at Carnegie Hall Friday night as part of its current North American tour, is an example of how France has systematically upgraded the quality of large-scale musical performance in its provinces over the last decade.

title: Food; Convenient Stews Provide a Hearty Main Course
description: WITH the weather beginning to feel seasonal the idea of setting a pot of stew on the stove to simmer away for a couple of hours no longer seems inappropiate. And sitting down to a dinner anchored securely by a hearty main course whets our appetites again.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: REPORTS by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the State Police show that crime declined in 20 of New Jersey's 21 counties in the first six months of this year. Only in Cumberland County was there an increase - 4 percent - in both violent and nonviolent crimes, according to both agencies.

title: DELAY ON CITY LABOR CONTRACTS WORKS TO KOCH'S ADVANTAGE
description: When the contracts of most New York City workers expired on June 30 without new ones in place, few eyebrows were raised. After all, brinkmanship had become such a ritual in city labor talks that contract expiration dates were generally seen as the starting point for negotiations instead of the deadline.

title: Shael Shapiro Marries Roslyn Ann Bernstein
description: Roslyn Ann Bernstein, the widow of Elliott Bernstein, and Shael Shapiro were married last night in a loft in SoHo in New York by Rabbi Jeffrey Troodler.

title: Lisa Whyte Has Nuptials
description: Lisa Whyte, a daughter of Mrs. Henry Whyte Jr. of Norfolk, Va., and the late Mr. Whyte, was married yesterday to Steven Edmund MacIntyre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. MacIntyre of Greenville, Del. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Popowich of Rydal, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Sue Popowich, to Robert Joshua Meislin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron G. Meislin of New York.

description: The State Division for Youth placed some children in homes with sexually abusive, suicidal or violent foster-care parents, state auditors have found.

Most conventions look for an additionally relevant area or seminar for those attending the convention and visiting New York.

title:
HIGHER EDUCATION;
GRASS-ROOTS COLLEGES: A FERTILE TIME
description: CARMEN LLADO recently persuaded the six families in her Brooklyn apartment building to sue their landlord jointly for more heat and hot water. ''I've always been bold,'' she said, but she didn't dare begin this legal battle before she studied tenant rights at the Neighborhood Women's College, a community-based college in the Greenpoint-Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Although she dropped out of high school as a teen-ager, Miss Llado, who is 30 years old, obtained a diploma last year by passing the state equivalency test; she is now halfway through an associate's degree program in liberal arts and labor studies at the college. After she graduates, she plans to begin work on a law degree.

title: Margaret Maass Plans to Wed in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Maass of Madison and Long Beach Island, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Margaret Lees Maass, to William Holt Jansen, a son of Elizabeth Holt Jansen of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late William Allan Jansen.

description: Closing a chapter on Vermont's ill- fated raid on a religious sect, the authorities have returned hundreds of personal belongings seized from members of the Northeast Kingdom Community Church in June.

MUSIC;
STATE OPERA TO OPEN WITH GALA CONCERT
description: NEWARK THE New Jersey State Opera will open its season tonight with a concert of ''Famous Mad Scenes From Grand Opera.''

title: Walter Arm, 75, Dies; Ex-Police Press Chief
description: Walter Arm, the deputy police commissioner in charge of community and press relations for the New York City Police Department from 1955 to 1965, died yesterday of heart failure at the Tarzana Medical Center in Tarzana, Calif. He was 75 years old and lived in North Hollywood.

title: LANDSLIDE ELECTION HEARTENS INVESTORS
description: Business responded enthusiastically to the landslide re-election of Ronald Reagan. Most executives had backed Mr. Reagan, giving him much of the credit for the economic recovery and noting his generally favorable policies. Now, business leaders said, the President should concentrate on cutting the huge Federal deficit before it becomes more onerous for business.

title: O'Rourke's Views: Other Perspectives
description: In response to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's reflections on Indian Point in the Oct. 14 Westchester section (''County Executive on Indian Point''), I would like to elaborate on some of the difficulties I have with his thoughts.

title: 'CHORUS LINE' VS. HOLLYWOOD-A SAGA
description: One day in May 1975, Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin - two movie producers best known for ''Cabaret'' - made an offer to Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival. They would pay $150,000 for the film rights to his new musical.

title: MEMORIES OF SPRINGTIME MURDERS CHILL SMALL ALASKAN TOWN
description: It was spring when a brooding, jobless loner from Illinois killed seven residents of this wilderness hamlet and dumped their bodies into the rain-swollen Tanana River.

title: Actor Gets a New Kidney
description: The actor Gary Coleman, star of NBC-TV's ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' underwent his second kidney transplant today and was ''doing well'' at the University of California-Los Angeles Medical Center, officials said. The 16-year-old actor had his first kidney transplant when he was 5, but that kidney failed about 18 months ago.

title: Leading Police Official Replaced in New Delhi
description: The police commissioner of this city was dismissed today, and his successor vowed to restore public confidence shaken by police failure to quell four days of rioting.

title: REMEMBERING VIETNAM VETERANS

title: A TOWN UNLIKE WAGNER
description: The town of Bayreuth, claimed for more than a century by Wagner and the Wagnerians, is about as un-Wagnerian as a town in Germany can be. It is content with traditional harmonies and abounds in them. It prizes balance, and its luxury is a kind of mock modesty achieved at huge expense. Bayreuth is - yes, why not say it? - sweet, right up to the foot of the Green Hill, where the Festpielhaus rises and Wagnerland begins.

PERSPECTIVES;
THE TEST OF GROWING STUDENT DIVERSITY

This concern for public education offers fresh hope that, in the days ahead, we will adopt a creative, coherent plan for the renewal of the nation's schools.

title: THE YOUNG READER'S CHRISTMAS
description: Molly Ivins is a columnist for The Dallas Times Herald.

title: CHOOSING A CHALLENGER: 2 EXAMPLES
description: ELECTION DAY is over, but it won't be long until the electoral cycle begins again with the candidate selection process. Long before the voters make a choice, political leaders must make a choice of a candidate to present to those same voters. In the case of incumbents, the selection is almost automatic, but picking challengers to run against incumbents is another matter.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Birth Control
description: For more than a decade, the Government has been striving to thin the populations of formerly domestic animals now roaming wild on Federal lands in the West. The animals, which are said to threaten the survival of indigenous wild creatures by their foraging, have included mustangs in the Grand Canyon, burros in Death Valley and goats and pigs on San Clemente Island, off California.

title: BOLIVIAN STAPLE: SPICY SALTENAS
description: PETER McFARREN is a journalist who lives in La Paz, Bolivia.

title: AFTER ELECTION, THE ECONOMY IS STILL AN ISSUE

title: Margaret D'Ambrosio Is Wed to Richard G. Doty
description: Margaret Rose D'Ambrosio, the associate librarian at the American Numismatic Society, and Richard George Doty, curator of modern coins and paper money at the society, were married yesterday. Jean Somerville Kotkin, executive director of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony at the Society for Ethical Culture.

title: FRANCE AND LIBYA SAY CHAD PULLOUT IS COMPLETE
description: France and Libya said today that they had completed an agreed withdrawal of their forces from Chad, and a French official said his Government was counting on the Chadians themselves to restore peace to the country.

title: THIRD-WORLD JOURNALISTS VIEW U.S. FIRSTHAND
description: To Shekhar Gupta, a young reporter from India who recently completed six weeks in the United States as part of an exchange program for journalists, it soon became apparent that he must not be introduced as a correspondent from the third world.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE MOST MEMORABLE WORDS ARE THE EASIEST TO READ
description: LANGUAGE in America has a bad case of mumps. It is swollen beyond understanding. And every new fad word or phrase balloons it more. Granted, language is a living, changing tool. But why do all the changes make it more inflated and befogged, instead of simpler and clearer?

title: Pat Nixon Leaves Hospital
description: Pat Nixon, the wife of former President Richard M. Nixon, has been released from New York Hospital, where she was being treated for a lung infection, Jed Golden, a hospital spokesman, said yesterday. Mrs. Nixon, 72 years old, spent five days in the hospital for treatment of a lung infection. Her husband ''visited her several times,'' Mr. Golden said.

description: David Binder, assistant news editor in the Washington bureau of The Times, served as a correspondent in the Balkans.

description: MOST of the brownstones where Hoboken's revival began have been claimed and the area around the city's PATH station has already been substantially rehabilitated. But that has not slowed the pace of change.

title: THE WORLD OF THE LONE-WOLF ENTREPRENEUR
description: Starting a business - it is never easy, always risky, and usually expensive. Partners and employees can share the risk and combat the loneliness and initial insecurity. But budding entrepreneurs rarely can afford a staff, and many start alone.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter John Dauk of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Gledhill Dauk, to Stephen H. Kiesling, a son of Roy A. Kiesling of San Francisco and Nancy Hunt Kiesling of Portola Valley, Calif. A summer wedding is planned.

THE SCHOOLS;
THE REFORM MOVEMENT STILL SURGING
description: THIS month, an ad hoc assortment of roughly 25 public educators and academic scholars calling themselves ''The Thanksgiving Day Group'' will release a reform manifesto, ''Developing Character, Transmitting Knowledge,'' calling for parental choice in selection of schools, the abolishment of undergraduate teacher programs and increasing emphasis on development of student character through the schools.

title: P.L.O. FACTION PICKS JORDAN FOR KEY PARLEY
description: Al Fatah, the largest faction within the the Palestine Liberation Organization, has decided to override objections from P.L.O. rivals and hold a much-delayed meeting of the Palestine National Council here later this month, a senior aide to Yasir Arafat said today.

description: New Jersey is preparing to check 600 drinking- water supplies for cancer-causing chemicals, according to a state environmental official.

description: As Ronald Reagan begins a second term with what appears to be a resounding endorsement of his economic policies, what dangers lie ahead? Four of the nation's prominent economists, each representing a different school of thought, were asked how they would counsel President Reagan as he prepares for the next four years. Martin S. Feldstein

title: Study of Working Mothers
description: Two psychology professors at Temple University are recruiting new mothers for a study on when women should return to work after giving birth and what effect such separations have on family relationships and child development. The professors, Lois Hoffman and Marsha Weinraub, are seeking women who resumed working within four months after giving birth; mothers who returned to work when their children were 8 to 14 months old, and women who never returned to a job or never held one. All the children in the study will be 1 to 2 years old.

description: Officers Win Praise In Third Precinct As a resident of the New Cassel section of Westbury, I am proud to have policemen like Lorenzo Rochester and Charles Campo patrolling our streets (''Assignment: Nassau's Busiest Precinct'').

title: CON EDISON SEEKING A 7.8% INCREASE IN GAS RATES
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has asked the state for permission to raise its gas rates for one million residential and commercial customers by 7.8 percent.

title: ALLEN GINSBERG: INTIMATIONS OF MORTALITY
description: HEY FATHER DEATH, I'M FLYING home,'' sounds the voice of the bald, gray-bearded poet singing to his dead sire. The song threads through the cobwebbed corridors of the abandoned Ellis Island immigration center, the haunting relic of a past age of hope that seems a perfect setting for the latest in Allen Ginsberg's endless experimenting with words and emotion and time.

title: UNCERTAINTY MARKS CONFERENCE ON HOW TO MEET STATE'S POWER NEEDS
description: How much electricity New York State will need and how best to supply it have become increasingly difficult to predict, according to experts at a two- day conference in Manhattan.

description: -EYED CAT

description: Soviet commentators have been trying to explain how Ronald Reagan, the man they have been blaming for most of the world's ills, could be so overwhelmingly re-elected by his own people.

title: Kim Susan Hirsh Betrothed
description: The engagement of Kim Susan Hirsh to Mark Widmann, a medical student at Yale University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hirsh of Springfield, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Warren Widmann of Morristown, N.J.

title: THE POWER OF THE FANATICS
description: Thomas Friedman gives a sensitive - and bone-chilling - account of ''The Power of the Fanatics,'' but he surely exaggerates in asserting that in the Middle East ''the extremists are winning'' and ''absolute crime pays absolutely.'' Ruthless violence has helped many Arab dictators consolidate their regimes, but the escalation of violence has not won any external contests.

title: Capitals Tied by Devils
description: The Devils trailed twice but came back tonight to tie the Washington Capitals, 2-2.

title: MAKING AN EARLY START IN THE WEST
description: ALEX WARD is the editor of The Living Section of The Times.

title: BURGER FAVORS EXPERT JURORS
description: Some civil cases have become so complex or protracted that they are more than a jury can handle, and there is no constitutional obstacle against settling them with an expert jury or a judicial panel, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today.

title:
GARDENING ;
PROTECTING AGAINST WINTER INJURY
description: LAST winter was tough one for plants. In the natural sequence of events, plants in our temperate climate begin to harden-off in anticipation of winter in response to two phenomena - decreasing day length and gradually falling temperatures. With most species, the maximum winter hardiness is not attained until midwinter, when the coldest temperatures are normally experienced.

title: GETTING A JUMP ON FORGERS
description: Office copying machines will soon be capable of reproduction in fine color, which is good news for the industry but bad news for Treasury agents concerned about counterfeit money. Their solution - likely to be announced next year - is a change in the dollar's design, which has been the same for 55 years.

title: CHINA OBSERVED IN TIANJIN
description: MICHAEL KAMMEN, professor of American history and culture at Cornell University, taught at Nankai University in Tianjin for 10 days during January.

title: A DISPUTE ERUPTS ON MEDICAL PRIZE
description: A controversy has erupted over an international prize for liver research because of a disclosure that the award was named for a Vienna physician who has been linked to experiments on prisoners in a Nazi concentration camp.

title: A SOVIET DESIGNER OF TANKS REVEALED AS A-BOMB PIONEER
description: The Soviet Union has lifted another corner of the veil of secrecy that has long shrouded the beginnings of its nuclear weapons program.

title: 7 Tamils Reported Slain By Sri Lanka Troops
description: Seven Tamils were killed and 50 were wounded Friday when Sri Lanka troops fired on passers-by in the northern city of Jaffna, the United News of India reported today.

title: LETTERS
description: TOPPING OUT

title: FLORIDA DEFEATS GEORGIA
description: Florida ended Georgia's five- season domination of the Southeastern Conference today with a 27-0 victory behind the passing of Kerwin Bell.

title: FUEL COOPERATIVES OFFER ALTERNATIVE
description: WHILE it is still uncertain whether retail prices for fuel oil this winter will rise to last season's $1.32 a gallon, 2,170 Westchester homeowners are attempting to avoid high heating bills by participating in purchasing consortiums or co-ops. There are four of these organizations operating in the county and a fifth is organizing.

title: Los Angeles Zoo Is Faulted
description: Management of the Los Angeles Zoo is ''inadequate'' and the city should consider turning it over to a private organization, according to a city audit. The audit found morale problems among employees, squabbling between zoo officials and a private support group, accounting problems and a lack of movement toward making the 18-year-old zoo a ''world class operation.''

title: DAVID STOREY: 'THE PLAYS SIMPLY POURED OUT'
description: We've heard of dramatists plunged into suicidal grief by the first night of a first play, and of others who have promptly jetted off to the South Seas in jubilation at the prospect of wealth and fame, but surely never of one who reacted quite like David Storey. After seeing his ''Restoration of Arnold Middleton'' staged in London in 1966, he went home and wrote six or seven plays in as many weeks.

title: AN ARTIST FINDS NEW FAVOR
description: The Russian-born artist John Graham (1881-1961) had so many strings to his bow that his gifts as a painter were somewhat underexercised. A brilliant if crochety theorist and critic, he wrote an insightful treatise, ''System and Dialectics of Art'' (1937), that prefigured Abstract Expressionism. A keen promoter of talent, he was the first to recognize Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning, and he influenced David Smith's decision to concentrate on sculpture. A connoisseur, collector and dealer, he helped to expand the interest in African and Oceanic art in this country. He was also a yoga practitioner, a linguist, an amateur anthropologist and a mystic. As a painter, he was far from prolific, but he understood thoroughly the language of Cubism, and he reaffirmed its validity for the younger generation of Gorky, de Kooning and Pollock at a time when American Regionalist painting had a powerful grip.

title: NEW S.I. BOROUGH PRESIDENT IS SWORN IN
description: Standing at the foot of the harbor that welcomed his grandparents 100 years ago, Ralph J. Lamberti was sworn in yesterday as the 12th Borough President of Staten Island.

title: DISPARITY IN SCHOOL SPENDING SAID TO AFFECT TEACHERS MOST
description: The growing disparity in spending among school districts in Connecticut has its greatest impact on teacher salaries, teacher experience and student-to- teacher ratios, according to two studies for the State Department of Education.

title: TEACHER-SHARING REMAINS UNTESTED
description: ON paper, the proposal that Wilton, Weston and Westport send students to one another's specialized high- school classes could hardly be simpler nor more responsive to the districts' common problems.

title: PROSPECTS
description: At first glance, the Government's consumer installment credit figures for September, due out this Thursday, will suggest that Americans are becoming increasingly hesitant about piling on debt. But that's not necessarily so, according to Joel Popkin, a Washington economic consultant. The September figure is expected to show a rise of only $2 billion or so, compared with $6 billion in August and $7.1 billion in July. ''But the decline occurred largely because of the sharp drop in auto sales that month,'' Mr. Popkin noted, ''and not because the consumer is overburdened with installment debt.'' Continuing labor problems again depressed domestic auto output in October, causing sales to fall to an annual rate of 6.9 million units, from 7.9 million in September. As a result, Mr. Popkin expects sluggish growth in installment debt to continue in October. But the trend should reverse in the final months of the year. ''The recent decline in interest rates should stimulate sales of autos and other durables normally bought on credit,'' he predicted.

title: WALL STREET'S OBSESSION WITH 'VALUE'
description: Investing strategies are often as trendy as Seventh Avenue fashions. In the late 1960's, money

title: Elizabeth Michael Sporkin and Richard Eisenberg To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Sporkin of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Michael Sporkin, to Richard Eisenberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Mervin Eisenberg of West Orange, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

title: POLY BEATS ST. PAUL'S, 42-14, IN 100TH ANNIVERSARY GAME
description: The excitement seemed to go beyond even a homecoming game: Homecomings had come and gone at Poly Prep, but never, it seemed, with this much ado.

title: Volunteer Adviser Named
description: President Reagan said Thursday that he was appointing Patricia Jacobson, a Republican state committeewoman from Texas, to be a member of the National Voluntary Service advisory council. She is a member of the Haltom-Richland Chamber of Commerce and resides in Houston.

Merkle, head of the Robert Bosch electrical products group, met in a suburb of D"usseldorf in October 1982 with leaders of the small but strategic Free Democratic party. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the party chairman, was there along with Otto Lambsdorff, Minister for Economic Affairs, and Richard Wurbs, the party treasurer.
