description: TTR

title: EXETER DEFEATS ANDOVER
description: For the first time anyone can remember, Phillips Exeter officials called off Saturday morning classes yesterday at the New Hampshire school. The reason for this unusual move was to give the student body the opportunity to have a pep rally before the football team left for its 104th game against Phillips Andover of Massachusetts.

title:
THE LEARNING DISABLED;
HOW L.D.'S ARE HANDLED IN NEW YORK'S SCHOOLS
description: CHILDREN diagnosed as learning disabled in the New York City school system fall under the jurisdiction of the division of special education, which is also concerned with the mentally retarded, and the physically and emotionally handicapped. Almost every school in the city has a variety of classes designed for L.D. youngsters.

title: LOUISIANA FAMILY FIGHTS THE COUNTRY IT ONCE RULED
description: The Perez family once ruled oil-rich Plaquemines Parish as though it was their private sheikdom.

title: HOSPICE BENEFIT OFF TO SLOW START
description: O NE YEAR after the Federal Government began paying for hospice care for terminally ill Medicare beneficiaries - what one hospice director described as the most comprehenive medical benefit ever provided by the Government - only about 1 percent of those eligible for the program in New Jersey have elected it.

title: BLOOMINGDALE'S 'NIGHTS' GO ON
description: SHORT HILLS WHEN the guests pulled up to Bloomingdale's here for a recent black-tie extravaganza, they were greeted by lion dancers cavorting in authentic costumes to the beat of an Oriental drummer.

title: ON THE WATERFRONT
description: An 82-year-old carousel that is a designated landmark on the National Register of Historic Places has been moved, in pieces, to a Brooklyn warehouse from its site in Youngstown, Ohio. Bought at auction for $385,000 by David Walentas and his wife, Jane, it will be reassembled on the Brooklyn waterfront only if Mr. Walentas can procede with his stalled proposal for a $159 million office, retail and entertainment project at Fulton Landing just north of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Czellecz Runs for 202 Yards
description: Darrin Czellecz, a senior halfback, ran for 202 yards on 30 carries and scored both touchdowns to give North Arlington (7-1) a 12-0 victory over Leonia yesterday in North Arlington.

title: HARPISCHORD: JOYCE LINDORFF
description: Given her skills as a player of the harpsichord and her musicality, it is a pity that Joyce Lindorff does not perform from memory. Perhaps she simply cannot do it.

title: CORNELL WINS, 19-7
description: Michael Brooks, a tailback used infrequently, rushed for 76 yards and his first touchdown yesterday, and Tony Baker ran for 73 yards as Cornell defeated Columbia, 19-7, in an Ivy League game at Wien Stadium.

title: WORLD'S FAIR CRIES 'HELP'
description: The 1984 World's Fair in New Orleans will close its doors on schedule today, but its books may be open for years. The fair, which drew high marks for quality but had trouble drawing crowds, last week filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: BEACON HILL: WHERE THE PAST IS PRESENT
description: PHYLLIS LEE LEVIN has completed a book on Abigail Adams.

title: 'STOP THE WORLD', A CIRCUS OF STEREOTYPES
description: '' STOP the World - I Want to Get Off,'' running at the Queens Theater in the Park through next Sunday, is essentially a one-man show surrounded by a circus tent full of pretentiousness. When it opened on Broadway in 1962, the musical, written by Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley, was also directed by Anthony Newley and starred Anthony Newley, which made it even more of a star vehicle than it already was.

title: COUNCIL REJECTS HOSPITAL'S BID
description: THE possibilty of a huge commercial and residential development that would double the size of White Plains's downtown was diminished or postponed last week, but not ruled out forever.

title: TERMS WORKE OUT FOR NUCLEAR DUMP
description: After 15 months of negotiations, the State of Washington this week put the finishing touches on a proposed agreement with the Federal Government that could bring 77,000 tons of the nation's most dangerous nuclear waste to the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in southern Washington.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE United States Navy is using accelerated procedures to prevent more PCB's from spilling into the Thames River near Groton. Bids for the work are to be opened this month.

title: Amherst Tops Williams
description: Jeff Templeton passed for 103 yards and ran for two touchdowns today as Amherst defeated Williams 23-6 to claim the Little Three championship.

title: 'ELLIS ISLAND' IS ENTERTAINING KITSCH
description: Imagine, if you will, a young Jew fleeing a pogrom in Russia after killing a murderous Cossack and, a couple of decades later, the same man, now a famous songwriter, attending a political gathering in New York to celebrate the successful election of his Italian immigrant friend, who has at last been married to the Irish colleen of his dreams. It will hardly come as a surprise if a heavyset woman in the crowd of well-wishers steps forward and, in a rich soprano, starts singing ''America, the Beautiful'' as the cameras begin heading for one final, spectacular shot of the Statue of Liberty. This, in brief, is the Pop Americana world of ''Ellis Island,'' the seven-hour CBS mini-series that gets underway tonight at 8 and continues on Tuesday and Wednesday at 9 each evening. It is ludicrously contrived and, if you are in the mood for choice kitsch, quite entertaining.

title: HAIL, SOCCER! GAME IS ALL TO ROME FANS
description: PAUL HOFMANN, the author of ''O Vatican! A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See'' (Congdon & Weed), is a former New York Times correspondent who lives in Rome.

title: ANACHRONISTIC DAVIES ON VIEW AT THE HUDSON RIVER MUSEUM
description: 1928), the subject of a new show at the Hudson River Museum, is customarily regarded as an eccentric - and not without reason. A painter of dreamy landscapes peopled by dancing nymphs and, in at least one instance, unicorns, he was a member of The Eight, most of whom were devoted to robust urban realism. His influences included Puvis de Chavannes and the dance, yet, as the prime organizer of the 1913 Armory Show, he unleashed Modernism on America.

title: STRIKING COAL MINERS IN BRITAIN EXPECT TO GET AID FROM LIBYA
description: The British coal miners union will receive aid from Libya for its striking members, a union fund-raiser says.

title: FAST SERVES ITS PURPOSE
description: Nearly two months ago, Mitch Snyder vowed to starve himself until the Reagan Administration agreed to commit funds to renovate an 800-bed shelter for the homeless in Washington, D.C. Last week, 51 days after he stopped eating, the Administration broke down and Mr. Snyder broke his fast. Mr. Snyder, who heads the Community for Creative Nonviolence, lost 62 pounds during his ordeal.

title:
THE LEARNING DISABLED;
SPOTTING PROBLEM AND SETTING A COURSE
description: ALTHOUGH a child's learning problems are usually identified first in school, parents frequently suspect very early that ''something isn't quite right,'' perhaps even before their children are old enough to go to school. They may notice that Jimmy at 6 months rarely sleeps through the night and has a hard time settling into a routine. At 4, he still can't count to three or remember color names. Betsy's second-grade teacher complains to her parents that she can't sit still in class and her writing is messy; while Joey, the class clown in sixth grade, never finishes an assignment and says he hates school.

title: PLAYERS MAY ASK FOR AN END TO FREE-AGENT DRAFT
description: Thirty-seven players of the 56 who were in Thursday's free-agent draft were selected by fewer than 4 teams, which means they can negotiate with all 28 teams. Some people, primarily on the players' side but also some among the owners, believe it is time to eliminate the draft and allow all teams to negotiate with all free agents. In the first five years of the draft, there were limits on the number of clubs that could select negotiating rights to a player, but the only way clubs are limited now is that they must select a player at the draft if they want to be sure to have the right to negotiate with him.

title: Mencken Tribute
description: A long argument in Baltimore over what to do with the three-story house that H. L. Mencken lived in for 68 years was resolved in June when the building opened as a city museum.

title: RANGEL SEES BRIGHT SPOTS IN ELECTION RESULTS
description: For Representative Charles B. Rangel, who was a co-chairman of Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign and is the most influential black politician from New York in the capital, reading the election results was not entirely bleak.

title: YONKERS RACEWAY HAS NEW CHIEF, 27
description: YONKERS JUST 15 years ago Bob Galterio saw his first harness horse race - at the Yonkers Raceway. His father, a Pelham podiatrist, had taken him to the track on one of the Raceway's fan-appreciation nights. Admission was free.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS' TRAUMA
description: Every Veteran's Day, we are exhorted to put Vietnam behind us. The individual veteran cannot do that until he has come to terms with the experience. Nor will we as a country be able to make Vietnam part of our past until we have faced what it did to the soldiers who fought there. When some of the symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorders - nightmares, insomnia, emotional withdrawal and outbursts of anger - were first recognized among veterans of World War I, the condition was assumed to be relatively rare. Only since World War II have we realized that killing and sustained exposure to death have lasting consequences for a high percentage of soldiers.

title: Some Poles and Church Disagree on Dissent
description: Supporters of Solidarity, Poland's banned labor union, said today that they had disagreed with Roman Catholic Church officials who asked them to end opposition activities at the church of a slain pro-Solidarity priest.

title: JARULSESKI TAKES OVER SECURITY
description: The murder of a Polish priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszco, seemed to boomerang last week for Communist hard-liners. Embarrassed and possibly threatened by an uncontrolled security force, Poland's leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, took over direct responsibility for the Interior Ministry and its police.

title: NEW IDEAS
description: After so many balloons, so many primaries and so much political opinion, it's easy to forget that the first chance most Americans had to send 'em a message this year didn't come until last Tuesday. They sent two.

title: A BOY SAVED BY THE BOMB
description: John Calvin Batchelor's new novel, ''American Falls,'' will be published next year. EMPIRE OF THE SUN

title: EXPLORING THE HIGHLANDS OF ZIMBABWE
description: By 6 P.M., the moon has risen, studded against an indigo sky that slides toward the western horizon and fuses there with the last flame of an African sunset. The day has been warm, but now there is a chill on the pine-blanketed uplands of eastern Zimbabwe, an intimation of cold nights and log fires and favorite cashmeres.

title: FLUTIE: MADNESS IN CONTROL
description: The Boston College Eagles had just scored a touchdown to come within 6 points of Penn State, and on the visiting team's sideline at Beaver Stadium, Doug Flutie had another idea. ''He comes running up to me,'' said Jack Bicknell, the coach who has been smart enough to listen for the last four seasons. ''He says, 'We've got to go for 2.' ''

title: THE EMPTY STAGE
description: WASHINGTON There is now a pause for rejoicing

title: FPM
description: Barbara Gudis, a registered nurse at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Dr. Dorian Tergis, a family physician in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Theodore Baglaneas performed the ceremony.

title: DIRECTORS EVOKE MANY AMERICAS
description: America, meaning mostly the United States, is not an easy concept to comprehend. It may be appropriate that it was discovered by a Genoese sailor, in the service of the Spanish crown, looking for some place else and that, for the next half- century, it was treated as a geographical impediment to be gotten through or around in order to reach some far-more-profitable other side.

title: REMEMBERING JOHN GARDNER: 'HIS MODERATION WAS OUR EXCESS'
description: Nicholas Delbanco directs the Bennington Writing Workshops. His study of the Beaux Arts Trio will appear this winter. HE illustration on the cover of John Gardner's collection of short stories, ''The Art of Living,'' shows a motorcyclist racing at the reader, straight ahead. His jacket is black leather, as was John's, and his expression is grim. It is as though he drives ''In the Suicide Mountains'' - the title of a book he wrote for children - prepared to take that leap described on the final page of ''Grendel''; there are fierce night rides throughout his work, and creatures everywhere at risk.

title: POLITICAL FOCUS SHIFTS TO KEAN AND 1985 RACE
description: TRENTON WHEN Governor Kean told Republican campaign workers Tuesday night that they had helped to build a G.O.P. majority in the country that would last for a long time to come, some of them said it was time to start Mr. Kean's re-election campaign.

title: VIRGINIA WOOLF IN NEW YORK
description: Anatole Broyard is an editor of The Book Review.

title: DRAWINGS THAT REFLECT A GREAT CONNOISSEUR
description: WASHINGTON

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary yesterday of William Kapelman, a former New York Assemblyman and State Supreme Court justice, misstated where he received his law degree. He graduated from New York Law School.

title: Stuyvesant to Valiant Lark
description: With a bold move on the turn, Valiant Lark rushed from last to first in a field of eight to score a three-length victory in the Stuyvesant Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: 12 Die in Egyptian Collapse
description: Twelve people died when an old five-story apartment house in Tanta, a Nile Delta city 52 miles north of Cairo, collapsed Friday afternoon while most of the residents were watching a soccer match on television, municipal officials in Tanta said today. The officials said by telephone that 17 people were treated at a hospital for injuries.

title: A SOVIET EXILE REFLECTS ON HIS LOT
description: PARIS

title: THEATER MUSEUM PLANNED
description: NEW HAVEN, for many years a tryout town for Broadway plays, is attempting to capitalize on its theater history with a Museum of American Theater, which is being established by a nonprofit group.

title:
THE EDUCATION CONSUMER;
TAX STRATEGIES TO EASE TUITION LOAD
description: SAVING enough money to pay for a child's higher education is a major problem for millions of Americans. Even with the availability of scholarships, low-interest government loans and other financial aid, most families will still have to come up with thousands of dollars more to meet the steadily rising costs of tuition, room and board every year to pay the bills. Recently, however, there has been a growing awareness among parents that they can substantially reduce educational outlays through early planning and making use of Federal tax laws.

title: ETHNIC ORAL HISTORY BECOMING BOOKLETS
description: TRENTON TAPES of the life histories of members of ethnic groups who settled in New Jersey are being transformed into booklets to be distributed to every school district in the state.

title: VIOLENCE IN INDIA: SEVERAL INTERTWINED ROOTS
description: Students of Indian culture see complex motivations behind the waves of violence that periodically rock this society.

CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
A CLASSIC, NEW AND COMPLETE

description: COME RUN WITH ME, SAYS BOSTON'S MAYOR

title: VARIED APPROACHES LEND SPICE TO EARLY MUSIC
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: THE WAR-SCARRED ASSEMBLE AT VIETNAM MEMORIAL
description: Thousands of Americans wounded, in one way or another, by the war in Vietnam came here today to share in what sponsors planned as a collective healing.

title: L.I. STUDENTS TRAIN TO BECOME PILOTS
description: MICHAEL SARISKY, a 17-year-old high school senior, plans to become a pilot. He's even decided that rather than working for a large commercial airline, he'd like to work on his own as a private pilot. His classmate, 16-year-old Carsten Toepper, on the other hand, hopes to return to his native Germany to train as a pilot for Lufthansa Airlines.

title: P.B.A., COMMUTER AIRLINE IN EAST, GROUNDED BY AGENCY OVER SAFETY
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered the emergency grounding of Provincetown-Boston Airline, which carries more passengers than any other commuter airline in the nation.

title: JERSEY ACTION ASKED ON SPEEDING
description: A New Jersey insurance organization has asked state officials to make a greater effort to enforce the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THOSE BACKYARD LEAVES ARE HARDEST TO APPRECIATE
description: MY husband, who fishes a great deal in upstate New York, had been encouraging me to come with him. ''You should see the leaves,'' he said, ''they're truly magnificent.''

title: L.I. SALUTES BYRANT, A 'RENAISSANCE MAN'
description: Softly breathes the west-wind beside the ruddy forest, Taking leaf by leaf from the

title: LEARNING DISABLED: A NEW AWARENESS
description: AT first glance Chris King is the model American teen-ager. The 18-year old student is president of the senior class at Staples High School in Westport, Conn., and this weekend he is playing the lead role in the drama club's production of ''Mr. Roberts.'' Next fall he hopes to move on to Boston University and, eventually, to graduate school.

title:
THE LEARNING DISABLED;
FIRST SCHOOL FOR DYSLEXIA BEGAN IN 20'S
description: SOUTH WALES, N.Y.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL EXPRESS CARRIES FEW PASSENGERS
description: WASHINGTON BEYOND President Reagan's landslide last week, Republicans had little to crow about on the national level. They lost two of the party's 55 Senate seats and gained at most 18 seats in the House of Representatives, although the Democrats said their losses in the House would be held to 12 after recounts are decided. Whichever the case, the Republicans are far short of their goal of reclaiming the 26 House seats they lost in 1982. And with 13 governorships at stake, they increased the number of Republicans by one, to 16.

title: SCHOLARSHIPS TO HONOR MUSICIANS
description: THE Simone Belsky Memorial Concert, Nov. 25 at 2:30 P.M. in St. Michael's Episcopal Church of Litchfield, is destined to be charged with emotion.

title: SEX EDUCATION IS NOT LIKE SNAKE OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Churchman Wed to a Lawyer
description: Diana Armit Churchman, an assistant to the director of development of Bryn Mawr College, and Samuel Mason, a lawyer in Philadelphia, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church there. Bishop John S. Spong of the Diocese of Newark performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Lee Richards.

title: The Power of the Fanatics
description: I read Thomas L. Friedman's article, ''The Power of the Fanatics'' (Oct. 7), with the same kind of perverse satisfaction one gets from prodding a painful spot on one's body. I found nothing to fault in the piece, and write merely to suggest that it might have taken the discussion one step further.

title: Soviet Volleyball Team Beats U.S. in Japan Cup
description: The Soviet Union's men's volleyball team, which did not compete at the Summer Olympics, rallied today to defeat the United States gold medal team at the Japan Cup tournament.

title: Skin and Emotions
description: Deborah Blumenthal's article, ''Skin and Emotions'' (Sept. 30), places undue emphasis on this interrelationship and plays right into the hands of many patients who are already convinced that every blemish or rash is ''due to nerves.'' Just because the skin is a visible organ doesn't mean that it is more susceptible to the vagaries of our mental set than our heart or liver.

title: BEHAN: 'NOW IT IS UP TO US'
description: THE dedication today in Washington of a statue of three servicemen, forming the last part of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, is viewed by many as a long-delayed tribute to those who fought in what has been termed an embarrassing war to this nation.

title: REST IN PEACE, SALIERI, NO ONE KILLED MOZART
description: Be honest, now. No matter what the evidence, wouldn't you rather go on believing that somebody murdered Mozart, if only by psychological means as in ''Amadeus,'' than that he died of natural causes? There must be a human instinct that favors complication over simplicity. It makes us take pleasure in conspiracy theories, no matter what the evidence says. It results in mystery stories taking up nearly as much space in book stores as books about cats.

title: THE IDEAL NEIGHBOR
description: I KNOW A LADY

title: Beth Krosskove Is Wed to Robert Nathan Grimes
description: The marriage of Beth Krosskove, a speech pathologist, to Robert Nathan Grimes, a systems analyst at the headquarters of the Marriott Corporation in Bethesda, Md., took place yesterday at Beth Sholom Congregation in Elkins Park, Pa. Rabbi Aaron Landes performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor David F. Tilman.

title: When India Was a Colony
description: R. K. Narayan gently scolds us for our fascination with the British Raj and then charmingly proceeds to demonstrate what made the Raj so fascinating (''When India Was a Colony,'' Sept. 16).

title: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS SET UP UMBRELLA GROUP
description: Some nonprofit organizations in New York City own imposing buildings and attract support from the affluent. Others are struggling neighborhood groups with skimpy budgets searching for cheap quarters.

title:
GARDENING ;
PROTECTING AGAINST WINTER INJURY
description: LAST winter was tough one for plants. In the natural sequence of events, plants in our temperate climate begin to harden-off in anticipation of winter in response to two phenomena - decreasing day length and gradually falling temperatures. With most species, the maximum winter hardiness is not attained until midwinter, when the coldest temperatures are normally experienced.

title: NEW LIFE FOR HOTEL
description: Since Atlantic City's resort appeal was bolstered by the legalization of gambling in 1976, large-scale hotel and condominium projects have been developed there, many of them with casinos. But four miles from the heart of the city, in Brigantine, a small 53-year-old beachfront hotel is undergoing a renovation and will reopen early next year as a timeshare condominium - without a casino on the premises.

title: 40 SAID TO LEAVE EMBASSY IN PRAGUE
description: About 40 of the East Germans who had taken refuge in the West German Embassy in Prague have given up their protest and returned home, officials familiar with the situation said today.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Changing the Approach To Local News The article about Karl Anton's purchase of the Community Newspapers chain and his philosophical differences with his former editors (''Weeklies Change Approach to News,'' Oct. 7) was comprehensive. However, it failed to represent one major component of the weeklies' new approach to the news: the readership.

title: Tax Executive Wed To Susan E. Condon
description: Susan E. Condon, a real-estate broker with Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc., was married in Sudbury, Mass., yesterday to Dennis McDade, the partner in charge of the tax department in Price Waterhouse's New York office. The Rev. Robert Harrah, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the Martha Mary Chapel at the Longfellow Wayside Inn.

title: Greenwich Stays Alive
description: Jeff Way, a senior quarterback, threw for two touchdowns and ran for a third to lead Greenwich (6-2) to a 28-20 victory yesterday over Stamford Catholic (5-3).

title: NANCY REAGAN'S ROLE GROWS
description: Shortly before the election, one of President Reagan's closest advisers grew nervous about California. The adviser pressed top campaign operatives for the latest polling results and repeatedly asked if everything was being done in Mr. Reagan's home state.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO BE STUDYING WAYS TO INCREASE PRESSURE ON NICARAGUA
description: The Reagan Administration, concerned about what it says is an increased flow of Soviet bloc weapons to Nicaragua, is considering placing greater diplomatic and military pressure on the Nicaraguan Government, senior Administration officials said today.

title: RUTGERS STUNS WEST VIRGINIA
description: The scouts from the bowl games were on hand at Giants Stadium today to see just how good West Virginia was. Instead, in an upset that few among even the most loyal Rutgers fans could have imagined, the Scarlet Knights won, 23-19.

title: HOW EMOTION IS BEING DEALT WITH IN 80'S DANCES
description: A certain prominent choreographer who made his name in the 1940's recently noted - privately, gleefully and sardonically - that the newest generation of modern-dance choreographers was rediscovering words such as ''emotion'' and ''narrative.'' He was aware, he said, that these choreographers were trying to deal with such elements in a dissociated way that would keep them from being accused of being old-fashioned. But implied in his point was the idea that the modernist revolution (manifest in modern-dance in the 1930's and 1940's) had already introduced nonlinear presentation of emotion and storytelling. The young generation was reinventing the wheel.

title: A ROMANTIC MODERNIST WINS A PLUM FROM THE GETTY
description: It is rare - perhaps unprecedented - that the architectural world awaits the awarding of a commission to design a building with the suspense associated with a

title: BEARING A CHILD IN MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: Perri Klass is a third-year student at the Harvard Medical School. Her fiction appeared in ''Prize Stories 1984: The O. Henry Awards.'' Her novel, ''Recombinations,'' will appear next year. ONE DAY LAST year, I sat with my classmates in our reproductive medicine course in Amphitheater E at the Harvard Medical School, listening to a lecture on the disorders of pregnancy. The professor discussed ectopic pregnancy, toxemia, spontaneous abortion and major birth defects. I was eight months pregnant. I sat there, rubbing my belly, telling my baby: ''Don't worry, you're O.K., you're healthy.'' I sat there wishing that this course would tell us more about normal pregnancy, that after memorizing all the possible disasters, we would be allowed to conclude that pregnancy itself is not a state of disease. But I think most of us, including me, came away from the course with a sense that pregnancy is a deeply dangerous medical condition, that one walks a fine line, avoiding one serious problem after another, to reach the statistically unlikely outcome of a healthy baby and a healthy mother.

title: Diane R. Spiegel Wed in Stamford
description: Temple Beth El in Stamford, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Diane Rose Spiegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James I. Spiegel of Stamford, to Robert Charles Sorcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Sorcher of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi Alex Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: BYARS CONFIDENTLY RUSHES INTO HEISMAN PICTURE

description: The Princeton-Yale game turned over twice today in the last five minutes of play, the last time in favor of the Elis. Mike Curtin's 14-yard pass to Kevin Moriarty for a touchdown with five seconds remaining gave Yale the victory, 27-24.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. H. Frederick Krimendahl 2d of New York and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Knowles Krimendahl to Christopher Robin Wolf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Arthur Wolf of Memphis and McCoy, Colo. description: Hundreds of police officers mingled with crowds today during the Lord Mayor's Procession, one of London's biggest annual spectacles, and security forces throughout Britain were on high alert for a possible attack by the Irish Republican Army.

description: Oak Park, a middle-class suburb of Chicago, has approved a plan to pay landlords to integrate their apartment buildings.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;
TEEN-AGERS IN PARADISE
description: THERE were maybe two people lying on the beach. My husband was standing close to the shoreline down by the jetty, trying his luck with a new silver lure.

title: B.Y.U. EXTENDS STREAK TO 21
description: Robbie Bosco threw for 326 yards and two touchdowns today as Brigham Young overpowered San Diego State, 34-3, to extend its winning streak to 21 games, the longest among major college teams.

description: In a day of few surprises in Suffolk County football yesterday, Bellport pulled off a big one, toppling previously undefeated Central Islip, 32-29, to advance to the Division II semifinals next Saturday.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Not so long ago, nobody much bought architectural drawings. Living architects would throw them away, and the drawings of the great dead found few takers.

title: Kelley A. Brown Wed in California
description: Kelley Anne Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beaumont James Brown of Laguna Niguel, Calif., and Stanton See Perry, a son of Mrs. Alfred William Lasher Jr. of Houston and Palm Beach, Fla., and John Holliday Perry Jr. of Palm Beach, were married yesterday. The Rev. Harold Fumo performed the ceremony at St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Laguna Beach.

title: KENYA'S WINDY RETREAT BY THE SEA
description: PYKE JOHNSON Jr., who lives in Old Greenwich, Conn., is the retired managing editor of Doubleday.

title: SAND MINES FACE MORE OPPOSITION
description: SAND mine operators, who once enjoyed an unfettered existence on Long Island, are facing stiff opposition from local governments and environmental groups these days because of the threat their businesses pose to the region's ground water.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article today in New Jersey Weekly gives an incorrect date for the opening concert of the New Jersey State Opera. The performance will take place next Sunday.

title:
CRAFTS;
RENAISSANCE OF GOLD ILLUMINATION
description: IN A move designed to seek more

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LISTENING TO AMERICA: An Illustrated History of Words and Phrases From Our Lively and Splendid Past, by Stuart Berg Flexner. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) This is a large-format book with hundreds of photographs, drawings and old advertisements. Our reviewer, William Cole, said last year that Stuart Berg Flexner ''shows us how our society has changed old words and wrought new ones.'' He is ''not a grammarian but a derivation detective.'' And ''Listening to America'' is ''a big browse of a book and, incidentally, beautifully indexed; slip it into the reference shelf after savoring.'' WALTZ IN MARATHON, by Charles Dickinson. (NAL, $6.95.) This 1983 story by a Chicago newspaperman is about a 62-year-old loan shark, Harry Waltz, a rich wid ower with children, and the surprise he and his lover, a 42- year-old attorney, feel when she becomes pregnant. Julian Moynahan wrote in The Book Review that ''Waltz in Marathon'' is ''an arresting first novel.'' The strength of Charles Dickinson's narrative ''lies in its authenticity. Eastern Michigan's fierce winters of fog and ice, the miseries and satisfactions in the daily affairs of ordinary people, the distinctive and essentially egalitarian social patterns of a long-established and important American region are rendered realistically and vividly but not without humor and surprise.''

title: ANOTHER SHUFFLE IN SPACE,AND A SENATOR ON DECK
description: Two astronauts have touched down in the Senate. It looks as if Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, will be the first Senator to take off into space. Mr. Garn said last week that he had accepted an invitation from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to fly on the space shuttle ''at a mutally agreeable date.'' ''I'm still pinching myself,'' said Mr. Garn, who has been jogging 20 to 25 miles a week to keep ''in physical shape so there would be no question.'' As a Navy pilot and later an Air National Guard officer, the 52- year-old Senator has logged more than 10,000 hours aloft - more than all but one astronaut. Perhaps more to the point, Mr. Garn is head of the subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee that oversees NASA, and the agency will be asking Congress next year for more seed money for its $8 billion space station program and for added funds to improve the shuttle's reliability.

title: SEPARATE AMPLIFIERS JUSTIFY HIGH EXPECTATIONS
description: Many of the more demanding listeners nowadays feel that the challenges of digital sound are better met by a separate amplifier rather than a one-piece receiver. The underlying reasoning is that fewer design compromises are made in a separate amplifier than in an amplifier/tuner combination.

title: SEWER BLASTS SHAKE YONKERS
description: A methane gas explosion ripped through sewer lines for several blocks in downtown Yonkers early yesterday morning, tearing up paving, shattering windows in 12 buildings and blowing off scores of manhole covers.

title: TRADES RUMORED FOR ISLANDERS
description: Tomas Jonsson, the young and talented defenseman, was one of five players the Islanders recently placed on waivers, according to two rival National Hockey League general managers who did not want to be identified.

title: PARENT-RUN SCHOOL: SUCCESSFUL TACTIC
description: HOBOKEN WHEN parents hung a bright blue and white sign reading ''Stevens Cooperative School'' at 220 Willow Avenue here earlier this month, they were celebrating not only the purchase of their first building but also their triumph over - and then an

title: STOCKHOLM
description: To the Editor:

title: WeddingPlanned By Miss Petersen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Engelhart Petersen Jr. of New York, Shelter Island, L.I., and Ocean Ridge, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christina Marie Petersen to Peter MacNair Rayton, a son of Mrs. Albert Ford of Hamilton, N.Y., and the late Willis M. Rayton. A summer wedding is planned.

title: CLAMMER IS ALSO A COLLECTOR
description: BRICK TOWN

title: NEW PRODUCTS MAKE A DEBUT AT PHOTOKINA
description: John Durniak is a freelance writer and photography critic. This year's Photokina, which was recently held in Cologne, Germany, introduced scores of new photographic products. Often referred to as ''the world's fair of photography,'' there were 35 photographic exhibitions - more than this city has ever had. It promised the possibility of electronic still picture-taking for the near future.

title: WILBUR L. WOODS TOUTS ADVANTAGES OF BOUROGH SITES
description: Wilbur L. Woods, the director of the Brooklyn Office of the Department of City Planning, has worked in Brooklyn since 1977. In an interview he discussed the city's efforts to encourage development of city-owned sites in Brooklyn.

title: G.O.P. GAINS SET STAGE FOR '86 RACE
description: HARTFORD THE sweeping gains scored by Republicans in the election last Tuesday were the opening rounds in a long bout for control of the Governor's office in 1986, according to many politicians.

title: CHRYSLER'S HARD CHARGER
description: Robert Townsend is the author of ''Further Up the Organization.'' IACOCCA

title: Youth Is Said to Admit He Set Fire Where 3 Died
description: A 15-year- old boy charged with setting an apartment house fire that killed three people last month told the police he did it because he had been chased from the site for break dancing, the authorities say.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
CUTTING FINE FIGURES
description: KATONAH YESTERDAY they were in Buffalo, skating under a spotlight before judges and parents and onlookers who watched their every move.

title: Stites Paces Glen Ridge (7-1)
description: Craig Stites, a sophomore quarterback, completed 13 of 19 passes for 168 yards and two touchdowns and guided Glen Ridge past Bayley-Ellard yesterday in Glen Ridge.

title: NEW RULES FOR CONSERVATORS
description: The spotlight on the finances of John A. Zaccaro did more than cause political discomfort for his wife, the Vice Presidential candidate Geraldine A. Ferraro. It also revealed some gray areas of New York law.

title: Fire Destroys a Church In Bedford-Stuyvesant
description: A three-alarm fire destroyed a six- story brick church and spread to two other buildings last night in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the Fire Department said. No injuries were reported.

title: READING REQUIRES MORE THAN WORDS
description: NOT ALL my ideas about information gaps in the young come from reading education articles. Some come from my son John, who teaches Latin in high school and eighth grade, and has fresh incidents to report every time he visits home. In one of his recent classes, for example, he mentioned in passing that Latin isn't spoken anymore. But one disbelieving student challenged this bit of news. ''What about Latin America?'' she asked.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WHILE most elected officials spent the day after Election Day recuperating, Representative Richard T. Ottinger began a still-unofficial retirement by conducting a seminar for students at the Pace University Law School on how to get bills passed. Happily anticipating the switch from ''writing a lot of laws to teaching them,'' Representative Ottinger said last week that he was looking forward to his new job as Pace University Distinguished Professor of Public Policy and the Law, a position that is to begin Jan. 1.

title: POLAND WORLD OPEN VICTORS
description: The United States was the winner of one title and Poland had clinched the other as play continued this afternoon on the last day of the world contract bridge team championships.

title: Q & A
description: My building is going to be converted to cooperative ownership. I am physically incapacitated due to poor vision and phlebitis and I know nothing about this subject. Can you tell me how to find a lawyer and other information? . . . R. E. S., Brooklyn

title: U.S. SAYS STUDY FOUND MANUEL BROKE NO LAW
description: The White House announced today that two investigations ordered by President Reagan had found that there had been ''no violation'' of the law in the preparation of a Central Intelligence Agency manual for Nicaraguan guerrillas.

title: Heart-Liver Transplant Performed on 2-Year-Old
description: A 2-year-old girl who became the second person to undergo a simultaneous heart-liver transplant remained in critical condition today, hospital officials said.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: When Pablo Moses came to New York last December, he gave one of the finest reggae concerts of the year. Mr. Moses writes high, plaintive melodies and stark lyrics about poverty and apocalypse, and sings them in a gentle but unbowed voice. What made the concert so striking, however, was the way he worked with his Revolutionary Dream Band.

title: FOR L.I.'S VETERANS, MEMORIES ARE MIXED
description: FOR over a century, veterans of foreign wars have been returning to Long Island. Veterans of World War II and the Korean conflict, sensing unparalleled opportunities, took advantage of low-cost mortgages and the proximity to New York City to spur the Island's growth.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: CAN WAR BE DULL? IT IS AT McCARTER
description: PRINCETON ASIGN in the lobby of the McCarter Theater, where the Soviet play, ''The Dawns Are Quiet Here,'' is having its American premiere through next Sunday, informs us that ''this production uses guns and realistic special effects.''

title: Laurie Gaberman Affianced
description: The engagement of Laurie Anne Gaberman to Dr. Lawrence Jay Lefcort has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gaberman of Fairfield, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Ilene Silverman of Woodmere, L.I., and Stanley Lefcort of New York.

title: LANDSLIDE BY REAGAN STILL LEAVES L.I. DIVIDED IN THE HOUSE
description: NASSAU and Suffolk Counties rolled up by far the largest pluralities for President Reagan of any counties in the state in last week's election, but the Island's delegation to the House remained split between the parties - testimony, politicians agreed, to the power of incumbency and a selective electorate.

title: CONCERT: BOEHM QUINTETTE
description: The world premiere of Francis Thorne's Divertimento No. 3 provided the principal interest at the Boehm Quintette's Thursday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. It is a jolly work, 15 minutes of witty American Neo-Classicism, complete with fluttering trills, several fughettas and a genuinely virtuosic finale.

title: Hunt Hopes to Keep Giant Starting Role
description: The player who held the job last year was traded. The two players who held it earlier this year were injured. So when the Giants play the Tampa Bay Buccaneers at 4 P.M. Sunday in Tampa, Fla., Byron Hunt will start again at left (strongside) outside linebacker.

title: TIMES SQUARE PLAN APPROVED
description: Mayor Koch has described it as the greatest project since the Pyramids. Garment district manufacturers fear that it will drive them out of business.

title: Coaches Must Monitor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SIMON & SCHUSTER'S EMPIRE BUILDER
description: Forty years ago today, the general manager of the Houghton Mifflin Company, the venerable Boston publishing house, registered his disgust that a story about book publishing had appeared in the business and financial section of Time magazine. ''They do not realize, I assume,'' Lovell Thompson wrote in Publishers Weekly, ''that there is nothing either businesslike or financial about publishing.''

title:
PERSPECTIVES;
CUT DOWN THAT INFERNAL P.A. PRATTLE
description: The teacher is reading Keats:

title: Talks Are Held in Bid To Avoid a Milk Strike
description: Negotiators yesterday sought to avert a strike that could halt deliveries of milk to much of the New York metropolitan area beginning this afternoon.

title: Winslow's Warning
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COUNCIL FOR ARTS GETTING NEW HOME
description: THE Darien Arts Council will have something to cheer about next weekend. Its 10th anniversary celebration will coincide with the opening of its new home in the new Town Hall on Renshaw Road. The council has 200 members and is dedicated to fostering participation in the arts in the Darien area.

title: CONSIDERING ERRORS, FREAKS AND ODDITIES
description: It is the hope of virtually all stamp

title: AFTER YEARS OF GROWTH, WHITE PLAINS DRAWS THE LINE
description: Twenty years ago, racks of secondhand clothes cluttered the sidewalks of Main Street, and Army surplus stores and shoe repair shops struggled to survive next to empty storefronts.

title: RACING'S GREATEST DAY
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

title: POISED AT THE GATEWAY TO THE ALPS
description: JEREMY BERNSTEIN's latest book is ''Three Degrees Above Zero: Bell Labs in the Information Age'' (Charles Scribner's Sons).

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Athol Fugard's ''Master Harold . . . and the Boys''' is the most personal play by this major contemporary playwright. Drawn from a traumatic episode in Mr. Fugard's childhood as a white South African, the three-character drama describes the heart- searing rite of passage of an adolescent forced to face truths about a world - domestic and political - where people unavoidably collide.

title: A TRIBUTE TO REAGAN, A MESSAGE TO DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON WHATEVER history's judgment on President Reagan, no one can accuse him of having entered the White House through the back door. On Tuesday, he won a second electoral landslide, and this time piled up a mighty popular vote to go along with 525 electoral votes, the largest total in the history of Presidential politics. These voters were not driven his way by war or economic collapse. Mr. Reagan's opponent, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, was a solid political figure, so he clearly did not win by being perceived the lesser of two evils. Rather, six out of ten voters said clearly and unambiguously that they wanted him to be President. In that sense, the election was a triumphant affirmation of Mr. Reagan's popularity.

title: CASE STUDY OF ONE TEEN-AGER'S VICTORY
description: EDUCATORS have made steady progress in developing techniques for dealing with learning disabilities. Witness the case of Jane, from Greenwich, Conn., at 15 years old the quintessential American teen-ager - surrounded by friends and involved in a multitude of school activities. The slim brunette skis, reads novels and is an expert in pop music. A diligent student, she earns B's and C's and is planning a career as a veterinarian's assistant or as a hair stylist.

title: ALL HAIL THE R.S.C., BUT WHAT IS TO BE LEARNED?
description: When the Royal Shakespeare Company comes to town, New York theatergoers are inclined to embark on a manic-depressive binge.

title: LEARN JAPANESE AND IMPROVE YOUR ENGLISH
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CARS BOLSTER SPEED CRACKDOWN
description: STATE troopers have a new tool to use in the crackdown on speeders that was ordered last month by Governor O'Neill.

title: AN INSURANCE GIANT IS A COMPUTER DEALER
description: WHILE many companies struggle with the explosion of new personal computers and worry whether their managers will have compatible machines, the Travelers Company has solved the problem by starting its own computer store.

title: IS STAE OF SIEGE ENOUGH TO KEEP THE LID ON CHILE?
description: The level of discontent in Chile, a businessman here said, can be measured by the number of vendors crammed along the pedestrian malls that crisscross downtown Santiago. The unemployed pour out onto the streets here, trying to sell everything from razor blades to cherries, earning as little as $2 a day.

title: OF HEARTH AND HOME AND THE RIGHT TO WORK
description: The Labor Department provoked an angry outcry five years ago when it moved against a Vermont company that, in violation of a 1942 regulation, employed women to knit ski caps at home. Last week, after public hearings, a reverse in Federal court and passionate testimonials from home-based workers, the department rescinded the home-knitting ban. It said the prohibition had outlived its initial purpose of protecting the poor from sweatshop-style victimization.

title: BEING NO.1 IN JAPAN
description: Clyde Haberman is chief of The Times's Tokyo bureau.

title: Liquor Kills 8 in India
description: At least 8 people died and 13 were hospitalized here after drinking bootleg liquor Thursday, the police said. A police spokesman said the woman who sold the liquor was arrested in the nearby industrial town of Faridabad.

title:
THE EDUCATION CONSUMER;
SCHOOLS THAT OVERCOME GIRLS' COMPUTER SHYNESS
description: HUDDLED around two computers at Mount Hebron Middle School in Montclair, N.J., five girls, three of them sharing one chair, watched intently for responses to their typed-in commands. Instinctive camaraderie, marked with amused and sometimes wistful smiles, reflected the accomplishments and mistakes of their exercise. ''Sometimes the computer gets you mad,'' said Vanessa Salazar, ''because it does some things you really don't want it to do. But then, after it comes out right, it's O.K.'' Does it always come out right? the 14-year-old was asked. ''No, not really,'' she replied. ''That's when you really get mad at it. I've banged on the computer a few times.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Essex Chemical Corporation has nearly completed the shutdown of its plant in the Middlesex County community of Monmouth Junction, an action that company officials said was necessary because of state and Federal air-pollution-control regulations.

title: Czechs Foil Bus Hijacking
description: Czechoslovak border guards and policemen disarmed and arrested a man who had hijacked a bus with 48 passengers aboard and tried to force the driver at gunpoint to cross into West Germany at a border checkpoint on Friday night, the official Czechoslovak press agency reported today.

title:
THE EDUCATION CONSUMER;
HOW TO PASS THE COLLEGE INTERVIEW
description: THE SCORES have been tabulated, the ranks established, soon the last of the applications will be signed, sealed and sent with high hopes to the picture-book colleges in quaint villages and the sprawling urban campuses. In the meantime all over the nation, prospective students are preparing for the alumni interview. They will visit doctors, lawyers, perhaps even an Indian chief who have volunteered to interview candidates for their alma maters. Although the interviewer probably doesn't share the student's trepidation, he or she also wants to make an impression. Both are looking: the interviewer to recruit, the applicant for the college of his or her choice.

title: Miss Makepeace Weds A. T. Rojas Jr.
description: Susan Morse Makepeace, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Denison Makepeace 2d of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Andres T. Rojas Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rojas of North Bergen, N.J. The Rev. Ernest Cockrell performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Marion, Mass.

title: 11 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 11 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: HIS NEXT CHALLENGE: KEEPING THE ECONOMY STRONG
description: The campaign for the Presidency is over and the campaign for the President's ear has begun.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Nicaraguans seem intent on militarizing their society and accumulating a level of weapons and armed capability that is entirely outside the standpoint of any conceivable defensive mission.''

title: SECOND SATELLITE PUT IN ORBIT BY SHUTTLE ASTRONAUTS
description: The Discovery astronauts released another communications satellite into orbit today, clearing the way for their attempt to retrieve two other satellites in the first space salvage operation.

title: Disaster Declared in Hawaii
description: Gov. George Ariyoshi declared several sections of the island of Hawaii ''major disaster areas'' Friday because of a continuing severe drought. The announcement makes state assistance available for emergency water projects and provides tax relief for certain losses.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago Bears have placed the quarterback Jim McMahon on the injured reserve list and have activated the tight end Mitch Krenk for today's game against the Rams. McMahon suffered a lacerated kidney in a game against the Raiders last Sunday and will remain hospitalized until tomorrow. . . . Jack Nicklaus , who underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair damage to his left knee last Tuesday, says he will be able to play in the second Skins Game, the four-man match-play tournament in Las Vegas, Nev., Nov. 24-25.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MAJOR SHOW AND A FORUM AT MORVEN
description: PRINCETON AMAJOR showing of antiques and fine art, a glowing exhibition of New Jersey china and porcelain, a four-lecture antiques forum and a gala preview reception will mark the second New Jersey Antiques Show here this week.

title: CITY ISSUES RULES TO MAKE JAILS SAFER
description: City prison officials have established new mental health guidelines in an effort to identify, isolate and treat mentally impaired prisoners prone to violence against themselves or others.

title: THE BABOON HEART AND BABY FAE
description: The baboon heart transplanted into Baby Fae opens a new and so far uncertain avenue of medicine. It provokes the usual train of questions, clouded in this case by unusual maladroitness at the Loma Linda University Medical Center in presenting full information.

title: AUTUMN CALLS TO SOCCER'S SPIRITED FANS
description: If its cold and windy, it must be soccer time-nail biting, breath holding, fearing and cheering time. The younger the players, the bigger the crowds.

title: THE ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX BLUES
description: Mr. M had a problem. His $170,000 salary as a corporate executive put him in an uncomfortably high tax bracket. So he decided to invest in a real estate tax shelter that was rehabilitating a building. The investment in the shelter allowed him to claim a large investment tax credit, reducing a potential $35,000 1984 tax bill to $1,500.

title: KEY ANGOLA REBEL WARNS OF ATTACKS
description: Jonas Savimbi, leader of a guerrilla movement based in southern Angola, is demanding that he be included in the newest phase of United States-sponsored peace talks in this region of intertwined conflicts.

title:
LEISURE;
WHEN FLOWERS HAVE GONE, OTHER FEATURES TAKE OVER
description: As winter approaches the leafless landscape is less suggestive of spring and more in need of thoughtful contribtuions to the creation of an attractive scene to carry the landscape through winter. However, many months are endured when the garden lies dormant, the principle attractions must be derived from non-folier characteristics, decorative berries and fruits plus needled and broadleaved evergreens. Emphasis must be laid on the artistry of their arrangement.

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF WORLD HISTORIES
description: World history is back. In the first half of this century, writers such as Oswald Spengler, H. G. Wells, Pitirim A. Sorokin and Arnold Toynbee caused sensations and reached popular audiences with universal histories that described and interpreted the entire history of mankind. But by midcentury these histories had lost their appeal. Rough treatment at the hands of professional historians had something to do with their fate, but events also played a part. World War II had made a mockery of H. G. Wells's optimistic vision of ''man rising from lonely beginnings to this present dawn of world fellowship,'' but the victory and survival of the Western democracies had also discredited the doomsayers who had predicted the decline of the West. The cold war heightened the sense of the separateness and uniqueness of the Western tradition. Courses in Western civilization flourished, and interest in world history waned.

title: ELUSIVE SLOPES OF MANCHURIA
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is the Peking bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: 'FACE THE NATION' MARKS ITS 30TH YEAR
description: It was an embattled Joseph R. McCarthy, facing censure by his Senate colleagues, who strode purposefully into the CBS studio in
