description: Henry Giniger and Milt Freudenheim

title: VALIDITY OF POLIS CONFIRMED OVER AND OVER
description: To the Editor:

title: Augusta Scribner, Lawyer For the N.L.R.B., Marries
description: Augusta Scribner, a lawyer in the Brooklyn regional office of the National Labor Relations Board, and David A. Kapelman, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
RESTAGING FUGARD FOR THE HOME SCREEN
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Question and Answer column in last Sunday's Travel Section included incorrect information, supplied by the Israel Government Tourist Office, about visiting Bethlehem on Christmas Eve. A ticket is not required to enter the town but a ticket is needed to attend the midnight mass in the Church of St. Catherine, which is next door to the Church of the Nativity.

title: BLUE EYES FOREVER
description: Michael Lydon is the author of the forthcoming ''How to Succeed in Show Business by Really Trying.'' SINATRA

title: DOC-UMENTING THE HISTORY OF A NICKNAME
description: THEY'VE been doctoring the

title: Mary L. Hobson, W. J. F4in Natchez
description: Mary Louise Hobson, an assistant vice president of the Riggs National Bank, and William James Feltus 4th, a senior analyst for Marketing Opinion Research, both in Washington, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Natchez, Miss. The Rev. Robert Trent performed the ceremony.

title: CHOICE MOUNTAINS, GREAT AND SMALL
description: Many skiers head for the extensive resorts, those whose names are synonomous not only with a great variety of slopes, from beginner to expert, but also with all the facilities that the growth of skiing has spawned. Big hotels, condominiums, ambitious restaurants, shops, indoor tennis and swimming pools now vie for the ski vacationer's attention and wallet. But skiing still has a scene that is less intense. It is found at ski areas that for a variety of reasons have been left behind in the stampede of investment and growth, or are content to remain pretty much as they are. Some are physically small, some not so small but less accessible than more popular rivals, some simply more serene, less hectic. Yet many of these unheralded places still have what it takes to attract the best of skiers.

title:
ART;
COMPELLING PIECES THAT RADIATE AURA OF MYSTERY
description: THE art of Carol Kreeger Davidson has definite strings attached. Ubiquitous black cords seem to be what binds the retrospective of her last 10 years' work at the University of Hartford's Joseloff Gallery.

title: PRESIDENT'S PROCLAMATION
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: The White House

title: Sports of The Times; Timely Tranfusion
description: ON the television screen, Larry Holmes's age was showing as clearly as the blood from the cut over his left eye. At 35, the still-undefeated heavyweight champion was plodding to an undistinguished 12th-round knockout Friday night of James (Bonecrusher) Smith, an undistinguished challenger who eventually surrendered, bloody and bowed.

title: WHAT'S A PARENT TO DO?
description: Ellen Goodman is a syndicated columnist based at The Boston Globe and the author of ''At Large.''

title: STAGE: 'THE DAWNS ARE QUIET HERE,' A SOVIET PLAY
description: When the exiled Soviet director Yuri Lyubimov was head of the Taganka Theater in Moscow, one of his productions was ''The Dawns Are Quiet Here,'' which he adapted from the novel by Boris Vassiliev. As directed by Alex Dmitriev at the McCarter Theater, that adaptation gives American audiences a sampling of Lyubimov in absentia. (For an interview with Mr. Lyubimov, see the Arts and Leisure section.)

title: SYRACUSE PREVAILS BY 29-0
description: Harold Gayden rushed for 94 yards on 13 carries, including touchdowns of 10 and 4 yards, as Syracuse defeated Navy, 29-0, today.

title: BETWEEN GIANTS
description: F. Stephen Larrabee is the vice president and director of studies of the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York. From 1978 to 1981 he was on the staff of the National Security Council. CYPRUS

title: Future Events Season in Full Swing
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on questionnaires completed by 8,671 voters as they left polling places on Election Day in 176 randomly selected precincts in all parts of the United States, except the states of Washington, Hawaii and Alaska.

title: UPSTATE MEMORIAL TO TILDEN RESTORED
description: In 1876, Samuel J. Tilden, then the Governor of New York and the Democratic candidate for President, lost the election by one electoral vote even though he won a popular majority.

title: REPUBLICANS GAIN IN STATE LEGISLATURE
description: Republican candidates for state legislatures made strong gains around the country in Tuesday's voting, including gains in the South that some political experts believe will prove to be permanent.

title: Children's Negligence Suit Upheld Over Injury to Father
description: Children have a right to sue negligent parties for damage for loss of love, care, companionship and guidance of parents who are killed or injured, Washington's Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Toni Santangelo Wed in Purchase
description: At the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y., yesterday Toni Marisa Santangelo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Santangelo of Harrison, N.Y., and Boynton Beach, Fla., was married to John James Archibald Jr., the son of Mrs. Archibald of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Archibald. The Rev. Edward M. Connors performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: TIME TRAVEL BY WATER
description: WHERE THE RIVER BEGINS

title: Aftermath of Fight
description: When basketball players named Larry Bird and Julius Erving fight each other, everyone wonders what could have provoked them. Officials of the National Basketball Association are certainly curious and they have said they will investigate the battle of the superstars that occurred in a game between Bird's Boston Celtics and Erving's Philadelphia 76ers Friday night in Boston.

title: RECTOR PLACE RESIDENTIAL PHASE READY FOR BUILDING
description: AMILESTONE in the history of Battery

title: MOZAMBIQUE CAPITAL SKIRTS FAMINE
description: This capital city is one of the luckier spots in this far-flung and impoverished country of 14 million people: there is no famine here, just acute shortages of all foods.

title: MUSIC: DAVID EYGES
description: David Eyges has put a lot of thought into his new quintet, which performed Friday at Cooper Union's Great Hall. The group's repertory aims to encompass all the combinations and connotations offered by an unsual lineup of four stringed instruments - violin, guitar, bass and Mr. Eyges's cello - and drums.

title: 6 Killed by Mine in Thailand
description: Six Thai soldiers were killed and six people were wounded when a mine believed set by Communist guerrillas destroyed a pickup truck Friday in southern Thailand, an army officer said today. The incident occurred in Suratthani Province about 550 miles south of Bangkok.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MAJOR AUCTIONS ARE STIRRING EXCITEMENT
description: Several recent auction sales attracted large galleries and produced impressive prices. A notable example was the six-session, 1,800- lot auction of foreign and ancient coins from the famous Garrett Collection which took place Oct. 16-18 in Zurich, Switzerland. It drew several hundred bidders and realized more than $3 million. That total exceeded the estimate by more than 50 percent, according to Dr. Alan Walker, a cataloger for Bank Leu Ltd., the Zurich company that staged the extravaganza.

title: A TIME CAPSULE IS UPDATED FOR RETURN TO SITE
description: ON June 25, 1897, the schoolchildren of Tarrytown walked three blocks from their old school to the dedication of the new Washington Irving School and watched as a time capsule was inserted into the cornerstone.

title: JERSEY TAKES OVER EAST ORANGE SCHOOLS' FINANCES
description: The New Jersey Board of Education this week took over the financial operations of the East Orange School District, which state officials say faces a deficit of as much as $5 million.

title: FLUTIE BOOSTS EAGLES
description: The emotional farewell, anticipated and dreaded all at once, took on historic significance this afternoon when Doug Flutie played his last game on the Boston College campus.

title: BUILDING PROFITS INTO CONSERVATION
description: The following is adapted from ''Dynamos and Virgins'' by David Roe, published by Random House, which recounts how the Environmental Defense Fund, a national public-interest group, persuaded the country's largest regulated public utility - Pacific Gas and Electric - to shift its expansion plans away from coal and nuclear plants toward conservation and small-scale alternative energy sources such as cogeneration, wind and solar energy.

title: LENDL, GOMEZ GAIN
description: Ivan Lendl defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 6-2, in 85 minutes today in a semifinal match of the $250,000 Benson and Hedges Grand Prix tournament. In the other semifinal, Andres Gomez of Ecuador needed only 68 minutes to eliminate Peter Fleming of the United States, 6-3, 6-1.

title:
MUSIC;
CENTER STARTING CONCERTS
description: CLINTON THE Hunterdon Art Center, housed in a 19th-century stone gristmill here, serves not only as an art gallery, but also as the setting for occasional concerts.

title: E.P.A.'s Aerial Survey Of Dow Plant Upheld
description: The Environmental Protection Agency was within its rights when it conducted aerial surveillance and photography of a Dow Chemical Company plant six years ago, a Federal appeals court ruled Friday.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Nov. 11, 1984Fiction*1 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. *2 CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. *3

title: At St. Anthony's, Tradition Is Being Updated
description: When a thousand students from an all-boys' school show up one day at a coed school, bringing with them their school's name and most of its teachers, there are bound to be some rough edges to smooth.

title: LONG-RANGE HOPE FOR REPUBLICANS IS FOUND IN POLL
description: President Reagan's lonely landslide is a personal victory with little precise policy mandate or clear ideological underpinning, but it offers the Republican Party several reasons for long-range hope, a New York Times/CBS News national poll of voters shows.

title: Juliana Bassett Weds S. J. McLaughlin
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday Juliana Lucille Bassett, a daughter of Thomas A. Bassett of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., and the late Irene McCallum Bassett, was married to Stephen John McLaughlin, a son of Clement W. McLaughlin of North Brunswick, N.J., and Joyce M. Crowley of Barrington, Ill. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: WOMEN SEE LITTLE PROGRESS IN HIRING BY U.N.
description: Six years after the General Assembly mandated that one-quarter of all professional posts in the Secretariat should be held by women, senior officials concede that the target has not been met.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A STANDARD OF SOCIAL JUSTICE FOR THE STATE'S INVESTMENT POLICIES
description: THE DAYS of unlimited government spending are over. It has fallen to us in state government to develop a bold and imaginative strategy for deriving maximum benefits from our existing resources.

title: CABARET: GAIL BOGGS, SONGS
description: Gail Boggs, the young pop-soul singer and improvisatory comedienne, who is appearing Thursday evenings Upstairs at Greene Street, is a promising solo performer with some rough edges that need to be smoothed. Miss Boggs has appeared both on and off Broadway, in 'Ain't Misbehavin', '' ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' and ''Candide,'' and she is a zesty belter in the theatrical pop-soul mold of Donna Summer and Irene Cara.

title: ST. JOHN'S RALLIES TO UPSET HOFSTRA
description: After trailing by 16-0 in the second period, St. John's rallied behind Mike Burrell, its quarterback, and upset previously undefeated Hofstra, 19-16, yesterday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Millionaire Dogs
description: When Eleanor Ritchey, an oil company heiress, died in 1968, she left all her money - $4.3 million - to 150 homeless dogs she had adopted over the years.

title:
SOCIAL ISSUES;
COURT ORDER STIRS BLACK RECRUITMENT
description: -glass window in a North Philadelphia office building the other day had some of the marks of a sales office and some aspects of a college-admissions office. In fact, it was a little of both. An actor dressed like a lion was handing out pens and T-shirts. He was a Nittany Lion, and the pens and shirts bore the name of the university he symbolized, Pennsylvania State. Nearby, the recipients, prospective students, huddled with counselors.

title: SPOTLIGHT ON VICTORIAN FURNITURE
description: Victorian furniture at Florian Papp? The news may shock some collectors of English antiques - especially enthusiasts of the styles from the William and Mary period through to Regency who believe that after Victoria's coronation came a deluge of bad-taste furniture.

title: IN A NICARAGUAN VILLAGE, 'WE'RE USED TO GUNFIRE'
description: Four bursts of machine gun fire awakened this small northern town.

title: Dobbs Ferry Wins
description: Dobbs Ferry (8-0) trailed an opponent for the first time this season when Hastings (5-3) took a 7-0 lead a minute into the game. But the Eagles dominated the rest of the way, winning 28-7 and clinching a tie for its eighth consecutive Conference C South championship.

title: Slide Closes Coast Highway
description: A section of California Highway 1 along the Pacific Coast south of here has been closed indefinitely because of a rock slide, the State Highway Patrol reports. The slide occurred Friday night two miles south of Pacifica, where rocks and dirt have closed the steep, winding road dozens of times over the years.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM AYN RAND TO CHARLIE BROWN
description: The Synchronicity Concert Featuring the Police A&M Video/I.R.S. Video 75 minutes. $39.95

title: U.S. Reports Accord With Japan on Whales
description: A United States Government spokesman says an agreement has been reached on means by which Japan can prevent reductions of its fishing rights in American waters.

title: Ousted Disk Jockey Awarded $194,000 in Age Bias Case
description: A 55- year-old disk jockey has been awarded $194,000 by a Federal jury that found that radio station WCLR of suburban Skokie unlawfully dismissed him in 1980 on the ground that he was too old.

title: EX-WELFARE CHIEFS RECALL AGENCY'S PROBLEMS
description: In 1959, shortly after being named the head of what is now the city's Human Resources Administration, James R. Dumpson received a state directive to reduce the number of ineligible people on welfare.

title: BRANDEIS SEEKS TO RESTORE ITS OLD SENSE OF IDENTITY
description: WALTHAM, Mass.

title: Tennis Reactions
description: The continuing tirades of John McEnroe are causing tennis officials to exercise more control and constraint in tennis matches, even those involving other players. That's according to one of McEnroe's main rivals, Ivan Lendl.''

title: HISTORIAN CONTENDS RAIDERS DIDN'T GET SITTING BULL BONES
description: South Dakotans who set out to steal Sitting Bull's bones from North Dakota in 1953 got the wrong remains, a state historian says.

title: PANEL FINDS RACISM IN A TOLEDO HIGH SCHOOL
description: Black students at a public high school have been placed in entry-level courses and white students have been placed in honors classes regardless of their grades, and the school superintendent says he will discipline whoever was responsible.

title: THE ROOTS OF REVOLUTION
description: Flora Lewis is foreign affairs columnist for The New York Times.

title: Jets Hope to End Skid at Two
description: It took half a season for the Jets to learn how to win. Now, they are trying to learn how not to lose.

title: CRICTICS' CHOICES
description: Film buffs eager for something a little different can sample a pair of ''sleepers'' - ''The Naked Spur'' (1953) and ''One Is a Lonely Number'' (1972). That industry label means good, unexpected surprises - well- reviewed movies often with elusive titles and short on star dazzle.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: WEST AFRICAN VOYAGES: NEW SEASIDE RESORT
description: 18-DAY TRIPS BEGINNING IN DAKAR'S PORT

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: A PROGRAM AT RISK
description: WHAT does Ronald Reagan really understand about Social Security, and what will he do about it?

title: Nazi Link Spurs U.S. Action
description: The Justice Department has filed a suit to revoke the citizenship of a Massachusetts man accused of concealing his wartime assistance to the Nazis to gain admission to the United States.

title: MURDER TRIAL SET IN COAST SLAYING
description: A preliminary hearing into the slaying of a California university professor has ended with as much mystery as it began.

title: DODGER FAN FROM CHONGQING
description: IN THE YEAR OF THE BOAR AND JACKIE ROBINSON

title: EASING THE TERROR
description: MONTCLAIR WINIFRED LEE died quietly here last week in the room with flowered carpeting that she and her husband, Bertram, had shared for 37 years.

title: MANAGUA CAN'T VOTE AWAY PRESSURES
description: The Sandinistas last week won their first ballot-box endorsement since their takeover five years ago. But if they expected that the national election would ease tensions, they were quickly disabused.

title: Football Sleuthing
description: The Denver Broncos' coach. Dan Reeves, has accused the San Diego Chargers of claiming the Broncos' tight end Bobby Micho from the waiver list for the purpose of ''pumping him for information'' just two days before the teams meet today.

title: Julia Troxell to Marry
description: Julia Wood Troxell, a management consultant at Booz, Allen & Hamilton in New York, plans to be married Jan. 19 to James Lawrence Alexandre, a securities analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, also in New York. Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Troxell of Weston, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Alexandre of Radnor, Pa.

title: BABOON TRANSPLANT TESTS DESCRIBED
description: Months before doctors here transplanted a baboon heart into Baby Fae, they performed several dummy operations to make sure human blood would not react with animal tissue to cause immediate rejection of the organ, according to a Stanford University surgeon who was a consultant to the doctors.

title: ORCHESTRAS OFFER PROGRAMS
description: GOOD things come in threes, they say, and it would certainly seem so when one looks at the Westchester arts calendar: All three of the county's professional orchestras are in action; there are three enticing programs especially for children; and, more remarkable, three fully staged operas.

title: S. CAROLINA WINS 9TH IN ROW
description: Surprising South Carolina remained undefeated and untied today and found the Orange Bowl suddenly interested after it easily defeated Florida State, 38-26.

title: 7 Die in Brazilian Shootout
description: Three prisoners holding a judge hostage in his courtroom were killed along with two policemen Friday in a shootout in Sao Mateus, 380 miles northeast of here, the police said.

title: PEORIA, ILL. BANS 3 BOOKS FROM SCHOOL LIBRARIES
description: School officials here have banned three books by one of America's most popular children's storytellers because of their sexual content or strong language.

title: U.P.I. SAYS NEW PROFITS EASE ITS ILLS
description: Eight weeks after most of the employees of United Press International agreed to severe temporary wage cuts, the news agency has not attracted outside capital investment or new partnerships that it must have to prosper.

title: VETERAN JOURNALIST RUNNING FROM LOVE
description: Pete Hamill, a novelist and journalist, writes a weekly short story in The Daily News. MISTER WHITE EYES

title: CORPORATIONS STRENGTHEN SECURITY IN ANSWER TO TERRORISM
description: A UNIFORMED guard in white gloves, an ex-Marine who was hired by a security firm, mans a security gate on the entrance roadway into Texaco's offices in the town of Harrison, questioning drivers before waving them through. According to the guard, Michael Capeci, for at least 18 months Texaco stationed no guards at the entrance but decided to do so again after the Sept. 26 bombing of a Union Carbide Corporation building in Mount Pleasant.

title: APRES MOI
description: PHYLLIS THEROUX lives in Washington, D.C.

title: N.F.L. THWARTED IN RAIDERS CASE
description: N.F.L. Thwarted In Raiders Case

title: MINISH CONSIDERS CAUSES OF HIS LOSS
description: Representative Joseph G. Minish, who lost a bid for a 12th term in Congress Tuesday, says he believes he was beaten by court-ordered redistricting as well as by the efforts of special-interest groups.

title: NEW PERFORMERS GET A SHOWCASE
description: called ''Griffin Galas'' will be presented today at the University of Hartford's Lincoln Theater at 2 P.M. The galas are produced by Charles G. Griffin Jr. of West Hartford, using a combination of what he calls ''charm, closeness and camaraderie'' to showcase new musical talent.

title: Rent Increase Set on Coast
description: The City Council, in a reversal, has decided to keep the allowable annual rent increase in the nation's second-largest city at 7 percent. The 7-to-7 vote Friday nullified an 8-to-5 vote last week that tentatively dropped the annual adjustment rate to 65 percent of the Consumer Price Index, or about 3 percent this year. Councilman Joel Wachs called the reversal, which followed a week of lobbying by landlord and tenant groups, a ''cruel hoax.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION ;
WHERE IS THE PRIVATE MONEY PRESIDENT REAGAN PROMISED?
description: THE failure of voluntary corporate and individual contributors to meet Ronald Reagan's expectations of $100 billion annually - for a second straight year since 1982 - has not only disappointed the President, but has proved to the vast array of nonprofit organizations that private- sector philanthropy counts for less and less as a source of financing.

title: AUTO RESTRAINTS CUT CHILD DEATHS, STUDY SAYS
description: The use of restraint devices virtually eliminates the risk of death in automobile accidents for children 4 years old and younger, a new study indicates.

title: MARCH PROTESTS ATTACK ON BLACKS
description: About 30 marchers protested today against an attack on the home of a black family that had moved into an all-white neighborhood. Some onlookers yelled racial slurs at the demonstration.

title: METHANE CONDEMNS 11 SUBURBAN AKRON HOMES
description: David Henry felt ill and could not sleep. His wife and three young daughters often felt the same way.

title: CHILEAN TROOPS RAID SHANTYTOWN AND DETAIN 2,000
description: Chilean soldiers made a door-to-door search early today in a poor neighborhood in southern Santiago and rounded up as many as 2,000 men, according to residents and church officials.

title:
GARDENING;
PROCTECTING AGIANST WINTER INJURY
description: LAST winter was tough one for plants. In the natural sequence of events, plants in our temperate climate begin to harden-off in anticipation of winter in response to two phenomena - decreasing day length and gradually falling temperatures. With most species, the maximum winter hardiness is not attained until midwinter, when the coldest temperatures are normally experienced.

title: BOARD OF EDUCATION TO ALLOW CHECKS ON EMPLOYEES
description: The Board of Education says it will allow the city's Department of Investigation to proceed with background investigations of more than 2,000 school employees.

title: A Woman's Attacker Is Slain in the Bronx
description: A Staten Island man stabbed to death a Bronx man who tried to rape a woman in her apartment, the police said yesterday,

title: WEDGE OF LAND STIRS DEBATE
description: but a serious contest nonetheless.

title: Jody S. Fink, an Attorney, Marries David B. Lippman
description: Jody S. Fink, an attorney with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in New York, and David B. Lippman, a bond trader with PaineWebber Real Estate Securities Inc., also in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbis Samuel Geffen and Michael Morgan officiated at the Woodcrest Club in Syosset, L.I.

title: BRICE, CLARK & CO.
description: Howard Teichmann, a playwright, biographer and professor of English at Barnard College, wrote the next-to-closing sketch for Olsen and Johnson's 1938 revue, ''Hellzapoppin.'' THE GREAT CLOWNS OF BROADWAY

title: TITLE TO MT. ST. MICHAEL'S
description: Season-long scores were settled yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, where the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association and Public Schools Athletic League championships were held. Other meets are important, but the success of a season is usually judged by a team's performance in the meets known to most as simply ''the city's.''

title: UTRECHT TO JACE JOHN JAY
description: John Jay and New semi-finals, John Jay and New Utrecht - the first- and second-place finishers in the Brooklyn B division of the Public Schools Athletic League - came up winners yesterday and earned spots in next week's championship game.

title: Hoban Returns Interception 105 Yards
description: Jed Hoban, a senior safety for Bergen Catholic, set a school record yesterday when he returned an interception 105 yards to a touchdown in a 28-6 victory over Hackensack in Oradell.

title: Alice Peterson Affianced
description: The engagement of Alice Susan Peterson to R. Thornton Lurie, a vice president of Shearson Lehman/ American Express, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond George Peterson of Brooklyn, parents of the bride to be. Her fiance is the son of Elizabeth Franklin Lurie of Jacksonville, Fla., and Robert Lurie. A March wedding is planned.

title: KNICKS END SLUMP BY DOWNING KINGS
description: The Knicks made up for their ailing and absent big men by using an urelenting, harassing defense last night to defeat the Kansas City Kings, 113- 110, at Madison Square Garden. The victory, their second of the season, snapped a six-game losing streak.

title:
FOOD;
CONVENIENT STEWS PROVIDE A HEARTY MAIN COURSE
description: Text not curently available

title: TERRACED OFFICES
description: One of the huge office parks in various stages of constrution along New Jersey's Route 1 is Princetonpark, in Monmonth Junction, where the Seltzer Organization of Fort Washington, Pa., plans to develop more than 9 million square feet of space on 550 acres over the next several years.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GUIDED TOURS AT THE FLICK OF A SWITCH
description: An increasingly popular dimension has been added to sightseeing by the growth of audio tape cassettes. They have made it possible both to marvel at unfamiliar sights and to learn a lot about them at the same time.

title: THE RISKY NEW WRINKLES IN LETTERS OF CREDIT
description: The letter of credit, which has

title: FOE OF THE GANDHIS VOWS TO PRESS HIS FIGHT
description: The Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh State said this week that while he mourned the passing of his principal political enemy, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, his opposition to her Congress Party would continue.

title:
THE LEARNING DISABLED;
STATE PROGRAMS ARE MANY AND VARIED
description: AMID rising concerns about the large number of children classified as learning disabled, confusion over eligibility requirements and shrinking funds, more schools and states are developing alternative programs as a screening device before referring a student to special-education services.

title: CANADIAN GAS OFFERS SAVINGS
description: NATURAL gas from Canada will make a difference over the next year in the gas bills paid by 156,000 customers of Northeast Utilities, company officials predict.

title: WESTCCHESTER GUIDE
description: HOLOCAUST MISSION

title: RAISING FUNDS TO RESTORE ART OF VATICAN
description: WHEN Msgr. Eugene V. Clark visited the Vatican last year, he witnessed a procedure he found ''fascinating'' - the restoration of the Madonna de MonteLuce, a painting begun by Raphael and completed by his collaborators Giulio Romano and Francesco Penni.

title: CHRISTIANSEN TAKES THE MASTERS OPEN
description: The first United States Masters Open Tournament, in Estes Park, Colo., was won by Larry Christiansen, a 28- year-old Los Angeles grandmaster. Six victories and three draws, for a 7 1/2-1 1/2 score, gave him the $1,500 first prize in the nine-round, Swiss-system competition.

title: KOCH WARNS OF SHIFT OF POWER IN GOVERNMENT
description: The legislative and executive branches of government have increasingly ''dumped'' important, complex decisions on the courts, and the process may be upsetting the nation's traditional balance of powers, Mayor Koch warned last week.

title: POLITICS TANGLES THE SUPPLY LINE TO ETHIOPIA
description: The politics of starvation is politics at its most brutal. It is also often subtle. The logistics of delivering food to hungry people are complicated enough. But there are also governments involved, and political alliances among governments; sometimes civil wars and revolutions get in the way; and famines themselves can have political as well as natural causes.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE sixth annual Channel 21 art and antiques auction winds up today with some of the best - and most costly - merchandise saved for the end.

title: 2 DIE
description: Two men died and a third was injured today after a pleasure boat entering Barnegat Inlet hit an eight-foot wave and flipped end over end, according to the Coast Guard.

title: SEASONAL MENU IN COUNTRY SETTING
description: WITH the weather beginning to feel seasonal, the idea of setting a pot of stew on the stove to simmer away for a couple of hours no longer seems inappropriate. And sitting down to a dinner anchored securely by a hearty main course whets our appetites again.

title: SALVADOR REBELS ARE STILL THERE
description: Peace talks between the Salvadoran Government and the rebels are due to resume at the end of the month. As if to put themselves in a position of force, the rebels last week carried out their strongest attack in six months, overrunning the town of Suchitoto, 30 miles northeast of the capital, in the center of the country.

title: LARGE AND SMALL CLOUDS OVER SEATTLE
description: When the World Team Olympiad began in Seattle two weeks ago there were some large clouds over the city and some small ones over those involved.

title: Decoy Carver Remembered in Book
description: KNOWLEDGEABLE collectors of waterfowl decoys have long known that Charles (Shang) Wheeler (1872- 1949) of Connecticut was one of this nation's most skillful practicioners of what has been described as a truly American art form.

title: HOW TO SURVIVE A SIBLING
description: 101 THINGS TO DO WITH A BABY

title: WORKING TOGETHER IS HIGH ON THE LIST OF '85 CHALLENGES
description: The country last week elected not only a President but also a Congress, the composition of which stayed essentially unchanged. The Week in Review asked members of each chamber's leadership - Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri - to talk about the meaning of the election result, the national agenda and the prospects for cooperation between parties and between Congress and the White House. Excerpts of their discussion with Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Steven V. Roberts, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, follow.

title:
THE SCHOOLS;
IT'S TEACHER SHORTAGE TIME AGAIN
description: THROUGHOUT his school career Edward Grant always excelled in mathematics. But he majored in English in college, and though he became a special-education teacher he never forgot his first love. So when he spotted an advertisement for a new retraining program for math teachers at Long Island University's Brooklyn campus, he enrolled. Today Mr. Grant is a math teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School. ''It was a real career change for me,'' he said. ''But the initial courses in geometry and algebra were for nonmath majors and this gave me confidence to pursue a degree in math.'' Since then Mr. Grant has also taken computer courses and is a computer specialist for his school.

title:
THE WORLD OF THE LONE-WOLF ENTREPRENEUR;
A FULL-SERVICE AGENCY ROLLED INTO ONE
description: JOSEPH SONNENREICH is no rookie at working alone. Since 1950, he has done advertising work that most agencies parcel out to at least three or more different departments. He single-handedly takes his ads from concept through story board through publication.

title: Nuptials Planned For Miss Gfeller
description: The engagement of Debra Ann Gfeller to Michael Steven Giaimo has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Robert John Gfeller of West Hartford, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario B. Giaimo of Summit, N.J.

title: BRAIN STUDIES SHED LIGHT ON DISORDERS
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS and parents have struggled for decades with questions of why Johnny can't read, speak clearly, sit still, stop fighting or listen. In recent years, however, scientists have for the first time begun to discover some of the biological mechanisms that underlie learning disorders. By slicing the brain tissue of deceased dyslexic adults, looking at the brain electrical activity of children who can't sit still, and studying the family trees of children who can't read, they are beginning to shed light on what's gone awry in the brains of people with learning disorders.

title: Peace Exchanges
description: To the Editor: The article and accom

title: Uganda Halts Dealings In Foreign Exchange
description: President Milton Obote has suspended foreign exchange transactions for two weeks to reassess the country's hard- currency auctions, the state radio reported today.

title: REAGAN AND THE COURT
description: On the morning after his ''bad night'' in the first debate with Walter Mondale, President Reagan traveled to Charlotte, N.C., to declare that ''busing takes innocent children out of the neighborhood school and makes them pawns in a social experiment that nobody wants . . . We've found out it failed.''

title: VERSIONS OF THE NATIVITY
description: Madeleine L'Engle 's most recent book for young adults is ''A House Like a Lotus.'' CHRISTMAS

title: Jane Herrman to Wed An Assistant Curator
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Davis Herrman 2d of Hewlett, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Jane Ellen Herrman to Richard J. Horwitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Horwitz of Evanston, Ill. A February wedding is planned.

title: PILGRIM AMONG THE CULTURATI
description: LIVES OF THE POETS

title: UT-NAPISHTIM REVISITED
description: GILGAMESH Translated by John Gardner and John Maier with Richard A. Henshaw. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. GILGAMESH THE KING

title: CO-OPS WARNED ON REJECTIONS
description: IN the last few weeks, lawyers have been

title: Lauren Rappoport to Be Married to a Physician
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Rappoport of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jill Rappoport, to Dr. Michael Feld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Feld of Massepequa Park, L.I.. A June wedding is planned.

title: SCOTTISH AGATE JEWELRY
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM, the author of ''Kosode: 16th- to 19th-Century Textiles From the Nomura Collection'' (Kodansha International), is a frequent visitor to Scotland.

title: Laura Ashley
description: To the Editor:

title: New Protests by Blacks Erupt in South Africa
description: Rioting, looting and arson erupted again today in black townships across South Africa, and the police said they repeatedly fired rubber bullets, birdshot and tear gas to disperse crowds of blacks.

title: VIOLENCE MAKES SIKHS FEAR FOR THEIR FUTURE IN INDIA
description: Within the past five months, the proud Sikhs of India have experienced two embittering traumas that have radically altered their sense of being full members of a pluralist nation. The first was the bloody army assault in June on the Sikhs' most sacred shrine, the Golden Temple in Amritsar, which had been converted into the bastion of a terrorist movement seemingly bent on carving an independent Sikh state from Punjab. The second shock was the savage wave of murder, looting and arson - centered on Sikh homes, shops, taxis and factories in New Delhi - that washed over northern India after Indira Gandhi's assassination by two bodyguards identified as Sikhs.

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOOKS
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1984.

title: LEBANON SUSPENDS TALKS WITH ISRAEL ON TROOP PULLOUT
description: The Lebanese Government, under fierce pressure from Islamic fundamentalists, announced today that it had suspended negotiations with Israel on a withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon.

title: CABARET: GEORGIA LOUIS SINGS
description: Georgia Louis, who made her first major New York cabaret appearance at Sweetwaters, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, last week, emphasizes the fact that she started out as a Gospel singer. The program she presented takes her into blues, rock and even Broadway musicals, but she still seems most secure in Gospel.

title: JILL H. EBBOT IS MARRIED TO V.K. BURG
description: Jill Haliday Ebbott, a daughter of Mrs. John David Igleheart of Redding, Conn., and John P. Ebbott of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Victor Kantor Burg, a son of Frances K. Burg of Charlotte, N.C., and the late Irving H. Burg. The Rev. Graham Ward, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the West Parish Church in Andover, Mass.

title: MUSIC: 'STILL LIVES,' A PERFORMANCE PIECE
description: The composer William Hellermann has concocted ''Still Lives,'' a performance piece at the Medicine Show Theater through today from bits of minimal music and stylized moments of everyday life, in 10 short vignettes. It is a droll, unpretentious work that directs as much attention to ordinary noises - snoring, sweeping, talking, clinking glasses - as to its music.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT PENGUINS, 5-4
description: Again playing give-and-take, but this time taking slightly more, the Islanders handed the Pittsburgh Penguins a 5-4 defeat tonight at Nassau Coliseum, after giving up leads four times.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN TAPPAN
description: ALTHOUGH the New York suburbs

title: ST. LOUIS FOSTERS NEW MUSIC
description: With all the attention that certain New York and California composers have been receiving lately, it is important to remember that the majority of American music is still composed somewhere between the Hudson River and the San Andreas fault line. In fact, New Music Circle, which bills itself as ''the oldest continuously active organization devoted to the promotion, presentation and promulgation of contemporary music,'' is located in St. Louis, which some anonymous Easterner once dubbed the ''Gateway to the West,'' and which is, in fact, pretty close to the center of the country.

title:
THE LEARNING DISABLED;
DYSLEXIA BATTLE THAT FORGED A CAREER

title: Gesundheit!
description: Headliners In the Soviet Union, where disappearance from the public eye is counted among the first symptoms of a cold, Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov is believed to be suffering something more serious than the sniffles. Mr. Ustinov has not been seen in public since Sept. 27, and last week he became the first Soviet Defense Minister to miss the military parade that marks the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, which is traditionally launched by the holder of that office. One news agency quoted a Politburo member as saying Mr. Ustinov had a sore throat; another quoted a Foreign Ministry official as saying the Defense Minister was ''unwell.'' And the word circulating among some Western diplomats was that Mr. Ustinov had come down with the flu.

title: TOY-BOOKS IN THE AGE OF PACKAGING
description: A century ago they were called movable toy-books. They had titles such as ''Scenes in the Life of a Masher,'' ''The Jolly Uncle,'' ''Fly-Away Pictures,'' ''The Prince of Lilliput,'' ''Wild Animals,'' and they were immensely popular. There were Cinderellas and Old Mother Hubbards too; as early as 1843, a mechanical Humpty Dumpty was printed in Welsh, Greek, Hebrew, Italian and German, all under a single cover. But more often the toy- books were stages on which different drummers marched than marched across the pages of traditional children's books.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTIONONE THING LEADING TO ANOTHER: And Other Stories. By Sylvia Townsend Warner. Selected and edited by Susanna Pinney. (Viking, $14.95.) In this posthumous collection of stories, fey mortals and all-too-mortal fairies abound. Of the 20 pieces - several of which appeared in The New Yorker over the past 40 years - most concern themselves with the real world; the rest take place in the imaginary, politically sensitive Kingdoms of Elfin. Whether writing naturalistically about village life in England, or fantastically about the destinies of elves, Sylvia Townsend Warner (who wrote in a wide variety of genres, including poetry) works her curious trick of showing how one thing does indeed lead to another, often in the most alarming way. ''Some Effects of a Hat'' is typical: an American tourist leaves his homburg behind in a chance encounter with an unmarried, unpopular woman living in Devonshire. Expecting him to come back for it and unwilling to let the expensive hat sink into the oblivion of daily neglect like ''the inexplicable key on the bathroom window sill, the dog-eared packet of wallflower seed behind the parlour clock,'' the woman keeps it spruced and ready on the table near her front door. Her hostile neighbors get suspicious of a man's hat (''It's been moved a good inch to the right since I saw it last Tuesday''), and she is eventually driven out of town, only to end up in Derbyshire and a new life. Warner's effects are especially delightful when characters appear in several stories.

title: LETTER FROM MEXICO - YOUNG WRITERS DISCOVER THE URBAN NOVEL
description: Jonathan Kandell, the author of ''Passage Through El Dorado,'' is writing a ''biography'' of Mexico City. MEXICO CITY OR 50 years after the Revolution of 1910-20, that bloody cataclysm that ushered Mexico into its modern century, the Government patronized the nation's cultural life with surprising adroitness. Through a sophisticated policy of financial inducements and prestigious awards, writers, painters and film directors were encouraged to deal with the revolution, the pre-Columbian Indian heritage, populism, the countryside, nationalism and related themes that had official approval. I do not mean to suggest that Mexico enforced a heavy- handed orthodoxy resembling Soviet Socialist Realism. In fact, many works emerged as classics even though they were sharply critical of Mexican society. But at the very least, a consensus existed among cultural luminaries and politicians on what subjects were important.
