LONG ISLAND OPINION;
'OUR COLLEGE IS NO PLACE FOR POLITICS'
description: SUFFOLK County Community College has always been a model for other two-year colleges in the state. It has operated quietly, efficiently and without controversy during its 20 years of existence. But in the last few months the college has been caught in a political mousetrap, and its autonomy as an educational institution may be placed at hazard.

title: Physician Is Wed T
description: Dr. Kimberly Rawlins, a resident in internal medicine at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y., and Dr. David M. Pilgrim, a fellow in geriatrics at the Harvard Medical School, were married yesterday. The Rev. Russell Davis, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church.

title: FIGHTING TO BE THE TABLOID KING ON LONDON'S FLEET STREET
description: ROBERT MAXWELL, one of Britain's leading publishers and an outspoken socialist whose tussles with trade unions have mired him in controversy, is back in battle again. He is going head to head with rival publisher Rupert Murdoch to become the next press lord of Fleet Street. His weapon is The Daily Mirror, a cheeky tabloid that he purchased four months ago. Since then, he has shaken up British journalism with a Murdoch-style offering of bingo games, cheesecake photos and splashy reporting - all designed to beat Mr. Murdoch at his own game.

title: U.S. BUSINESSMAN TRIES TO RAISE CASH FOR MODERATE GRENADA PARTY
description: With elections in Grenada three weeks away, a New Jersey businessman has pledged $2,500 to one of the leading political parties and says he is going to try to raise more money for the campaign from other businessmen in the United States.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DENVER
description: IVER PETERSON is chief of the Denver bureau of The Times.

title: UNDERGROUND MUSIC New York subway riders have learned to dread the itinerant musicians: the saxophonist who honks out choruses of ''Blue Moon'' while struggling to keep his balance in a moving car; the accordionist who grinds out old polkas on packed trains. But the other evening on a BMT platform at Times Square, a violinist offered selections from Bach and Paganini with style and mastery. Between numbers, he kept up a friendly line of patter about the music and the fun of playing for a subway crowd.
description: His Brooklyn-bound blue-collar audience was appreciative. When a train arrived, drowning out the performer, many paused to drop coins or bills in his violin case. Why does the violin enthrall while the accordion irritates? Because even in a subway, no performer in New York should ever underestimate the audience.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
LIFE AND DEATH, A PANE OF GLASS
description: ILIKE the wildlife I have stumbled across in Westchester but,

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
KEEPING A LOG ON STAYING WARM
description: THE DAYS are getting shorter, the temperature is dropping and the wind coming out of the north carries not only newly fallen leaves, but also promises of colder nights.

title: PARALLEL INJUSTICES
description: Gerald Jonas regularly reviews science fiction for The Book Review. JOB

title:
ABOUT MEN;
AMONG WARRIORS
description: I ALWAYS CONSIDERED 322 THE LUCKIEST SET OF DIGITS

title: Man Guilty in Clinic Arsons
description: Curtis Beseda, 29 years old, of Everett, Wash., who admitted in court that he set fire to abortion clinics to try to save the unborn, was convicted of arson Friday by a Federal jury.

title: BRITAIN'S AMERICAN BAND
description: Robert Palmer is a rock critic for The New York Times. DANCE WITH THE DEVIL

title: AN 'OBSESSION' THAT IS NOT TRIVIAL
description: CECELIA NORWOOD of Bridgeport was losing sleep. Knowing the only two people in the Baseball Hall of Fame who were not involved with the sport, and not being able to do anything with that knowledge, ''can put pressure on you,'' she explained.

title: Miss Hauserman To Marry in June
description: A June wedding is planned by Patricia Martin Hauserman and Peter Studebaker Winder, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Foley Hauserman of Cleveland, have announced.

title: MissLeBourgeois Is Newport Bride
description: Anne Armour LeBourgeois, the daughter of Vice Adm. Julien J. LeBourgeois, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. LeBourgeois of Tamworth, N.H., was married yesterday to Robert Thomas Grieves, the son of Mrs. James H. Grieves of Kenmore, N.Y., and Sans Souci, Ontario, and the late Mr. Grieves.

title:
THE SCHOOLS;
CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS CUSTOMIZE SCHOOL TRIPS
description: IN the children's section at the Brooklyn Botanic

title: 2 Slain in Shooting On the West Side
description: Two men were slain and a third was seriously wounded late Saturday in shooting on the Upper West Side that was apparently drug-related, the police said yesterday.

title: CUP RACES FILLED WITH HIGH DRAMA
description: On the day after the richest horse race in history, the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic, the principals involved in Saturday's turbulent and controversial finish sat down for a close look at what happened. They decided the stewards had probably made the best possible decision in disqualifying Gate Dancer from second place but leaving Wild Again as the winner.

title: EXILED SOUTH KOREAN PLANS TO RETURN SOON TO PRESS FIGHT FOR RIGHTS
description: Kim Dae Jung, the leading critic of the South Korean Government, says he plans to end his exile here and return home soon because he has been frustrated by his inability to influence South Korean politics from the United States.

title: JOB SEEKERS GROWINGLY INFLEXIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: SIKHS IN U.S. RELIVING INDIA'S HORROR
description: Although the violence in India that occurred after Indira Gandhi's assassination appears to have come to an end, many Sikhs in the United States are reliving the tragedy through friends and relatives, who have told them of the killings, burnings and looting. The experience has moved many of them to action.

title: Skepticism on Rally's Future
description: The optimism in the bond market, where interest rates have been declining for five months, was tested last week when the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose from less than 11.50 percent on Monday to as high as 11.87 percent Thursday before closing at 11.64 percent Friday.

title: HORATIO ON TERRORISM
description: To the Editor:

title: IN NICARAGUA, THE LUCKY BUY PLENTY WITH DOLLARS
description: People are complaining these days about shortages of soap, toilet paper, meat, aspirin and tires. But for lucky Managua residents with dollars, there's no need to suffer the inconvenience.

title: NETS OVERPOWERED BY LAKERS, 121-111
description: When Darryl Dawkins recently entered a New Jersey Hospital with a back ailment, there were worries that his backup, Mike Gminski, would not be able to handle being a starting center, because he had spent his career as a substitute.

title: SusannaMorgenthauWedsAlanMintz
description: Susanna Gisella Morgenthau and Alan Lawrence Mintz were married yesterday at the Riverdale Jewish Center in the Bronx by Rabbis Ephraim Buchwald and Daniel Shevitz.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: The principal interest in yesterday afternoon's American Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall was - or should have been - ''Le Sacre du Printemps.'' Robert Craft was there to conduct it, and Mr. Craft's long association with the composer makes his thoughts on Stravinsky's great masterpiece worth our while.

title: Research on Haggling Influences Ad Effort
description: Consumers in the market for electronic products can go to a department store, a specialty chain or a neighborhood mom and pop shop. Business is divided about evenly among them.

title: DANCE: 'SUMMERDANCE' BY BETH SOLL & COMPANY
description: What was going on in the rest of the woods that famed midsummer's night, or in the far corner of the grove in which Mallarme placed his faun? And did these prancing nymphs pass through a woods concocted by Louis Eilshemius, that painter of mysteriously inhabited woodlands, on their way to Beth Soll's ''Summerdance''?

title: WITH SON, A LEADER IN RIGHTS MOVEMENT
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr., one of the South's most influential black clergymen for decades and the father of the slain civil rights leader who bore his name, died of heart disease yesterday in Atlanta. He was 84 years old.

title: Revamped Seahawks Stealing Success
description: SEATTLE

title: FREE-SPEECH ISSUES SURROUND COMPUTER BULLETIN BOARD USE
description: On May 16, the police raided the Los Angeles home of Thomas G. Tcimpidis and seized his personal computer and data storage devices. The ensuing case has ignited a nationwide debate that could influence the future of computerized communications and electronic publishing.

title: KINGS WIN BY 4-2, HALT RANGER STREAK
description: A letdown had been anticipated, and it happened. In the aftermath of the great Islander affair, the Rangers were without the same sparkle. They lost to the Los Angeles Kings, 4-2, last night in a dry contest at the Garden that was impossible to consider without remembering Friday night, when the Rangers came back from four goals down to defeat the Islanders.

title: Steel Workers' Minister Defies Sheriff on Church
description: Proclaiming ''everyone is welcome,'' including the sheriff, a dissident minister unlocked his steel-mill town church for services today in defiance of his bishop and a judge.

title: RYAN IS STILL NO. 1
description: Although Pat Ryan was replaced twice by Ken O'Brien during the Jets' 9-5 loss to the Indianapolis Colts today, Coach Joe Walton said that Ryan would remain the No. 1 quarterback.

title: DISPUTED COAST REACTOR GOES TO WORK
description: After a decade of controversy, the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant began generating its first kilowatts of electricity for consumer use today.

title: Jonsson Is Confused by Waiver Reports
description: The morning wake-up call was early - and rude - for Tomas Jonsson.

title: Elorde Is Ailing
description: Flash Elorde, the former world junior lightweight champion, is undergoing treatment for lung cancer at a suburban hospital, his family said today.

title: ; BRINGING THE YOUNG INTO THE LABOR FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Synthetic Fuels Mystery
description: It looks as if the battered Synthetic Fuels Corporation, immobilized for the last seven months for lack of directors, is about to get back in business. Just who will be calling the shots, however, remains a mystery. Will it be Edward E. Noble, the current chairman, who as head of President Reagan's 1980 transition team for the corporation, recommended abolishing the infant organization? Or might it be four-term Representative Tom Corcoran, an Illinois Republican, who sponsored legislation this year to wipe it out?

title: Jailed Soviet Dissident May Be in Labor Camp
description: The wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a Soviet Jew serving a 13-year sentence for anti- Soviet activities, said today that she believed her husband had been taken from prison to a labor camp in the Ural Mountains.

title: Farmers Group Picks Chief Operating Officer
description: The Farmers Group Inc. has elected Leo E. Denlea Jr. president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 2.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1984 International Israel offered to begin a cease-fire in south Lebanon with the Shiite Moslem militia there. The move was a response to Lebanon's suspension of troop withdrawal talks over the arrest of a group of Moslem militiamen. (Page A1, Column 4.) Israel destroyed 28 homes of Palestinian farmers in the West Bank of the Jordan Valley. Israel has now destroyed nearly 80 such houses in the last 10 days, according to a spokesman for the Civil Administration, the Israeli agency that governs occupied territories, who said the houses were built without permission. (A14:4.)

title: MUSEUMS OF VATICAN GET PATRONS
description: The Vatican Museums, which lent more than 200 of their artistic treasures to three major American museums in a traveling exhibition last year, have significantly added to their fund-raising, artworks conservation and exhibition programs as a result of new patrons and ideas gathered during the show's yearlong travels in this country, according to Walter Persegati, the secretary-general of the museums.

title: Paying for a Phone Revolution
description: Responding to Congress's resistance, the Federal Communications Commission has tentatively decided to trim sail on its plan to levy ''access charges'' on residential telephones. These fees, intended to reduce the cost burden on long-distance service, were scheduled to reach $4 a month by 1989. Under the new plan, the fees will be capped at $2.80. Now the commission's job is to teach a skeptical public why the cost shift makes good economic sense.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Seahawks vs. Los Angeles Raiders, at Seattle. This is a key game for both teams, which are struggling to keep up with the Denver Broncos in the A.F.C. West.

title: GREENS DON'T WANT TO PLAY GAMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile Prelate Deplores Raid on a Shantytown
description: Chile's senior Roman Catholic prelate today deplored the military raid on a shantytown, warning that ''the end does not justify the means'' in the Government's crackdown on violent unrest.

title: ACTRESS PLAYS HERSELF IN 'VICTIMS FOR VICTIMS'
description: In case you hadn't noticed, actors are a strange breed. Theresa Saldana, whose career got

title: Bracing for Injury
description: Every year, scores of football players are hurt so badly that they miss games and, in many cases, the rest of the season. Knees, ankles and shoulders are especially vulnerable. And the team suffers.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: ard Lesson For the Giants
description: TAMPA, Fla. For an improving but still immature team, often the most difficult assignment is to win a game that it's expected to win. When the Jets were developing into a Super Bowl contender a few years ago, they learned that - the hard way.

title: Ghana Cabinet Members Are Reported Dismissed
description: Ghana has dismissed several key ministers, the Accra radio said today. The radio, monitored here, said the ruling Provisional National Defense Council had named new ministers of industry, education, information, agriculture and trade.

title: ISRAELIS DESTROY HOUSES OF 28 WEST BANK ARABS
description: Twenty- eight crude houses belonging to Palestinian farmers in the West Bank were demolished by Israeli authorities today as ''illegal structures.''

title: Kings Weigh Shift to Coast
description: The franchise began as the Rochester Royals. It was also the Cincinnati Royals, the Kansas City-Omaha Kings and now just the Kansas City Kings. By next season, the team could be on the move again, this time to Sacramento, Calif.

title: 6 Seized at Teterboro Airport In Plane With Guns and Drugs
description: Six people were arrested yesterday after they landed at Teterboro Airport in a small chartered plane containing a submachine gun, two other firearms and small amounts of marijuana and cocaine, authorities said.

title: OLYMPIC SURPLUS FUNDS FOR WHEELCHAIR ATHLETES
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMY PERSONNEL ARE SUPPORTING WESTMORELAND
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland's suit against CBS may not have started fires in the minds of the public but it has rallied the Army behind the general - not simply the serving Army but thousands of former officers and enlisted men who feel that his cause is theirs too.

title: A NEW STYLE IN INDIA
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has barely begun to confront the daunting challenges and the opportunities for new beginnings that he faces. But it has already become apparent to many here that if he survives politically, he will differ significantly from his mother in policy and style.

title: AMERICAN KENNEL CLUB'S CENTENNIAL IS A CELEBRATION OF DOGS
description: The founding fathers met in Philadelphia on Sept. 17, 1884. It was

title: A Champion of Breakfast
description: When historians compile the annals of the 1984 campaign, they should not overlook one of its small oratorical gems, the introduction given Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro by her 18- year-old daughter, Laura Zaccaro, in Van Nuys, Calif., one morning late in the Democratic effort. Miss Zaccaro wrote the speech, and a campaign aide edited it. The subject was a bread-and-butter issue: breakfast.

title: PRIVATE SATELLITE ANTENNAS: ONE BATTLE IS ENDED
description: When President Reagan legalized possession and use of satellite earth stations by private individuals last month, he dispelled the legal miasma that had shrouded the big dish antennas that pull in programs directly from satellites.

title: EUGENIA SHEPPARD, FASHION COLUMNIST, DIES
description: Eugenia Sheppard, one of the most influential fashion writers of the 1950's and 60's, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was believed to be in her 80's and lived in Manhattan.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: ALCOHOLISM IN WOMEN UNDER 30
description: TWO years ago Barbara T. of San Francisco drank a pint of vodka a day. ''My relationships with my family and friends suffered because all I thought about was drinking,'' said Barbara, who is now 21. ''I lost my part-time job, and my college roommates refused to speak to me because their patience had worn thin.''

title: China Mine-Flooding Kills 10
description: At least 10 people have died in severe flooding in coal mines in Hebei Province, but the full extent of the damage has yet to be disclosed, China Daily said today. The situation is likely to worsen a power shortage expected this winter in northern China, the English- language newspaper said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has named Martin J. Hummel vice president- corporate executive consumer relations.

title: ECONOMIC CHILL SEEN IN 2D TERM
description: The nation's vigorous economy may have played a major role in President Reagan's overwhelming re-election, but most analysts doubt that the economic performance Americans endorsed last Tuesday is the one they will get in the coming four years.

title: REAGAN'S CAMPAIGN DOUBLE-CROSSED THE G.O.P.
description: Ronald Reagan faces two years with a hostile Congress - and the likelihood of an electoral disaster in the 1986 Congressional elections. Why?

title: CEDAR RAPIDS VOTE BAFFLES DEMOCRATS
description: Michael Newmeister is baffled why his neighbors voted for President Reagan at the same time they voted against one of the President's most dedicated allies, Senator Roger W. Jepsen.

title: THEATER: A MUSICAL 'THREE MUSKETEERS' OPENS
description: The one real lift in ''The Three Musketeers,'' the new musical at the Broadway, occurs early - when D'Artagnan enters the auditorium on a horse. Enjoy this spectacle while it lasts. Once the horse has deposited his passenger on stage, he disappears - never to return, not even for his curtain call. Where does the horse go? We're never told, but if he has any horse sense, he's probably around the corner at the Gershwin, trying to curry favor with the more gainfully employed D'Artagnan of ''Cyrano de Bergerac.''

title: Scholl Captures Jersey Marathon
description: Bill Scholl of Manasquan, running in heavy rain and strong winds, captured the Jersey Shore Marathon today in 2 hours 30 minutes 55 seconds, the slowest winning time in the race's 14 years.

title: IRAN'S LEADERS OPEN CAMPAIGN AGAINST CORRUPTION IN GOVERNMENT
description: Iran's governing clergymen appear to have begun a campaign against corruption in the Government in an attempt to improve the public image of their leadership.

title: DOLPHINS WIN AND ARE 11-0
description: Doug Betters, a defensive end, blocked an extra-point attempt by Paul McFadden with 1 minute 52 seconds left today, enabling the Miami Dolphins to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 24-23, and stay unbeaten in the National Football League.

title: IMAGINE OFFICIALDOM WITH NO PLACE TO SIT
description: Newly elected members of Congress and the staffs that they hire may as well face it: their office quarters will be far from spacious.

title: Pollution Protest in Munich
description: About 20,000 people took part in a five-mile march and rally here Saturday to protest damage to Bavaria's forests and to demand highway speed limits to reduce air pollution. Organizers said it was the biggest such protest yet held in West Germany.

title: PROMISING BEGINNING
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

title: COWBOYS GAIN TIE FOR FIRST
description: Gary Hogeboom threw a 26-yard fourth- quarter touchdown pass to Ron Springs to break a 17-17 tie today as the Dallas Cowboys took advantage of six turnovers to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 24-17.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page Oct. 30 about the addition of a statue to the site of the Vietnam Memorial incompletely described the memorial's black granite wall. It lists Americans missing in action as well as those killed.

title: MILK DELIVERERS EXTEND TALKS ON PACT PAST STRIKE DEADLINE
description: Milk deliverers agreed to put aside a strike deadline yesterday and continued bargaining in hopes of averting a strike that could halt milk deliveries to much of the New York metropolitan area.

title: TAKE SMALL STEPS TOWARD MOSCOW
description: Now that the Presidential election is over, Americans can at last return to business and politics as usual. Among the pressing issues at hand, few things are more important than relations with the Soviet Union. What's more, for the first time since the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in December 1979, there are tentative signs of improvement in the American-Soviet relationship.

title: Of Books That Wiggle
description: ''A pop-up is exactly what we stand

title: CITY BOARD ASKS COMPUTER SETUP FOR '88 ELECTION
description: The New York City Board of Elections, facing increasing pressure to modernize its operations, hopes to introduce a new computer system for voting and record-keeping in time for the 1988 Presidential election, according to the board's president.

title: Coleman Gets a New Kidney
description: The television actor Gary Coleman, who underwent his second kidney transplant operation Saturday, was reported in satisfactory condition today at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center. Mr. Coleman, who is 16 years old, stars in the series ''Diff'rent Strokes'' on NBC. He had been undergoing dialysis for 18 months, since a kidney that he received in a transplant operation when he was 5 failed. Larry Goldman, Mr. Coleman's publicist, said the actor was expected to be away from the show for about a month.

title: Plan Would Oust Unruly Students
description: The State Commissioner of Education said today his department is planning a $1 million pilot program to remove disruptive students from high school classrooms.

title: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS VIETNAM MEMORIAL
description: President Reagan formally accepted the privately financed Vietnam Veterans memorial for the nation today, calling it a symbol of healing.

title: MUSIC: ESTRELLA, PIANIST
description: Miguel Angel Estretta TRELLA is an Argentine pianist who found his career in the 1970's more and more wrapped up with political activism. He played to the urban poor, to agricultural laborers, to informal audiences outdoors, with a leftist, Peronist message. In post- Peronist years he paid a harrowing price. In December of 1977 he was abducted from his home in Uruguay, where he had moved to teach and play after pressure on him in his homeland mounted. He was tortured and interrogated, and sent to the Libertad Prison; there he stayed until 1980, when a campaign that had enlisted the support of Leonard Bernstein, Yehudi Menuhin, Nadia Boulanger and others won his freedom.

title: POLICE TURN BACK WARSAW MARCHERS
description: Phalanxes of riot policemen, backed up with water cannons, blocked several thousand marchers here tonight as they sought to place wreaths at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier on the 66th anniversary of Poland's independence.

title: CUT IN HELIPORT FLIGHTS IS SOUGHT ON EAST SIDE
description: Some residents of the Upper East Side and Roosevelt Island are hoping that city officials will seek a reduction in helicopter traffic at the East 60th Street Metroport in exchange for allowing construction of a new hotel directly to the south.

title: Election Advice
description: Mayor Koch's letter endorsing Andrew J. Stein for Congress was effusive.

title: Outboard Marine Corp. Chooses New President
description: James C. Chapman has been named president and chief operating officer of the Outboard Marine Corporation, the company announced.

title: BOWL PICTURE BRIGHT FOR SOUTH CAROLINA
description: South Carolina, one of the few recent major college teams to go unbeaten and untied through nine games, still needed some help to open the doors to the Orange Bowl or another New Year's Day bowl game.

title: INNOVATIONS SPUR BOOM IN VCR SALES
description: Sales of video cassette recorders, already booming as prices drop, are getting an additional push this year from two major innovations: stereo sound and the ''camcorder'' - a lightweight, hand-held, battery-powered camera/recorder combination.

title: Lendl Trounces Gomez in Final
description: Ivan Lendl unleashed 12 aces today, including four in a row once, and defeated Andres Gomez, 7-6, 6-2, 6-1, today in the final of a $250,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament at Wembley Arena.

title: Recital Series to Feature Young Instrumentalists
description: A four-part series to showcase young instrumentalists at Carnegie Recital Hall begins Nov. 19, with a recital by the bass clarinetist Dennis Smylie. Mr. Smylie is a member of the American Symphony Orchestra and the chamber group Parnassus.

title: Vector Graphics Loss
description: Vector Graphics Inc., once one of the fastest-growing microcomputer companies, has reported a loss of $1.9 million for the quarter ended Sept. 29, compared with a loss of $701,000 in the comparable period of 1983.

title: Ill Tunisian Leader Gaining
description: The condition of Tunisia's 81-year-old President, Habib Bourguiba, who was hospitalized a week ago, continues to improve, a medical bulletin said today. The bulletin, signed by three doctors, said Mr. Bourguiba ''passed a good night'' and this morning saw Prime Minister Mohamed Mazli for a briefing on national affairs. Mr. Bourguiba entered the hospital last Monday with heart trouble.

title: THE BUCK DOESN'T STOP
description: BOSTON A secret agency that carries out war,

title: MEMBERS OF PANEL SPAN RANGE OF EXPERIENCE
description: The panel members who wrote the Pastoral Letter on Catholic Social Teaching and the United States Economy have no formal background in economics. But they have served in parishes and dioceses that spanned a wide range of economic conditions, from the rural Middle West to the urban East.

title: Allan Miller to Head Hebrew Arts School
description: Allan Miller will become president of the Hebrew Arts School on Jan. 1, succeeding Dr. Tzipora H. Jochsberger, who founded the school and directed it for 32 years.

title: Scouts Order New Tests For Dioxin at Camp Site
description: The Boy Scouts have arranged for tests at a Virginia Army post where 32,000 Boy Scouts camped in 1981 near dioxin contamination. In addition, an official said today, the Scouts still planned their jamboree there in 1985.

title: Washington Watch; Hardliners Cite Soviet Threat
description: WASHINGTON

title: Amy Friedman Weds Mitchell E. Radin, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Amy Janine Friedman, a daughter of Selma M. Friedman of Brooklyn and the late Harold I. Friedman, to Mitchell E. Radin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwin S. Radin of Fayetteville, N.Y., took place yesterday. Rabbi David Halpern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Peres Wants Mubarak To Meet Him for Talks
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said tonight that he had invited President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to meet him at the Israeli-Egyptian border to discuss ways to improve relations between their countries.

title: FAIR-TAX PARADOX
description: To the Editor:

title: SONIC BOOMS SHAKE CITIES IN NICARAGUA FOR THE FOURTH DAY
description: More sonic booms shook Nicaraguan cities today in what diplomats saw as a continuing effort by the United States to exert psychological pressure on the Government.

title: SWINGING THE CLUB
description: WASHINGTON People with faint hearts and weak stomachs should not watch sausages being made or the Republicans in the United States Senate choosing a new majority leader.

title: Latin Debtors Bar O.A.S. Bid BRASILIA, Nov. 11 (Reuters) - Latin America's 11
description: most indebted nations met today to prepare for their next

title: Singled Out
description: Federal Express enjoys a reputation for reliable overnight delivery of letters and parcels virtually anywhere in the United States. But in recent years, the company now acknowledges, that hasn't included the Bedford-Stuyvesant community of Brooklyn.

title: Ronald Allan Grobel and Margo L. Greene Marry
description: The marriage of Margo Lynn Greene, an assistant for research in biophysics at Rockefeller University, and Ronald Allan Grobel, a vice president in the bond portfolio analysis group at Salomon Brothers, took place yesterday at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi Seth Bernstein officiated.

title: EXECUTIVE SEARCHERS AID JAPAN JOB SHIFTS
description: The business manuals may still call this the land of lifetime employment, a place where children are reared to believe they will grow up and grow old in the sheltering arms of one company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A FANATIC HEART. Selected Stories of Edna O'Brien. With a foreword by Philip Roth. 461 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: People
description: * Charles Walsh and Elaine Reiss have been elected executive vice presidents of Ogilvy & Mather, U.S.

title: MEANWHILE, BACK AT THE RANCH
description: The spoils of victory for the second Reagan Administration may be nothing fancy. They may be as simple and priceless as the days that pass here in a pristine mix of oceanfront blue, vineyard green and the mauve of the California chaparral. For, fast as a landslide, the re-elected President's scheduled time here at his beloved ranch retreat is quietly being extended.

title: Making of Midtown: The Woman's Touch
description: Women have helped change the face of New York in the last three decades, designing buildings, graphics and sculptures that are part of the cityscape.

title: THE TECHNOLOGY EXISTS TO ELIMINATE DIOXIN EMISSIONS NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: OILERS BACK UP THEIR SWAGGERING STYLE
description: They had acquired a reputation around the National Hockey League as cocky rogues, overly impressed with everything about themselves, from their hockey skills to their haberdashery. The Edmonton Oilers had an image as the team that was sassy to airline stewardesses and smug to opponents, the team that always cruised into town with more than a bit of a swagger - and until this year, the team that always got its comeuppance in the playoffs.

title: BRAZIL'S PLAN FOR RESCHEDULING DEBT
description: Brazil will seek to postpone repayment of $49.3 billion in foreign credits coming due over the next five years when it meets its principal creditors in New York this week, according to Brazilian officials.

title: Bridge:U.S. and Polish Teams Win At World Team Olympiad
description: The two- week World Team Olympiad has ended here in victories for the United States and Poland, achieved in markedly different fashions.

title: A GEORGIA DYNAMO IN 'FIRECRACKER'
description: ''I'm itty,'' says Holly Hunter in her Georgia twang. ''It was itty, too.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 12 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MUSIC: JEAN REDPATH, SCOTTISH TRADITIONAL SINGER
description: In her purity of line, precision of

title: International Festival Honors 4 Agencies
description: Chiat/Day was on the winners' platform again Friday night at the International Film and TV Festival at the Sheraton Centre. But this time it had to share the limelight with the J. Walter Thompson Company, each agency taking five awards.

title: 1 Dead and 11 Hurt In Jersey CrashEAST WINDSOR, N.J., Nov. 11 (UPI) - A Brooklyn man was killed and at least 11 other people were injured in a six-car chain-reaction accident on the New Jersey Turnpike early today, the state police said.
description: The accident occurred at about 1:30 A.M. in the northbound lanes of the turnpike in East Windsor Township, in Mercer County, said Sgt. Ken Richter of the state police.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Is there anyone closing in on Lou Gehrig's record for grand slams in a career?

title: U.S. OIL REFINERS IN SQUEEZE
description: American oil refiners are having a terrible year, squeezed by flagging demand, excess capacity, new overseas refineries and a rise in imports of gasoline and heating oil.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 12, 1984: MONDAY Amer Brdcstg CosGifford-Hills & CoCompugraphic CorpMeredith CorpFischbach CorpZurn Ind TUESDAY AMF IncMickelberry CorpFoote Cone & BeldRobertson (H H) CoHeileman (G) BrewSears Roebuck & CoHousehold IntlStaley (AE) MfgInter North IncTracor IncMcCermott IntlTyco Labs WEDNESDAY Avnet IncMorse ShoeCBS IncNatl StandardCSX CorpRealty Refund TrColt IndusSafeguard Business SysCurrent Income ShsU S Air groupLouisiana Genl Svc

title: A BREATH OF FRESH AIR FROM CALVIN KLEIN AND RALPH LAUREN
description: It is strange to consider Calvin Klein avant- garde since his clothes are not designed to shock. He made his mark in fashion in the late 1960's with calm, well-tailored coats, at a time when the miniskirt was rampant and blue jeans and T-shirts reflected the anti-establishment spirit of the time.

title: Company to Broaden Homosexual Campaign
description: Christopher Street Financial at 80 Wall Street, named for a Greenwich Village area popular with the city's homosexuals, was founded three years ago as a financial services company for that segment of the population. Until now, according to Robert Casaletto, its president, it has advertised only in The Native and The Advocate, publications intended for homosexuals, and in programs for cultural events intended for homosexual audiences.

title: MUSIC: JOHN WYRE'S 'CONNEXUS' BY PHILHARMONIC
description: The current New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall, the final installment of which can be heard tomorrow night at 7:30, offers a sweet piece of contemporary music that serves to break down several overly rigid categorizations.

title: JAPAN GAIN REPORTED IN COMPUTERS
description: The first stage of Japan's ambitious 10-year project to build a new kind of computer enabled the Japanese to catch up with research in other countries but resulted in no scientific breakthroughs, according to interviews with more than a dozen American and European scientists here.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Bally Manufacturing Corp., a Chicago-based manufacturer of coin-operated amusement and gaming machines, said its Six Flags Corp. subsidiary is offering $125 million of debentures due 1999 and priced at $1,000 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Mr. Bell's Legacy to Education
description: In one sense, Terrel Bell, who is resigning as Secretary of Education, should be rated a dismal failure: He was unable to make good on his boss's 1980 campaign promise to abolish the Department of Education. In fact, despite President Reagan's repeated efforts to cut Federal aid, education is enjoying a ''renaissance,'' as Mr. Bell noted in announcing his departure. And if he was a loyal Administration player on stage, he also worked behind the scenes to defend the Federal role in education against zealots bent on crippling it.

title: FIRE IN CONNECTICUT KILLS 8 AS HEAT THWARTS RESCUERS
description: Eight people, including five children, died in a fire that destroyed a three-story frame house in Waterbury, Conn., early yesterday, fire officials said.

title: Blue Is Pitching In Puerto Rico
description: Vida Blue, the former All-Star pitcher who pleaded guilty last year to drug charges, has begun a comeback attempt in the Puerto Rico Winter League.

title: Futures/Options; Big Shifts In Money Markets
description: ONE of the startling developments in the financial futures markets this year has been the dramatic shriveling of trading activity in the domestic 90-day bank certificates of deposit and the concomitant surge in volume of Eurodollar futures. Both futures are traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Kimberly-Clark Forms Top Office
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation has announced a major restructuring of its management and operations.

title: Nancy Strickman Weds B. H. Stein
description: Nancy Ann Strickman, a research analyst at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and Bradley Harris Stein, an associate in the New York law firm of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh, were married last evening at the Rainbow Grill in Rockefeller Center by Rabbi Roger Herst.

title: F.B.I. Gets Order For Hair Samples
description: A Federal judge has ruled that investigators can take handwriting and hair samples from five suspected radicals, including one arrested in the slaying of a New Jersey state trooper.

title: Ireland Hunts Woman Linked to Bombings
description: The Irish police have begun searching for a woman sought by Britain in connection with a series of Irish Republican Army bombings. But today Irish authorities accused Scotland Yard of hampering the search by divulging the suspect's name to newspapers.

title: Conservators and Cronies
description: When a New York judge removed John Zaccaro as conservator for an incompetent widow because he'd borrowed her funds for a real estate deal, there was reason to hope for reform at last. This highly publicized case in Queens, involving the husband of Geraldine Ferraro, might finally force a change in an appointment system that too often rewards cronies and relatives. The state's five highest ranking jurists, constituting an administrative board, promptly met to see what might be done.

title: Florida Drops Review Of Private Citrus Trees
description: State agriculture officials suspended plans to inspect citrus trees in backyards in their search for the source of a deadly canker disease threatening the state's $2.5 billion citrus industry.

title: FAILED FAIR GIVES NEW ORLEANS A PAINFUL HANGOVER
description: The bankrupt 1984 World's Fair closed and sadly began sweeping up the trash tonight after a disastrous six-month run.

title: U.S. AIDES SPLIT ON PLAN TO PRESS THE SANDINISTAS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials appeared to differ today on whether new military and diplomatic measures were being considered to counter what the Administration says is an increased flow of Soviet-bloc arms into Nicaragua.

title: A STRUGGLER FOR DIGNITY
description: Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee remembers vividly how his economic sensibilities were shaped by his Depression childhood.

title: 14 Hotels in Philippines Will Search Guests
description: Fourteen tourist hotels have agreed to search the luggage and handbags of all guests and to make quick searches of everyone who enters their lobbies following a series of fires that killed 40 people, including 13 foreigners, a hotel official said today.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS ASK VAST CHANGES IN ECONOMY OF U.S.
description: Calling for ''a new commitment to economic justice,'' a committee of Roman Catholic bishops today issued a first draft of a pastoral letter that proposes sweeping changes to help the poor.

title: Linda Berman Is Married to Robert S. Weisbein
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday Linda Carole Berman and Robert Steven Weisbein, graduates of the Emory University School of Law, were married by Rabbi Philmore Berger, assisted by Cantor David Weg.

title: BLACK YOUTH SLAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 11 (Reuters) - An 18-year-old black youth died today after he was shot when a black policeman opened fire on a mob attacking his house as rioting, looting and arson continued across South Africa, a police spokesman said.
description: About 200 blacks stormed the house of the black policeman who shot the youth, the police said. Attacks were also reported on other black local officials, who are often singled out by rioters as agents of the white minority Government.

title: SENDS DUKE TO SAY SO
description: His Royal Highness Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg - he has nine other given names and is also Duke of Nassau and Prince of Bourbon Parma - is head of state of what is arguably Europe's most unabashedly pro-American country.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DRAWING CARD The illustrator, an artist who is usually assigned to create art for a specific purpose, such as accompaniment to text in a book, an advertisement or magazine story, is somehow often overlooked when it comes to creating pantheons of painters and other picture makers. This is something that the Society of Illustrators, at 128 East 63d Street (838-2560), has naturally been seeking to correct, and its big new show should go a long way to getting the idea across that good illustration can be good art.

title: David Hillel Ebstein Marries Rena Magun
description: Rena Faye Magun, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Magun of Oaklyn, N.J., and David Hillel Ebstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Ebstein of Highland Park, Ill., were married yesterday. Rabbis William Lebeau, Michael A. Monson and Albert Lewis officiated at Congregation Beth El in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Advertising; Cinematic Tack for Wrangler
description: IF you wanted to reach the 12-to-34

title: DAMASCUS WARNS THE P.L.O. NOT TO HOLD TALKS IN JORDAN
description: Syria has warned the Palestine Liberation Organization against holding a meeting of its government in exile here later this month.

title: BRONCOS WIN WITH 0:38 LEFT
description: Sammy Winder's 1-yard plunge with 38 seconds left capped a 77-yard drive that lifted the Denver Broncos to a 16- 13 victory over the San Diego Chargers today.

title: JAZZ: RICHARD LANDRY IMPROVISES 2 FORMS FOR SAXOPHONE
description: Richard Landry shaped a small stock of raw materials into two different forms Saturday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. From short, modal melodies, trills and the arpeggio figures he used to play with the Philip Glass Ensemble, he built a 70- minute, electronically assisted tenor saxophone solo and a jazzy improvisation for two saxophonists, two singers and two percussionists.

title: Sudie Bond, an ActressIn Films, TV and Stage
description: Sudie Bond, the movie, television and stage actress currently appearing at the Astor Place Theater in ''The Foreigner,'' was found dead in her apartment Saturday. She was 56 years old and lived on Manhattan's East Side.

title: DESERTERS RETURN TO SOVIET FROM LONDON
description: Two Soviet soldiers who came to Britain after deserting from their military unit in Afghanistan returned to the Soviet Union today.

title: Whither Deaver?
description: For most of the first term of the

title: JERSEY BALLOT ISSUE WON WITH WRONG QUESTION
description: It was just a little mistake, a few extra phrases in the fine print about refinancing old bonds. But the wrong words somehow found their way onto the ballot in New Jersey last week and - as any parodist might have predicted - they won by a landslide.

title: Wendy Lipkind Weds Hillel Black, Publisher
description: Wendy Diane Lipkind, a literary agent, and Hillel Black, publisher of the adult general books division of the Macmillan Publishing Company, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: FLYERS STOP OILERS
description: Despite two goals by Wayne Gretzky, the Philadelphia Flyers downed the Edmonton Oilers, 7-5, tonight and ended their record season-opening unbeaten streak at 15 games. Brian Propp and Jari Kurri scored twice for the victors. Edmonton, which has not beaten the Flyers in six games over two seasons, now has a 12-1-3 record. On Friday night, the Oilers beat the Washington Capitals to break the previous National Hockey League mark of 14 set by Montreal in the 1943-1944 season.

title: POLICY RIFF ON NICARAGUA
description: The stir last week over the possible delivery of advanced Soviet fighter planes to Nicaragua marked a new phase in a policy struggle within the Reagan Administration over whether the United States can accept the existence of a Nicaragua aligned with the Soviet Union and Cuba. Administration officials said this policy fight might ultimately settle the issue, which has defied resolution over the last four years because divisions within the Government prevented agreement on what some have called ''a bottom line'' for United States policy toward Nicaragua.

title: TESTS MAKE NIAGARA FALLS RECALL FEARS OF LOVE CANAL
description: To the people who live in the grimy industrial neighborhood on the east side of town, across the street from one of the most active toxic waste dumps in the East, it seemed all too familiar.

title: Once More, the Budget
description: -making progress on the 1986 budget that President Reagan will submit to Congress in January, suspended to avoid embarrassing leaks in the political campaign, will finally resume today. Ordinarily the Office of Management and Budget would have been back at the drawing board immediately after the election, but David A. Stockman, the director, flew to the Virgin Islands for one of his rare vacations, and he is described by associates as ''so central to the process'' that the machinery will not really grind into motion until his return today.

title: TAX RISE IS PROPOSED TO EASE ERIE COUNTY FISCAL PROBLEMS
description: The Erie County Executive, faced with a serious fiscal crisis, has proposed a budget for 1985 that would increase sales and property taxes substantially and eliminate more than 300 county jobs.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DRAFT OF BISHOPS' LETTER ON THE U.S. ECONOMY
description: Following are excerpts from a 120- page draft of the ''Pastoral Letter on Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy.''

title: Market Place; The Rate Bulls Vs. Profit Bears
description: THE stock market has been engaged in one of

title: Amy Adelson Marries
description: Amy Star Adelson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Adelson of New York, was married yesterday to Herman Glaswand, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mordechai Glaswand of Stuttgart, West Germany. Rabbi Joseph Singer performed the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof. The bride's father is vice president and director of sales of the Monarch Wine Company in New York.

title: LEMUEL BANNISTER Jr.
description: Lemuel Bannister Jr., a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Bannister, Stitt & Krause, died last Thursday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: PHILIP HOFER, 86, A BOOK COLLECTOR AT HARVARD
description: Philip Hofer, a book collector and former curator of printing and graphic arts at Harvard University, died Nov. 9 in his sleep at home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: DISCOVERY NEARS A STRAY SATELLITE
description: The space shuttle Discovery closed in on an errant satellite today as the astronauts prepared for one of the most complex operations of the shuttle program, the retrieval of a satellite for return to earth.

title: Whither Mondale?
description: There seems to be no rest for

title: BABY FAE APPEARS WELL AFTER FIRST SIGN OF REJECTING BABOON HEART
description: Baby Fae showed the first signs of rejecting her implanted baboon heart two days ago but now appears to be responding favorably, her doctors revealed today.

title: Jill Gerson, Martin Price Married in New Rochelle
description: At Temple Israel of New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday Jill Gerson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin C. Gerson of New York and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married to Martin L. Price, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jesse L. Price of Brooklyn.

title: No Headline
description: Terry Schoonover, making only his second start in a Nascar Grand National auto race, died after a crash during The Atlanta Journal 500 today.

title: Nigeria Will Recognize Western Sahara Rebels
description: Nigeria said today that it would recognize the rebel movement fighting Moroccan rule in Western Sahara, an issue crucial to the success or failure of the Organization of African Unity meeting opening here tomorrow.

title: BROOKLYN PARISHIONERS MOURN CHURCH'S RUIN
description: Members of the Janes United Methodist Church gathered yesterday to celebrate the 125th anniversary of their congregation. They crowded into their parsonage on Stuyvesant Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, but their hearts were a block away, where the church they had planned to honor was still smoldering from the fire that consumed it late Saturday night.

title: A CALL FOR ECONOMIC CHANGE BADRF ON MORAL VIEW
description: The pastoral letter on the economy made public yesterday by a panel of Roman Catholic bishops sternly criticizes many current policies and recommends measures that depart sharply from the Reagan Administration's economic philosophy. The bishops' letter argues that the level of inequality in income and wealth in the United States is morally unacceptable, and asserts that economic policies must be judged by their effect on the poor.

title: JETS BEATEN BY COLTS
description: The Giants found prosperity too much to handle today. After keeping the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in check for two and a half quarters, they allowed the Bucs to score 17 points in 15 minutes and earn a 20-17 victory.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Most of all we are concerned how our economic decisions affect the poor.

title: ISRAELIS PROPOSE A LEBANON TRUCE TO MOSLEM MILITIA
description: Israel responded today to Lebanon's suspension of troop withdrawal talks by offering to begin a cease-fire in south Lebanon with the Shiite Moslem militia there.

title: SALVADORAN FOES WILL DEBATE IN U.S.
description: In an unexpected development, senior Salvadoran Government and leftist rebel officials have agreed to meet in Los Angeles this week for a public debate on the prospects for peace in El Salvador.

title: Pakistan Regime Again Vows To Hold Elections by March
description: Pakistan's military Government today repeated its pledge to hold national elections by next March.

title: WESTERN JOURNAL ; THEY RELY ON WATER OR STEAM
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein's all-out campaign to persuade the Navy to pick San Francisco as the home port of the U.S.S. Missouri has run into resistance from some other local politicians and opponents of nuclear weapons.

title: Stars 7, Leafs 6
description: Dennis Maruk got two goals, including the 300th of his career, to pace the victory. He notched the game-winner at 16:17 of the third period to quell a Leaf rally and give Minnesota only its second victory in 12 games. Toronto has not won in eight.

title: TAX CODE CHANGE WILL RAISE SOME TAX BILLS, SENATORS SAY
description: Two Republican Senators, Bob Dole of Kansas and Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, predicted today that Congress would alter the tax code in a way that would increase tax payments for some Americans.

title: PRESSURE FOR DEATH PENALTY GROWS IN CANADA
description: Public sentiment in Canada for reinstating capital punishment for at least some crimes appears to be rapidly mounting after the killings of six policemen this year.

title: The Great Beer War
description: Hockey's great beer war may be coming to a head. According to Gil Stein, the general counsel of the National Hockey League, a judge in Chicago is expected to rule within a month on the league's request for a declaratory judgment upholding the right of the 14 American teams and the Quebec Nordiques to telecast their home games in Canada.

title: Volcker Remark Reviewed
description: When Paul A. Volcker was nominated by President Reagan in mid-1983 for a second four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, he told the Senate that he might not serve out the full four years.

title: Gabrielle Lansner, Dancer, Is Married to Elliot Caplan
description: At the Jewish Center in New York yesterday Gabrielle Elizabeth Lansner, a dancer and choreographer, was married to Elliot Caplan, a film maker.

title: Colombia Coffee Losses
description: Heavy rain has ruined 30 percent of Colombia's coffee crop and caused losses of $200 million, industry officials said today. Directors of the four main coffee-producing areas said the recent rain had affected plants that would have been harvested in March, April and May.

title: GROUNDED AIRLINE'S BOARD NAMES NEW CHAIRMAN IN REORGANIZATION
description: The board of Provincetown-Boston Airline named a new chairman yesterday and said a team of consultants had flown to the company's Naples, Fla. headquarters to rewrite training manuals. The moves are part of a reorganization designed to return the grounded airline to operation.

title: OUTDOORS: PACKING UP TACKLE
description: This is perhaps the most propitious time for those who live in the Northeast to attend to fishing gear that lies where it was tossed on the day the last cast was made. This is not to say that, for all anglers in the region, their sport is over for the year. In the ocean, bluefish and striped bass are still about and codfishing never seems to end, and in some states one may go after such species as black bass, yellow perch and lake trout through this month and more. There are also, of course, certain trout streams, such as the no-kill sections of the Beaverkill and Willowemoc in the Catskills, where one may fish year-round. All I am suggesting is that, if one is truly done with angling for the season, one should pay proper attention to his gear. Some anglers don't quit until the season for the species sought has closed, or, as in the case of the bluefish and striped bass, until the fish have moved away. Others follow a self-imposed closure schedule. I stop in late October, preferably after a particularly successful morning or evening so that I can savor my recollection of that time in the frozen months ahead. This ritual is sometimes difficult to honor, as it was the past few days, when friends persisted in telling me of the superlative surf fishing for striped bass that was less than 20 miles from my home.

title: Baldwin-United
description: Citing the need for urgency, a Federal judge has rejected appeals and given the Baldwin-United Corporation permission to sell 19 Colorado banks to the Ameritrust Corporation of Cleveland. ''Time is of the essence,'' United States District Judge David S. Porter said after denying stays of execution of the sales. Baldwin-United, based in Cincinnati, is selling off assets while trying to reorganize under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: A BREATHER FOR NEW TREASURY ISSUES
description: An abundant supply of all kinds of bonds exists, with record or near record amounts of financings during the last month in the Treasury, municipal and corporate sectors.

title: 11 Children in Commune Removed by Oregon
description: A state agency investigating ''threatening'' living conditions at a commune has removed 11 children to foster homes, officials said Saturday.

title: Ford Workers in Canada Vote to Accept Contract
description: About 14,200 workers at Ford Motor Company of Canada voted overwhelmingly today to ratify a three-year contract, heading off a general strike against the company's nine Ontario plants, union spokesmen said.

title: A Bettor's Dream
description: Can you think of one good reason why horse-racing fans shouldn't be able to sit back in the cozy comfort of their living rooms watching live telecasts of an evening's card and placing bets by telephone right up to post time?

title: EVALUATING TELECOM'S OUTLOOK
description: Potential investors will learn on Friday how much it will cost to buy a piece of British Telecom P.L.C., the world's fourth-largest telephone enterprise. The British Government will sell control of the company to the private sector on Nov. 28.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1984

title: Hollywood East
description: The Oscar ceremony, which runs

title: A Canadian Reporter Is Arrested in Amritsar
description: A Canadian reporter has been arrested near the Golden Temple while interviewing residents about the Indian Army's assault on the Sikhs' holiest shrine in June, the police said today.

title: FRANCE'S NUCLEAR CUTBACKS
description: The French Government is taking an ax to its nuclear power program - the most ambitious in the world - because the country's appetite for electricity is growing less than planners had hoped.

title: OPERA: AT THE KENNEDY, 'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO'
description: ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' traditionally fights its domestic guerrilla war with good humor and a sense of the absurd - weapons that jab at the servant- master relationship without ever engaging it in frontal combat.

title: BRITISH COAL MINERS BATTLE AS STRIKE WEAKENS
description: Thousands of striking coal miners armed with firebombs and homemade spears fought with the police in northern England and Wales today while hundreds more broke ranks and returned to work. The police said 54 people were injured in one of the worst nights of violence so far.

title: ;  A Coach's Concern
description: Injuries to college football players are reaching epidemic dimensions, according to Coach Hayden Fry of Iowa, who says the reason is that improvements in protective equipment have not kept pace with the increased size and strength of today's athletes.

title: ;  Eagles Staying Put
description: Susan Fletcher, the Philadelphia Eagles' vice president and general counsel, confirmed that she and her father, Leonard Tose , were negotiating to sell a share of the team.

title: Vandals Spray Memorial To Victims of the Nazis
description: A sculpture memorial to the victims of the Nazi holocaust was sprayed with paint less than a week after it was unveiled, according to the police.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. The company is in transition from a fiscal year ending Oct. 31 to a calendar year and therefore the results for the latest and year-ago periods are for two months.

title: FOUR MORE YEARS
description: PARIS Now foreign leaders are asking where President Reagan wants to take U.S. policy in four more years. There have been important changes in the world since he first moved into the White House, bringing new opportunities for U.S. initiative, new problems and new approaches to old problems. The period between elections and the inauguration should be a time for reviewing what the old assumptions produced and trying to learn some lessons for the future, not just plunging on in the euphoria of landslide.

title: GRIM OUTLOOK FOR HUNGRY MOZAMBIQUE
description: In Inhaouza, a village on a dirt track even bumpier than the main track leading out of this provincial capital, Graca Alfandega said, ''Hunger has already entered this house.''

title: A SALESMAN ABROAD:KOCH CHARMS MADRID WHILE GETTING A TASTE FOR EELS
description: Mayor Koch, extolling the virtues of New York City with his own irrepressible brand of salesmanship, lectured students and entertained crowds here today.

DESPITE THIN CROWDS, GENERATIONS OF VETERANS MARCH IN PRIDE
description: Patriotism reached across the years yesterday as veterans from the world wars and the Korean War marched alongside veterans from the Vietnam War and shared the loneliness of the sparse crowds that greeted their parade down Fifth Avenue.

title: U.S. AND IRAQ REPORTED READY TO RENEW TIES AFTER 17 YEARS
description: The United States and Iraq have agreed to announce the restoration of diplomatic relations next Monday, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: ;  Duriel Harris Waived
description: Duriel Harris was waived by the Cleveland Browns yesterday because Coach Marty Schottenheimer thought the 29-year-old veteran wide receiver ''was not making the contribution to our football team he was supposed to make'' and also dropped ''several key passes.'' . . . Nolan Cromwell , four times an all-pro as a safety for the Los Angeles Rams, is out for the season after suffering ligament damage in his right knee.

title: RICKOVER: STILL FEISTY
description: THE Center for Defense Information keeps a watchful eye on military spending, policies and weapons systems, and it imported a living legend for its annual New York luncheon. Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, father of the nuclear navy, scourge of military inefficiency and waste, and as crusty an 84- year-old as you're likely to encounter, was the speaker.

description: The shape of President Reagan's second term in office will be greatly influenced by what he concludes and says over the next few weeks.

description: -Operating earnings c-Net income.

title: 2 SEIZED IN SICILY IN DRIVE ON MAFIA
description: Two leading Sicilian businessmen were arrested today in a continuing drive against organized crime in Sicily. The drive has been spurred in part by the confessions of Tommaso Buscetta, a former Mafia leader.

title: Advertising; Election A Salute To Coast
description: At the beginning of its 75th annual meeting here this morning, the Association of National Advertisers rather symbolically elected Spencer C. Boise of Mattel chairman, the organization's first leader from the West Coast.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL WARNS OF POSSIBLE ATTACKS
description: A top Nicaraguan rebel leader asserted today that if the Sandinistas began using a type of Soviet attack helicopters that he said had been sent recently, the insurgents would respond by attacking ''strategic targets.''

title: Steel Output Rises by 1.2% By The Associated Press Steel production rose to 1.469
description: million tons in the week ended

title: A Serious Landmark Question
description: New York's Landmarks Commission today considers a long-avoided suggestion that it recognize historic value in a convent on Manhattan's Upper East Side. But the convent has no genuine claim to be a landmark. It is an undistinguished work by a 19th-century German-American designer of ecclesiastical buildings, William Schickel, whose better works already are landmarks.

description: TRIBUTE TO WILLIAMS

description: President Reagan's top economic and political advisers agree that he should seek deep domestic spending cuts, despite the likelihood that Congress will reject them, key Administration officials said today.

description: The lightly filtered mouthpiece

title: VIETNAM VETERANS TURN TO THERAPY
description: THE arrival of Veterans Day seems to trigger the onset or return of mental problems among a growing number of Vietnam veterans, the legacy of unresolved emotional difficulties that stem from hostilities that ended more than a dozen years ago, according to doctors who have been monitoring such cases.

title: SURPRISING HEALTH IMPACT DISCOVERED FOR LIGHT
description: FROM now until Dec. 21, residents of the northern latitudes will experience a continuous decrease in a substance that has recently been shown to counter depression, increase alertness, inhibit sleepiness and perhaps stimulate sexual reproduction. That substance is sunlight, worshiped by people since earliest times for reasons that science is just now beginning to understand and extend.

CHESS MATCH: A DRAW AGAIN
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played to a 22-move draw today in the 23d game of their world chess championship match. It was the 14th consecutive draw of the match, extending the record for world title play.

title: SHOULD SMOKING RESTRICTIONS BE WRITTEN INTO LAW?
description: Are there any legitimate rules about nonsmokers telling smokers when and where to smoke, ''Gentle Reader'' asks Miss Manners in her ''Guide to Excruciatingly Correct Behavior''?

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3,315,000 for the quarter and $3,564,000 for the 9 months.

title: Rita C. Davidson Dies at 56; A Judge in Maryland Courts
description: Judge Rita Charmatz Davidson, the first woman to serve on the Maryland Court of Appeals, died Sunday in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: E.E.C. Bond Issue in U.S.
description: The European Economic Community's commission said today that it had filed a registration statement with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission for a planned $150 million European Currency Unit bond issue to be floated on the American market later this year.

title: No Headline
description: National Symphony Launches Fund Drive

title: JAMES GARNER STARS IN TV DRAMA
description: ''The Glitter Dome,'' a melodrama about the seamy side of the movie business made for Home Box Office, reflects the sentiments of Joseph Wambaugh, the author of the novel, who has frequently expressed his displeasure over the way Hollywood has treated his books and marketed his movies.

title: MUSIC: ENSEMBLE IN FESTIVAL BENELUX

title: STAUB BECOMES A FREE AGENT
description: Rusty Staub became a free agent yesterday when he refused to accept assignment to the Mets' minor league roster. But the Mets invited him to spring training, and the 40-year-old pinch-hitter said he would go if he had not signed with another club by then.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS STOCK DROP
description: Shares of the Federal Express Corporation fell sharply in very heavy trading yesterday after the company announced that it was cutting the price of its Zapmail electronic mail service to try to stimulate demand for the service.

title: NOW, GLITTER IN THE SUMMER
description: Sequins for summer? The answer is a resounding yes. Just as linen and satin have slipped into the category of year-round materials, so sequins and beads are as likely to turn up in warm-weather collections as they are in clothes destined for midwinter festivities.

title: LONDON HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MOROCCO QUITS O.A.U. OVER POLISARIO
description: Morocco, a founding member of the Organization of African Unity, quit the organization today over the seating of guerrillas who are fighting the Moroccans in Western Sahara.

description: A carelessly discarded cigarette apparently caused the fire Sunday that killed eight people in a three-family house, city authorities said today.

description: Heublein, a wine and spirits marketer based in Farmington, Conn., and a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, announced yesterday that it had assigned its Harveys Bristol Cream and Harveys line of sherry imports to DYR.

NEW CERAMIC COMPOUNDS SET FOR MAJOR TECHNOLOGY ROLE
description: OVER the course of a decade chemists have learned to blend, beat and bake different kinds of ceramic compounds into materials that are stronger than steel, hard as diamonds, and tough enough to take the heat of a blast furnace.

title: WHAT THE SIKHS OF THE PUNJAB WANT
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT THE GLASS MAY HOLD FOR '88
description: Timing is everything in life. This is especially true in politics, where the prize goes to the person who best foresees the circumstances under which he will be running and then patiently bends that reality to his own will until he becomes the right man, in the right place, at the right time. Last Wednesday morning, the political clock was reset and now some politicians will be turning their thoughts to what circumstances will prevail in 1988 when we have a new President.

title: Transactions
description: Announced that Rusty Staub, pinch-hitter, had chosen to become free agent rather than report to Class AAA Tidewater farm. Added seven players to roster: Ronn Reynolds, catcher; Dave Cochrane, infielder; Randy Myers, Bill Latham, Roger McDowell, Jeff Bettendorf and Floyd Youmans, pitchers.

title: A DIAMOND MAVERICK'S WAR WITH THE CLUB ON 47TH STREET
description: Martin Rapaport talks about free trade and the First Amendment, but finally it comes down to simple geography. ''Forty-Seventh Street has to recognize that it's in America,'' he says.

title: GENERAL STRIKE STARTS IN LEBANON IN PROTEST AGAINST ISRAELI ARRESTS
description: A general strike began in southern Lebanon today to protest arrests of Shiite Moslem militia leaders by Israeli troops. The Lebanese Government cited the arrests in its decision Saturday to suspend negotiations on the withdrawal of Israeli troops.

description: To the Editor:

title: ARTIST FOR CRACKER JACK DIES
description: -C. Carey Cloud, an artist who invented many of the prizes in Cracker Jack boxes, died Friday at St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 85 years old. Mr. Cloud, in addition to creating the tops, stickers and other toys for the popcorn snack for 25 years, also designed pop-up books and puzzles and drew cartoons.

title: TRIAL IN SHARON LIBEL SUIT VS. TIME OPENS TODAY
description: A major American news organization detailed the purported misconduct of a prominent military leader in a far-off, unpopular war. The official said his reputation had been blackened by the charge, which he denied. So he filed a multimillion-dollar libel suit against the media giant in Federal court in Manhattan.

title: Lotus Software For Macintosh
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, as expected, introduced a software product that Apple Computer Inc. is counting on to help it sell its Macintosh machine to large corporations. Lotus, based in Cambridge, Mass., is a leading supplier of personal computer programs.

title: Bid by Lee Data
description: The Lee Data Corporation said it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the Visual Technology Corporation in a transaction valued at $16.8 million. The planned acquisition provides for the exchange of one-half share of Lee Data's common for each share of Visual's 4.9 million common shares outstanding. Visual has also granted Lee Data, a marketer of equipment, an option to purchase 1.4 million Visual shares at $2.75 each.

title: EXCESS ELECTRICITY TROUBLES ROCKIES
description: A stream of coal snakes its way into the boiler of Colstrip 3, the big new generating plant here. Smoke wafts from the high stack, and electricity crackles and hums in the transmission lines heading west.

title: DOWN TO THE DRAWING BOARD IN SHIPS
description: They have been a secret well-kept from most people for nearly 50 years, but Emily F. Whitney, Sidney O. Neff and Sarah B. Ridgeway are finally coming out of the closet.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1984

title: FESTIVE NIGHT FOR LIBRARY LIONS
description: The New York Public Library's famous pair of lions had company last night, 22 prominent authors who were honored as this year's pride of Literary Lions.

title: 2 ZIMBABWE OPPOSITION OFFICIALS DISMISSED
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe ousted the last two officials of the chief opposition party from his Cabinet today, virtually ending cooperation in the Government between the two parties.

title: GUERRILLAS' THREATS CRIPPLE ROAD TRAVEL IN MUCH OF SALVADOR
description: Leftist guerrillas crippled traffic across most of El Salvador today by threatening to destroy vehicles caught on the highways, the authorities said.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHAT was most striking about the American spring collections was the similarity of the clothes on the runways. If the designers have their way, it seems that women next spring will be wearing little more than long black skirts and white shirts.

title: Executive at Manville Promoted to President
description: John A. McKinney, who has been acting as chief executive, chairman and president of the Manville Corporation, yesterday announced that the president's position will be taken over on Dec. 1 by J.T. Hulce, a 42-year-old lawyer who has been one of the company's senior vice presidents for the last two years.

title: Market Place; Analysts Favor Military Stock
description: -quarter profits

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Performer's Legacy

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks, helped by a harassing defense, finally won a game Saturday night.

title: No Headline
description: Union Gets Playoff Berth KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) - Augustana College of Rock

title: Awry Computer Delays Racing
description: A computer malfunction caused severe delays in the card after the fifth race at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Greek Students Jeer At U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Hundreds of Greek students, chanting ''Reagan! Fascist! Murderer!'' rallied outside the gates of the United States Embassy tonight in a protest against what they called American imperialism.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Software Technology, Bay Harbor Island, Fla., said its board had approved the repurchase of up to 5 million common shares in the open market.

title: PROTECTING AGAINST SURGES
description: MOST computer manufacturers have designed their machines to guard against the common, everyday fluctuations that occur on power lines. Even so, some experts say, transients - sudden spikes or surges of voltage - can leap up the power cord and overwhelm a computer's built-in power protector. The damage may be swift and sudden, resulting in partial or total memory loss, garbled data or worse, or it may be subtle but cumulative, resulting in shorter computer life and high repair bills.

title: ;  Strike Bargaining Resumes at Yale
description: Yale University and the striking Local 34 of the Federation of University Employees resumed negotiations today for the first time since Oct. 9. The two sides are divided over wages, job security, health and dental benefits, and pensions.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1984 International Israeli officials expressed optimism that a formula could be worked out with Lebanon to allow troop withdrawal talks to resume tomorrow. But there was no sign from Beirut that the Lebanese would accept anything short of their original demand - that Israel free a group of Shiite Moslem militia leaders arrested in south Lebanon. (Page A1, Cols. 4-5.) Renewal of American-Iraqi ties will be announced Monday, according to Reagan Administration officials. Baghdad severed relations with Washington in 1967. (A14:3-4.)

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
That Manual's Real Damage
description: ''Neutralizing,'' it develops, means not murder but only removal from office, and ''removal'' from the C.I.A. of those who counsel murder in Nicaragua means only a reprimand. In plainer English, the Administration's creative semantics means stonewalling, to impede a vital inquiry into the means, ends and accountability of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: BEN LUCIEN BURMAN, 88, AUTHOR OF 22 BOOKS
description: Ben Lucien Burman, the author of 22 books, many of them affectionate portraits of the Mississippi and the Kentucky mountain region, died of a stroke yesterday in St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Shultz Soviet Trip Rumored
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz might visit the Kremlin in January for talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, the Yugoslav press agency reported from Moscow today. The report was attributed to ''well-informed Soviet circles.''

description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi pledged continuity tonight with the foreign and domestic policies of his grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru, and his mother, Indira Gandhi, who was assassinated 12 days ago.

description: By dawn, the junior sumo wrestlers had already started their workouts, slapping and pounding into each other behind a tarpaulin screen on the grounds of a Buddhist temple.

title: The Good News on Toxic Waste
description: After a landslide victory at the polls, President Reagan could very easily have vetoed a far-reaching bill on toxic waste disposal that awaited his signature - especially since the bill runs directly counter to his policies of decreasing regulation and delegating more power to the states. Mr. Reagan deserves credit for signing the bill into law despite his reservations.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Pro forma figures.

title: ;  Coetzee Hurt Again
description: Despite yet another injury to his right hand, Gerrie Coetzee, the World Boxing Association's heavyweight champion, will go ahead with plans to defend his title Dec. 1 against Greg Page. The champion hurt his right thumb while sparring three weeks ago and sprained it yesterday, again during a sparring session. Coetzee has now been advised by doctors to take a few days off from sparring.

title: 7 Killed by Fire in Taipei
description: A fire at a barbershop in downtown Taipei killed seven people today, the police reported. They said that five male customers and two women employees of the shop died from smoke inhalation and that another man suffered minor burns. About 20 people escaped from the blaze, firemen said.

title: ;  Milk Deliverers Continue Talks
description: Milk dealers and deliverers continued to negotiate yesterday as both sides sought to avoid a strike that could deprive much of the New York metropolitan area of fresh milk.

Employees at Mack Trucks Ratify New 3-Year Contract
description: The employees of Mack Trucks Inc. have ratified a three-year contract that ended a strike last month, the United Automobile Workers announced today.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $45,057 for the quarter and $45,595 for the 9 months.

title: APPLYING ROMAN CATHOLIC TRADITION TO U.S. ECONOMY
description: The Roman Catholic pastoral letter on the economy released Sunday by five American bishops is the first comprehensive attempt to apply a tradition from scripture, theology and papal pronouncements to the United States economy. The 120-page document is a first draft prepared by the bishops' committee and will undergo a year of discussion before it is voted on by American bishops. But it is already considered by many theologians to be one of the more significant pastoral letters in the history of the American church hierarchy.

title: OPERA: 'MERRY WIDOW' BY WASHINGTON TROUPE
description: The Washington Opera's new production of ''The Merry Widow'' could have claimed success Saturday night without playing a note of music. It is strikingly handsome to look at - vast, opulent and pleasing to the eye. The scenery and costumes are by Zack Brown, who continues to design much of the company's best work.
