title: PLAN GAINS TO RAISE FUNDS TO PAY FOR LEGAL SERVICES FOR POOR
description: A new plan being used more and more across the country has raised almost $20 million to pay for legal services for poor people. Supporters say there is no cost to anyone, except banks that participate voluntarily.

title: GEORGE MATHEWS, 73, ACTOR ON BROADWAY AND IN MOVIES
description: George Mathews, an actor who had a long career that took him from the classics to gangster roles, died of heart disease Wednesday. He was 73 years old and lived in Caesars Head, S.C.

title: ORGANIZERS ROSY ON CHICAGO'S FAIR
description: The specter of the debt-ridden New Orleans fair has made officials working on a 1992 World's Fair in Chicago predict that it will be harder for them to get legislative approval for their billion-dollar exposition, but their hopes still run high.

title: AUTHOR OF BOOK ON POPE SUBPOENAED
description: A Federal grand jury in Philadelphia has subpoenaed Antoni Gronowicz, the author of ''God's Broker,'' a book about Pope John Paul II that was recalled by its publisher as being ''fraudulent.''

title: Shell, Arco Cuts
description: The Shell Oil Company, based in Houston, and the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles cut their posted price for West Texas Intermediate, a light crude, by $1 a barrel, to $29. That virtually completes the round of price cuts that has been sweeping the nation's oil industry. After the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to curb production by 1.5 million barrels a day Nov. 1 to bolster sagging world oil prices, major American oil companies began reducing the price they are willing to pay for high-quality, light domestic crude oil.

title: K.G.B. Chief Visits Prague
description: Viktor M. Chebrikov, head of the K.G.B. and an alternate member of the Soviet Politburo, arrived in Prague today, the official Czechoslovak press agency reported. The dispatch said Mr. Chebrikov and Czechoslovak Interior Ministry officials would discuss ''questions of mutual cooperation among friendly security corps and the further deepening of their cooperation in the protection of the social and state system of the two socialist states.''

title: 2-Year-Old Transplant Patient Dies After Her New Liver Fails
description: A 2-year-old girl who was the second person to have her heart and liver replaced by transplanted organs died today when her new liver failed, a hospital spokesman said.

title: SNIPER AT THE UNIVERSITY OF OREGON SLAYS A FORMER OLYMPIC SPRINTER
description: A troubled student dressed in combat gear opened fire indiscriminately at the University of Oregon's football stadium today, killing a former Olympic sprinter and wounding a college wrestler, and then apparently committed suicide, officials said.

title: A SIMPLER TAX BUT COSTLIER FOR SOME
description: On the surface, the sharply lower income tax rates that could be adopted by Congress under a simplified tax system would seem to promise that virtually all Americans would wind up with greatly reduced tax bills.

title: Continental Group To Sell Georgia Mill
description: The Continental Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its bleached paperboard mill in Augusta, Ga., and related operations to the Federal Paper Board Company for about $305 million.

description: to an effort to cut Federal income tax rates, while weeding

title: REPORTER LINKS ANCIENT LAND TO MICROBES
description: BACTERIA and other microbes are thought to be among the most ancient forms of life, but it is hard to prove just how ancient are some of the species that cause human disease.

title: A Prairie Option Granted to Placer
description: The Prairie Producing Company said its chairman, George F. Watford, had granted an option to Placer Development Ltd. to buy his 2,280,690 shares, or about 28.3 percent of the company's shares outstanding, for $17.68 a share, or about $40.3 million. The option expires on Dec. 3 and may not be exercised unless Placer, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, enters into a definitive agreement or takes steps to acquire all of Prairie's shares at not less than $17.68 each, Prairie said.

title: BABY FAE CONTINUES TO MEND
description: Baby Fae, the infant who received a baboon's heart 18 days ago, is recovering from a moderate rather than a mild rejection episode, doctors at Loma Linda Medical Center said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'd rather have someone with a mop or a wrench in their hand than a pencil.'' - David L. Gunn, president of the Transit Authority. (A1:2.)

title: 37 Indonesia Generals Retire In Program to Trim Military
description: Indonesia's Defense Department announced today that 37 army generals had been retired as part of a Government program to create a smaller but more efficient military by the end of 1985.

title: Holiday Affects Tables
description: Because most Government offices and banks were closed yesterday in observance of Veterans Day, these financial tables do not appear today: Treasury Bills, Bonds and Notes, Foreign Exchange and Government Agency Bonds. Results of the weekly Treasury bill auction, which was postponed until today, will appear tomorrow.

description: The Government, following up on its warnings of a United States invasion, deployed tanks in strategic areas in and around the capital today and put its armed forces on combat alert.

THERE'S NO EXIT. ALSO, NO ENTRANCE.
description: Federal attempts at efficiency can produce special mysteries. Once I passed two mail boxes, one marked ''Air Mail,'' the other ''Regular Mail.''

title: ;  Jersey Fire Ruins A Town Garage
description: Fire destroyed the public-works garage here today, and most of the vehicles owned by the town were damaged or destroyed when the building's roof collapsed, authorities said.

title: IN DIVISION SCRAMBLE, THE REDSKINS HAVE AN EDGE
description: After 11 weeks, the Eastern Division of the National Conference has that old familiar look to it. The Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys are tied for the lead at 7-4, with the Giants, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Philadelphia Eagles chasing.

title: SCIENCE WATCH;
description: Super Refrigerator

title: Ruckelshaus's Travels
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, plans to travel to Ottawa in three weeks to discuss a variety of environmental issues of mutual interest to the United States and Canada. But Canadians who have been hoping for a break in the deadlock over acid rain will be disappointed by the visit.

title: CRITICISM REPORTED ON BID FOR REGISTER
description: The chairman of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, David Kruidenier, has reportedly criticized the $112 million buyout offer the company received last week from Dow Jones & Company and an investor group that includes two top Register executives, saying that he regretted it had been made.

title: Esty Moves Bushell To Chief Executive
description: Gordon P. Bushell, president and chief operating officer of the William Esty Company, has been named chairman and chief executive, succeeding Robert B. Betts. Mr. Bushell, 51 years old, has been with Esty for 24 years.

CATHOLIC BISHOP URGES COHESION ON PUBLIC ISSUES
description: Roman Catholic bishops should follow the lead of their national conference in shaping efforts to change public policy, the head of that group said today.

title: ISRAEL HOPEFUL ON LEBANON TALKS, BUT THERE IS NO SIGN FROM BEIRUT
description: Israeli officials expressed guarded optimism today that a formula could be worked out with Lebanon to allow troop withdrawal talks with Lebanon to resume on Wednesday.

title: TROUBLES FOR CALIFORNIA COTTON
description: The cotton harvest, now winding up, is usually a happy occasion for growers in California's San Joaquin Valley, one of the country's most prolific cotton- growing regions. But this year is different, with the farmers pitted against nearly all of the economic and natural elements that once brought them bounty.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Northwest Names Ex-Esmark Official
description: Frederick B. Rentschler will become president and chief operating officer of Northwest Industries when a $1 billion leveraged buyout of Northwest by private investors is completed later this year.

title: Fischbach Payout
description: The Fischbach Corporation, a contracting concern, said it had reduced its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share, from 66.25 cents, payable Dec. 1 to shareholders of record Nov. 23. The company, in explaining the reduction, said it expects to report a loss for the fourth quarter, ended Sept. 30, although it said it would have a profit for the year. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Fischbach plunged $2.25, to $36.25.

description: SECRETARY of Education T. H. Bell has announced that he will step down from the Cabinet post Dec. 30 to become a professor at the University of Utah. In an interview after his resignation last week, the 62-year-old career educator spoke about his tenure as a cabinet member. Following are excerpts from that interview.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH SEEN
description: Britain can look forward to a modest reduction in net taxes next year, a slight decline in inflation and continued economic growth, Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson told the House of Commons today.

Louis XV Cabinet Fetches $1.6 Million
description: A gilded French 18th-century cabinet, used at Versailles during the reign of Louis XV, sold Sunday in Monte Carlo for 15 million French francs or about $1.6 million.

title: LEXICON
description: There is growing agreement here that the next session of Congress will be marked by some intense lobbying for restoration of regulation of some of the nation's major industries.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY PROPOSES BUDGET WITH 90-CENT FARE
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that no increase in New York City's bus and subway fare would be needed next year if the state continued its present subsidies.

title: NEW U.S.-JAPAN STRAINS
description: Now that both countries' leaders have cleared autumn election hurdles, United States and Japanese officials expect their relations to be marred more insistently by disputes, especially on economic issues. A cease-fire on mutual criticism has prevailed for the last year while President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone tended to domestic politics. It helped that the two men share a close personal relationship, said to be so warm that despite customary Japanese formality they refer to each other as Ron and Yasu.

description: The city will begin fingerprinting and running criminal-record checks on more than 90,000 child-care workers today, officials said yesterday.

description: Next month President Reagan is expected to receive a Treasury Department blueprint outlining an overhaul of the 70- year-old Federal income tax in the name of lower and simpler taxes.

title: Trude Weishaupt, 72, Is Dead; Active in Charities in Queens
description: Trude Weishaupt, a leader in civic and charitable organizations in Queens, died Saturday after heart surgery at the Westchester County Medical Center. She was 72 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

description: Optimists in bridge, as in life, look for the small ray of light at the end of the long, dark tunnel. They may not find it, but at least they have a chance; the pessimists who do not bother to look never see it.

title: TWO OFFERS CONSIDERED BY PABST
description: The Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's sixth-largest brewer and the subject of repeated takeover bids in the last few years, announced yesterday that it had received two new offers, each valued at $63 million.

;  Rowers Are Cleared
description: Two Norwegian rowers who competed in the Olympics last summer and were later accused of taking drugs have been cleared of the charge. The rowers, Vetle Vinje and Esten Torsen, were tested during a training session last June, but the results, analyzed for the Norwegian Sports Federation by Huddinge Hospital near Stockholm, were not forthcoming until after the Olympics had ended in August.

title: Iran Says It Seized an Agent Of Iraq With Explosives in Car
description: A man described as an Iraqi agent was arrested after parking an explosives- laden car outside a mosque in Teheran, Iran's capital, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

title: Brock, Americana
description: The Brock Hotel Corporation said that under a letter of agreement signed last week with the Americana Hotels Corporation, Brock will own 45 percent and Americana 55 percent of a new concern that will combine the hotel units of the two companies. Brock said the initial ownership arrangement would be subject to adjustment based on cash-flow contributions of the two hotel chains during 1985. Under the proposal, Brock said it would receive a 10-year payout equal to 50 percent of the development fees, royalties and initial franchising of its new Brock Residence Inns Inc. hotel chain.

title: PROFESSOR DEBATES KAHANE ON ISRAEL
description: They attended the same yeshiva high school in Brooklyn and grew up conversant with the sacred Jewish texts, but the lives of Meir Kahane and Alan Dershowitz have taken radically different courses.

title: Business and the Law; New Asbestos Property Suits
description: WITH more than 25,000 personal injury suits pending against the asbestos companies, a second wave of asbestos litigation is beginning to flood the courts - and it may be even larger and more costly than the claims by individuals who have developed lung disease or cancer after exposure to asbestos.

title: GIANTS ARE SPURRED BY STRONGER TEAMS
description: The conclusion is inescapable: The Giants rise to the opposition, playing better football against the better teams. If they could play the Washington Redskins and Dallas Cowboys more often, it seems, they would have a better chance to make the playoffs.

description: '' READING to your children may be the single most powerful contribution that you, as a parent, can make toward their success in school,'' William F. Russell says.

title: Wells, Rich Expands Its Executive Ranks
description: Wells, Rich, Greene/East, because of what it describes as explosive growth, has named four executive vice presidents and plans to add another to the list before the year ends.

title: Let's Really Get Out the Vote
description: Although voter turnout in 1984 increased for the first time since 1960, almost as many people of voting age did not participate in the Presidential election. Despite the efforts of parties and nonpartisan volunteer groups, nearly 50 million qualified Americans failed even to register. No volunteer effort will ever reach the majority of them. This is a job for government, Federal and state.

title: SUSPICION OF BUSINESS SEEN IN BONN
description: Gerhard Stoltenberg, the Finance Minister of West Germany, says that the investigations into business contributions to political parties are arousing ''emotions of anticapitalism'' and a ''general suspiciousness toward business'' in West Germany.

title: Feldstein Views Deficit
description: Martin S. Feldstein, former chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that ''there is simply no basis'' for the Reagan Administration to believe that economic growth would reduce the Government's budget deficits significantly.

title: INSUROR DELIGHTED BY SPACE RESCUE AND IMPLICATIONS
description: Insurance underwriters, ecstatic over the capture today of the wayward satellite Palapa, praised the shuttle astronauts' operation, which one official said ''ushered in a new era of insurance practice.''

title: NBC CONTRACT REFLECTS CHANGING TECHNOLOGY
description: The agreement that the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians reached with NBC last Friday takes into account technological changes reaching into a broad range of broadcasting areas, according to NBC.

description: One hundred Army engineers from Fort Bragg, N.C., have arrived to improve roads at the Palmerola air base, United States and Honduran sources said today.

description: One of the six dissidents on trial in Belgrade told the court today that a security officer ''in charge of intellectuals'' threatened to kill him earlier this year.

I want a neat and orderly robot.'' ''Can't we pick up two crystals at once?'' ''No.'' ''Hey, look, you can hide an object inside the robot and the sensor doesn't detect it.'' ''You need to split it with a nor-gate there.''

title: D'Arcy Selection
description: D'Arcy MacManus Masius has named Eugene F. Bartley Jr. president of DMM/New York. Mr. Bartley, 39, was president of Cadwell Davis Partners, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi/ Compton. He will fill the post vacated by Keith Fischer, who left May 1 and is now a consultant for Grey Advertising. DMM/New York's projected billings for 1984 will be about $110 million.

description: b-Net loss The latest 6 months net resulted in a loss per share after giving effect to preferred dividend requirements.

title: MORE COLLEGE CREDITS EARNED IN HIGH SCHOOL
description: More than 6,000 of the nation's 23,000 high schools last year gave promising juniors and seniors a chance to earn college credits by taking college-level courses and then passing examinations, the College Board said yesterday in a report on its advanced placement program.

title: Parents Offer Reward In Sex Abuse Case
description: A group of parents offered a $10,000 reward today for pornographic photos showing children with employees of a preschool where seven people have been accused of sexually abusing 42 children.

title: ;  Surgery for Referee
description: A National Basketball Association referee, Jack Madden , underwent surgery Monday for a knee injury he suffered during last Friday's game between the Celtics and the 76ers in Boston. Dr. James Funk, who performed the operation at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta, said it was ''highly questionable'' whether Madden could return to action this season.

title: ;  $150,000inJewelry Taken by Burglars
description: Burglars broke into the offices of a wholesale jewelry concern in Manhattan's diamond district early yesterday and stole $150,000 in diamonds and gold rings, the police said.

title: MARGUERITE DURAS WINS CONCOURT PRIZE FOR 1984
description: Marguerite Duras, the 70-year-old author of ''L'Amant,'' an autobiographical tale of adolescent love set in Indochina, today received the Goncourt Prize, France's most prestigious literary award.

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss on sale of discontinued operation of $480,000 and an extraordinary gain on termination of pension plan of $470,000. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $108,000 for the quarter and $327,000 for the 9 months. d-After a gain on sale of discontinued operation of $2,573,000 and an extraordinary gain on termination of pension plan of $470,000. Both year-ago periods were restated for discontinued operations.

description: Harold K. Blum, former executive vice president of the K-M Grocery Corporation, died Sunday at Montefiore Hospital.

title: WHEN MOM WALKS OFF THE JOB
description: DESPITE the plebian title of ''Mom's on Stike,'' tomorrow's Afterschool Special, on ABC at 4:30 P.M., turns out to be one of the more diverting entries in this award-winning series for younger viewers.

title: COVERAGE TO BENEFIT AN OLYMPICS OF RACING
description: Nobody sits happily through four hours of one television program unless the program is exceptionally dramatic or concerns a topic dear to the viewer's heart. So how is it that at least one viewer who is not a passionate follower of horse racing sat through four hours of a horse-racing program last Saturday with scarcely a fidget?

title: People
description: * Michael Robinson has been named senior partner at Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago.

title: STAGE: MICHAEL WELLER'S 'BALLAD OF SOAPY SMITH'
description: NOW that the dislocations of the 1960's have become mass culture cliches, it's only right that Michael Weller, our most sensitive and knowing dramatist of the big-chill generation, has left the territory behind. In ''The Ballad of Soapy Smith,'' his new play at the Public's Newman Theater, Mr. Weller has journeyed about as far in period and style from his wounding comedies ''Moonchildren'' and ''Loose Ends'' as he could conceivably go.

title: EGYPT BARS HIGH-LEVEL TALKS WITH ISRAEL FOR NOW
description: President Hosni Mubarak's senior foreign policy adviser said today that Egypt had ruled out a meeting with Israel's Prime Minister or Middle East peace talks now.

title: Bond Holder Suit Is Due
description: A committee representing 70,000 bond holders said it intends to file a lawsuit Tuesday charging that the State of Washington is responsible for $7.25 billion in principal and interest on two nuclear plants that the Washington Public Power Supply System has abandoned.

description: Representatives of the world's leading cocoa producing and consuming nations will meet here early in December in an attempt to narrow differences that prevented agreement earlier this month on a new price- stabilization pact.

description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest company involved in disposing of hazardous wastes, announced yesterday that Phillip B. Rooney had been named president and chief operating officer. The appointment is effective immediately.

description: The Chrysler Corporation will spend approximately $10 billion over the next five years on new products and production facilities, Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman, said today.

description: b-After a tax credit of $241,000. c-After a tax credit of $96,000.

title: Rangers' Saarinen Out 4 to 6 Weeks The string of injuries to the Ranger defensemen goes on and on. The team lost to the Los Angeles Kings Sunday night, 4-2, and they lost Simo Saarinen when the defenseman crashed into the goal post late in the first period. Saarinen underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital for torn ligaments in his left knee and is expected to be out for four to six weeks.
description: The injury means that, for the second time in little more than a week, and the third time this season, the Rangers lost a defenseman for a prolonged period. Ron Greschner suffered a separated shoulder on Nov. 3 in a game against Pittsburgh and will probably be idled for about a month.

JACK WRATHER, 66, DIES IN CALIFORNIA
description: Jack Wrather, a California industrialist who headed the Wrather Corporation, a combination of oil, entertainment and real-estate businesses, died of cancer yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 66 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A REVIVAL IN WASHINGTON FOR THE MONROE DOCTRINE
description: The Monroe Doctrine, largely shunned by United States officials for the past 30 years, has had a minor revival amid the recent round of official hints that military force might be used to curb Soviet arming of Nicaragua.

title: SECRET REAGAN WEAPON IN RACE: COMPUTER
description: While Republicans celebrated their Presidential election landslide in the cavernous ballroom below, members of a little-known political cadre sat in an upstairs hotel room pouring champagne and playing a videotape ridiculing Walter F. Mondale, the man they called ''Vice President Malaise.''

description: b-Net loss.

description: Gov. Edwin Edwards stepped in today to stop the execution of Robert Lee Willie less than 12 hours before he was to have been put to death in Louisiana's electric chair.

title: SOVIET CRITICIZES NATO STRATEGY
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda today denounced as dangerous a new NATO military doctrine.

title: Benoit Holds Out
description: Business and tourist officials in Maine, her home state, are trying to entice Joan Benoit, who last summer won the first Olympic women's marathon, into working for them. But they have so far been unable to agree to her asking price, reported to be $250,000.

title: German-Soviet Talks
description: The West German Government said today that economic talks with the Soviet Union, postponed in September, would be held in January. A date has not been set, but the Soviet delegation, led by Deputy Prime Minister Aleksei K. Antonov, will travel to Bonn between Jan. 20 and Jan. 27, Peter Boenisch, a West German spokesman, said.

title: PLAN TO SHUT FACTORY STUNS UPSTATE VILLAGE
description: There are, in the lives of communities, occasions of hope and moments of despair, periods of confidence and times of uncertainty.

description: A $50 million libel trial pitting one of Israel's most powerful leaders, Ariel Sharon, against the communications conglomerate that publishes Time magazine opened yesterday in Manhattan.

description: Marshall Criser, the Florida president, said today that the university would appeal the National Collegiate Athletic Association's sanctions imposed on the school's football program for rule infractions.

title: NASA IS CRITICIZED ON SPACE STATION
description: The space agency's current plans for an $8 billion space station are not justified on scientific, economic or military grounds and are not apt to produce the best facility, a Congressional study asserted today.

title: Campbell Soup Ltd.
description: The Campbell Soup Company Ltd., 70 percent owned by the Campbell Soup Company of the United States, said it would try to achieve 15 percent growth in earnings in each of the next four years. Earnings for the fiscal year that ended July 29 were down 3.1 percent, to $18.6 million (Canadian), from $19.2 million. The company attributed that to higher marketing and administrative costs in its first year as a public company.

title: Frontier Holdings Drops Dividend
description: The directors of Frontier Holdings Inc. voted yesterday to suspend the company's 9-cent-a-share dividend until profitability improves. The airline reported a loss of $10 million for the nine months ended Sept. 30, after losing $14.9 million in same period a year earlier.

title: Scaling the Heights
description: Thomas M. Macioce, this year's recipient of Columbia College's Alexander Hamilton Medal - the school's highest honor - recalls the spring day in 1935 when he received something else from Columbia: word that he had earned a scholarship there.

title: ROCKETS GO 8-0; JORDAN'S 45 LIFT BULLS
description: Lewis Lloyd scored 20 points to help Houston remain the league's only unbeaten team and keep Cleveland the only one without a victory tonight as the Rockets beat the Cavaliers, 106-98.

title: Advertising; An Agency Marketing Role Seen
description: Some advertisers will be returning to the old days of just after World War II, when ad agencies served as their marketing departments, too, Philip H. Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Interpublic Group of Companies, predicted here today.

title: POLAND WARNS CIVIC WATCHDOG GROUPS
description: The Polish Government said today that it would soon ''take steps'' against people who had been forming civic committees to monitor police violence.

description: The United States Football League's New Orleans Breakers announced today that the franchise would move to Portland for the 1985 spring season.

description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split effective Oct. 3, 1984.

description: The Air Force today announced it had conducted its second live-firing test of its new air-launched anti-satellite rocket.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Suffolk County Offers $136.8 Million in Bonds
description: Suffolk County, L.I., which has been hurt by the Long Island Lighting Company's refusal to pay real estate taxes on the Shoreham nuclear plant, is offering $136.8 million of general obligation bonds to refund bonds it previously sold to finance the Southwest Sewer District.

title: ANOTHER NEW STEP FOR STALEY
description: The A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company, the corn miller and soybean processor, took another step away from its traditional businesses today when it announced that it was thinking of selling its soybean operations.

title: LYDIA ARTMIW: PIANIST, PERFORMS AT TULLY HALL
description: Lydia Artymiw's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night presented a compelling musical personality that often glowed too warmly for its own good. In six Choral Preludes by Brahms, the second set of Debussy's ''Images'' and the Chopin Polonaise-Fantaisie, Miss Artymiw's hot- blooded approach exploited individual phrases - compressing and extending their movement for maximum effect but severing the threads that bind these parts together.

title: SOME SEE ACID RAIN FALL, IN PRIORITY
description: In the Federal bureaucracy, seemingly routine labor-management issues have a way of becoming entangled in matters of high policy. A case in point is the recent proposal by the Environmental Protection Agency to create an Office of Acid Deposition under its Assistant Administrator for Research and Development.

title: NICARAGUAN VOWS TO RESIST U.S.
description: The Minister of Defense said today that Nicaragua would not alter its policies in the face of pressure from the Reagan Administration.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 27
description: The share earnings for both the year-ago and latest third quarter and 9 months are restated to reflect a 10 percent common dividend paid May 1984, as well as, a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 1983. LIFO provisions increased net income for the latest quarter by $350,000 versus a reduction of $1,750,000 for the comparable year-ago period. On a year-to-date basis LIFO reduced net income for the latest 9 months by $450,000 against $3.6 million for the year-earlier period.

title: NEW POSTMASTER PICKED TO RUN $25 BILLION SYSTEM
description: The governing board of the United States Postal Service voted today to appoint Paul N. Carlin the new postmaster general, according to sources familiar with the closed meeting.

description: A chain-reaction accident involving five tractor-trailers killed one trucker, injured two others and forced the closing of a stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike in this morning's rush hour, the state police said.

title: MINISTER IS SENT TO JAIL IN PROTEST OF JOBLESSNESS
description: A minister who has defied both church and state in repeatedly refusing to stop his agitation for unemployed steelworkers was arrested in his church and sent to jail today.

title: HEART AND KIDNEYS BEGINTO FAIL
description: Baby Fae took a serious turn for the worse today, her doctors said, as they battled to save her from rejecting the baboon heart she received 18 days ago.

title: OFF-BROADWAY COMEDY,'GREATER TUNA,' ON HBO
description: WRITTEN by Joe Sears, Jaston Williams and Ed Howard, ''Greater Tuna,'' which had a successful run Off Broadway, features 24 speaking roles and a corpse. There is, to be sure, a gimmick. All the parts - male and female, child and adult, even the corpse - are played by Mr. Sears and Mr. Williams. The exercise is certainly curious and quite often hilarious, as is demonstrated in the one- hour adaptation going onto the schedule of Home Box Office, the pay-cable channel, tonight at 8.

title: Market Place; Taking Losses To Save Taxes
description: NO investor enjoys buying a stock and watching it plunge in value, but the approach of the tax-loss selling season on Wall Street has the potential of easing that pain somewhat. The principle here is that selling some market losers - and there are plenty around these days - in a portfolio can ease a person's tax bite to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: SPAIN WILL EXTRADITE MAN CITED AS LEADER OF DRUG RING TO U.S.
description: A man described by American officials as one of the most-wanted drug traffickers in the United States will be extradited by Spain and sent to New York within the next several days, Spanish and American authorities said today.

description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) reduced its posted price for some grades of crude oil by $1 a barrel, bringing West Texas Intermediate to $29 a barrel, oil industry sources said.

description: At first, after the second Presidential debate, there was only the sound of the Democrats' fallen hopes. But that silence was soon pierced by the familiar political drumbeat of pre-emptive scapegoating.

title: MACMILLAN, AT 90, ROUSES THE LORDS
description: The Earl of Stockton, who as Harold Macmillan served as Prime Minister from 1957 to 1963, made his debut in the House of Lords today with a speech depicting Britain as a country deeply divided by what he called ''a new kind of wicked hatred.''

The results of Jonathan Logan Inc. are included in the latest quarter and account for $39,000,000 of the increase in sales and $374,000 in net income.

M.V.P. AWARD TO SANDBERG
description: Ryne Sandberg, whose efforts afield and at bat helped the Chicago Cubs win their first championship in 39 years, was named the Most Valuable Player in the National League yesterday. In gaining 22 first-place votes in the balloting by 24 members of the Baseball Writers Association of America, Sandberg finished far ahead of Keith Hernandez of the Mets and Tony Gwynn of San Diego, who each received 1 vote for first place.

13 ARE INJURED AS STORES BURN IN HUNTINGTON
description: Thirteen stores were damaged by a stubborn, smoky fire that burned out of control for four hours today at the Walt Whitman Mall, the largest shopping center in Suffolk County.

description: O single, white, heterosexual, nonsmoking, anti-nuke male professional with a growing practice who likes dining out, European travel and mildly Rubenesque women - where art thou?

description: * Burlington Northern Inc., Seattle, has named Ronald H. Reimann vice president-public affairs.

title: Henry C. Merritt, 91, Is Dead; Retired Broker on Wall Street
description: Henry C. Merritt, a retired Wall Street broker and a decorated veteran of World War I, died Sunday at New York Hospital of complications after surgery. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ATARI MAKES PLANS FOR STOCK OFFERINGS
description: The Atari Corporation will raise $150 million over the next 18 months in three installments, ''and we hope to go public sometime in '85,'' Jack Tramiel, the company's chairman, said today.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Faces New Counts in Spy Case
description: Eight new charges involving bribery and stealing Government property have been filed against Richard Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and two of seven original spying charges have been dropped, attorneys disclosed today.

title: The Harder They Run
description: The Reagan Landslide, as awesome as was its sweep around

title: Automatic Switch Considering Sale
description: Trading in the shares of the Automatic Switch Company, a big maker of valves and switches, was halted yesterday after the company announced that it had retained the First Boston Corporation to explore a possible sale of the company.

title: Memory Lane
description: Joe Norris, who bowled his first perfect game at the age of 18 and competed for an American team when bowling was staged as an exhibition sport at the Berlin Olympics in 1936, is being honored Friday night as part of the $150,000 Brunswick Memorial Open in Glendale Heights, Ill.

title: Police in South Africa Raid Black Township
description: A convoy of South African police and army trucks today rolled into the black township of Tembisa, northeast of here, in what the authorities described as an anticrime operation.

title: Berkley Publishing Appoints President
description: Rena Wolner, who joined the Berkley Publishing Corporation as vice president and publisher in 1978, has been named president of Berkley, the mass-market division of the Putnam Publishing Group.

title: MOON SEES FUTURE IN HOUSTAN VICTORY
description: After the Houston Oilers won their first game of the season Sunday, and their first on the road since September 1981, the trip home from Kansas City was a celebration described by one participant as ''a champagne flight, especially for the veterans.''

title: 23D GAME IN CHESS MATCH: A CAREFUL AND CORRECT DRAW
description: Although the contenders in the world chess championship in Moscow had not crossed swords for a week, the indisposition day that the challenger, Gary Kasparov, took on Friday and the time off they took last Wednesday to celebrate the Russian Revolution did nothing to fire up their courage. Their game on Monday, the 23d of the match, was like most of the draws that stretch back to Game 9 - unenterprising but careful and correct.

title: Careers; Executive Training Programs
description: DEMOGRAPHICS, fast catching up with the nation's graduate schools of business administration, is changing their role. Now there are fewer M.B.A.'s to teach but more executives who need training.

title: Vote Challenge Dropped
description: Battle Robinson, a Republican, Monday conceded the race for Lieutenant Governor to S. B. Woo, a Democrat, saying that pursuing challenges to the vote count probably would not change the outcome. Mrs. Robinson had sought a recount in each county after election results a week ago had her losing by a little more than 500 votes. Sussex and New Castle Counties complied with her request, but Kent County denied it. Mr. Woo is a physics professor at the University of Delaware.

title: Stearns Reinjures Elbow SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 13 (AP) - John Stearns, the former Met
description: catcher trying to make a comeback from a 1982 injury, has been forced

title: U.S.-JAPAN ACCORD ON WHALING
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced today that an agreement had been reached with Japan under which the Japanese will end all whaling no later than 1988.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Diversified Industries, Richmond Heights, Mo., said it had acquired all production assets of Midwest Steel Processing Inc. of Center Line, Mich., which processes steel wire. Midwest is a wholly owned unit of Allied Products Corp.; terms were not disclosed.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS: THE FIRST STEPS
description: JESSICA ALICE RICHTER is 4 years old and about to have her first encounter with the competitive world. She will soon begin meeting unfamilar people who will measure her intelligence, verbal ability and social and physical development. Jessica's parents, Carol and Louis Richter, will be subjected to a similar but more subtle set of tests in their interviews with the admissions staffs of several Manhattan private schools. Months will pass before the Richter family finds out if Jessica is accepted or rejected for kindergarten.

title: U.S. SAYS IT WOULD HELP ALLIES REPEL SANDINISTAS
description: The Department of Defense said today that the United States would respond ''with whatever assistance was necessary'' if Honduras or El Salvador asked for military help in repelling an invasion from Nicaragua.

title: NEWHOUSE TO ACQUIRE 17% OF THE NEW YORKER
description: Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., who controls a publishing group that includes the Conde Nast magazines and Random House books, said yesterday that his company intends to acquire 17 percent of The New Yorker Magazine Inc. for about $180 a share, or a total of about $25.5 million.

title: Article 083658 -- No Title
description: A group that has financial backing from the Chemical Bank filed suit today asserting that Washington State has a moral obligation to pay $7.25 billion in principal and interest to the bondholders of two terminated nuclear power units. The suit, brought by a bondholder committee, charges fraud, negligence, misfeasance and that the State Auditor failed to warn bondholders of the Washington Public Power Supply System's ''serious financial difficulties.''

title: Japan Scrambles 32 Jets To Meet Soviet Bombers
description: The Japan Defense Agency said today that it scrambled 32 jet fighters when 7 Soviet bombers flew south in international airspace between South Korea and Japan.

title: MONEY BRINGS OUT BRELAND'S CRITICS
description: Mark Breland could afford to ignore the warning sign on the clean white wall: ''Remember to Pay Your Dues.'' Before he makes his professional boxing debut tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, Breland is virtually assured of being a millionaire. But Mario Costa, who owns the Ringside Gym, a well-lighted walkup one story safely above Eighth Avenue at 40th Street, is letting Breland and the four other Olympic headliners train without having to pay the $25 monthly dues.

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

description: For nearly four years, Americans have been participating in an improvisational play that could be entitled ''Waiting for Dario Fo.''

title: U.S. FAULTED AT TALKS ON LATIN PEACE TREATY
description: The regional bloc known as the Contadora group worked today to keep alive its two- year-old mediation effort in Central America amid growing concern over Washington's attitude toward a regional peace treaty.

title: THE STAGE: 'RED LIGHT'
description: LENORA CHAMPAGNE put her thoughts on stage Monday night at Performance Space 122. The result was ''From the Red Light District,'' a 50-minute event with words and movement by Miss Champagne that dealt with such matters as sex, love, death, money and religion.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE nomenclature of French dishes has a certain fascination. Many of the names indicate the use of one ingredient - duBarry always means the presence of cauliflower; Florentine always means spinach, and Crecy invariably suggests carrots. Other terms are based on the presence of two or more particular ingredients but allow for the inclusion of many more. Ni,coise, for example, indicates the use of olive oil, tomatoes and garlic. But dishes bearing that name might also include other ingredients that are typical of the region around Nice and the South of France: black olives, anchovies and sometimes eggplant and squash.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 6
description: b-Including a gain of $3,025,000 from a change in accounting.

title: TUTU ELECTED FIRST BLACK BISHOP OF JOHANNESBURG
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, winner of this year's Nobel Peace Prize and a critic of South Africa's racial policies, was elected today as the first black Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg.

title: THE BIG GRAPE: NOUVEAU YORK CITY
description: THE wine merchant William Sokolin, in a published letter commenting on how to produce good vintages, has suggested that cabernet sauvignon grapes should be planted in Central Park. In fuller bloom, that idea offers the prospect of a new New York - or, more aptly, a new Nouveau York. In short, turn Manhattan into a vineyard.

title: Boesky Discloses New Purchases
description: Ivan F. Boesky, a New York investor, and a group of companies he controls told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had purchased stakes in the Rolm Corporation and the American Sterilizer Company.

title: Woman's Punishment Is Termed Too Harsh
description: Gov. Bob Graham said today that too harsh a punishment was ordered for Rosemary Furman, a stenographer who was sentenced to 30 days in jail for offering advice while selling do-it-yourself legal forms.

title: Michihiro Sato Plays In Tsugaru Tradition
description: The shamisen, a fretless, three- stringed banjolike instrument, is most often used in Japan to accompany singers, dancers or drama. But in the Tsugaru region of northern Japan, it has a solo tradition that is as stark and powerful as rock, as improvisational as jazz, as sparing as minimalism and as virtuosic as raga.

title: PENNEY, J.C. CO INC reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 27
description: The company said LIFO credits of $13 million and $21 million have been reflected in the latest third quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: MUSIC: CHRISTA LUDWIG SINGS WOLF AND STRAUSS
description: THE program Christa Ludwig and James Levine gave at Fisher Hall Sunday comprised 23 songs in German, at least 16 of them masterpieces, and all by two masters, Hugo Wolf and Richard Strauss. Most were familiar, and a delightful several were charming, but the performers did not shy away from difficult, serious songs and did not flinch from their toughness of thought.

title: ITT Reports Earnings
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that net income rose 11.4 percent in the third quarter because of a one- time gain but that earnings without the special gain fell 41.2 percent.

title: Japan Steel Gains
description: Japan's major steelmakers returned to profitability in the first half of the latest fiscal year amid strong exports, good domestic demand and lower costs, according to results released today for the six-month period ended Sept. 30.

description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted today to put off for two weeks a sweeping antipornography bill.

title: SHUTTLE CREW MANEUVERS FOR ITS NEXT SALVAGE JOB
description: The Discovery astronauts, rested and confident of success, steered their spaceship today toward a second errant communication satellite, which they are to retrieve in history's first space salvage mission.

title: NBC TO GO AHEAD WITH 'FATAL VISION' BROADCASTS
description: NBC yesterday remained adamant in its decision to broadcast on Sunday and Monday ''Fatal Vision,'' the television adaptation of a book about the murder of Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald's wife and family, despite Dr. MacDonald's attorneys' insistence that it would harm his chances in a new trial.

title: Bird, Erving Fined $7,500 for Fighting
description: Two of the National Basketball Association's biggest stars, Julius Erving and Larry Bird, were each fined '7,500 yesterday for their part in a brawl during a game last Friday night in Boston between the 76ers and the Celtics. Neither player was suspended.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: POETRY, LIVE New York serves not only as inspiration for poets, it also serves as platform for their lines to be heard. In this city, there are probably more poetry readings in a week than other towns may have in, if not a year, than in a month.

title: COOK HELPS NETS TURN BACK CLIPPERS
description: Life without Darryl Dawkins took a turn for the better for the Nets tonight. They snapped a two-game losing streak by defeating the struggling Los Angeles Clippers, 99-90, before 7,322 fans at the Sports Arena.

title: Rulings Stand On WOR License
description: The Supreme Court today let stand rulings that allowed RKO General Inc. to keep its broadcasting license for WOR-TV, based on the station's move from New York City to Secaucus, N.J. The Court, without comment, rejected an appeal by Multi- State Communications Inc., which had been challenging RKO's license renewal.

title: AIR ATLANTA PRESIDENT IS EX-T.W.A. OFFICER
description: Neil M. Effman, who was forced out as senior vice president of Trans World Airlines last August, when Richard D. Pearson was named its executive vice president and chief operating officer, has been named Air Atlanta's president and chief operating officer.

title: OFFICIALS IN OHIO SHUT KEY DUMP FOR TOXIC WASTE
description: The Ohio Environmental Protection Agency has shut down one of the country's biggest toxic waste dumps after receiving reports that its operators knowingly pumped contaminated water into the drinking water supply of a nearby town.

title: Roger Straus to Avon
description: Roger W. Straus 3d has been appointed executive editor of Avon Books, publishers of Avon, Bard, Discus, Camelot and Flare. Mr. Straus began his career in publishing in 1967 as an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, where he became director of marketing. In 1976 he joined Harper & Row, where he became associate publisher. Most recently he was vice president and director of marketing for Times Books.

title: From One Party to Another
description: The Democratic national chairman, Charles T. Manatt, has

title: TURKEY AND TRIMMINGS READY TO GO
description: FOR those New Yorkers who find the prospect of cooking a traditional Thanksgiving dinner as appealing as a tax audit and infinitely more time-consuming, there are caterers that prepare holiday dinners to go. This service appears to be increasingly in demand.

title: Bond Sale Is On Despite Ballot Slip
description: New Jersey can sell $60 million in bonds to finance human services projects despite faulty wording of the bond ballot question approved by voters, the State Attorney General's office said today.

title: 2 STATE BUILDINGS IN CITY TO BE SHELTERS
description: Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that two state-owned buildings in Manhattan would be converted into shelters for the homeless.

title: OPEC REFINING ALARMS U.S. OILMEN
description: The oil industry has begun two studies to consider ways to counter a perceived economic and national security threat from new refineries in the Middle East, built to export petroleum products.

title: CONCERT: LUKAS FOSS AND ROBERTA PETERS
description: IT'S always a pleasure to visit the

title: NATIONAL SYSTEM TO TEST SCHOOLS IS ENDORSED
description: A group of the country's top state educational officials today endorsed the idea of a national system of achievement tests and other devices to measure the quality of elementary and high schools.

title: Four Irish Journalists Die in Air Crash
description: Four Irish journalists taking part in a race to bring back the first Beaujolais nouveau wine from France were killed when their light plane crashed and burned during a rainstorm tonight.

title: Republican Wins House Race
description: David S. Monson, a Republican, today defeated his Democratic opponent, Frances Farley, in a close Congressional race that ended with the counting of 1,500 absentee ballots.

title: Heisman Original
description: A ceremony at the Downtown Athletic Club on Dec. 1 will mark the 50th time that the 25-pound bronze statue called the Heisman Trophy has been awarded.

title: Afghan Children Reportedly Sent to Soviet
description: Western diplomats said today that the Soviet authorities in Afghanistan had begun a program to send thousands of primary-school Afghan children to the Soviet Union for at least 10 years of indoctrination into Communism and the Soviet way of life.

title: REAGAN ASKS HELP FROM CABINET ON CUTS IN GOVERNMENT SPENDING
description: President Reagan appealed to his Cabinet today to help ''dam the river'' of Federal outlays by accepting cuts and other savings aimed at further reducing the rate of growth in Government spending.

description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Del-Lords Perform At Irving Plaza
description: The Del-Lords twang and thump like country-rockers without ever turning their back on their hometown, New York City. Sharing a bill Friday at Irving Plaza with Human Switchboard, the Del-Lords played a set that was rowdy, danceable and hardheaded all at once.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THEATER: 'KID PURPLE' FROM FROM DONALD WOLLNER
description: BENJAMIN SCHWARTZ was born with ''a slight pigmentation abnormality.'' From the neck up, he is purple, and in grammar school his classmates make fun of him, calling him a grape. Naturally he responds by growing up to become the heavyweight champion of the world. Donald Wollner's new play, ''Kid Purple,'' is a comedy about parental expectation, peer prejudice and pugilism.

title: CHILE'S WOMEN EW A PROTEST MESSAGE IN FOLK ART HANGINGS
description: THEY took her only son away March 4, 1975. She has not seen him since. At first Anita wanted to commit suicide. (Her last name cannot be disclosed because she lives under the military dictatorship in Chile.) Then she began to look for her son, visiting hospitals, morgue, the psychiatric institution, the International Red Cross, detention centers and jails, to no avail.

title: Record Canceled
description: The Nov. 3 marathon time of Portugal's Cidalio Caetano, which appeared to have equaled the world record, has been canceled after judges found the course was short of the proper distance, Noticias de Portugal, a news agency, reported today.

title: SAUL, B.F. REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $843,000 from early payment of debt. c-Net income after gains of $1,424,000 for the quarter and $10,068,000 for the year from property sales and tax credits of $830,000 and $4,192,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-After a gain of $136,000 from a property sale and a loss of $843,000 from early payment of debt.

title: Stalin's Daughter Is Seen in Moscow
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, who returned to the Soviet Union after 17 years in the West, was seen leaving a hotel today. She told Western reporters she had nothing to say to them.

title: Viking Drug Issue
description: Les Steckel, the coach of the Minnesota Vikings, says that the club has been conducting regular but surprise drug tests on several players who, he says, have agreed to them. Such tests, according to Dick Berthelsen, counsel for the National Football League Players Association, violate the union's collective-bargaining agreement with the league, and Berthelsen has Article 31, Section 7 of the agreement to back him up.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary yesterday of a Queens civic leader and co-founder of a wholesale stamp supply company misidentified her in some editions. She was Trude Weishaupt.

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Perplexing the Forecasters
description: A trace of snow (less than one-hundredth of an inch) fell yesterday, slightly perplexing the National Weather Service but leaving the city's Sanitation Department unruffled.

title: Lambert's End
description: Jack Lambert, the Pittsburgh Steeler linebacker who has tried a series of comebacks since dislocating a toe in the season opener, may never be able to play again, according to Coach Chuck Noll. ''When he works, he ends up reinjuring it,'' Noll said.

title: Cowles Denies Merger Rumors
description: Cowles Media Inc. said yesterday that it was ''not for sale'' and disassociated itself from rumors that directors were seeking a merger with the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, which owns 14.3 percent of Cowles Media.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Cletis Boyer, the Oakland third- base coach, and Bill Caudill, the star reliever, were fined $250 and given suspended 60-day jail sentences in Cleveland. The punishment was imposed after they had pleaded no contest to charges stemming from a hotel bar-room dispute with two off- duty policemen who were serving as security guards. . . . . . . Ivan Lendl has qualified with John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors for the 12-man, $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament in January at Madison Square Garden.

title: FAR WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MICHIGAN PROFESSOR WINS SILBERT PRIZE
description: The last few years have been rough for many economists. Their forecasts have suffered during a period of volatile interest rates and swelling Federal budget deficits.

title: TEEN-AGE SMOKING IS PUBLIC TV TOPIC
description: A year after ''The Chemical People,'' public television's series aimed at teen- age drug and alcohol abuse, the program's producers are tackling another youth health problem - cigarette smoking.

title: A SLOW PACE FOR IRAN CLAIMS
description: When two Iranian judges pummeled a Swedish colleague two months ago at the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague, they apparently were expressing a dissatisfaction that many participants in the process share.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 14, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: WINE TALK
description: THE Beaujolais nouveau arrives tomorrow, as it does almost every year on Nov. 15. As in the past, the promoters have dreamed up a variety of stunts to show that theirs is the first bottle or case or whatever of the new wine to arrive in New York. No matter that it's been shown that all the races and competition are nonsense, that the wine has been here for days - the myth of the race goes on. ''It's symbolic,'' one importer said.

title: NATO Satellite Is Launched
description: A fourth and final satellite designed to provide communications between military forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization soared into space today from the Kennedy Space Center. The Delta rocket carrying the NATO III-D satellite blasted off at 7:34 P.M., rising like a fireball over the clear Florida night sky toward its initial elliptical orbit. ''Everything's looking good so far,'' Rocky Raab, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said after the launching.

title: DANCE: KOHL TROUPE
description: THE choreographic fantasies that Linda Kohl and Dancers presented Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. suggested that Miss Kohl seeks to cast magic spells. Unfortunately, none of them worked.

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A Human Touch In Computer Art
description: When Seattle Song's owners pulled the horse out of one of the Breeders' Cup races last week, Stacey McDonough gave a discouraged sigh. ''I just spent an hour on him,'' she said.

title: NOMINEE FOR CHIEF JUDGE
description: Ellen Ash Peters, nominated today by Gov. William A. O'Neill as Chief Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, was asked if being the first woman to head the state's highest court would put added pressure on her. ''That's bound to be a factor that I have to think about,'' Justice Peters said, ''but I believe the Governor chose me because he believed I was the best person for the job.''

title: 2 OFFICIALS HAVE LEFT ROTHSCHILDS' U.S. ARMS
description: The Rothschild family feud and the role of the legendary banking name in modern-day finance took another turn recently.

title: Bridge: The Post-Mortem of a DealMay Benefit as Time Passes
description: Nearly all bridge post-mortems are conducted quite briefly at the table. But they are likely to be more accurate if they are delayed until there is no time pressure. Some deals are subjected to both procedures, and the diagramed layout is an example. It was played in October in the Flight B regional Swiss teams in Swan Lake, N.Y.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE health effects of sunlight are common topics of discussion in June and July, when people bask in the brilliant rays, increasing the risk of skin cancer, premature wrinkling, sun-triggered allergies, eye injuries and, of course, sunburn. It may seem odd, then, to read a report about sunlight and health at this time of year, when many Americans do not even see much of the light of day, except perhaps on their way to or from work.

title: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Monday with a dispatch from Luxembourg about Grand Duke Jean's visit to the United States misidentified his wife.

title: Quitting for Good After only seven years, the Great American Smokeout has earned a worthy place on the nation's calendar of important annual observances. Tomorrow being the third Thursday of November, it's time to try, try again.
description: The American Cancer Society, which sponsors the event, estimates that as many as 19 million of the nation's 55 million smokers will take up the challenge of trying to quit for just one day. Surveys in past years indicate that as many as five million will make it, and perhaps half of those will still be off cigarettes for at least a few days.

title: Vincent J. Mutari, 62, Lawyer Active in Legal Help to Poor
description: Vincent J. Mutari, a lawyer who was active in civil rights and in legal services to the poor, died of heart disease Sunday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 62 years old and lived in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Dow Drops 12.59, to Close at 1,206.60
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday in heavier trading, reflecting the weakness in bond prices and concern over the huge Government budget deficits and the slowing economy.

title: FROM THE CAMPAIGN WHIRL TO THE RESUME WHIRL

title: MOST LIBYAN TROOPS IN CHAD YET TO LEAVE, U.S. AIDES SAY
description: United States officials said today that most of Libya's 5,500 troops remained in Chad despite a Libyan-French communique and a public statement by France's Foreign Minister that all Libyan and French troops had been withdrawn.

description: To the Editor:

title: General Cinema Proposes Stock
description: The General Cinema Corporation said its board had recommended the creation of 40 million shares of a new class B stock, subject to shareholder approval. The company said the move would enable it to make acquisitions for common stock without diluting the control of the Smith family.

title: IRA GUILDEN, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Ira Guilden, a New York investment banker and financier who was a major supporter of Israel's economic and cultural development, died of a heart attack Sunday while visiting the home of a friend in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FRANKIE GOES TO HOLLYWOOD
description: WILL success spoil Frankie Goes to Hollywood? ''Totally, I hope,'' said the band's lead singer, Holly Johnson.

description: More than 4,600 residents of New York City complained yesterday of heatless apartments as sharp northwesterly winds dropped a wintry chill on the metropolitan area.

title: WESTERN UNION MAY END PAYOUT
description: The Western Union Corporation, facing its second consecutive yearly loss, said yesterday that it might eliminate its quarterly dividend of 35 cents a common share.

title: FAUST, SKIING ON A SUNNY DAY AND THE DOLLAR VALUE OF LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sniper Reportedly Tried To Kill Himself Earlier
description: A sniper who killed a former Olympic athlete and then himself Monday at a stadium at the University of Oregon had tried to kill himself at the same site in July, friends said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on Monday, about the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, misattributed the comment that ''instead of Vietnam veterans building a memorial to give the Government, maybe the Government should have built a memorial to Vietnam veterans.'' The speaker was Jan C. Scruggs, president of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, not Secretary of the Interior William P. Clark.

title: NEW TACTICS ALMOST HALT EXIT OF SOVIET JEWS
description: After four years of waiting, the scientist had despaired of emigration when the passport office called him in for a talk, something it had never done before.

title: Get Serious About Work at Home If new Federal regulations survive court tests, it will again be permissible to knit ski wear at home for pay. The Department of Labor hyperbolically calls this a victory for the ''spirit of free enterprise.'' It is a victory for common sense, but there's much more serious thinking to be done about work in the home.
description: The Government prohibited such work in half a dozen different crafts in the 1940's, after studies found it to be a dodge around both the minimum wage and child labor laws. Rather extremely, the Carter Administration chose in 1979 to invoke the ban against 30 Vermont housewives who had been knitting ski caps at home.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WEAKER VESSEL. By Antonia Fraser. 544 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $19.95.

title: CONDUCTOR'S PAY TOPS $100,000
description: A 34-year-old Metro-North train conductor, working long hours under particular contract provisions, has been paid $102,723 so far this year and is likely to end 1984 with higher pay than the president of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's commuter rail line, officials said yesterday.

title: GANDHI CALLS VOTE FOR NEXT MONTH, 2 STATES EXCEPTED
description: The new Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today called a general election for Dec. 24 and 27.

title: DEADLOCK REMAINS ON LEBANON TALKS
description: Israeli and Lebanese officials failed today to break the deadlock over the reconvening of their withdrawal talks. It is unclear when, or even if, the negotiations over an Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon will resume.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at 9.274 percent, down from 9.379 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 9.287 percent, down from 9.349 percent last week.

The net for the year-ago quarter includes a loss equal to 3 cents a share from realized losses on investments and a gain of 1 cent a share from a tax credit. The net for the year-ago 9 months includes a loss equal to 2 cents a share related to realized losses on investments and a gain of 1 cent a share from a tax credit.

title: Attempt Fails to Halt Fire at Aircraft Facility
description: A fire burning two days in tar and insulation in the mile-long ceiling of the Air Force's largest jet engine maintenance facility today jumped a fire-break trench and neared a second one.

title: Expos to Pick Rodgers
description: Bob Rodgers, former manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, is expected to be named manager of the Montreal Expos today.

title: The Bishops and the Poor Who can dispute the Roman Catholic bishops' assertion that the current level of unemployment is ''morally unjustified''? Or that America is duty bound to share more of its wealth with the abject poor of the third world? The problem is not worthy ends but means.
description: The bishops' draft pastoral letter on the economy, like their 1983 statement on war and peace, appeals to conscience. Drawing on centuries of doctrine, it is not a sudden discovery of destitution nor a detailed blueprint for relief. Rather, it is a plea that America give priority to the human condition.

title: Testimony Heard OnConventStatus
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission heard more than five hours of testimony yesterday on a petition to designate a convent on the Upper East Side as a landmark.

description: Rising improbably from the prairie, where small herds of wild antelope still play, a gleaming new synthetic fuels plant 75 miles northwest of this city daily puts large quantities of gas into a pipeline system serving millions of consumers.

title: THE SCREEN: 'SNOWDROP FESTIVAL'
description: JIRI MENZEL'S ''Snowdrop Festival,'' the Czechoslovak film that opens today at the Film Forum, is like a month in the country. It's full of fresh air. It's soothing and it's just a little bit longer than is absolutely necessary.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1984 International A general election in India will be held on Dec. 24 and 27. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's decision to call for a vote on schedule was regarded as a further effort to insure stability and continuity after the assassination of his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, on Oct. 31. (Page A1, Col. 3.) Pierre Elliott Trudeau condemned the ''macho posturing'' of NATO members and urged Western countries to renounce the first use of nuclear weapons after sufficiently building up conventional forces. The former Canadian Prime Minister made some other new proposals to break the East-West deadlock, including a suggestion that Washington delay deployment of missiles in Europe to prod Moscow into making concessions. (A1:1-2.)

title: SUICIDE-PILL MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: TV (AND WITH IT THE WORLD) COMES TO MOGOLIANS
description: When Jimuya, a herdsman in Inner Mongolia, sold the wool sheared from his 200 sheep last spring, half of the $320 that he earned went to buy a locally made Swan television set.

title: RUTGERS BOWL HOPES DIM
description: Despite the presence of representatives from three bowls at the 23-19 upset of West Virginia last Saturday, Rutgers does not express much optimism about the chances of being picked for one of the postseason games.

title: KNICKS FIND 'DIAMOND IN THE ROUGH'
description: With an ironic smile, Ron Cavenall took note of the hand-me-down folder given him by the Knick coaching staff after yesterday's practice at Madison Square Garden. The orange binder of scouting reports had a label on its cover, with Cavenall's name squeezed in below Bill Cartwright's.

title: Unversity Sued on Ban Of Sex Counseling Ads
description: With the help of the American Civil Liberties Union, a student newspaper editor filed suit today against Louisiana State University for banning advertisements for abortion clinic and pregnancy counseling services.

SOLD: PICASSO'S 'WOMAN WITH A HAT
description: Pablo Picasso's ''Woman Seated With a Hat,'' a 1923 pastel depicting a voluptuous woman in a blue hat, was sold at auction last night at Christie's to a collector bidding by telephone. The buyer of the work, which had hung for 26 years in London's Tate Gallery, was not identified.

title: Bidder Is Blocked
description: It has been almost six months since David LeFevre, a New York lawyer, reached an agreement to buy the Cleveland Indians for $41 million. But after a series of lawsuits filed by some of the club's 64 limited partners, general partners and shareholders seeking to block or alter the sale, it still hasn't gone through, and LeFevre is now re-evaluating his offer. Faced with the prospect of two months' further delay as a result of a motion by a litigant, LeFevre said he and his lawyers were reviewing their legal options.

title: Behind the Malt Curtain
description: You may not be aware that the Government-controlled price of beer went up by 40 to 65 percent in Czechoslovakia a month ago, but Radio Free Europe assures us in its Washington newsletter that the move ''can be expected to do more to increase the unpopularity of the Government than any other belt-tightening measure introduced in the last five years.'' Softer Czechoslovak drinkers are in trouble, too, for the cost of canned orange juice went up about 50 percent.

title: Arrests Increase In Wife-Beatings
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that arrests had ''gone up significantly'' since new police procedures were instituted last April to deal with domestic violence.

title: June Duprez, 66, an ActressIn Movies and on Broadway
description: June Duprez, an actress seen in such films as ''The Thief of Baghdad'' and ''None But the Lonely Heart,'' died Oct. 30 at her home in London after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

title: THE CABLE TV LAW HURTS THE PUBLIC
description: President Reagan, late last month, signed the Cable Franchise Policy and Communications Act of 1984, an industry wish list in which Congress has given cable system owners a free hand to control every program and service they carry. Rather than establish a coherent national policy on cable television access, Congress succumbed to heavy lobbying by cable operators. The public, as usual, will be the loser.

Mrs. Torresy had lived abroad for 17 years, but she still knew of the area's reputation as a blighted neighborhood.

description: Negotiators for the city and 200,000 nonuniformed municipal employees are to meet today to begin working out plans to bring a mediator into their stalled contract talks.

description: The commander of NATO forces in Europe said here today that a revised military doctrine for fighting wars could eventually reduce the reliance on tactical nuclear weapons to deter an attack.

description: In a ruling with potential significance for voting rights enforcement throughout the South, the Supreme Court today upheld the boundaries for Mississippi's five Congressional districts as redrawn by a Federal court to comply with the recently amended Voting Rights Act.

description: The White House said today that President Reagan ''welcomes'' a proposed pastoral letter on the economy by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops, but would refrain from commenting on it.

description: By comparing Nicaragua to Cuba and talking about the possible delivery of advanced fighter aircraft to the Sandinistas, the Reagan Administration has tried in the last week to portray Nicaragua as a direct threat to the security of the United States.

title: OFF THE STREET, PROSTITUTION IS FLOURISHING
description: While the New York City police made 17,000 arrests for prostitution last year, nearly all were made on the street, leaving the illicit industry flourishing indoors almost without impediment, according to law enforcement authorities.

description: The former head of Vietnamese affairs for the Central Intelligence Agency startled the Westmoreland- CBS libel trial yesterday by shouting from the witness stand that CBS lied in its 1982 documentary charging a military cover-up of enemy strength in South Vietnam in 1967.

description: Mayor Koch defended New York City's reputation to Spanish reporters today, denying that the city is the world capital of crime.

description: A blind woman arrested after refusing to leave her seat near an airplane emergency exit pleaded not guilty today to a disorderly conduct charge, saying airline policies restricting seating for the disabled were discriminatory.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I bear solemn witness to the fact that NATO heads of state and of government meet only to go through the tedious motions of reading speeches, drafted by others, with the principal objective of not rocking the boat.'' - Pierre Elliott Trudeau, former Prime Minister of Canada. (A1:1.)
