description: Suffolk County does not expect to be able to block the loading of nuclear fuel at Shoreham, the chief deputy county executive said yesterday.

title: JESSE THE HELMSMAN
description: WASHINGTON Consider the dilemma of Jesse Helms, the victorious conservative Republican Senator from North Carolina.

title: BUTCHER, 2 OTHERS ARRESTED
description: Jacob F. Butcher, the Tennessee banker, and two associates were arrested today on Federal indictments charging them with conspiracy and bank fraud in connection with the failures last year of two banks that Mr. Butcher controlled.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CAROLE BROWNELL hailed the cab at 12th Street in Greenwich Village, her destination being Henry Street in Brooklyn Heights. The cab had both front and back speakers. The driver was Jan C. van Arkel, who was playing tapes of classical music, and in the course of the ride to Brooklyn he and Miss Brownell, a public-affairs consultant, got onto the subjects of music, weather, summer, England. Miss Brownell said she'd been there recently. Mr. van Arkel said he'd been there, too, and that his hobby is preserving and playing pipe organs. Indeed, he modestly informed his passenger, some summers ago he played the organ at the Royal Albert Hall in London. The occasion was a Promenade Concert - an informal sort of musical event similar to the Mostly Mozart series - at which Mr. van Arkel was joined by the BBC Symphony Orchestra as well as the BBC Chorus.

title: Seven-Up Shift To Aspartame The Seven-Up Company, the
description: nation's third-largest maker of

title: Police Rout Students In Seoul Party Office
description: Hundreds of students stormed and occupied the offices of the ruling Democratic Justice Party overnight to press demands for full democracy in South Korea. Early today, policemen broke through a wall and arrested 264 students.

title: REAGAN AND HIS TOP AIDES CONFER ON HOW TO RESUME ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan met today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, to discuss how to revive arms control talks with the Soviet Union.

title: DANCE: 'THE ART OF WAR' BY CUMMINGS AND HAGEDORN
description: ''THE ART OF WAR/NINE SITUATIONS,'' a new theater-dance piece conceived by Blondell Cummings in collaboration with Jessica Hagedorn, sets out the world with an unusual scope and density of texture. Miss Cummings and Miss Hagedorn have taken on the idea and practice of warfare, both as a science and as a metaphor for the everyday wars and death of the heart.

title: LITTLEFIELD ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITIZENS' GROUP BECOMING WATCHDOGS OF NURSING HOMES
description: THEIR numbers having grown from only a handful a decade ago to more than 250 now, citizen-run nursing-home-information organizations throughout the country are acting as consumer watchdogs and public advocates for the more than 1.4 million elderly residents in America's long-term-care facilities.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE DANCE: PREMIERE AT JOYCE
description: HANS VAN MANEN, from the Netherlands, has been a major choreographer in Europe since the 1960's, and his works are usually seen here with major companies. It was unusual, then, for the American premiere of one of his ballets to be given Tuesday night by Boston's Dinosaur Dance Company at the Joyce Theater.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; President Named At World Airways
description: World Airways said yesterday that it had named Arthur H. Hutton president, effective immediately. The announcement followed the resignation of Donald L. Beck, who had held the position of president and chief executive officer at the financially troubled carrier since May 1.

title: A FORMER ENVOY
description: Louis A. Lerner, a Chicago newspaper publisher and the United States Ambassador to Norway in the Carter Administration, died of cancer yesterday at the University of Illinois Hospital in Chicago. He was 49 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $4,395,000 for the quarter and $9,032,000 for the 9 months. c-Including realized gains on investments of $28,331,000 for the quarter and $94,405,000 for the 9 months.

title: 'Zero, None, Zip, Nada'
description: At 7:30 on election night last week, with the polls still open in 42 states, Dan Rather came on CBS and said, ''Good evening, everyone. Can Ronald Reagan make it a 50-state sweep?'' The President, he said, was piling up electoral votes. Walter Mondale had ''zero, none, zip, nada.''

title: WRITER ON CONSTABLE WINS MITCHELL PRIZE FOR ART HISTORY
description: The art historian and writer Graham Reynolds has won the $10,000 Mitchell Prize for the history of art in 1984, it was announced today. The annual prize, which was founded in 1977, is given to an author who writes in English about the visual arts.

title: Cancer Society Prepared For 'Smokeout' Today By The Associated Press
description: Smokers struggling to kick their habits in today's eighth annual Great American Smokeout will have a cheering section that will include Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, who asked non-smokers to lend moral support to smokers trying to quit.

title: CALIFORNIA HELD IN CASE OF CROATIAN WAR CRIMES
description: A Croatian Cabinet minister under the Nazis, whom American authorities have repeatedly sought to deport as a war criminal, was arrested yesterday at his home near Los Angeles on a new extradition request by Yugoslavia, officials announced.

title: ROCKET STREAK ENDS AT 8
description: Herb Williams scored 26 points and Terence Stansbury added 25 tonight for Indiana as the Pacers handed the Houston Rockets their first loss this season, 125-117.

title: BRANDYWINE SPORTS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
'DEBATING' BRITISH CREATIVITY
description: The new international language is the language of marketing, John F. Bergin, president of McCann-Erickson, told the closing session of the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Camelback Inn here today.

title: ANIMAL RIGHTS IN BRITAIN: THE HUNTERS ARE HUNTED
description: The eagle and the arctic foxes refused to leave, but Marquis, a 10-year-old European wolf, fled when the Animal Liberation Army freed him in a raid on a Scottish wildlife park before dawn on Monday. He had killed two park sheep and was stalking the deer by the time officials, worried about children living nearby, overcame him with a tranquilizer dart.

title: TOP REAGAN CAMPAIGN AIDE IS PASSED OVER FOR POSTAL JOB
description: The board of the United States Postal Service today announced its choice of Paul N. Carlin to become the 66th Postmaster General, rejecting a last-minute appeal from the White House to give the $82,900-a-year job to Edward J. Rollins, director of the Reagan-Bush campaign committee.

title: AN ISRAELI GENERAL ON A STRANGE BATTLEFIELD
description: Ariel Sharon sat stolidly in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday with his stocky arms folded across his chest and his eyes straight ahead as hour after hour a lawyer went through a cavalcade of portrayals of Mr. Sharon as ''a murderer,'' ''a monster'' and ''Israel's Minister of Death.''

title: Weaver Prefers Leisure
description: Earl Weaver , for 14 1/2 seasons the skipper of the Baltimore Orioles and for the last two years a television commentator, said he turned down six offers to manage in 1985 because he decided ''this would be my first full year of retirement.'' He decided, he said, that the competitive fires were not burning hotly enough, and added, ''Maybe these feelings will come back to me.''

title: U.S. Says It Will Help Turkey Update and Fortify Air Bases
description: The United States will help to modernize two air bases in eastern Turkey and provide air defense systems for at least two others, Richard Perle, United States Assistant Secretary of Defense, said today.

title: Atlantans Lose Effort To Block Carter Parkway
description: A Federal judge today rejected a request by a group of residents to block construction of a 2.4-mile parkway that would cut through their neighborhood on its way to Jimmy Carter's planned Presidential library.

title: STOCKS WEAKEN, BUT DOW INCHES UP
description: The stock market posted its sixth consecutive setback yesterday as prices again fell amid growing fears about the slackening economy.

title: Denver Airport's $170 Million Issue
description: A $170 million issue of revenue bonds for the Stapleton Airport in Denver was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.504 percent for bonds due in 2000, according to underwriters led by Boettcher & Company.

title: Way to Stop Choking Without Help Cited
description: Dr. Henry J. Heimlich, who originated the ''Heimlich maneuver'' to save those with obstructed windpipes, yesterday described a new method for a choking victim to save himself.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Intelsat, the satellite communications consortium, misidentified the director general. He is Richard R. Colino.

title: Southern Miss. Admits Violation
description: Southern Mississippi said today that 11 violations cited by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in the recruiting of Donald Palmer, a prep football standout, ''are substantially correct.''

title: Carnegie-Mellon Wins Pentagon Software Unit
description: The Defense Department today selected Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh as the site for a $103 million Software Engineering Institute.

title: City Investing's Severance Pay
description: George T. Scharffenberger, chairman of the City Investing Company, will collect at least $17.9 million in severance pay and retirement benefits when the company goes out of business, papers sent to stockholders showed yesterday. Peter C.R. Huang, president, will collect at least $12.7 million.

title: General Strike Brings Bolivia to a Standstill
description: Bolivia was paralyzed by a general strike today, and the opposition urged the Government to resign and call early elections.

title: A FEW FUMBLES ASIDE, IVY FOOTBALL DREW CROWD
description: They missed a touchdown in their first game, had to extricate a skunk from their equipment in the third and lost their power for the first half-hour of the seventh, but the producers of the first telecasts of Ivy League football on public television have attracted nearly 700,000 viewers each Saturday.

title: REZONE SCHOOLS, BUT KEEP DECENTRALIZATION
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFENSE INEPT AS NETS FALL
description: Despite the loss of Walter Davis, their best player, to an injury before the season, the surprising Phoenix Suns have bolted to the top of the Pacific Division.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 25 about the Control Data Corporation misstated its involvement in the disk drive business. The company has announced that it will stop making disk drives for large I.B.M. computers.

title: THIRST IN WEST FOR FARM WATER MAY BE COSTLY
description: Like a puddle drying in the desert sun, Federal support for Western irrigation projects is drying up, and the farmers and ranchers are looking for new ideas and new friends to help them get the money, and the water, flowing again.

title: FRENCH CENTRAL BANK HEAD QUITS AFTER DISPUTES
description: The head of France's central bank resigned today following a series of unusual public disputes with the Government over economic policy.

title: MACY, R.H. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CHAD THERAPEUTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL-STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Secretary Gets Reprieve In Legal-Advice Case
description: Gov. Bob Graham granted a 30-day reprieve from jail today to Rosemary Furman, a secretary who has been denounced by the Florida Bar Association as practicing law without a license.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ONE MORE APARTMENT HOUSE FIRE AND 148 MORE HOMELESS PEOPLE
description: The fire started in the basement of the East Harlem apartment building, and by the time the firefighters brought it under control yesterday morning, 58 more families had been added to the growing list of poor people in New York who have no homes and little chance of finding them soon.

title: KNICKS, WITH KING OUT, ARE DEFEATED BY CELTICS
description: It looked like a joke. The Knicks, already without their regular power forward and centers, took the court tonight against the defending National Basketball Association champion Boston Celtics without their leading scorer, Bernard King.

title: MURPHY, G.C. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: The 9 months results in 1984 included a non-taxable extraordinary gain of $664,000, or 16 cents a share, resulting from the exchange of 68,973 common shares for $3 million principal amount of debentures. The 9 months results for a year ago included $1,381,000, or 34 cents a share, from the exchange of 102,742 common shares for $4.7 million in debentures.

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $13,903,000 from oil-field rental equipment inventories, accounts receivable and accruals for lease commitments for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a gain of $4 million from a discontinued employee benefit plan.

title: Brink's Robber Sentenced
description: Richard Thomas of Philadelphia, convicted of his second attempt to rob a Brink's guard, was sentenced Tuesday to 8 to 20 years in prison for a holdup attempt last year at a Sears, Roebuck & Company store. Judge William T. Nicholas ordered the sentence to run consecutively with an earlier 10- to 20- year prison term that the 31-year-old defendant is already serving for the earlier Brink's robbery.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Mortgage Agency Sets Offering of $556 Million
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $556 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The obligations, backed by more than $630 million of conventional home mortgages, are also backed by the corporation.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Results for the latest year include a tax gain relating to domestic international sales corporations equal to 4 cents a share.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Baldwin-United Corp. , Cincinnati, said it had completed the sale of its limited partnership interest in Central Colorado Co. to Ameritrust Corp.

title: SLAIN PRIME MINISTER HONORED
description: Two weeks after her assassination, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was named today as the winner of the 1984 Jawaharlal Nehru Award for International Understanding.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 15, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $28,800.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Potato Blight in Idaho
description: The blight that struck Ireland's potatoes 140 years ago has hit Idaho's crop, but experts say modern disease control methods can easily halt the outbreak. About 3,000 acres of seed-potato fields in eastern Idaho have been affected by the disease, late blight, which rots potatoes.

title: Brazil Seeking Iraq Oil Deal
description: Brazil is negotiating with Iraq to trade cars for oil, the state petroleum company, Petrobras, said today.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago revenues have been restated.

title: Schlichter May Start
description: Art Schlichter , the quarterback who missed last season because of a league-imposed suspension for compulsive gambling, may get his first pro start next Sunday, when the Indianapolis Colts play the New England Patriots. ''I think he deserves an opportunity,'' said Coach Frank Kush , whose club has gone nowhere this season with Mike Pagel and Mark Herrmann calling signals.

title: KEEPING BELTS IN ORDER
description: THERE are better ways to organize belts than to toss them in an already-cluttered drawer or hang them precariously on a wire hanger. Several gadgets designed to arrange belts to make them easily accessible are available.

title: Warsaw Rights Panel Called on the Carpet
description: The authorities called in organizers of Warsaw's new human rights committee today and told them they could face five years in jail if they persist in their activities.

title: BRONX GROUP STARTS PUSH TO ATTRACT INDUSTRY
description: A campaign to lure industry and investors to the Bronx was begun yesterday by Borough President Stanley Simon and a group of political and business figures.

title: 40 FRENCH, 40 U.S. JETS FOR GREECE
description: The Greek Government announced tonight that it had decided to purchase 40 American F-16G jet fighter planes and 40 French Mirage-2000's to meet the needs of its air force over the next decade.

title: MUSIC: NATIONAL ORCHESTRA OF NEW YORK
description: a training ensemble under the direction of Alvaro Cassuto - plays regularly scheduled concerts as part of its learning process, and on Tuesday night it opened its 1984-85 season at Carnegie Hall. Alan Hovhaness's 18- year-old ''Ode to the Temple of Sound'' was given its first New York performance, Malcolm Frager was on hand to play Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 and the concluding work was Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique.''

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nine Challenges Of Ads Resolved
description: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus reports that nine challenges to national advertising were resolved in October. Six were resolved when the advertising was withdrawn or modified and three when N.A.D. agreed that the advertisers had substantiated their claims.

title: A CUOMO PANEL PLANS TO SUGGEST INCOME-TAX CUT
description: A package of New York State tax changes focusing on income-tax cuts has been drafted by a panel appointed by Governor Cuomo.

title: INDIRA GANDHI REAPED THE INDIAN WHIRLWIND
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ONE SMALL STEP
description: ST. LOUIS There was an unusual celebration

title: DEBATE SPONSOR: A DORMANT INSTITUTE WAKENS
description: As sponsor of the talks today between opposing sides in El Salvador, the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions is stirring from a seven-year slumber.

title: CHILE STATE OF SIEGE ATTACKED
description: The Archbishop of Santiago today denounced the state of siege imposed by Chile's military Government.

title: A Friend Indeed Is Priest's Pacer
description: The winner of the $75,000 Ireland Fund Purse at Yonkers Raceway on Saturday night was, appropriately, a 6-year-old pacer named Caramore whose name in Gaelic means ''big friend.''

title: Chrysler Delay In Plant Plans
description: The Chrysler Corporation will delay its planned $250 million renovation and expansion of a Fenton, Mo., plant to continue producing the models currently made at the plant, a company official said.

title: MONDALE OUTLINES SOME OF HIS PLANS
description: Relaxing at this scenic vacation island after suffering a historic election defeat, Walter F. Mondale said today that he would return at least briefly to his former law firm in Washington.

title: LaPorte Winner
description: Juan LaPorte, the former World Boxing Council featherweight champion making his first start as a junior lightweight, scored a unanimous 10- round decision over Dwight Pratchett of Gary, Ind., last night at the Felt Forum. LaPorte, who weighed 131 pounds, knocked down Pratchett in the ninth round on the way to improving his record to 26-5. Pratchett is 10- 5.

title: Koreans Talk About Trade
description: South Korea today called for economic cooperation with North Korea as unprecedented trade talks opened here.

title: Jameson Is Chosen For Bantam Software
description: Bantam Books Inc. has assigned to Jameson Advertising the introduction of a line called Bantam Software from its Bantam Electronics Publishing division.

title: Housing Aide Resigning
description: Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. said today that his principal deputy, Under Secretary Philip Abrams, would leave his post by the end of the year. Mr. Abrams will return to private industry where he was a developer of multifamily housing.

title: PACIFIC GAS TRANSMISSION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $3 million, or 32 cents a share, reflecting Pacific Gas's share of proceeds from the sale by the company and Natural Gas Corp. of California, an affiliate of Pacific Gas and Electric Co., of their combined rights to some deep leasehold interests with low heating value reserves.

title: SISTER-IN-LAW PLANS TO RUN AGAINST GANDHI
description: Maneka Gandhi, the estranged sister-in-law of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and a bitter opponent of his mother, Indira, announced today that she would run against Mr. Gandhi in the general election next month.

title: CALENDAR: WORKSHOPS FOR HOLIDAY GIFTS
description: Holiday Gift Workshops, Y.W.C.A.,

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from investments of $1,449,000 for the quarter and $66,038,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains from investments of $4,840,000 for the quarter and $35,218,000 for the 9 months. The Reliance Insurance Co. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: HEALTH FOOD COMPANY IS INDICTED ON PROMOTION OF OIL OF PRIMROSE
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that General Nutrition Inc., which runs a chain of 1,000 health-food stores, had been indicted on charges of improperly promoting one of its products, oil of primrose.

title: MASTER CHEF'S BODY IS DISCOVERED IN HIS SAN FRANCISCO APARTMENT
description: Masataka Kobayashi, master chef at several of the best-known restaurants in the country, was found dead in his apartment here Tuesday, possibly the victim of murder. He was 45 years old.

title: SANDINISTAS WIN 63 PERCENT OF VOTE IN FINAL TALLY
description: The ruling Sandinistas won 63 percent of the votes cast in the Nov. 4 presidential election, according to official final results published today.

title: Structural Crack Cited In Sinking of Oil Ship
description: An unexplained crack led to the flooding of two storage tanks and the capsizing of an American oil drilling vessel during a typhoon off the China coast, Federal investigators concluded today.

title: ; PUBLIC ACTIVISM IS NEEDED ON THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: ZAPATA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.9 million for the quarter and $4.9 million for the year. c-After a gain of $4.7 million on a stock-for-debt swap.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Panel Rejects Plan For Seaport Tower
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, meeting in executive session, has rejected a plan to build a 43-story apartment tower at the north end of the South Street Seaport Historic District.

title: CREATING SPACE FOR BABY: MEETING A MANHATTAN CHALLENGE
description: ''WE were thinking of starting a family and the studio next door became available,'' said Stephen Newman. ''We realized we could use the extra space for the extra person.'' Mr. Newman and his wife, Catherine, bought the 300-square-foot studio next to their 725-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side in June 1983. Several months after the purchase, the couple, both lawyers, learned that Mrs. Newman was pregnant. There would be room for the baby.

title: THEATER REBELS OF 60'S GATHER TO REMINISCE
description: The Class of '64 held a reunion on Tuesday night. The immediate reason was to celebrate the 41st birthday of one of its famous sons, Sam Shepard. But in a broader sense it was an occasion for the theatrical rebels of 20 years ago to remember, to take stock.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SEIZES FIRST WHITES IN WAVE OF UNREST
description: The South African security police detained white political activists today for the first time since the country's latest spate of unrest began in early September. A major crackdown continued, meanwhile, on black labor leaders after a huge protest strike in South Africa's industrial heartland around Johannesburg last week.

title: HOLYFIELD FUTURE IS IN HIS HANDS
description: At first, Lou Duva thought Evander Holyfield must have been etched in bronze, because the fighter just stood there, like a statue, ignoring the trainer's instructions to sprint.

title: Burlington to Shut Plant in Ireland
description: Burlington Industries said it intends to close its finishing plant for textured woven polyester fabrics in Gilloge, Ireland, because of reduced demand for the product in Europe as a result of fashion changes, and increased competition from Far East imports.

title: Messiah Sing-In
description: The annual Messiah Sing-In - in which the audience is the chorus for Handel's Messiah - will take place Dec. 19 at 7:30 P.M at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: BOONE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Report Urges Overhaul Of Banking Supervision
description: An Administration report scheduled to be formally released this week will press Congress to overhaul the Government's unwieldy system for watching over financial companies, partly by reducing the number of bank supervisors.

title: Baseball Talks Are Opened
description: Baseball players and club owners opened talks on a new labor contract yesterday, with both sides expressing hope that they could avoid the hostility that led to a two-month shutdown of the major leagues three years ago.

title: SHOPS FOR THAT UNUSUAL ANTIQUE
description: WERE it not for the old shop sign in front of Valley House Antiques in Locust Valley, L.I., the little turn-of-the-century cottage could easily be mistaken for a private home.

title: 'ALL ABOUT YOU,' DEVOTED TO KIDS
description: THERE are nice little programs on television, not catering to the many, but devoted to the few. Consider ''All About You.'' It is a series, each episode only 15 minutes long, and it deals with anatomy, physiology and psychology. Its audience is made up mostly of first and second graders, but because television programming is democratic the rest of us may watch, too. The episode today, ''Take a Deep Breath,'' will be shown on Channel 13 at 1:30 P.M.

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $400,000 for the quarter and 9 months from a nonrecurring forgiveness of income tax associated wth the company's domestic international sales corporation unit. c-Net losses from discontinued operations of $3,915,000 for the quarter and $4,007,000 for the 9 months.

title: NEW CURBS ON INDUSTRY UNDER STUDY
description: In the last two years, the Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills nearly quintupled in size, swelling to $4.9 billion in assets, from $1 billion at the end of 1982. It often paid top dollar to attract funds quickly.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt
description: * Banque Nationale de Paris is lead manager of its own issue of $400 million of 15-year floating-rate Euronotes paying 1/8 point over the six- month mean of the London interbank bid and offered rates.

title: GRAY BREAKS HAND, DOUBTFUL FOR CARDS
description: The Giants said today that Earnest Gray, their most experienced pass receiver and their leader this season with 38 receptions, had fractured a bone in his right hand. Coach Bill Parcells said Gray was doubtful for the key game Sunday here against the St. Louis Cardinals, which meant he had only a 25 percent chance to play.

title: BANK MONEY ACCOUNTS
description: Bank Money Accounts Money6-monthMarketC.D.'s(%)(%) Bankers Trust *9.85*9.70 Chase Manhattan *9.64*9.69 Chemical Bank *9.69*9.74 Citibank *9.42*9.64 Manufacturers Hanover *9.31*9.97 Bowery Savings 10.2510.75 Dime Savings (N.Y.) 10.5011.00 Dollar Dry Dock Savings *9.7610.75 Goldome 9.4210.79 Metropolitan Savings 10.0711.00 City Federal (N.J.) 9.5410.45 First Fidelity (N.J.) 8.849.50 Midlantic National Bank (N.J.) 9.03*9.50 United Jersey Banks 9.11*9.99 Connecticut Bank & Trust 9.1110.20 Connecticut National 9.1110.13 People's Bank (Conn.) *9.3810.25 Bank Rate Monitor Index* 9.3910.05 **Annual effective yields offered by 50 large institutions in the five largest U.S. markets.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ares-Serono Group, Geneva, a pharmaceutical and diagnostics company, has named John E. Roelker president and chief operating officer.

title: Butch Keeling of Rangers;Helped Win '33 Stanley Cup
description: Melvin (Butch) Keeling, who scored 147 goals while playing left wing for the Rangers in 1928-1938, died in Toronto Monday after a heart attack. He was 81 years old.

title: Robert Ludlum Sued Over 'Gandolfo'
description: A playwright has sued the novelist Robert Ludlum, claiming he is entitled to at least $500,000 because Mr. Ludlum stole his idea of kidnapping a pope to write ''The Road to Gandolfo.''

title: SECOND SATELLITE IN SPACE RESCUED BY 2 ASTRONAUTS
description: With joyous ease and the sureness of experience, two space-walking astronauts captured a second wayward satellite today and hauled it into the cargo bay of the shuttle Discovery for the dramatic completion of the first salvage operation in space.

title: CRABLE INJURY ELEVATES CLIFTON
description: Kyle Clifton, a rookie from a college that won only seven games in his four years there, suddenly found himself today as the present and future middle linebacker of the Jets.

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: Once again this week, the familiar flames flickered in the night sky over Boston. Again there were the shouted commands, the blur of moving figures playing out the hoses, the crackle of the dispatchers' voices on the radio, the ascending roar of the fire.

title: The John Bull Flies
description: At the National Museum of American History, it is not considered trivial to know the answer to the question ''What is the oldest operable self-propelling vehicle in the world?'' The answer, according to the museum's curator for transportation, is a wood-burning steam locomotive called the John Bull, sent here from England in 1831.

title: BLACK HAWKS RALLY TO BEAT RANGERS
description: The plot had turned out well before for the Rangers: Play half-alertly in the first period, find the spirit in the second period and surge ahead, and then cruise on in for a victory. But tonight the story twisted one time too many. The Rangers faltered in the third period and lost to the Black Hawks, 5-4.

title: British Earnings Up
description: Average earnings in Britain rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in September from August and climbed 6.4 percent from September 1983, the Department of Employment said today.

title: Bank of Boston Selling Building
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said it had reached an agreement to sell its 37-story headquarters for $365 million.

title: Caution on Vitamin E For Premature Is Urged
description: Giving high doses of vitamin E to premature infants to prevent eye disease and blindness is ineffective and could be dangerous, two new studies have found.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FRENCH CONNECTIONS

title: O'Neill Appoints JudgetoTopCourt
description: The chief presiding judge of the State Appellate Court, Joseph F. Dannehy, was appointed today by Gov. William A. O'Neill to the State Supreme Court, Connecticut's highest court.

title: Financial Corp. May Restate Nets
description: The Financial Corporation of America said it may have to reduce its previously reported profits for 1980 and 1981.

title: SHEA STADIUM WON'T GET ARTIFICIAL TURF
description: The city has dropped plans to install artificial turf in the renovation of Shea Stadium, municipal officials said yesterday. ''It is the best grass field in the majors,'' Deputy Mayor Robert Esnard said. ''If you have everybody happy, why spoil it?''

title: DOCUMENT PRAISED AT BISHOP PARLEY
description: Roman Catholic bishops expressed enthusiasm today in their first public discussion of a proposed pastoral letter on the nation's economy.

title: Air Base Fire Under Control
description: A stubborn two-day fire that burned 700,000 square feet of the roof of a maintenance building at Tinker Air Force Base was brought under control about 4 A.M. today after firefighters made a five-foot-wide trench on the roof that flames could not cross. A damage assessment team is to make recommendations on how to clean up or repair the mile-long building, a base spokesman said. The Oklahoma Air Logistics Center, of which the building is a part, is one of only six places nationwide that provide maintenance for Air Force planes.

title: F.T.C. REJECTS DEFECTS STICKERS FOR USED CARS
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced final approval today of a rule that provides used car buyers with more information, but drops an earlier provision that would have required dealers to post known defects on window stickers.

title: RECITAL: KROSNICK PLAYS CELLO WORKS OF MODERNS
description: SINCE the beginning of this year, the cellist Joel Krosnick has been engaged in a venturesome, six-recital survey of 20th-century American cello music, the final program of which took place Monday evening at the Juilliard Theater. One could complain that Mr. Krosnick's range of repertory wasn't quite as wide as he thought it was (not enough experimental scores, for instance) and that not every performance was at his own highest level. Still, this has been a bold venture, and Monday's program had much to recommend it.

title: Investor Group Ends Dorsey Bid
description: The Dorsey Corporation said it had bought 1,064,600 shares, or about 28.5 percent of its common shares outstanding, from an investor group for $33 a share plus $1 a share in related costs and expenses.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Tunnel Ties Delays, Too
description: Commuter train riders have discovered that the new Center City Commuter Tunnel, hailed as the connection between the city's two commuter rail systems, has also linked their delays. Officials of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority said 34 out of 100 morning trains were more than five minutes late to their destinations on Tuesday, the first full working day of service.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: GROUNDED AIRLINE MAY RESUME FLIGHTS NEXT WEEK
description: Provincetown-Boston Airline, which was grounded Saturday on charges of ''fraudulent'' actions in qualifying pilots and other safety violations, could resume limited small-plane service as early as next week, Government sources said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, a dispatch from Omaha on Friday, about the convictions of three men charged with helping a fugitive who killed two United States marshals, misidentified the appeals court and one defendant. The ruling was by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The defendant was Scott Faul.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $2,500,000 from the sale and lease back of a shipyard facility. c-Includes gains from tax benefits of $4,639,000 for the quarter and $14.9 million for the 9 months.

title: Vietnam Reports Clash
description: Vietnamese border guards killed 15 Chinese soldiers and captured two others after the group penetrated 800 yards inside Vietnam on Friday, Radio Hanoi said today in a broadcast monitored in Bangkok. China and Vietnam have fought sporadically along the border and have exchanged artillery fire since their brief war in 1979.

title: FIVE NAMED AS WINNERS OF LASKER MEDICAL RESEARCH AWARDS
description: Three scientists whose discoveries laid the basis for mass production of identical antibodies, a researcher who developed a magnetic method of producing images of the body's interior and the man whose ''Heimlich maneuver'' has saved thousands of people from death by choking have won Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards.

title: 16 Stores Reopen After Fire at Mall
description: Sixteen stores in the Walt Whitman Mall reopened for business today, one day after a fire closed the shopping center.

title: Offer for Mediflex
description: HBO & Company said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Mediflex Systems Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at about $83 million. HBO, based in Atlanta, and Mediflex, with headquarters in Evanston, Ill., both provide information-processing services to the health care industry. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Mediflex jumped $1.75, to $15.50.

title: Obstacles Remain
description: By appealing the decision, Florida has effectively postponed sanctions imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for numerous violations and cleared the way for the football team to play in a bowl this season - almost. The Southeastern Conference may yet act to impose immediate sanctions of its own that would bar the Gators from winning the S.E.C. championship, from the resulting honor of acting as host at the Cotton Bowl and from playing in any other bowl.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 'SLOW' SEASON, ITALIAN STYLE
description: Music lovers, art patrons and socialites will gather Thursday evening at Firenze House, the palatial residence of the Italian Ambassador, Rinaldo Petrignani, and his Danish-born wife, Anne, for a ''Divertimento Musicale'' to benefit the Theater Chamber Players of Kennedy Center.

title: MX CABLE GIVES AIR FORCE AND SIOUX A BOND
description: For almost two weeks last month, an Indian medicine man combed the windy plains of eastern Wyoming, looking for any of his ancestors' graves that might be in the path of a communications cable for MX missiles.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Note and Bond Prices Fall
description: Note and bond prices declined yesterday as securities dealers struggled to attract buyers for new and recent offerings by the United States Treasury and various state and local governments.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $2,357,000 for the quarter and $1,431,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $2,721,000 for the quarter and $3,912,000 for the 9 months.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1984 Lebanon decided to resume talks with Israel on an Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon after the Israeli Army in southern Lebanon released three of four Shiite Moslem militia leaders and reportedly pledged to free the fourth one soon. The talks are to resume today. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) Several C.I.A. officials objected to discipline over the agency's production of a manual for Nicaraguan rebels, contending they were being made ''scapegoats'' to protect senior agency officials, according to Reagan Administration and Congressional informants. They said the several disciplined middle-level agency officials contended they had no role in approving the manual. (A1:3.)

title: Another Delay For Wollman Rink
description: The reopening of the reconstructed Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park has been delayed once again.

title: Islanders Sharpen Checking
description: The hitting was earnest, but done with some jest nonetheless. And when the practice finished, Pat Flatley, Bryan Trottier and Bob Nystrom, with smiles on their faces, alternately took turns checking one another into the boards and reveling in their little hard-hitting conquests.

title: IZOD'S FALL FROM VOGUE A DRAG ON GENERAL MILLS
description: Yesterday General Mills was bitten by its little alligator.

title: Bridge:For a While, Austria Seemed To Be New Team of Destiny
description: When the first multi-team world championship was played in 1937, Austria emerged as the winner. That country has not won a similar title since, but seemed to be the team of destiny in the recent Olympiad in Seattle.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income for all periods include $128,916 from amortization of net assets acquired in excess of costs. Net income for the latest 9 months includes a gain of $586,557 on the sale of land.

title: New Vintage Faces Its First Challenges
description: The signs go up today all over France, and maybe Madison Square Garden: Le Nouveau est arrive! Mere coincidence, perhaps, but the celebration of the harvest is the same. In France, it is the annual arrival of the beaujolais nouveau, the first wine ready for consumption. At the Garden, tonight's show celebrates the crop of 1984 Olympic boxers.

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Doctors And Women
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:The Hers columns of Perri Klass have impressed me with their humanity - the extra dimension of empathy for the variety of people, staff and patients she interacts with as a young medical student. Although she is a ''new woman,'' she is not willing to follow the traditional male model in a profession that has historically been dominated by men.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $672,000 and a tax credit of $247,000. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: Whither Laxalt?
description: There is increasing talk among

title: Cattle Supply Grows
description: Cattle being fed for the consumer market as of Nov. 1 in the seven major beef-producing states totaled 8.22 million head, up 7 percent from one year ago and 1 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: D.A.B. Talks End
description: D.A.B. Industries said talks on its possible acquisition by TRW Inc. had been terminated. It said the two companies expect to continue their business relationship. In over-the-counter trading today, D.A.B. shares plummeted $4, to $8.

title: Docutel/Olivetti
description: The Docutel/Olivetti Corporation, which reported a loss in the third quarter, said it had put into effect a freeze on pay increases for salaried personnel as part of its cost-control efforts. The company said it lost $11.9 million on sales of $44.1 million in the third period, in contrast to a profit of $710,000 on sales of $60.4 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: AN ARGUMENT IN FAVOR OF SUPERTITLES FOR OPERA
description: OPERA was meant to make peace between music and language, but judging from the arguments over supertitles which now race back and forth across the pages of our press, opera's synthesis of the arts seems to have divided itself into a war of words.

title: Dow Jones Appointments Dow Jones & Company said
description: yesterday that Peter R. Kann

title: FLEXWATT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Serkin to Play Beethoven
description: The pianist Rudolf Serkin will perform an all-Beethoven program Dec. 8 at 8:30 P.M. at Long Island University's Concert Theater in Greenvale, L.I. Tickets are $20 to $22.50, and are available from Friends of the Arts (516-922-0061).

title: DOCTORS AND WOMEN
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:I was very interested in the Hers column (Nov. 1) about women in the hospital. I recently took my 2 1/2-year- old daughter to the pediatrician's office, where all the doctors are men and the nurses women.

title: CHAMPION PONDERS SCALING HIGH WALL
description: Alicia McConnell has never forgotten the feeling. It was about

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RIGHTS FOR TERRORISTS?
description: WASHINGTON Down in the murky depths of the Reagan bureaucracy, where the light of landslides never penetrates and the sound of Cabinet voices cannot be heard, a move is afoot that would enhance the international status of terrorist organizations and give individual terrorists new rights in war.

title: CONCERT: 'MUSIC FROM MARLBORO'
description: THE Marlboro Music Festival, Rudolf Serkin's summer retreat in Vermont, has for two decades sent out touring groups under the rubric ''Music From Marlboro,'' which opened its anniversary season with an all- strings concert Monday evening at Tully Hall.

title: INSURER'S CAPITAL RAISED BY AMERICAN EXPRESS
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had added $200 million to the surplus of its Fireman's Fund Insurance unit, most of which was to comply with a ruling by the California Insurance Department.

title: A NEW FLOWER SHOW FOR NEW YORK'S SPRING
description: A major flower show will make a comeback next March. Last seen in New York in 1970 as the International Flower Show, it was held in the Coliseum. This edition, known as the New York Flower Show, is scheduled for March 20 to 24 in a new home, the Hudson River Exhibition Pier, at 50th Street. Plans were announced yesterday at a fund-raising breakfast at Gracie Mansion.

title: Chicago Issuing Mortgage Bonds
description: Chicago, which sold the first tax-exempt single-family mortgage revenue bonds in 1978, is offering $113.6 million of new bonds with a maximum yield of 10.583 percent for bonds due in 2010.

title: Macy's Net Drops 27%
description: R.H. Macy & Company reported a 27 percent drop in net income for the quarter that ended Oct. 27, its first quarter of the fiscal year 1985. The decrease was in line with the trend at other retailers, as sales have weakened and promotional outlays have risen.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARGE CARRYING SUBWAY RAILS CAPSIZES AND SINKS
description: A barge carrying more than six miles of new subway track sank in high winds off the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday, minutes before the cargo was to have been delivered to the Transit Authority.

title: Big Write-Down By Trimac Ltd.
description: Trimac Ltd. said it had written down the carrying value of its Cactus drilling companies by $53.8 million (Canadian) in the third quarter, and had begun excluding Cactus accounts from its consolidated revenues. It said negotiations were taking place with the subsidiaries' primary lender for a financial restructuring.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ADM. HERBERT E. SCHONLAND, MEDAL OF HONOR HERO, DIES
description: Rear Adm. Herbert E. Schonland, retired, died Tuesday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospitals, exactly 42 years after the sea battle in which he won the Congressional Medal of Honor. He was 84 years old and lived in New London.

title: DISNEY, WALT PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $165,960,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: SHARON TESTIFIES HE CAME TO U.S. TO DEFEND TRUTH
description: Ariel Sharon, on the witness stand in Manhattan, confronted an unfamiliar battlefield. About New York, page B8.

title: Swiss Jobless Rate Up
description: Swiss unemployment climbed to 1.1 percent in October, up from 1 percent in September and nine-tenths of 1 percent in the year before, the federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The agency said 33,055 people were unemployed in October.

title: BABY FAE RALLYING WITH 2 NEW DRUGS
description: Baby Fae rallied again today and gave signs that she might be defeating her body's attempt to destroy her transplanted baboon heart, according to hospital officials.

title: LEBANESE DECIDE TO RESUME TALKS AND ISRAEL RELEASES 3 OF 4 SHIITES
description: Lebanon decided today to return to the troop withdrawal negotiations with Israel after the Israeli Army in southern Lebanon released three Shiite activists and reportedly promised to free a fourth soon.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Racing Board Suspends Jockey for Second Time
description: Victor Lopez, a 23-year-old jockey at Aqueduct, was suspended indefinitely by the State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday after a drug test on Nov. 9 revealed traces of cocaine. It was the second such suspension for Lopez, whose license is likely to be revoked.

title: 24th GameofTitleMatch Is Postponed by Karpov
description: Anatoly Karpov has taken a timeout in the world chess championship match, postponing the 24th game with Gary Kasparov until Friday, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $2.5 million for provision for losses on office space lease commitments. c-Net income

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chief at Thompson Has Stiff Challenge
description: As Burton J. Manning sees it, beer is ''an absolutely fascinating product.''

title: 14 WOMEN HONORED FOR ACHIEVEMENTS
description: A NUN who reunites women in prison and their children at the Bedford Hills Correctional Center in New York was among 14 women over the age of 40 honored yesterday by the Wonder Woman Foundation. Each winner received $7,500.

title: The Phillips Booms
description: Many Washingtonians consider the Phillips Collection their favorite museum, in part because it is off the crowded tourist path, situated in a mansion near Duport Circle.

title: PIANO CONCERT: VALDEZ MENA
description: OSCAR LUIS VALDEZ MENA, who presented a piano concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday evening, is at his best in the music of his native Dominican Republic. Two direct and uncomplicated works by R. Bullomba Landestoy - ''Marionetas-Romantico'' and ''Danza Loca'' - were played with rhythmic vitality, a big tone and an endearing directness. Mr. Valdez Mena was also proficient in some witty 20th- century music from France, including works by Erik Satie, Francis Poulenc and Darius Milhaud.

title: Kohl Is Said to Seek A Meeting With Reagan
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl is seeking an early meeting with President Reagan to urge the United States to improve East-West relations and revive discussions with the Soviet Union on medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe, a Government official said today.

title: DISNEY HAS LOSS OF $64 MILLION
description: Walt Disney Productions, operating under new management for less than two months, said yesterday that it took a $166 million write-off in its fourth quarter, ending Sept. 30, which produced a loss for the period of $64 million. The company earned $24.5 million in the fourth quarter a year ago.

title: First Lady Asserts Dizziness From Bump on Head Is Over
description: Nancy Reagan, who danced with her husband at a star-studded state dinner for Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg, says she has fully recovered from her recent dizzy spells.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $30,354,000 for the quarter and $31,641,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $491,000 for the quarter and $1,991,000 for the 9 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Democracy is a process that has to be built every day.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net realized loss of $231,000 for the quarter and a net realized gain of $355,000 for the 9 months on investments. c-After net realized gains on investments of $600,000 for the quarter and $1,460,000 for the 9 months.

title: MONDALE'S COURAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO: RUTH SLENCZYNSKA
description: HOW many pianists still in middle age can celebrate the 50th anniversary of their New York debuts? Since Ruth Slenczynska made her debut at Town Hall at the age of 8 - ''an electrifying experience; something nature has produced in one of her most bounteous moods,'' wrote The New York Times critic - her youthful longevity is easier to understand.

title: '68 MEMO BY C.I.A. AIDE READ AT CBS LIBEL TRIAL
description: Thirteen years before he became a paid consultant to CBS-TV on its 1982 documentary on Vietnam, a C.I.A. analyst told his superiors that Gen. William C. Westmoreland's command had engaged in a ''monument of deceit'' regarding estimates of enemy strength in the Vietnam War.

title: Italy Industrial Output
description: Italy's industrial production doubled in September from August as factories resumed after the summer holidays, but output was down 2.1 percent from the comparable period 12 months before, the State Statistical Institute said today. Over the first nine months of the year, output climbed 3.1 percent from the year before.

title: Utility Abandons Marble Hill Nuclear Plant
description: Public Service Company of Indiana Inc.'s directors today formally announced the cancellation and abandonment of the $2.8 billion Marble Hill nuclear power plant.

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIBUNAL IN ARGENTINA RESIGNS
description: The eight remaining members of Argentina's highest military court submitted their resignations today.

title: Investors Trust Obligations
description: Investors G.N.M.A. Mortgage- Backed Securities Trust is offering $300 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Mortgage Securities.

title: INDIA HOLDS SECURITY AIDE TO INDIRA GANDHI IN CONSPIRACY INQUIRY
description: Officials investigating the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have arrested a member of her security team and interrogated several of her bodyguards in what the prosecutor today called ''a criminal conspiracy.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about prostitution gave an incorrect title for Bernard Cohen, who has written a book on the subject. He is a professor of sociology at Queens College.

title: Transactions
description: Gates Brown, batting coach, resigned. CLEVELAND (AL) - David E. LeFevre, New York lawyer, withdrew his offer to buy club because of continued litigation involving minority stockholders. MONTREAL (NL) - Named Bob Rodgers, former manager of Milwaukee Brewers, as manager. BOSTON (AL) - Named Rac Slider, manager of New Britian of Class AA Eastern League, to replace Tony Torchia as manager of Pawtucket of International League. Torchia moves up to the parent club. BASKETBALL NETS (NBA) - Signed Tom LaGarde, forward-center, and waived Mike Wilson, guard. SEATTLE (NBA) - Placed Scooter McCray, forward, and Danny Young, guard, on waivers and activated Reggie King, forward, and John Schweitz, swingman and a rookie free agent. BOXING NEW YORK STATE ATHLETIC COMMISSION - John Branca resigned as commissioner. COLLEGES NORTHERN ARIZONA - Hired Larry Kentera to replace Joe Harper as football coach. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Released Warren Bryant, offensive tackle, and added Mike Chapman, guard-center, to the roster. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Signed Glen Young, wide receiver, and Greg Best, safetyman, to fill roster berths vacated by Duriel Harris, receiver, who was put on waivers, and Tim Stracka, tight end, who was placed on injured reserve. DALLAS (NFC) - Released Harold Carmichael, wide receiver; re-signed Jimmie Turner, linebacker, and placed John Warren, punter, on waivers. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Signed Ted Petersen, offensive tackle, to replace Ellis Gardner, offensive lineman, who has been placed on injured reserve list. LOS ANGELES RAMS (NFC) - Signed Mike Shriner, tackle; Mike Pleasant, defensive back, and Francois Wise, tight end. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Signed the following free agents for 1985: John Kimmel, linebacker who played in the United States Football League, and Neil Maune, a guard from Notre Dame who was waived by Dallas in 1984 preseason.

title: MIDLANDS ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said a lower effective income tax rate increased latest quarter net by about $1 million. The year-ago figures are on a pro- forma basis. The company was spun off from KN Energy Inc. in December 1983.

title: Lost Birthday
description: There will be no birthday party this year for Zina Garrison, the 20-year- old tennis player from Houston who on Nov. 4 captured her first professional tournament, the Swiss Indoor championships at Zurich.

title: MARCOS FOE SLAIN
description: A leading Philippine opposition figure was shot dead today in the Mindanao city of Zamboanga.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Hidden Boon in Profit-Sharing
description: For all the good news these days, there is little reason to believe that basic economic problems have been licked for good. Another oil shock, uncurbed Federal deficits or a misstep by the Federal Reserve could cause a deep recession or steep inflation.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1984
description: The Economy

title: STAGE: 'ROMANCE LANGUAGE' OPENS
description: TO write a play about the history and meaning of the American imagination, one must have dreams as big as the territory. For all that's sloppy, juvenile and exasperating in ''Romance Language,'' the new Peter Parnell play receiving an exquisite production at Playwrights Horizons, it is the creation of a bold writer with an abundant vision.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STALIN'S U.S.-BORN GRANDDAUGHTER IS SUBJECT OF AN AMERICAN INQUIRY
description: The United States Embassy said today that it had asked the Soviet Union for information about Olga Peters, the 13-year-old American-born granddaughter of Stalin who was brought here by her mother last month.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gretzky, Oilers Stopped EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 14 (UPI) - Mario Tremblay and Mats
description: Naslund had a goal and an assist each, and the Montreal defense held

title: BLACKMUN SEES THREAT TO CIVIL RIGHTS PROTECTION
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court cautioned last night against a growing tendency to reduce key Federal civil rights protections in the name of cutting caseloads and increasing the power of the states.

title: JAPAN DENIES PACT TO END ALL WHALING
description: Japanese officials today denied American reports that Japan had agreed to end all commercial whaling by 1988.

title: Another Japan Candy Maker Receives Extortion Demand
description: The so-called poison candy gang is demanding $250,000 from a second Japanese candy manufacturing company, but a spokesman for the company said today it had not handed over the money.

title: Quake in North Philippines
description: An earthquake shook the northern Philippines today and people fled buildings in the province of Ilocos Norte but no injuries were reported, the Government geophysical observatory reported. A spokesman said the epicenter was 180 miles north of Manila.

title: A Free Ride
description: ''Hudson Tunnels.'' The words gleam again - polished brass set against the chocolate brown cast- iron canopy of the PATH station at Christopher Street.

title: Southmark in Bid
description: The Southmark Corporation said it had signed an agreement to acquire the Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company, a Midland, Tex., syndicator of oil and gas drilling partnerships, for about $32 million. Southmark is a real estate company with headquarters in Dallas.

title: HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,138,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1.6 million for the 9 months. c-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $2,266,000. d-Including a tax credit of $6.7 million.

title: IN COLORS TO MATCH
description: ELLEN FINE, above, is a straightforward person with distinctive ideas. ''I began with the concept of translating ready-to-wear trends into home furnishings,'' said Miss Fine, who recently opened Fine Design, a small shop that offers an intriguing mix of wares.

title: MENTAL HEALTH REPORT
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Net income

Nixon Urged Reagan's Aides To Focus on Industrial State
description: President Reagan's campaign strategists received advice from former President Richard M. Nixon several months ago that led to a decision to target Ohio as one of the main states in Mr. Reagan's re-election effort.

title: Whites in S.I. Group Accuse Police of 6 Years of Brutality
description: The New York City Commission on Human Rights said in a report issued yesterday that there was a ''perception'' among some white residents of Staten Island that they were ''victims of police brutality,'' including beatings, in the last six years.

title: What Background?
description: On Tuesday a White House spokesman gave reporters a briefing on the Reagan Administration's justification for its policy in Central America in general and in Nicaragua in particular. Under the rules of the briefing, the reporters agreed to attribute the views only to anonymous ''Administration officials.''

title: Dioxin Danger to Scouts Termed Very 'Remote'
description: The national Centers for Disease Control said today that dioxin contamination at a site where 32,000 Boy Scouts camped in 1981 was unlikely to have caused harmful effects and those who were exposed need not seek medical attention.

title: PANEL SEES SOME POLICE RACISM IN NEW YORK
description: A House subcommittee has concluded that ''racism appears to be a major factor in alleged police misconduct specifically and in police-community relations generally'' in New York City.

title: REGENTS MAY MODIFY PLAN TO UPGRADE THE SCHOOLS
description: Part of the sweeping new plan to strengthen the curriculum in schools throughout New York State may have to be modified even before it takes effect because student schedules cannot absorb the extra courses, according to some members of the Board of Regents.

title: Amax May Take a Big Charge
description: Amax Inc., a minerals and energy company, said yesterday that it might take a big charge in the fourth quarter to adjust the carrying values of its depressed agricultural chemicals business. The company said the adjustment could result in a charge against net and retained earnings of ''less than $200 million.''

title: JURY HEARS MATTHEWS IN TAPE ON BIDS
description: Former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City, in a secretly recorded conversation played in Federal court today, talked of giving a company seeking a contract with Atlantic City an edge over its competitors.

title: POP MUSIC: CULTURE CLUB AND BOY GEORGE PERFORM
description: IT was only two years ago that

title: SALVADORANS, IN U.S. DEBATE, SIDESTEP A REBEL TRUCE PLAN
description: In a televised debate here today, a senior Salvadoran Government official sidestepped a proposal by Salvadoran rebel leaders that they begin discussing a formal cease-fire in their five-year civil war.

title: Landlord Arrested In Fire Fatal to 8
description: The owner of a house where eight people died in a fire Sunday has been arrested on six charges in connection with failure to install smoke detectors, the authorities said today.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rev. King Is Praised At Memorial Service
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. was remembered tonight as someone who was ''so good no evil on earth could make him hate,'' despite the murders of both his son and wife.

title: Ralph J. Furey Dead;Star Columbia Athlete
description: Ralph J. Furey, the director of athletics at Columbia University from 1943 until 1968, died yesterday in Durango, Colo., after having been hospitalized for four days. He was 81 years old.

title: THE RISE OF BANKING LAW: LOVE THEM LOOPHOLES
description: Time was when a young lawyer, out to make a reputation, would give little thought to specializing in banking. It was, some said, a staid, risk-averse industry; its legal foundations, dating from the 1930's, seemed firm and fast. There just was not a lot of law to interpret, it was widely believed.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Accord Cited in Dalkon Cases
description: Nearly 200 cases alleging injury from the Dalkon Shield intrauterine device have been settled, an attorney for the plaintiffs said today, and the amount was reported to be about $38 million.

title: HANOI LINKED TO CAMBODIAN TORTURE
description: A visiting American civil rights group says that Vietnamese Government officials are widely involved in the arrest and torture of Cambodian citizens.

title: PROFIT SURPRISE FROM INSURER
description: THE New York Stock Exchange scored a competitive coup on Oct. 10 when the American

title: The Peril of the Missing MIG's
description: The Administration's post-election war of nerves against Nicaragua continues with ominous fervor. The campaign, inspired by a mistaken report about MIG deliveries, has made a virtue out of sloppy American intelligence and a vice out of Nicaragua's alarmed response. It has involved the release of secret reconnaissance information whose disclosure is normally condemned as treason. And it plays crudely on American sensitivities about another superpower confrontation in the Caribbean.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $951,000 for the quarter and $1,078,000 for the 9 months on the sale of real estate. c-Including a gain of $806,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: Mental Health Panel Urges Major Changes
description: The Governor's Commission on the Future of the Mental Health System released its final recommendations in Albany yesterday and called for a gradual shift of mental health services from state psychiatric centers to community-based agencies.

title: CARNATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAPITAL AIR GETS ESOP PROPOSAL
description: The employees of Capitol Air Inc. yesterday proposed a plan for them to eventually control 56 percent of the troubled company in return for wage concessions.

title: CHICAGO JUDGE INDICTED IN CORRUPTION INQUIRY
description: Cook County Circuit Judge Richard F. LeFevour, his cousin and six other people were indicted today as part of Operation Greylord, the undercover Federal investigation of judicial corruption here.

title: Another Chance
description: Coach Dennis Green seemed destined for dismissal after Northwestern lost to Purdue, 49-7, on Oct. 27. Green was in the final season of a four-year contract that had produced 8 victories and 35 defeats.

title: An Expensive Gift
description: Members of the New York Public Library's board of trustees oohed and aahed in unison yesterday over the lavish facsimile of ''Les Tr es Riches Heures du Duc de Berry,'' the treasured 15th-century Latin prayer book and one of the world's most beautiful manuscripts.

title: THE SOFTWARE TROUBLES AT MANAGEMENT SCIENCE
description: When Management Science America Inc. brought its brand-name marketing approach to the microcomputer software business, many analysts said the company had resources to make the strategy work. Last month, however, the company declared its three- year venture into the industry a failure and announced it would sell or spin off its personal computer software division, Peachtree Software Inc.

title: INDIA'S TEA CONSUMPTION SURGING
description: It is called ''chai'' in Hindi, and it is usually taken sweet and light, with hot milk and lots of sugar. It has become India's favorite drink by far, from the fancy restaurants in big hotels to the poorest villages and the meanest stalls in the most raffish bazaars.

title: SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $382,000 for the quarter and $9,093,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after tax credits of $184,000 for the quarter and $2,113,000 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months net includes a pretax gain of $42.9 million in connection with the sale of the company's investment in Gulf Corp.

title: Yields on C.D.'s Fall for 4th Week in Row
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts plunged for the fourth consecutive week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. The Monitor's national index of money market accounts fell to 9.39 percent, from 9.49 percent, as the index of six-month C.D.'s declined to 10.05 percent, from 10.28 percent.

title: A Traffic Jam
description: Within sight of City Hall, on the morning after city officials declared their latest this-time-we- mean-business campaign against traffic congestion (dubbed ''Gridlock Busters''), there was this:

title: HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Auerbach's Opinion
description: Red Auerbach , the longtime Boston Celtic coach and general manager who now serves as the team's president, had a thing or two to say the other day on the subject of high school and college administrators who exploit athletes and give them unearned diplomas. ''Does a high school or college have to win so bad,'' he asked during a lecture in Springfield, Mass., ''that the principal, superintendent, condones such a thing?''

title: Nov. 1-10 Car Sales Fell by 4.7 Percent
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's six major auto manufacturers slipped 4.7 percent in the first 10 days of November, the companies reported here today.

title: Kicker's Dream Goal
description: Only Tony Dorsett , the Heisman Trophy winner who accounted for 356 points as a Pitt running back from 1973 to 1976, scored more points in college football than Luis Zendejas , the Arizona State place-kicker, who reached the 355 mark last Saturday in the victory over Oregon. And when it comes time for Zendejas to break Dorsett's record - perhaps as early as the first quarter Saturday against Colorado State - Zendejas wants to do so the Dorsett way.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hood, Hope Acquires Yount-Moeller
description: Hood, Hope & Associates, Tulsa, Okla.'s largest ad agency, with billings of about $30 million, has acquired Yount-Moeller Inc. of Tulsa for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock.

title: CUTTING DOWN ON DIESEL'S ILLS
description: NOT so long ago, American drivers were being told that diesel oil was the wave of the future; that the diesel automobile was the solution to low fuel economy and high prices at the pump. That forecast failed to come true for a number of reasons, but now technology has eliminated at least two of them: smoke and odor.

title: FINDING ADVICE AND INFORMATION
description: ''EVEN if you've planned

title: NICARAGUA WARNS OF A MOVE BY U.S.
description: Nicaragua told the Organization of American States today that the United States was looking for ''the right moment and the political excuse'' to intervene in its territory.

title: LEWIS GALOOB TOYS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. FILES RIGHTS SUIT AGAINST SAN FRANCISCO
description: The civil rights division of the United States Justice Department filed suit Tuesday against the City of San Francisco, charging its Fire Department with discriminatory hiring policies.

title: CITY OPERA BOASTS A SMASH SEASON
description: The New York City Opera's first combined summer-fall season, which ends on Sunday, has been an unexpected success at the box office, according to Beverly Sills, general director of the company.

THURSDAY SPORTS Boxing
description: The Night of Gold, at Madison Square Garden, 7 P.M. This is the long-awaited card comprising the professional debuts of six Americans who won medals at the Olympics last summer. The pairings, with the medalist listed first in each, are: Mark Breland vs.

Greatwest Hospitals Fills a Top Position
description: Greatwest Hospitals Inc. announced yesterday that William C. Scott had been elected president and chief operating officer.
