MODIGLIANI WORK SOLD FOR RECORD
description: Amedeo Modigliani's ''Dreamer,'' a 1917-18 version of the only horizontal image ever painted by the Italian artist, aroused worldwide interest and intense bidding by several American collectors when it was auctioned last night at Sotheby's.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doug Flutie , the Boston College quarterback, has signed to play on the East team in the Hula Bowl on Jan. 5, according to The Honolulu Advertiser. . . . Sam Bowie , the Portland Trail Blazers' rookie center, sprained his ankle in a game against the Dallas Mavericks and will be out 10 to 12 days, the club said. . . . As expected, John Branca resigned as chairman of the State Athletic Commission to run for Mayor of his hometown, Mount Vernon.

title: Opera by P.D.Q. Bach
description: Peter Schickele will present excerpts from ''The Abduction of Figaro,'' his latest ''discovery'' from the works of ''history's most justifiably neglected composer,'' P. D. Q. Bach, at Avery Fisher Hall Dec. 27, 28 and 29 at 8 P.M. and Dec. 30 at 3 P.M. According to Mr. Schickele, ''The Abduction of Figaro'' is P. D. Q. Bach's only known opera, and will be performed by the New York Pick-Up Ensemble and members of the Minnesota Opera Company. Also on the program are the ''Missa Hilarious'' and two madrigals, including ''The Queen to Me a Royal Pain Doth Give.'' Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50, available through the box office or Centercharge (874-6770).

title: Martin Bookspan Takes Music Consulting Post
description: Martin Bookspan has been named consultant to the National Westminster Bank USA Arts in the Garden series, it was announced yesterday.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said earnings for the latest quarter and 6 months include an after-tax provision of $2.2 million for a possible settlement with the Internal Revenue Service for a proposed tax deficiency totaling $7.2 million for the years 1975 through 1977. The company said the $2.2 million provision is for the period 1975 through Sept. 30, 1984.

title: RETAIL SALES OFF IN OCTOBER
description: Retail sales dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the third monthly decline since June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Infants Contract AIDS From Healthy Mothers
description: Six infants in New York have contracted aquired immune deficiency syndrome from their healthy mothers, supporting the theory that the disease can exist in a remissive state that can become deadly when passed on to infants, researchers said today.

title: Yamani's Oil Views
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today that OPEC's production cutback appears to have stabilized world oil prices and that the group might be able to pump more oil starting next month.

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,500 for the latest 9 months and $12,781 for the year-ago 9 months.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Just to keep things in perspective, Peter and Vicky Markstein want to make it perfectly clear that they do not - repeat, do not - bear the dogs in this world or their owners any ill will. As a matter of fact, they have a dog themselves - a frisky boxer named Toby.

title: THE SUBMERGED COSTS OF TRIDENT 2 MISSILES
description: To the Editor:

title: 30-YEARS OF WORK BY PIONEER IN GLASS
description: A 30-YEAR retrospective of the work of Harvey K. Littleton, tomorrow through Jan. 12 at the American Craft Museum, explores studio glass through the works of one of its pioneers.

title: Alexander C. Neave,86,Dies; Ex-Head of PatentLawGroup
description: Alexander C. Neave, a retired lawyer and former president of the New York Patent Law Association, died last Friday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: A French Minister
description: A group of feminists gathered the other night at Betty Friedan's to meet Yvette Roudy, the French Minister for Women's Rights. She's here preparing for the international world conference on women, to be held in Nairobi, Kenya, in 1986.

title: JOHN DE PROSPO
description: John De Prospo, the former executive officer of WNYC, the New York City municipal radio station, died Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 81 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -it-yourselfers may be, some will need contractors sooner or later, either because the job is too large to tackle or because it calls for specialized tools and materials. Unfortunately, the experience can lead to unpleasant complications and disappointments - not because contractors are fly-by- night operators or are unethical but because many homeowners simply do not know how to hire and deal with them.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SEX ABUSE INQUIRY FINDS NO EVIDENCE OF CHILDREN DEATHS
description: Investigators have found no evidence that any children who were victims of sexual abuse in Scott County were murdered, but that does not mean the slaying reports were fabricated, the authorities said today.

title: ALBANY G.O.P. AIDE CALLS FOR A $1 MILLION CITY TRANSIT FARE
description: The chief fiscal spokesman for Republicans in the State Senate said yesterday that subway and bus fares in New York City should be raised to $1 - and commuter rail fares also should rise - as part of a package to balance the budget of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BLACKS NOT MUCH WORSE OFF UNDER REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: A BRITISH WRITER WHO LOVES THE SOIL
description: ''THE best way to learn is from the original sources,'' said Rosemary Verey, the English author and garden designer, whose conversation includes a generous smattering of the advice she has gleaned from history's great gardeners.

title: CALLING ALL DPL'S
description: A telephone extension in the State Department's Office of Foreign Missions is answered these days with the words: ''Diplomatic Motor Vehicle Office.''

title: ABC '20/20' SEGMENT ON CHILD ABUSE PUT OFF
description: ABC said yesterday that a segment of its television magazine ''20/20,'' about charges of child sex abuse in a private nursery school in California, was being postponed until next month. The segment had been tentatively scheduled for tonight.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BUDGET AIDES SAY DEFICIT TO EXCEED $200 BILLION IN '86
description: Budget officials now forecast a deficit of about $200 billion for the next fiscal year if no actions are taken to cut spending or increase revenue, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: AT COMPUTER SHOW, MANY RETRENCHING
description: The personal computer industry's premier trade show, Comdex, opened here today with a smattering of new product announcements and a host of retrenchments by companies whose once-optimistic predictions for a booming 1984 have gone awry.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
description: ''We are saying, 'Give to your small brothers,''' Juan Antonio Samaranch said the other day. The ''small brothers'' are the nations that sent athletes to the Olympics in Los Angeles. The ''big brother'' is the host country, which realized an unprecedented $150 million surplus from those Games.

title: No Home Team
description: Army has fielded football teams since 1890 and the University of Montana only seven fewer years, but the meeting Saturday between the Cadets and Grizzlies will be the first and both teams will be on the road. The site will not be West Point or Missoula, but Memorial Stadium in Tokyo before a capacity crowd of 80,000 at the eighth Mirage Bowl.

title: Max Gissen, Ex-Books EditorAt Time Magazine Dies at 75
description: Max Gissen, who served as books editor of Time Magazine for 20 years until his retirement in 1967, died last night of heart arrest at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: Ford Motor Credit
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $100 million of 12 percent notes due in 1989 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 12.068 percent. Underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's, may be called by the company at any time at a price of 102. Goldman, Sachs & Company, Ford Motor Credit's regular investment banker and distributor of its commercial paper, was a co-lead manager of the offering.

title: CANADA'S OFFICIAL RESIDENCES: THE POLITICS OF REDECORATION
description: OTTAWA

title: 'FRAUD' IN NICARAGUA
description: The most fraudulent thing about the Nicaraguan election was the part the Reagan Administration played in it.

title: LeFevre Cancels Offer for Indians
description: David E. LeFevre, a New York attorney, today withdrew his offer to buy the Cleveland Indians because of continued litigation involving some of the minority stockholders.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.75-12.00 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR IS NAMED ON NEW CHARGES
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego, already facing charges regarding campaign financing, was indicted again today by a county grand jury on charges involving acceptance of a $3,000 check in 1981 from J. David Dominelli, a San Diego financier, for a list of political contributors.

title: TRULY INSPIRED GIBBERISH
description: I am, perversely perhaps, a collector of malapropisms. When I left the United States for an extended time, I knew exactly what I was going to miss most, apart from my family and friends: American plumbing and telephones, baseball and football, autumn in New England - and Howard Cosell, who once called Baltimore ''an imbued city,'' and who described a thrown bottle as ''a dangerous instrumentality.''

title: SETTLEMENT REACHED IN 1975 CRASH OF ORPHANS' JET
description: Lawyers for 78 of the Vietnamese orphans who survived a crash near Saigon of an Air Force transport plane in April 1975 today announced a settlement under which the Government and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation would pay more than $17.8 million.

title: 60'S TROUPE TAKES POLITICAL ACTIVISM ON THE ROAD
description: The San Francisco Mime Troupe, a group identified with the activism of the 1960's, is barnstorming the Middle West with a strong message about industrial decline.

title: Hesitation in Brazil Brazil's long and fitful shift from one-party military rule to civilian democracy has hit another snag. Some military leaders are having second thoughts about a process that may make the opposition's candidate the next President, and there is talk of aborting the scheduled transition.
description: A president is to be chosen by an electoral college on Jan. 15, ending 20 years of military rule. The favorite is Tancredo Neves, a civilian first put forward by the opposition Brazilian Democratic Movement Party.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $961,000 which represents equity in an insurance claim of an affiliate. c-After an extraordinary credit of $961,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $807,000. The year-ago 9 months net was restated and reduced by $3,362,000 to reflect the reversal of adjustments made to increase the value of LIFO inventories that had previously been written down to market at Dec. 31, 1982.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATES BANK'S CHARGE-OFF
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating possible violations of securities laws in connection with the First National Bank of Chicago's unexpected charge-off of $278 million in bad loans in the third quarter, the First Chicago Corporation, which owns the bank, disclosed yesterday.

title: THE THEATER: DARIO FO, 'DEATH OF AN ANARCHIST'
description: Unitl the State Department at last lifted its ban and granted him a visa this month, the leftist Italian playwright Dario Fo was deemed too incendiary to be admitted into the United States. Theatergoers who now visit the first Broadway production of a Fo work, ''Accidental Death of an Anarchist,'' can't be blamed if they wonder what all the fuss was about. The farce at the Belasco is considerably less biting than the average David Letterman monologue and not nearly as funny.

title: Money Fund Assets Climb Assets of the nation's money
description: market mutual funds continued

title: Muncie Ineligible
description: Chuck Muncie, the running back who is undergoing rehabilitation for drug problems, has been declared ineligible for the remainder of the National Football League season by Commissioner Pete Rozelle . The announcement was made by the office of the San Diego Chargers, who hold Muncie's contract.

title: Moody's Raises Chrysler Ratings
description: The senior debt rating of both the Chrysler Corporation and its Chrysler Financial Corporation subsidiary was raised to an investment grade level of Baa-3, from a speculative grade of Ba-2, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: U.S. LISTS TECHNOLOGY EXPORT CURBS
description: The Defense Department made public today a previously secret list of technologies regarded as militarily critical that may not be exported to the Soviet Union, its allies or nations with the potential for acquiring nuclear weapons.

title: NEW REPRODUCTION TECHNIQUES REDEFINE PARENTHOOD
description: What makes a parent? That once- simple question has been complicated in recent years by the development of techniques that one law professor has termed ''noncoital collaborative reproduction,'' the introduction of third, fourth or even fifth parties in the creation of a child.

title: STAGE: SPALDING GRAY AS STORYTELLER
description: Where it not for the absolute simplicity of the presentation, one might be tempted to say that Spalding Gray has invented a performance art form. Sitting at a card table and talking to the audience, he offers a virtuosic evening of autobiographic storytelling. With the perspicacity of a master travel writer, he acts as reporter, comic and playwright of his own life.

title: Singapore Growth
description: Singapore's gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 8 percent in the third quarter, down from 9.2 percent in the second quarter, the Ministry of Trade and Industry said today.

title: Japan-U.S. Financial Talks
description: Two days of discussions on measures to liberalize Japan's financial markets ended today with the United States criticizing Japan for acting too slowly to open its markets to foreign competition.

title: FAULTY LOANS DECLINE AT ONTINENTAL ILLINOIS
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that its level of nonperforming loans declined in the third quarter to $949 million, or 3.6 percent of its loan portfolio, after it transferred $400 million of Penn Square Bank-related loans to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Diner's Journal
description: New York has its share of eccentric restaurants, but perhaps none is so delightfully bizarre as Chez Leonie (1711 First Avenue, between 88th and 89th Streets), a tiny storefront dining room run by a jaunty Haitian woman who serves Creole fare that is as spicy as her personality. The restaurant looks like a palm reader's salon, with huge, dripping candelabras, pale yellow walls, faded photographs and a half-dozen mismatched tables and chairs. A vintage phonograph in the back room plays lilting island tunes.

title: COORS SEEKS TO REGAIN CACHET USING $625 MILLION LEVERAGE
description: A decade ago the fortunes of the Adolph Coors Company brewery based in Golden near here were as luminous as the name of its hometown.

title: More Security At Yale-Harvard
description: To insure that there be no recurrence of the postgame crowd rowdiness that led to a near-fatal injury for a student last year in New Haven, tomorrow's football game between Harvard and Yale at Harvard Stadium will be played with increased security in force.

title: SHARON, ON WITNESS STAND, TELLS OF 'HIGH MORAL VALUES'
description: Ariel Sharon testified yesterday that ''high moral values'' had guided his long career as one of Israel's most celebrated military leaders.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27

description: Among the thousands of players converging on this city for the Fall National Championships beginning here Friday are the six American women who won the World Team Olympiad title in Seattle last week.

description: b-Net income.

description: It used to be that the New York dancegoer had to

description: Walter H. Annenberg, the 76-year- old president and chief executive officer of Triangle Publications Inc., announced yesterday that William J. Henrich Jr. would succeed him as president of the privately held company.

title: DEVILS BEATEN, 5-3
description: Tom Fergus scored two goals and set up another tonight as the Boston Bruins extended their home unbeaten streak to seven games with a 5-3 victory over the Devils.

title: WELFARE CURBS WOULD INSURE RENT PAYMENTS
description: The Administration today proposed rules that would permit state and local governments to make sure welfare recipients pay their rent.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two articles in Metropolitan Report on Nov. 8 about voter turnout in New York State and about the party alignment in the State Legislature - incorrectly reported the result of the Presidential balloting in Tompkins County. Walter F. Mondale outscored President Reagan there.

description: -elected,

title: WESTCHESTER BUDGET WITH NO TAX RISE IS OFFERED
description: A $683.5 million county operating budget for 1985, which carries no increase in the property-tax rate, was proposed today by the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: RETIRING NAME AN NUMBER
description: At the Spectrum tonight, Bob Clarke came to see the retirement of Bobby Clarke's number.

PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Admit Perjury In Parsons Trial
description: Pam Parsons, the former women's basketball coach at South Carolina, and one of her former players, Tina Buck, pleaded guilty today of having perjured themselves in Miss Parsons's unsuccessful libel suit against Sports Illustrated. The maximum penalty is five years' imprisonment and fines of $10,000 each.

title: Stamp Show at Garden
description: Amateur stamp collectors will gather this weekend at the 36th Postage Stamp Show at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: BISHOPS' AGENDA: TURNING PASTORAL LETTERS INTO PUBLIC POLICY
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today ended a key meeting at which they took several steps toward uniting behind an ambitious campaign to influence public policy. Many believe that their chances for success, however, rest on an effective strategy of activism that the bishops concede has yet to be developed. The focus of the four-day annual session of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops was a proposed pastoral letter that takes a sharply critical view of the American economy. Though the 280 bishops discussed a first draft only briefly, they appeared to be solidly in support of its main contentions.

title: BABY FAE, WHO RECEIVED A HEART FROM BABOON, DIES AFTER 20 DAYS
description: Baby Fae, the infant who received the heart of a baboon 20 days ago to replace her own defective heart, died today at 9 P.M,, officials of the Loma Linda University Medical Center said.

title: Jazz Film Showing
description: David Chertok, a jazz collector and historian, will show rare films of Louis Armstrong, Count Basie, Duke Ellington and Benny Goodman tonight at 8 P.M. in the sanctuary of St. Peter's Church (935-2200), Lexington Avenue at 54th Street in the Citicorp Center. There is a $5 donation.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.5 million for the latest first quarter and $639,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Stop Rights Activity, Polish Authorities Warn
description: Human rights campaigners in the cities of Cracow and Wroclaw were warned today to halt their activities as the authorities continued their campaign against dissidents.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW CAJUN DICTIONARY LETS 'LE BON TEMPS ROULER'
description: Understanding the tongue of the Cajuns, says Msgr. Jules O. Daigle, who has just written the first comprehensive Cajun dictionary, requires a certain amount of imagination.

title: 2 POLICE OFFICERS INDICTED BY JURY IN BEATINGS CASE
description: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted two city police officers on charges that they severely beat a Rutgers University sophomore with their nightsticks when he ''intervened'' after one of the officers struck his brother, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: THE 'REFUSENIKS' NEED HELP
description: They were the first. The first to reject the reign of terror. The first to defy the Kremlin. The first to claim freely, openly, their right to difference - and to freedom. I am talking about the Russian Jews. I met them in 1965 during a trip to the Soviet Union. In a work published afterward, I tried to bear witness for them. I described their victories over fear. I told of their Simhat Torah in front of the Choral Synagogue in Moscow: thousands and thousands of young people had gathered to sing and dance and thereby celebrate their devotion to the history of the Jewish people. It was obvious - some 50 years of dictatorship and Communist education had not Elie Wiesel is a novelist. (This article was translated from the French by Richard Howard.) been able to stifle Jewish memory. A great number of these young idealists are already in Israel and almost everywhere throughout the free world. But not all. The majority have remained behind. Now they are known as ''refuseniks,'' because they are refused visas. They remain our heroes. How do they manage not to lose hope? I met with some of them in 1979 during my third visit to their country. We spent a whole night talking about Jewish literature and philosophy. Some had been waiting three years for their visas, others three times that long. From the moment they sent in their request for emigration papers, they lived marginally, in an oppressive atmosphere of unemployment.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The year-ago revenue for both periods were restated to eliminate revenue from processing of company owned gas.

title: 'FATAL VISION,' STORY OF FORMER GREEN BERET
description: ''Fatal Vission,'' the true story of a seemingly all- American boy who ends up convicted of murdering his pregnant wife and two small daughters, has been made into a four-hour television movie. The first half will be broadcast Sunday evening at 9 on Channel 4, the second half on Monday at 9.

title: Reagans Plan Ranch Holiday
description: President Reagan, his wife, Nancy, and members of their family will celebrate Thanksgiving with a turkey dinner at their ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1984

title: HELEN W. WOODWARD
description: Helen Whittier Woodward, a philanthropist who donated millions to the San Diego Zoo and to aid the blind and elderly, died of cancer Monday at Scripps Memorial Hospital. She was 77 years old.

title: Swiss Trade Gap Wider
description: Switzerland's foreign trade deficit widened to 938 million francs, or about $384 million, in October, from 592 million francs in September and 488 million francs a year earlier, the Customs Office said today. It said imports totaled 6.632 billion francs, or about $2.72 billion, in October. Exports were 5.694 billion francs, or about $2.33 billion.

title: TIMES MIRROR IN ACCORD
description: Settling a four-year legal fight with the State of Connecticut over cross-ownership of the media, the Times Mirror Company has agreed to retain ownership of The Hartford Courant but to sell one of its two cable television franchises, under an accord announced today.

title: ARTIFICIAL WAYS FOR COUPLES TO HAVE A CHILD
description: A variety of techniques have been developed in recent years to meet the needs of couples who want a child but are unable to reproduce in the natural way. The variations fall into these categories: Artificial insemination: A woman is inseminated with her husband's sperm by artificial means. This most widely employed of artificial techniques is often used to concentrate sperm when the husband has a low sperm count. It is also helpful when the egg cannot be naturally fertilized because of the wife's physical problems. If the husband is infertile or may pass along a harmful genetic condition, the sperm of a ''donor,'' generally an anonymous medical student, can be used. This technique is known as artificial insemination by donor.

title: TAVERNIER DIRECTS 'SUNDAY INT HE COUNTRY'
description: ''A Sunday in the Country'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2. The film opens today at the Paris Theater, 58th Street west of Fifth Avenue.

title: NANCY REAGAN LIFTS A G.O.P. AIDE'S BAN ON 11-YEAR-OLD GIRL
description: When Nancy Reagan heard that a Republican campaign worker had said that an 11-year-old school girl who supported Walter F. Mondale for President would not be invited to attend the White House Easter egg roll with her classmates next spring, she personally invited the child, Mrs. Reagan's press secretary said today.

title: DIGIGRAPHIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHY SHOULDN'T JUDGESHIPS BE POLITICAL CHOICES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz Agrees to Stay In Reagan State Dept.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has agreed to stay at his post in the second Reagan Administration, his spokesman said today. The decision had been expected.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an inventory writedown of $4,436,425.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Crime Control Inc., a maker of electronic security systems based in Indianapolis, said its lender banks had agreed in principle to a restructuring of its loan agreement, effectively removing the loan defaults under which the company has been operating.

title: GAMES PEOPLE PLAY, AND WHERE
description: At almost any hour someplace in New York City one can hear the clack of backgammon counters, the pop of stones falling onto a board of the Asian game go, or the murmur of a close-knit clique of chess players and kibitzers hunched over a board pondering strategies.

title: STATE EXPANDS ITS FISHING BAN FOR THE HUDSON
description: New York State issued new regulations today prohibiting commercial fishing for five additional species in the Hudson River to comply with new, more-stringent Federal health guidelines on PCB-tainted fish.

title: Cocaine Found in Sniper
description: A sniper who killed one athlete and wounded another before committing suicide Monday at the University of Oregon football stadium had cocaine in his body system, the police said today. A toxicology report conducted on urine samples taken from the sniper, Michael E. Feher, 19 years old, showed the presence of cocaine in his system, Det. Edward Van Horn said.

title: Claims for Jobless Benefits Show 2,000 Rise to 414,000
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits rose by 2,000 in the week ended Nov. 3, the Labor Department said today.

title: 2 SATELLITES LAUNCHED, 2 RECAPTURED, ASTRONAUTS PREPARE FOR HOME
description: Their mission accomplished, with two new satellites delivered to orbit and two old ones salvaged, the astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery prepared today to come home to earth.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Braniff Fare Cuts
description: For the first time since Braniff Inc. resumed flight service in March, American Airlines said it would not match Braniff's reduced fares. When Braniff's current introductory fares for a reduced service schedule expire Tuesday, the airline will set prices below previous levels but slightly above the promotional level - some $4 to $10 less each way than American.

title: Stelco Cutback
description: Stelco Inc., Canada's largest steel company, said it will permanently close its Griffith iron ore mine at Red Lake, Ontario, next April and estimated that the closure would result in a $50 million write-down of assets. The mine, with a rated annual capacity of 1.5 million tons, has operated at 50 to 66 percent of capacity during the last three years and currently employs 280 workers, it said. Stelco said the closing was part of a cost-reduction and rationalization program designed to improve profits and allow for a major upgrading at its Hamilton, Ontario, steel plant.

title: U.N. Again Demands Soviet Quit Afghanistan
description: The General Assembly reiterated a demand today that the Soviet Union withdraw its troops from Afghanistan. It was the fifth such measure passed by the Assembly since the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOOD GRIEF! 'PEANUTS' HAS BEEN MUSEUMIZED!
description: Here's the World War I flying ace zooming through the air and swooping down to the Museum of Broadcasting.

title: Producers Sales, Delphi in Merger
description: The Producers Sales Organization, the largest independent distributor of motion pictures abroad, and the Delphi Companies, which finances movies through public offerings, said today that they had merged. The newly formed company, PSO Delphi, will commit at least $350 million to the production of motion pictures during the next five years.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Foreign Issue Included In Treasury Note Sale
description: The Treasury announced plans yesterday to sell on Nov. 28 about $6.75 billion of new five-year, two-month notes in the domestic market and an additional $1 billion of notes with the same maturity to foreign investors. The issues will mature Feb. 15, 1990.

title: DEMOCRATS MEET IN VIRGIN ISLANDS TO PONDER PARTY'S FUTURE
description: Democratic officials from around the nation gathered on this sunswept island today in hopes of reviving the electoral fortunes of their wounded party.

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: The share earnings are per American Depositary Receipts. The translation rate was $1.24 to the pound, the approximate rate on Sept. 28.

title: Debt Issues
description: * C.I.T. Financial Corp. is offering $100 million of 11 1/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Co. The notes may be redeemed by investors at a price of 100 on May 15, 1987.

title: German Medical Prize Canceled Over Nazi Link
description: The sponsor of a West German prize for liver research says he has decided to cancel the award after complaints that it honored a Vienna physician who had conducted experiments on prisoners in a Nazi concentration camp.

title: Fit for a King
description: It's not too early to spot a present

title: ISLANDERS WIN WITH CHANGES
description: The Islanders found their heart tonight in a 6-1 victory over the Minnesota North Stars, along with their forechecking, playmaking, defense and hitting. And it was all embodied in Bryan Trottier.

title: A VERY GENEROUS BENEFIT PACKAGE FOR RETIRED CIVIL SERVANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Julius Erving of the Philadelphia 76ers said he would appeal a $7,500 fine levied for his part in a fight with Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics in a game last week because the amount was ''excessive.'' . . . Donald Curry, World Boxing Association welterweight champion, will defend his title for the fifth time in a bout against Colin Jones of Wales in Birmingham, England, Jan. 19, according to the promoter, Bob Arum . . . . Jim McMahon , the Chicago Bear quarterback who suffered a kidney injury Nov. 4, has been released from a hospital but will not play for the rest of the season.

title: A Fairer Verdict for the Police After a long investigation into charges of police brutality in New York City, a House subcommittee now issues a report whose conclusions hardly match the passions that its hearings aroused last year. Its assertion that ''racism appears to be a major factor'' in police-community relations here has merit, but it's a far cry from earlier charges that police brutality was not only systemic but ''condoned'' by the city.
description: Mayor Koch has every right to resent the casualness with which the subcommittee's chairman, Representative John Conyers, entertained and repeated that now-abandoned assertion. The subcommittee began its inquiry at the request of black leaders.

title: Curb on Inauguration Sought port by Congressional auditors that some military personnel were improperly used in President Reagan's first inauguration, said today the taxpayer- financed practice should be halted or paid for by the private group organizing this year's festivities.
description: But James Lake, a spokesman for the forthcoming inauguration, said that although many of the decisions about the ceremonies had yet to be made, ''we're not going to do anything improper'' and the taxpayers ''are going to get their money's worth.''

title: Stock Routing Unit Widened
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it will begin full-scale operation on Monday of its new Super Dot 250 system for electronic order execution. A pilot program for the system, which routes market and limit orders automatically to trading posts on the floor from brokerage firm order rooms, has been operating for about a year.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC AND ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: The ''religion of the pianoforte,'' as Shaw once called it, still exists, complete with its hallowed rituals, its priesthood, its established institutions and its pews full of faithful. There is no scarcity of musicians eager to throw themselves at the feet of the 88- toothed monster, which with its lid up does rather resemble a hungry and unappeasable deity. Most of these musicians, however, spend their lives worshiping the glossy instrument and its technical mysteries, never passing into the higher realm where music is all that matters.

title: BRADFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $549,000. c-After a loss of $139,000 for the quarter and a gain of $164,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE BIG MAGAZINE AUCTION
description: Whether you ski, sail, fly, ride a motorcycle, go backpacking or do nothing more dangerous than get married, there is something of interest in the package.

title: NICARAGUAN VOTE: 'FREE, FAIR, HOTLY CONTESTED'

title: Altman Purchase Reported Near
description: A group of investors is nearing agreement with the Altman Foundation to buy the seven B. Altman stores, for a price that probably will be more than $100 million, according to a source close to the transaction.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page caption on Wednesday with a picture of the Grand Duke of Luxembourg gave an incorrect date for his most recent previous visit to Washington. It was in 1963.

title: THE FOLK TRADITION, FROM THE CELTIC TO THE APPALACHIAN
description: ''A society without tradition,'' declared the otherwise mild-mannered folk singer Martin Carthy, ''is not a society worth maintaining. In our society, in England, they show us pictures of the Tower of London and of the Queen, and they tell us that's tradition. It's not. Tradition is what ordinary people do, and what ordinary people have evolved.''

title: Racing Tragedy
description: When a wonderfully fast daughter of Seattle Slew named Landaluce died suddenly and unexpectedly two years ago, the racing world was thrown into shock.

title: DON'T TAKE YUPPIES FOR GRANTED
description: What do yuppies want? That was the surprise political question of this election year, as young urban professionals, who came of age in the 1960's, returned to national politics after a decade's absence. We made our presence known in the Democratic primaries by supporting Gary Hart, but in the general election most of us voted for Ronald Reagan. This moved many Democratic factotums to excoriate us for our selfishness, our indifference to the poor and other sins - not least of which was our refusal to follow their instructions. We voted for Mr. Reagan for good reasons. Inflation is down, the economy is growing and a sense of prosperity has replaced the malaise of stagflation. The sectors of the economy where most yuppies earn their living - high tech, financial services, the professions - are doing especially well. Since yuppies are fair, we had to give him credit.

title: Sweden's Output Rises
description: Sweden's industrial output was up a seasonally adjusted 1.6 percent in September from August and rose 9.2 percent from a year earlier, Statistics Sweden said today. It said September's rise resulted from gains in the engineering, wood products, chemical and basic metal industries.

description: Industrial production in the United States was unchanged in October, the Federal Reserve Board said today. But a number of analysts attributed the sluggishness to temporary factors and predicted modest gains in coming months.

title: The Cave collection.

Cave inherited her passion for French 18th- century furniture from her mother, Olive Lady Baillie, and the wherewithal to buy such treasures from her maternal American ancestors, who were Whitneys (financiers) and Paynes (Standard Oil). Today, Mrs. Cave's $1.5 million collection - 300 French porcelains, furnishings, rugs and Impressionist paintings - will be sold in two sessions at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: FRENCH MINISTER CITES U.S. CULTUURAL INFLUENCE
description: Jack Lang, France's Minister Delegate of Culture, said yesterday that he had made a mistake in a controversial 1982 speech in terming American cultural influence in France ''imperialism.'' But Mr. Lang held by his belief that the United States is a powerful cultural force in France, one with both positive and negative effects on France's own art.

In the view of many Democratic politicians, that is where the highly regarded Mr. Moe should have been throughout the Presidential campaign. Instead, the man who served as Mr. Mondale's chief of staff in the Senate and the Vice Presidency was shut out of the campaign by Mr. Mondale's senior aides, and the candidate let it be.

The debate really has little to do with the U.S. It merely provides a ricochet shot in the argument over President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government and its presently not-so-socialist policies.

title: Walking Toward Moscow
description: At about 10 o'clock this morning, a small and very unusual group is to walk over Memorial Bridge into Washington. Its seven members belong to the International Fellowship of Reconciliation, and the capital is just one stop on their 8,500- mile pilgrimage on foot from Point Conception, Calif., to Moscow; theirs is an international demonstration for peace and disarmament.

title: Economic Scene; Post-Election Deficit Blues
description: NOW that President Reagan has won a landslide victory largely as a result of an election-year economic boom, the nation and Wall Street - and even the White House - are waking up to the bleak dawn of a worsening budget deficit, a widening trade deficit, a weakening economy and a President who is uncomfortable with economics and economists.

At first glance, Sistina, a rakish, three- month-old restaurant at Second Avenue near 81st Street, appeared to fall into this category. Happily, it does not.

title: The Oil Crisis Plan Needs Repair The world is glutted with oil and OPEC is straining to hold up the price. What an odd moment to worry about another oil shock. But good times may be the only times when governments can plan sensibly for a supply interruption. And as two experts recently warned in The Times's Business Forum, the present international agreement for sharing oil in a crisis is a recipe for chaos.
description: The treaty, signed by the industrial democracies after the 1973-74 oil embargo, calls for ''orderly and equitable'' sharing when supplies fall by 7 percent. All signatories are then supposed to sacrifice on an equal basis. Those obtaining relatively more would be required to share it with have-nots. A ''fair'' price for shared oil would be set by a committee of buyers and sellers inside the pact.

title: O.A.U. PARLEY ENDS IN ETHIOPIA

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 16 1984 International Thousands of Chilean men were herded into a soccer stadium in Santiago and questioned by army and air force troops and plainclothesmen. At dawn, the Government forces raided a poor Santiago neighborhood that has witnessed many clashes and demonstrations against the military Government. The Government forces occupied the slum for seven hours, searching house to house, and then bused or trucked virtually all males over 16 years old to the stadium. (Page A1, Column 1.) A desire to move promptly into talks with Moscow on ways of resuming arm control negotiations was repeated by the Reagan Administration. It said it was eager to ''flesh out'' its plan for so-called umbrella talks with the Soviet Union. At the same time, officials said that negotiations on a new agreement for cultural exchanges were snagged over the issue of possible defections by Soviet participants. (A1:3-4.)

description: Gilbert and Sullivan disliked each other and rarely met.Renata Scotto often sang beautifully with Luciano Pavarotti, but excoriates him in her recent autobiography. Some very successful musical collaborations have been based on shaky personal relationships.

title: ANTI-SIKH WHIRLWIND: WHERE DID IT COME FROM?
description: A poor man's maharajah, Dharam Dass Shastri, Member of Parliament, was holding court on the sprawling lawn of his official villa.

title: Flyers 6, Whalers 1
description: Tim Kerr scored his 16th and 17th goals - his sixth two-goal game of the season - for the Flyers, who made three goals in an 8-minute span of the first period on the way to their fourth consecutive victory. Derrick Smith, a rookie, opened the scoring at 11:24 by converting a behind-the-back pass from Murray Craven for his third goal of the season, a rising shot over the stick of the goalie Greg Millen.

title: Songwriter at Folk City
description: The songwriter Suzanne Vega will perform tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M. at Folk City (254-8449), 130 West Third Street. Tickets are $6.

title: COMMANDER OF AN AMERICAN DEFEAT
description: After one of the most promising early careers in American military annals, William Childs Westmoreland became the commander who presided in Vietnam over one of the worst defeats in United States history. In the view of those who know him well he has never fully recovered from the experience.

title: ART: APOCALYPTIC VISION OF CUCCHIE'S PAINTINGS
description: Among the well-known trio of Italian neo-Expressionists (or, as someone has called them, espresso Expressionists) - Sandro Chia, Francesco Clemente and Enzo Cucchi - the work of Cucchi seems the most extravagant. In its try for grand themes, it presents an engaging combination of apocalyptic vision, high operatic silliness and unabashed swipes from masters of the past, ranging from Masaccio to Dali. And in the six larger works of Cucchi's third New York show, divided between Sperone Westwater, 142 Greene Street (through Dec. 1), and the Mary Boone-Michael Werner Gallery, 417 West Broadway (through Nov. 24), his reach is even more ambitious, in terms of scale and - well, cosmicality.

title: Life Is Just . . .
description: The Cherry Bowl may be new to football - it makes its debut in Pontiac, Mich., on Dec. 22 - but don't sell it short.

title: R.S.V.P. Requested
description: Rick Sutcliffe , the Cy Young Award-winning free agent, completed his initial talks with the Kansas City Royals yesterday and, armed with what the club described as a ''very generous'' offer, turned his attention to the seven other teams that selected him in the re-entry draft.

title: PLANNERS SAID TO FAVOR A MODIFIED FLAT TAX
description: A top tax planner at the Treasury Department said at a private meeting of business lobbyists today that the Treasury would send a study to the White House by Dec. 1 that would ''hit all the options'' on tax proposals while still making ''specific recommendations to the President,'' according to people who were at the meeting and took notes.

title: REDSKINS OVERCOME KEY INJURIES WITH DEPTH IN THE BACKFIELD
description: Few teams in the National Football League have been beset by injuries as badly as the Washington Redskins, who at one point this season had 26 players on their injured-reserve list. At present, the list has 20 players, 11 of whom were on the 49- man squad at the beginning of the season and 9 of whom are usually starters or major contributors.

title: WOOLWORTH, F.W. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GERMAN EVENTS PUSHED LENIN INTO POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Rehab Hospital Takeover Set
description: The Rehab Hospital Services Corporation of Camp Hill, Pa., said it had agreed to be acquired by National Medical Enterprises Inc. of Los Angeles in a transaction National Medical said was valued at about $120 million.

title: FRANCE AND LIBYA MEET ON CHAD ACCORD
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and President Francois Mitterrand held talks here today and were said to have agreed to keep their troops out of Chad as reports persisted that Libya had not honored its agreement with France for a simultaneous withdrawal of troops from the North African country.

title: Military Contracts
description: The General Electric Company received a $176.7 million Air Force contract for MX missile re-entry vehicle parts and a $56.4 million contract from the Army for vehicle transmissions, the Defense Department said. The Army also gave the Thiokol Corporation's Aerospace division a $56.4 million contract to operate a Government facility in Shreveport, La.

title: MUSIC: PENNY FULLER IN CABARET
description: Penny Fuller's career has been centered primarily on nonmusical roles in television and on stage, but she started out climbing the ladder of the musical theater from chorus (''South Pacific'') to understudy (''Cabaret'') to Tony nomination for the role of Eve Harrington in ''Applause'' in 1970. Since then, her only musical appearance in New York had been in Richard Rodgers's short-lived ''Rex'' eight years ago, but she has now returned to music to make her New York cabaret debut at Freddy's.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Including tax credits of $142,500 for the quarter and $480,000 for the year. c-After a pretax provision of $450,000 from the take back of restaurants subleased to a franchisee.

title: Room Reimbursement
description: Peter Ueberroth, who before entering the world of baseball served as president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, supports a proposal that a small part of the committee's $150 million surplus be used to reimburse the countries that took part in the Games last summer for the living expenses they incurred there. The proposal, which has been advanced by the International Olympic Committee, was addressed by Ueberroth at a sports banquet in Anaheim, Calif., earlier this week.

title: Occidental Halts Joint Oil Venture
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had canceled plans to form a new joint venture, Arab Oxy, to locate and develop oilfields in the Middle East and North Sea, apparently because of a shortage of investors. Occidental said it had terminated an offering of 21.5 million shares of stock for half of the proposed privately held company because of ''a tightening of liquidity in the Middle East.''

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
JETS SIGN AVELLINI AS EXTRA QUARTERBACK
description: After staying home, reading a book and watching television to rest after his second concussion in 15 days, Pat Ryan rejoined the Jets today.

title: The Beaujolais Is Running
description: AT 9:50 A.M. yesterday, Joan Benoit, the Olympic marathon champion, picked up a bottle of Beaujolais nouveau at the United Nations and ran across town through the city streets with it to the Parker Meridien Hotel.

title: Advertising; Marketing Potential At Tracks
description: WHEN attendance at harness racing tracks began to dwindle, William Rosenberg convinced people in the sport that it was time for some joint marketing efforts. That wasn't surprising; after all, Mr. Rosenberg may be a horse breeder and owner these days, but first he was the founder of the Dunkin' Donuts chain of franchises. And if that isn't the essence of a joint marketing effort, what is?

title: U.S. and Teamsters Negotiating in Suit
description: The Labor Department has begun talks to settle a suit it filed against leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, but a Federal district judge says he may bar one Government lawyer from participating.

title: T.I.M.E.-DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Adams Resources and Energy Inc., Houston, has promoted Edwin H. Laws to executive vice president- marketing and transportation; William R. Sharp to vice president-engineering and production; Claude H. Lewis to vice president-land transportation, and Donald Temperton, controller, to the additional post of treasurer.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY, SERIES AT GOODMAN HOUSE
description: Over the last three seasons, Gerard Schwarz's Music Today at the Abraham Goodman House has established itself as one of the most interesting, nonpolemical new-music series in town. This season's first concert, Wednesday night, handsomely reaffirmed that distinction.

title: KHOMEINI'S GRIP IN IRAN APPEARS UNSHAKABLE
description: Six years after the Islamic revolution that toppled Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Government appears firmly in control, despite some lingering problems.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5.1 million and a tax credit of $3.1 million, both for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $29,437,000 for the quarter and $63,648,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary credit of $19,792,000 from an exchange offer for the quarter and 9 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday of Louis A. Lerner, a Chicago newspaper publisher and United States Ambassador to Norway in the Carter Administration, omitted three survivors. They are his mother, Deana Lerner; his brother, Robert Lerner, and his sister, Rosanne Holly, all of Chicago.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Cenergy Corp. was spun off from Centex Corp. on Oct. 1.

title: ENERGY EXCHANGE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: SPANISH PAINTERS, 'IN SEARCH OF LIGHT''
description: On the score of novelty, the new show at the National Academy of Design could not be faulted. Of the painters included in ''In Search of Light: Spanish Painters 1850-1950,'' hardly one will be known to most visitors.

title: DAUGHTER OF STALIN, BESET BY REPORTERS, HINTS AT PUBLIC TALK
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, who returned from the West to Moscow last month, hinted today that she might hold a news conference. But she said it was not up to her to decide when that might be.

title: MAYOR ON COAST DENIES NEW PERJURY CHARGES
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego today pleaded not guilty to new perjury charges involving alleged illegal campaign contributions from the J. David & Company investment house.

title: EARNINGS ; Woolworth Gains 30%
description: F.W. Woolworth & Company yesterday reported a 30 percent jump in earnings for the third quarter, ended Oct. 31. Sales increased 3.7 percent.

title: 'Murph,' Jewel Thief, May Leave Prison
description: The jewel thief Jack Murphy, known as ''Murph the Surf,'' may soon leave prison for a work-release program.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The police colonel in charge told me his men were under orders to act correctly.

title: Some P.B.A. Flights May Resume Tuesday
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday it had agreed to a plan by Provincetown-Boston Airline, grounded last week for rules violations, to resume service Tuesday if safety checks of pilots and equipment could be completed according to schedule.

title: AMENDMENTS MAY IMPERIL LATIN PACT
description: Three allies of Washington in Central America have proposed changes in a draft peace treaty for the region that are so far-reaching that they threaten to set back negotiating efforts by months, according to diplomats close to the situation.

title: COURT RULING MAY INCREASE LOCAL TAXES PAID BY STATE
description: New York State, which paid $40 million in property taxes to local governments and school districts last year, could be taxed considerably more under a decision today by the State Court of Appeals.

title: Bid for Cenvill
description: First American Bank and Trust said it intended to tender for all the shares of the Cenvill Development Corporation and Cenvill Properties Inc., which trade as a single unit, at $17.25 for each Cenvill paired share.

title: U.S. Attorney to Head CBS Washington Office
description: Robert A. McConnell, Assistant Attorney General for legislative affairs, has been named vice president in charge of the Washington office of CBS Inc., with overall responsibility for regulatory and legislative matters.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NICARAGUAN VOTE:'FREE, FAIR, HOTLY CONTESTED'
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE OLYMPIANS WIN PRO DEBUTS
description: The expected was not always dull last night as five Olympic boxing stars, to varying degrees of artistic success, all won their professional debuts on prime-time television before a crowd of 19,000 at Madison Square Garden.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SAYS IT IS EAGER TO 'FLUSH OUT' THE IDEA OF SOVIET UMBRELLA TALKS
description: The United States repeated its desire today to move promptly into discussions with the Soviet Union on ways of resuming talks on nuclear arms control.

title: Dr. Florence Schumer; Wrote Psychology Text
description: Dr. Florence Schumer, a clinical psychologist and authority on abnormal behavior, died of cancer Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Guilty Verdict In Dallas Club Shootings
description: Abdelk rim Belachheb was found guilty today of murdering six restaurant patrons in a shooting spree last summer touched off when two women at the club insulted him. The jury rejected a contention that the 39-year-old Moroccan national was insane when he committed the crime June 29.

title: Hill, Untelevised, Wins His Debut
description: Boxing's sixth man, feeling ''left out'' and inconspicuous although he was a silver thread among the gold, also made his pro debut last night. And while the prime-time television cameras were on five of his more famous and more richly rewarded former Olympic teammates, Virgil Hill, the 165-pound silver medalist at Los Angeles, beat his buddies to the punch as a professional.

title: MORTON TO SELL TEXIZE TO DOW FOR $256 MILLION
description: Heading off the threat of a takeover by the Dow Chemical Company, Morton Thiokol Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Texize household products division to Dow for an estimated $256 million.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: VISITING royalty and aristocracy lent a touch of class to this

title: Friday ROCKETTES SPECTACULAR
description: The Rockettes have a new high- kick routine for this year's edition of the ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular'' at Radio City Music Hall. But the show, which opens today and runs through Jan. 10, also has traditional fare: the Rockettes performing ''The Parade of the Wooden Soldiers''; parts of Tchaikovsky's ballet ''The Nutcracker''; Dickens's ''Christmas Carol''; the lighting of a menorah for Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, and a ''Living Nativity'' with kings, angels, shepherds, camels, donkeys, sheep and a horse. Tickets: $18 to $22, at the box office (757-3100) and through Ticketron (977-9020), Chargit (944-9300) and Teletron (947- 5850). TV FESTIVAL AT MODERN

title: Helms Repeats His Intention To Stay on Agriculture Panel
description: Senator Jesse Helms today restated his intention to remain as chairman of the Agriculture Committee rather than switch to Foreign Relations.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
USTINOV RUMORED TO SUFFER STROKE
description: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, may have suffered a stroke last month, according to a report here.

title: POSSIBLE REASONS FOR TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: The alarming increase in teen-age suicides has created widespread concern and led to the appointment of various committees to search for causes and possible means of prevention. The primary focus will be on the psychopathology of the victims, actual and potential. But there are two other factors to be taken into consideration.

title: 2 Sentenced In Chicago
description: Two former officials of the Chicago Board of Trade Clearing Corporation today were placed on probation, fined and ordered to perform community service by a Federal judge for making nearly $30,000 in illegal campaign contributions.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,000 for the quarter and $429,000 for the year and a loss of $700,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $72,000 for the quarter and a gain of $17,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: PANEL BACKS LOWER PHONE FEE OF $1
description: A panel of Federal and state regulators yesterday retreated on the hotly debated issue of what to charge consumers for access to the nation's telephone system. The panel cut the proposed charge to $1 a month, from $2, starting next June.

title: COUNCIL OBSTRUCTS NEW RENTAL HOUSING
description: To the Editor:

title: EDGCOMB STEEL OF NEW ENGAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Griffin Bacal Receives More From Hasbro
description: Griffin Bacal, which was founded in 1978 with $1.7 million in billings from the Hasbro toy company and has been adding to it since, yesterday received its latest bit of Hasbro business, bringing the total to some $75 million.

title: CONFERENCE LOOKS AT BISHOPS' LETTER ON ECONOMY
description: Even before copies of the Roman Catholic bishops' 120-page draft of their pastoral letter on the economy arrived here today from Washington, the debate was heavy.

title: FILM: KRISTY MCNICHOL IN 'JUST THE WAY YOU ARE'
description: Kristy McNichol suffers from two serious afflictions in ''Just the Way You Are,'' which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters: a crippled leg (as a result of a childhood illness) and a fatal attractiveness to men. The film surrounds Susan Berlanger (Miss McNichol), a talented flutist with more handsome admirers than she cares to count. Everywhere Susan goes, it seems, she is the target of relentless male flirting. Two of the film's problems are that Miss McNichol is never appealing enough to explain all this, and that she hasn't the faintest notion of how to flirt back.

title: NORTH AND SOUTH KOREA HOLD TALKS ON ECONOMIC CONTACTS
description: North and South Korean officials met today in the demilitarized zone between their two countries for their first talks on possible joint economic development and trade.

title: THREE WRITERS WIN BOOK AWARDS
description: Harriet Doerr, a first-novelist born in 1910, won the American Book Award for a work of first fiction last night for her novel ''Stones for Ibarra'' (Viking Press). Ellen Gilchrist, who is a painter as well as a writer, won the overall fiction award for ''Victory Over Japan'' (Little, Brown) a collection of 14 stories about Southern women set in the period from World War II to the present.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago revenues have been restated for an accounting change.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: IN SEARCH OF L. L. BEAN. By M. R.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CITY AND FIREFIGHTERS UNION SELECT U.S. MEDIATOR FOR CONTRACT TALKS
description: Negotiators for the Koch administration and city firefighters said yesterday that they had selected a Federal mediator to help get their stalled contract talks moving again.

title: GETTING OUT THE WORD ON THE NEW CRIME ACT
description: In the last several weeks, the Federal prison population has grown by more than 400 inmates, mostly because the multifaceted crime legislation passed last month has made it more difficult for convicts to go free on bail, pending appeals.

title: HYPONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the 9 months

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,000 for the quarter and $156,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $331,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 9 months.

title: TECH/AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CARDS' GREEN RECEIVES PRAISE
description: Roy Green played defensive back and returned kicks at Henderson State in Arkansas. The St. Louis Cardinals drafted him in 1979, and for two years he did the same jobs for them.

title: FOR THE CAVIAR CROWD, A NEW PLACE ON 7TH AVE.
description: This is the dawning of the age of caviar.

title: PRICE SET ON SHARES OF BRITISH TELECOM
description: The British Government today set a price of 130 pence, or about $1.64, for each of the three billion shares of British Telecom it plans to sell to the public. The price was within expectations.

title: Blue Bell Buyout
description: Blue Bell Inc. said shareholders had approved an offer of of $47.65 a share from a group seeking to to take the company private. Blue Bell, which has about 9.9 million shares outstanding, will be owned principally by an employee stock ownership plan, certain members of the company's management and a partnership organized by Kelso & Company. Blue Bell, based in Greensboro, N.C., is an apparel maker whose brands include Wrangler, Jantzen, Red Kap and Rustler.

title: FORMER BOAT PEOPLE LAND THE GOOD LIFE IN CHINA
description: When the workday begins, this small Chinese port on the Gulf of Tonkin takes on a distinctly Vietnamese air.

title: Held Over in San Diego
description: Tony Gwynn , the Padre outfielder who won the National League's batting championship with a .351 average and helped the club make its first trip to the World Series, has signed a five-year contract that will pay him more than $500,000 in 1985 and more than $1 million in 1990 if the Padres exercise an option on him for that year. Lew Muller , a San Diego agent who negotiated the contract, said Gwynn received a six-figure signing bonus and increases that will escalate the salary to nearly $1 million during the 1989 season.

title: Tennstedt Withdraws From Season's 'Elektra'
description: Klaus Tennstedt, the conductor, has withdrawn from this season's performances of ''Elektra,'' the Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ROUNDS UP 2,300 IN BLACK TOWNSHIP
description: The South African police said today that they had rounded up 2,300 black workers in raids on a black township south of here. It was the biggest mass arrest in years.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $44,000 for the latest first quarter and $2,807,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: S.E.C. BACKS PLEA ON NASDAQ
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission struck a blow to listed stock exchanges yesterday by approving a plan by the National Association of Securities Dealers to more than double the size of its national market system.

title: QUALITY ADMINISTRATORS FOR QUALITY TEACHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Boyum Scores Upset in Squash
description: David Boyum of Brooklyn Heights upset fourth-seeded Clive Caldwell of Toronto, 15-11, 15-14, 9-15, 15-8, yesterday afternoon as the Chivas Regal Open squash racquets tournament opened at the Uptown Racquet Club.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After non-recurring credits from insurance proceeds of $2,110,936 for the quarter and $1,849,243 for the 9 months.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,549,000 from an accounting change.

title: 280 French Policemen Sent to New Caledonia
description: France flew 280 riot policemen to this South Pacific territory today to counter threats of trouble from pro-independence militants determined to disrupt parliamentary elections on Sunday.

title: YONKERS POLICE ACCUSED OF BEATING A SUSPECT
description: The police today were investigating reports that two witnesses saw three officers beat a narcotics suspect on a city street Tuesday night, hours before he was found hanging in his jail cell.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI AT GARDEN
description: ''Gate four, straight ahead,'' chanted the usher, ''there's a hot dog stand, there's a bar, there's everything.'' All that and Luciano Pavarotti too, at Madison Square Garden last night, where thousands of fans gathered to hear dozens of loudspeakers through which was transmitted the most famous tenor voice of our time (and perhaps the most-transmitted operatic voice of all time).

title: FILMTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

PATENTS ;
Analyzing Inventions In Telecommunications
description: This week, when patents were awarded for various means of transmitting information, the Patent and Trademark Office also issued a detailed study covering more than 48,000 telecommunications patents granted from 1963 to 1983.

title: 2 Children Die in Jersey Fire
description: Two young children died in their bedroom and their mother was severely burned when fire swept through their tenement apartment here today, fire officials said.

title: WEAKNESS IN COVERAGE
description: Hardly are the ballots cold in their boxes, and already we hear the perennial cries that press coverage of Campaign '84 was obsessed with the horse race and heedless of the issues.

title: ASSAILING WEST, STALIN'S DAUGHTER SAYS SHE LONGED TO SEE CHILDREN
description: Text of statement, page 6.

title: Jaruzelski Visits East Berlin
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, made an unannounced visit to East Berlin today and met with Erich Honecker, the East German leader. No communique was issued about the visit, which came after General Jaruzelski's equally abrupt trip to Hungary last week. Some party members have privately suggested that the Polish leader wanted to assure his allies that he was in control after the killing of a pro-Solidarity priest in October.

title: Olympians Suffer Prime Time Loss
description: Laughed off the screen by Bill Cosby and shot down by ''Magnum P.I.,'' ABC's prime-time boxing show Thursday night did not reach Olympian heights in the overnight Nielsen television ratings. And the card, with six Olympic medal winners making their professional debuts, did not fill Madison Square Garden, although all the tickets were free.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
BUTTERFIELD EQUITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Equimark Corp.
description: The PNC Financial Corporation said it did not plan to buy any stock in the Equimark Corporation. Earlier in the week, Equimark, which is based in Pittsburgh, said an investor group led by a PNC unit had indicated a willingness to buy a 4.9 percent stake, an acquisition that would have provided slightly more than $3 million in new capital. Equimark's principal subsidiary, Equibank, has been ordered by bank regulators to raise $100 million in new capital by the middle of next year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; The Search for Dr. Mengele
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney,

title: REGENTS URGE STATE TO INCREASE BY 11% FUNDS FOR SCHOOL AID
description: The Board of Regents today recommended an increase of $634 million in state aid for elementary and secondary schools in 1985-86, a rise of 11 percent.

title: Indonesia Project
description: Texaco Inc. and the Chevron Corporation said subsidiaries had signed a contract to explore for and develop geothermal resources in Indonesia. The Indonesian Government is encouraging such development to help meet domestic energy needs, making more of its oil available for sale abroad. The contract is with Pertamina, the national oil company.

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,022,510 from the sale of real estate.

title: TELECONCEPTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BUSINESS DIGESET
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1984

title: ANGOLA TALKS END IN JOHANNESBURG
description: South Africa held out the possibility tonight of three-way talks with the United States and Angola on the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from the former Portuguese colony.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORKING VISION OF FUTURE
description: In a week of startling images of the shuttle Discovery on a salvage mission in space, one stands out as a vision of the future: astronauts manipulating wrenches as they worked methodically in the cold void. They plucked satellites from orbit, wrestled them into the payload bay and bolted them into place.

title: Nancy Reagan Traveling
description: Nancy Reagan will visit her mother, Edith Davis, in Phoenix on Saturday, the First Lady's office announced today. Mrs. Reagan will fly to Los Angeles on Sunday and join her husband Monday at their ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., for Thanksgiving.

title: HADRON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $47,005 for the quarter and $166,678 for the 6 months and tax credits of $86,000 and $130,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $136,341.

title: Conjecture Over Coach
description: Ever since Galen Hall took over as interim football coach at Florida with the dismissal of Charley Pell this autumn, a number of Gator supporters have been campaigning to get him the job on a permanent basis. Now some of those boosters have told The Orlando Sentinel that Athletic Director Bill Carr announced at a dinner this week that Hall would be asked to stay on. Whatever Carr may have said at the gathering, he offered only ''I have no comment'' yesterday.

title: Turkey Killing at School Stirs Furor in Kentucky
description: A group of eighth-graders studying pioneer life killed their own Thanksgiving turkey, a bit of realism that has prompted complaints from the humane society.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Oct. 18 with an article about Silicon Valley incorrectly described reporting by The San Jose Mercury-News on trade secrets obtained from an industry newsletter. The Mercury- News reported how the secrets became public but did not describe them.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized gains of $40,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the 9 months. c-After a realized loss of $17,000. d-After realized gains of $88,000.

G.E. Contract
description: The General Electric Company's Space Systems division received a $423 million contract from the Air Force for six communications satellites as part of the Defense Satellite Communications System III Program, the Defense Department said.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Robert Stover, Lawyer And Environmentalist
description: Robert C. Stover, a lawyer and president of the Environmental Planning Lobby, died last Saturday at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., after suffering a heart attack while jogging. He was 62 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WITCHING WATER IN THE NORTH COUNTRY
description: Bruce Hanson needed water.

title: SCREEN: NORRIS IN 'MISSING IN ACTION'
description: It's possible to watch a Chuck Norris film like ''Missing in Action,'' which opened yesterday at the United Artists Twin, and come away with the misimpression that Mr. Norris has not said a word. He does talk, of course, but his real eloquence is exclusively physical. There's not quite enough of it to explain why someone of Mr. Norris's taciturn manner and unprepossessing blond looks has managed to become an international B-movie star. But there

title: WARD DISPUTES PANEL'S REPORT ON POLICE BIAS
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that he would not allow the Police Department to be ''smeared'' because of the racist actions of a few officers.

title: 120-Day Term In Bribery Case
description: A city sewer inspector who continued to take bribes from plumbing contractors after being caught once and cooperating with investigators was sentenced yesterday to 120 days and a $12,000 fine.

title: 15TH STRAIGHT DRAW IN CHESS
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today after 17 moves in the 24th game of their world chess championship match.

title: EX-REP. CHARLES MOSHER OF OHIO

title: THE HOUR THAT AMTRAK'S MIND LEFT THE RAILS
description: I'm probably the last person to tell Amtrak how to run its business. After all, the federally subsidized passenger railroad cost the Government only $2.15 billion over the last three years. And the line hasn't suffered a derailment or head-on collision for some weeks now. Still, after my excursion from Baltimore to New York the night of Oct. 27-28, I felt that Amtrak was getting some bad advice somewhere, and that even a rank amateur could offer a pointer. Meredith Platt is a graduate student in biopsychology at Hunter College. The subject is scheduling. As an alert reader may already have noted, Oct. 28 is the night we all turned the clocks back from Daylight Savings Time to Eastern Standard Time. As our sleek Amtrak coach hurtled through the night toward New York, we had no inkling of the extraordinary experience that lay ahead - in time, not space. Sure, there had been that unexplained burst of fireworks near Wilmington. But that hardly prepared us for the surprise that Amtrak held in store. You see, Amtrak takes very seriously our great annual ritual called The Turning of the Clock. At precisely 2 A.M., all over the country, Amtrak trains hit the air brakes, pulled over and stopped. For one hour, thousands of passengers and crew silently waited while Daylight Savings Time became Eastern Standard Time. We ''fell back'' together.

title: The Life and Death of Baby Fae Just because Baby Fae survived for 20 days with a baboon's heart doesn't mean the experiment at Loma Linda University Medical Center was a success. Neither does her death mean failure. But her surgeon, Leonard Bailey, was premature in contending yesterday that Baby Fae ''has opened new vistas for all, including the as-yet unborn infants with lethal heart diseases.''
description: After a single experiment, with little information of relevance yet released by the Loma Linda authorities, it's too early to tell whether the operation represents a bizarre blind alley in medicine, an interesting but premature development or a promising first step.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1984 International A return to Soviet-American detente was called for by Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. He said this could open the way to ''broad possibilities for cooperation,'' such as in combating famine and protecting the world's environment. In responding to written questions submitted by an NBC News correspondent, Mr. Chernenko also said that if the Reagan Administration was sincere, the way was open to resolving key arms-control questions. (Page 1, Column 6.) Salvadoran rebels eased their policy of refusing to participate in elections until they gain a formal role in the Government, one of the rebel leaders said. He said they are prepared, in principle, to take part in elections organized by the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte. (1:3.)

title: What Puerto Rico Cares About Last week's election in Puerto Rico must have disappointed scholars, politicians and writers who have been trying to push the island's political status higher on Washington's agenda. The disappointment was not in who won and who lost. It was in the continuation of a decade-long stalemate between partisans of statehood and those of commonwealth status, and the seeming indifference of the average Puerto Rican to the choice.
description: In the race for governor, advocates of the two positions divided 97 percent of the vote nearly equally, with the tiny Independence Party picking up the remainder. The election produced a change of administration but no decisive shift in the underlying balance of support on the status question.

None of the money has been recovered, officials say.

description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block told top members of his staff today that he planned to continue in his job in President Reagan's second term, a department spokesman said.
