title: WESTMORELAND DENIES CBS REPORT ON 'CEILING'
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland repeatedly asserted at his libel trial against CBS yesterday that he had never imposed a ceiling on estimates of enemy strength in South Vietnam nor had he ordered those figures to be suppressed or altered.

title: Traffic-Fine Safe Emptied in Bronx
description: One or more burglars used an acetylene torch to open a safe in a Department of Motor Vehicles office in the Bronx and took up to $25,000 in traffic-fine money, the police said yesterday.

title: Thousand Trails
description: Thousand Trails Inc.'s stock plunged after the company said that preliminary talks on its possible acquisition had been terminated. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Thousand Trails fell $7.625, to $16.625, on a volume of 726,200 shares. The company, a Seattle-based outdoor recreation concern, said last week that it was holding talks with a suitor it did not identify.

title: Rangers' Poll
description: A new feature of the Rangers' yearbook this season is a listing of players' responses to about 20 questions regarding their likes, dislikes and preferences.

title: VERMONT'S GOURMET FOODS GET THE STATE'S BLESSING
description: Several booths away from the pizza-scented memo pads and just down the aisle from the beater that scrambles eggs in the shell, a clutch of earnest-looking'Vepmonters were exhibiting their handmade mustards, chutneys, dressings and sauces.

title: ECONOMICS IN OUTER SPACE
description: The spectacular television coverage of the space shuttle's outer-space rescue of two damaged satellites has provided graphic evidence that space is becoming a common part of life. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is planning a permanent space station, and private companies are developing orbital manufacturing processes and entering the satellite business in increasing numbers. Space, our last great frontier, seems open for man's advance.

title: BOURNE REGAINS THE WINNING FEELING
description: The bruise was fresh on Bob Bourne's chin, where a puck hit him Thursday night. His head still ached from a concussion last week, suffered when he was gashed on the scalp, requiring 21 stitches, during a practice. And there was still a slight scar over his left eyebrow, where a few other stitches were recently removed.

title: MEDICAL EXPERTS DISAGREE ON MERITS OF BABY'S BABOON HEART TRANSPLANT
description: Reaction to the death of Baby Fae came quickly yesterday from heart and organ transplant experts.

title: TV AS ELECTION CULPRIT
description: It is an inescapable fact that television makes the man who seeks the office. And while it is hard to imagine a candidate more perfectly crafted for TV than Ronald Reagan (or less perfectly crafted than Walter F. Mondale), both TV and the political parties surely will continue casting for someone who is even better. In the process, one thing is certain - factual reporting of campaigns will recede even further into murkiness in favor of events that fit the TV mold.

title: PUSH GROWS FOR BELTS ON SCHOOL-BUS SEATS IN NEW YORK REGION
description: The Suffolk County Legislature this week voted to require seat belts in all new school buses starting in 1986. School officials in West Orange, N.J., took delivery of nine school buses equipped with seat belts in September.

title: More Jobless in France
description: France's unemployment rate edged up to 10.2 percent in October from 10.1 percent the previous month, the Labor Ministry said today. The agency said the number of unemployed people, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose to 2,467,300. That was up three-tenths of a percent from the previous month and 16.4 percent from October 1983.

description: Voicing determination to ''recapture the middle'' in American politics, Democrats from around the country searched today for explanations of their losses in last week's elections and groped for a successful path toward the future.

title: MINORITIES ADVISED ON HOW TO HAVE BUSINESS CAREERS
description: Growing up in Harlem, Ruth Clark had big dreams - too big, people were always reminding her, for a barber's daughter from 111th Street.

title: UNIVERSAL TO REISSUE 'GLENN MILLER STORY'
description: ''The Glenn Miller Story,'' a 1954 movie starring James Stewart and June Allyson, has been pulled off the shelf at Universal Studio and will be reissued around the world next April or May.

title: BABY FAE DIES, BUT DOCTOR SEES GAIN FOR SCIENCE
description: Baby Fae died Thursday night, but her doctor said today that the operation in which she received a baboon's heart had advanced science and one day would save the lives of many children.

title: Persistence Pays
description: Joe Auer, who works at Kennedy International Airport in the lost-baggage department of Trans World Airlines, had waited weeks for someone to claim two bundles of fiberglass poles used for vaulting. But no one did, and, if not for some persistence on Mr. Auer's part - combined with a little bit of luck - there would have been disappointment a continent away, in the land of the Pacific-10 Conference.

title: Three Killed as Plane Crashes Into Ocean off Atlantic City
description: At least three people died tonight when a single-engine plane plunged into the ocean about half a mile from the Boardwalk here, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Levi Sees Profits Drop
description: Levi Strauss & Company estimated late yesterday that profits for its fiscal fourth quarter ending Nov. 25 will plunge 97 percent, to about $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share, from $51.6 million, or $1.22 a share, in the year- earlier period. It sales sales would decline about 15 percent, to about $600 million, from $705 million.

title: VICORP'S BIG BUYING SPREE
description: Twenty-six years ago, scarcely anybody who stopped for a meal at the Village Inn, a small pancake house in the Rocky Mountains, could have guessed that it would one day grow into a coast-to-coast food chain with 525 restaurants.

title: Goalie Suspended
description: Don Beaupre , a goaltender for the Minnesota North Stars, was suspended by the National Hockey League for six games for hitting a Buffalo Sabre, Ric Selling , on the head with a stick Nov. 9. Beaupre is to begin serving the suspension today and will be eligible to return Dec. 1, against Calgary. . . . Pat Boutette , a 32-year-old forward for the Pittsburgh Penguins, was traded to the Hartford Whalers, his former team, for the rights to Ville Siren , a 20-year- old defenseman now serving in the military in Finland.

title: Women Voters, Winners and Losers
description: Through the political campaign the women's vote was courted and analyzed, simplified into a monolith and dismissed as a myth. In other arenas, as we said last spring, women are finally earning ''the sacred sixpence'' - Virginia Woolf's term for the influence that arises out of independence.

title: U.S. Delegation in Taiwan
description: A United States Congressional delegation arrived here today for a three-day visit and talks with Taiwanese leaders. Foreign Ministry sources said the delegation, led by Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, was expected to assure Taiwan of Washington's continued friendship during President Reagan's second term in office.

title:

Clark said yesterday at a conference marking the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Civil Rights Act.

title: REFINING THE BASICS OF A TAX STRATEGY
description: WHEN the cocktail party chatter turns to taxes and investments, someone in the crowd half-jests about a recurring nightmare: His tax shelter has suddenly turned profitable. The tax losses that were supposed to whittle down his taxes suddenly turn into profits on which more taxes are due than ever.

title: A DEMOCRATIC NATION OF SPECIAL INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LISZT'S REQUIEM -A DEFINITE RARITY
description: Franz Liszt, who took four minor church orders in 1865 and thenceforth called himself an abbe, did seem to have a strong religious feeling. That is part of his eternal fascination. Liszt's curiously lopsided path through life saw him Europe's greatest pianist, whose career as a touring virtuoso lasted only some eight years. It saw him admired as one of Europe's great lovers; and yet from the beginning he had a mystical, religious bent. It saw him vain and spoiled, yet extraordinarily kind and helpful to his colleagues. He made a big thing about being Hungarian, but could never speak the language. A complicated man, Franz Liszt, and there have been those able to see only one side of his profile. The great English critic Ernest Newman was one, and his study of Liszt remains one of the all-time hatchet jobs.

title: A NEW GENERATION OF NAVAJOS
description: WHEN PETERSON Zah, chairman of the Navajo Tribal Council, visits his parents, he travels to one of the rocky, windswept valleys that seam the face of the 2.1 million-acre Black Mesa in northeastern Arizona. On the map, the spot is identified as Low Mountain. To the Navajos, it is ''the place where the gum flows,'' a reference to the sweet, sticky pitch of the pinons that dot the hillsides. Low Mountain is remote, even by the standards of the sparsely populated, 21,400 square-mile Navajo reservation; winter snowstorms and spring mudslides can make impassable the deeply rutted dirt roads linking the region to the rest of the world.

title: A UNION COPES WITH DEREGULATION
description: WASHINGTON

title: POLLS AND PALLS; ABSOLUTE MINIMUM
description: Republican John Rowland caused something of a stir this month when, at age 27, he defeated Representative William Ratchford in Connecticut's 5th District. But as the final votes were counted, focus shifted to the contest for the state assembly seat from Waterbury that Mr. Rowland is vacating.

title: OHIO STATE TAKES TITLE BY 21-6
description: Mike Tomczak's key third-down passes in the fourth quarter and Keith Byars's three touchdowns led Ohio State to a 21-6 victory over Michigan for the Big Ten Conference title and the Rose Bowl berth.

description: The Reagan Administration is discussing the possibility of shifting funds in the Defense Department's 1986 budget so that more military assistance may be sent to friendly developing countries, a White House official has said.

description: With his team inches from the goal line and the outcome of another football season at stake, the fortunes of the Nebraska Cornhuskers again awaited the decision of Coach Tom Osborne. For the second time in less than 11 months, he made the less secure choice and put his team in a position to preserve a No. 1 ranking. And again, the game and the ranking were lost.

title: BOARD OF ELECTIONS CONTINUES COUNTING
description: THE balloting has ended, but for the County Board of Elections, the counting lingers on. By last week, all voting machines had been counted and recanvassed. Still to be counted, however, are 17,255 absentee ballots that arrived by mail by last Tuesday's deadline and at least 4,841 ''affidavit'' ballots, the Board reported.

description: MORE than two years ago, Diane Mallah of Roslyn noticed that her son Lloyd was developing tics.

Fleming of Fort Lee, N.J., and Bellport, L.I., was married to Mark Andrew Smith, the son of Shirley LaMunyon of La Jolla, Calif., and Clifford Smith of San Diego. The Rev. title: FUTURE EVENTS
description: Time for Thanksgiving

title: CONTRARIANS ON CAMPUS
description: If things were always as they appear, investing would be a harvest, not a roll of the dice. Instead, Wall Street is a place where ''the little guy is always wrong,'' and a contrary outlook on life is elevated into an investment theology. No single source is more perversely surprising than the fruits of academic research. The professors, combing through millions of transactions with their computers, have an affinity for against-the-grain results.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FASHIONABLE WORDS
description: THE announcer on the television advertisement said if I purchased a particular car I could go ''from zero to awesome.'' I had been there already. After the policeman pulled me over I posed the obligatory question, ''How fast was I going, officer?'' He replied dryly, ''You were doing awesome.'' Somewhat encouraged, I was emboldened to ask, ''Do I get a citation, sir?'' To which he retorted sharply: ''Don't be a wiseacre, buddy. It's going to cost you 50 simoleons.''

title: VENTURE CAPITALIST
description: EDWARD DUGGER 3d, chief executive officer of a Boston based venture capital firm, whose income is in the six figures, does not rely on professionals for investment advice. ''My wife and I make all our own decisions,'' he said. ''My annual income fluctuates because much of it is dependent on a bonus. So I don't make commitments beyone what I know I have.''

title: LUISA CHOOSES SERVITUDE
description: Paula Giddings is the author of ''When and Where I Enter: The Impact of Black Women on Race and Sex in America.'' A SERVANT'S TALE

description: The nation's horse population is once again thriving as more people, especially in the heavily populated Northeast and in California, take up riding for recreation.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: World Guide for the Jewish Traveler

title: ART: PAINTINGS, PASTELS AND DRAWINGS OF FRANTISEK KUPKA, AT THE HOFFELD
description: Art scholarship, like paleontology, searches constantly for ''firsts,'' and though few of these turn out to be ''Piltdown men,'' some are subject to periodic revision. Among those who came up for revision was Wassily Kandinsky, who was long considered to have pioneered abstraction (around 1910), trailed by Frantisek Kupka and Robert Delaunay, among others. Today, the consensus is that no single individual invented abstraction, but that it was an idea filling the air in the years preceding World War I, with Cubist-oriented exponents running neck-and-neck with the then expressionistic Russian.

title: 23 BLACKS HURT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Policemen firing rubber bullets, birdshot and tear gas clashed with stone- hurling black mourners during a funeral, leaving at least 23 people wounded, the authorities said today.

title: MOTHER LIKED HER ROOM WARM
description: GYPSY & ME

title: CALIFORNIA JUSTICES AWAIT VERDICT-ON THEMSELVES
description: With Election Day 1984 only 10 days past, five of California's most powerful public figures are looking ahead to November 1986. They have been for some time. The five are members of the California Supreme Court, and they face elections then. Organized opposition to some of them took shape earlier this year. So did fund-raising efforts by their defenders. Controversy is a constant on the seven-member court's docket. Twice in the last 12 months it has stirred conservative anger with rulings that knocked initiative measures off the ballot. One was a reapportionment proposal backed by most Republicans, who wanted to replace the 1982 Democratic redrawing of boundaries for legislative and Congressional districts. The court ruled that the state's constitution allowed only one reapportionment every 10 years, and the Democrats' bill had used up the quota for the 1980's. On Aug. 27, the court tossed out another initiative that, if approved, would have directed the Legislature to petition Congress to call a Constitutional Convention on an amendment to require an balanced Federal budget. The court's reasoning was that only the Legislature is empowered to petition Congress; therefore, it would be improper to allow Californians to consider withholding legislators' salaries until the petition was filed, as the initiative provided.

title: LETTERS
description: RENT REGULATIONS

title: LEBANESE SHIITE, FREED BY ISRAELIS, SAYS HE WAS BEATEN IN CAPTIVITY
description: A southern Lebanese Shiite Moslem leader who Israeli security forces had detained for nine days said today that he had been handcuffed and beaten with rifle butts, and had been kept with a bag over his head for three days.

title: NEW STYLE AT PACE
description: When they are completed, the brick-and-frame residences under construction on Bedford Road in Pleasantville, N.Y., will look like yet another of the town-house condominium developments that are springing up in just about every corner of Westchester County.

title: NASSAU BUDGET WITH SMALL TAX CUT OFFERED
description: The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, has proposed a county budget for 1985 that allows for a small decrease in the property-tax rate.

title: EAST AFRICANS MOVE TO REBUILD TIES
description: Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda are moving cautiously toward reconstructing their shattered East African Community. After nearly six years of sometimes acrimonious negotiations, they reached agreement in May on dividing the assets and liabilities of the community, which collapsed under the weight of economic and ideological rivalries in 1977. The agreement followed the reopening of the Tanzania-Kenya border, closed that year by Tanzanian President Julius K. Nyerere. A delegation of Kenyan businessmen recently visited Tanzania to promote trade. Since the border was reopened, a Kenyan official said, the growth rate in trade between the two countries has doubled. The rate between Kenya and Uganda has tripled.

title: DIVORCED MOTHER OF TWO IN JERSEY WINS RIGHT TO MOVE TO WEST COAST
description: The State Supreme Court has ruled that a divorced mother from Princeton may move to San Diego with her two young sons despite the objections of her former husband.

title: Benefits and Risks of Caffeine
description: Caffeine may both contribute to heart disease and help alleviate its symptoms, according to studies presented at a meeting of the American Heart Association here.

title: JOB GLUT WORRIES MERCHANTS
description: TOM VOGEL, the manager of Arthur's, a clothing store in Westfarms Mall, was worried. Mr. Vogel said he had anticipated ''droves of applicants'' for jobs this holiday season at the mall in West Hartford.

title: Carol E. Sweeney B a B
description: Carol Elizabeth Sweeney, a daughter of Virginia M. Sweeney of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Michael J. Sweeney, was married yesterday to Lawrence Cooper Schmidlapp, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl J. Schmidlapp 2d of Oyster Bay, L.I. Msgr. title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LIBEL: ISSUE IN A STATE OF FLUX
description: THE growing number of public-person libel suits against the press - Westmoreland v. CBS and

title:
THE BISHOP'S LETTER ON THE U.S. ECONOMY;
VISION FOR A BRIGHT ECONOMIC FUTURE
description: THE bishops have done it again. In a kind of epistolary eucharist, they have laid hands on the lifeless graphs and inert numbers often used to describe the American economy and have transformed them into a song of hope. In their ''Pastoral Letter on Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy,'' they beckon entrepreneurs, government officials, labor leaders and ordinary citizens toward a wider and more humane view of what an economy, guided by the values of dignity and participation, can and should do.

title: BACH FESTIVAL: A JOINT EFFORT
description: PRINCETON AFOUR-PART festival of J. S. Bach cantatas to celebrate the composer's impending tercentenary - Bach was born in 1685 - is scheduled to open here this month and continue through March 3. The first concert is Nov. 30.

title: Mellon Grant to Aid Humanities at Yale
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has granted $500,000 to Yale University as an endowment base for educational programs in the humanities, the university president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, announced this week.

title: TEXAS ENDS T.C.U.'S DREAM
description: They put thousands of folding chairs in Amon G. Carter Stadium today in places where people had never watched a Texas Christian football game before. After all, the Horned Frogs were battling for a possible Cotton Bowl berth with the powerful Texas Longhorns, and T.C.U. hadn't been to that bowl in 25 years, the last time it won the Southwest Conference title.

title: CENTERS FOR PEACE FIND HOMES IN THE COUNTY
description: IN two different parts of the county, centers have recently been established that will offer

title: A MUDDLE IN A PUDDLE
description: AT PENN STATION IN New York I sat in a puddle of beer.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE calendar on the kitchen wall is rapidly being filled in as the social season evolves. The boxes in it are pencilled in with duty visits, pleasure visits, doctor and dentist appointments, dates for having the car checked, ceremonial occasions that will demand the purchase of gifts with comfortable foresightedness (just after we had thought to settle down with ZPG - remember that? - the Zero Population Growth in our circles has given way to a baby boom that requires gift giving almost on a weekly schedule).

title: ON LIBEL AND OFFICIALS
description: Everyone knnws that media attacks on public officials Nre sometimes unfair, dishonest, careless, mean-spirited and self-serving. But a public official who claims he or she was maligned by critics and seeks redrers in court must meet a standard of proof more stringent than that faced by a private citizen.

title: BEST SELLERS Nov. 18, 1984
description: Fiction*1 14 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 25 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *3

title: ISRAELI DANCERS WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: ''For me, it's not a matter of the deaf and the hearing, but the meeting of two worlds, Moshe Efrati says, talking of the Kol Demama Dance Company, the Israeli troupe of deaf and hearing modern dancers that opens on Tuesday at City Center. ''We are two peoples living on the same planet but with different stimulations.''

title: HOLIDAY AMERICANA: FROM REVUE TO JAZZ
description: WITH Thanksgiving only a few days away, let's start with a few cheerful displays of Americana.

title: SOME CHANGES IN THE MAKING FOR COLLEGE BASKETBALL
description: IT seems as though John Thompson

title: YALE RALLIES TO TOPPLE HARVARD, 30-27
description: Carm Cozza, Yale's coach for the last 20 seasons, finally saw his team win a game in Harvard Stadium that it was expected to lose.

title: HANDMADE LACE: IN THE BRAZILIAN STYLE
description: ANNETTE EBERLY DUMBACH is a writer who lives in Fortaleza, Brazil.

title: THERE ARE WAYS TO OUTWIT GARDEN INVADERS;
description: The fur-bearing population is causing problems in suburbia. The question often asked by wildlife management professionals is ''Who is the nuisance? Man or beast?''

title: SEARCHING FOR TRUTH IN THE STRIKE ZONE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. GTS TOUGH WITH 2 BIG BANKS
description: The Government's unprecedented move to force the First National Bank of Chicago and Bank of America, parents of two of the nation's biggest banks, to shore up their foundations, reflects increasing worries that fiercer competition will lead to more failed banks. The move requires the banks to improve liquidity by increasing their capital base, and to toughen their credit policies. The Comptroller of the Currency was particularly hard on First Chicago, which reported a $71.8 million loss for the quarter after charging off $278 million in bad loans. First Chicago's main competitor, Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust, collapsed earlier this year, mainly because of bad loans and an eroded capital base.

title: MILNES FINDS A CHALLENGE IN 'BOCCANEGRA'
'A VIEW FROM THE BRIDGE' IS ONE OF ARENA'S BEST
description: ARTHUR MILLER'S ''A View From the Bridge,'' at the Arena Players Main Stage Theater in East Farmingdale, is a powerful, heartbreaking drama about love and jealousy on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: THE GLUT IN TAX-EXEMPT BONDS
description: -free bonds are wondering why they have not participated in the bond market rally of the past five months. Despite the significant price advances of Treasury and corporate issues since May, prices of tax-exempt bonds have languished.

title: Susan Spanton to Wed Bruce Blum, Executive
description: Susan Beth Spanton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Spanton of Roslyn Heights, L.I., plans to be married Dec. 22 to Bruce Alan Blum, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Blum of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: A LOT FOR $225
description: Instead of Park Place, there is Fort Salonga Road, and Boardwalk has been replaced by Woodbine Avenue. Both are major commercial streets in Northport, a village on Long Island's North Shore.

title: AFFORDABLE RENTALS CAN BE FOUND
description: If you're realistic, we have an apartment for you,'' said

title: STRIKING THAT FIRST BLOW FOR 'GOOD NEWS'
description: HARTFORD FOLLOWING major losses by the Democrats in the Nov. 6 election, Governor O'Neill sought last week to take the initiative in the political struggles that will begin officially with the convening of the new Republican-controlled General Assembly on Jan. 9.

title: IN CHILEAN SLUM, A RAID, THEN A VISIT
description: By midmorning today, Claudina Nunez had set up a wooden table behind the parish hall to continue taking the names of men who have not been seen since the armed forces swept through an impoverished neighborhood here Thursday morning and rounded up 2,000 people.

title: The LegacyOf Baby Fae
description: She was a curiosity and a cause cel ebre, at once the embodiment of bold new medical technology and of many ethical questions it raises. Death came Thursday evening, 20 days after the heart of a baboon replaced the faltering heart of the tiny, helpless infant known around the world as Baby Fae. But the arguments about the experiment may only be beginning.

title: NURSING TEACHERS HELPING IN HOSPITALS
description: THE UConn Nursing School is sending faculty members to two hospitals in the Hartford area one day a week to train the staffs and recommend changes in procedures and patient care.

title: EDEN ON THE ISLE OF BAHRAIN
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: A CASE OF WOUNDED PRIDE
description: Wayne Kalyn

title: TITLE TO FLORIDA AND JOB TO HALL
description: After Galen Hall led Florida to seven consecutive victories and the Southeastern Conference title that eluded the Gators since 1933, the university today rewarded him by naming him the head coach after the 25-17 victory over Kentucky. Florida won the title outright when Mississippi State upset Louisiana State, 16-14.

title: GUIDELINES THE GRADUATE COURSE
description: CERTAIN routes to easy money should make an investor wary. Take the case of Thomas C. Reed, a former national security adviser in the Reagan Administration. He turned a quick $431,000 profit on the $3,400 he invested in Amax Inc. after his father, a director of the mining company, told him the company was the object of a takeover . But Mr. Reed did not get to keep his profits for long. When the Securities and Exchange Commission complained that Mr. Reed had engaged in illegal inside trading, he relinquished the profits - and now faces Federal criminal charges of securities fraud, wire fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: REPORTERS ARE A CONTINUING STORY FOR MOVIEMAKERS
description: Among others things, the arrival of the Television Age appears to have made more sharp and contradictory the nature of the American public's longstanding love-hate relationship with journalists and journalism. If various polls are to be believed, many Americans today are convinced that newspaper and television reporting, especially of politics, is more biased than it's ever been, usually in favor of liberal positions.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CONFERENCE TO FOCUS ON EARLY AMERICAN CENTS
description: Early American coppers, one of the most fascinating areas of United States numismatics, will serve as a focus for the three-day conference Nov. 30 through Dec. 2, at the New York Museum of the American Numismatic Society.

title: On Language; Shape Up Or Ship Out
description: built young woman wearing what looked to me like a white bathing suit with lace around the top and bottom. The headline identified her garment as a

title: Miss Brief to Wed M S L
description: Dr. and Mrs. Donald Kent Brief of South Orange, N.J., and Quechee Lakes, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet Gail Brief to Mark Steven Landau, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Landau of Boston. The wedding is to be March 23.

title: JAZZ OFFERINGS IN WAYNE
description: James Moody, the jazz saxophonist and flutist, will appear this afternoon at William Paterson College in Wayne. Next Sunday, the college's Jazz Room Series will offer the Rufus Reid Trio.

title: LISA HESS BRIDE OF WAYNE JONES
description: Lisa Hess, a soloist with the New York City Ballet, was married in Salt Lake City yesterday to Wayne Alan Jones, an associate with the New York law firm of Kenyon & Kenyon. G. Carlos Smith, a patriarch of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony at the Salt Lake Temple.

title: ORGANIZED LABOR IS INCREASINGLY LESS SO
description: If unions want to deal successfully with employers, Ray Rogers, a labor consultant, said recently, ''they won't get far by simply trying to harass and embarrass'' corporations. Unions, the former field representative for the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers said, must ''organize'' workers and ''disorganize'' employers, utilizing a ''divide and conquer strategy'' that pits employer against employer. Companies must be ''forced to deal with inescapable economic and political pressure,'' Mr. Rogers added.

title: BULLETIN BOARDS GO ELECTRONIC
description: WHEN Ken Sperling comes home from work and wants to talk to his friends, he turns on his personal computer and connects it to his telephone.

title: ELVIS PRESLEY: HOMAGE TO A ROCK KING
description: Elvis Presley, who was born almost 50 years ago, on Jan.8, 1935, has long been recognized as one of America's most gifted, distinctive and influential popular singers. He applied his deft, fluid phrasing, derived from blues and gospel music, to songs from the rhythm-and-blues, country, pop and gospel idioms and developed an overtly sensual, largely black-derived performance style. He was the first American popular singer to intuitively understand and creatively exploit the then nascent medium of television, which made him a star almost overnight. In one stroke, he changed the sound, the look and the feel of our popular music. He created a new dimension of celebrity as the first music-and-video-made rock star. Perhaps most important, he bound white and black, urban and rural musical idioms together so tightly that it became impossible to even imagine unraveling them.

title: INDIANS LAUNCH RELIEF DRIVE
description: Prominent Indians in the New York metropolitan area have issued an appeal for relief for the victims of the violence that followed the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TURKEY OLYMPICS

title: ; Boxers Pay Brutal Dues
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SURVIVING LIFE
description: Lisa Zeidner is the author of two novels, ''Customs'' and ''Alexandra Freed,'' and a book of poems, ''Talking Cure.'' VOICES FROM THE MOON

title: AMERICAN MALE THROWS IN THE TOWEL
description: David Lehman is the editor of ''James Merrill: Essays in Criticism.'' TOO LATE AMERICAN BOYHOOD BLUES

title: Q AND A
description: If two people have a joint lease on a rent- stabilized apartment in New York, but only one maintains it as a primary residence, can a lease be denied to one or both tenants? . . . M.B., New Brunswick, N. J.

title: WESTMORELAND AND SHARON: 2 VERY DIFFERENT STYLES
description: On the third floor of the United States Court House in lower Manhattan, a retired American general is testifying in a $120 million libel suit against CBS. On the ninth floor, a former Israeli general is pressing his own libel suit for $50 million against Time magazine.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: ON-AGAIN, OFF-AGAIN BARGAIN AIR FARES
description: Sometimes travel bargains are almost illusory: momentarily they seem within your grasp, then suddenly they disappear, at least temporarily. Such was the case with the recent promise that you could fly between most American gateway cities and London this winter on scheduled flights of major airlines for as low as $378 round trip.

title: CITY'S RENTAL-SUBSIDY PROGRAM TO GET FIRST TEST SOON
description: The next few weeks should provide the

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
SAILOR'S FAVORITE FOOD
description: SALLY HASSAN is a food and travel writer who lives in Milwaukee.

title: MIDDLESEX TAKES TITLE AGAIN
description: Middlesex (8-1) won its third Central Jersey, Group 1 championship in the last four years when it scored a 21- 0 victory over Keyport (7-2) in Middlesex. Mark Masessa led with touchdown runs of 2 and 6 yards, boosting his season total to 15 touchdowns. The senior halfback has also rushed for 1,048 yards.

title: BID FOR STANDARD JUDICIAL SENTENCES CRITICIZED
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 17 - A committee set up to draft a system of fixed sentences for criminals in New York State was strongly criticized here today when it presented its preliminary guidelines to a group of judges, lawyers and law enforcement officials.

title: PENN ROLLS, 24-0, FOR IVY TITLE
description: John McGeehan completed 11 of 16 passes for 210 yards and 2 touchdowns today as Pennsylvania routed Cornell, 24-0. The victory gave Penn its first undisputed Ivy League football title in 25 years.

title: IF IT'S TOO BAD TO BE TRUE, IT COULD BE 'DISINFORMATION'
description: The document seemed to disclose a serious foreign policy blunder by the United States, a clumsy attempt to push Austria toward military ties with the West. The letter, bearing a handwritten signature, ''Helene Von Damm'' - the American Ambassador to Austria - and written on embassy stationery with the typescript favored by Miss Von Damm's office, was particularly embarrassing in view of Austria's closely held neutrality.

title: HOW THE BIG MIG SCARE FLARED UP AND DIED DOWN
description: President Reagan keeps saying arms control tops the foreign policy agenda for his second term. But a sudden squall in Central America has disrupted his timetable. The crisis mood since his re-election has carried echoes of the early Reagan days when former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. warned of a Marxist menace in Nicaragua and urged ''going to the source'' in Cuba to quench the fire. The recent leak that the Russians might be delivering MIG fighters to Nicaragua has grown into a flood of threats and charges. It is as if Election Day had broken a dam, venting official furies penned up during the campaign and fueling suspended policy disputes.

title: Socialite-Murderer Moved
description: Frances Bernice Schreuder, the New York socialite convicted of first-degree murder in the death of her father, is suffering from ''culture shock'' and has been moved from Utah State Prison, Tony Bair, deputy warden of the prison, said Friday.

title: BROOKHAVEN GETS 'STAR WARS' CONTRACT
description: THE Brookhaven National Laboratory will receive about $2.9 million in funds from the United States Defense Department's Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as ''Star Wars,'' to conduct basic research on the effects of irradiation of semiconductors and electronic circuits, according to laboratory officials.

title: CONTROVERSIAL ARCHBISHOP O'CONNOR
description: According to Archbishop O'Connor, abortion is an act of violence. His reasoning, as stated in the article, is that ''violence never corrects violence.''

title: UNION EARNS SEMIFINAL BERTH
description: Dan Stewart passed for two touchdowns and John Johnson ran for two as Union College defeated previously unbeaten Plymouth State, 26-14, today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern Regional. Union (9-1) advanced to the semifinal next Saturday at Augustana (10-0), a 14-13 victor today at Dayton (10-1).

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: D. . MANUS PINKWATER, author of ''The Hoboken Chicken Emergency'' (Prentice-Hall, Englewood Cliffs, N.J.; $8.95), described himself in a recent interview as a victim of what he insists is a ''fairly common phobia.'' He is deathly afraid of being eaten by a chicken.

title: Nancy Rosenfeld Wed To Gary Weiss on L.I.
description: Nancy Jill Rosenfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rosenfeld of East Rockaway, L.I., was married yesterday to Gary Michael Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn I. Weiss of Muttontown, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Stanley Platik, assisted by Cantor Emanuel Perlman, performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Miss Stack Plans Dec. 29 Wedding
description: Claire Elizabeth Stack, a financial analyst with the Fidelity Management Trust Company in Boston, and Gerard Paul Richer, a member of the class of '85 at the Boston College Law School, plan to be married Dec. 29.

title: THE HARSH SPLENDOR OF THE SINAI
description: TERENCE SMITH, Washington Talk editor of The Times, was a correspondent in Israel from 1967 to 1968 and the Times bureau chief in Jerusalem from 1972 to 1976.

title: SOUTHERN CAL UPSET BY U.C.L.A., 29-10
description: John Lee set a National Collegiate Athletic Association single-season record today with five field goals as U.C.L.A stunned Rose Bowl-bound Southern Cal, 29-10. It was U.C.L.A.'s third consecutive victory, and fourth in five seasons, in the Pacific 10 Conference crosstown rivalry.

title: A CITY BALLET DANCER ADDS TO HIS ROLE AS CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Burton Taylor, a former principal dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, is a contributing editor to Dance magazine.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS THRIVING DESPITE SO-SO RECORD
description: IF statistics are an accurate barometer, the investor's attraction to mutual funds is getting stronger and stronger, in spite of their mediocre track record over the past 15 months. The reasons that individual and institutional inves- tors keep pouring money into the funds - at the end of August the combined assets of 770 equity mutual funds tracked by the Investment Company Institute in Washington totalled $128.2 billion, up from $104.6 billion a year earlier - are clear, investment specialists say. But there are drawbacks, too.

title: BAD ADVICE ON BLACKS
description: A lot of conventional ignorance has been spewed out in the wake of the Presidential election. The worst of it is couched as advice to the Democrats about what to do about blacks in framing an appeal that will woo back a white majority in 1988.

title: Christine Boeke Wed to William Jenks
description: Christine Boeke, an account manager for Muir Cornelius Moore Inc., a New York advertising and sales promotion agency, and William James Jenks, a manager in the liquid packaging division of the International Paper Company in New York, were married in Indianapolis yesterday. The Rev. Tanya Vonnegut Beck performed the ceremony at Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral.

title: FOR U.S. BROKERS OVERSEAS,HOW SWEET IT IS
description: The rush by foreigners into dollar-denominated securities has meant some good times for overseas offices of American brokerages in the past several years. Many experienced a sharp rise in sales, staff and office space to keep up with demand.

title: YEAR-END TACTICS FOR TAXES
description: PHIL POHL, a Huntington Beach, Calif., engineer, intends to check out his financial situation soon to determine if there are any steps he can take to reduce his 1984 taxes. ''I'll try to look for something that I can do before the end of the year,'' he said. ''For example, I was thinking of putting a little bit of money into a real estate limited partnership that will give me a little more write-off.''

title:
DINING OUT;
A MINGLING OF THE UNEXPECTED
description: -star restaurant going on two serves up light, imaginative renditions of commonly offered dishes. The kitchen's skill in seasoning and its experiments in mingling unexpected flavors and textures deserves admiration. Furthermore, it has a knack for letting the natural flavors of the ingredients speak for themselves and eschews masking them with heavy, intense sauces. With a little fine tuning in the kitchen and better managerial judgment in the dining rooms, the 1852 Inn could be a standout spot.

title: CASUALTIES
description: Cornell Capa, formerly a photojournalist, is director of the International Center for Photography in New York City. WAR TORN

title: International
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1984 Private talks with Soviet officials will be given priority in coming weeks by the Reagan Administration in the hope of beginning high-level discussions early next year on a wide range of arms-control issues. Administration officials assert that in the aftermath of President Reagan's re-election, signs of movement toward negotiations, which have been suspended, have become apparent in recent public statements from Moscow and Washington. (Page 1, Column 4.) Ethiopia's food aid must continue for at least a year and possibly more, according to Western experts. The experts, who include relief officials as well as Western diplomats, estimate that a minimum of of 600,000 metric tons of grain will be needed in the next 12 months. So far, only half that amount has been pledged. (1:1.)

title: LIBRARY FOR BLIND IS MORE ACCESSILE
description: ANEW $1.1 million Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped in Rocky Hill houses over 120,000 talking books - books on records or tapes - and over 10,000 Braille volumes. That is a great improvement over the library's previous facilities, in the basement of an office building in Hartford.

title: DEVELOPER GREENS A BLOCK IN BROOKLYN
description: Twenty-two new trees were planted

title: FOR EPISCOPALIANS, A RENEWAL
description: -HUNDRED years ago this month, a Connecticut clergyman named Samuel Seabury journeyed to Scotland, knelt before a church leader and became the first Anglican Bishop for the new United States.

title: HOW COMPANIESBID FAREWELL
description: Donald MacNaughton says that when he became president and chief executive of Prudential in 1969 he squirmed at the way his predecessor, Orville Beal, had been abruptly ushered out. ''The poor guy was trying to keep up with all his correspondence and his files without an office and secretary.''

title: They Pick UpAnd Deliver
description: NASA has always had trouble drumming up business for - and inspiring confidence in - its space shuttle flights. Last week, the voyage of the spaceship Discovery offered the most dramatic sales pitch to date for the shuttle's services.

title: FIVE DECADES OF CHAIR DESIGN
description: The most ambitious, comprehensive and superbly presented of the many decorative arts exhibitions on view this season in New York galleries is ''Mackintosh to Mollino - 50 Years of Chair Design,'' at Barry Friedman, 26 East 82d Street (through Feb. 14). Mr. Friedman assembled 75 examples of 20th-century European and American chairs over the past two years - many more than he expected he would uncover. When the formidable results exceeded the capacity of his main gallery, Mr. Friedman decided that instead of limiting the scope and size of the show, he would expand the exhibition to the gallery's new annex at 242 East 82d Street.

title: NETS TRIUMPH DESPITE SHORT'S 59 POINTS
description: The Nets overcame a 59-point performance by Golden State forward Purvis Short, the highest single-game output in the National Basketball Association this season, to defeat the Warriors tonight, 131-114.

title: Flights Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION ; 90-Cent Fare,Theoretically
description: The Transit Authority has a plan to save New York's 90-cent fare, at least through 1985, but there are the usual uncertainties. For one, some Republicans in Albany have already suggested that it should be raised to a dollar.

title: 15TH STRAIGHT DRAW IN CHESS SAW LITTLE ACTION ON BOARD
description: The 24th game of the world championship chess match in Moscow featured a lot of homework but little action during the actual playing session.

title: Tiffany Cross to Become Bride of Timothy P. Daly
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Cross of Somers, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Tiffany Cross to Timothy P. Daly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Daly of Windsor Locks, Conn. A March wedding is planned.

title: KING SCORES 30 AS KNICKS ROMP
description: The Knicks (3-9) faced the Cleveland Cavaliers (1-10) last night at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks, injury-riddled, undermanned and struggling, won easily, 112-88, an indication of how bad the Cavaliers are.

title: INVESMENTS TO BALANCE PORTFOLIOS
description: Where is the market headed? What strategies should an investor now follow? Three professionals - Leon G. Cooperman, partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, Henry R. Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Charles Flather, executive vice president of the State Street Research and Management Company, Boston - give assessments in a discussion with editors of The New York Times.

title: A Transplant Patient Dies in Connecticut
description: The first heart transplant patient in Connecticut, 52-year-old Mary Jendraszek, died suddenly tonight at Yale-New Haven Hospital, officials said.

title: Melissa Noelle Keehn the Bride of D. R. Grossman
description: Melissa Noelle Keehn, a daughter of Theodora A. Remas of Madison, N.J., and Robert W. Keehn of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday to Donald Reed Grossman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Grossman of East Hanover, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David R. Hegg performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Frederick Depenbrock, a Presbyterian minister.

title: The A.R.M.S. Concert
description: Part I: Featuring Eric Clapton and Steve Winwood. 60 minutes. Part II: Featuring Jimmy Page, Jeff Beck, Eric Clapton, Ronnie Lane. 59 minutes.

title: LUNCHTIME LIBERTY DEBATED
description: THE Lawrence Board of Education and parents of elementary school children in the district have locked horns over who ultimately has authority to decide whether the children can risk going into the outside world during lunch hour.

title: Tiger Coaches Resign Saying he wanted to spend more time with his family, and citing other personal reasons,
description: Roger Craig announced his retirement as pitching coach of the World Series champion Detroit Tigers.

title: THE ESSAY LIVES - IN DISGUISE
description: The informal or familiar essay is a wonderfully tolerant form, able to accommodate rumination, memoir, anecdote, diatribe, scholarship, fantasy and moral philosophy. It might have an elegant form or an amoebic shapelessness, held together by little more than the author's voice. Working in it liberates you from the structure of the ''well-made'' short story and allows you to ramble in a way that reflects the mind at work. You have an added freedom at this historical moment, because no one is looking over your shoulder. Nobody much cares. Commercially, essay volumes rank even lower than poetry. Phillip Lopate, a professor of English at the University of Houston, has written several volumes of poetry and essays and a novel, ''Confessions of Summer.''

title: TOP NEW YORK COURT REJECTS GIRL'S SUIT FOR 'WRONGFUL LIFE'
description: An 8-year- old girl born with Down's syndrome after her mother was told to expect a healthy baby boy cannot sue for ''wrongful life'' payments, New York's highest court has ruled.

title: PANEL'S FINDINGS ON POLICE ABUSE
description: Do white New York City police officers routinely use excessive force against black people? That politically charged question was in the forefront of public debate last year, in part because of hearings organized by a House subcommittee. Last week, the subcommittee released its long-awaited report, but the 24-page document never quite answered the question.

title: HELP WHEN HELP IS NEEDED
description: DECISIONS lead to other decisions, questions to harder questions. So it is with financial planning. Increasingly, Americans are overwhelmed by the complexity of their finances and are turning to professional financial planners for help in sorting things out. How much to save, how much to invest, how much for retirement, what about the second home, how about the four-year-old's college tuition years down the line?

title: FOR VISITING WOMEN, THE WELCOME VARIES
description: JUDITH MILLER is chief of the Cairo bureau of The New York Times.

title: AN OASIS BETWEEN TWO CIVILIZATIONS
description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The Times.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Caroline Hightower is the director of the American Institute of Graphic Arts. THE LOOK AGAIN . . . AND AGAIN, AND AGAIN, AND AGAIN BOOK.

title: PIANO VIRTUOSOS EXPLORE BEETHOVEN
description: James R. Oestreich writes frequently about recorded music.

title: THE NATION ; A CAREER MAN GETS POSTAL JOB
description: Perhaps Edward J. Rollins should have conducted his own campaign for the job of Postmaster General instead of leaving it to White House aides. Last week, the Postal Service board rejected the Administration's appeal on behalf of Mr. Rollins, director of the Reagan-Bush campaign committee, and chose Paul N. Carlin for the job.

title: MAYOR SHARPE'S LEGACY IN MOUNT VERNON
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: THE SAD REALITIES IF INDEXING
description: WITH the advent of indexing, the traditional link between inflation and the personal income tax will be broken for the first time. When the indexing mechanism goes into effect next year, tax rates will be automatically adjusted for inflation - but this historic step may turn out to be more rhetoric than reality for most taxpayers. And once higher Social Security taxes are factored in, most people will find that at best they have just a few extra dollars in their paychecks each week.

title: WELFARE RECIPIENTS INCREASE
description: DESPITE an unemployment rate that is one of the lowest in the nation, there has been a steady and unexpected growth in the number of people in Connecticut receiving general welfare assistance, and studies of the situation are in progress.

description: To the Editor:

description: ''Many others, particularly children, will suffer problems for the rest of their lives, including impaired physical and mental growth.'' - Hugh Goyder, field representative in Ethiopia for Oxfam. (18:4.)

title: A GOLDEN AGE MUST RUN THE GAMUT OF ACHIEVEMENT
description: Short of engendering a golden age, as from time to time seems possible in first youth, we should all of us like to live in one. To live through what W. H. Auden called ''a low, dishonest decade'' is degradation, and although Auden had the 1930's in mind, the phrase will bear more recent application.

title: CONTROVERSIAL ARCHBISHOP O'CONNOR
description: It was refreshing to read the article about Archbishop O'Connor. As a practicing Roman Catholic, I strongly support the Archbishop.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Derailing Cats
description: Hundreds of stray cats were reported prowling the railroad tunnels of Grand Central Terminal, and in July there was an epidemic of flea bites among workers in the tunnels. A cat lover suggested that the workers wear flea collars on their ankles, but the Metro-North railroad had a more permanent solution in mind.

description: LOU CARNESECCA begins his 17th

description: To the Editor:

description: The 55-plus group is active, affluent, growing in size and willing to spend,'' said Carole B. Allan, a consultant on the needs of older Americans.

title: CHILREN OF CRISIS ON TOUR
description: NEWTON THIS tranquil Sussex County community was the jumping- off point recently for 26 young survivors of war and political struggle as they began a nationwide tour for peace by sharing their stories of childhood suffering.

title: U.S. WEIGHING CUT IN MEDICAID FOR SOME STATE
description: The Reagan Administration is considering recommending further restrictions on Medicaid payments to states where health-care costs are considered excessive.

description: This newly incorporated town is to hold its first municipal election Christmas Eve. Elsie Garrett, Okaloosa County's supervisor of elections, said she had received many complaints about the election date. The City Charter says the election for Mayor and City Council shall take place 45 days after certification of incorporation.

title: TOWN-HOUSE COMPLEX GETS A RUSTIC CAST
description: Sal F. Falciglia faced a knotty problem when it came time to install a sewage treatment system in the 440-unit town-house development he was building on a hillside in West Milford.

title: Diana Silver Is Wed To Karl W. Johnson
description: At the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York yesterday Diana R. Silver, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Richard Silver of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married to Karl W. Johnson, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William A. Johnson, also of Scarsdale. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father, canon theologian at the Cathedral and the Albert V. Danielsen Professor of Christian Thought and Philosophy at Brandeis University.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN A FIRSTBORN CHILD CLINGS PRECARIOUSLY TO LIFE
description: RACHEL is 5 years old now. An active 5 who hangs upside down from the monkey bars, with her sandy hair flying and arms waving. An inquisitive 5 whose metaphysical questions have us scratching our heads even as we stifle our giggles.

title: O'BRIEN UNDER PRESURE AGAINST OILERS
description: In yet another twist in his stalled quarterback career, Ken O'Brien makes his National Football League debut as a starter today in the Astrodome. Perhaps it will settle him.

title: SEALS, ACROBATS, ELEPHANTS, CLOWNS-AND ONE RING
description: Valerie Brooks writes freguently about the arts.

title: Fighter's Close Call
description: Kim Chong Suk, a 19-year-old South Korean fighter, survived a close call in Manila Friday night when he collapsed in his dressing room after absorbing a barrage of punches in a nontitle fight against the World Boxing Council flyweight champion, Frank Cedeno. Kim, who lost the fight in a seventh-round knockout, was taken to a hospital where doctors performed an emergency operation to remove a fist-sized blood clot that had formed beneath his skull. Later, hospital spokesmen said he had regained consciousness and was out of danger, but would probably remain in the hospital for a month.

title: WHAT IS TV DOING TO THE ELECTION PROCESS?
description: What hath television wrought? The Reagan landslide? The Mondale defeat? The abandonment of substantive issues? Arguments flourish. Politicians and scholars look back. They agree that television has changed the political process; they disagree on what this means. Clearly, television has altered party structure and revised election campaigns. A pretty face, if not a necessity, is an asset not to be despised. At the same time, no one seems quite sure how this works. What on television registers on our psyches, and what only passes us by? What, in fact, is television?

title: A NATION HOOKED ON FOREIGN FUNDS
description: THE Reagan Administration's

title: REAL ESTATE: MORE THAN A HOME
description: Investing in real estate is becoming increasingly popular with small investors. While Americans for decades have enjoyed the tax advantages of owning their own homes, in recent years they have been discovering the financial benefits of owning property as an investment. Following are four profiles of investors who have bought properties with an eye to what it will do for their investment portfolios.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HOLIDAY BAZAAR IN GREENWICH
description: CLASSIC holiday colors provided by crimson poinsettias and deep green pine garlands will decorate the hall of the Greenwich Community Center the weekend starting Nov. 30 when the annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar is held.

title: TROOPERS IN FIGHT ON RETIRING
description: TRENTON THE New Jersey State Police are embroiled in an internal dispute over mandatory retirement that is pitting younger troopers and officers against older executives.

title: NEW DIRECTOR RELFECTS ON SUMERFARE
description: CALL Christopher Hunt an ''embrysario'': His own word for an impressario in a formative - or embryonic - phase. That is how the 46-year-old British-born arts administrator/consultant/critic/promoter/manager perceives his role as the newly appointed festival director of Pepsico's Summerfare at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: TEMPLE UPSETS WEST VA.
description: Jim Cooper made a second-chance field goal from 36 yards as time ran out to give Temple a 19-17 upset of West Virginia today.

title: NON-STORY PLAYS THAT POSE DIFFICULT QUESTIONS
description: There are some ideas that even the best well- made plays aren't designed to handle comfortably. Mainstream Western drama typically tells a story in a straightforward narrative style, with actors playing recognizable characters. Whether the drama ends with an emotional catharsis or with specific insights into human behavior, its conclusions are usually tidy.

title: SECOND-TERM ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY
description: WASHINGTON FOR two years the country has reveled in a booming economy, but as the economic expansion now enters its third year, investors have reason to worry. The months ahead are rife with uncertain-ty, making betting on the future a crap shoot.

title: IN SHORT
description: Queen Elizabeth has arrived in San Francisco; just as Mary Ann Singleton, television reporter, goes to cover the scene, one of the Queen's officers jumps ship. Mary Ann's husband, Brian, doesn't know that he's infertile, but Mary Ann does, so she decides to. . . . Thus begins ''Babycakes,'' and the fourth installment of Armistead Maupin's San Francisco saga careens beautifully on. People who haven't read his ''Tales of the City,'' ''More Tales of the City'' and ''Further Tales of the City'' might initially be confused by the plethora of characters, but they should continue. ''Babycakes,'' unlike the ''Tales,'' preserves a sense of irony while making paramount the values of warmth and love. Almost a decade into their promiscuous but caring friendships, the characters are tempered by age and wisdom, though still layered in reflecting, intermittently revealing levels of absurdity. Gestures have a life of their own - an ''Elizabethan'' wave of the hand, for example, belongs first to the Queen, then to a socialite, then to Mona, a mail-order lesbian bride, making equal the essentially unequal. If British high life and low life don't come across as different from San Francisco's, who cares? Credit, as Mr. Maupin does, ''the global village,'' or suspend disbelief and concentrate on the mostly deft twists and turns of plot. ''Babycakes'' seethes with pleasantly nasty topical references and has been likened by the over-enthusiastic to Dickens's Victorian melodramas and to Wodehouse's cheerful fables. Mr. Maupin's style, though, with all its near-perfect ear (''crumbling umber castle''), is still too alienated and grotesque for many, and Babycakes herself - Mary Ann - isn't central enough to function as a proper picaresque heroine.

title: STEAKHOUSE WITH AN AIR OF FINESSE
description: THE Polo Club, which opened a few months ago in Roslyn, is a steakhouse and theN some. The suggestion of pretension in its name does not detract from the seriousness of its approach.

title: VENTURE CAPITAL'S HOT NEW BREED
description: WASHINGTON LIKE the entrepreneurs they finance, a new generation of venture capitalists has spotted a market niche and rushed to fill it. Scooping up the riskiest deals around - new companies just starting up - and ''seeding'' them with small and ''seeding'' them with small amounts of capital in exchange for a hefty chunk of ownership, these new venture capitalists are handling deals that many of their older, larger brethren now shun.

title: NEW LABEL CAPTURES AN OLD JAZZ STYLE
description: For more than a quarter of a century, Bob Erdos, one of the owners of Danskin, Inc., a firm that manufacturers leotards, tights and other clothing for dancers, was an avid fan of traditional jazz - primarily music recorded in the 1920's. He would travel anywhere in this country or overseas to hear musicians who were still trying to play the musical styles and the songs that typified that first decade of recorded jazz.

title: HINGE OF HISTORY
description: John Milton Cooper Jr. is a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. His most recent book is ''The Warrior and the Priest,'' on Woodrow Wilson and Theodore Roosevelt. SAFE FOR DEMOCRACY

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 BEST FRIENDS
description: While this may be the day of the robot and other science-fiction-related toys, back in the Victorian era animals dominated the children's toy and book markets. There were hand- painted wooden rocking horses, four- wheeled pony cycles, books featuring ''The Roosevelt Bears'' and ''Young Riders'' paper dolls. Samples of these items, and some 80 other vintage objects gleaned from its own vaults and borrowed from private and institutional collections, go on display today at the History Museum of the Museums of Stony Brook. The holiday exhibition, called ''Best Friends: The Family Pet in 19th-Century America'' to suggest the special relationship between Victorian youngsters and their pets, runs through April 14 and can be seen from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesdays through Saturdays and noon to 5 P.M. Sundays. The museum is on Route 25A and admission is $2.75, or $2.25 for the elderly and students, $1.50 for children 6 through 12, and free for those under 6. In conjunction with the exhibition, the museum is also holding child-parent workshops, ''Come Along to Yesterday,'' on Dec. 8 and 15. For registration information call 751-0066. PAISLEY SHAWLS

title: Data Bank; November 18, 1984
U.S. TO EMPHASIZE PRIVATE MEETINGS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Administration officials said today that they would give priority in coming weeks to private discussions with Soviet officials in the hope of beginning high-level talks early next year on a wide range of arms-control issues.

title: SAHARAN REBELS WIN A DIPLOMATIC VICTORY
description: In the empty expanse and pounding heat of the Western Sahara, the Polisario Front, an army of leftist rebels, has been losing ground in its fight for independence from Morocco. But although unable to win on the battlefield, the front scored an important diplomatic victory last week, jolting the complex power calculations in North Africa. The Organization of African Unity, meeting in Ethiopia, recognized and seated the Polisario's proclaimed Saharan Arab Democratic Republic. Morocco promptly withdrew from membership in the 21- year-old regional organization, an unprecedented action. In support of Morocco, Zaire walked out temporarily.

title: UNAFFILIATED VOTERS STILL 'SECOND PARTY'
description: for at least a decade the state's ''second party'' - may hold the key to the state's political future, according to political observers.

title: HOW TO TAKE ON THE PROS AND COME OUT AT THE TOP
description: Generations of investors - some naive, some sophisticated - have searched for the key to success in the stock market. Most, however, have searched in vain. Like disillusioned horse players, many have concluded it is a game that cannot be won, at least not by ordinary souls, not when they are forced to match wits with highly paid professionals whose command of hundreds of millions of dollars gives them special information and dirt- cheap commission rates.

title: SCHOOL WHERE HOPE IS AN 'A'
description: SOUTH ORANGE THE children who pour noisily out of the yellow school bus that pulls up in front of 342 South Ridgewood Road here each weekday look like schoolchildren everywhere.

title: SHE DICTATES HOW TO BE A SECRETARY
description: '' THIS country is becoming more and more a service country,'' said Eleanor P. Vreeland of Garden City. ''And there is nothing that is more in the service industry than a secretarial position.''

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: On How to Handle A Wrong Number I must chide the Westchester section for its selection on Oct. 28 entitled, ''Wrong Number? Get Even.'' Of all the beautiful, sensitive, humorous and timely pieces you must receive, it's difficult to fathom why this almost malicious piece of writing was chosen.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATS COLGATE BY 17-7
description: The afternoon ticked along and everyone waited for Rutgers to do as expected, but that did not happen. The Scarlet Knights, a new power in the East, defeated Colgate by 17-7 today, but did not crash down heavily on the Red Raiders.

title: HMONG IN U.S. FIND LITTLE PROFIT IN AN ANCIENT ART
description: When Pai Yi Vu was a young girl living on a farm in Laos, she learned the ancient needlework patterns of the Hmong people by watching her mother and sister decorate the family's clothes.

title: DANCE: WORK INSPIRED BY CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY
description: The inspiration dance can draw from the art of Chinese calligraphy was on view again Friday night at the Asia Society with a dance work entitled ''Dancing Ink II'' by the Israeli- born choreographer, Ohad Naharin.

title: BBC to Stop Televising Beauty Pageants
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation will stop televising beauty pageants because they are anachronistic and almost offensive, the state-owned network announced today.

title: SEARCHING FOR TRUTH IN THE STRIKE ZONE
description: To the Editor:

title: POLLS AND PALLS; BustersStarting in 1936 there was ''Gangbusters,'' the radio program that came on with roaring cars and blasting submachine guns - came on, that is, like gangbusters. The program faded but the idiom lingers on. Now, since June, we have had ''Ghostbusters,'' the movie about some amiable hustlers who exorcise mysterious spirits from much of Manhattan. Even people who didn't see the film have seen its logotype - a ghost, under a red circle crossed by the diagonal slash that says Stop. This time, it's the logotype that lingers on. More than lingers: flourishes. It's turning out to be the most copied bit of iconography since we all learned how to H New York. The imitations of Ghostbusters are coming on like gangbusters. The Presidential campaign brought Fritzbusters and Reagan Busters. Teen-age thugs in California who beat up vagrants who sleep under bridges pronounce themselves Trollbusters. Pan Am advertises vacation Pricebusters. New York City traffic agents have become Gridlock Busters and cigarette foes are Smokebusters.
description: Enough already. There comes a time in the history of any good idea when to copy it anymore is to run it into the ground.

title: KEPPING TRACK WITH A COLLECTION INVENTORY
description: As the end of the year draws near and philatelic thoughts may flow to end- of-the-year tax time, an inventory system may be important. Keeping track of a stamp collection is complicated by a number of factors, not the least of which is the hoarding instinct.

title: SYRACUSE BEATEN BY BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Syracuse, and some strong winds, frustrated Boston College's passing attack today, so Doug Flutie and his teammates turned to the running game and came away with a victory and an anticipated berth in the Cotton Bowl.

title: FROM THE FIRST GREAT FLOWERING OF ENGLISH ART
description: Anglo-Saxon England was created by tribesmen living on the northern coasts of Holland and Germany during the late stages of the Roman Empire. When Rome pulled its garrisons out of Britain in A.D. 410, leaving the island undefended, the Angles and the Saxons leapt across the North Sea, and 40 years later their villages were well established.

title:
THE WORLD;
Third Marcos FoeIs a Victim
description: The wheels of justice have begun to turn against those who conspired to kill the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino last year, but this has not discouraged others from using assassination as a political weapon in the Philippines.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: STRAIGHT from the Sixth Middle School of Changsha, in China's Hunan Province, to the high school in Hastings-on-Hudson will soon come 26-year-old Yi-Wen Yu , teacher of English. Mrs. Yu will arrive in the county next month, accompanied by another teacher from Hunan Province, Yang-Wen Zheng , who will head for Bronxville High School. Late last week, the American Field Service announced a third teacher had been assigned to Pelham High School. The teacher, Sumalee Timcharoen , is a 32 year old from Nakorn Pathom, Thailand.

title: L.I. FERRIES VIE FOR NEW ROUTES
description: WITH the foundering of plans for a bridge linking eastern Long Island and the Connecticut shore, the two passenger ferry lines that ply Long Island Sound have embarked on a race for new crossing routes.

title: Reaching 60, As Good as Ever
description: I would like to add to Janet K. Weisman's ''Topic'' (Nov. 4) on being a senior citizen.

title: 5 INVESTMENTS FAVORED UNDER THE TAX LAWS
description: WASHINGTON INVESTMENTS that receive favorable tax treatment are much in demand - and a wide choice is available. On one end of the spectrum are tax shelters, traditionally favored by the affluent, who have substantial incomes they need to protect. At the other end are the more popular and more conservative Individual Retirement Accounts and municipal bonds. Following is a look at five tax-advantaged investments: I.R.A.'s, annuities, municipal bonds, real estate and tax shelters.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHY GRANDCHILDREN ARE SO MUCH 'BETTER' THAN CHILDREN
description: LAST year, Sept. 11 was a Sunday. At 3 A.M. an exhausted, exalted, tearful telephone voice said, ''Happy Grandparents Day.'' The miracle had happened. A new baby was born to our family.

title: In Search of Asia's Mighty Mahseer
description: IF you are well-heeled and have become

title: Pop Music
description: ''Accentuate the Positive,'' a revue-tribute featuring the lyrics and music of the late Johnnny Mercer, sung by a number of talented singers from Broadway and beyond, begins three evenings of performances Sunday night at the Bottom Line. The two-act show, directed by Robert Nigro, will touch on some 70 songs by the Georgia-born songwriter.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Zimbabwe Leader Vows To Have Free Election
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today that the Government would do all it could to insure that a general election due by next March was free and fair.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
TAKE TIME TO APPRECIATE SIMPLE PLEASURES
description: WE have a tradition in this country of setting aside a day each year for honoring mothers, fathers, sweethearts, independence and then take them for granted the other 364 days. Perhaps in our daily lives we could be more cognizant of the good things we do have. Yes, call it Thanksgiving but practice it more than on just the last Thursday of November.

title: GEORGES BANK CASE UPSETS FISHERMEN
description: THOUGH few Stonington fishermen work as far away as the Georges Bank, the Oct. 12 World Court ruling dividing the disputed fishing area there between the United States and Canada is expected to have at least an indirect effect on Connecticut's only commercial fishing fleet.

title: MAN, NOT NATURE, BLAMED FOR MANY DISASTERS
description: Many disasters attributed to nature, such as floods and droughts, are actually caused or made worse by human activity, according to a new study of the causes and effects of major calamities.

title: Laurie Grant Married To Douglas C. Gelber
description: Laurie Jean Grant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Randolph Grant of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Douglas Charles Gelber, a son of Margaret Gelber of Oradell, N.J., and David Alan Gelber of Bergenfield, N.J. The Rev. Richard Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: MATTHEWS JURY TO HEAR TAPES CONTAINING NEW ALLEGATIONS
description: When the Federal jury in the extortion and bribery trial of Michael J. Matthews returns to the courtroom in Newark this week, it will hear new allegations of organized-crime involvement by the former Atlantic City Mayor.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AT THE age of 72, Morris Pesin of Jersey City has become an official legend in his own time. This month's ''legend'' in New Jersey Bell's Tel- News tells of Mr. Pesin's 18-year dream of turning the rubble of Jersey City's shoreline facing the Statue of Liberty into a park.

title: OPPOSITION VOWS STRONG CHALLENGE TO SANDINISTAS
description: Opposition leaders who won seats in the new National Assembly said in interviews this week that they intended to present a strong challenge to the governing Sandinista Front.

title: ACTIVIST CLERGY DEFINES ITS ROLE
description: ''MY avocation,'' Rabbi Michael A. Robinson said last week, ''is hiking. I'll march for any cause.'' Rabbi Robinson, who heads Croton's Temple Israel of Northern Westchester is one of several religious leaders in the county as comfortable on a picket line as in a pulpit.

title: ST. ANTHONY'S WINS THIRD STATE TITLE
description: St. Anthony's of Smithtown, L.I., won its third New York State Federation Cross-Country title yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, scoring 238 points in the boys' team race to defeat the runner-up, Wantagh, which had 244.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: NEW JERSEY'S Right to Know Law, which already has begun to touch 42,000 businesses, is entangled in two suits that include at least 64 parties on both sides.

title: STATE PANEL ASKS $815 MILLION CUT IN INCOME TAXES
description: Personal income taxes would be reduced by 6 percent for most New York State residents with annual incomes of more than $15,000 under a plan recommended to Governor Cuomo by a citizen panel that he appointed.

title: 10 Illustrators Win Children's Book Prizes
description: Maurice Sendak and nine other illustrators have won awards for the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1984. The awards, in the form of certificates, were presented by The New York Times Book Review.

title: CITY SCRUTINIZING LOFTS IN BROOKLYN
description: An environmental-impact study about to begin

title: January Wedding For Gail Frawley
description: Dr. and Mrs. James M. Frawley of Potomac, Md., and Myrtle Beach, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Elizabeth Frawley, to Steven Jay Zitzer, a son of Barbara N. LeBray of Seattle and Dr. Jerald M. Zitzer of San Francisco. A January wedding is planned.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Broadcast TV
description: With considerable inventiveness and more than a little trimming, public television's ''Great Performances'' series transformed a disastrous stage production of ''Alice in Wonderland'' into a production of impressive charm. The clever adaptation, reduced to 90 minutes, will be rebroadcast on Channel 13 on Friday evening at 9.

title: Jacqueline Winn, a Lawyer, Is Married
description: Jacqueline Winn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Winn of Syracuse, and Dr. Robert J. Friedlander Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Friedlander of New York and East Hampton, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: 20TH-CENTURY SYMPHONIES OFFER RICHES
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: Clearing the Air
description: Don King , the boxing promoter, has been a member of the executive committee of Artists and Athletes Against Apartheid, a group that tries to discourage performers and athletes from accepting engagements in South Africa. So when it was disclosed that one of King's fighters, Greg Page , would go to South Africa to fight the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, Gerrie Coetzee , and that King would get $1 million from the deal, the promoter came under heavy criticism from members of his own group.

title: BRITAIN MAY FOLLOW U.S. LEAD ON UNESCO PULLOUT
description: Britain has told its principal allies that it is prepared to follow the Reagan Administration's example and give notice that it intends to leave Unesco in a year unless the organization agrees to further changes in the way it operates, according to Western diplomats.

title: THE LIGHT AT THE BEGINNING OF THE TUNNEL
description: DAY ONE

title: SKI-LODGE CO-OP
description: Ever since vacationers were sold on the idea of owning their own retreats, ski-resort towns have been a magnet for developers. Many of the projects have been condominium developments, but in Hunter, N. Y., the new owners of O'Shea's, a small lodge at the foot of Hunter Mountain, will convert the 60-year-old hotel into a vacation cooperative.

title:
ART;
ARCHITECTURE, SCULPTURE EXAMINED IN SPARKILL
description: ORDINARILY a lot of verbiage is a distraction in an art exhibition; the visuals tend to become reduced to illustrations of the words. But in the exhibition ''Architecture/Sculpture - Sculpture/Architecture'' at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill the many words are the core of the show.

title: PARENTS CALL STATE LAX ON DISABLED
description: TRENTON ANGRY parents have charged that the state's Division of Advocacy for the Developmentally Disabled, an arm of the Department of the Public Advocate, is not protecting and advocating the rights of their handicapped children, as required by Federal and state law.
