title: POLLS AND PALLS; LABOR FORCE
description: The Census Bureau has developed people-counting to a fine art. As of 8 o'clock this morning, it calculates, there are 236,971,465 of us in the United States - 5,564 more than yesterday.

title: Paige A. Barbour And Tyler Davis Exchange Vows
description: Paige Acheson Barbour, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Barbour of Bronxville, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Tyler Doniphan Davis, a son of Mrs. John Johnston Davis of Louisville, Ky., and the late Mr. Davis. The Rev. Wallis Landrum, assisted by the Rev. Charles Amstein, performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title:
THE WORLD ;
Chile Rounds Up2,000 'Suspects'
description: Chile's jails were unable to take in all of President Augusto Pinochet's presumed enemies during his first years in power in the 1970's, so he turned soccer stadiums into holding pens. Last week, a Santiago soccer stadium was again pressed into service unrelated to sports.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
IT'S NOT THE FOOD THAT NOURISHES A FAMILY AT THANKSGIVING
description: TIMMY and Roberta will pick up Gram and drive to Janet's house for Thanksgiving. Janet's husband, Dick, will drive to Manchester and bring Uncle George back for dinner. Gerry is going to Fran's. Stephen and Gretchen are eating with Gretchen's family. Fred and Peggie are having neighbors in. Hal and I and our four children will have our bird here, and Cathie and the baby will join us.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; 30's COMEDY PROVES A CLASSIC
description: MOSS HART'S and George S. Kaufman's Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy, ''You Can't Take It With You,'' is the current production of Theater Three in Port Jefferson. This play, about the zany Sycamore family and their unconventional life style, was a huge success when it opened in 1936.

title: OKLAHOMA ST. RALLY TOPS IOWA ST., 16-10
description: Jamie Harris caught a 7-yard touchdown pass from Rusty Hilger, and Thurman Thomas scored on a 1-yard plunge to rally Oklahoma State to a 16-10 victory over Iowa State today in a Big Eight game.

title: Ann Maley Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wyss Maley of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Dwyer Maley, to James Harding Shannon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Van Arsdale Shannon, also of Darien. The wedding is to take place in June.

title: Nuptials for Miss Laffan
description: Regina T. Laffan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Laffan of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Warren Gwydir Kraft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren G. Kraft of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Joseph Amato, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich. Mrs. Kraft graduated from the University of Arizona, as did her husband, an insurance broker with the John L. Gwydir Company, a Mineola, L.I., concern founded by his late grandfather.

title: THE MIG'S ARE COMING!
description: Those nonexistent MIG fighter

title: HIS PEEVES AND ENTHUSIASMS
description: Walter Kendrick is a professor of English at Fordham University. He is the coeditor of ''The Treasury of English Poetry.'' THE FRIDAY BOOK

title: BEAUX ARTS TRIO, AN ENDURING SOUND
description: Heidi Waleson writes frequently on music and other arts.

title: A NEW COURSE FOR THOSE ADRIFT IN CLUTTER
description: WHILE most of us struggle to conquer clutter and chaos in our personal and professional lives, Anita Caggiano of Westport offers businesses, professionals and other people ''a fresh eye and some common- sense suggestions'' for getting organized.

title: REPORT SAYS PROJECTIONS CUT VOTER TURNOUT
description: Television projections of President Reagan's re- election on Nov. 6 may have reduced voter turnout in Western states.

title: Pacific Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Guard Search Is On for Trawler
description: The Coast Guard intensified the search today for a 87-foot fishing trawler that disappeared in the Atlantic Ocean four days ago along with its nine-man crew.

title: ANTIQUES BAZAAR PLANNED
description: CLASSIC holiday colors provided by crimson poinsettias and deep green pine garlands will decorate the hall of the Greenwich Community Center in Connecticut the weekend starting Nov. 30, when the annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar is held.

title: CRIME
description: Two first novels by Americans feature private eyes. J. F. Healy, in BLUNT DARTS (Walker, $12.95), introduces John Francis Cuddy, a Bostonian who is the more interesting of the two.

title: FEEDING NEEDY IN A SEASON OF PLENTY
description: AS many Connecticut residents are making preparations for their own elaborate Thanksgiving dinners, individuals, schools, companies and civic clubs across the state are collecting canned goods to help feed poor people throughout the winter.

title: Of Eberstadt and Alliance
description: The fall-out has begun at New York's Eberstadt Asset Management. The $1.7 billion investment firm was acquired last month by Alliance Capital Management from Marsh & McLennan.

title: THE APPEAL OF UNIVERSAL ACCOUNTS
description: LIKE many investors, John M. is lazy when it comes to finaancial affairs. To be sure, he owns some stocks, has money in a bank or two and keeps a sum in a money market mutual fund that is managed by Merrill Lynch & Company. but it takes a lot to stir him to move his business from one financial institution to another, even when he knows he is being charged too much. He is likely to procrastinate for months before closing an account and opening a new one to get a higher return.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME LAST-MINUTE AUTUMN CHORES
description: WE have been fortunate this fall in having good weather in which to complete our garden chores. However, there is always a list of last-minute tasks to be done before the ground freezes and the season comes to an end.

title: ON BRIAN DE PALMA-CROSSING THE LINE BETWEEN ART AN PORNOGRAPHY?
description: Brian De Palma, the sensationalist of American films, has done it again. In ''Body Double,'' he draws on his usual themes of suspense, violence, greed and sex to create a film that has attracted a great deal of attention - and controversy.

title: Margaret Farley, Editor, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent W. Farley of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Farley, to Robert Patrick Steele, a son of Col. and Mrs. Robert Steele of Salisbury, England.

title: VIC DICKENSON, A TROMBONIST WITH BASIE BAND IN 40'S, DIES
description: Vic Dickenson, a jazz trombonist with a sly, dry and mordantly witty style who was one of the most individualistic stars of Count Basie's orchestra, died Friday at New York Hospital as a result of cancer. He was 78 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: GEORGETOWN GOES FOR TWO IN A ROW
description: IT is a team of antiheroes that

title: Pornography And the 'Truth'
description: This letter is in response to the article ''Public Policy and Pornography: A Double Standard'' (Opinion Page, Oct. 14). I am not an apologist for the pornography industry; however, I found the article by Wayne Prospect quite disturbing on several levels.

title: THE NATION ; Taking RentOff the Top
description: Welfare recipients may soon receive less in cash and more in kind if a new Reagan Administration proposal is adopted. Its stated aim is to prevent the poor from being evicted from their homes by allowing local governments to withhold part of a family's welfare check and to pay it directly to the landlord.

title: MANHATTAN IS BEST IN SHEPHERD CLASS
description: Ch. Covy Tucker Hills Manhattan, the top-winning German shepherd in the breed's history in this country, advanced to Sunday's final in the American Kennel Club's Centennial Show, which opened a two-day run at the Civic Center today.

title: AVOIDING MORTGAGE PENALTIES
description: Way down among the seemingly less important provisions of many mortgage contracts is a clause allowing the lender to charge a fee if the loan is paid off within the first few years.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME LAST-MINUTE AUTUMN CHORES
description: WE have been fortunate this fall in having good weather in which to complete our garden chores. However, there is always a list of last-minute tasks to be done before the ground freezes and the season comes to an end.

title: WHERE AMERICA FEARS TO TREAD
description: It is a political curiosity of our time that the nation that invented Madison Avenue should be so poor in conveying the truth to Germans, Russians, Frenchmen and Bulgarians about the real nature of United States society, the values Americans cherish and the traditions that make its democracy into what it is.

title: SHOREHAM'S IMPACT WORRIES UTILITIES
description: WHEN 300 utility executives, engineers, analysts and regulators gathered earlier this month for a conference titled ''New York's Electric Future,'' the debate covered problems of all seven of the state's electric companies. But much of it centered on the problem for which the Long Island Lighting Company is, to its dismay, famous: the construction of a giant generating station that has the potential of massive cost overruns and regulatory problems.

title: NICARAGUA'S COMBATIVE ARCHBISHOP
description: Stephen Kinzer is chief of The Times's bureau in Nicaragua.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS ; A Plan to CapMedicare Costs
description: Since the Reagan Administration changed the payments systems a year ago, hospitals have been sending Medicare patients home sooner. The average hospital stay for Medicare patients has dropped more than 20 percent, from 9.5 days to 7.5 days.

title: A Skewed C.P.I.
description: When the Consumer Price Index is released on Wednesday, it will probably show that prices rose another four-tenths of 1 percent in October. But according to Philip Braverman, chief economist at the Irving Trust Company's Briggs Schaedle unit, the figure is more a reflection of random events in Detroit than of price trends.

title: The President And the Press
description: The illustration on the opening page of Steven R. Weisman's article ''The President and the Press'' (Oct. 14), suggests one remedy for the unhappy situation he describes. Look at all those soup-can- sized zoom lenses used to create the impression that the news media and the President are in close proximity.

title: WESTPORT FEUD OVER LIBRARY
description: WHEN the table talk at Nancy Sendecke's dinner party in Westport last Sunday turned to the building of a new library, the chitchat turned into an argument.

title: Nigeria Said to Execute 40 Soldiers Plotting Coup
description: More than 40 soldiers have been executed in Lagos after a plot to assassinate Nigeria's military leaders was uncovered, a London newspaper said in its Sunday issue.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: EVERYBODY WAS WRONG ABOUT COOKIES AND PRAYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGINIA TO CONSIDER LIFTING A MORATORIUM ON URANIUM MINING
description: Virginia officials are considering lifting a moratorium that has prohibited uranium mining among the rolling tobacco fields of this quiet town in southern Virginia.

title: Have I Got a Story for You!
description: Featuring Shari Lewis MGM/UV Home Video 60 minutes. $29.95

title: OUR TOWN, 1984
description: From Mr. Lukas's article, one gets the impression that Mansfield is a very racist town.

title: MINNESOTA DOCTORS BEGIN EFFORT TO END SMOKING IN THE STATE
description: The Minnesota Medical Association has organized a coalition to end smoking in Minnesota by the year 2000. The association hopes to accomplish that goal mainly by educating the public on the hazards of smoking and proposing laws and public policies.

title: WALL STREET'S LAST GENTLEMAN:Richard Jenrette; FORGING THE EQUITABLE CONNECTION
description: BACK in Raleigh, N.C., young Richard H. Jenrette got his first taste of business by selling insurance. He wasn't too successful - his customers kept saying they'd rather buy stocks. That lesson sent Mr. Jenrette to Wall Street, where he was one of three upstarts who founded Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a trend-setting firm that rattled the industry with its maverick ways. Now, with the purchase of Donaldson Lufkin by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Mr. Jenrette's career has come full circle and he's back in insurance again.

title: SCHOOL'S ALUMNUS GIVES IT $5 MILLION
description: Robert E. Brennan, who graduated from St. Benedict's Preparatory School in 1962, is the kind of alumnus every school wishes it had.

title: Kelly L. Crockett Becomes a Bride
description: Kelly Lee Crockett, the daughter of Joan Brook Stone and Edward Randolph Crockett of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Martin Edmunds Slusser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York and Santa Rosa, Calif. The Rev. Mark S. Lieske performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS ; Westmoreland's View
description: Meanwhile, six floors down in the Federal Courthouse, General Westmoreland was the 14th witness in his month-old trial against CBS. He disputed statements in a 1982 documentary that his command had engaged in a ''conspiracy'' to ''suppress and alter'' information on enemy troop strength in South Vietnam in the months before the Tet offensive of 1968.

title: Miss Humes To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gale S. Humes of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janice Anne Humes to George Vanderneth Merrill, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Merrill of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME LAST-MINUTE AUTUMN CHORES
description: WE have been fortunate this fall in having good weather in which to complete our garden chores. However, there is always a list of last-minute tasks to be done before the ground freezes and the season comes to an end.

title: ON THE MOVE BUT NOT YET ON THE WANE
description: According to current estimates by the Environmental Protection Agency, some 264 million metric tons of liquid and solid hazardous waste are produced from the manufacture and use of chemicals, heavy metals and other dangerous substances each year. That is more than a ton for every man, woman and child in the United States.

title: WHERE ECHOES OF VERDI ARE ONLY AN OVERTURE
description: MORTON N. COHEN is the editor of ''The Letters of Lewis Carroll'' (Oxford University Press).

title: A CALMER CAPITAL
description: -election mood of President Reagan is one of deliberate

title: JOBS SCARCE FOR PICKERS COMING BACK TO FLORIDA
description: Thousands of migrant workers returning to Florida for the start of the annual citrus harvest are finding few jobs and low wages because of the severe freeze that killed millions of citrus trees last year.

title: WHERE TO FIND A REFEREE IF CLIENT AND BROKER FIGHT
description: HAS anyone urged you to put your money into Alaskan oil properties? Or how about into discount priced gold - for later delivery, of course? These and dozens of other get-rich-quick schemes are over the telephone. Most investors suspect they are too good to be true - as they are - but far too many are taken in.

title: JAPAN CROWD WARMS UP TO ARMY'S OFFENSIVE SHOW
description: GAMES do not always travel well. Baseball is wildly popular here, but there seems little passion for football, even though about 50,000 people came to the great Olympic Stadium yesterday, where they watched Army pummel the University of Montana, 45-31, in the eighth Mirage Bowl.

title: INDIVIDUALS ARE BUYING BONDS IN RECORD NUMBERS
description: WITH bond yields remaining high, individual investors are diving into the bond markets in record numbers. Indeed, while high interest rates have been a bane to home buyers and other borrowers, as well as to economists concerned about the strong dollar, they have been a boon to individual investors. In the past few years, small investors, who normally have bypassed the bond markets, have decided the yields are too good to pass up.

title: STUDENTS LEANING TO THE RIGHT
description: IN HIS freshman year at Princeton University, Peter Heinecke

title: Ellen Partridge Becomes Bride Of R. G. Johnson
description: At the Pilgrim Congregational Church in Sherborn, Mass., yesterday Ellen Hancock Partridge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Hall Partridge of Sherborn and Cataumet, Mass., was married to Richard Gerwe Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Richard Johnson of Williamsburg, Va., formerly of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth Powell performed the ceremony.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH EDNA O'BRIEN: 'THE BODY CONTAINS THE LIFE STORY'
description: The Irish writer Edna O'Brien, who has lived in London now for many years, moved recently to a wide boulevard of imposing 19th- century facades, a street that in the 1870's, when it was built, was renowned, she tells me, for its mistresses and kept women. The real estate agents have taken to calling this corner of the Maida Vale district ''the Belgravia of tomorrow''; at the moment it looks a little like a builder's yard because of all the renovation going on.

title: CHRISTMAS PROFITS SQUEEZE
description: Christmas shopping budgets may stretch a bit further than usual this season. October's retail sales, announced last week, were down one-tenth of a percent, the third month-to-month drop since June.

title: HOMECOMING AT STONY BROOK: A SIGN OF A CHANGED CAMPUS
description: At the urging of its alumni association, the State University at Stony Brook this year for the first time has a homecoming king and queen.

title: CO-OPS FOR NOHO
description: For years the area north of Houston Street and east of the Bowery, now known as NoHo, was a residential no-man's-land where all but a few of the living spaces were illegal.

title: BOSCH'S 'GARDEN' IS BROUGHT TO LIFE
description: ''I'm about as articulate as a tortoise

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
POPULAR BUT COSTLY CRIME
description: YOU hear it at cocktail parties, around the office water cooler, over business lunches. The people you hear it from are normally honest but seem to be proud they are doing it. They are so pleased about ''ripping off the big company'' that they are eager to tell you about it.

title: Susan Nichols Marries Patrick Ferriere
description: Susan Mitchell Nichols, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Remington Nichols Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Patrick Louis Ferriere, the son of Mrs. Walter Blenk of New York and the late Dr. Louis Ferriere. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: April Trek: All Light, No Flowers
description: With a month to go before the official onset of winter, talk of a spring trip seems appropriate. But before the imagination fills with flower-covered meadows and balmy zephyrs, the destination should be made clear; it's one of the most inaccessible areas on the face of the earth: the North Pole.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
IN WORLD WAR II LONDON, AN AMERICAN FEAST FROM A TIN
description: SINCE the Pilgrims settled here in the 17th century, Thanksgiving has been an occasion to celebrate the extraordinary abundance of this land. As an American living in London during World War II, however, I was sometimes hard put to live up to our traditions. When I look back at my journal for those years, I find some vivid memories of Thanksgiving in Britain. Thanksgiving Day - 1942, London.

title: TEMPERING OPTIMISM ON STOCKS
description: WHAT are the stock market's prospects over the next six months or so? Many professional investors, chastened by the disappointments of the past year, are tempering their optimism. In 1984, investors saw their world turn topsy-turvy, when a strong economy - normally the precondition for higher stock prices - served instead to raise fears of interest rate increases and divert money to fixed-income securities.

title: State Unit Reactivated For Famine Relief Aid
description: Governor Cuomo reactivated the state's International Disaster Emergency Assistance Committee yesterday to promote a statewide appeal for funds for famine relief in Africa.

title: LEGACY OF THE RADICALS
description: Henry Horwitz teaches history at the University of Iowa. THE EXPERIENCE OF DEFEAT

title: DAUGHTERS OF A VIOLET AGE
description: Mary Lee Settle is the author of ''The Beulah Quintet,'' the first novel of which, ''Prisons,'' is set in 17th- century England. THE WEAKER VESSEL

title: STATE CONSUMER OFFICIALS LIST PLANS FOR LEGISLATIVE SESSION
description: Protecting New Yorkers from unscrupulous home contractors and easing the impact of two nuclear power plants should be at the top of the consumer agenda for next year, two state officials said this week.

title: THE REGION ; Report to CuomoUrges CuttingThe Income Tax
description: The best way to make business executives really love New York, says a panel appointed by Governor Cuomo, is to cut the state's personal income tax. That advice, contained in a report submitted to Mr. Cuomo yesterday, was expected to kick off a debate in the Legislature over how to streamline taxes and disburse what appears to be a growing surplus.

title:
THE WORLD;
WORDS AS TOOLS IN THE DIPLOMATIC GAME
description: Detente, at least the word, was in the air last week as Soviet and American leaders sounded each other out on the possibilities of resuming talks on arms control and other subjects. Answering questions by NBC News, the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, called for a return to the era of detente, saying it could open the way to ''broad possibilities of cooperation'' if Washington's stated desire for solutions to arms problems ''do not remain just words.''

title: Serious Juvenile Arrests Dip
description: There were 1,263 juvenile-offender arrests in New York State in 1983, a decrease of 11.1 percent from 1982, according to the State Division of Criminal Justice Services. It said nearly 90 percent of the arrests of juvenile offenders, 13- to 15-year-olds who were tried in adult courts for violent felonies, was in New York City. The report said 73 percent of the arrests was for robbery; 18 percent for burglary, arson and sex offenses, and about 6 percent for murder.

title: STATE TRUCKS WATER TO 225 FAMILIES
description: HARTFORD ABOUT 225 families in several Connecticut communities whose regular drinking water has been contaminated by the pesticide ethylene dibromide have begun to receive deliveries of bottled water from the state.

title: GAINING SELF-RELIANCE A KEY FOR PUERTO RICO
description: The incoming government of Puerto Rico must persuade Washington to help the commonwealth become more self-reliant or risk watching the island, in the words of a leading economist, become ''the South Bronx of the Caribbean.''

title: Tucker Leslie a Bride
description: Tucker Cady Leslie, a daughter of James Leslie Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and Clarissa Leslie of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Pierson Mitchell, a son of Sidney A. Mitchell Jr., also of Locust Valley, and Ellinor Robinson Mitchell of New York. The Rev. Thomas Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bride is a sculptor and painter. Mr. Mitchell is an account executive for Hempstead Auto, a Jaguar franchise.

title: ARCHBISHOP PLANS A 'MASSIVE EFFORT' TO AID NEEDY
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor says he is planning a ''massive effort'' by the Archdiocese of New York to provide housing and food to needy New Yorkers.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIALS IN PURSUIT OF TOXIC WASTES LEARN FROM MOCK RAIDS
description: Law enforcement and environmental officials from several states staged mock raids on a fake toxic-waste site this week as part of a state course designed to show them how to seize evidence without getting contaminated.

title: CONNECTICUT REPUBLICANS SAVORING THE NEW ORDER
description: A sure sign that power is shifting in the Connecticut General Assembly came last week when Republican lawmakers began stopping by the offices of Democratic legislative leaders to check out the draperies and carpeting.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Practical Traveler column of Nov. 4, concerning consumer complaints, gave an incorrect city for the offices of the travel-law firm of Bessel & Pestronk. It is in Washington, D.C.

title: HOT COLLEGES AND HOW THEY GET THAT WAY
description: LAURA COOK, A BRIGHT HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR AT TAFT PREP IN Watertown, Conn., would like to go to Vanderbilt University. She's heard the atmosphere at the Nashville college is relaxed and the sororities filled with good living. But she may never get there. ''Everybody's really pushing U-VA, and Duke,'' she says. Everybody? ''Well, my father, he's not the type to push, but . . . .''

title: SOME UNTRADITIONAL OFFERINGS FOR THE THANKSGIVING TABLE
description: THANKSGIVING is, after all, a celebration of the harvest. So it is fitting to serve a bounty of different vegetables with the traditional turkey. Purees of autumn fruits and vegetables such as butternut squash and carrots, young white turnips with pears or parsnips with yams are easy to make if you own a food processor. The purees can be cooked in advance and briefly heated in the oven when you are ready to eat. Their colors will brighten any table.

title: Spain Is Host to Talks On Fighting Terrorism
description: Antiterrorism specialists from 13 European nations met secretly in Madrid this week, the independent daily newspaper El Pais said today.

title: AMERICA'S RETURN TO PRAYER
description: TIMOTHY J. FINE ONCE REJECTED THE FAITH of his forefathers as ''intellectually incompatible'' with his thinking. But these days, Fine, a 31-year-old Manhattan corporate real estate executive, carries on what amounts to a running conversation with God. ''It started when I just wanted to thank God for getting me past the drug scene,'' Fine says. ''For years, I had wanted to pray, but I didn't know how.'' Then the dam burst.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; 'Masterpiece' Villa
description: It was described as the most beautiful seaside house in the world, a relic and ''a masterpiece of very good taste.'' The owner of this villa on the Isle of Capri was Countess Mona Bismark, who was considered one of the most beautiful women in American society in the 1920's and 30's. At that time she was married to Harrison Williams, the father of the former New Jersey Senator.

title: ST. JOHN DEFEATS FARRELL BY 7-6
description: Rich Sperling, a missed 2-point conversion and a stiff wind were the key factors in St. John the Baptist's 7-6 victory over Monsignor Farrell yesterday in the Catholic High Schools' Football League championship game at Flushing Memorial Field in Queens.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE American Thread Company has hired Realty Advisory Services of Los Angeles, a division of Security Pacific Bank, to investigate uses for its Windham site after it closes its mills in two years.

title: ISLANDERS TROUNCE RANGERS
description: Mike Bossy tied a National Hockey League record tonight with his 32d career hat trick. And although official records are unavailable, the Rangers may have set the league standard for tossing in the towel.

title: THE REGION ; A New Job-BiasBan Is Upheld
description: Although Mayor Koch may not have the authority to ban discrimination against homosexuals by private agencies doing business with New York City, the Board of Estimate certainly does, a State Supreme Court justice ruled last week. The decision upheld a board resolution to enforce job protections, but it is unlikely to end a challenge by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, the Salvation Army and several other charitable groups.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: WORKING: People Talk About What They Do All Day and How They Feel About What They Do, by Studs Terkel. (Pantheon, $7.95.) Our reviewer, Marshall Berman, said in 1974 that in recording the comments of more than one hundred men and women in ''Working,'' Studs Terkel ''uses the discussion of work to get at so much of what is deepest and most intimate in so many people's lives, to understand work as Freud understood it, as the individual's firmest connection with reality.'' Mr. Berman concluded that ''Working'' ''should be a best seller'' - and, in fact, it became one. PATRIOTIC GORE: Studies in the Literature of the American Civil War, by Edmund Wilson. (Northeastern University, $12.50.) A chronicle of the lives and writings of 27 men and women of the Civil War era - from Harriet Beecher Stowe and Mary Chesnut to Ambrose Bierce and Abraham Lincoln. Our reviewer, Henry Steele Commager, called Edmund Wilson's 1962 work ''a series of reflections on that literature and on the men and women, and the societies, that produced it. It is original, skeptical, allusive, penetrating. It is discursive, ranging widely from North to South, and even more widely in time.''

title: Helen C. Swiggett, Account Executive, To Marry Peter Leland Getz in Spring
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James E. Swiggett of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Helen Chinn Swiggett, to Peter Leland Getz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Leland Getz of Greenwich, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Regulation And Radio
description: I read with exuberance Jerry Dunklee's dissertion on the deregulation of radio (''Radio for Profit: Listener Beware,'' Oct. 28), and the ''benefits'' it brings to the long-suffering public.

title: INVISIBLE FENCE CONTROLS DOGS
description: CAROL HILL'S two dogs, a black Labrador retriever and a basset hound, followed her eagerly down the driveway of her suburban home early one October day, tongues lolling and tails beating the air.

title: MOTIVE SEEN AS BURGLARY IN 2 SLAYINGS
description: Six years ago, Shura and Zina Kogan and their son, Edward, came to New York from Odessa, in the Soviet Union, to build a new life.

title: NEW MUSIC: ENSEMBLE AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL
description: The first concert this season of the New York New Music Ensemble, Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, was intended, in the words of a news release, to examine the idea of a ''California School'' of contemporary composition. Unfortunately, despite the interest of several of the pieces and their performance, the program never really addressed the issue.

title: KENNEDY AND JOHN JAY CAPTURE DIVISIONAL CROWNS
description: John F. Kennedy used a sleight-of- hand offense and powerful defense to defeat John Adams, 24-10, yesterday. It was the first time a Bronx team won the Public Schools Athletic League Division A Championship.

title: UNSENTIMENTAL JOURNEY
description: SARAH PHILLIPS

title: West Bank Solution?
description: To the Editor:

title: CD'S EMBRACE THE PAST
description: When the printing press came into general use, a great many books were lost and forgotten. Writers turned facile to feed the new presses while older manuscripts of great merit never saw print. Erasmus, who as overseer of the university press at Basel was one of the world's first publishers, used to complain about this. All that happened in 1500 or thereabouts. Today, the world of recorded music finds itself in a similar quandary.

title: SAKHAROV'S STEPDAUGHTER SAYS SHE HEARD FROM THE COUPLE
description: The stepdaughter of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov said today that she had received a photograph of her mother and the Nobel Prize winner along with a note saying it was sent ''to convince you at last that we are alive.''

title:
THE WORLD;
Why SvetlanaWent Home
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Joseph Stalin, left the Soviet Union for the West 17 years ago, lured by ''blind idealization of the so-called free world.'' But ''I was not free there a single day,'' she told her first - and presumably last - news conference since her return to Moscow last month.

title: NUNS OPPOSE LANDMARK STATUS FOR THEIR CONVENT
description: To the Little Sisters of the Assumption, the 19th-century convent they own and want to sell represents a way to raise money to continue their ''mission of humanity,'' helping the afflicted and poor of nearby East Harlem.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Mexico City last Sunday on John Gavin, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, incorrectly described his mother's background. She was born in the Mexican state of Sonora and is a naturalized United States citizen who now lives in California.

title: A PLAYGROUND FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP HER long blond hair streaming behind her, 13-year-old Christine Phillips swings back and forth, smiling into the sun. For Christine, a ride on a swing is still a novelty.

title: FARM OPTIONS CUSHION RISK IN PLAYING COMMODITIES
description: A HOST of new options on domestic farm futures are being introduced this fall, and while they are a high-risk investment - as are the underlying commodities - they offer individuals who want to speculate in the commodity markets a way to do so while limiting their risk to the purchase price of the option.

title: BRIGHTER PROSPECTS FOR THE VIDEO DISK
description: Something Darwinian happened with video disks. The fittest survived. Of the two competing systems, LaserVision has emerged triumphant. Earlier this year, RCA announced that it would no longer produce its CED-type video-disk players.

title: OUT TOWN, 1984
description: J. Anthony Lukas's article, ''Our Town 1984'' (Oct. 21), may serve as the definitive treatise on Middle-American political philosophies.

title: TANGLE OF HEIRS TO THE DODGE FORTUNE DEVELOPS A NEW KNOT
description: The long-running saga of who should inherit one of the automobile industry's great fortunes has taken an odd twist.

title:
DINING OUT;
STEAKHOUSE WITH AN AIR OF FINESSE
description: ONE would expect a county seat to have an interesting selection of restaurants, but Somerville, which is where the governing bodies of Somerset County reside, has a dearth of eating places. This perhaps explains why La Cucina, an Italian restaurant there, is so popular.

title: AN UNSEEN FENCE KEEPS DOGS AT HOME
description: CAROL HILL'S two dogs, a black Labrador retriever and a basset hound, followed her eagerly down the driveway of her Darien home early one October day, tongues lolling and tails beating the air.

title: THREE SURPRISES IN PLAYOFFS
description: Several upsets in the county's first- round playoff games yesterday may provide support for critics of the power-point system, a mathematical formula used to determine the seeding of the county's top-16 teams.

title: 'STRANGLES' TRIED BY COMMODITY SPECULATORS
description: This strategy paid off late last month in Treasury bond option strangles, when interest rates suddenly dropped, so that bond prices rose - and with them the premiums on T-bond calls soared.

title: A DELUXE HAVEN OUTSIDE ATHENS
description: JANET MASLIN is a film critic for The New York Times.

title: A Correction
description: An article about Gulf and Western Industries last Sunday incorrectly described the company. It is a conglomerate doing business in entertainment, publishing, financial services and the manufacture of consumer products. The article also misstated the status of the company's bid to acquire Prentice-Hall Inc. It has made a tender offer for Prentice-Hall, but has not yet actually bought any of that company's stock.

title: PURCELL DEFINITE: HE'S RUNNING
description: FRANCIS T. PURCELL, the Nassau County Executive, made a tape recording recently to answer reporters' questions on whether he would seek a third term next year.

title: HEART DISEASE DEATHS ARE DROPPING, BUT WHY?
description: MIAMI IF

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Reaching 60, As Good as Ever I would like to add to Janet K. Weisman's ''Topic'' (Nov. 4) on being a senior citizen.

title: MAJOR NEWS ; An Attempt atNormal PoliticsIn IndiaRajiv Gandhi moved swiftly last week to energize the machinery of Indian democracy and consolidate his position as Prime Minister. After 12 days of official mourning for his assassinated mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, he turned to politics, taking charge of the ruling Congress-I Party and scheduling general elections on Dec. 24 and 27.
description: In his first policy speech, he promised to continue on the course set by his mother and his grandfather, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. Its lodestars are ''adherence to socialism'' and to India's version of nonalignment - that is, preserving the ''wide-ranging and time-tested relationship with the Soviet Union,'' India's main source of advanced weapons, and continuing economic, technological and cultural cooperation with the United States.

title: A GUIDE TO THE GODS
description: John S. Henderson, director of the archeology program at Cornell University, is the author of ''The World of the Ancient Maya.'' THE CODEX MAGLIABECHIANO

title: The Need for Controls In Patient Care
description: The Pilgrim Psychiatric Center, where 24-year-old Rona Lenhoff was killed by a car last January, was perhaps the psychiatric facility least responsible for her death. Where else could she have been sent when she got out of control once again (''Care of Prader-Willi Victims Assailed,'' Oct. 7)?

title: Detroit Rides Again
description: Auto prices may be up, but Detroit still is winning back the American driver. The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's Donnelley Marketing unit recently surveyed 520,000 people who intended to buy new cars within six months, and the results spelled good news for domestic auto makers.

title: FACING A HARD CHOICE
description: Marilyn Abrams works at an abortion clinic in Boston and has written on teen-age abortion. MOMENTS ON MAPLE AVENUE

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE PRESS
description: The observation that the press is a surrogate for the public is an obvious one but no less important for that.

title: 'Family Week' Proclaimed
description: President Reagan has designated Sunday as the start of National Family Week, saying all Americans should give toanks ''for the manr blessings they have received from their family relationships.'' In his proclamation, issued Thursday, he said: ''Strong families are the foundation of society. National Family Week gives us a chance to honor families and to renew our commitment to the family strength that gives people the ability to withstand external influences and maintain their individual integrity.''

title: DEMOCRATS BEGIN TRYING TO DIG THEIR WAY OUT
description: The landslide that buried Walter F. Mondale in the Presidential election was big enough to provide every Democratic faction with a stone of blame to cast. And cast they were last week, from the Virgin Islands, where Democratic state leaders gathered for an autopsy of the campaign, to Washington, where national leaders and their aides exchanged individual accusations.

title: Miss Murphy to Wed Glen D. MacGillivray
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Murphy of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Murphy to Glen Donald MacGillivray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. MacGillivray, also of Scarsdale.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SUNNYSIDE SCENE

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BIOTECHNOLOGY;
WHAT THE FUTURE MAY HOLD IN STORE
description: BIOTECHNOLOGY

title: HANGING ANARCHISTS
description: Richard C. Wade is Distinguished Professor of History at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. THE HAYMARKET TRAGEDY

title: TWO HOSPITALS JOIN FORCES
description: NEWARK TRUSTEES of two of this city's six hospitals have voted to proceed with a 5-year, $88 million plan to create the largest acute-care hospital complex at a single site in the state.

title: Food; A BLAZING HEARTH
description: FOOD COOKED on a wood fire has a flavor like none other. But when it comes to the fireplace, few people have ambitions beyond toasting marshmallows on the end of a stick.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: It isn't usual for a debut recital to feature the world premiere of a work by one of the most celebrated living composers. But then it isn't usual for a debutant to be as accomplished as the clarinetist Paul Meyer, who played Tuesday at the 92nd Street Y - unless, of course, the debut is sponsored, as Mr. Meyer's was, by Young Concert Artists, whose track record for spotting the best new talent in classical music is legendary.

title: Zendejas Sets Scoring Mark TEMPE, Ariz., Nov. 17 (AP)
description: The Arizona State place-

title: ROYAL BUSINESS His Royal Highness
description: Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg stopped off at the White House last week for a ceremonial handshake with President Reagan, but his real business in the United States was business. After the Washington visit, the Grand Duke was off to California to chat with the royalty of Silicon Valley.

title: BROKERS EAST TO WEST
description: Six brokers in smaller cities across the country name thier favorite stocks of companies in their areas and describe their selections.

title: A SWIMMER AGAINST THE TIDE
description: FAIR LAWN

title: ITALY-VATICAN PACT TO END SUBSIDIES FOR CLERGY
description: Italy and the Vatican signed a protocol this week that will eliminate state subsidies for the clergy's salaries and tighten tax benefits for church institutions.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BIOTECHNOLOGY;
FIRST, THERE WAS INTERFERON
description: IF any one product pushed biotechnology from a science fiction pipedream to a much-ballyhooed scientific revolution, it was interferon. And, ironically, interferon also is a good barometer of biotechnology's continued limitations.

title: GETTING READY FOR THE SEASON: CULINARY SOURCES
description: FROM now through Twelfth Night, the entertaining and shopping and gift-giving world is on. This often-exhilarating season can become impossibly hectic, and rather than bear the strain of it, take time out for a breather. Cut down on dinner and party preparations by letting someone else do the shopping and cooking. Although those who know their way around a kitchen usually have a stock of cans to open, tins to unlid and packages to defrost for surprise visitors and for quick family meals, the season calls for those tins and boxes to be something a little special.

title: CONTROVERSIAL ARCHBISHOP O'CONNOR
description: Ari Goldman's article carried in it a reference to the Bishops of the Diocese of Brooklyn and their concern that Archbishop O'Connor's outspoken beliefs, especially on abortion, will get the Church in trouble with the liberal intelligentsia.

title: NEW MYSTERY PLAY DOES NOT DELIVER
description: THE newest piece of frippery the Hartman Theater in Stamford has come up with is more enticing in anticipation than in actuality.

title: PARTY HEADS STAY ALOOF FROM JAPAN'S POLITIC
description: Every public opinion poll shows that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is uncommonly popular, enjoying approval ratings as high as 58 percent. In Japanese politics, however, that does not mean much. Despite the widely held impression that he has been an effective national leader, Mr. Nakasone is intensely disliked within his conservative Liberal Democratic Party. Many of the party's members - it may well be a majority - view him as self-important and untrustworthy. When the professionals gathered in party caucuses this month, they cared not one bit about his broad appeal. Several worked out a plan to oust him as their leader and thus as Prime Minister.

title: Columbia Wins Soccer Crown Columbia, the sixth-ranked
description: team in the nation, clinched a

title: TO GO American law enforcement officials apparently were handed the biggest slice yet in the ''pizza connection'' drug trafficking case when Spain's highest court agreed last week to extradite
description: Gaetano Badalamenti . Mr. Badalamenti was then shipped to New York for arraignment on charges that he headed a Sicilian ring that has smuggled $1.65 billion worth of heroin into the United States since 1979 and distributed it through pizza parlors. Negotiations for his extradition began several months ago after he was arrested in Madrid. Federal prosecutors apparently agreed to Spain's request that, if guilty, Mr. Badalamenti be sentenced to no more than 30 years in prison, the maximum sentence under Spanish law in such cases.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LIKE JAKE AND ME

title: IN SOUTHERN ILLINOIS, PROFITS FROM 'GOD'S OIL'
description: Money is a problem for a tiny church here in southern Illinois - not collecting it, but deciding how to spend the thousands coming in each month since the church struck oil.

title: MEMORIAL SERVICE HELD FOR BABY FAE
description: Tearful over their loss and prideful in their sense of common achievement, the community of Loma Linda paid tribute today to Baby Fae with the words of a 245-year-old hymn, ''Where, O Death, is now thy sting?''

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
NATURE'S WORLD: GOING, GOING...
description: ILIVE near the part of Morristown National Historical Park

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THANKSGIVING FOR EVERYONE-A CHANCE FOR CHANGE AND PEACE
description: WITH all the big deal being made in past months about separation of church and state, a simple holiday comes as a breath of fresh air because it is for everybody. It offers a chance for change and peace. It is Thanksgiving. Thanksgiving can be both religious and secular, about food, about feeling, and about images of life.

title: FOOTBALL KICKERS FIND THEIR GROOVE
description: Phil Patton is a freelance writer whose book ''Razzle Dazzle: The Curious Marriage of Television and Football'' was published this fall.

title: VON KARAJAN VS. VON KARAJAN IN 'ROSENKLAVIER'
description: Albums of Richard Strauss's ''Rosenkavalier'' come and go, but the version recorded in London in December 1956 by the producer Walter Legge, with Herbert von Karajan conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra and Elisabeth Schwarzkopf as the Feldmarschallin, has long dominated the field. Now it has been digitally remastered (EMI/ Angel SDLX-3970, four disks), and at the same time Mr. Karajan has come forth with a brand-new account of the score (Deutsche Grammophon 413 163-2, four compact disks).

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HERE AND THERE
description: WHITE PLAINS NEW YORK CITY, it isn't. There are no bicycles, no youths who look more at home on the street corners than in the offices to which they make deliveries, no ambling on foot from building to building.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Adoption Story
description: Twenty-six years after giving up her infant son for adoption, Pat McDermott of Coal Valley, Ill., learned that she had been buying groceries from him unaware for three years. The son, Jerry Blanford, was manager of the store in town, and he had a critical liver ailment.

title: INDIA SAID TO WIDEN INQUIRY ON SLAYING
description: The authorities investigating the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have detained more than three dozen members of her personal security force, it was reported here today.

title: BELLAMY ASSERTS MAYOR IS 'BORED'
description: Mayor Koch is ''tired'' and ''bored'' with his job, and displayed a lack of leadership by taking a European vacation amid an uproar over the fatal police shooting of an elderly woman in an eviction dispute, the City Council President has charged.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI AT GARDEN
description: Gate four, straight ahead,'' chanted the usher, ''there's a hot dog stand, there's a bar, there's everything.'' All that and Luciano Pavarotti too, at Madison Square Garden last night, where thousands of fans gathered to hear dozens of loudspeakers through which was transmitted the most famous tenor voice of our time (and perhaps the most-transmitted operatic voice of all time).

title:
ART;
DIFFERENT WAYS TO APPROACH NATURE
description: ARTISTS' comments on the world are frequently in the form of landscape painting. ''Over the River and Through the Woods,'' a new show at the Wunsch Arts Center Gallery in Glen Cove, surveys the theme through the work of 22 Long Island artists and succeeds in making one think about different ways to approach nature.

title: PACKAGE: STORE PATRONS SAMPLING WARES
description: SINCE Oct. 1, Connecticut's 1,500 package stores have been allowed to offer tastings of wine, beer and liquors, and some vendors are finding the new law is an effective marketing tool.

title: MUSIC TO MATCH THE BEAT IN EARLY SHEPARD
description: Alto saxophone in hand, Peter Jay Fernandez strides across the La Mama Theater's Great Jones Street rehearsal loft, declaiming ''The story of Niles, from the top!,'' a monologue by a character named Petrone in Sam Shepard's play ''Suicide in B-Flat.'' Jeremy Kahn punches out gospel- organ chords from his synthesizer, Stephen Mellor and Raul Aranas - as Louis and Pablo, the play's pair of philosopher-cops - snap their fingers, the director George Ferencz nods in time. Between phrases Max Roach, the master jazz drummer, responds ''Tell it! Tell it!'' as he might to a gospel preacher or a blues singer.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: ON Oct. 14, 1980, Genentech, then a four-year-old biotechnology company, went public. In an unprecedented 20-minute trading spree, its stock soared to 89 a share from $35 , setting a record for the fastest pre share price increase in Wall Street history. Five months later, Cetus, the oldest biotech concern, raised $107 million, at the time the largest initial public offering in american corporate history.

title: NOT THE FATHER OF THE MAN
description: Daniel Goleman writes about science for The New York Times. THE NATURE OF THE CHILD

title: WHY EDMOND ROSTAND'S 'CYRANO' LIVES ON
description: Anthony Burgess, the novelist, did the translation of ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' that is currently being performed on Broadway by the Royal Shakespeare Company.

title: BEVERLY CECELIA LANNQUIST MARRIES L.C. HAMILTON JR., FELLOW EXECUTIVE
description: Beverly Cecelia Lannquist, a vice president of the United Technologies Corporation in Hartford, was married in New York yesterday to Lyman Critchfield Hamilton Jr., chairman and president of Tamco Enterprises, an investment company in New York, and former president and chief executive officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: President of Texas Local Is Ousted by Teamsters
description: The teamsters, in a bitter internal wrangle, placed a local into trusteeship and ousted its president because of accusations that he used unauthorized union funds to lease an automobile, finance an audit and hire bodyguards.

title: George Tames's Photographs
description: It is good to see The New York Times honoring one of its own, and in the case of George Tames, may I say the recognition is long overdue (''Images,'' by Francis X. Clines, Oct. 14).

title: ART FOR THE ARTIST'S SAKE STILL APPLIES TO DANCE
description: One of the truths that is increasingly being lost sight of in the performing arts is that the creative artist should be serving himself rather than the public. Perhaps only dance has been able to embody this ideal more consistently than the other arts - largely because of the unique place held by the choreographer in cultural activity.

title: EX-JET'S SON MAKES MARK
description: On Jan. 12, 1969, the night his father intercepted two Johnny Unitas passes to help lead the Jets to a stunning 16-7 Super Bowl victory over the Baltimore Colts, Randy Beverly Jr. slept like a baby at his grandmother's house.

title: STATUE REDEDICATED
description: FREEHOLD WHEN Donald DeSanto was growing up in Brooklyn, there seemed to be little space for monuments commemorating significant moments in history. By the time he was a student at St. Francis College, he was acutely aware of his hometown shortcoming.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: From Local Artisans The World Over The Bruce Museum's Fifth International Folk Arts Bazaar in Greenwich, Conn., is open today from 2 to 5 P.M. as a display in the lecture gallery, and by Monday thousands of these unusual objects will still be available through the gift shop, where prices range from 25 cents for children's ''button baby'' trinkets to $500 for a Foo dog from China.

title: CINEMA TURNS A NEW REEL
description: LEE FORMATO winces whenever a caller seeking directions to his twin cinema in Stamford inquires whether it is at the same site as the old Art Cine, an X-rated movie house that became renowned for its marquee that read, ''Have a Nice Day.''

title: BRITISH COAL MINE STRIKE LOSING MOMENTUM
description: The strike that has immobilized most of Britain's coal fields for more than 36 weeks appears to be losing some of its momentum.

title: WHO WANTS TO BE PAID FOR JUST SITTING?
description: IN a men's room at the Supreme Court Building in

title: NOTRE DAME ROUTS PENN STATE BY 44-7
description: Allen Pinkett scored four touchdowns in the first half today as Notre Dame played one of its best games in four seasons under Coach Gerry Faust and trounced Penn State, 44-7.

title: Beatrice M. Richter Is Wed to Dr. J. Anthony Zito
description: Beatrice M. Richter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix J. Richter of Munich, West Germany, and Dr. J. Anthony Zito, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Zito of Rochester, were married yesterday. Marvin Axelrod, an assistant leader of the Westchester Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the couple's New York apartment.

title: REVAMPING CARE OF MENTALLY ILL
description: Governor Cuomo says he will propose mental health legislation that is based on a gubernatorial commission report that recommends a complete restructuring of New York's mental health system.

title: BOARD BEGINS TO SCRUTINIZE THE DETAILS OF THE '85 BUDGET
description: THE submission of his proposed 1985 budget last week by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to the Board of Legislators marked the start of a month and a half of legislative scrutiny and public hearings, leading to the Dec. 27 deadline for adoption of a budget by the Board.

title: IT'S LIKE IN-HOUSE MAIL, SENT ELECTRONICALLY
description: ONCE the province of the home computer hobbyist, electronic bulletin boards are now popping up in offices.

title: FANTASY TAKES FORM IN A HOBOKEN WAREHOUSE
description: HOBOKEN SOME of the best living theater in the New York metropolitan area is found not in the theaters themselves each night, but on the streets of Manhattan once a year, on that magical morning when storybook characters come to life for two hours in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: BORROWING TROUBLE
description: Jacob F. Butcher hasn't had any trouble getting big loans recently, and Federal prosecutors think they know why. Mr. Butcher and two associates were arrested last week on charges that they had systematically looted two Tennessee banks Mr. Butcher headed, using fraudulent loans to companies they owned to divert nearly $15 million for their personal use. The charges stemmed from an 18-month investigation into the collapse of Mr. Butcher's banking empire, which at one point included 27 institutions in Tennessee and Kentucky that Mr.Butcher and his brother, C. H. Butcher Jr., either owned or controlled. Eleven banks in that empire have failed in the last two years.

title: U.S. Plans to Increase Patrols Near Colombia
description: The United States plans to step up its efforts to block the two major shipping lanes from Colombia in an attempt to reduce drug smuggling, a Drug Enforcement Administration official said tonight.

title:
THE BISHOP'S LETTER ON THE U.S. ECONOMY;
A PLAN FOR SPREADING MISERY, NOT WEALTH
description: BEING Jewish, I would normally consider it an act of impertinence to intervene in a discussion among Roman Catholics of church teaching, especially one conducted by no less authoratative a group than the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. But in their ''Pastoral Letter on Catholic Social Teaching and the U. S. Economy,'' the bishops not only ask people who do not share their faith to enter into debate; they even issue a special invitation to their ''Jewish brothers and sisters'' to join with them ''in seeking an economic life worthy'' of our common Biblical heritage.

title: Work on Secret Shuttle Trip
description: With astronauts and space officials still glowing over their first space salvage mission, technicians started preparing the space shuttle Discovery for a top-secret Defense Department flight in January.

title: A TELLING 'CRUCIBLE' AT DREW
description: MADISON THE downs and ups and downs of Arthur Miller's playwrighting career have been chronicled in almost colliding contrasts of late.

title: NEW REPORT CITES A HEPATITIS CAUSE
description: Scientists of the New York Blood Center have reported the discovery of a new virus they believe may be the major cause of hepatitis transmitted through blood transfusion.

title: HOLY GROUND TO HALF THE WORLD
description: ABRAHAM RABINOVICH, a reporter for The Jerusalem Post, is the author of ''The Battle for Jerusalem'' (Jewish Publication Society).

title: SEVEN MISTAKES INVESTORS MAKE OVER AND OVER
description: IF investors were ranked according to their skill, the results would resemble a bell-shaped curve. At one end would be a very small number of individuals who did extremely well, and, at the other, a very small number who did extremely poorly. The overwhelming majority's per- formance would be average, falling in the middle of the curve.

title: GRANT FOR LIVER STUDY
description: A $2.4 MILLION grant from the National Institutes of Health has been given to the Yale University School of Medicine for the establishment of a comprehensive liver research center.

title: DONATED BLOOD
description: Lawrence K. Altman, M.D., reports on medicine for The New York Times.

title: MALL FIRE DIMS HOLIDAY HOPES
description: ON Monday the Veterans Day sales had been brisk, and the merchants of Walt Whitman Mall in Huntington Station felt it could only portend the start of a profitable Christmas season.

title: Taxes Up, Down and Simpler As the Reagan Administration turns from politics to governing and looks again at the large Federal deficits, it needs to reconcile, or choose among, three distinct lines of thought about taxes. Most economists and many business leaders believe that taxes have to be raised as part of any deficit reduction. Most Americans and many politicians want the tax system simplified and made more fair. And President Reagan wants to press for a tax reform that does not violate his promise to raise taxes only as a last resort.
description: These approaches are not automatically compatible. Taxes can be raised without being made more fair. They can be made more fair with or without increasing the revenues collected. The next tax law can raise the tax

title:
DINING OUT;
DINING IN SOMERSET'S COUNTY SEAT
description: ONE would expect a county seat to have an interesting selection of restaurants, but Somerville, which is where the governing bodies of Somerset County reside, has a dearth of eating places. This perhaps explains why La Cucina, an Italian restaurant there, is so popular.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME LAST-MINUTE AUTUMN CHORES
description: WE have been fortunate this fall in having good weather in which to complete our garden chores. However, there is always a list of last-minute tasks to be done before the ground freezes and the season comes to an end.

title: CANDIDATES SEEK TOP DEMOCRATIC PARTY POST
description: Democrats meeting here have had a look at the first candidates to declare that they would like to replace Charles T. Manatt as the party's national chairman.

title: Controversial Archbishop O'Connor
description: When New York Archbishop John J. O'Connor asserts that Catholics holding public office must pursue the Church's legislative agenda, whether they or their constituents personally support that agenda or not, it would seem he is trying to strangle individual conscience with the ropes of a narrow and simplistic orthodoxy (''New York's Controversial Archbishop,'' by Ari L. Goldman, Oct. 14).

title: HARTMAN SEEKS A SUCESSOR TO SHERIN
description: THE Hartman Theater, central element in the development of the $10 million Stamford Center for the Arts, is going on a headhunting expedition.

title: COMSEWOGUE BEATS BELLPORT
description: Comsewogue's runners ripped through the Bellport defense yesterday on the way to a 36-16 triumph that earned the Warriors a place in the Division II playoff finals next Saturday.

title: RESERVATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: ACID RAIN THREAT REPORTED IN WEST
description: The state Environmental Quality Council has been warned by scientists and United States Forest Service officials that precipitation from industrial and power plants threatens the lakes of the Wind River Mountains.

title: LABONTE PRIMED FOR AUTO TITLE
description: All Terry Labonte needs to do this afternoon at Riverside, Calif., is to keep his Chevrolet on the track and finish seventh or better and he will be the new Winston Cup stock-car racing champion.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS Nov. 18, 1984Fiction*1
description: CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. *2 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. *3

title: Mexico Proposes Budget With No Real Growth
description: President Miguel de la Madrid has proposed a 1985 national budget that would increase spending by 54 percent, to $90 billion, but that would not quite keep pace with this year's inflation rate of 55 percent.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHILE poverty is not always outwardly visible in the midst of the Island's holiday bounty, this Thanksgiving season the Church of Our Holy Redeemer in Freeport is going beyond its traditional Thanksgiving project to include a whole week in which the parish will focus on the needs of the poor. Three special collections, sponsored by Parish Outreach and the St. Vincent de Paul Society, will be held, titled, ''Where's the Beef?,'' ''Where's the Food?'' and ''Where's the Clothing?''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHY NOT HAVE ANOTHER CHILD?
description: WHEN the phone rang, we were finishing the form for our son's college loans. A social- worker friend asked if I knew of a couple who were interested in adopting an infant. I told her I'd call her back.

title: Sports of The Times; Skating Pair Together Again
description: THEY will never forget the

title: CABLE TV
description: The BBC Northern Symphony of Great Britain and the conductor Edward Downes came up with an inspired idea for a Promenade Concert at Royal Albert Hall in London in 1982, and, fortunately, it was captured on video tape for future enjoyment. It will be broadcast on the Arts & Entertainment Network on Thursday at 8 P.M. and midnight and Friday at 7 P.M. The two works it offers are Serge Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 1, completed in 1912 when he was 21, and Dmitri Shostakovich's Symphony No. 1 dating from 1925 when he was 19. These winning, youthful compositions of Russia's two most gifted composers go well together, especially in the sympathetic performances they are given here.

title: PUNISHMENT THAT FITS THE PAST
description: IN the best of times, sports commissioners should be like small

title: SOFTWARE TO MANAGE PORTFOLIOS
description: NOT long ago, using a personal computer as an investing tool was still more art than science. Just ask Patricia Lehrburger. Bitten by the technical investing bug four years ago, Miss Lehrburger decided that she wanted a computer to draw her graphs with moving averages. But finding the software to do the job was tricky then. ''The situation was a lot different,'' Miss Lehrburger said. ''We had to hunt to see where we could get this program and where we could get that one. Today there is so much more software that it's bewildering.''

title: BATTLE WITHIN THE P.L.O. THREATENS A FORMAL SPLIT
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization, the unruly coalition of Palestinian groups that has weathered 20 years of internal strife and military setbacks, may be headed for the first formal split in its ranks.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: ULTIMATE QUESTIONS
description: Walter Kaiser is the chairman of the Department of Comparative Literature at Harvard University. OTHERWISE

title:
THE WORLD;
Lebanon MakesTough Demands
description: Lebanon, which at a minimum would like to get rid of Israeli troops on its soil, seemed to feel last week it had nothing to lose in thinking big. When Lebanese officers sat down with the Israelis in the heavily protected Lebanese town of Naqura, they called for Lebanese Army control of all areas Israel now occupies and up to $10 billion in reparations for damages inflicted by Israel during its 1982 invasion.

title: HARTMAN SEEKS DIRECTOR
description: THE Hartman Theater, central element in the development of the $10 million Stamford Center for the Arts in Connecticut, is going on a headhunting expedition.

title: Search Temporarily Stopped For 4th Victim in Plane Crash
description: Authorities temporarily suspended the search today for the pilot of a four- seater plane that plunged into the waters off the Boardwalk here Friday night, killing the three passengers aboard.

title: AN OLD-TIME BARBERSHOP ENDURES
description: The fluted milk-glass shakers, inscribed in silver script with ''Lilac,'' ''Witch Hazel'' and ''Water,'' stand on marble shelves alongside bottles of hair tonics and lotions with nostalgic names like Wildroot Cream-Oil, Vitalis and Beau Kreml. The raised letters on the shop's front windows, which reach from the marble tile floor to the tin ceiling, spell out Broadway Barber Shop in gold leaf.

title: Mediator Is Appointed In City Contract Talks
description: A mediator was appointed yesterday in the stalled contract talks between New York City and 200,000 nonuniformed municipal employees.

title: PITY THE HOMELESS PERIPATETIC PLAYER
description: Chessplayers don't have homes, just addresses for the deposit of chess magazines, tournament bulletins and revised schedules for coming events on the circuit.

title: Alice C. Fleming to Wed Gary J. Feder in January
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fleming of New York and Westbrook, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Alice Carew Fleming, to Gary J. Feder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Feder of Old Westbury, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: HELP FOR FAMILIES OF ALZHEIMER VICTIMS
description: THEY sit in a circle on folding chairs, in the conference room at the main office of the Westchester Jewish Community Services in Hartsdale.

title: Iris Zurawin Is Wed To James P. Marden
description: Iris Zurawin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Zurawin of New York, was married yesterday to James P. Marden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Marden of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Center for Inter-American Relations in New York.

title: CUBS' GREEN SEEKING TO BRING FREE-AGENT PITCHERS INTO PORT
description: One of the strangest cruises in baseball history, and maybe shipping history, ended yesterday when the Chicago Cubs and 700 of their fans docked in San Juan after a week of sailing the Caribbean.

title: THE THOUGHT CONTAINS THE THINKER
description: DREAMS, ILLUSION AND OTHER REALITIES

title: AUDIT FINDS H.R.A. IS WASTING SPACE
description: The City Comptroller has asserted in an audit that the Human Resources Administration wasted one-quarter of the space it rented last year, more rental space than is contained in the Pan Am Building.

title: WHO GETS ELLIS AND LIBERTY I. REVENUE?
description: JERSEY CITY DECLARING that their move was not just another skirmish in the war of words between New York and New Jersey, officials here have filed suit charging that Liberty Island and Ellis Island were illegally taken over by their neighbors across the river.

title: Verbatim: Between East and West
description: 'The politicians, who once stated that war was too important to be left to the generals, now act as though peace were too complex to be left to themselves.

title: CONSUMER RATES
EVIL BENEATH THE SURFACE
description: HEARTSTOP

title: FALL NATIONAL BRIDGE TOURNEY DRAWS LARGE FIELD OF ENTRIES
description: Judging by participation on the opening day Friday, the Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League will be one of the largest ever: 1,118 tables were in play.

title: LEARNING FROM BABY FAE
description: For a public display of medical research, the Baby Fae case has raised more questions and provided fewer answers than many other recent experiments.

title: DISCOVERING IMMORTAL DILMUN
description: GEOFFREY BIBBY, the director of Oriental antiquities at the Prehistoric Museum of Aarhus, Denmark, is the author of ''Looking for Dilmun.''

title: STONEWHITE CAPTURES REMSEN
description: Stonewhite, who had never run in stakes company, pulled away from favored Mighty Appealing in the stretch yesterday to win the $252,800 Remsen Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct.

title: Kate Wiggins Is Wed
description: Kathleen Louise Wiggins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne B. Wiggins of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Richard Howard Maitland, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Maitland of Merrick, L.I. The Rev. Robert W. Wiggins, the bride's brother, performed the Methodist ceremony at the Puck Building. The bride, known as Kate, is an actress. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Maitland, president and owner of Westec Audio Video, a supplier of professional television equipment in New York, is the sound effects artist for ''Sesame Street.''

title: Margie Sperber Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sperber of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Margie Ann Sperber, to William Strauss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Strauss of Wayne, N.J.

title: Vicki Volper to Marry
description: Vicki Ellen Volper, a tax associate in the New York law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren, and Dr. Mark Jeffrey Goldstein, chief dermatology resident at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, plan to be married in January. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Volper of New York, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Goldstein, also of New York.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: DEADLY FAMINE IN MOZAMBIQUE CALLED INEVITABLE
description: United Nations relief officials here said today that famine as severe as that which killed at least 100,000 people in Mozambique less than a year ago was now virtually unavoidable in the months to come.

title: TREASURES THAT ILLUMINATE THE VICTORIAN EMPIRE
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: DEDICATED GOLFERS MOVING INDOORS
description: -pound Debbie Doniger, a ninth grader at the Greenwich Country Day School, consistently hitting superb 130-yard iron shots straight down the middle of the Saxon Woods Golf Driving Indoor Range, much to the admiration of those who stopped by to watch.

title: SEEKING THE PERFECT PCKEREL FILLET
description: SONDRA GOTLIEB, whose most recent novel is ''A Woman of Consequence,'' is working on a book of humorous pieces about Washington.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
CARL SANDBURG COMES TO LIFE IN A ONE-MAN SHOW
description: AFTER nine years of ''being Carl Sandburg,'' of reciting his words and singing his songs in a one-man show that attempts to capture the essence of this ''totally American poet,'' there are times, the actor and singer Rufus Norris said, when he has to step back and separate himself from his stage persona.

title: 'WINNIE ILLE PU' NEARLY XXV YEARS LATER
description: Edwin McDowell reports on publishing for The New York Times. LMOST a quarter-century after its original publication, ''Winnie Ille Pu,'' a Latin version of A. A. Milne's ''Winnie the Pooh,'' is back in the nation's bookstores. Now, as then, the book contains not a single page in English, yet that handicap did not prevent its becoming the only Latin book - and perhaps the only book in any foreign language - ever to become a New York Times best seller. Published in December 1960, it remained on the Times list for 20 weeks and sold 125,000 copies in 21 printings.

title: NEW MARGIN ACCOUNTS PROLIFERATE
description: MARGIN. The very word implies risk. To be on the margin, the dictionary says, is to be on the edge, or the brink. And for some investors, buying on margin - that is, buying with money borrowed from a broker - often represents being on the brink of disaster. But when used successfully, margin can multiply an investor's profit.

title: GREENPORT DEBATES BOATYARD GROWTH
description: THE waters of Greenport are quiet now, engaged in the steady, silent process of renewal that comes with the tides of autumn. It is a welcome renewal, similar to that experienced in the village's boatyards, where the season brings long-awaited work for the carpenters, painters, mechanics and riggers who will steadfastly set about repairing boats used in the summer.

title: DIDJA HEAR WHAT SARTRE SAID THE OTHER DAY?
description: Vivien Raynor is an art critic for The New York Times. THE INTELLECTUAL FOLLIES

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BIOTECHNOLOGY;
THE LIGHTER SIDE OF BIOTECH
description: MOST of the serious research in biotechnology revolves around three areas: medicine, agriculture, and energy. But there are any number of offshoot projects going on that can only be called, well,

title: WORDS CAST THEIR SPELL
description: Nonesuch Records, which has increasingly gone farther and farther afield in its search for repertory over the years, has just embarked upon yet another new direction: the spoken word. Its first production is a two-disk recording of Tom Stoppard's Broadway hit ''The Real Thing,'' which won the 1984 Tony Award as best play. The cast is the original one, starring Jeremy Irons and Glenn Close.

title: LABOR MUSEUM SEEKS FIRMER BASE
description: -story house here on a

title: A FEW USE A COMPUTER TO BUY STOCK
description: JUST about every evening Wright Gore Jr. heads for his den, sits down at a Apple IIe computer and runs a oneman brokerage house whose only client is Wright Gore Jr. With the touch of a few buttons on the computer, Mr. Gore, who lives in Freeprot, Texas automatically fetches stock quotations for about a dozen secutieies, some in his portfolio and others he is contemplating buying.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN THE UPPER EAST SIDE
description: The Upper East Side is New York

title: LOVE IN 3-D
description: THE FACTS OF LIFE

title: ARAB REQUESTS FOR ARMS BEING WEIGHED BY U.S.
description: With the Presidential election behind them, Reagan Administration officials say they are once again looking at multibillion-dollar requests from Saudi Arabia and Jordan for advanced weapons.

title: The Nightsticks of South Africa Those were warm, welcome words from President Reagan to South Africa's new Nobel laureate a few weeks ago: ''All Americans join me,'' he wrote to Bishop Desmond Tutu, ''in recognizing your labors in seeking to promote non-violent change away from apartheid, toward a form of government based on the consent of the governed and toward a society that offers equal rights and opportunities to all its citizens, without regard to race.''
description: In South Africa, simply uttering those ideas can be a criminal act. And that is the disturbing reality the Administration ignores in its passive response to the white regime's police-state crackdown on dissenters of all races, the worst in years. Those being arrested are not violent revolutionary conspirators but advocates of nonviolent change, the disciples of Gandhi and Martin Luther King.

title: REPLACING FITTINGS ON COPPER PIPES
description: MOST homes built within the last 30 or 40 years use copper pipe in their plumbing systems, and these copper pipes are almost always joined with soldered fittings - usually referred to as ''sweat'' fittings (this is short for sweat-soldering, the technique used in soldering the fittings).

title: THE NATION ; Big Banks ToldTo Tighten Up
description: Still smarting from criticism that followed the recent $4.5 billion Government bailout of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, Federal officials have prescribed an unusual dose of preventive regulation for two of the nation's largest banks. The Comptroller of the Currency ordered the Bank of America and the First National Bank of Chicago to shore up their financial underpinnings and tighten their credit policies, officials at the two banks disclosed last week.

title: THE SUTTERS VISIT THE BOYS
description: They're getting ''a lot of winter'' back home in Viking, Alberta, and this probably isn't the ideal time for Louis and Grace Sutter to be East visiting the boys. But a neighbor said he would look after things, feed the cattle and such, and the airline reservations were made a long time ago. The farm work could wait.

title: CANADIENS DOWN DEVILS, 5-0
description: Mats Naslund scored twice and assisted on another goal, and Steve Penney recorded his first regular-season shutout as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Devils tonight, 5-0.

title: WEST BANK ARABS SQUEEZED BY 2 ECONOMIES
description: -Occupied West Bank - Trapped between Israel's 1,000 percent inflation and the shrinking job market in Jordan and the Persian Gulf, the Arabs of the West Bank and Gaza Strip are facing a serious economic squeeze. Israeli officials are increasingly concerned that widespread unemployoen could politicize middle-class Arabs who up to now have tended to abjure political activism.

title: Forger Is Captured After Prison Escape
description: A convicted forger who faked a release order to slip out of prison in New Hampshire has been recaptured in Colorado after more than six weeks of freedom.

title: DISCIPLINARY ACTION BEING URGED FOR 2 WORKERS IN EVICTION DEATH
description: Disciplinary actions, possibly including dismissal, are being recommended against two, and perhaps three, city social workers for their roles in the case of a Bronx woman who was killed by a police officer, city officials said.

title: SOUP KITCHEN OPENS TO ALL FOR A DAY
description: THOUGH most of the state's 40 soup kitchens will be serving Thanksgiving dinner to the needy on Thursday, the Covenant Soup Kitchen in Willimantic will be opening its doors to the entire community on that day.

title: CAN RUSSIA BE REFORMED FROM THE OUTSIDE?
description: SURVIVAL IS NOT ENOUGH Soviet Realities and America's Future. By Richard Pipes. 302 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: UP FOR GRABS
description: WINE AUCTIONS ARE NOT YET an important part of the American wine scene, though they are getting more popular all the time. They are central to London's wine world, where they were first held in the 18th century. But they have never caught on in Paris, where, heaven knows, wine is a most important commodity.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
OUR THANKSGIVING WASN'T PLANNED BY NORMAN ROCKWELL
description: FOR more than 20 years, my husband and I and our two children traveled to Grandmother and Grandfather's house to celebrate Thanksgiving. But it wasn't over the river and through the trees.

title: 'OVER MY DEAD BODY' SPOOF OF MYSTERIES
