description: THE newest piece of frippery the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., has come up with is more enticing in anticipation than in actuality.

title: Trial Schedule Changed Because of TV Movie
description: A judge presiding over the trial of a man accused of killing his wife and three children has scheduled night sessions Sunday and Monday so jurors cannot see a movie, made for television, about an Army doctor convicted of killing his family.

title: PARENT INVOLVEMENT TO GROW
description: ALTHOUGH Federal and state laws require parents of handicapped children to participate in formulating educational programs, their influence in shaping New Jersey policy on the handicapped has been minimal. More often than not, they are silent members of state councils and advisory committees dominated by education professionals.

title: Free Trade a Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: SLEEPER SERVICE TO THE CAPITAL
description: BETSY WADE is an editor on the national desk of The New York Times.

title: WHAT HERITAGE FOUNDATION DOES
description: The Heritage Foundation describes itself as a tax-exempt, nonpartisan public policy research institution dedicated to the principles of free enterprise, limited government, individual liberty and a strong national defense.

title: CHAMPIONSHIP PLAY
description: The World Team Olympiad which ended a week ago in Seattle was perhaps themost exciting in the quadrennial series that began in 1960. There were many triumphs and disasters, both at the table and away from it.

title: STORE IS FAMILY PROJECT
description: WHEN Fred Pressman was a young man, he related the other day, his father would tell him to stop thinking so much about baseball. Today, he still thinks a bit about baseball, but can't stop thinking about Barney's, the Manhattan men's store that bears his father's name, and about ways to keep up with the world's changes and grow with them.

title: Suspect Is Seized In Florida Slayings
description: An X-ray technician was held without bail today on charges of killing nine young women since May, and the authorities say a 10th victim may be related to the other killings.

title: CITY PLAN DEBATED FOR ALBUQUERQUE
description: A debate over a plan to alter part of the downtown section has intensified with new questions being raised about its design and financial outlook.

title: Disputing the Disputant
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Expert Views Surgery on Baby Fae
description: A leading Vatican theologian said today that the Roman Catholic Church approved of implanting animal organs in humans under certain conditions but that these had not been met in the case of Baby Fae.

title: CITY OPERA'S BIG GAMBLES PAID OFF HANDSOMELY
description: The New York City Opera, which began its 40th season 20 weeks ago in deep uncertainty, closes it this evening in the most confident frame of mind it has enjoyed in many years. Despite a few artistic reverses of the sort that any opera season is heir to, the mood is upbeat. This was the season in which Beverly Sills, the general director, decided to gamble on two extremely chancy innovations: the company's first summertime run and the first full season of subtitled or supertitled operas. Both gambles paid off heavily.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS ; Two Soldiers Seek Redress In Libel Suits
description: History is being relived, and made, in Federal District Court in Manhattan. In their respective libel suits against CBS and Time magazine, two former generals, William C. Westmoreland and former Israeli Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, have in effect put themselves on trial and reopened wounds of wars past. Lawyers for CBS and Time contend that the suits involve the improper use of libel actions to try to vindicate controversial acts of government. Under United States Supreme Court standards, the generals must prove that CBS and Time acted recklessly or maliciously, even if what was said or written about them is false.

title: A VERY EARLYCHANGING OF THE GUARD
description: Last September Glenn E. Watts, 64, who has presided over the Communications Workers of America's transition to a deregulated environment, stunned attendees at an executive board meeting in Keystone, Colo. He said he would step down as president a year early so that a successor could be named in time to prepare for a daunting round of bargaining with the telephone industry in 1986.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SINGAPORE
description: BARBARA CROSSETTE is a New York Times correspondent based in Bangkok.

title: Dance
description: The New York City Ballet begins its 81st season on Tuesday at the New York State Theater with a gala benefit program that celebrates George Balanchine, company choreographer and co-founder with Lincoln Kirstein. There will be the erotic Balanchine, in ''Bugaku,'' the almost fecklessly exuberant Balanchine, in ''Walpurgisnacht Ballet,'' and, in ''Symphony in C,'' the matter-of-fact maker of monuments.

title: TECHNICAL ANALYSIS Spotting Trends
description: At the heart of technical analysis is the belief that stocks follow noticeable, definable patterns, and that these patterns repeat themselves. This suggests that if investors can discern the patterns, they can predict stock prices.

title: 'BOUND, GAGGED AND LEFT IN THE PANTRY'
description: Thomas M. Disch's latest novel is ''The Businessman: A Tale of Terror.'' MISS PEABODY'S INHERITANCE

title: COSBY PUTS HIS STAMP ON A TV HIT
description: Bill Cosby walks up to a long table on the edge of the set for his NBC series ''The Cosby Show.'' Dressed in a Howard University T-shirt and sweat pants, a bottle-green sweat shirt slung over his shoulders, he joins the show's cast and production staff to dissect the script of the episode to be shown Thanksgiving night. It is a Monday in late October, and the pressure is on: By the following Thursday the cast must appear before the cameras and a studio audience for the show's taping at the network's Brooklyn studio.

title: Robert White 2d Wed To Katherine S. West
description: The marriage of Katherine Scott West, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph O'Neal West of Wellesley, Mass., to Robert Hooper White 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert King White of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley. The Rev. Vincent W. Warner performed the ceremony.

title: CHATEAU COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Hail Lomax As Matured Player
description: It was the next-to-last Sunday of the 1981 season, the year the Giants were driving to the playoffs. They were playing the Cardinals in St. Louis, and the Cardinals were leading, 3-0, in the first quarter and had the ball in their territory.

title: ARMS FREEZE ADVOCATES COUNT ON 1986 RACES
description: Leaders of the movement for a freeze on nuclear weapons say that they view President Reagan's re-election as a major defeat but that they have been heartened by the victories of several Congressional candidates favoring a halt in the deployment of nuclear arms.

title: THE FAILURE OF TRUE LOVE
description: A FANATIC HEART

title: WHEN AND WHY AN OUTLOOK CHANGES
description: I DON'T know what caused me to

title: AN L.I. MAGAZINE THAT'S EXPANDING
description: FOUR years ago, Michael J. Cutino recalls, he pounded the pavements of Manhattan, knocking on doors to solicit ads for his start-up magazine, Nightlife, with just enough money for a day's commutation in his pocket. Operating out of a $50-a-month rented office in the basement of a Huntington funeral home, he lost $25,000 a month the first year, he says.

title: PROGRAM REVIVED
description: EIGHTEEN years ago, New Haven was the second city for a new job-training program for poor, functionally illiterate inner-city people.

title: FIRE BRINGS HAVOC TO TOKYO PHONES
description: Nearly a million people were without telephone service today in the aftermath of a fire in a Tokyo underground utility tunnel.

title: Conrail
description: To the Editor:

title: Large Prostitution Operation Broken Up, Investigators Say
description: The authorities say they have broken up the largest prostitution ring they have seen here, with 100 ployees and an annual gross revenue of $800,000.

title: HARTFORD COLLEGE CHIEF PICKED AS MANHATTANVILLE PRESIDENT
description: The president of Hartford College for Women has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Manhattanville College, the school's board of trustees has announced.

title:
FORUM:FELDSTEIN ON THE DEFICIT;
'85 IS THE YEAR TO CORRECT THE IMBALANCE
description: NOW that the election is over, it is time to focus on the principal challenge facing the American economy: reducing the Federal budget deficit in a way that sustains and strengthens our economic expansion. Failure to deal appropriately with the deficit would have very serious consequences for the American economy in the years ahead. If no legislative action is taken to reduce spending and raise tax revenue, the deficit is likely to exceed $250 billion in 1989 even if the economy continues to experience favorable growth rates of 3 to 4 percent and interest rates continue to decline.

title: Joy of Teaching Is Its Own Reward
description: I have a reputation for being a fancy-schmancy cook and a creative decorator. Since I feel I deserve this reputation and people are paying me my pin money to cook for them and decorate, my case rests on that. The only bad thing about serving chicken cutlets highly decorated with a chaud-froid sauce or marbleizing mirrors for my home is that many well-meaning friends pay me the dubious compliment of, ''Why are you wasting your time teaching?''

title: 45 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 45 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: SORTING OUT THE CONFUSION AFTER A.T.& T.'S BREAKUP
description: JEWEL MORGAN, a retired social services worker in Westchester County, held 40 shares of American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock for 25 years. She was one of 3.2 million shareholders who put their faith in the world's largest company, and over the years Ma Bell did not fail her or other shareholders, at least when it came to the sanctity of the dividend.

title: Dr. J Deserved A Suspension
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STOCKMAN'S DATA COLLIDE WITH BOSS'S PROMISES
description: WASHINGTON AS if on cue, the deficit alarms went off in the White House last week. Gone was the talk of prosperity and painless budget choices in President Reagan's re-election campaign. In its place were distasteful quandaries about taxes, spending and dark economic forecasts.

title:
ANTIQUES;
3 CENTURIES OF ARTIFACTS FROM BERGEN COUNTY AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON JUST what constitutes folk art is one of the gray areas of investment collecting, and when a major museum announces an exhibition, such as the one currently at the State Museum here, the question of ''It's folk, but is it art?'' can turn out to be just as perplexing.

title: JUSTICE ASSAILS HIGH COURT
description: LONDON IN A sharply worded speech before 1,500 members of the New

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Ode to the Machine

title: A HUGE FOOD NEED SEEN FOR ETHIOPIA
description: Victims of the drought and famine afflicting much of Ethiopia will require huge shipments of emergency food supplies for at least a year and possibly beyond, according to Western experts.

title: CONVENTION CHIEF FAVORS EXPANSION
description: The president of the New York City Convention Center says he believes a substantial expansion of the uncompleted building will be necessary if the center is to attract the nation's largest conventions.

title: Bishops TackleThe Economy
description: Traditionally, a pastoral letter was a document read to the faithful in place of the usual sermon at Sunday morning service. But last year a committee of American Catholic bishops plunged into the political arena, issuing a statement about Christian responsibility in face of the nuclear threat.

title: Decker Back on Track
description: The bitterness, the anger and the frustration that enveloped Mary Decker after her fall and injury in the 3,000-meter Olympic final last summer have disappeared.

title: Queens Woman Slain In Attack in Elevator
description: The police were looking for more information yesterday about the man who stabbed a woman to death and seriously injured another woman in an elevator of a Flushing apartment building Friday night.

title: WARSAW REPORTS STALINIST'S ARREST
description: A former Polish Government minister who fled to Albania in 1966 has been arrested after re-entering the country with forged identity papers, the Interior Ministry said today.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: BROWN ENDS COLUMBIA'S SEASON AT 0-9
description: On the final afternoon of the longest football season in Columbia's history, the lion did not roar.

title: THE CLIMATE FOR INVESTMENT CHOICE
description: THE explosive stock market rally of early August went down in the record books both for the volume of business it generated and the speed with which it came and went. But one record it did not chalk up was retail participation.

title: MONTCLAIR BEATS MORRIS KNOLLS TO GAIN IN PLAYOFFS
description: Wayne Ross passed for two touchdowns and ran for another, leading Montclair (7-1-1) to a 25-7 victory over Morris Knolls (6-3) in the first round of the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 state playoffs yesterday at Montclair.

title: DRAWING UP A FINANCIAL BLUEPRINT
description: THOSE who can send their children to the best colleges or retire in luxury are not necessarily corporate chieftains or lottery winners. Many have simply invested wisely and consistently. ''People who just save whatever is left over,'' David Bugen, a financial planner in Morristown, N.J., said. ''usually have too much month at the end of their money.''

title: DEVELOPING DRUGS TAKEN NASALLY
description: NASTECH Inc. of Hauppauge is a company without a marketable product - yet. By next year, the two-year-old pharmaceutical concern, which has bought patent rights to more than 20 drugs, may be selling its first product, a nasally administered form of progesterone, the hormone used to relieve premenstrual stress in millions of women.

title: Greeks Fight at March Marking Student Revolt
description: Fighting with stones and clubs broke out in central Athens tonight at a mass march celebrating the 11th anniversary of a student revolt. The police said at least two people were hurt.

title: CAPPING ONE CAREER WITH ANOTHER
description: FIVE years ago, Harold Geneen

title: Nuptials Planned By Miss Gelardin
description: The engagement of Christine Victoria Gelardin to Basil C. Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Williams of Demarest, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hugo J. Gelardin of New York and Quogue, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: RETRACING MAO'S LONG MARCH
description: WE ARE CRUISING THE blacktop in our air-conditioned Toyota minibus at a comfortable 45 miles an hour. The driver rams his favorite tape into the deck and I begin to hear the mellow tones of ''Old Black Joe.'' I sip my can of Sprite and stare out the window at the stream of passing tankers and timber-laden trucks. This is the old Burma Road where Americans sweated their pack mules over the mountains in World War II? This is the back-country trail Mao Zedong's Red Army followed on its Long March to power?

title: Letters ; Rent Regulations
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Rand Is Engaged
description: Kathleen Gina Rand and John Anthony Aldren Turner plan to be married in April. Mr. and Mrs. William Rand of New York have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Turner of Lodsworth, West Sussex, England. Miss Rand is a New York real-estate sales agent with the Ambrose Mar Elia Company and her father is president of William Rand Inc., a jewelry importer. Mr. Turner is a book publisher in London and his father is a physician and specialist in tropical medicine.

title: Washington Watch; Baldrige Push For a Merger
description: WASHINGTON

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1984
description: International

title: 3 CITY G.O.P. AIDES OPPOSE ENDORSING KOCH
description: Three of the five Republican county leaders in New York City say they would oppose a Republican endorsement of Mayor Koch for re-election next year.

title: TALBOTT AND SANCHEZ IN FINAL
description: Mark Talbott of Boston and Mario Sanchez of Mexico City will meet in the final of the $34,000 Chivas Regal open squash-racquets tournament tonight at the Uptown Racquet Club.

title: RADAR SIGHTINGS IN HONDURAS POSE A MYSTERY
description: United States and Honduran military officials are trying unsuccessfully to explain what appear to be a series of incursions by unidentified aircraft into Honduran airspace.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Eudora Welty Wins Award for Literature
description: Eudora Welty has won the fifth annual Common Wealth Award for Distinguished Service in Literature. The award, of $23,500, has been given previously to Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Robert Penn Warren, Milan Kundera, Nadine Gordimer, Wright Morris and Christopher Isherwood.

title: NEW YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, PROUD OF ITS HYPHEN, CELEBRATES ITS HISTORY
description: Past the room where the city's biggest collection of Tiffany lamps glows softly in the dimness, past the dramatic Hudson River School landscapes, the crumbling manuscripts about women in American politics, people will dance tonight at the New-York Historical Society.

title: MUST BRIBES BE PART OF THE COST OF DOING BUSINESS IN NEW YORK?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHURCH CANNOT BE NEUTRAL ABOUT HOMOSEXUALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Winnipeg Wins Grey Cup
description: The Winnipeg Blue Bombers overcame a 14-point first-quarter deficit today to earn their first Canadian Football League championship since 1962 with a 47-17 victory over the Hamilton Tiger-Cats in the Grey Cup.

title: BIOGRAPHY AS ART FORM DISCUSSED BY WRITERS
description: Like all forms of humanist writing, biography has gone through its phases and fashions. In recent years, judging by its five distinguished practitioners who spoke at the New York Public Library last week, the genre has been infused with a new sense of complexity and nuance.

title: Weak Bridge Knocks Out Philadelphia Tunnel
description: The highly publicized downtown commuter rail tunnel, opened a week ago, was virtually shut Saturday because of a deteriorating bridge further out, in north Philadelphia, the local transit authority reported.

title: Futures/Options; Discounters' New Allies
description: -service brokerage houses may soon regret letting go large numbers of commodity account executives in belt- tightening moves brought on by shrinking business and the increasing competition from discount brokers. The reason: Many of the fired brokers have become ''introducing brokers,'' and they are generating even more business for the discounters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1984

title: Explosion at a Mill In Jersey Injures 3
description: An explosion ripped through a milling company here today, blowing the walls out and critically injuring three workers.

title: Market Place; A Major Shift To Corn Syrup
description: MANY Wall Street analysts are suddenly taking a closer look at the equities of three of the nation's leading producers of corn sweeteners - the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, CPC International and the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company.

title: Miami Youth Shot Dead In Melee After Game
description: A youth was fatally shot in the head while trying to escape a rowdy crowd terrorizing people on a public bus after a high school football game Saturday. He died today despite surgery to remove the bullet from his brain.

title: INSTITUTE ON WOMEN CREATED
description: After five days of strategy meetings in a feminist think tank in Stony Brook, L.I., a group of 25 women from third world, Western, Socialist and Communist countries announced the creation of an international institute to improve the lives of women around the world. In a statement to be presented at a press conference today, the women express solidarity despite their political and cultural differences saying, ''In a world of many tragic divisions, we believe that women can find a common language.''

title: ARREST IN POLAND HINTS AT PARTY SPLIT
description: A terse announcement over the weekend saying Polish authorities had arrested a fugitive Stalinist official appears to underscore a growing view here that long latent rivalries in the Polish Communist Party have risen to the surface after the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest.

title: GIANTS BEAT CARDINALS, 16-10, TO GAIN FIRST-PLACE TIE
description: Not long after Phil Simms found Lionel Manuel for the 11-yard touchdown that turned out to be the difference in the Giants' 16-10 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday, Bob Sheppard's voice was heard over the public-address system.

title: ETHIOPIA LINKS U.S. AND SOVIET RELIEF EFFORTS
description: The 100-pound sacks of wheat being loaded from a truck onto a Soviet MI-8 helicopter bore the stamp, ''Furnished by the People of the United States of America.''

title: Dean Witter Official Gets Top N.A.S.D. Post
description: Last Friday must have been a heady day for Peter D. Byrne.

title: ; MOVING WALKWAY IN PLACE OF THE SHUTTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME PRIESTS IN MOZAMBIQUE PUT MATERIAL MATTERS FIRST
description: ''I'm a materialist,'' said the Rev. Giuseppe Brunelli, walking his motorcycle along a bone-dry dirt path in the northern village of Boroma, where 50 people died of starvation earlier this year and food is again running out.

title: THE CONCLUSION OF 'CIVILIZATION AND THE JEWS'
description: Heritage: Civilization and the Jews'' concludes tonight with ''Into the Future,'' an examination of the emergence of modern Israel. Thus the nine-hour series finishes where it began - in the ancient Jewish homeland. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: HOME OF CABBAGE PATCHERS ALREADY SWAMPED FOR CHRISTMAS
description: It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas in this tiny north Georgia town: The local telephone trunk lines are jammed with frantic out-of-state callers, and by 8 A.M., there's already a line outside the doors of BabyLand General Hospital.

title: ECONOMIC REBOUND AWAITED
description: Economists, investors and bankers have not learned how to predict interest rates, but they have learned that the health of the nation's economy is a key arbiter of changes in rates.

title: IN ILLINOIS, ECONOMICS
description: The surprising Senate victories of Paul Simon and Tom Harkin, Democratic Representatives in Illinois and Iowa, should give pause to those strategists who would heal the Democratic Party's ills by pushing ever further to the right. Not even Ronald Reagan's overwhelming popularity could save Senator Charles H. Percy, in Illinois, or Senator Roger W. Jepsen, in Iowa, from challenges based, in many respects, on the traditional liberal agenda.

title: EGYPTIANS SAY LIBYAN 'DEATH SQUAD' HOPED TO STEAL A U.S.-MADE F-16 JET
description: The accused leader of a Libyan ''death squad'' arrested in Cairo has admitted that his group was going to try to steal a United States-made F-16 fighter jet from Egypt and take it to Libya, Egypt's Interior Minister was quoted today as saying.

title: SUCCESS IS A SURPRISE FOR B.Y.U.
description: Time was when LaVell Edwards did not have to endure this. He could put on his favorite windbreaker, hop into his Pontiac and drive down to the University Mall with his wife, Patti, and quietly enjoy an ice cream cone. Or a soda. Or he could walk round this quiet city, which is a short drive from where he was born in Orem, one of 14 children of farming parents, and raised as a devout member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chairman Retires At Campbell Soup
description: John T. Dorrance Jr., chairman of the Campbell Soup Company for the past 22 years, has announced his retirement. The announcement was made at the company's annual meeting at which Campbell's directors elected William S. Cashel Jr. as Mr. Dorrance's successor. The changes are effective immediately.

title: GERMAN SHEPHERD BEST IN SHOW
description: The top-winning German shepherd in the history of the breed in the United States stood alone tonight in the center of a carpeted ring in the Civic Center as the winner of the American Kennel Club's Centennial Show.

title: Addenda
description: * DYR has reached an agreement with R. W. Eggert in D"usseldorf whereby the Eggert agency will represent DYR in West Germany.

title: People
description: * Michael D. Drazen is joining Havas Conseil Marsteller as executive vice president-creative director.

title: Brynna Chernofsky Marries in Jersey
description: Brynna Chernofsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob L. Chernofsky of Monsey, N.Y., and Samuel John Bloomfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton W. Bloomfield of Cambridge, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Leo Jung, the bride's great- uncle, and Rabbi Moses Tendler performed the ceremony at the Ahavath Torah Congregation in Englewood, N.J.

title: EXTRAS AT THE OPERA: A SILENT BUT DEDICATED CORPS
description: Gilbert Ireland hasn't taken a vacation in 21 years. The four weeks Bergdorf Goodman gives him annually are lovingly divided into an hour here, an hour there, that he spends at the Metropolitan Opera House, transforming himself from a store window dresser into a Parisian bohemian, a Greek slave or a waiter.

title: SILICON VALLEY FOR HEALTH SEEN
description: The 14-minute videotape sales pitch makes the mart sound irresistible. Somewhere in the yawning exhibit space, a visiting doctor or hospital official can find every imaginable health care product. A computer gives directions. If the doctor wishes to look at cough medicine, the locations of the relevant exhibits will come spewing out.

title: NICARAGUAN SAYS U.S. STIRS FEARS
description: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister accused the Reagan Administration today of whipping up ''official hysteria'' against his Government and said the success of talks beginning Monday rested with the United States.

title: AGREEMENT, NOT DISASTER, ATUNESCO MEETING
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BUFFALO, A LONG-SUFFERING FEW STILL ROOT FOR NEW YORK'S TEAM
description: First off, the weatherman promised lots of heavy gray clouds, freezing rain and snow, with falling temperatures thrown in for good measure.

title: N.C.A.A. Cites Tennessee State
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association decided today not to allow unbeaten Tennessee State, the No. 1- ranked Division I-AA team, to participate in postseason play, an N.C.A.A. spokesman said today.

title: DAWN DWEIR, LAWYER WEDS MORRIS L. EFFRON
description: At the Midway Jewish Center in Syosset, L.I., yesterday Dawn Allison Dweir, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irv Dweir of Woodbury, L.I., was married to Morris L. Effron, the son of Carole R. Wallace and Howard P. Effron, both of New York. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein performed the ceremony.

title: A TALE OF LONDONDERRY, A CITY WITH TWO NAMES
description: This is a city so divided that it is not even possible to mention its name without choosing sides.

title: Jailed Minister's Wife Delivers His Sermon
description: As union activists sat in the front pew, the wife of a minister jailed in a dispute with his church delivered a sermon Sunday attacking ''corporate evil'' and the Lutheran officials who disciplined her husband.

title: SPANIARDS ASSAIL LAW IMPOSING STATE RULE ON SCHOOLS
description: Hundreds of thousands of Spaniards, joining in a growing battle between the Roman Catholic Church and the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, marched here today to protest a new law imposing state controls on most church-run schools.

title: Death Squads Cross the Pacific
description: Not one but three treacherous murders: first Benigno Aquino, then Alexander Orcullo, now Cesar Climaco. It may be that each crime came as a shock to Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos. But for these and other killings, no one has been punished. It's as if Central America's death-squads were taking distant root.

title: FOR ARAFAT, EFFORT TO CONVENE PALESTINIAN ASSEMBLY IS A 'MATTER OF SURVIVAL'
description: When the Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas sailed from Israeli-besieged Beirut two years ago, firing their Kalashnikov rifles wildly into the air as if to convince themselves they had won a famous victory, their military power was battered but seemingly intact.

title: Lipper Weighing Bid For Elected City Post
description: Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper said yesterday that he was considering running for an elected position in city government, either for City Council President or City Comptroller.

title: Basketball Diplomacy
description: The way Bob Peck sees it, when it comes to resolving international disputes, basketball is by and large better than bombs. Peck, to be sure, is prejudiced. He is by profession a basketball coach, but as the athletic director at Williams College, he is also something of an amateur peacemaker, one who is putting his basketball-for-peace theory to the test.

title: Union Leaders Gather To Back Copper Strikes
description: About 4,000 striking copper workers and their allies gathered here today to hear national union leaders voice support of two strikes, including a bitter 16-month-old walkout against Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: VOTE COMES TO A 'HOMELAND,' BUT AFRICAN PROBLEMS LINGER
description: Under capricious skies that brought rain and light by turn to places of little hope, the officials and the policeman stood before the galvanized iron hut that represented a polling booth and said, well, yes, the turnout had been sluggish.

title: A French Aide Links Chad and Nicaragua
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today that concern expressed in the United States about the withdrawal of French troops from Chad without a Libyan pullout corresponded ''to the Americans' desire to show that their way of dealing with Nicaragua is the right one.''

title: Fedders Cleared by S.E.C. Staff
description: A House subcommittee has dropped an inquiry into the involvement of John M. Fedders, the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement head, in a corporate bribery scheme, after an S.E.C. staff report cleared him of any violations of federal securities laws.

title: Coghlan Winner In Cross-Country
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, showing no effects of the stress fracture that kept him out of the Olympics last summer, led the New York Athletic Club to the title with 21 points in the Avon/Metropolitan Athletic Congress 10-kilometer cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Bridge: 2 Teams From Middle West Take Titles at Fall Nationals
description: Two Middle Western partnerships captured titles here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: AMERICANS IN POLL VIEW GOVERNMENT MORE CONFIDENTLY
description: The American public, its level of confidence in government rebounding after more than a decade of doubts, expects President Reagan to avoid an economic recession in his second term and to make a real effort to negotiate an arms control treaty, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Sarah Eve Asnes Wed to Marc Ira Altman, C.P.A.
description: Sarah Eve Asnes, a daughter of Naomi Asnes of Leonia, N.J., and Montauk, L.I., and the late Harry Asnes, was married yesterday to Marc Ira Altman, a son of Abraham Altman of Closter, N.J., and the late Ruth Suckno Altman. Rabbi Zelich Block performed the ceremony at the Congregation Sons of Israel in Leonia.

title: CENTRISM IS CRUCIAL
description: The Democratic Party may be compared to a losing business under poor management that nonetheless retains significant assets. Like many such businesses, it may have to resort to voluntary receivership for a thorough reorganization. Nothing less is likely to force it to focus on its strengths and to discard the patterns of conduct that have brought it to the brink of disaster.

title: 'What's What'
description: If there's a bookish sports fan on your Christmas list who thinks he knows everything, Reginald Bragonier Jr. and David Fisher may have just the book to put him in his place, or at least keep him quiet for a while.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Why did an obituary on George (High Pockets) Kelly last month neglect to mention that he once hit four home runs in a game?

title: Wife of U.S. Citizen Deported to Philippines
description: A woman who married a United States citizen earlier this year and is five months pregnant has been deported to her native Philippines because she lived here illegally for nearly 10 years and ignored early deportation orders.

title: Briefcases
description: - The North American Securities Administrators Association, a little-known body of state regulators, will begin its first coordinated strike today, so far unidentified, against a fraudulent tax shelter that has obtained an estimated $2 million from 250 investors in 18 states.

title: MUST BRIBES BE PART OF THE COST OF DOING BUSINESS IN NEW YORK?
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAKTHROUGH IN PROBLEM SOLVING
description: A 28-year-old mathematician at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories has made a startling theoretical breakthrough in the solving of systems of equations that often grow too vast and complex for the most powerful computers.

title: Munch Works Stolen in Oslo
description: Four lithographs by the Norwegian painter Edvard Munch, valued at more than $115,000, were stolen Saturday from the home of a foreign resident of Oslo. The police declined to identify the lithographs, but said two oil paintings by lesser-known artists also were stolen from the house.

title: COCAINE TRAFFICKERS KILL 17 IN PERU RAID ON ANTIDRUG TEAM
description: A band of cocaine traffickers burst into a jungle campsite and opened fire with automatic weapons, killing at least 17 people employed by a United States-financed program to destroy coca crops, the police said today.

title: Talks to Resume In Strike at Yale
description: Yale University and the union representing 1,500 striking white-collar workers have agreed to resume negotiations and could meet as early as Monday.

title: Vietnamese Attack Cambodian Rebel Camp
description: Vietnamese tanks and artillery attacked a Cambodian rebel camp today in what Thai military officials said could signal the start of an early dry- season offensive.

title: West Bank Arsonists Destroy Car of Pro-Arafat Spokesman
description: Unidentified arsonists in the Israeli-occupied West Bank today destroyed an automobile belonging to a spokesman for the mainstream of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Girl Is Run Down After Argument
description: A Wantagh (L.I.) High School senior was critically injured early yesterday by a hit-and- run driver who had argued with her and her friends in a parking field in Hempstead, L.I., the police said.

title: MUSIC: YO-YO MA AND EMANUEL AX
description: It has been clear for several seasons that Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax are a cello-piano duo of the highest distinction. Observing that distinction, trying to put a finger on its precise nature, made for an unusually rewarding couple of hours as they played a trio of demanding sonatas Saturday at Carnegie Hall.

title: ARIK-WESTY PINCERS
description: WASHINGTON A former U.S. Government official

title: G.E. Executive Chosen To Head Barnes Group
description: William R. Fenoglio has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Barnes Group Inc., an automotive parts manufacturer and distributor. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

title: Got a Match?
description: If a persistent politician digs deep

title: Pacing the Pacemakers
description: Pacemakers have become big

title: DISCLOSURE RULE DELAYED FOR SOME
description: Many of the New York City school employees who are to undergo background investigations and file financial disclosure forms will not be required to do so until two lawsuits have been resolved.

title: THE CHURCH CANNOT BE NEUTRAL ABOUT HOMOSEXUALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DREAMER BEHIND ECUMED IDEA
description: The people who beat the drum for Ecumed are hardly shy about dropping the names of its blue-ribbon board, some of the leading lights in health care. One name that gets lost, though, is Robert Weneck.

title: DON MALONEY HURT
description: Another severe injury befell the Rangers last night. Don Maloney suffered a broken left ankle in the first 2 minutes of a game with the Devils and will be gone for at least three months.

title: KEEPING EQUIPMENT IN TUNE
description: One of the biggest misconceptions about skis is that they are ready to use right from the shop. Another misconception is that, except for repairing large gouges and nicks in the base or fixing delaminations, skis need no maintenance.

title: Gunmen Kill 7 in Raid On Colombia Restaurant
description: At least 15 gunmen opened fire on customers eating breakfast in a restaurant in the town of Jagua today, killing seven and wounding four, the authorities said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEGIN. The Haunted Prophet. By Eric Silver. 278 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $17.95.

title: SALVADOR FOES SHARE CAUTION ON CHANCE FOR PEACE
description: Salvadoran Government and rebel officials who met here for a televised debate last week offered new insights into their respective strategies as they prepare for a second round of peace talks.

title: 3 FOUND GUILTY IN KILLING IN MOB POWER FIGHT
description: Harry Riccobene and two other men were convicted of murder today in a 1982 case that the authorities said was part of the battle for control of organized crime in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, including Atlantic City.

title: Islanders, Flyers in 3-3 Draw
description: Kelly Hrudey waited and waited. ''Three weeks,'' he said. ''Three weeks and one day, to be truthful.''

title: KEY PERFORMER AND TEACHER
description: Leonard Rose, a distinguished American cellist celebrated for his solo performances and his musical collaborations with such artists as Isaac Stern and Eugene Istomin, died Friday night in the White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Labonte Clinches Driving Title
description: Terry Labonte finished third in a Chevrolet Monte Carlo SS today in the Winston Western 500 at Riverside International Raceway, clinching the Grand National stock car driving title in the final race of the season.

title: JUST THE THING TO MEET DEMAND FOR A WIDGET
description: The New York Framistan Corporation makes framistans at 10 factories in different cities from Buffalo to Albany. It sells them at 20 stores, in cities from New York to Easthampton, and it has a fleet of trucks to pick up the framistans as they roll off the assembly line.

title: Australian Ambassador Of Photography
description: Sir Robert Cotton thought it was time for a hobby, so he became an amateur photographer. And now Sir Robert, the Australian Ambassador to the United States, is having an exhibition of his works at the office of Qantas, the Australian airline, on Fifth Avenue at 44th Street, through Nov. 29.

title: FORMER BONN AIDE IS ACCUSED
description: The news magazine Der Spiegel said today that another member of West Germany's Free Democratic Party was involved in illegal party financing in the 1970's.

title: NETWORKS SHIFTING ROLE OF ANCHORMEN
description: A subtle shift appears to be taking place in the format of the network evening newscast. It is an effort, largely by ABC and to a somewhat lesser extent by NBC, to chip at the traditional mold of network news - an illustrated headline service within 22 minutes - by involving the anchorman in more stories and showing him as an interviewer in addition to a reader of the news.

title: STAGE: AT RADIO CITY, HOLIDAY SPECTACULAR
description: There were several indications of things to come in town over the weekend. The temperature dipped, the traffic crested, there was a snow forecast and Radio City Music Hall's ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular'' opened, with the usual seasonal wrapping of people around the hall waiting to get in to see it.

title: Israel Faces Further Cuts
description: The Israeli Cabinet was told today that 15,000 federal employees may have to be dismissed if the battle against 800 percent inflation is to succeed, a Government spokesman said.

title: MEANING WHAT WE SAY
description: BOSTON Around the world brutal governments torment their people, and

title: 5 Thrift Units Ordered Shut
description: Five Tennessee savings and loan associations were closed and their insured deposits transferred to a newly created institution, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced Friday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * John Blair & Co., a diversified marketing and communications company, has elected to its board C. E. Meyer Jr., president and chief executive of Trans World Airlines.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 19, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO TOWER
description: Senator John Tower, who has railed at members of Congress for some time about what he sees as their flaws, is firing his final fusillades these days before retiring to the calm of Southern Methodist University in January.

title: 'Yellow Pages' Agency Silent About a Project
description: You might wish to call this Project X. The client, Reuben H. Donnelley, the division of Dun & Bradstreet that publishes a lot of the Yellow Pages directories, declines to acknowledge that it even has such a product.

title: FOR A CITY, MODESTY IS NO VIRTUE
description: Kansas Cityans don't seem to do a lot of bragging, but when they do, they brag with a moderation that brought some facetious scolding the other day from a popular columnist.

title: GERMAN SHEPHERD BEST IN SHOW
description: The top-winning German shepherd in the history of the breed in the United States stood alone tonight in the center of a carpeted ring in the Civic Center as the winner of the American Kennel Club's Centennial Show.

title: NURSING HOME LOSES PAYMENTS FROM THE U.S.
description: Medicated and Medicare payments for new patients admitted to the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in Manhattan have been withdrawn as sanction against what offical paid were violations at the home involving inadequate medical and nursing care.

title: WALL ST.'S MERCHANT BANKERS
description: After years of urging investors to take a stake in American business, a great many Wall Street firms have decided to follow their own advice.

title: Richard Burton Left A $4.5 Million Estate
description: The actor Richard Burton left an estate worth $4.58 million in his will, the bulk of it to his widow, Sally, The Sunday Mirror reported today. He died in Switzerland on Aug. 5.

title: An Antigun Appeal Is Extended to Youths
description: After John Lennon was shot to death in 1980, Jann S. Wenner, editor of Rolling Stone, founded the National Alliance Against Violence, a nonprofit organization dedicated to getting guns out of the hands of private citizens.

title: Victoria Breen, Writer, Marries Charles Gelber
description: Nancy Victoria Breen, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Breen of Briarcliff, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Nathan Gelber, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Julius Gelber of Scotia, N.Y. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Upgrading For Michigan
description: Michigan, which has had the lowest bond rating of any state for the past 30 months, lost that status yesterday when Moody's Investors Service raised its bond rating to medium grade A from the low investment grade rating of Baa-1.

title: ALBANY LEADERS PREDICTING A CUT IN INCOME TAXES
description: Republicans and Democrats in Albany predicted yesterday that a cut in personal income taxes similar to that recommended by a Cuomo administration panel over the weekend would be enacted next year.

title: Archbishop Doubts Letter Mirrors Catholics' Attitude
description: The chairman of a committee of Roman Catholic bishops, which released the first draft of a pastoral letter on the economy last week, said Friday that the letter probably did not reflect the current thinking of most American Catholics.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football

title: SOME IN RIGHTS COUNCIL FEAR RACIAL POLARIZATION IN POLITICS
description: Like many of those at the 40th annual meeting of the Southern Regional Council, 86-year-old Septima Clark said she was saddened by the death of the Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. on Nov. 11 and unhappy with Ronald Reagan's re-election Nov. 6.

title: 5 Children Hurt In Fire in Albany
description: A fire swept through an apartment building here before dawn today, seriously injuring five children, including a 4-year-old girl who jumped from the third floor, the police said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 19, 1984: MONDAY BankAmer Rlty InvInterlake IncBaxter TravenolJohnson ControlsCentury Tel EntNafco Fin GroupGoodrich (BF) CoSan Diego G & E TUESDAY Armstrong RubberIrving BankCluett PeabodyLongs Drug StsColeman CoMohasco CorpDuquesne LightOhio EdisonGap StoresPan Amer BanksGenl Equip EntUnited Cos FinlGuardsman ChemsWells Fargo & CoInterpublic Grp

title: KARL A. SCHUON
description: Karl A. Schuon, an author who was the longtime editor of the magazine of the United States Marine Corps, died Friday at his home in Colonial Beach, Va. He would have been 71 years old on Nov. 26.

title: THE CHURCH CANNOT BE NEUTRAL ABOUT HOMOSEXUALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: NUMBER OF SINGLE PARENT ADOPTIONS GROWS
description: Dr. Judith Kuppersmith, a Brooklyn psychologist, was in her late 30's when she decided she wanted to adopt a child. But after visiting several adoption agencies, she found she was ''last on everybody's list.'' ''I had three problems,'' she said. ''My age, I was single, and I wanted an infant.''

title: OFFICIALS DISQUALIFY WINNER OF REMSEN
description: The Aqueduct stewards yesterday disqualified Stonewhite, winner of Saturday's Remsen Stakes for 2-year- olds, because the gelding was found to have raced with incorrect weight.

title: Censors in Feminist Garb
description: A strange alliance of bluenosed censors and a branch of the feminist movement has surfaced in Suffolk County and is approaching New York City. Garbed as civil-rights champions, they have lobbied in Minneapolis, Indianapolis, Los Angeles and elsewhere to outlaw ''graphic sexually explicit subordination of women.''

title: ILLINOIS TAKES OPENER
description: George Montgomery scored 17 points and helped contain Wayman Tisdale as Illinois routed Oklahoma, 81-64, today in the annual Hall of Fame Tip-Off Classic.

title: A LAWYER ADVERTISES HIM, HIMSELF AND HIM
description: ''Demonstrative evidence works like magic for Mark Dombroff,'' says Crystal L. Palmer. ''Mark Dombroff recognizes the essentially theatrical nature of trial work and has mastered the art,'' she continues.

title: Flutie Downgraded
description: One of the first public assessments of Doug Flutie as a candidate for pro football is at hand, and it is not so positive.

title: Gord Lane's New Look
description: Gord Lane claims that when he showed up wearing a helmet Saturday night, the referee, Bob Myers, told him to ''take it off so I can tell where you are.'' A defenseman who provided more muscle than finesse in the Islanders' four Stanley Cup championships, Lane had thought he might blend into the background with his new headgear.

title: Miss Frankel, Lawyer, Wed to Joseph Bonacci
description: Cathy J. Frankel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Frankel of New York, and Joseph Bonacci, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Bonacci of Lido Beach, L.I., were married yesterday at the Palisadium in Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: MUSICAL COMEDIES SET FOR CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera has received a $5 million gift for the establishment of a spring musical-comedy season starting in 1986 at the New York State Theater, according to Beverly Sills, general director of the company.

title: DOLPHINS LOSE IN OVERTIME
description: Buford McGee bounced off tackle and scampered 25 yards for a touchdown 3 minutes 17 seconds into overtime today as San Diego ended Miami's unbeaten streak with a 34-28 comeback victory.

title: STAGE: ANDRE DE SHIELDS IN 'HAARLEM NOCTURNE'
description: ''Haarlem Nocturne'' was conceived by Andre De Shields, who is also the co-author and co-director, wrote the music and lyrics for several of the evening's songs and is the most conspicuous performer on stage. This is not a cohesive anthology on the order of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' but an eclectic collage primarily designed to show off Mr. De Shields. The musical opened last night at the newly restored Latin Quarter - formerly the Latin Quarter, but in recent years known as 22 Steps and the Princess Theater.

title: OUTDOORS: NEW LIFTS AND FRESH SNOW AWAIT SKIERS
description: The East is about to get its winter. Despite lingering warm temperatures through most of the fall, a few ski areas have managed to pop out enough machine-made snow to cover a slope or two and offer skiing.

title: 4 Die in South African Mine
description: Four miners, three white and one black, have died in a torrent of mud two miles down a gold mine, the mining company, Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, said today. A spokesman said the bodies of the four had been brought to the surface after the accident Saturday at the President Steyn Gold Mining Company at Welkom, 125 miles south of Johannesburg.

title: MUSIC: THE KODALY QUARTET
description: Bartok's music came to large numbers of postwar listeners in recorded performances that stressed its asceticism and uncompromising originality. The Kodaly Quartet from Budapest widened our outlook a little at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday - by surrounding the composer's Fourth Quartet with quartets of his colleagues, Kodaly and Dohnanyi.

title: Cosmos Beaten By Blast, 6-1
description: The Baltimore Blast battered the Cosmos, 6-1, in a Major Indoor Indoor Soccer League game today.

title: P.L.O. Unable to Hold Full Leadership Talks
description: An attempt to hold a full meeting of the Palestine Liberation Organization's leadership, aimed at resolving differences between Chairman Yasir Arafat and his opponents, collapsed Saturday night because of a boycott by Syrian- backed members, a senior P.L.O. official said today.

title: Dr. Haim Blanc Dies at 58; An Israeli Professor of Arabic
description: Dr. Haim Blanc, professor emeritus of Arabic languages and literature at Hebrew University, died Saturday at his home in Jerusalem after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

title: Of Mixed-Up Robots And Children's Authors
description: Wearing a bolo tie with an orange robot on its slide, Isaac Asimov talked gently and humorously to young readers yesterday at Eeyore's, the children's bookstore on Broadway at 81st Street. He and his wife, Dr. Janet O. Jeppson, have written two children's books about Norby, a mixed-up robot.

title: Only a Moment for Transit
description: The approaching special session of New York's Legislature will be a hasty December wedding of clever politics and sound budgeting. Politics discouraged action before Election Day on the 18 percent tax surcharge on corporate earnings that helps support metropolitan transit.

title: Beverly Hills Reports Loss
description: Citing what it called ''questionable'' real estate loans, the Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association reported a loss of $10.1 million in the third quarter, compared with earnings of $548,000, or 30 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE HEROIC MOLD

title: Skiers Organize
description: Apparently no one had read the rules - not the athletes, not the coaches, not the managers. But when a couple of members of the United States Olympic Alpine ski team did get around to reading the rules, they discovered they had some rights.

title: Pausing for His Own Party
description: ''Im embarrassed by these things,'' Rabbi Balfour Brickner said yesterday. ''Usually, I give them for other people.''

title: Capitol Moves Its Ad Account
description: Capitol Air has chosen Berger, Stone & Partners as its advertising agency, Joe Stone of the agency said Friday.

title: Islamic Chief Chides The 'Holy Warriors'
description: Middle East terrorist groups calling themselves holy warriors were criticized as abusers of a sacred tenet of Islam by a Saudi Arabian religious leader at the weekend.

title: Limiting RICO's Sway
description: Morgan Stanley, American Express, E. F. Hutton and Lloyd's of London are among hundreds of companies that have recently found their names smeared with racketeering charges, and have faced costly triple-damage claims and the awarding of attorney fees. The Reagan Administration wants to put a stop to all that.

title: Ex-Georgia Official Convicted Of Plot in Sinking of a Yacht
description: A former Georgia Labor Commissioner was convicted Saturday of Federal charges that he and an associate sank their yacht in the Atlantic in 1980 to collect on a $95,000 insurance policy.

title: A GIANT OF SOCIALISM IS HAILED ON 100TH ANNIVERSARY OF BIRTH
description: The fires of socialism have burned low in the United States for the last half-century, but the memory of Norman Thomas, who ran six times as the Socialist Party's candidate for President, cast a glow this weekend at a gathering to mark the centennial of his birth.

title: The Worm and the Apple ; Drive and Park
description: Christmas Present

title: CHANGES WEIGHED IN DATA ON CRIMES
description: The Justice Department has undertaken a study that could lead to major changes in the gathering of national crime statistics, which help shape Federal and local policies on law enforcement and other social issues.

title: O.A.S. HOPES FOR 'REVITALIZED' ROLE IN REGION
description: After a week of discussions, the 31 members of the Organization of American States have agreed to make a new attempt at strengthening the regional body.

title: TREASURY MAY ASK INCREASES IN TAXES OF SOME CONCERNS
description: The Treasury Department is writing a proposal to raise the taxes of some businesses by modifying depreciation rules and reduce the taxes many other companies owe by lowering rates over all, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: HOW ANDERSON TURNED RUTGERS AROUND
description: When Dick Anderson arrived at Rutgers early this year as the new football coach, many players on the team did not quite know what to make of him. He looked like an all- American from the 1950's - tall, slim, polite, conservatively dressed and with now-unfashionable short hair.

title: Gwynn Cornell Is Dead at 46; Mezzo-Soprano at MetOpera
description: Gwynn Cornell, a mezzo-soprano who made appearances with the Metropolitan Opera, the San Diego Opera and the Cincinnati Opera, among others, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Oct. 31.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I just don't see a groundswell of support out there for tax simplification.''

title: A.T.& T. Runner Wins on Wall St.
description: Tom Donahue of Denville, N.J., outkicked a field of more than 1,000 competitors yesterday to win the Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge National Championship.

title: JETS LOSE TO OILERS
description: The Jets started brightly today, just like their season, then they were swamped by a relentless Houston Oiler team that played as if its 10 season-opening losses had happened to someone else.

title: A RECORD SALE OF TREASURY NOTES
description: After an absence of nearly two weeks, the Treasury will return to the note market this week with a record $9 billion sale of two-year notes on Wednesday. In addition, the Treasury will sell $13.6 billion of bills at its regular auction today.

title: Hunger Strike in Pakistan
description: Thirty-one Pakistanis are staging a hunger strike to protest their trial on charges of plotting to overthrow the military Government, a lawyers' group said today. Six of the hunger strikers, who are part of a group of 54 people being tried by a secret military court in Lahore, are in serious condition, the Political Prisoners Release and Relief Committee said.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 8 to 14 with 1,798 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Satellite Launching Delayed
description: Winds in the upper atmosphere delayed today's scheduled launching of a weather satellite until Monday. The device was designed to determine whether the earth is being warmed by the buildup of carbon dioxide, the ''greenhouse effect,'' and if the ozone layer is decreasing.

title: CANADA SENDS U.S. MORE GAS
description: Because of Canada's recent formal deregulation of export prices, its natural gas is beginning to pour across the border in large quantities at increasingly low prices after years of being overpriced compared with American gas.

title: CHAMBER: SCHWARZ CONDUCTS Y SUMPHONY
description: There were enough riches in the Y Chamber Symphony's two-hour concert at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night to satisfy a concertgoer for a month. Peter Serkin played Mozart; Ned Rorem had his second New York premiere in two nights; and to sing it was a splendid British mezzo-soprano named Delia Wallis, who is not as well known here as she should be. Underlying all this was the playing of the Y Chamber Symphony under Gerard Schwarz - an orchestra and a conductor who continue year by year to add impressive subtlety and grace to the virtuosity they have always had.

title: Second Bid For Register
description: A bidding war may be evolving for the purchase of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company with news of a second offer to buy the company.

title: THE REV. PAUL RISHELL
description: The Rev. Paul W. Rishell, who led a drive to lift the ban on birth control prescriptions in New York City hospitals in the 1950's, died of respiratory failure yesterday at the Audubon Villa, a nursing home in Lititz, Pa.

title: WORKERS IN SPAIN PROTEST CUTBACKS
description: Here on Spain's craggy northwestern coast, a fog-ridden area steeped in the lore of fighting pirates and building ships, the giant pieces of what would have been Ship No. 265 lie strewn across the yard of the Astano ship works.

title: HELPING TROUBLED CHILDREN
description: Andy and Josephine went for a walk in East Harlem the other day. Andy is 4 years old, going on 5, and tall for his age, and Josephine is 42 but doesn't look it. Josephine is not Andy's mother or his cousin or his aunt; she's a special friend. Or, in the language of those who work with children who have emotional and developmental disabilities, she is a therapeutic companion.

title: NETS TOP SONICS FOR 2D STRAIGHT
description: What had loomed as a perilous road trip has suddenly become a success. The Nets, still without the center Darryl Dawkins, survived a furious fourth- period rally by Seattle tonight to win their second consecutive game, 102- 97, before a crowd of 5,473 at the Kingdome.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: NEW CALEDONIA VOTE IS UNRULY
description: French settlers opposed to independence for this French Pacific territory swept to power today in elections for a National Assembly after the police fired tear gas and stun grenades against militants attempting to disrupt the voting.

title: Some Candy Off Shelves After Threat in Britain
description: A British candy company began removing its chocolate bars from stores today after animal rights militants warned that they had injected rat poison into candy bars and at least three people said the candy had made them sick.

title: MAGAZINE GIVES VOICE TO TODAY'S WEST
description: Andrew Weil, a Harvard-trained physician who is the author of several books on alternatives to standard medicine, was asked if he wanted to be called ''doctor'' or ''mister.''

title: KEY BRITISH RULING ON WAGES
description: Julie Hayward joined the apprentice cook's program in the canteen at the Cammell Laird shipyard in Liverpool nine years ago, fresh out of school. When she completed it four years later, she found herself serving meals to men at the yard, including former schoolmates, who had a comparable level of training, easier jobs and higher salaries.

title: Next, Majority Leader
description: The focal question in political

title: Soviet Defense Minister Still Issuing Orders
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri F. Ustinov, who has not been seen in public since Sept. 27, issued the customary ''order of the day'' for Monday's observance of the Day of Rocket Forces.

title: UPSETS CAUSE SHIFT IN BOWLS
description: Another week of major upsets has rearranged the college football bowl picture.

title: THE HALF-PULLOUT IN CHAD
description: Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi's success in bluffing French troops out of Chad while keeping a contingent of his own army in place has created not only deep embarrassment for President Francois Mitterrand, but also problems for the United States. Perhaps more than the Reagan Administration would have wished, the botched withdrawal process in Chad appears to be drawing the United States into a more visible role in the future of the fragmented country.

title: Article 094586 -- No Title
description: Bikini atoll, a ring of islands in the Pacific contaminated by nuclear tests, could be made habitable again for $40 million, according to a study made public today.

title: I.B.M. ENTRY UNCHALLENGED AT SHOW
description: The International Business Machines Corporation seems likely to face substantially less competition in the personal computer field over the next year, according to industry experts who say the giant's flurry of new products has left I.B.M.-compatible makers far behind.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Amax Inc. filed for a proposed offering of $125 million of notes due 1994 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc.

title: Growth in Jails' Populations
description: The number of inmates in local jails in the United States grew by 41 percent in the five years after 1978, reaching a record 223,551 in 1983, the Justice Department said today.

title: 250 Dead in India Floods
description: The death toll from floods caused by a hurricane that hit southern India climbed to more than 250 today, the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said the floods killed 205 people in Andhra Pradesh state, which was hit by the hurricane four days ago. About 200 villages in the state are still under water, it said.

title: Roller Coaster Regulation
description: The folks who sell roller coasters and other bone- rattling rides expect another skirmish with consumer activists in the House over a revival of last year's unsuccessful effort to reinstate the Consumer Product Safety Commission's jurisdiction over their business.

title: Canadiens Send Shutt to Kings
description: The Los Angeles Kings announced today that they had acquired the left wing Steve Shutt from the Montreal Canadiens in exchange for ''future considerations.''

title: Advertising; Contrasts In Bulova's Campaign
description: AMONG the companies that sell the most watches in this country, the Bulova Watch Company has two endearing qualities: It is venerable, and it is American.

title: BILLS STUN COWBOYS FOR FIRST VICTORY
description: The rookie running back Greg Bell scored two touchdowns, one on an 85-yard run on the first play of the game, as the Buffalo Bills won their first game of the season, stunning the Dallas Cowboys, 14-3, today.

title: HOMELESS SPEND NIGHTS IN CITY WELFARE OFFICE
description: For the last 10 weeks, homeless families, mostly mothers and young children, have been spending weekend nights on plastic chairs, on countertops or on the floor in New York City's emergency welfare office because the city's welfare agency has run out of beds.

title: Erid D. Rosen Is Married To Dr. Sharon R. Maza
description: Dr. Sharon R. Maza, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Gabriel Maza of Deer Park, L.I., was married there yesterday to Eric D. Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rosen of New Milford, N.J. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Suffolk Jewish Center, of which he is the religious leader.

title: Dr. Susan Ruskin Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Dr. Susan Edith Ruskin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Ruskin of Waterbury, Conn., to David Bruce Friend, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Friend of Fairfield, Conn., took place yesterday at B'nai Shalom Synagogue in Waterbury. Rabbi Morris Gorelik, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony

title: HANDICPPED GAIN CONFIDENCE ON SNOW
description: For the handicapped, the words ''You can't get there from here'' have been heard and felt often. Access ramps and designated parking spaces represent signs of progress, but ''getting there'' has only recently come to include getting to the top - or the bottom - of a ski slope. Ski trails, which have been depicted as disabling those not handicapped, are fast becoming avenues to un-handicap the disabled.

title: SEARCHING FOR TALENT AND A 'PLATINUM' SOUND
description: DOWNSTAIRS at Trax, a club at 72d Street and Columbus Avenue, the decibel level was so high on a recent evening that even the record company executives were whimpering. Jeff Aldrich, whose job is to find new acts for Chrysalis Records, a company with headquarters in New York and London, had come to see a singer whose tape he liked. But within five off-key minutes, it was apparent that she had no future at Chrysalis.

title: CAPITOL AIR PILOTS PUSH LOAN PLAN
description: A committee representing employees of Capitol Air has put together a plan that could provide the ailing carrier with $1 million in cash from a loan some time this week to help it keep operating.

title: THE PLOT THICKENS: REDSKINS DEFEATED
description: The lead in the division was there for the taking. A touchdown would have done it, and the Washington Redskins had almost 25 minutes to get it.

title: HIGH CUBAN DEFECTOR SPEAKS OUT, DENOUNCING CASTRO AS 'IMPULSIVE'
description: A Cuban defector whose position, according to United States authorities, gave him entree to high-level Government meetings in Havana says that Fidel Castro's style of leadership in domestic affairs is personal, impulsive and at times intrusive.

title: Season to Remember
description: Although it forfeited its league season, George Washington High School's football team counts 1984 as one of the most educational seasons ever.

title: 'RICHARD BELZER SHOW,' COMEDY SERIES ON CABLE
description: Richard Belzer is the kind of comedian who is described in press releases as irreverent. In other words, much of his material cannot be quoted in a family newspaper. But Mr. Belzer and his basic act can be sampled, unexpurgated, on a series of six half-hours now being carried on Cinemax, the pay-cable channel. The experience is uneven but not without some redeeming merit. Program No. 2 of ''The Richard Belzer Show'' can be seen tonight at 8:30.

title: Israeli Captain Is Suspended After Ship Put Stowaway Off
description: An Israeli sea captain accused of having forced a Kenyan stowaway off his ship off the East African coast has been suspended and the case has been turned over to the police, a Government spokesman said today.

title: SEARCH PRESSED
description: A tugboat with a crew of six disappeared over the weekend on a 12-hour trip from Bridgeport, Conn., to Port Newark. Coast Guard and police boats that searched Long Island Sound and New York Harbor yesterday were unable to find any sign of the tug or the barge that she had been towing.

title: Rare Books on Display
description: More than 100 rare books from the Berg Collection of American and English literature bearing inscriptions by their authors are on display at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: 2 Killed in Philippines
description: Two people were killed in the latest outbreak of guerrilla fighting in this southern Philippine city. Military sources said today that on Saturday night gunmen shot dead a banana plantation security guard and a woman suspected of being an informer for the Communist New People's Army.

title: Dutch Production
description: Industrial production in the Netherlands fell 1 percent in September from August, but was up 7.4 percent from 12 months earlier, the Central Bureau of Statistics said Friday. The figures were corrected for seasonal factors.

title: The Worm and the Apple ; Drive and Park Backyard CleanupCentral Park is known all over the world as New York City's backyard. But ask millions of New Yorkers to name their backyards and they're apt to answer ''the Coleman Square playground,'' or ''J. J. Byrne Memorial.'' Coleman Square and J. J. Byrne, not to mention Jackson Square, Rainey and Leif Ericson, are 5 of the city's 1,077 neighborhood parks. Far too many of them have fallen into disrepair. The once-inviting places to take a toddler, sit in the sun, play cards or shoot a few baskets have become slums of graffiti and litter.
description: The Parks Department is finally responding. Within the next nine months it will spend $6.1 million to spruce up 211 of the neighborhood parks.

title: MCKINNEY RESIGNS AS KINGS' COACH
description: Jack McKinney resigned today as coach of the Kansas City Kings, blaming the stress of the job, and Phil Johnson was hired to replace him for his second tour with the team.

title: COMPUTING THE BUDGET
description: In all the wrangling over budget deficits, taxes and prospects for the economy, absolute numbers seem to be fading from use. Instead, the talk among the Reagan Administration and economists is of percentages, which appear to be much smaller than the actual numbers themselves. One reason for the emphasis on percentages seems to be that the absolute numbers for the United States economy simply frighten politicians and befuddle the public. In its first year in office, the Reagan Administration delivered the nation its first million million-dollar national debt, and next year, it could produce the country's first million million-dollar budget.

title: JAZZ:CECIL TAYLOR SEPTET
description: -piece Cecil Taylor Unit's first show Saturday at Irving Plaza included quasi- Arabic singing by Mr. Taylor, a fast riff piece for horns, a fanfare- like tune, an interlude for piano trio, a stretch of eerie horn chords, a chorale-like ballad and a speed-demon encore.

title: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income which includes income from discontinued operations of $1,179,649.

title: Saints Top Steelers
description: Richard Todd threw two touchdown passes tonight in leading the New Orleans Saints to a 27-24 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Group Criticizes U.S. Effort To License Foreign Reporter
description: The Inter-American Press Association said today that the United States Government used ''ill-advised tactics'' when it attempted to force a reporter for Prensa Latina, the Cuban press agency, to obtain a license.

title: A NEW ELITISM APPEARS IN HIGHER EDUCATION
description: WHILE politicians advertise this as the era of opportunity, for many of the least affluent young people the opportunity to go to college is receding.

title: PLAYFUL ALI GOES THE DISTANCE WITH REPORTERS
description: Questions from reporters were always his best medicine. And as the 65-minute interview warmed up yesterday and the questions got tougher, Muhammad Ali got sharper.

title: BISHOPS' LETTER ON ECONOMY LEFT OUT FAMILY
description: To the Editor:

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $30,000. c-Including a tax credit of $27,000.

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary loss of $165,000.

title: GOLDSMITH PLANS MOVE ON COLGATE
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, has made an application to increase his holdings in the Colgate-Palmolive Company to more than 10 percent, and the United States Government is not expected to oppose the move, New York antitrust lawyers said yesterday.

title: CONTRAST IN REAGAN'S WORDS AND DIFICIT SIGNS DEFENDED
description: A White House spokesman said today that there was no inconsistency between President Reagan's optimistic words about the Federal deficit just before the election while Administration experts were privately measuring far bleaker trends.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Russian Criticizes Seoul MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (Reuters) - Marat Gramov, president of the
description: Soviet Olympic Committee, today publicly criticized the choice of Seoul

title: King's Singers Perform At Avery Fisher Hall
description: One adversity of success is having to please increasing numbers of listeners even if the music would be happier without them. Thus, while most of the King's Singers program Friday night was really chamber music, it was sung in Avery Fisher Hall - hardly a chamber in the intended sense.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 M.T.A. LINES SEE NO INCREASE IN FARES FOR '85
description: There will be no fare increases in 1985 for passengers who ride on the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad if New York State continues its subsidies at the present levels, the lines said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1984 International An inferno engulfed a slum area near Mexico City as a storage center for liquefied gas exploded in flames, reportedly killing at least 261 people and seriously injuring 500. The authorities said that 100,000 people had been evacuated in buses from the neighborhood of wooden shacks. (Page A1, Column 6.) Food supplies were cut off for thousands of famine victims as secessionist rebels seized a major refuge center in northern Ethiopia, according to sources in the relief effort. They said the center, at Korem, which contains up to 40,000 refugees, 15,000 of them children, had been overrun after a daylong battle between the rebels and Government troops. (A3:4-6.)

title: MEDICINE UNDR SCRUTINY
description: In early 1964, for the first time in medical history, surgeons at the University of Mississippi Medical Center transplanted an animal heart into a human. They were treating a 68-year-old man whose heart was failing. No human heart was available, so they used a chimpanzee heart instead. The heart lasted only an hour before it proved incapable of handling the larger blood flow of an adult man, and the patient died.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ed Reinhardt, the Colorado football player who suffered a severe head injury in a game against Oregon two months ago, has been transferred from the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center to Craig Hospital in Denver, where he will begin physical rehabilitation. Reinhardt, who had three brain operations while in Eugene, Ore., has emerged from a coma, according to Tom Reese , a hospital spokesman, but still responds inconsistently to commands. . . . Bobby Chacon , the former World Boxing Council featherweight champion, has pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor charge of wife beating. Sentencing has been scheduled for Dec. 17.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS' NAVY CONTRACT UNDER ATTACK
description: The chairman of a House committee has demanded that the Navy take control of two General Dynamics Corporation shipyards because the company gave gifts to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover in 1977 when he was head of the Navy's nuclear submarine program.

title: BAD RAPS; Dim Lamp
description: A strange awards ceremony occurs in Washington today. Four women are to receive the first Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award in recognition of their work in El Salvador.

title: PAOLO MONELLI
description: Paolo Monelli, for half a century one of Italy's most distinguished journalists and noted writers, died today at the age of 93 after a long illness, hospital sources said.

title: OPERA:NEW CHAMBER GROUP IN AN AMERICAN DOUBLE BILL
description: ANOTHER small opera company has surfaced in New York - the American Chamber Opera, which has just ended a four-performance run of an American double bill. The company is stationed in a small theater at St. Michael's Church on West 99th Street, and Sunday's performances of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Telephone'' and ''Hello Out There'' by Jack Beeson featured modest production values, some shaky orchestra playing and singing which was usually healthy but sometimes misdirected.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: VETA GRANDE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,775,000 for the quarter and $6,031,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $246,000 for the quarter and $918,000 for the 9 months.

title: Boy, 8, Found Hanged After Theft Accusation
description: An 8-year-old boy, said to be depressed over accusations that he stole $4 at school, was on a hospital life support system today after being found hanging by his belt from his bunk bed, police officials said.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARMY LIKELY FOR CHERRY BOWL
description: Army is expected to accept a bid to play in the new Cherry Bowl, the first bowl appearance ever for the Cadets.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DIRE RUMORS ABOUT MARCO'S HEALTH ARE DENIED
description: A Government spokesman said tonight that President Ferdinand E. Marcos was ''well and continues to perform his duties.''

title: UNITED BANK CALIFORNIA SSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Family Portrait
description: Guggenheims filled the Guggenheim.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $146,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations and extraordinary credits of $553,000 for the quarter and $1,163,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $1,134,000 for the quarter and $2,861,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary credit of $153,000 for the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago results have been restated to exclude discontinued operations and to reflect the fourth quarter 1983 retroactive reversal of equity in the extraordinary credit of an affiliate relating to a tax credit generated prior to acquisition.

title: ARGENTINE POLITICS MUST COOL DOWN
description: After nearly one year in office, President Raul Alfonsin's personal mystique remains. But the legacy of government by threat and violence also remains. Unless more-rational methods of problem-solving are adopted, this legacy may shatter the fragile democracy.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
