description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $366,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $553,000 for the quarter and $2,296,000 for the 6 months. d-After income from discontinued operations of $1,137,000.

title: Helene Curtis Sees Loss; Stock Falls
description: Helene Curtis Industries said that despite record sales it expects to report a ''significant loss'' for the third quarter, ending Nov. 30, and reduced profits for the year. It attributed the expected loss to ''unprecedented competition'' in the beauty and hair care products industry.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.75-12.00 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S.-Nicaragua Talks Held
description: American and Nicaraguan negotiators began a fresh round of talks in Mexico today on settling policy differences.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Dollar Dry Dock Appoints Chairman
description: The Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank announced yesterday that Robert H. Steele, the bank's current president, had been named chairman and chief executive officer.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Warriors, making their only stop at the Garden this season, come in with Purvis Short, one of the National Basketball Association's hottest shooters.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: SAXTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Gentle Corporation
description: In a ceremony yesterday at the Columbia Law School's Proskauer Auditorium, the university's

title: STRATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ACTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of properties of $568,000 for the quarter and $1,914,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income including a gain of $2,350,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of properties.

title: Avoiding Perils Of Turning Pro
description: At its new home at the Doral Country Club in Miami, the Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament will again be the stage for a series of seminars for parents and coaches who are managing - or mismanaging - the athletic careers of teen-agers. ''We want to see that tennis creates well-rounded, healthy, sane people, not misfits,'' said Arthur Ashe, the tournament's honorary chairman and an adviser to Head Racquet Sports, sponsor of the Easter Bowl.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICATION NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2.5 million. c-Net income includes income from discontinued operations of $4.1 million and a tax credit of $9.1 million.

title: Advertising; National Mattress Campaign
description: ''CABLE television will be a perfect bed for continuous advertising,'' said Robert Bloom, chairman of the Bloom Companies of Dallas.

title: REAGAN ORDERS AN END TO AIR TRAVEL INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department said today that it had closed, at the direction of President Reagan, a criminal antitrust investigation into passenger air travel that has soured relations between the United States and Britain.

title: DORIS C. SCHUSTER
description: Doris C. Schuster, former member of the Stamford (Conn.) Board of Education and former president of the Stamford Council of Catholic Women, died Sunday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in South Bend, Ind.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE VOTES SMOKING RESTRICTIONS
description: Six bills that would regulate smoking in most public areas in New Jersey were released today by the Assembly Judiciary Committee.

title: MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS CAUSING CONCERN IN KEY WEST
description: The rate of multiple sclerosis in Key West is ''as high as anywhere in North America,'' according to a leading Government expert in the disease. A study by a University of Miami scientist found 23 cases of multiple sclerosis among the 30,000 longtime residents of this island resort. The Government expert, Dr. David Poskanzer, a research scientist with the National Institute of Health, said that rate had unheard of for a subtropical latitude. ''The geographical distribution is the thing that is so consistent about MS, and it is a disease of the northern latitudes,'' said Dr. Poskanzer. According to Dr. Poskanzer, a comparable rate for northern New England would be 80 cases per 100,000, dropping to 40 per 100,00 in the Boston area. The rate declines rapidly as one moves toward the equator, he explained.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD'S NET UP 13.6% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, one of the leading manufacturers of electronic test and measurement equipment, reported yesterday that earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter of 1984 rose 13.6 percent, on a sales gain of 27.1 percent.

title: DANCE:'THE WATCHERS,' A WORK WITH VIDEO
description: VIDEO is popular in the dance world these days, as sheer gadgetry, an extra mirror or choreographic tool. Used as an artistic device, it often ends up being a distraction that doesn't reveal or extend the dance. But in ''The Watchers (Made for TV),'' a new work commissioned by Dance Theater Workshop and performed on Friday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater, Lisa Kraus has created a mutually dependent process that offered not just interesting video and dance but provocative speculation on the nature and perception of reality.

title: 'STARFEVER': STAGING A DOCUMENTARY
description: LOS ANGELESAn intriguing new television venture that blurs the line between fact and fiction - a documentary about rock music called ''Starfever,'' - recently wound up production in Los Angeles in preparation for a March air date on NBC-TV.

title: CHALONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: 16.3% INCREASE IN RATED SOUGHT IN NEW YORK TELEPHONE PROPOSAL
description: Long-distance customers in Minne- sota may get to defer some payments to A.T.&T. but pay interest. Page D9.

title: 'DYNASTY' AT BLOOMINDALE'S
description: They called it D-day, and it was an invasion of sorts. Thousands of fans of ''Dynasty'' poured into Bloomingdale's when the doors opened Sunday, screaming and shouting and hoping for a glimpse of Linda Evans and six other stars of the television series about a wealthy Denver family.

title: 2 EX-IRISH RUSHERS TURN IN BIG GAMES
description: The Buffalo Bills won for the first time this season Sunday, and the Houston Oilers for the second. There's a coincidence: Each team was powered by a running back from Notre Dame.

title: Bored Police Arrest Chicken
description: Things were so slow at the local police station last week that when a motorist complained that there was a chicken in his parked car, the police arrested the bird.

title:
TV SPORTS ;
FOR TWO NETWORKS, PRIDE TAKES A FALL
description: Both ABC and CBS take pride in the reportorial side of their college football pre-game shows, but on Saturday both shows skimmed over one of the weekend's major stories, and ABC reported a story that turned out to be wrong.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONTMARTE MURDERS: A NEIGHBORHOOD CHANGES
description: The killings started with that of Anna Barbier, an 83-year-old woman whose body, bound and gagged, was found Oct. 5 in her apartment at 10 Rue Saulnier in the shadow of the Basilica of Sacre-Coeur in the Montmartre district of Paris.

title: EUROPE LAGS BEHIND
description: BRUSSELS The dialogue between America

title: RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BAD RAPS; Shredded Hopes
description: Is there an adult who doesn't know what it is to arrive at the theater without the tickets? To dine at a restaurant where it is announced, as the bill is proffered, that it doesn't accept credit cards? To leave a briefcase on a subway seat?

title: Anta to Sell Unit
description: The Anta Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Nichols-Homeshield Inc. subsidiary for more than $30 million to a group of private Dallas investors. Anta, which is based in Oklahoma City, said the sale is expected to be completed within 60 days. Nichols-Homeshield, a manufacturer of aluminum products, is one of two units still owned by Anta, which is liquidating and disposing of its assets.

title: British and Irish Chiefs Discuss Ulster's Future
description: The Irish and British Prime Ministers met today for a long-awaited conference on the future of Northern Ireland. They emerged with no dramatic initiatives, but did agree to work toward finding some political framework acceptable to the province's Roman Catholic nationalist minority as well as its Protestant loyalist majority.

title: Subdued Ceremony
description: The director of public relations for the Los Angeles Lakers has sent a message to other teams in the National Basketball Association, urging modest retirement ceremonies for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. The reason? The 37-year-old center could reconsider his decision to make this season his last. ''I would hate for Kareem to decide next summer he wanted to play and feel embarrassed to come back because he had been given gifts,'' said Josh Rosenfeld , the publicity man.

title: THEATER:'BLACK RIVER,' BY SAMM-ART WILLIAMS
description: -ART WILLIAMS'S ''Welcome to Black River,'' which has been revived at the New Federal Theater, is a fatalistic family drama of epic ambitions that sadly fails to deliver the punches it sets up. Detailing the psychological struggles among two rural North Carolina families - one black, one white - at the dawn of the civil- rights era, the play wants to carry race relations and miscegenation to the level of Greek tragedy. And each of its eight characters is given Eugene O'Neill-like passages of stumbling poetic eloquence. But tragedy never arrives. After building for two- and-a-half hours to a cathartic purge, ''Welcome to Black River'' disintegrates with a limp, sitcom ending, in which the characters hug each other and call off the family curse.

title: EFFICIENT SOFTWARE FOR PROOF READING

Use it for a while, discover its idiosyncrasies, unearth its bugs, if any, and only then consider applying it to the real world. That's my motto. So why, at the tail end of turning out a book, did I suddenly decide to try out PFS:Proof on the manuscript?

title: BAD RAPS; THE LADY IS A VAMP The female praying mantis has the kind of reputation that amuses women and confirms men's worst fears. Three centuries of scientific literature, all anecdotal, have had her biting off the head of an amorous male, thus triggering some rather satisfactory automatic reflexes on his part. Having had her fill of pleasure, the story went, she then had her fill of him, as dinner. A neurophysiologist named W. Jackson Davis says, however, that the female praying mantis is actually no more lethal than a saucy wench. Mr. Davis, according to The Washington Post, put 30 pairs of males and females in laboratory cages, trained video cameras on them and waited for the decapitations. Instead, a frame-by-frame analysis revealed a courtship ritual that is, he said, ''a lovely thing to see.'' Some females, in fact, encouraged their suitors by what in another species would be called knee-tickling.
description: Thus Mr. Davis destroys one more stereotype of the deadly female. Now let him turn his cameras on the Queen Bee.

title: STOP SENDING AMBASSADOLTS ABROAD
description: Long ago, the Venetian Ambassador to Rome, en route to his post, was staying overnight with the Grand Duke of Tuscany. The Duke complained of the poor quality of the envoy the Republic of Venice had sent to his court. ''I am not surprised,'' was the Venetian's reply. ''We have many fools in Venice.'' To which the Duke retorted, ''We also have fools in Florence, but we take care not to export them.''

title: How to Spend a State Surplus ; Is a Tax Cut New York's Highest Priority?
description: New York State has the stimulating challenge of deciding how to spend a modest budget surplus of about $800 million a year. If the rush to reduce income taxes were the best way to spend that sum, the plan that Governor Cuomo arranged to have proposed to him last week seems to be a sound approach. But if the Governor has been dragged to a tax cut screaming and kicking, as Republican legislators contend, it would be useful if he struggled just long enough to let the citizenry debate the prior question: given the state's annual spring debt, and urgent public needs in education and the care of the homeless, what's the best way to spend the money?

The move was announced by Barbara Uehling , the university's chancellor, who said that ''the lack of public support'' had precipitated the dismissal of Powers after a 46-33-3 record in his seven years at the helm.

title: 8 Who Write Children's Books Protest Ban on Blume Works
description: Eight prize-winning writers of children's books have appealed to the Board of Education in Peoria, Ill., to restore to the bookshelves three novels by Judy Blume that were banned early this month from the school district's libraries on the grounds of sexual content or strong language.

title: PANEL CALLS FOR SPENDING TO STRENGTHEN RUTGERS
description: A panel of corporate, educational and civic leaders called today for higher state and private spending, as well as a tuition increase, to bring Rutgers University into the ''first rank'' of public state universities.

Morton Thiokol To Acquire Bee
description: Morton Thiokol Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Bee Chemical, a maker of automotive plastic coatings, for $77 million.

title: There Sits a State Terrorist
description: Colonel Qaddafi of Libya has taught us a good deal in his bungled attempt to reach into Egypt to kill a political opponent. The going rate for murder among British and Maltese contractors is $250,000, plus $150,000 to the Egyptian locals for dirty work. The fee is payable on receipt, at the Libyan Embassy in Malta, of a clear snapshot of the dead victim. That evidence then becomes the basis for broadcast boasts that patriotic ''suicide squads'' have eliminated yet another infidel or Zionist tool.

title: OFFICE AND ABORTION CLINIC DAMAGED
description: Two bombs that exploded early this morning destroyed an abortion clinic and caused substantial damage to a family planning center in this suburb of Washington.

title: JACKSON KEEPING HIS OPTIONS OPEN AS DEMOCRATS DISCUSS HIS FUTURE ROLE
description: In the aftermath of a Presidential campaign on which the Rev. Jesse Jackson left an indelible mark, he shows little inclination to settle on any one pursuit.

title: Replacing Kirkpatrick
description: Ranking Reagan Administration officials have begun to discuss who might replace Jeane J. Kirkpatrick as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations. Mrs. Kirkpatrick has indicated she does not want to remain at the United Nations after January.

title: Weinberger Is to Stay, Aide to Reagan Says
description: President Reagan has asked Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to keep his job in Mr. Reagan's second term and Mr. Weinberger has accepted, a White House official said today.

title: Clay Is Chosen For Cup Final
description: The Swedish Davis Cup Committee said today that the Davis Cup final, to be held Dec. 16-18 in Goteborg against the United States, would be played on clay, the Swedes' favorite tennis surface.

title: HOUSE CANDIDATE LOST RACE AND JOB
description: The Democratic candidate for Congress in the Second District, who was overwhelmingly defeated this month, now finds himself without a job and is preparing to file for unemployment compensation.

title: Y.&R. Group Chooses Klein to Be President
description: Young & Rubicam, the largest American ad agency, has promoted Arthur R. Klein, 47 years old, to president of its Y.&R. Direct Marketing Group, made up of three agencies.

title: And Also Connecticut's?
description: Tax-cut fever has also seized Connecticut. The Republicans, controlling the Legislature for the first time in 10 years, have already declared for reducing sales taxes and a few others.

title: Food Lion in Bid
description: Food Lion Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Giant Food Markets Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Giant operates 25 supermarkets and 23 convience stores in eastern Tennessee and has annual sales of about $130 million. Food Lion, which operates a chain of 248 supermarkets in North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, Georgia, Tennessee and Maryland, said the transaction is scheduled for completion on Dec. 31.

title: A DEADLY BATTLE BETWEEN MEDICINE AND THE POWER OF THE BODY
description: LOMA LINDA, CALIF. THE Baby Fae case was in a very real sense mortal combat between the art of medicine and the still only partially understood devastation of the rejection phenomenon.

title: Columbia Sued on Ghost
description: The company that created Casper the Friendly Ghost filed a $52 million lawsuit Friday against the makers of the movie ''Ghostbusters'' on the grounds that the movie's logo was stolen from their cartoon. Harvey Famous Cartoons claims that Columbia Pictures Industries used a character from ''The Ghostly Trio'' - who were friends of the cartoon Casper - in their advertising and promotional campaign for the film.

title: Poles Warn Reporters On Watchdog Groups
description: The Polish Foreign Ministry warned Western reporters today that they risked prosecution if they attended news conferences given by illegal civic watchdog groups that have been set up to monitor police brutality.

title: PORNOGRAPHY BAN IN INDIANA IS UPSET AS UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: A city ordinance outlawing pornography on the ground that it is a form of sexual discrimination was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal district judge.

title: Tokyo Still Feeling Loss of Phones
description: While hundreds of thousands of Tokyo residents were still making do with temporary outdoor telephones, some banks and post offices had their computer services restored today after a fire put them out of operation Friday.

description: ''You cannot make a policy case for taking a worthwhile program and spending less on it.

description: Thirteen days after the election, Oren J. Teicher conceded victory today to Joseph J. DioGuardi in their race for the 20th Congressional District seat in Westchester County.

title: Professor Ferenc A. Vali, 79; Taught in Hungary and U.S.
description: Ferenc A. Vali, who taught government and international relations in his native Budapest and at the University of Massachusetts, died of cancer yesterday at Hampshire County Hospital in Leeds, Mass. He was 79 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass., and Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Baxter Labs Plans $116 Million Charge
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it would report an estimated $116 million special after- tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings as part of a series of ''strategic measures'' to reposition the company. The charge will reflect the cost of the consolidation of the company's worldwide operations and the revaluation of assets.

title: MELANSON TRADED TO NORTH STARS
description: Rollie Melanson reported to practice early this morning, was told he'd been traded to Minnesota for a first- round draft pick, and within minutes was on the ice at Cantiague Park for his final skate with the Islanders, his former teammates.

description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that Alfred S. Crimmins had been promoted to president.

title: Jonathan Schwartz Interprets Standards
description: The gift of gab, which makes Jonathan Schwartz the most interesting disk jockey in New York, extends to his singing style. Whether talking or singing, Mr. Schwartz, who is playing an extended engagement at Michael's Pub, through Dec. 8, loves to tell stories.

title: Rail Collision in South Africa
description: More than 130 people were injured today when two trains collided in a suburb of Cape Town. Witnesses said that one of the trains was traveling to a black township and the other to mixed- race residential areas.

title: ETHIOPIA REBELS SEIZE KEY RELIEF CENTER
description: Secessionist rebels have seized a major famine relief center, resulting in a cutoff of food supplies for thousands of drought victims, according to sources connected with the relief effort.

title: GANDHI TELLS CHEERING CROWD BULLETS WILL NOT SHAKE INDIA
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, speaking on the 67th anniversary of his mother's birth, told tens of thousands of his cheering countrymen here today that India in recent days had shown the world that ''this country is not shaken by bullets'' and that it ''cannot break so easily.''

description: A Salvadoran Army officer accused of plotting the 1981 slayings of the head of the country's land-redistribution program and two United States labor advisers has been cleared by the Salvadoran Supreme Court, according to a ruling released today.

description: Indonesia had a trade surplus of $720 million in August with exports of $1.82 billion and imports of $1.1 billion, the Government said today. The August 1983 surplus was $950 million.

description: Fire broke out aboard a military helicopter as it lifted a piece of artillery in a training mission today, killing three Marines, injuring at least 11 others and leaving three missing, officials said.

description: Shrinking audiences and too many inferior movies have depressed profits for China's state-run film industry, China's Economic Daily said today. Theaters sold 2 billion fewer tickets last year than they did in 1980.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: MATISSE. By Pierre Schneider. Translated From the French by Michael Taylor and Bridget Strevens Romer. 752 pages. Illustrated. Rizzoli. $95. PIERRE SCHNEIDER'S ''Matisse'' is one of the most ambitious monographs on a modern artist. It is 752 pages long, 14 years in the making, and it sets out to throw fresh light not only on every aspect of Henri Matisse's work, but on many of the artistic developments around him.

title: SHORTS SET TREND IN RESORT DRESSING
description: Shorts surfaced during the resort collections in New York as a comfortable, easy way of dressing for leisure hours in warm climates. A few months later, when the spring openings began, what had been a tentative move by designers developed into a worldwide trend. Starting with the first spring shows in Milan, continuing through the London and Paris presentations, and reaching its peak at the New York shows, the fashion for shorts is gaining momentum.

description: Four more people have been named to the Art Directors Hall of Fame: Wallace Elton, a former officer and director of J. Walter Thompson, who was a founder of the International Executive Service Corps; Sam Scali, vice chairman and creative director of Scali, McCabe, Sloves; Louis Silverstein, corporate art director of The New York Times and an assistant managing editor, and the late Charles Eames, architect and designer.

title: House-Hunting
description: Emboldened by his success in winning a Senate seat, Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and his wife, Sharon, are already hunting for housing in the Washington area. Congressional sources say they are concentrating on the $1.5 million to $2 million price bracket, which should simplify the problem considerably. Moving into the Georgetown home of Senator Charles H. Percy, Mrs. Rockefeller's father, does not seem to be an option, for the Senator's friends expect that he and his wife will remain in Washington, despite his defeat for a fourth term by Illinois voters two weeks ago.

title: Lakers 130, Suns 108
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 29 points and had 10 assists to pace Los Angeles. The Lakers (8-5) shot a season-high 67.8 percent from the field and moved into a first-place tie with Phoenix in the Pacific Division. The Lakers' Byron Scott scored 21 points and had nine assists, and Jamaal Wilkes scored 14 for the Lakers, who outrebounded the Suns, 47-24.

description: Wien Airlines must keep flying at least until Friday despite the struggling airline's desire to shut down for 25 days, a Federal judge ruled.

description: Ben Wilson, rated one of the top prep basketball prospects in the nation, was shot and critically wounded today a block from Simeon High, the South Side school that he attends.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL TROUPE PERFORMS TO GERSHWIN
description: GEORGE GERSHWIN was not a ballet composer. Nevertheless, dancers love his music. One can understand why after seeing Festival Dance Theater, a new chamber-ballet troupe directed by George Daugherty and Charla Genn, in ''Gershwin! A Celebration of Music and Dance'' on Monday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. This evening of ballets to Gershwin emphasized the music's rhythmic verve. Gershwin wrote music that moves. In fact, it moves beautifully.

description: John Reed, veteran actor with the former D'Oyly Carte Opera Company of England, will appear in the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players' production of ''The Gondoliers'' on Dec. 28 at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Mr. Reed, who was principal comic baritone with the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company for some 25 years before its demise in 1982, will be featured in the role of the Duke of Plaza Toro. The production opens the company's 11th season and will run through Jan. 6.

title: Herman Wouk's Mother Dies
description: Esther Wouk, the mother of Herman Wouk, the Pulitzer P?ize-winning author, died in her sleep Sunday at her Manhattan apartment. She was 95 years old. Mrs. Wouk, who devoted most of her energies to volunteer work for Jewish organizations, immigrated from Russia as a child. Her husband, Abraham, died in 1942.

description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has dropped disciplinary action against one of six middle-level C.I.A. employees said to have been punished over production of a manual for Nicaraguan rebels, intelligence officials said Tuesday.

title: I.B.M. SET TO SELL A ROLM UNIT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday agreed to sell the military computer division of the Rolm Corporation within six months, in order to get Federal approval to acquire the rest of the company. The agreement came in a consent decree with the Justice Department.

title: MOTHER JOSEPHINE

title: SCREEN: DE NIRO, STREEP STAR IN 'FALLING IN LOVE'

title: CBS TO BUY 12 OF ZIFF'S MAGAZINES
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the 12 consumer magazines of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company for $362.5 million, believed to be the highest price ever paid for a group of magazines.

title: MARGARINE CHOICES: A GUIDE FOR CONSUMERS
description: T HE proliferation of margarine brands and types, which began in the mid-1970's with the introduction of margarine ''spreads,'' has reached the point where a shopper faces an almost overwhelming choice: there is hard margarine in sticks, soft margarine in tubs or liquid margarine in bottles; margarine with or without salt and reduced in calories; margarine made from corn, soybean, safflower, cottonseed or sunflower oil. The newest variation is a blend that contains a surprise ingredient - butter.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1984 The Economy
description: G.N.P. growth slumped to a 1.9 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the lowest level since the recovery began in late 1982. The rate was well below the 2.7 percent growth estimated by the Commerce Department a month ago, and gave support to the view that the economy may be growing so little that unemployment will rise. The Commerce Department also said after-tax corporate profits fell 7.3 percent from the second quarter. (Page A1.)

title: U.S. Will Not Supply Honduras With F-5's
description: The United States plans to deny a request from Honduras for F-5 fighter planes, a State Department spokesman said today.

description: The New York City Board of Elections has fewer inventory and management controls than an ''ordinary grocery store,'' Mayor Koch's Investigations Commissioner charged yesterday.

title: Chicago and Cicero Sued In Siege of Black Family
description: A black family forced out of an all-white neighborhood by a group that threw bricks through the windows of their apartment has filed a $1 million civil rights suit charging that the police in Chicago and neighboring Cicero failed to come to their aid.

title: TROOPS PATROL DEVASTATED SUBURB

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

But on Thanksgiving Day, after an early-afternoon repast, Jack Gasnick will leave his home in Forest Hills and begin his annual holiday hike to Fresh Meadows, Queens, there to visit his oak tree and spread cheer and blessings among its occupants.

title: THE HOLIDAY SEASON: A LOOK BENEATH THE SURFACE
description: Richard Brown, a hard-nosed parking garage owner, decided that he was going to be charitable this Thanksgiving - and he didn't care who tried to stop him.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Crocker Chairman Resigns His Post

Mr. Place began to lose his influence early this year, when Midland Bank P.L.C., the owner of 57 percent of Crocker, began exerting more direct operational control.

title: Starting From Scratch

St. Peter's suspended football in September, after the team had lost its opening game by 72-0 and officials had discovered that 4 of the 29 players were ineligible. ''The goal,'' Gilrain said, ''will be to increase the number of kids in the football program and have them better at the end of the year.''

title: THERE'S JUST NO ESCAPE: IT'S TIME TO ROAST THAT - - - - - -
description: BENJAMIN FRANKLIN deplored the choice of the bald eagle as ''the representative of our country.'' He preferred the turkey, ''a much more respectable bird, withal a true original native of America.'' Today it seems a downright blessing that, at least as far as Thanksgiving is concerned, the noble turkey was spared such an august honor. Who would be profane enough to stuff the national bird with sausage or oysters or chestnuts, roast it to a turn and carve away?

SORTING OUT FATS AND CHOLESTEROL
description: ALTHOUGH most people still call it butter when they ask that it be passed, in three households out of four the spread people use is actually margarine. Health concerns have been one of the main motivations behind the tremendous switch from butter to margarine among Americans since the 1950's. Yet confusion regarding margarine's health benefits is still widespread, fostered by contentions in some scientific quarters that the role of fats and cholesterol (butter has considerably more of both than margarine) in heart disease has been overemphasized and that the methods used to make margarine negate some of its potential benefits to the heart and create possible cancer hazards.

Erlenborn, who retired this year after 10 terms in the House of Representatives. In the outgoing Congress, he was ranking Republican on the House Education and Labor Committee.

title: WITH THE HOLIDAY BIRD, VARIETY OF WINES
description: ASK a New Yorker what he or she will be eating on Thanksgiving and the answer is hardly surprising: It starts with turkey, or perhaps ham, and proceeds to a variety of regional trimmings, most of them familiar. But ask the same New Yorkers what wines they have chosen to accompany those dishes and you will get a lot of different answers.

title: TAX CHANGES THAT WOULD HURT NEW YORK
description: Congress is about to embark on a major attempt at tax simplification. The principal thrust of the various proposals, including one that is to come from the Administration, is to lower tax rates by cutting back the tangle of deducDaniel Patrick Moynihan, Democratic Senator of New York, is a member of the Finance Committee. tions, credits and different treatment for different kinds of income that has grown up in the current code. That this needs doing, there is no doubt. But if the present deduction for state and local taxes were to be eliminated or sharply reduced, the effect on New York State would be devastating. It is no news that taxes are high in New York, especially in the city. It may not be generally realized, however, just how high our taxes are, and how precarious our state's tax system is. No other state comes close to matching New York's combination of an enormous state and local tax burden - income, property and sales taxes - resting on a surprisingly and increasingly narrow tax base.

title: TRUCKERS SUCCUMB TO A COLOGNE STOP
description: Jim Hawkins, a trucker from Reno, extended his right index finger, sprayed a dainty mist of cologne on it, and gave a contemplative sniff as a small crowd at the Truckstops of America off Interstate 30 looked on warily. ''Don't smell too bad,'' he said, flaring his nostrils like a wine connoisseur. ''I think it must have some musk in it or something. I wish my wife was here. She could tell you what's in it in a damn split second.''

title: The Green Party Drops Backing for a Cabinet
description: The Green Party withdrew its support for the minority Social Democratic cabinet in Hesse today to protest a decision permitting the expansion of a plutonium-enrichment plant.

title: SYNANON RULINGS IN CALIFORNIA BACK REPORTERS
description: In a decision expanding the rights of reporters who face civil libel suits in California, the State Supreme Court ruled Monday for the first time that journalists could sometimes withhold confidential sources and unpublished information supplied by such sources.

title: Cowboy Promoted
description: Danny White has been named the starting quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys in their game against the New England Patriots tomorrow, a move that Coach Tom Landry said was designed to ''spark us up'' after the team's 14-3 loss to the Buffalo Bills. The elevation of White and the demotion of Gary Hogeboom - the second such for each this season - will be cccompanied by a couple of other changes: Timmy Newsome replaces Ron Springs at fullback, and Doug Donley has recaptured the flanker position from Mike Renfro.

title: Dantley Sidelined
description: Adrian Dantley , the scoring champion from the Utah Jazz, may have broken his little toe, the club said. Dantley was sidelined for last night's game against the Kansas City Kings and will likely sit out tonight's game against Atlanta. He could be out longer, depending on the results of a bone scan he is to have Wednesday in Salt Lake City.

title: Joiner Is Ready For Record Book

The 37-year-old receiver for the San Diego Chargers this season has 49 catches (for 629 yards and 5 touchdowns), lifting his career total to 645, 4 short of the record held by Charley Taylor of Washington.

title: NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERA: 'WILLIAM TELL,' UNDER QUELER
description: IF you know anything at all about Rossini's ''William Tell,'' you know that at some point Tell shoots an apple off his son's head, that the Lone Ranger appropriated part of the overture as his theme music and that it has a reputation for extraordinary length. What you also should know is that ''Tell'' is an impressive work, difficult to cast but full of noble music that suffers only in comparison with Rossini's greatest comic masterpieces. The work, once wildly popular, dropped out of favor around the end of the 19th century, but when properly performed it can still stir an audience. That was loudly apparent in last night's concert version at Carnegie Hall by Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York.

title: Spacecraft Returned In Best Condition Yet
description: The space shuttle Discovery returned to the earth from its satellite rescue mission in better shape than any shuttle did on a previous mission and should be ready to ferry a secret military satellite into orbit in January, officials said today.

A P.S.A.L. First
description: Tzu Ling Moy , a 15-year-old sophomore at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, won the Public Schools Athletic League individual fencing title yesterday in competition with boys. She became the first girl to win a P.S.A.L. title against boys. P.S.A.L. fencing is only with the foil; there is no epee and saber competition, Miss Moy, who began fencing two years ago, won the Manhattan-Bronx Division crown on Monday. Yesterday, competing as the only girl against eight boys, she finished a round robin with a 7-1 record, tying with a Stuyvesant teammate, Jordan Foster .

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1984 International Moscow has proposed to Washington that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko set an early date for a meeting to discuss arms control and other issues, Reagan Administration officials said. But they stressed that the date, place and agenda had to be worked out. (Page A1, Column 1.) Konstantin U. Chernenko's portrait and pronouncements are a fixture on Soviet billboards, in the speeches of his colleagues and in the press nine months after he became the Soviet leader. title: Soviet Grain Purchases

They did not ask for permission to buy any more than that in the coming 10 months.

title: Rolm-I.B.M. Link
description: Shareholders of the Rolm Corporation approved an approximately $1.25 billion acquisition bid from the International Business Machines Corporation. The shareholder vote, which took place at the company's annual meeting, clears the way for I.B.M. to complete its buyout of Rolm, a leading maker of telephone switching equipment. I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, already owns 23 percent of Rolm. I.B.M. said on Tuesday that it had obtained Justice Department antitrust clearance for the buyout on the condition that it divest itself of Rolm's military-computer division.

title: OPERA: 'WILLIAM TELL,' UNDER QUELER
description: For much of his career as a composer and conductor, Gunther Schuller has shown a deep fascination with music written for competing or interacting instrumental ensembles. The idea did not originate with him, certainly. The Baroque concerto grosso was based on a confrontation of a solo group and the full orchestra. Mozart makes four separate bands play simultaneously at one point in ''Don Giovanni.'' Bartok employed opposing instrumental groups in his ''Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta.'' More recently, the device came back into vogue with the avant-garde in the late 1950's with such works as Stockhausen's ''Gruppen.''

Bozik, wanting to ''put to rest all speculation and discussion,'' said that the university remained committed to Fazio despite the record, the team's worst since a 1-10 season in 1972. The athletic director's statement, in which he called the coach a man of ''compassion, warmth, integrity and loyalty,'' came three days before the Panthers end their season, at Penn State, and three weeks after Bozik had prompted much of the speculation by declining at a news conference to give Fazio a vote of confidence.

With considerable care and craft, it sets out complex family problems - parental repression, old age, alcoholism and an unhappy marriage - and then happily if unconvincingly resolves them.

description: A demoted supervisor in a city social services agency said yesterday that city officials had made her and another supervisor ''scapegoats'' for the death of an elderly woman who was shot by the police in an eviction dispute last month.

title: GEORGE BARRETT OF THE TIMES, CITED FOR WAR COVERAGE, DIES
description: George Barrett, a reporter, a war correspondent and an assistant metropolitan editor during a 43-year career at The New York Times, died of Parkinson's disease Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giving Thanks, and Food
description: What does it mean to celebrate food in America while African children starve before our eyes on television?

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from San Salvador on Tuesday about a court action clearing an officer in the slayings of a Salvadoran land program official and two United States labor advisers misstated the date of the killings. It was Jan. 3, 1981.

title: MITTERRAND CONTRADICTED BY FRENCH INTELLIGENCE ON TROOPS IN CHAD
description: A French intelligence report, agreeing with estimates by the United States State Deparment, today contradicted President Francois Mitterrand's assessments of Libyan troop strength in Chad and deepened his political difficulties.

title: AREA'S PRICE INDEX OFF 0.1%
description: Led by sharp declines in the cost of natural gas and electricity, prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area edged down slightly in October, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BAY PACIFIC HEALTH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPLAINT BY C.I.A. OVER REPORT ON TV
description: The Central Intelligence Agency complained to the Federal Communications Commission today about an ABC News report, broadcast in September, alleging that the agency planned to assassinate a Honolulu man.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline on the Style page Tuesday with an article about fashion misidentified the season for which the clothes were designed. The shorts were all from collections for spring.

title: UNWELCOME WINTER GUESTS: RODENTS
description: WHILE the birds, squirrels and rabbits may add to the charm of warm- weather living, other types of wildlife assuredly do not. That is especially true when the weather gets colder and the family wants to spend time indoors - and so do the mice and the rats.

title: PULITZER PRIZES IN JOURNALISM ARE EXPANDED
description: The Pulitzer Prize Board has established two new categories in journalism - explanatory journalism and specialized journalism - and has revised the definitions of two existing categories for the prizes that will be given in the spring.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $112,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $308,000 for the quarter and $483,000 for the 6 months. The share earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend paid in October 1984.

title: A HOMECOMING FOR BERNSTEIN
description: Leonard Bernstein, who left Boston and its famed Boston Latin School to become a boy wonder and then a doyen of American music, came home tonight to be honored by his alma mater. It was an emotional occasion, and standing before those who were among the first to see and hear his musical talent, his usual polish deserted him.

title: LONG VIEW OF A SMALL, COMBUSTIBLE PLANET
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons of the Bumpurs Case
description: New York City's official reports on the killing of Eleanor Bumpurs during an eviction proceeding confess multiple errors of judgment and procedure. But it was the final error that resulted in the death of the disturbed 66-year-old woman - a grave error of police procedure and judgment.

title: Massachusetts Tightens Rules Governing Taverns
description: Regulations approved today as part of a campaign against drunken driving will soon ban happy hours and beer-drinking contests in Massachusetts bars.

title: Utah Power Halts $700 Million Plant
description: The Utah Power and Light Company said it had canceled plans for a $700 million power plant in Castle Dale, Utah, and as a result, it estimates a write-off in 1985 of about $60 million. Utah Power said it plans to seek regulatory permission to recover the money spent on the Hunter No. 4 power plant on an amortized basis over a five-year period.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI, IN THOMSON SCORE
description: Far and away the highlight of the season's first Philharmonia Virtuosi concert Tuesday night at the refurbished Town Hall was Virgil Thomson's music for ''The Plow That Broke the Plains'' - heard not in the relatively familiar, condensed concert suite but in the actual score that accompanied Pare Lorentz's film of 1936.

title: And Now the Recount
description: How quickly the bloom has faded from the Administration's rosy economic forecasts. It's barely two weeks since Election Day and two vital statistics have had to be radically revised. The deficit will be much larger than advertised and economic growth will be much slower. The public deserves one more surprise - some sign that the Administration recognizes the problem thus created.

title: UNION SUES CALIFORNIA ON SEX DISCRIMINATION
description: A union filed suit against California today charging sex discrimination in the salaries of 37,000 female state employees in jobs commonly held by women, such as clerks, nurses and librarians.

title: TEST DRUG MAY FIGHT PREMENSTRUAL DISORDER
description: An experimental drug treatment that relieves the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome has been reported by doctors at the University of California at San Diego.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25

POINTS OF VIEW Of a WallOn a visit to China, Senator Jake Garn inspected the Great Wall and told his pleased hosts he looked forward to seeing it again from the space shuttle next year. Finally proving whether this is possible may be the only value of the Senator's far- fetched junket. Somehow it has become a chestnut of the space age that the Great Wall, stretching 3,750 miles, is the only man-made structure visible from space, even from the moon. The claim pops up, irrepressibly. Even this column once reported it as fact.
description: But subsequent inquiry revealed that no astronaut ever saw the wall from the moon. Buzz Aldrin ascribes the tale's origin to the pilots of Gemini flights, much closer to earth.

title: Texas Stadium May Be Covered
description: The Dallas Cowboys may cap the two- and-a-half-acre hole in the roof of Texas Stadium as part of an overall plan of stadium improvement, according to Tex Schramm, the team's president.

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $30,000 for the quarter and $47,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: A.O. Smith To Drop Units The A.O. Smith Company
description: said it was withdrawing from

title: Ray Knight Has Surgery Ray Knight of the Mets underwent arthroscopic surgery Tuesday to
description: repair a chronic inflammation in his right shoulder. He reported yesterday that he expected to report on time for spring training and to resume

title: U.S. Seeks To Block Deal WASHINGTON, Nov. 21
description: The Justice Department said today that it intends

title: Parents Found for Boy Lacking Most of Brain
description: Adoptive parents have been found for a 4-month-old boy born with a rare birth defect that left him lacking most of his brain.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $32,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $226,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $150,000 for the quarter and $1,200,000 for the year.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS ITS LOAN RATE TO 8 1/2% FROM 9%
description: The Federal Reserve approved a half- point cut today in its basic charge on loans to commercial banks and other financial institutions. The new rate is 8 1/2 percent.

title: 4 People Killed In Head-On Crash
description: Four people, including two 4-year-old girls, were killed when a speeding car passed two vehicles and crashed head on into a pickup truck here today, the state police said.

title: LaBarge Unit Sale
description: LaBarge Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Tubular Products division to a division management group for $16 million to $18 million, including nearly $8.3 million in cash and the remainder in notes and preferred stock. LaBarge, which also has interests in electronics and furniture, said it expected to complete the deal by year-end. The company said the division being sold had revenues of $45 million in 1983 out of total company revenues of $129 million.

title: U.S. Accuses Russians On Reports on Gandhi
description: The State Department said today that the Soviet Union was continuing to publish reports blaming the United States for the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, despite private admissions by Soviet leaders that the charge was untrue.

title: 3 Killed in Plane Crash At Disney World Lot
description: A single-engine airplane apparently attempting an emergency landing crashed today in the parking lot at Walt Disney World, killing two adults and a child and critically injuring two other children. All five were aboard the plane.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING CONTRACTOR GIFTS TO RICKOVER
description: The Navy and the Justice Department are investigating evidence that four military contractors gave ''gifts and gratuities'' to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover while the admiral was the head of the Navy nuclear propulsion program, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman said in a letter made public today.

title: BITTER CLASH IN CBS TRIAL TESTIMONY
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland and CBS lawyers clashed sharply in court yesterday, as the general stabbed the air with his glasses and asserted his prerogatives as a commander and the CBS lawyers, catching him in various discrepancies, suggested that he couldn't get straight his decisions in 1967 or his testimony now.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BUDGET TALKS TURN TO TRANSIT AND STUDENT LOANS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering proposals to tighten requirements for student loans and cut mass transit subsidies as part of the White House effort to restrain Federal budget deficits, officials said today.

title: ESSAY ; THE PEACE OFFENSIVES
description: WASHINGTON The first dual Peace Offensive has

title: Sugar Concern Plans Payment DENVER, Nov. 21 (AP) -
description: The Great Western Sugar Company announced today that it

title: Rivals Sue United Air and American
description: Eleven United States airlines have filed a $350 million antitrust suit against American Airlines and United Air Lines over the defendants' two computerized ticket reservations systems.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: ONE DECORATOR'S WORLD: ELEGANCE TO ORDER
description: MARK HAMPTON will not tell you how much money he makes, nor how big or small the budgets are for the interiors he designs for his clients' houses. He won't even tell you the price of the Regency chairs he found in England, the ones with swags draped across the backs.

title: SOVIET DEFECTOR BACK ON THE JOB AT MOSCOW PAPER
description: Oleg G. Bitov, a Soviet journalist who returned to Moscow three months ago after defecting to the West, reappeared in print today in his former newspaper with an admiring critique of an article by Norman Mailer about Russia.

title: THE SEASON FOR SERIOUS DUCK HUNTERS
description: Now that the unseasonably warm weather has apparently ended, the Northeast's waterfowlers - particularly those along the coast - have become truly serious about their sport.

title: FAMINE REPORTS SHOW POWER OF TV
description: The harrowing images of emaciated children - their bellies distended, arms and legs fragile sticks, eyes glazed - have become a familiar sight to television viewers in the past month.

title: AMERICAN QUASAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MURDOCH BUYS 12 ZIFF PUBLICATION
description: Rupert Murdoch yesterday announced his purchase of the 12 trade publications of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company for $350 million.

title: Cambodian Says Battle For Rebel Base Goes On
description: A Cambodian rebel leader said today that fighting was continuing for a major guerrilla base near the Thai border, and he denied that Vietnamese troops had overrun the camp.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Merger Cleared
description: The United States Football League's Michigan Panthers have freed themselves from a long-term lease at the Silverdome by agreeing to pay $1,325,000 to the Pontiac Stadium Building Authority. The agreement clears the way for the team to proceed with its merger with the Oakland Invaders, which will have the combined club playing in Oakland next season.

title: LONG VIEW OF A SMALL, COMBUSTIBLE PLANET
description: To the Editor:

title: MALIBU GRAND PRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRESIDENT'S WIFE TELLS OF ANEMIA
description: Nancy Reagan has acknowledged that she suffers from anemia, and that President Reagan is estranged from his eldest son, Michael.

title: JAPAN'S GROWING LOVE AFFAIR WITH ROOMY OLD FARMHOUSES
description: KAMAKURA, Japan

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1984 International An accord on U.S.-Soviet talks in early January in Geneva on arms control and other issues is near, according to White House officials. They said an announcement of the scheduled meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko was expected in the next few days, after the last details are resolved. (Page A1, Column 5.) Moscow's allies in the Warsaw Pact have lived amid uncertainty over the Soviet leadership during the 15-month reign of Yuri V. Andropov and the nine-month-old reign of Konstantin U. Chernenko. East European officials speak openly of the current era as merely a transition. (A1:3-4.)

title: BRIEFING ; Say the Secret Word
description: The Library of Congress, which

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $10,808,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $8,092,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a tax credit of $11,638,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $10,629,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the company's settlement with the S.E.C. on Aug. 13, 1984.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
OLD DOMINION REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $643 for the quarter and $2,040,170 for the 9 months. c-Includes investment gains of $6,681 for the quarter and $522,487 for the 9 months.

title: ; SHOW DOGS ARE JUST LIKE ORDINARY FOLKS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: ROD RODGERS COMPANY
description: Demonstrating its versatility, the Rod Rodgers Dance Company presented three new works and revived an old one Sunday night at the New York University Education Theater. Two premieres were portrait studies.

title: GIVING AID WHEN TIMES TURN HARD
description: At the bank on 13th Avenue in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, people pass and ask, ''Where is Mr. W?'' or, ''Have you heard how Mr. W is doing?''

title: Report Tells of Chance In Coronary Treatment
description: People with coronary artery disease have a slightly better chance of surviving if they undergo bypass surgery rather than only taking drugs, but their advantage eventually disappears, according to a report released today.

title: THE BOUNTY OF AGE
description: Thanksgiving dawn. The turkey's in its oven; all's right with the world. Why did no one tell us how wonderful life after 65 can be? When we were very young, our elders kept insisting that our younger years were the happiest years of our lives. Now we know better - at least those of us with enough luck and gene-power to be still around, with mind and limb, relationships and pocketbook in working order.

title: Canucks Dismiss Coach
description: Bill LaForge , in his first season as coach, was dropped by the Vancouver Canucks yesterday after the team had won just four of its first 20 games. The dismissal came the day after the Canucks, playing at home before fewer than 10,000 fans, had lost a 5-1 decision to the St. Louis Blues. General Manager Harry Neale said he would assume coaching duties immediately.

title: CBS NEWS CHIEF HINTS AT DOUBT ON LIBEL CASE
description: The president of CBS News, Edward M. Joyce, told a Rotary Club gathering in Maine on Tuesday that he expected the network would lose Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit at the jury level but would win on appeal.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PKS-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Athlete's Pressure
description: Olden Polynice , the 6-foot-10-inch sophomore center for Virginia's basketball team, has been exonerated by the school's honor committee after admitting that he submitted another student's paper to a freshman English composition course, according to students familiar with the secret proceedings. School officials, citing a state confidentiality law, refused to comment.

title: VICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics Points of View Of Censorship
description: Contrary to our comment Monday, the sponsors of antipornography laws in the Middle West do not support a similar bill in New York's Suffolk County. We regret the error.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Football
description: Dallas Cowboys vs. New England Patriots , at Irving, Tex. Danny White has taken the starting-quarterback job away from Gary Hogeboom once again as Dallas looks for a more potent offense than the one that was shut down by Buffalo last Sunday.

title: IN 1621, THE ORIGINAL CATERED AFFAIR
description: After Plymouth Rock was pulverized last July 4 to make way for a croissant shop, the diary of an unknown Pilgrim was found underneath. He had been wait-listed on the Mayflower and, after the other passengers reconfirmed, stowed away behind a case of duty-free liquor. The diary, excerpted here, records events through Thanksgiving 1621 - America's first dinner party.

title: More European Flights
description: Airlines serving Western Europe plan to increase the number of their flights there by 5 to 10 percent next summer, the International Air Transport Association said today.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Cattle and Hogs Gain; Grain Under Pressure
description: Live cattle and hog futures gained in active pre-holiday trading today on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, buoyed by traders' expectations that both meats will be in greater demand after Thanksgiving.

title: 20th Birthday Party ForVerrazanoBridge
description: The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge yesterday celebrated its 20th year of linking Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: SOLES ON ICE
description: Hours are expanded today at the Mary Lasker Skating Rink at the northern end of Central Park, giving everyone time either to work up an appetite or to skate off a big meal. The rink will be open from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: MATH BOX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SIGMA RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REMEMBERING THE '39 WORLD'S FAIR
description: ''The World of Tomorrow'' is a dandy documentary. It tells us neither too little nor too much; it allows us to ruminate. It is about the World's Fair of 1939, an event remembered both by our oldest inhabitants and a large number of the middle-aged as well. What do they remember? The documentary offers hints. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: ROSSINI'S FINAL OPERA, A VOLATILE STORY IN ITS TIME
description: ''William Tell,'' or ''Guillaume Tell,'' as it is known in its original French version, was the last of Rossini's 39 operas. During much of the 19th century it was famous around the world.

title: CAPITOL AIR ASKS WORKERS FOR CASH
description: Capitol Air said yesterday that it had asked an employee committee seeking to gain control of the airline to come up with $1 million in cash by Saturday to help it meet a severe cash squeeze and pay for immediate operational expenses.

title: MERRIMAC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 6
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $90,000 from a change in tax regulations.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: PHONE RATE CUT ORDERED TO OFFSET OVERCHARGES
description: The Federal Communications Commission today ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its former operating companies to reduce interstate long-distance rates and other charges by $178.2 million next year.

title: INDIVIDUAL RIGHTS: EASIER SAID THAN ADJUDICATED
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Hasidic Festival In 15th Year at Hunter
description: The 1984 Israeli Hasidic Festival musical show brought a highly professional troupe of Israeli singer- dancers to the Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday and Sunday. Held annually, the festival is a contest of Biblical verses set to music by composers from around the world.

title: Topics Points of View
description: Of a WallOn a visit to China, Senator Jake Garn inspected the Great Wall and told his pleased hosts he looked forward to seeing it again from the space shuttle next year. Finally proving whether this is possible may be the only value of the Senator's far- fetched junket.

title: CHICAGO PREP STAR IS DEAD OF WOUNDS
description: A youth heralded by some as the top high school basketball player in the nation died today of gunshot wounds he suffered in what the authorities described as a ''senseless'' altercation a block away from his school Tuesday.

title: Pittston Outlook
description: The Pittston Company said it had increased its previously estimated $15 million fourth-quarter pretax loss from its coal operations to as much as $30 million. It cited further declines in already weak customer shipping schedules. The company said coal sales in the fourth quarter are expected to total only about 1.9 million tons, down sharply from 4.8 million in the third quarter, when domestic and foreign customers were stockpiling coal in anticipation of a then-possible strike by the United Mine Workers.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BRIEFING ; Wriston Signs On
description: Without any fanfare, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has asked an old friend, Walter B. Wriston, former chairman of Citicorp, to serve as an unpaid consultant on long-term telecommunications policies.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHOREHAM TESTING AT VERY LOW LEVEL APPROVED BY N.R.C.
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 5 to 0 today to allow the Long Island Lighting Company to load uranium fuel at the Shoreham nuclear plant and begin operating at extremely low levels for tests.

title: Girl Returns to School But Sits for Anthem
description: A high school senior who skipped school because she was harassed for refusing to stand for the national anthem returned to classes today, but she stayed in her seat when the anthem was played.

title: Sun-Times Editor Is Named
description: Frank Devine, a senior staff editor at the Reader's Digest and a former corresponent for The Melbourne (Australia) Herald, on Tuesday was named editor of The Chicago Sun-Times. Mr. Devine, 52 years old, is a native of New Zealand who joined the Reader's Digest in 1970. He worked for The Herald in New York, London and Tokyo. The Sun-Times said Mr. Devine would assume his post in January. Mr. Devine will succeed Roger Wood, who has been acting editor since shortly after The Sun-Times was purchased by Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, last January.

title: Ex-Federal Official Sentenced To 4 Years for Extortion Bid
description: The former commissioner of public buildings for the General Services Administration was sentenced Tuesday to four years in Federal prison for trying to extort nearly $20,000 from a developer in return for placing a Social Security office in a shopping mall.

title: GOBBLE, GOBBLE AND GAB, GAB
description: This is a city that likes to talk about ''talking turkey,'' and at least once a year the cliche can be taken literally.

title: Vindicate Intellectuals, Chinese Party Urges
description: The Communist Party today made its strongest appeal yet for rehabilitation of China's intellectuals, persecuted during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution.

title: Perone Concedes In Senate Race
description: John M. Perone, a Republican, conceded defeat today to the Democratic candidate, Suzi Oppenheimer, in the race to succeed Joseph R. Pisani in the State Senate from the 36th District.

title: A HARVESTER-TENNECO DEAL?
description: The International Harvester Company may soon announce the sale of its farm equiment business to Tenneco Inc., analysts said today.

title: BRUINS DEFEATED BY FLYERS, 4-3
description: Ilkka Sinisalo, Tim Kerr and Ron Sutter scored second-period goals tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Boston Bruins, 4-3, and extended their unbeaten streak to seven games.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 7
CITY SCHOOLS MISS GOAL FOR CLASS SIZE
description: The New York City school system has reduced class sizes in only a third of its overcrowded high school classes despite special city financing to eliminate crowding in all of its high school classes, the Schools Chancellor said yesterday.

title: KOHL SAYS SETBACK WON'T BAR AMITY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl declared today that West Germany would continue to seek to improve its relations with Eastern Europe despite the last-minute cancellation of a visit to Poland by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from the sale of securities of $17,913 for the quarter and $94,473 for the 9 months. c-Net income which includes gains from the sale of securities of $19,355 for the quarter and $201,162 for the 9 months, and a gain from the sale of assets of $322,316 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: NUI CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Singer Contract
description: The Singer Company's Link Flight Simulation division said it had received a $240 million contract from the Army for 25 helicopter simulators. The company said Link will produce 19 simulators and will modify six older simulators over a five-year period.

title: APPLE'S MAC TAKING ON I.B.M.
description: When Steven P. Jobs, the brash and free-wheeling 29-year-old chairman f Apple Computer Inc., appeared before the top data processing executives of some of the nation's largest corporations earlier this year, it seemed likely to be the ultimate clash of cultures.

title: U.S. Judge in Michigan Bars A Cr eche From City Property
description: A Federal judge today refused to allow a Christmas Nativity scene on city property in Birmingham, Mich., saying it conveyed an unfortunate official message of rejection to all non-Christians.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BLISS, A.T. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $618,749 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,365,206 for the quarter and 9 months. d-Net income.

title: Yugoslav Dissident Arrested
description: The police have arrested a Yugoslav teacher on charges of anti-state activities and having links with hostile emigre organizations in France, Belgrade newspapers reported today. A court investigation has begun against Milan Mladenovic over purported contacts with leaders of the Serbian nationalist and royalist emigre organization called the Chetniks in Paris and articles he wrote in emigre publications in the West, the newspapers said.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by Anne Farrer Scott, a writer and former lawyer who lives in Minneapolis.

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $4.8 million from the settlement of claims under prior and current year's sales contracts. c-Net income

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $193,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $236,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary credits of $545,000 for the quarter and $589,000 for the year.

title: Regan Is Said to Favor Equalizing Tax Burden
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a group of business lobbyists at a private meeting today that companies with the same profits should pay the same amount of taxes, according to someone who attended the meeting.

title: TECHNOLOGY FOR COMMUNICAIONS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TURKEY WELCOMES INFORMATION ABOUT ALLEGED MISTREATMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Eyes of Texas
description: Calvin Schiraldi, the bright pitching prospect for the Mets, was the most valuable player of the College World Series in 1983, when he led the University of Texas to the title.

title: Market Place; Strong's Funds Set Basic Goal
description: NEAR the peak of Wall Street's bull market in the summer of 1983, the Strong Total Return Fund and the Strong Investment Fund - a pair of mutual funds based in Milwaukee - sold virtually all their stocks. The proceeds went into commercial paper to take advantage of rising interest rates. That proved to be admirable timing; shortly thereafter equities went into a tailspin.

title: Israelis Want a Local Force To Patrol Southern Lebanon
description: An Israeli general who is negotiating conditions for a withdrawal from Lebanon said today that Israel wanted a territorial force of 3,000 or 4,000 south Lebanese, and not the Lebanese Army, to look after security in the border area.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1984

title: A Florida Judge Orders Burning of Citrus Trees
description: A state judge ordered Wednesday that more than 10,000 citrus trees suspected of being infected with citrus canker be burned. Judge Hale Stancil gave the order to burn the trees, owned by the Crittenden Fruit Company, in Marion County Circuit Court after an attorney for the State Department of Agriculture, Robert Chastain, argued that any delay could cause the disease to contaminate Florida's $1.2 billion citrus industry.

title: AFTER 1984, WHAT?
description: After losing four of the last five

title: Search for Trawler Takes New Turn
description: An empty lifeboat from the fishing trawler Amazing Grace has been spotted off the cost of Virginia, prompting the Coast Guard to resume its search yesterday for the vessel and the seven men aboard.

title: Howe Finally Honored
description: It was back in 1971 that Gordie Howe turned in his skates after a 25- year career with the Detroit Red Wings, and it was a year later that he was inducted into the National Hockey League Hall of Fame. But Howe, who holds 25 N.H.L. records, was never inducted into the Red Wings' own Hall of Fame, in part perhaps because he returned to the ice with the Houston Aeros of the World Hockey Association in 1973 and played for seven more seasons before ending his second career with the Hartford Whalers in 1980, at age 52.

title: IRISH SCOLD THATCHER FOR ULSTER REMARKS
description: Irish leaders have sharply criticized Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for remarks she made about joint efforts to end the conflict in Northern Ireland,

title: DESPITE THE REAGAN SWEEP, A GENDER GAP REMAINS
description: In the aftermath of President Reagan's sweeping victory, questions have been raised about the strength of women as a political force. In short, what happened to the celebrated ''gender gap?''

title: EUROPEANS PUSH SALES OF REACTOR FUEL IN U..S
description: Europe's two manufacturers of enriched uranium reactor fuel are opening an aggressive sales drive in the United States, where a change in Department of Energy regulations has allowed American utilities to order fuel from abroad for the first time.

title: ART: EXHIBITION OF NEIL JENNEY WORK
description: Neil Jenney has been called a political artist but while the subject he addresses, landscape, has indeed been politicized, his interest in it seems more that of a moralist than a manipulator.

title: Economic Scene; Anxiety Grows With Deficit
description: A major cause of growing anxiety about the American economy since the election is the swelling Federal budget deficit.

title: Drivers Seized At Checkpoints
description: A dozen people were seized overnight at two Thanksgiving Day drunken-driving checkpoints in Westchester County and charged with driving while intoxicated or impaired by drugs or alcohol, the police said today.

title: Charges Are Dismissed In Suspected Sex Abuse
description: A judge has dismissed charges against two employees of the Minneapolis Children's Theater and School who were accused of failing to report suspected sexual abuse of children.

title: DELEGATE WHO WAS JAILED CALLS SIT-IN 'MORAL' ACT
description: The District of Columbia's delegate to Congress, appearing in court after a night in jail in connection with his arrest for a sit-in at the Embassy of South Africa, said today that the protest had been ''an act of moral witness.''

title: ONLY NEXT TO REAGAN TAX CUTS IS INDEXING FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: COWBOYS GAIN EAST LEAD
description: With an exemplary defensive performance and a winning field goal with 4 seconds remaining, the Dallas Cowboys today moved into sole possession of first place in the Eastern Division of the National Conference.

title: CRAFT SHOWS, A LISTING
description: Uptown and Downtown Crafts Festival,

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND ; Dance
description: The New York City Ballet has just opened at the New York State Theater, which means that before the ''Nutcracker'' crunch early next month, the only time to see a variety of ballets is in the current repertory mini-season. This weekend is an especially good time to catch up with premieres that have been presented within the last year.

title: SoHo thefts: The outcome.
description: The mystery was that 10 paintings and sculptures, worth a total of about $200,000, had disappeared from nine SoHo art galleries in September and October. All the pieces were stolen while the galleries were open, usually in the morning, and sometimes while a crowd was milling around.

title: RESTAURANTS ; Distinctive pasta and French bistro.
description: When a restaurant menu starts off with a declaration of its cooking philosophy or the admonition ''Good food takes time to prepare, so please be patient,'' that is usually a signal for wise diners to flee. Contrapunto, a chic, informal pasta restaurant at 60th Street and Third Avenue, above a sister establishment called Yellowfingers, does just that, boasting of a uniqueness and quality ''not generally found elsewhere.'' Fortunately, however, there is more than hot air blowing out of the kitchen. This restaurant, while limited in scope, puts considerable energy and imagination into making its pastas truly distinctive.

title: Walk-On Player Scores at DePaul
description: The Blue Demons of DePaul are ranked among the top five in most preseason college basketball polls. So what in the world is Ken Stout doing on the team's roster? Working hard, that's what.

title: Kaplan Course Founder To Remain at the Helm
description: This week's agreement to sell the New York-based Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Centers to the Washington Post Company does not end the teaching career of the concern's founder, Stanley H. Kaplan.

title: Tunisian Out of Hospital
description: President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia left the hospital today after 17 days of treatment for heart trouble, a statement from his office said.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Title To Cold Spring Harbor
description: Cold Spring Harbor, capitalizing on six turnovers, marched over Mineola yesterday, 36-8, to win its first Nassau County Conference IV championship in six years.

title: Real Estate; Bonds Aid Housing in Manhattan
description: -exempt financing, a modest surge of new

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday, and in some editions Wednesday, on the history of Rossini's ''William Tell'' incorrectly stated the language of the opera's first performance at the Metropolitan Opera. Presented on Nov. 28, 1884, it was in German.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS AGREE TO RESUME ARMAMENTS TALKS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would meet in Geneva Jan. 7 and 8 to negotiate an agenda for talks on limiting nuclear arms.

title: FREE ENTERPRISE VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out Guide: Pizza
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAROLINA, 355 West 46th Street (245-0058)

title: Paraguay Is Said to Promise Manhunt for a Nazi Fugitive
description: A team searching for the Nazi fugitive Josef Mengele said today that senior Paraguayan officials had promised a nationwide manhunt for him.

title: LONG COMEBACK IN OKLAHOMA
description: Oklahoma A&M College was ranked fifth in The Associated Press's final college football poll for 1945, after its team had gone unbeaten and untied and captured the Sugar Bowl. A&M that season routed its archrival, the University of Oklahoma, by 47-0, the worst defeat in Sooner history, and the magnitude of the beating inspired a massive effort by the Sooners to strengthen their football program to the level of their neighbors 90 miles to the north.

title: LAWYER WILL NOT SEEK DISCLOSURE OF PHOTOS IN DAVID KENNEDY CASE
description: A lawyer representing several news organizations has agreed not to seek the release of photographs and a videotape made in the investigation of David Kennedy's drug-related death.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: The New York City Ballet leaped into town with not one but

title: Barry Harris Trio
description: The pianist Barry Harris and his trio, plus the alto saxophonist C Sharpe and the singer Roberta Davis will play be-bop and other jazz tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater (244-0997), 368 Eighth Avenue above 28th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1:15 A.M.; admission is $8.

title: CURRIER AIDS GIANTS FROM STRONG SAFETY
description: The figure almost jumped out of the statistics sheet after the Giants' 16-10 victory last Sunday over the St. Louis Cardinals. Bill Currier had been credited with 10 unassisted tackles.

title: St. Francis Shuts Out Bayside
description: In one of a series of ''turkey bowls'' played throughout the city yesterday, St. Francis dominated Bayside, 34-0, at the losers' home field in Queens.

title: BLUES GUITARIST
description: The blues guitarist Roy Buchanan will perform tonight and tomorrow at 9:30 and midnight at Tramps (777- 5077), 125 East 15th Street. There is an $8 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Anti-Castro Terrorist Faces Miami Charges
description: The man said to be the leader of the Cuban anti-Castro group known as Omega 7 has been ordered held without bail here to face charges stemming from the bombings of the Mexican and Venezuelan Consulates more than two years ago.

title: UNEASY PERIOD FOR ANDERSEN
