description: Every major accounting firm sporadically gets hit with multimillion-dollar lawsuits arising from audits they conducted on companies that later wound up in financial trouble. Shareholders and creditors of the company, hoping to recoup their losses, often hone in on the auditors, who tend to be the deepest pockets left in the financial rubble.

title: HANDEL SERIES TO OPEN AT CARNEGIE
description: Although George Frideric Handel's ''Messiah'' is the most popular oratorio ever written, the rest of the composer's myriad vocal works contain a trove of musical treasures all but unknown to the public. Handel wrote well over 100 cantatas, more than 40 operas and some 25 oratorios, in English, German and Italian. Some of the cantatas are still in church use, and the oratorios were a beloved fixture of Victorian musical life, but the operas have languished until very recently.

title: Fire Lieutenant Rescues 3 at Blaze
description: A Fire Department lieutenant, using his body as a shield, rescued a woman and her two children yesterday from a burning housing project on the Lower East Side, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: TEXAN TALKS OF REPLACING O'NEILL AS SPEAKER
description: Representative Charles Stenholm, a conservative Democrat from Texas, says there is ''a 99 percent certainty'' that he will challenge Thomas P. O'Neill for the post of Speaker of the House next month in the Democratic caucus.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS STEP UP RAIDS IN COFFEE AREAS AS HARVEST NEARS
description: As thousands of workers prepare to begin harvesting the coffee beans on which Nicaragua's economy depends, insurgents have stepped up their raids in the fertile northern hills where most of the coffee is grown.

title: TYPEWRITERS OF ELECTRONIC ERA
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which used to dominate the market for office typewriters with its ubiquitous Selectric line, has found itself losing ground since the arrival of electronic models.

title: Five Virginia Inmates Escape By Cutting Through Fences
description: Five inmates escaped from a medium- security prison tonight by cutting through two fences near the base of a guard tower, the authorities said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 23, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Injured List
description: Tommy Kramer, the injury- plagued Minnesota Viking quarterback who has missed 17 of his team's last 26 games, including 3 this season, will miss another one Sunday when the Vikings play the Chicago Bears. The Vikings announced that Kramer was suffering from a sore shoulder and would be replaced by Wade Wilson. The club also suffered another setback when doctors said Mark Mullaney, the defensive end who sustained a neck injury Oct. 28, would be sidelined the rest of the season.

title: HOLIDAY IN CITY: FEASTING AND FELLOWSHIP
description: There may have been hundreds of strangers in the cavernous gymnasium where the Salvation Army served Thanksgiving dinner yesterday, but the dinner at Table No. 10 held all the warmth that home can offer.

title: APPEAL BY VASQUEZ IS DENIED
description: A State Supreme Court justice has denied Jacinto Vasquez's latest appeal of his one-year suspension by the Racing and Wagering Board, finding that a hearing officer's recommendation that the full board refuse to grant Vasquez a new hearing was not ''patently irrational and unreasonable.''

title: 'Arts and Sports USA'
description: Working for the Department of Commerce in the Carter Administration, Louise W. Wiener discovered that convention planners picking out their next host city could easily spot attractive lodgings with the ''Hotel and Motel Red Book'' and travel connections with the ''Official Airline Guide.'' But nowhere was there a city-by-city list of the collateral amenities that conventioneers and spouses enjoy: museums, theaters, zoos, sports arenas and the like.

title: TRANSFER MAKES MARK AT RHODE ISLAND
description: Along the ground-floor corridors of Keaney Gymnasium, the accent one recent afternoon was on jungle fatigues and combat boots as students made their way to Army R.O.T.C. classes.

title: JAZZ: AT BLUE NOTE, HEALTH AND GRIFFIN LEAD GROUPS
description: Both Jimmy Heath and Johnny Griffin play tenor saxophone, have been active since the 1950's and stand under 5 feet 5 inches. Sharing a double bill at the Blue Note through Sunday - with each musician leading a quartet - that's about all they have in common.

title: VAST, UNDREAMED-OF DRUG USE FEARED
description: A recent marijuana raid in northern Mexico, the largest recorded drug seizure ever, is forcing American officials to question whether they have been seriously underestimating drug production around the world, and drug abuse in the United States.

title: THE DEMOCRATS AND THEIR HUMPTY DUMPTY
description: The Democratic Party is once again in the intensive-care unit of American politics. At its bedside are politicians, party strategists and political professionals who are prescribing strong medicine for its recovery.

title: 2D ARAB DEMONSTRATOR IN 2 DAYS IS SHOT DEAD BY ISRAELI ARMY FIRE
description: In the second such incident in as many days, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a young Palestinian demonstrator today in the occupied West Bank.

title: Stradivarius Is Sold In London for $491,040
description: A Stradivarius violin and an 18th-century silver dinner service were auctioned for record prices in separate sales here today, a spokesman for Sotheby's auction house said.

title: STATE'S SECOND-OPINION RULE REDUCES OPERATIONS
description: A rule requiring a second surgeon's opinion for six elective procedures has significantly reduced the number of those operations performed on members of New York State's publicemployee health plan, according to state officials.

title: McEnroe Sidelined
description: John McEnroe has withdrawn from the Australian Open next week, citing a wrist injury that could also cause him problems in the Davis Cup final between the United States and Sweden next month. Dr. Omar Fareed, a member of the sports medicine committee of the United States Tennis Association, said he had examined McEnroe after the player hurt his left wrist in practice the other day, and had advised him not to compete for two weeks.

title: REVISION OF BIBLE FOR GENDER GOES ON
description: Efforts to remove exclusively male terminology from the Bible are continuing despite some setbacks and obstacles.

title: MAN WHO LOST LEG TO RESCUE DOG SAYS HE HAS NO REGRETS
description: Five months ago Cole McFarland leaped in front of an onrushing train to save his dog. It cost him his leg, but he says he has no regrets.

title: NUANCES IN CHESS TITLE PLAY LEAD ONLY TO DRAWN GAMES
description: Small nuances adorning worn tracks produce the conflicts in the world championship chess match in Moscow between the challenger, 21- year-old Gary Kasparov, and the champion, 33-year-old Anatoly Karpov.

title: Miami of Ohio Tops Cincinnati
description: Al Marlow ran for one touchdown and passed for another to lift Miami of Ohio to a 31-26 victory over Cincinnati today in the 89th renewal of college football's fifth-oldest rivalry.

title: BRIEFING ; Waste Not, Want Not
description: Senator Gary Hart, whose campaign debt from the 1984 Democratic primaries is more than $4 million, recently bought himself a sporty new Pontiac Firebird, but he resourcefully declined to trade in his dozen-year-old Mustang.

title: Early-American Gourmets
description: George Washington liked to eat well

title: MAN WITH A BRAIN DISORDER DIES OUTSIDE SHELTER
description: A 48-year-old homeless man who suffered from an organic brain disorder was found dead early Wednesday a few hundred feet from the shelter on Wards Island where he had been staying, officials said.

title: Heart Surgeon 'Fine' After Ulcer Operation
description: Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the renowned surgeon who helped develop the artificial heart, was resting in ''fine condition'' today after undergoing surgery for a bleeding ulcer, a Methodist Hospital spokesman said.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW BURROUGHS BOOKS
description: When William Burroughs wrote a novel in 1951 about life in the homosexual underground of the 1940's, it was considered too controversial to publish. However, that novel, ''Queer,'' will appear next fall, one of seven new Burroughs books that Viking Penguin will publish over the next five years.

title: No More Fruit Flies Found
description: A county agriculture official said today that no more Mediterranean fruit flies had been found since a single male was discovered in a trap in Beverly Hills Tuesday.

title: HEINZ W. GOTTWALD
description: Heinz W. Gottwald, a retired banker, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, L.I. He was 78 years old and lived in Babylon, L.I.

title: NO THREAT OF PLUTONIUM CONTAMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Ceausescu, on Re-election, Warns of Continued Hardship
description: Nicolae Ceausescu was re-elected leader of Rumania's Communist Party tonight and used the occasion to tell his countrymen that they faced continued economic hardship.

title: On a War Footing
description: Regulars in the White House press corps customarily display their press cards on a chain worn around the neck, often with other passes. The latest in-joke among some members of that group involves wearing on the same chain an authentic-appearing ''credential'' in laminated plastic, complete with photograph of the bearer, name and number and an overprint that reads: ''Official Press - Nicaraguan Invasion.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND ; Pop and Rock
description: Feeling a little sentimental after the holiday? Well, there's hardly anything more sentimental than the heart- on-sleeve Cuban ballad style known, in perfect Spanglish, as ''el feeling.'' It is the province of courtly crooners who make Julio Iglesias (a kind of modernized, internationalized ''el feeling'' singer) seem a little unromantic. The style is rarely heard outside the Cuban community, but tomorrow at 9 P.M., Soundscape - which will be set up like a nightclub, with tables and chairs - will present ''Una Noche del 'Feeling' '' (a night of ''feeling'') with the singer Regino Tellechea. The singer-guitarist Cary Del Rio and the virtuoso conga drummer Daniel Ponce will be special guests, and the backup band will include the drummer Ignacio Berroa. In the tradition of ''el feeling,'' other singers have been invited and are likely to perform. Soundscape is at 500 West 52d Street, near 10th Avenue, and admission is $8 (581-7032).

title: Chevette Recall Suggested
description: The Federal Government said Tuesday that it had recommended the recall of 29,000 Chevrolet Chevette subcompact cars because of the potential for a rear- brake lockup.

title: COMMUNE CHIEF WANTED ON CHILD ABUSE CHARGES
description: The leader of a religious commune in Salem is being sought by the police on child abuse charges and 15 children from the commune have been placed into temporary custody.

title: B&B Direct Promotes Executive to President
description: John Verdon, who honed his direct marketing skills at Time Inc., has just been named president of B&B Direct, the specialty unit at Benton & Bowles.

title: Rock Hudson Stars In Movie About Vegas
description: In the nutty world of ''The Vegas Strip War,'' casino hotels are referred to as ''shrines,'' and flamboyant entrepreneurs loudly negotiate multimillion-dollar deals while chasing each other through crowded hotel lobbies. The movie, which was produced, directed and written by George Englund, will be shown on Channel 4 Sunday at 9 P.M., and it stars Rock Hudson as an entrepreneurial prince among thieves.

title: ART: SOCIETY PORTRAITS OF GIOVANNI BOLDINI
description: Not too many artists could dash off a portrait with the panache of Giovanni Boldini (1842-1931), who was adored by the glitterati of Belle Epoque Paris. If his taste was rococo and his likenesses not always penetrating, he was clever at catching his subjects - hostesses, actresses, courtesans, musicians, writers and other artists - as they enacted the high life fantasy-drama that played in their heads, conferring on them style and the appearance of aristocracy. In light of the current appeal of figure painting, and what seems to be a spreading curatorial interest in salon art, it's not at all surprising that a Boldini show should surface: ''Giovanni Boldini and Society Portraiture: 1880-1920,'' at New York University's Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 33 Washington Place (through Dec. 22).

title: JAZZ: LES MCCANN QUARTET
description: A common reason for the use of electric pianos by touring jazz musicians is the unreliability of the acoustic pianos they find in the clubs into which they are booked. So it is not unusual to find Les McCann playing an electric piano at Fat Tuesday's, where his quartet is appearing through Sunday, even though there is an acoustic piano at his side.

title: Speedy Repairs Planned For Philadelphia Bridge
description: A deteriorated railroad bridge that has caused chaos for commuters since it closed last week will be rebuilt and reopened within three weeks, city officials announced today.

title: ART: SCULPTURE BY JONATHAN SILVER
description: In the entrance to the New York

title: OFFICERS OF THE C.C.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZILIAN PARTY TO PURGE ELECTION DISSIDENTS
description: In a maneuver to revive its faltering campaign, the governing Brazilian party has decided to purge all dissidents who refuse to support the official candidate for a civilian President.

title: KAWAKUBO: FROM FASHION TO FURNITURE
description: About five years ago Rei Kawakubo, the Tokyo fashion designer, became dissatisfied with her work. Fashion designers everywhere were fooling around with folklore themes and reworkings of designs from each decade of the 20th century. She decided that she would get rid of those influences, she said in an interview a few years later, and would start ''from nothing, from zero.'' She sought to break away from conventional forms and develop a new style for ''the independent woman of today.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some editions of Weekend yesterday incorrectly identified the position held by Grover A. Whalen in 1939. He was president of the World's Fair.

title: Advertising; Another British Rivalry
description: WHEN it comes to buying space in international publications, London media people do a better job than their New York counterparts, according to Crocker Snow Jr., who is in a position to know.

title: PRESIDENT OF ADELPHI SAYS HE WILL RETIRE AT SCHOOL YEAR'S END
description: Dr. Timothy W. Costello, who as president of Adelphi University has been instrumental in a major expansion of the school's activities since he took over in 1972, announced this week that he would retire at the end of the academic year.

title: AUTHOR TOLD TO SUBMIT BOOK NOTES
description: A Federal judge Wednesday ordered an author to produce documents and photographs used in writing a book that his publisher branded as fraudulent and withdrew from stores.

title: GOVERNOR COLLINS BEGINS RECOVERY
description: Gov. Martha Layne Collins of Kentucky was in good condition but suffering ''intense pain'' after three-and-a-half hours of surgery to remove a jagged piece of glass from her small intestine, her husband said today.

title: BRIEFING ; Reagan the Organic Farmer
description: Under the Reagan Administration thus far, the Department of Agriculture has cut back on spending for research on organic farming, the use of nonchemical techniques for raising crops and livestock, and ended the work of its only real authority in the area, I. Garth Youngberg. But President Reagan himself, it turns out, follows organic precepts on his California ranch, although he may be influenced more by taste than conviction.

title: OLDER SMOKERS URGED TO QUIT
description: People over the age of 65 who have smoked for years can still reduce their chance of death from coronary heart disease by stopping, researchers at the Yale School of Medicine said today.

title: Canadiens 3, Black Hawks 2
description: Guy Carbonneau of Montreal scored his second goal of the game at 15:12 of the third period to snap a 2-2 tie. With a burst of speed, Carbonneau split the defense of Keith Brown and Behn Wilson just over the Chicago blue line, then snapped a shot off the left goal post and over the goalie Murray Bannerman's shoulder.

title: Police and Basques Clash During Protest Strike
description: Policemen and small groups of youths clashed throughout Spain's Basque country today during a general strike over Tuesday's killing of a separatist leader, which E.T.A. guerrillas avenged by wounding a general.

title: Doctors Rule Out Transplant From Organs of Hanged Boy
description: Surgeons have determined that they could not save any organs for transplants from the body of a second- grader whose father said he had hanged himself because classmates accused him of stealing money from a teacher's purse.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Officials Switched At Dayton-Hudson
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation continues to show reverberations from its consolidation of the Dayton and Hudson department stores last March.

title: L.I. MALL STILL ASSESSING FIRE LOSSES
description: With the holiday shopping rush at hand, work crews at the Walt Whitman Mall here have been pressing to clear away the debris from a fire that swept through the mall last week.

title: PRESIDENT'S SON SEES 'JEALOUSY' IN THE FAMILY
description: Michael Reagan, the adopted son of Ronald Reagan, said today that ''jealousy' was the source of friction between himself and his father's wife, Nancy, and urged his stepmother to apologize for saying he had been estranged from his father.

title: STRIDE PIANO BY ENGINEER WITH DIGITAL INCLINATIONS
description: The pianist who is strutting through stride-style performances in the manner of Fats Waller at Hanratty's this weekend is a man who is known in the music world as ''Thins'' Francis. In the world of science, he is known as Henry A. Francis, Harvard 1960, a research engineer who, over the last 20 years, has done work on the oxidation of metals, on lubrication and friction in relation to the roughness of engineering surfaces and, currently, on contact mechanics relevant to ball bearings.

title: A Lutheran Minister Shot Dead in Salvador
description: A leader of the Lutheran Church in El Salvador was found shot dead and mutilated Wednesday in a rural village near the eastern city of San Miguel.

title: Addendum
description: * Seventeen magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 3.2 percent, to 1.6 million, from 1.55 million, and its advertising rates 9.5 percent with the February issue.

title: LIONS RALLY TO BEAT PACKERS
description: A strong pregame speech by Coach Monte Clark fired up Detroit, and the Lions responded today with a 31-28 comeback victory over the Green Bay Packers in their nationally televised game.

title: THREE SETS OF ARMS TALKS
description: Following are the three areas of arms control that the United States and the Soviet Union are expected to hold preliminary discussions about during talks in Geneva in January 1985. Medium-Range Missile Talks - The United States and the Soviet Union began talks in Geneva in November 1981 on limiting medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: YUGOSLAVIA'S DILEMMA
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

title: E.P.A. DRIFTS IN STALEMATE
description: Environmental policy making and administration by the Federal Government, like downtown traffic in a rainy rush hour, is gradually slowing to near paralysis.

title: Like a Hair Shirt
description: Grand masters of the pun are so sensitive that misplacement of a letter in one of their efforts will set them quivering with rage and demanding a public retraction.

title: CARTOON OLD-TIMERS AND UPSTARTS ARE PARADE HITS
description: Get ready to un-net Underdog. Everybody, you are human sandbags. Take tension in your lines.''

title: Federal Judge Delays Sale of Indian Objects
description: A Federal district judge has issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting Michael R. Johnson, an Arizona art dealer, from selling Alaska Indian artifacts valued at more than $2 million.

title: Moscow Hails Indira Gandhi
description: A street in Moscow, a new Soviet ship, a school and a library will bear the name Indira Gandhi as the Soviet Union's tribute to the assassinated Indian Prime Minister, Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced today. A square in Moscow is named after Mrs. Gandhi's father, Jawaharlal Nehru, who was India's first Prime Minister.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND ; Museums
description: From Igor Stravinsky to D. H. Lawrence, and from ''Tristes Tropiques'' by Claude Levi-Strauss to ''The Ik,'' directed by Peter Brook, high culture in the 20th century has lived much of its life under the sign of what used to be called ''The Primitive.''

title: AUCTIONS ; Tribal art to be sold.
description: Collectors of tribal art rarely own more than a few examples of African furniture and household objects. Since most auctions usually offer only a handful of such furnishings, the sale of 106 examples of head and neck rests, stools, chairs, drums, shields, buckets, bowls, mortars and boxes next Friday at 10:15 A.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, is considered most unusual.

title: ANNIVERSARY OF KENNEDY'S DEATH IS NOTED QUIETLY AT DEALEY PLAZA
description: For the first time in 20 years, Dealey Plaza was quiet on the anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: British Banks Cut Rates
description: Three of Britain's major commercial banks today cut their base lending rates to their best corporate customers to 9 1/2 percent, from 10 percent.

title: ; ONLY NEXT TO REAGAN TAX CUTS IS INDEXING FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESSMAN AND EX-ENVOY
description: Maxwell H. Gluck, a businessman, philanthropist and thoroughbred horse breeder who served a year as Ambassador to Ceylon, died of heart failure Wednesday night at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 85 years old and lived in Los Angeles and Lexington, Ky.

title: BRITAIN THREATENS TO LEAVE UNESCO UNLESS IT CHANGES
description: Britain announced today that it would withdraw from Unesco at the end of next year unless there was clear evidence of further progress toward changing the agency.

title: Chilean Singer
description: The Chilean singer Isabel Aldunate will perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Washington Irving High School Auditorium, Irving Place at 16th Street, sponsored by the Pablo Neruda Cultural Center (718-471- 9456). Tickets are $8.

title: The Gobblers' Last Stand
description: The turkey is an endangered species among sports nicknames, a

title: Union Rolls, 30-0, For 10th Victory
description: Union scored three touchdowns after turnovers yesterday and defeated Linden, 30-0, before 5,000 in Union. It was the sixth shutout of the season and the 10th victory for undefeated Union.

title: Phone Directory For the Elderly
description: To the Yellow Pages and the White Pages, add the Silver Pages.

title: HAILS 'ETERNAL CONTINUITY'
description: Yasir Arafat rallied his scattered Palestine Liberation Organization supporters for a long-delayed meeting of the Palestinian parliament in exile here tonight.

title: Work in Progress
description: ''Four to Four,'' a theater work-in- progress by Michel Garneau with a full-length score by Henry Threadgill, will be seen Sunday at 3 P.M. at Port Royal, 837 Union Street, Brooklyn, near the Union Street stop of the RR train and the Seventh Avenue stop of the D train. The work is presented by the Manhattan Bridge Theater Company's Sunday Oasis series of new music. Tickets are $6; the number for more information is 638-2404.

title: DUARTE IS FAULTED ON PLAN FOR TALKS
description: A leading Salvadoran rebel accused the Government today of violating ''the spirit of dialogue'' by failing to discuss proposals for a second round of peace talks with the rebels.

title: Europeans Draft Curb On Steel Pipe Exports
description: Common Market officials meeting in Brussels agreed today to propose a 50 percent cut in their exports of steel pipes to the United States to defuse a growing trade conflict.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Galleries

title: THE WORRISOME PROSPECT OF AN INVASION OF NICARAGUA
description: It is no secret that the Sandinista Government is unpopular in this capital. The Administration is united in its conviction that the Sandinistas must go: the only issue is how and when.

title: SAD Excuses
description: As the days draw in and the year goes out, dwellers in the northern latitudes tend to get moody. Some accuse the stars - Saturn, for instance, may be squatting malevolently on their moon.

title: RETAILERS HOPEFUL FOR CHRISTMAS
description: The Christmas shopping season, which only a few weeks ago seemed full of promise and glad tidings, opens today on a note of uncertainty sounded by recent indications of a sharper economic slowdown.

title: TOUCH OF HOME FOR AUSTRALIANS IN NEW YORK
description: There isn't an Earls Court in New York City. That enclave in London is filled with expatriate Australians. Other Australians, visitors or immigrants, go there to listen to friendly accents and to give parties for each other. New York isn't London, but there is an increasingly visible Australian community here, too.

title: On the plains, the weather plays a role.
description: Hollywood's current fascination with rural Americana has engendered, among other things, some special effects that are really special. Robert Benton's ''Places in the Heart,'' Richard Pearce's ''Country'' and Mark Rydell's ''River'' all feature elaborate storm sequences that measure the marvels of Hollywood technology against the elements themselves.

title: CUOMO FAULTS BIDS ON L.I. ROAD WORK
description: Governor Cuomo, saying that competitive bidding for state highway construction contracts on Long Island has been a failure, has called on state officials to authorize negotiated contracts for state road work in Nassau and Suffolk counties.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1984 International An agenda for arms control talks will be negotiated by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva Jan. 7 and 8, Washington and Moscow announced. The White House said the agenda would be for future negotitions on ''the whole range of questions concerning nuclear and outer space arms.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington is studying Moscow in an effort to determine whether the current Kremlin leadership is ready for decisive actions to help break the impasse in arms negotiations. (A1:4-5.)

title: Heirs Sue Over Implant Story
description: Heirs of the first permanent artificial heart recipient have filed a $2 million lawsuit against the Reader's Digest and Bantam Books for not publishing a book on the implant, court officials said Wednesday.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND ; Movies
description: The most romantic film of the year may also be the year's most unmistakably political, Andrzej Wajda's ''Love in Germany,'' in which Hanna Schygulla gives one of the finest performances of her career or, for that matter, of anyone else's. The film, at the Lincoln Plaza 1 Theater, ranks with Mr. Wajda's best, including the recent ''Danton'' and ''Man of Marble,'' and going all the way back to his early classics ''Kanal'' (1956) and ''Ashes and Diamonds'' (1958).

title: 2 Zimbabwean Rebels Given Death Sentences
description: Two Zimbabwean rebels were convicted today and sentenced to death by hanging for taking part in the kidnappng of six foreign tourists, including two Americans, in July 1982.

title: A double agenda for the Manhattan Theater Club.
description: A community of 17th-century Polish Jews ecstatic over what they expect to be the imminent arrival of the Messiah, a pit-bulldog fight in contemporary California, a mother who chokes to death on moo shu pork one night but then decides she is not quite ready to die and returns to monitor her family's goings-on, and a romance between a disillusioned New Yorker and a woman he meets at an art gallery opening when he discovers her underneath a pile of coats, with another man - such are the range of subjects scheduled to hit the boards in the coming season of the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: By John Gross;
description: THE ABANDONMENT OF THE JEWS.

title: STAFF CUTS FOR STATISTICAL AGENCIES ARE STUDIED
description: The eight major agencies that chart the health, economy and educational status of the United States and maintain the census of its people underwent an overall staff reduction of 12 percent in the first term of the Reagan Administration.

title: ONE-RING CIRCUS OPENS
description: It doesn't want to be the Greatest Show on Earth. Man and beast, the Big Apple Circus wants to be little and lovable.

title: WALKER PRAISED AT LAST
description: While the Knicks were beating the Cleveland Cavaliers, 109-101, Wednesday night in Richfield, Ohio, Coach Hubie Brown warned Butch Carter that the next time he failed to get back on defense, ''you're coming out of the game.''

title: Hockey Player Charged
description: A 20-year-old Canadian hockey player, Alain Harvey Chatlain, is being held in Czechoslovakia on three charges of assault and hooliganism after an attack on a 78-year-old arena usher in Prague, Canadian Government officials said. Chatlain, a member of a British Columbia junior team, is accused of beating the usher so severely that his eyesight is endangered. Canadian officials said the player will be held in Prague until the case is resolved, which could take several months.

title: Carlos Montoya
description: The flamenco guitarist Carlos Montoya will perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall (247-7800), Seventh Avenue at 57th Street. Tickets are $11.50 to $15.50.

title: President of Ukraine Dies
description: Alexei F. Vatchenko, president of the Republic of the Ukraine and one of 15 deputy presidents of the Soviet Union, died today at age 70 after an illness, the official Tass press agency said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Shower of White Light For the RCA Building
description: The 75-foot Norway spruce that is

title: A SMALL-TOWN BOXING CLUB PUTS YOUNG LIVES IN ORDER
description: When darkness settles over Main Street here, a faint thumph- thumph echoes from the windows above Citizens Hose Company No. 5.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Black, Starr & Frost Ltd. has named William T. Sharp to the new position of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: NO THREAT OF PLUTONIUM CONTAMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Thomas J. O'Rourke has joined the CIT Financial Corporation, Livingston, N.J., as senior vice president- marketing.

title: HEAVY FALL RAINS HAVE HARMED MISSISSIPPI GOTTON FARMERS
description: William Pearson has watched his dreams of a 2,200-bale cotton crop dissolve under almost 20 inches of rain in the last few weeks.

title: A Dedicated Volunteer
description: In 42 years Elsie Groundsel has piled

title: Sextet at Jazz Center
description: The tenor saxophonist Ricky Ford will play music by Wayne Shorter with a sextet - Jimmy Knepper on trombone, James Spaulding on saxophone and flute, Kirk Lightsey on piano, Rufus Reid on bass and Jimmy Cobb on drums - tomorrow at 9 and 10:30 P.M. at the Jazz Center of New York (505-5660), 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street. Tickets are $8, or a Theater Development Fund voucher plus $2, and $6 for students and the elderly.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE AND ROBBINS
description: Dance may be a physical art. Nevertheless, the New York City Ballet presented nothing but dreams and visions on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Herman Phleger Dies; Was Eisenhower Aide
description: Herman Phleger, a lawyer who served as a diplomat and an adviser in the Eisenhower Administration, died Wednesday at his home. He was 94 years old.

title: OIL PRICES DEFY PROPS BY OPEC
description: Petroleum prices have continued to fall even though the cold season has arrived and OPEC has trimmed its output ceiling.

title: CHINA'S FORGOTTEN CORNER DREAMS OF DAYS TO COME
description: This remote province, slightly larger than Texas, has more yaks than people.

title: Gunman Kills 8-Year-Old Boy AndHimselfasAnotherFlees
description: A man with a shotgun killed an 8-year-old relative whom he was holding hostage inside a house and then shot and killed himself today, ending a daylong standoff with the police.

title: Crash Landing for Free Enterprise
description: There was nothing inherently improper about President Reagan's decision to end a grand jury investigation of international airline price-fixing ''for reasons of foreign policy.'' Britain bitterly protested the inquiry into charges that government- owned British Airways had conspired to bankrupt Laker Airlines. No sensible person would argue that the investigation was worth jeopardizing relations with a close ally. But there is something troubling about the decision: the President's unwillingness to explain it.

title: Big, Big Numbers
description: Over time, modern society has begun to comprehend a billion. It's no longer an abstraction - not when China has a billion people, or a single ship, like a Ticonderoga cruiser, costs a billion dollars. But no sooner have we mastered that than we're forced to contend with the meaning of a trillion. A good place to start would be by agreeing on what to call it.

title: Jump Is Seen In Car Sales
description: Fifteen million cars and trucks will be sold in the United States next year, Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicts.

title: Don Bosco Beats Bergen Catholic, 13-0
description: In a warm-up to their Dec. 1 meeting for the North Jersey, Parochial A state playoff championship, Don Bosco Prep shut out Bergen Catholic, 13-0, yesterday in Ramsey. Both teams have 8-2 records.

title: Legislature Dissolved In South Indian State
description: The Legislative Assembly in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh was dissolved today, after completing less than two years of a scheduled five-year term, paving the way for a major popularity test for its ruler.

title: Geographic Drops Plan
description: National Geographic magazine has abandoned a plan to sell advertising in Canada in a special edition of the magazine.

title: Jazz and Cabaret
description: Roger Kellaway, an awesomely versatile and unpredictable pianist and composer, has been presenting a series of ''duets'' on Friday evenings since early last month in the intimate Upstairs room of the Greene Street Cafe. It has included an evening of gospel, blues and jazz with the singer Gail Wynters, an evening of chamber jazz with the bassist Michael Moore, an evening in which Mr. Kellaway played and sang with Adrienne Alpert his own songs as well as those of Igor Stravinsky, Edward Lear and Gene Lees, and an evening with the one-time Count Basie singer Irene Reid, recalling songs from an album she and Mr. Kellaway made 20 years ago. Tonight at 8:30, Mr. Kellaway will be joined by another remarkable musician, Toots Thielemans, the uncategorizable Belgian jazz virtuoso who expresses himself on harmonica, on guitar and through his whistling. A common thread tying Mr. Thielemans to Mr. Kellaway is the humor that bubbles through their music. Upstairs at the Greene Street Cafe is at 101 Greene Street (925-2415). Music charge, $10.

title: WOMAN SEEKS CHANGE IN RACIAL DESIGNATION
description: Lawyers for a woman who found out six years ago that her birth certificate had classified her as ''colored'' have asked a state appeals court to allow her to change the designation to ''white.''

title: Ceremonies Urged for Youths
description: A group of educators and scholars has suggested more school ceremonies as a way to help cut the soaring rates of teen-age suicides, murders and out-of- wedlock births.

title: ITALY STRESSES MORE EXPENSIVE WINES
description: Ezio Rivella was dwarfed by the tower of stainless steel tanks and tubes that, for anyone unfamiliar with modern wine making, could have been part of a gasoline refinery.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND ; Music
description: There are those who believe primitive man first made music with his voice; certainly today vocal music plays a central role in our musical experience. In the realm of Classical music, three especially interesting events offer vocal music in three guises this weekend: large-scale sacred, large-scale secular and solo song.

title: BONN SEES STRENGTH FOR DOLLAR
description: Karl Otto P"ohl, president of West Germany's central bank, predicted today, with some caution, that the dollar would continue its strong performance.

title: A.&P. Nears Pact With U.S. WASHINGTON, Nov. 22
description: The Justice Department has tentatively agreed to

title: STATE, AND FARMERS, WISHING DEER HUNTERS LUCK
description: At harvest time this fall, Ben Feder recalled, deer were everywhere, nibbling at the grapevines in his vineyard.

title: U.S. GRANT'S ADVICE ON NOT INTERVENING
description: To the Editor:

title: PICTURE CALENDARS ON DISPLAY
description: First you see the portrait of the infant. Its curly hair flops over its forehead, the folds of baby fat in its neck supporting the chubby cheeks that surround the rosebud lips. It wears its woolen hat at a winsomely rakish angle, and its large, appealing eyes are open wide, staring off into the distance.

title: CONCERT: CLASSICAL QUARTET
description: By general consent,'' wrote Charles Rosen in the book that by general consent best explains the period in music we call Classical, ''Mozart's greatest achievement in chamber music is the group of string quintets with two violas.'' So when the Classical Quartet sat down with the guest violist Judson Griffin to play three of them Tuesday at Christ and St. Stephen's, an evening of rare richness was promised.

title: WEEKENDERR GUIDE
description: Friday VICTORIAN WORLD IN 3-D AT PARK

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Pontiac, Mich. The Knicks opened their season last month by beating the Pistons at Madison Square Garden despite a 22-point, 16-assist effort by Isiah Thomas. The clubs have not met since. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Thanksgiving Closings
description: All Government offices, banks and stock and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving Day. The weekly money supply report will be released today.

title: LEBANES LEADER URGES CHANGES IN POWER-SHARING ARRANGEMENTS
description: President Amin Gemayel, marking the 41st anniversary of Lebanon's independence, called today for a new national charter governing coexistence between Christian and Moslem communities.

title: FIVE QUIT CABINET IN QUEBEC DISPUTE
description: A revolt within Quebec's governing separatist party led to the resignations of five provincial Cabinet ministers today.

title: Indian Crafts Auction
description: An auction to benefit a scholarship fund set up by the Thunderbird American Indian Dancers will highlight the group's annual autumn pow-wow tomorrow at the McBurney Y.M.C.A., 215 West 23d Street.

title: ABRAHAM AILON
description: Abraham Ailon, an owner of residential hotels in New York City, died last Sunday in Virginia Beach, Va., where he had lived in retirement. He was 67 years old.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENT ON U.S.-SOVIET ARMS CONTROL TALKS
description: Following is a transcript of a statement today on arms talks by Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, as recorded by the White House. A similar statement was issued in Moscow.

title: E.E.C. Nuclear Power
description: Nuclear power should provide about 40 percent of the European Economic Community's electricity in 1995, rising to about 50 percent by the year 2000, the European Commission said today. The Commission said in a statement that by 1990 electricity from nuclear power should meet about 14 percent of the Common Markets's total energy needs and 35 percent of its electricity production.

title: A Colonial Tour
description: The colonial history of Lower Manhattan will be covered on a free walking tour and exhibition tomorrow at Battery Park sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers.

title: P. Y. CHEN
description: P. Y. Chen, a longtime United Press International correspondent, died today in the Taiwan Adventist Hospital.

title: An Iowa Sport
description: The University of Iowa stunned the field-hockey world by upsetting the second- and third-seeded teams to get to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's championship tournament. Field hockey, after all, is supposed to be an Eastern sport.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: Robert Lyon and Ron Morici are keeping a Philadelphia tradition alive. So is Henry Di Stefano. The tradition lives in a little restaurant in a quiet neighborhood of row houses and shops at 13th and Dickinson in South Philadelphia, not far from Broad Street, a place called the Victor Cafe.

title: 2 ALSATIAN MAYORS GIVE A SNUB TO MITTERRAND
description: The mayors of two French cities and other elected officials boycotted a state visit to Alsace today by President Francois Mitterrand. The President reacted with what was described by reporters as deep anger.

title: Opportunity Knocks
description: Bobby Ross, the Maryland football coach, is being considered at Missouri as a replacement for Warren Powers, who was dismissed this week. But Ross, who signed a multiyear contract with Maryland after rejecting feelers from Rice, Minnesota and the Houston Oilers a year ago, said he had not talked directly to Missouri officials and didn't plan to until after Maryland's game tomorrow against Virginia.

title: LIBYA OFFICIAL SAYS TROOPS WILL LEAVE CHAD DESPITE DELAY
description: The Libyan Foreign Minister said today that Libyan soldiers would leave Chad despite a delay in carrying out a troop withdrawal agreement with France.

title: Bombing in Chilean Port
description: A powerful car bomb exploded outside police and Government offices early today, damaging shops, shattering dozens of windows and waking residents across this Chilean port city.

title: SUIT FILED TO STOP TESTS OF BIOLOGICAL WEAPONS
description: A suit to block the Army's proposal to expand its biological weapon-testing center in Utah was filed in Federal Distrcit Court Wednesday.

title: Texas Police Think Bad Debt Led to Shooting Spree in Bar
description: A man accused of killing one person and wounding five others in a barroom shooting spree might have been aiming for a bar patron who owed him money but was not injured in the attack, the police say.

title: THE EBB AND THE FLOW OF SEQUOIA'S FORTUNES
description: The Sequoia, the former yacht of Presidents, is back at its East Potomac Park dock with a new commanding officer, a new board of trustees, some fresh caulk in its seams, fresh paint on its beams and hopes of entertaining still another leader of the nation.

title: AS TALKS NEAR, U.S. STRAINS TO DIVINE MOSCOW'S OMENS
description: The Reagan Administration is looking at the Soviet Union these days through a particularly narrow focus: It is trying to find out if the Kremlin's leaders are ready for decisive actions to help break the impasse in Soviet-American negotiations and produce arms control agreements with Washington.

title: DeSoto Chief Welcomes A Looser Link to Sears
description: When Richard R. Missar, the chairman of DeSoto Inc., announced this week that his company was buying back 867,609 shares of its stock from Sears, Roebuck & Company, it was a further assertion of DeSoto's independence from the giant retailer.

title: Carolers at Seaport
description: Beginning tonight at 7:15, free performances of holiday music will be presented at the South Street Seaport, Fulton and Water Streets. The music will be delivered by a ''living, singing Christmas tree,'' made up of the seaport's carolers standing on a pyramid-like structure simulating the holiday tree. The singers will perform through Dec. 31, with concerts Monday through Friday at 7:15 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday at 5:15.

title: Woman Wins Right to Visits To Child of Lesbian Ex-Lover
description: A woman has won the right to regular visits with the child her former lesbian lover bore six years ago through artifical insemination.

title: SCREEN
description: The most sobering film of the moment is also one of the most powerful: ''The Killing Fields,'' a precise and chilling account of Cambodia's agony at the hands of the Khmer Rouge. Though it is also a story of friendship between Sydney Schanberg, then a correspondent of The New York Times and now a Times columnist, and his Cambodian assistant, Dith Pran, ''The Killing Fields'' is less effective as a personal story than as an indictment of the Communists' brutality. Roland Joffe, whose previous directorial experience was with documentaries, gives this film a realistic and involving visual style. When tanks roll into Phnom Penh and Mr. Joffe pulls the camera backward as if daunted by their menace, he ably draws the audience into the populace's point of view. ''The Killing Fields'' is at Cinema I.

title: SAN FRANCISCO SURVEY FINDS 40% OF SINGLE MEN TO BE HOMOSEXUAL
description: Forty percent of the single men in San Francisco are homosexual, and most of them are well-educated and earning more than $20,000 a year, according to a professional survey.

title: Lynn Rejects Offer
description: Fred Lynn, the California Angels' free-agent outfielder, has rejected an Angel contract offer that would have forced him to take a sharp reduction in his $1.45 million annual salary. The 32-year-old, nine-time all-star was reportedly offered an $800,000 salary and bonus provisions.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY WEEKEND ; Stage
description: In ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' the outstanding new play of the season, the legendary blues singer Gertrude (Ma) Rainey and her band make music in a Chicago recording studio of 1927. By the time they've finished, the playwright August Wilson has transported the audience through a funny, spicy and finally searing exorcism of the black American experience in this century. As directed by Lloyd Richards, the cast is as tight and fervent as any blues ensemble. Theresa Merritt is the flamboyant, at times monstrous Ma Rainey; an explosive young actor named Charles S. Dutton plays a trumpeter who harbors his own dreams of show-business stardom. At the Cort, 138 West 48th Street (239-6200).

title: CABARET: CELESTE, A SINGER AND COMEDIENNE, AT FREDDY'S
description: A comedienne who is also a good singer often has difficulty calling attention to one talent without undercutting the other. Many years ago, Fanny Brice's popular Baby Snooks routine on radio overshadowed her earlier success as a serious and emotional singer with ''My Man.''

title: 20 ARE DECONTAMINATED IN TULSA IN APPARENT TOXIC CHEMICAL SPILL
description: Twenty people were taken to a fire station for showers and then sent home in jail clothes today after toxic PCB's apparently spilled from a capacitor on a utility pole that had been knocked down in a traffic accident, the authorities said.

title: East Orange Romps, 54-0 Bruce Williams, a senior running back, rushed for 134 yards
description: East Orange to 54-0 drubbing of

title: 2 MEN ELECTROCUTED WHILE RIDING ATOP A COMMUTER TRAIN IN JERSEY
description: Two 21-year-old men riding atop an N.J. Transit commuter train were killed yesterday when they were electrocuted by the train's power arm, authorities said. One of the men was also hurled into the path of an oncoming Amtrak train outside Newark.

title: Diner's Journal
description: When the thermometer plummets and steam rises from the manholes, mother's age-old plea to put ''something warm in your stomach'' before heading out the door seems to carry a belated aroma of logic. But even the most enthusiastic home cooks may find preparing anything more than strong coffee too much of a challenge before noon.

title: KOREAN THAW: A TRUNING POINT OF JUST AN INTERLUDE?
description: South Korean analysts and foreign diplomats say they see possible policy changes in North Korea that are pushing it toward more regular contact with non-Communist governments, including the one in Seoul. The start of economic talks between the two Koreas last week and their agreement to resume the discussions in early December have produced a broadly held view here that a shift in Korean relations could be occurring.

title: ALABAMA PRISON SUIT SETTLEMENT SEEN NEARER
description: Conditions in Alabama's state prisons have improved to the point that it may be possible to settle a Federal lawsuit charging the prison system violated the constitutional protection against cruel and unusual punishment, according to representatives of prison officials and inmates.

title: Taxes on Reagan Ranch Up
description: President Reagan, who opposes raising Federal taxes, has himself been hit with a slight tax increase by Santa Barbara County. Mr. Reagan has received a $2,841 bill for property taxes on his ranch near here, up $76.68 from last year, according to The Santa Barbara News-Press.

title: BRIDGE ; WOMEN, IN NUMBER OF WAYS, MAKE MARK AT THE NATIONALS
description: Women have made their mark in several ways during the Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League here this week.

title: ONE RANGER NEED IS FILLED BY FTOREK
description: Unassumingly, Robbie Ftorek came back to the Rangers this week. Like a repairman on call, he laid out his tool satchel and worked with no celebration, no sense of redemption.

title: MICHIGAN COUPLE SETTLE SUIT IN KILLING OF SON
description: Five years ago a policeman killed Charles and Lauretta Riddle's youngest son.

title: FLAWS SLOWING PEOPLE MOVER PROJECT
description: A year before it is scheduled to move anyone anywhere, Detroit's People Mover rail loop has become a high-technology headache.

title: STAGE: AT ST. CLEMENT'S, NEW 'EARTHY DELIGHTS'
description: ''The Garden of Earthly Delights,'' Martha Clarke's theatrical realization of the Hieronymus Bosch painting, first presented last season as a work in progress, has returned to St. Clement's in finished form. Whether one approaches it as theater, dance or music - or, more aptly, as a blending of the performing and visual arts - it is a work of exhilarating beauty.

title: Hitler-Diary Forger Is Rearrested
description: The confessed forger of Hitler's diaries, Konrad Kujau, was arrested today one week after being freed from custody.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We just don't see things like this back home.'' - Aileen Rice, of Maggie Valley, N.C., at Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. (B3:6.)

title: Aid for Needy Infants
description: Hunger is affecting more and more

title: ALASKA COMPANY OFFERS USED PIPELINE CAMPS
description: Half the 30 construction camps used in building the $8 billion Trans-Alaska Pipeline during the mid-1970's have been sold for an undisclosed amount to an Anchorage concern that specializes in the resale of construction camp equipment.

title: WHERE THE CHRISTMAS SEASON IS ALREADY OVER
description: Kermit has finally been outfitted in the red suit that turned him from a frog into Santa Claus. Two horses must still be painted, and some dolls have yet to receive their applications of lace, velvet and yak hair. But most of the inventory at Spaeth Design has already been shipped to stores - including the Fifth Avenue windows of Lord & Taylor and Saks - and to shopping malls. It is only when the nation's stores are beginning to look like Christmas, in fact, that Spaeth no longer does.

title: Whalers 9, Penguins 3
description: Greg Malone scored two goals and collected three assists, and Mark Johnson added two goals to spark Hartford.

title: Guilty Plea Filed In Doll Importing
description: A New Jersey importer has pleaded guilty to filing false documents with the Customs Service in an attempt to import counterfeit Cabbage Patch dolls for sale in this country.

title: 'THE EWOK ADVENTURE,' SUNDAY MOVIE ON ABC
description: George Lucas, creator of the ''Star Wars'' trilogy and the executive producer and co-writer of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and ''Indiana Jones and The Temple of Doom,'' all box-office gold mines, is bringing his imagination and special effects to television this Sunday. ''The Ewok Adventure,'' a Lucasfilm Ltd.-Korty Films production, can be seen on Channel 7 at 8 P.M. Although it is being promoted as family entertainment, the younger the viewer, the better.

title: PENNSYLVANIA MOVES TO EXPAND HEATING PLAN
description: Pennsylvania's share of the Federal program to help low-income families pay their heating bills is expected to shrink next year under a new distribution formula that shifts money to Southern states.

title: Auto Light Rules Changed To Match Those of Europe
description: Some Federal automobile lighting standards have been changed to conform with European standards, the Transportation Department said Wednesday.

title: REAL MARIJUANA ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoover Plant
description: The Hoover Company said it plans to build an assembly plant in Juarez, Mexico, as part of efforts to compete more effectively with foreign manufacturers.

title: U.S. DRIVE OPPOSES SOUTH AFRICAN RACIAL POLICIES
description: Less than 24 hours after their release from jail, Walter E. Fauntroy, the delegate to Congress from the District of Columbia, and two other black leaders announced a national campaign to oppose South Africa's policies of racial separation.

title: Jets Add Defensive Back The Jets signed another defensive back yesterday, this one a former Giant, Mike Dennis, as the wounded team prepared for Monday
description: night's game, against the Dolphins in Miami. Pat Ryan, for the second consecutive practice day, did not participate in the passing drills, an indication that Ken O'Brien would be the

title: 3 KOREANS KILLED AS SOLDIERS TRADE SHOTS IN THE DMZ
description: North Korean troops and soldiers of the United Nations Command opened fire on each other Friday in a clash that erupted over an apparent defection by a Soviet citizen at the Demilitarized Zone.

title: Disputed Coast Atom Plant Producing 30% of Capacity
description: The Unit 1 reactor of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant generated electricity at 30 percent of its full capacity today, its highest level of output in the plant's rocky 16-year history, and officials predicted the facility will soon produce 50 percent of its power.

title: IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE FOR US TO MONITOR FLIGHT 007
description: To the Editor:

title: Squeeze Play
description: A top Finnish sports official who destroyed evidence that an Olympic runner had taken steroids has now lost his job, after the athlete described his extensive use of the hormones in a new book about his career. The official, Antti Lanameki , was dismissed as chief coach of the Finnish Athletic Association after disclosing that he had destroyed test results showing that Martti Vainio , a star distance runner, had taken steroids before the Rotterdam Marathon last April.

title: CALIFORNIA'S DESERT OASIS GETS A DOSE OF PROGRESS
description: For years this city has been known as the exclusive playground of wealthy, influential sun worshipers and Hollywood stars. Shielded from the daily grind by the San Jacinto Mountains and miles of scrubby desert, Palm Springs bloomed with golf courses, tennis courts and swimming pools into a refuge for those seasonal visitors and retirees who could afford it.

title: KING SCORES 45
description: The Knicks defeated the Detroit Pistons, 120-97, tonight at the Silverdome on the strength of an old offensive weapon and a new one.

title: Dave Maloney Out
description: Dave Maloney , the Ranger defenseman, will be out of the lineup tonight when his team plays the Nordiques at Quebec.

title: U.S. WOULD MAKE MUTUAL RESTRAINT ARMS TALK TOPIC
description: The Administration said today that ''mutual restraint'' in such areas as the deployment of new nuclear missiles in Europe would be an appropriate item for discussion when arms control talks are renewed with the Soviet Union.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Sturz Says He's Staying
description: There are always rumors,'' said

title: Philippine Rebels Kidnap 2 American Tourists
description: Moslem rebels kidnapped two American tourists this week on a remote island in the southern Philippines, a United states Embassy spokesman said today.

title: J. Waldo Ackerman, A Chief Judge, Is Dead
description: J. Waldo Ackerman, chief judge of the Federal District Court for Central Illinois, who had been a Federal judge for eight years, died today at Memorial Medical Center. He was 58 years old.

title: GOOD FEELINGS FOR A RUNNER
description: Nearly four months ago, on the day of the most awaited race in the history of women's distance running, Cathy Schiro of Dover, N.H., was in front, a position she has grown more accustomed to as her career has developed. But on that day, Aug. 5, the day of the first Olympic marathon for women, she was merely in front of a television.

title: Redmen Win In Exhibition Chris Mullin scored 21 points
description: as St. John's routed Palmeiras

title: 2D EFFORT TO IMPLANT AN ARTIFICIAL HEART PLANNED TOMORROW
description: Doctors in Louisville, Ky., said last night that they had selected a 52-year- old man to be the recipient of the second permanent artificial heart and that they planned to implant it in him Sunday morning.

title: Colgate Rule Called Takeover Defense
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company, which has been mentioned as a takeover candidate lately, disclosed yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its board had amended its bylaws to make it more difficult to call special meetings.

title: BRITISH DECISION IS SAID TO CLOUD UNESCO'S FUTURE
description: Delegates to Unesco said here today that a decision by Britain to withdraw from the agency unless major changes were made could threaten Unesco's survival in the long term.

title: Sonoma Warns Of Chapter 11
description: Sonoma Vineyards said it would have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if it does not obtain substantial financing or continue to receive creditor support.

title: NO WAY TO RUN KENNEDY AIRPORT
description: When a foreign head of state arrives at John F. Kennedy International Airport, his entry into the United States is gloriously simple, thanks to red carpets, limousines and police escorts. But the procedure that takes tourists, foreign or American, through the International Arrivals Building can be maddening.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1984
description: International

title: Books of The Times; Essays: A Joy Forever
description: THE PENGUIN BOOK OF CONTEMPORARY AMERICAN ESSAYS. Maureen Howard, editor. Viking. 285 pages.

title: Two Arraigned in Plot To Smuggle Bacteria
description: Two Canadians were arraigned here today in connection with an attempt to acquire potentially deadly bacteria and smuggle it into Canada, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: A FEDERAL GRANT TO ADD TO POWER ON METRO-NORTH
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad has received a $14.8 million Federal grant to help rebuild the power system on the Hudson and Harlem Lines, officials said yesterday.

title: MISSING THE HAND TOOL BOOM
description: By all rights, with the baby boom generation buying and fixing up houses, sales of tools for the do-it-yourself market should be humming. And, indeed, the industry-leading Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., with a vigorous marketing and advertising campaign to make its name synonymous with quality, is forging record sales and profits.

title: Transactions
description: Signed Craig Piette, free-agent right wing.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day Wednesday about a railroad and natural resources company's plan to repurchase 10 million shares of its common stock misstated the company's name. It is the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

title: New Procedures Used To Remove a Tenant
description: In the first police action to use procedures developed after a Bronx woman was shot to death during an eviction, officers removed a 69-year-old woman from her Bronx apartment last night for psychiatric evaluation.

title: ON THE BOWERY, A SEASONAL GIFT OF GLOVES
description: On a crisp sunny morning this week, a jaunty little man with a canvas bag slung over his shoulder walked briskly through the Bowery handing out pairs of gloves. In his wake, the sidewalks were dotted with men who had stopped to slip on the gloves and take a moment to admire them.

title: PORT AGENCY TO RULE ON RESUMING FERRY SERVICE ACROSS THE HUDSON
description: Regular ferryboat service between New York and New Jersey would resume after nearly two decades under a proposal being completed for the Port Authority.

title: Price of Losing
description: As the college football season winds down, coaches with disappointing records continue to fall by the wayside. The latest to do so is Joe Avezzano , whose Oregon State teams have managed only 6 victories in 55 games over 5 seasons. Yesterday John Byrne , the university's president, announced that Avezzano would not be back next year. No successor was named, but Sam Boghosian , a former Oregon State assistant now with the Los Angeles Raiders, and Dennis Erickson , Idaho's head coach, are considered leading candidates.

title: Contingency Refunds
description: Caveat gambler. A numbers parlor

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not saying that I anticipated it happening, but I'm saying that we had a chance and that's all I can ask for.'' - Doug Flutie, Boston College quarterback, after desperation touchdown pass. (19:4.)

title: French Economic Rise
description: The French gross domestic product rose 1 percent in the third quarter after falling by five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, the National Statistics Institute said in a provisional report today. In the third quarter of 1983, the G.D.P. had shown no change.

title: Fight Over Eligibility
description: Albert Butts , a 24-year-old senior who plays center for LaSalle's basketball team, has been declared ineligible but promises to fight the ruling in court. The decision was handed down by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which found that Butts had violated a special rule limiting eligibility for athletes who, before entering college, participated in ''organized competition'' and were over age 20 when they did so.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allied Products Corp., Chicago, said it had agreed in principle to buy the assets of Xonics Inc. for $5 million in cash and stock. Xonics and its subsidiaries are operating as debtors in possession, subject to the jurisdiction of a Federal bankruptcy court.

title: VENICE PREMIERE IN 1857
description: ''Simon Boccanegra,'' the 21st of Verdi's 28 operas, failed at its Venice premiere in 1857. La Scala heard his revision of the score, with a remodeled libretto by Arrigo Boito, in 1881, when the starry cast included Victor Maurel, Francesco Tamagno and Edouard de Reszke.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
THANKS RENDERED, HOLIDAY SHOPPERS BEGIN IN EARNEST
description: Diagonally across from the Museum of Modern Art and directly in front of a ''No Standing'' sign, the driver of a station wagon came back to find a parking ticket on the car's windshield. ''They can't do this today,'' he said to no one in particular. ''Today's a holiday, isn't it?''

title: ITALIAN CASE UNCOVERS AN ALPINE HEART OF DARKNESS
description: This northern mountain city, known for its cautious Roman Catholicism, sweet Alpine air and a love of peace and quiet, has become the center of charges of dark international conspiracies.

title: Trophy Winners On the Block
description: The winner of the Heisman Trophy will be announced a week from today, and once more, just as in every other year for the last half-century, the man considered the best college football player in the nation will leave the Downtown Athletic Club with a rare honor - rare, that is, in the minds of most people.

title: 5 Convicts Are Recaptured After Virginia Prison Break
description: The last of five inmates who escaped from a southern Virignia prison was captured tonight about a half-mile from the institution, the authorities said.

title: Strong-Mayor Government Is Defeated in Yonkers Vote
description: A proposition to change the form of Yonkers government by eliminating the city- manager post and making the mayor more powerful has been defeated, officials said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Zola Budd , who plans to enter a five-mile road race in Zurich next month, said she had made no plans for further races. ''At the moment, I'm keeping my options open,'' she said at a news conference in South Africa. . . . Yannick Noah , playing in his first tournament since June, was upset by Mark Dickson in the quarterfinals of the Toulouse Grand Prix in France. Noah had been sidelined the last five months because of a groin injury. . . . Valerie Brisco-Hooks will compete in the Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Jan. 25, according to Howard Schmertz , the meet director.

title: New Belgian Tax Rules
description: Belgium has devised new tax rules for affiliates of United States companies known as foreign sales corporations, Willy De Clercq, the Foreign Minister, said today. He said the new tax rules would effectively limit the taxable income in Belgium of each foreign sales corporation.

title: Florida Cypress Dissident Move
description: Florida Cypress Gardens Inc. said Harold Lieberman, a Winter Haven, Fla., investor, had said that he would seek liquidation of the company and urge shareholder support for the action if the company's chairman, Dick Pope, does not sell his 43.9 percent interest to an investor group.

title: 4 Employees Sue Capitol Air Four employees of financially struggling Capitol Air
description: Inc. filed a suit in bankruptcy

title: U.S. PLANS TO BAN LEAD SHOT IN SOME AREAS TO SAVE EAGLES
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service, concerned about lead poisoning of American bald eagles, is planning to ban the use of lead shot in the 1985-86 hunting season in five counties in California, Oregon and Missouri.

title: More Than 2 Million Serving Armed Forces on Active Duty
description: The Defense Department said today that 2.14 million people were serving on active duty in the armed forces at the end of October.

title: ALLIED: CENTER OF ATTENTION
description: The name of the Allied Corporation, which swallowed the Bendix Corporation last year in perhaps the wildest and woolliest of takeover battles, crops up often when Wall Street professionals start to spin acquisition stories.

title: 10 Hurt in British Mine Violence
description: Ten people were injured today in violence on picket lines near struck coal mines, and the National Coal Board said 800 more miners had abandoned their eight-month-old walkout and returned to work.

FLORIDA GALE KILLS MAN AND FORCES EVACUATION
description: Up to 1,000 people living along a 10-mile stretch of ocean front were evacuated tonight as heavy seas battered the Florida coast, killing one man, beaching a cargo vessel, flooding roads and destroying a pier. Gov. Bob Graham declared a state of emergency for Volusia and St. Johns Counties tonight, said Mick Collins, an official with the Florida division of emergency management.

description: The world's major non-Communist industrial nations

title: Solidarity Activist Seized On Broadcasts Charge
description: A Solidarity activist who was a witness in cases of reported kidnappings of members of the banned Polish trade union has been arrested and charged with making illegal broadcasts, the official press agency P.A.P. said today.

description: Craig Hartsburg's overtime goal gave the Minnesota North Stars a 5-4 victory over the Devils in National Hockey League play tonight.

title: Swazi Ex-Official Detained
description: A former Swazi Finance Minister, Sishayi S. Nxumalo, was detained by the police for questioning Thursday, sources close to his family said here today. Mr. Nxumalo was dismissed as Finance Minister in June, shortly after he charged that unidentified prominent figures in Swaziland were implicated in a $10.4 million customs fraud.

Bail Reduced for 2 In Manslaughter
description: Two Wantaugh, L.I., men charged with manslaughter in the death of a young woman who was hit by a car after an argument in a parking lot had their bail lowered today to $10,000.

description: The saxophonist Buddy Tate and the trombonist Al Grey are leading a quintet through tomorrow at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is an $8 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; 10 U.S. Diplomats Leave Colombia After Threats
description: More than 10 American diplomats and their families have left Colombia because of threats from drug traffickers angered by a United States-Colombian crackdown on international cocaine smuggling, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Memorial Climb
description: -man American team led by Lou Whittaker of Ashford, Wash., completed a successful ascent up the north wall of Mount Everest, 29,028 feet high. With the 11 other team members spread out among 6 camps that had been created on the way up, it was Phil Ershler who actually got to climb to the summit of the world's highest mountain. Ershler, a 33-year-old mountain guide from Bellevue, Wash., used bottled oxygen for the final three hours of his climb, and finally reached the peak shortly before sunset.

title: 2 in Traffic Plane Are Hurt in Crash
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 23 - A light airplane being used to monitor traffic crashed today just west of the Sprain Brook Parkway in Westchester County, critically injuring the pilot and a passenger.

title: STRONG EARTHQUAKE HITS CALIFORNIA AND NEVADA, CAUSING ROCK SLIDES
description: A strong earthquake today jolted a wide area of central California and western Nevada, causing rock slides and knocking items from shelves as it rolled from the mountains to the sea. There were no immediate reports of injuries or serious damage.

title: The Ins and Outs of Ireland In diplomatic reports, ''full and frank'' talks are those that fail to reach agreement. Britain's Prime Minister Thatcher went even further in describing her recent meeting with Ireland's Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald. ''That is out'' is how she dealt with his Government's three ideas for ending the agony in Northern Ireland.
description: Mrs. Thatcher may be in no mood for concessions to Irish nationalism so soon after she was nearly killed by the bomb of its violent fringe. But if Britain persists in rejecting every peaceful change, the hit-squads of the Irish Republican Army will be the beneficiaries. This is doubly true if Britain also fails to address the legitimate grievances about criminal justice in Northern Ireland.

title: POPE MAY REVIEW THEOLOGY DISPUTE
description: Pope John Paul II is said to have asked the Vatican to prepare a new statement on the theology of liberation, this time taking into account the views of the many Latin American bishops who support social activism by the clergy.

PATENTS ;
Way to Dispose of Old Nuclear Power Plants
description: A method of disposing of shutdown nuclear power plants was patented this week for Alfred Kunz & Company of Munich, West Germany.

title: HARVARD IS BATTLING ALL-MALE CLUBS
description: They are the last vestiges of an age that is past at Harvard College: nine all- male, private clubs, tucked away behind unmarked doors and tall hedges in the narrow and winding streets off Harvard Square.

title: British Tax Proposal
description: The British Government said today that it plans to eliminate a tax break for multinational corporations that have set up units with dual residency in the United States and Britain. The proposed legislation would prevent such units from claiming tax relief on borrowing costs in both the United States and Britain. Inland Revenue, a Government agency, estimated that 100 multinational corporations use dual- resident companies ''just for tax relief reasons,'' depriving the British Treasury of about $125 million a year.

title: DUARTE WILL NOT ATTEND PEACE TALKS NEXT WEEK
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that he would not attend peace talks with rebel officials next week because the meeting is intended to deal only with procedural matters for future negotiations.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Pacers' Vern Fleming, who played at Mater Christi in Queens, at Georgia and with the United States Olympic team, makes his New York pro debut. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:30 P.M.)

description: WASHINGTON An ultrasonic instrument that has been used successfully in treating glaucoma, a sight- threatening disease, will be patented next week for the Riverside Research Institute and Cornell University Medical College in New York City.

title: RARE WOODPECKERS NOT WELL PROTECTED BY U.S., GROUPS SAY
description: Several conservation groups have charged that the Interior Department has failed to take adequate steps to protect a colony of endangered red-cockaded woodpeckers in the D'Arbonne National Wildlife Refuge in Louisiana from the effects of gas drilling.

title: BONN CABINET SAID TO OPPOSE SEA TREATY
description: A majority of the West German Cabinet is now opposed to signing an international convention on controlling the use of the sea and its resources, a senior aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said this week.

title: Transactions
description: Waived Robert Smith, guard. Signed Mark West, free agent forward-center. COLLEGES OREGON STATE - Announced it would not rehire Joe Avezzano, football coach.

title: Stimuli for Chiefs
description: Coach John Mackovic, whose Kansas City Chiefs meet the Giants in East Rutherford, N.J., Sunday, has watched his players struggle to a 5-7 record, but was that any reason to bring a box of dog biscuits to practice yesterday? ''I was interested in talking to them about stimulus response,'' the coach said, ''so I told the guys about the experiments of Pavlov and his dogs.

title: RETHINKING POLICY TOWARD SOUTH ASIA
description: It took the tragic death of Mrs. Indira Gandhi to bring India back into the American consciousness. But this shocking event may have provided an opportunity to correct a thus far misconceived and provocative American policy in South Asia.

title: ARAFAT'S SUPPORTERS CLAIM A VICTORY
description: Yasir Arafat's supporters in the Palestine Liberation Organizaition said today that they had legitimized his leadership by assembling a quorum of delegates at a meeting here of the Palestinian parliament in exile.

title: PLAN FOR HIGH-SPEED TRAIN ON WEST COAST IS SCRAPPED
description: For almost three years an ambitious plan has been afoot to build America's first high-speed rail line along the coast between Los Angeles and San Diego. The trains would run at speeds over 100 miles an hour, like the sleek trains that race between Tokyo and Osaka, London and Edinburgh, and Paris and Lyons.

title: CORRECTION

FLUTIE'S PASS ON LAST PLAY OVERCOMES MIAMI BY 47-45
description: Doug Flutie enhanced his legend today with a last- play touchdown pass that soared 64 yards, just out of reach of three defenders at the goal-line and into the hands of Gerard Phelan to give Boston College a 47-45 victory over Miami.

title:

A Computer Screen Sensitive to the Touch
description: A screen that is sensitive to the touch and might be used, instead of a keyboard, with a personal computer has been invented for the Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. Finger pressure can be applied to control the intensity of sound or color, or to actuate drawings.

title: CELTICS HALT BULLETS
description: Larry Bird scored 13 of his game-high 29 points in the third quarter and Kevin McHale sparked a 12-2 fourth-quarter surge as the Boston Celtics avenged their only loss of the season with a 118-110 victory over the Washington Bullets tonight.

description: The Hudson shimmers in the sunlight. Across the river, some of the Palisades trees still wear the last vestiges of foliage.

description: The Greek Supreme Court has overturned a one- year libel sentence against a Cypriot journalist who asserted in a book that Greece's largest-selling daily newspaper operated in cooperation with the K.G.B.

title: Boy, 11, Is Killed Trying To Prevent Kidnapping
description: A would-be kidnapper shot an 11-year-old boy to death Thursday when he tried to prevent the abduction of his 13-year-old cousin, the authorities said.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'SIMON BOCCANEGRA'
description: Of all the mature Verdi operas, ''Simon Boccanegra'' is the hardest to come to grips with, both for performers and audiences. It has never taken the place in the standard repertory that by rights it should, although it contains some of the most powerful music the composer ever wrote. There are just too many drab stretches along the way. However, despite its unremitting gloom, the opera grows on one and a respectable performance such as the Metropolitan Opera put on last night always seems to win over a few new converts.

title: ITEMS UNDER RECALL OR FOUND TO NEED REPAIR
description: The following were recalled voluntarily by manufacturers in the last year under agreement with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Children should not be permitted to use any of them and they should be returned to the retail store or manufacturer for refund or replacement.

title: A BASIC SCHISM IN U.S. ELECTION POLITICS
description: The debate about whether the 1984 election signified a realignment misses the point. The fundamental feature of contemporary American politics is a schism involving two distinct systems - one national, the other state and local.

title: IN SUPERMARKETS, IS THE HEALTH FOOD HEALTHY?
description: Most of us spend as little time in the supermarket as possible. We move quickly and knowledgeably down the aisles, plucking the items on the shopping list off the shelves, never looking to the left or right of them. Before we notice a new product or an old product in a new guise we have usually heard of it through advertising or from a friend.

title: Flu Vaccine Is Expected To Protect Most People
description: It is too early to tell whether the 1984-1985 influenza season will be serious or mild, but the flu vaccine available this winter should protect most people, Federal health officials said today.
