title: Kristin Ann Kliemann Is Wed to Eric F. Sweeting
description: Kristin Ann Kliemann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Kliemann of Fort Worth, Tex., was married in Brooklyn yesterday to Eric Francis Sweeting, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Sweeting of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Ann Quick of the New Utrecht Reformed Church in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Montauk Club.

title: FOR A U.S. COMMISSION ON THE SOVIET UNION
description: Because Americans are deeply divided about the Soviet Union, we have found it difficult to maintain a coherent policy toward that country. The result has been insecurity and missed opportunities. With the election over, we must think seriously about ways to improve the policy making process. One way would be to create a Soviet Assessment Commission to produce an annual report on the Soviet military, political and economic situations. Such a body could help build both our knowledge of our principal adversary and bipartisan consensus.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

All But Annexed Afghanistan Afghanistan ostensibly remains an independent country, with its own flag and seat in the U.N. But the reality is otherwise. A puppet Communist government totters in Kabul, held in place by 110,000 Soviet troops. What was supposed to be a limited and temporary intervention in 1979 has lasted longer than the Soviet Union's war against Hitler. The invaders have made four million Afghans stateless refugees in Pakistan and Iran - one-fourth of the population they allegedly came to assist.
description: In a now pious annual ritual, the United Nations has again admonished the Soviet Union with a gently worded resolution that calls for the withdrawal of ''foreign troops'' from Afghanistan. The General Assembly passed it for the fifth time last week, 119 to 20, with 14 abstentions. That's three more ayes than in 1983, which will hardly deter the Soviet Union from shrugging it off again.

title: . . . Spirits of 12th Night
description: Forty-two people from the Washington area are going to celebrate Twelfth Night at Berkeley Springs, W.Va. The trip is sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution's Resident Associate Program.

title: Robert Allen Marries Shirley Hui, Engineer
description: The marriage of Shirley Hui, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Y. Hui of Elmhurst, Queens, to Robert Mitchell Allen took place yesterday at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Sally Priesand performed the ceremony.

title: Don't Ban the Van, Use It Right
description: New York City's neglected subways and buses are natural targets for competition. That can be a stimulus to reform, but whether it's legal competition like private cars, or the illegal kind now offered by private passenger vans, it can also be destructive and only make matters worse.

title: 3 MORE FORMER OFFICERS CONVICTED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A Federal jury today convicted three former policemen and acquitted two others of taking bribes in a racketeering conspiracy that extorted $350,000 to protect illegal gambling in the city.

title: MAN FATALLY STABBED IN A DISPUTE OVER $1 HE FOUND IN A STORE
description: A 24-year-old computer supervisor was fatally stabbed Thursday in an argument over a $1 bill he found in a Brooklyn grocery store, and the police continued their search for suspects yesterday.

title: Transtechnology's Stake in Lundy
description: The Transtechnology Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 6.3 percent of Lundy Electronics and Systems Inc.'s common shares and was studying obtaining a role in directing the company's affairs.

title: U.S. FAULTS 2 COMPANIES FOR HANDLING OF DIOXIN
description: A report by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has accused two companies of the unsafe disposal of dioxin-contaminated waste from an upstate dump near Love Canal three years ago.

title: LEGAL LEGEND URGES VICTIMS TO SPEAK OUT
description: A few years ago, Karen Korematsu came home from high school in San Leandro, Calif., flushed with excitement. In a discussion in her social studies class on the internment of 112,000 Japanese- Americans during World War II, she learned for the first time how one man had gone to court to challenge the entire program.

title: Where to Send Help for Ethiopia
description: Following are some of the agencies accepting donations for famine relief in Africa. Mark checks ''African Famine Relief'' or as designated in the listing.

title: OPEC Cites '83 Export Drop
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that its crude oil exports declined 13.8 percent in 1983 from the previous year and that the value of the shipments dropped 20.25 percent.

PATENTS ;
A Method to Assemble Details of Family Trees
description: Complete charts of family relationships can be compiled with a method and apparatus patented this week by Louise A. Daly, a Seattle architect.

title: Fire Kills 4 in Illinois Family
description: A couple and two of their three children died early Thursday when fire broke out in their home here.

title: HONDURAN POLITICIANS QUIETLY RAISE ISSUE OF SUSPENDING VOTE
description: With the country's two major political parties mired in internecine warfare, Honduran politicians have quietly begun talking of suspending next year's presidential elections.

title: ANGLO GOLD MINES reports earnings for Year to June 30
Madison Shares
description: The Inspiration Resources Corporation said it had received nearly 6.9 million shares of Madison Resources Inc. in response to its exchange offer for four million shares.

title: STALIN'S KIN: LEGAL ISSUES
description: First Walter Polovchak. Then Andrei Berezhkov. Now Olga Peters. For the third time in recent years, an international controversy with legal as well as diplomatic overtones has arisen over the reluctance - or the presumed reluctance - of a teen-ager to move to the Soviet Union. The current episode involves Olga Peters, the 13- year-old American-born granddaughter of Joseph Stalin. She was taken to Moscow last month by her mother and seems destined to remain there whether she likes it or not, at least until she reaches 18, the Soviet age of majority.

title: A MATTER OF MUSCLES
description: There, in the living room of the

title: Marybeth Carney, Editor, Is a Bride in Garden City
description: Marybeth Carney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Carney of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kevin A. McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McCarthy, also of Garden City.

title: COMPUTER DIGESTS THE TALMUD TO HELP RABBIS
description: It can't perform bar mitzvahs or say a blessing over the wine, but the computer at Bar Ilan University is nonetheless challenging the traditional role of the rabbi as teacher and sage.

title: THE 'FIRST LADY' OF A WORLD OF ART
description: She borrows from castles and kings and barons and dukes, but she says the key to success is persistence, patience and connections.

title: Judge Postpones Hearing
description: A judge in Polk County, Ore., has postponed a hearing to determine permanent custody of 15 children who were taken from a religious commune, the Good Shepherd Tabernacle, after allegations were made that they were being abused. The hearing had been scheduled for Tuesday, but was postponed Wednesday until Dec. 17 by Polk County Circuit Judge Darrell Williams to give the state authorities more time to prepare their case. The motion for postponement was strongly protested by lawyers for the children's parents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1984 International American-Soviet ''mutual restraint'' in such areas as the deployment of new nuclear missiles in Europe would be an appropriate item for discussion when arms control talks are renewed, the Reagan Administration said. A spokesman for President Reagan made the comment in response to reports that the Administration had already decided to slow the rate of deployment of the Pershing 2, one of two types of medium-range missiles that are now being installed in Western Europe. (Page 1, Column 6.) Fighting in Panmunjom, the truce area separating North and South Korea, broke out between North Korean troops and United Nations Command soldiers over an apparent defection by a Soviet citizen. At least two North Korean soldiers and one South Korean were reported killed and an American soldier was wounded. It was the most serious incident in the truce area in eight years. (1:4.)

title: Rare Visitor: Leonardo
description: There are not many firsts in

title: Grains and Soybeans Are Mixed to Lower
description: The continued strength of the dollar against foreign currencies prompted mixed to lower futures prices for grains, soybeans and precious metals today.

title: FOREIGN AID BY U.S. IS TIED TO EXPORTS
description: In what Washington describes as an attempt to counter countries that unabashedly subsidize their exports, the United States is using funds intended for foreign aid to reduce the price of American exports.

title: EASE UP ON THE AMAZON
description: New roads bore into the soul of Amazonia, still the world's largest and least trampled tropical forest. Colonists with machetes and chain saws, gold prospectors and tradesmen are swarming in. Recently opened mines, power stations and heavy industries overlay an ecosystem never before so stressed. The frontiers are shrinking. But is this officially supported frenzy the most appropriate development path?

title: Malfunction Halts Traffic on Seaway
description: A malfunctioning lift bridge near Montreal has brought shipping on the St. Lawrence Seaway to a virtual standstill, Seaway officials said today.

title: Tawian Import Plan
description: Government officials are asking the legislature to approve plans to eliminate import taxes on 35 items and scale down those on 1,058 other items, officials said today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: Thailand's Prices Rise
description: Rising food and housing prices were largely responsible for increasing consumer prices in Thailand by three-tenths of 1 percent in October from September, the Department of Business Economics said today. Consumer prices were up five-tenths of 1 percent in October from a year earlier, the department said.

title: ADJOURNMENT IN TITLE CHESS
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, sealed his 41st move today to adjourn the 27th game of his title match against Gary Kasparov.

description: An inmate in a Texas prison was stabbed to death today, the 23d prisoner killed in a year of record violence in the state's penal system.

title: Your Money ; RETIREMENT PLAN'S LOANS
description: More and more workers are voluntarily accepting cuts in take-home pay in order to have the money placed in tax-sheltered retirement accounts. And many of the participants in these so-called 401(k) plans are borrowing from their plan accounts.

description: The world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov is deep into its third month now, and even the Soviet press has begun grumbling about the tedious string of draws.

description: A 19-year-old man was charged today with killing a 48-year-old woman in the same house where her husband's first wife was found murdered 11 years ago, the police said.

description: A consortium of 37 Western banks, led by the Deutsche Bank, the largest West German commercial bank, has assembled a loan package for East Germany totaling $400 million, the Deutsche Bank said today.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a merger in February 1984 with Famous Restaurants.

title: Honduran Aide Denies His Nation Seeks F-5's
description: The Ambassador of Honduras denied today that his Government had ever sought or wished to have a fleet of F-5 jet fighters.

title: Prices Up in Belgium
description: Belgium's wholesale prices rose very slightly in October from a month earlier and were up 4 percent from a year earlier.

title: Nature Walk in Queens
description: An identification walk is planned today at 10 A.M. through the Alley Pond Woodland Nature Center, Winchester Boulevard and Grand Central Parkway, in the Douglaston section of Queens.

title: AIR-GROUND PHONE BAN BY F.C.C. STIRS PROTEST
description: A decision by the Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday to deny permanent frequencies for air-to-ground phone service on commercial airlines has drawn a flurry of protest from proponents and a statement by an F.C.C. commissioner yesterday that the agency acted too hastily.

description: Before Representative Paul Simon, a Democrat, defeated Senator Charles H. Percy, a Republican, in the voting nearly three weeks ago, followers of politics here speculated on who would be able to take credit if Mr. Simon won: Mayor Harold Washington or Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak, the county Democratic chairman.

title: REAGAN APPOINTS LEGAL AID BOARD
description: Bypassing the Senate, President Reagan appointed 11 people today to the Legal Services Corporation's board of directors. The same 11 people previously failed to gain Senate confirmation, and one of the 11 did not get a Senate committee's approval.

title: Indian Police Question Reporter on Amritsar
description: The police in Amritsar interrogated an Associated Press reporter for five hours today in connection with a dispatch published abroad about the army assault last June on the Golden Temple, the holiest of Sikh shrines.

title: TV Notes; 'Testament' and 'Threads' to Depict The Aftermath of Nuclear Warfare
description: Nuclear war is coming to television again - one year after ABC's telecast of ''The Day After'' was seen by 100 million viewers. In the next two months, two films not before shown on American television will offer grim depictions of life after a nuclear conflict.

title: COLORADO TURNS TO OPEN THREAT OVER DENVER AIR
description: ''We've tried the easy things,'' an aide to Gov. Dick Lamm said. ''If this doesn't work, we'll have to look at what Governor Lamm calls 'some Draconian measures.' ''

title: MATTHEWS LOSES EFFORT TO QUESTION ACCUSED CO-CONSPIRATOR AT TRIAL
description: A Federal judge ruled today that an accused co- conspirator was not required to testify in the extortion and bribery trial of former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City.

description: A group searching for the Nazi fugitive Dr. Josef Mengele said today that the United States Ambassador here had agreed to follow up on Paraguayan promises to begin a manhunt.

title: Chile Banishes 9 Leftists; Rebels Kill a Conscript

The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Slocum of Newport, R.I. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, assisted by Canon D. Lorne Coyle, performed the ceremony.

They occurred soon after a round of demonstrations by antiabortion activists, and they were followed by an anonymous caller's claim that the bombs had been planted by the ''Army of God.''

title: CUP CHALLENGE LIST EXPECTED TO SHRINK
description: In the last year, a kind of guessing game has surfaced among yachtsmen who care about the America's Cup. The game plan has no purpose other than to stir speculation on how many of the original 24 challengers for the cup will be able to weather the financial burden of multimillion-dollar campaigns.

title: IS DRUG WAR MERELY A HOLDING ACTION?
description: Cocaine traffickers scored a significant victory last week. In Peru, the world's leading grower of coca leaf, the United States suspended its antidrug program after at least 20 workers were killed in a murderous raid on a coca eradication workers' camp. In Mexico, meanwhile, marijuana traffickers suffered an important defeat. Authorities there made the largest drug seizure ever recorded, destroying more than 10,000 tons of marijuana.

description: James Floyd, former operations supervisor for the Unit 2 reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, has asked a Federal court here to overturn his conviction for cheating on a test to requalify as a reactor operator.

description: TRENTON HUDSON COUNTY Republicans, a group that many outsiders believe exists only in folklore, are celebrating a notable achievement in the recent general election: a victory in the county Freeholder races for the first time since 1956.

description: Cynthia Anne Fetzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lee Fetzer of Wantagh, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Sargent Sundy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Sundy of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Paul C. Reisch performed the ceremony at Christ Lutheran Church.

title:
FOOD;
UNRAVELING CHINESE NOODLES
description: THE QUEST for a variety of Chinese pasta dishes goes hand in hand with the desire to understand the multifarious Chinese noodle. Which rice noodle is required for a deep-fried garnish? Which brand is best? How do I store fresh noodles? Just a walk down the aisle displaying noodles at a well-stocked Chinese market will send an aspiring cook into a state of utter confusion. Chinese pasta, however, is less bewildering when one realizes that there are only three primary, commonly used types: rice noodles, made of rice and water; cellophane noodles, made of mung-bean flour and water, and egg noodles, made of eggs, flour and water.

title: CHILE POLICE STAGE ROUNDUP IN CITIES
description: Chilean policemen and troops swept through 12 poor neighborhoods in the capital today, briefly rounding up hundreds of people for identification checks and arresting 42 men, human rights officials and residents said.

description: Freed in Athens

title: Measuring Pilots
description: New Navy flight training standards were reported in May. They required pilots to have slightly shorter torsos and legs but longer arms.

title: PUPIL PROGRAM CUT
description: A$135,000 state grant for early- childhood development in the Hewlett-Woodmere School District has been jeopardized because the district has removed its early-childhood administrator.

title: Headliners ; 'Friendly Artifact' If there was any doubt that
description: Fred Rogers is the nicest guy in the neighborhood, it was probably cleared up last week when he gave the nation the sweater off his back.

title: ;  International
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1984 More than 100 more Polish tourists on a cruise to West Germany have abandoned a ferryboat with the apparent intention of seeking political asylum, the West German border police said. The episode brings to 428 the number of Polish travelers who have jumped ship in West German ports in the last two weeks seeking to emigrate to the the West. (Page 1, Column 3.) U.S. and North Korean officers blamed each other for the exchange of gunfire at the Panmunjom truce area between North and South Korea Friday that left four soldiers dead and as many as six wounded. (3:3.)

description: John A. Jenkins writes frequently about legal matters for The New York Times Magazine.

title: IT'S 'NO FUN,' SAYS BROTHER OF PRESIDENT
description: Neil Reagan says he really does not want to attend another inauguration, that he hates the Thanksgiving Day drive to his brother's ranch and that, all in all, being President Reagan's brother is no fun.

title: Koch, Down by 5 Shots, Is Leader by 1 in Japan
description: Gary Koch, winner of the San Diego Open and the Bay Hill Classic this year, shot a 7-under-par 65 today to rally from a five-stroke deficit and take a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the $306,000 Casio World Golf tournament.

title: TRIBES DISPUTE RIGHT TO HUNT ON INDIAN LAND
description: A century ago, white hunters nearly wiped out the bison that fed and clothed the Plains Indians. Today Shoshone Indians are fighting again to preserve the few big game animals left on their reservation. But this time their opponent is another Indian tribe and the battlefield is a Federal court.

title: Robin D. Beard, an Editor, To Wed Daniel Chambers
description: Robin Dianne Beard, editor of 212 Magazine, a bimonthly on entertainment in New York, and Daniel Whitney Chambers, president of Vertical Advertising there and an associate publisher of 212, plan to be married in the spring.

title: Martha Rossi Is Married
description: At the Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan yesterday Martha Cleopatra Rossi, the daughter of Martha Alarcon Rossi of New York and the late Alfredo Francisco Rossi of New York and Guayaquil, Ecuador, was married to Carl John Ray by the Rev. Stanert Dransfield. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon T. Ray of Watchung, N.J., and a grandson of the late John H. Ray, a former member of the House of Representative from New York.

In ''The Lucky Piece'' and ''The Sunflower Forest'' we read about child abuse, infanticide, and murder, but neither book falls into the senstionalism with which these subjects are often treated. Francelia Butler and Torey Hayden both wirte about mothers who inspire and terrify, and both wirte fom the point of view of daughters. Susan, the child in Francelia Butler's novel, ''The LUcky Piece,'' grows from age 5 to 9. Lisley O'Malley, the young woman in ''The Sunflower Forest,'' is in her 18th century year. Both girls have to understand and come to terms with the frightening fact that their mothers are not normal. They do so in very different ways.

title: COLUMBIA TO HOUSE A REINER ARCHIVE
description: The creation of the Fritz Reiner Center for Contemporary Music at Columbia University was announced last month in Chicago in conjunction with a fund-raising drive launched there. The university is the major beneficiary of the will of the conductor's widow Carlotta, who died in 1983; the gift includes funds of $1.2 million, Reiner's correspondence and memorabilia (including letters from Bartok, Stravinsky, Richard Strauss, Schoenberg and Milhaud), and the rights to future royalty earnings on the conductor's many recordings.

title: Sarita Armstrong Is Married
description: Sara Storey Armstrong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tobin Armstrong of Armstrong, Tex., was married yesterday to Robert Brooks Hixon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lloyd Hixon 3d of Houston. The Rev. Burton H. Shepherd, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

description: ''Limit Bid! Limit Bid!'' by Charles Baxter Clement. Jameson Books. Ottawa, Ill. 236 pages, $13.95.

title: LONDON SHUNS PROPOSALS ON IRELAND, SETS OFF A STORM
description: The Republic of Ireland, born in violence and delivered by the same Irish Republican Army it now opposes, has always laid territorial claim to Northern Ireland and has fixed this claim in its Constitution. It was thus seen as a significant concession last spring when nationalist parties of the north and south said in the report of the New Ireland Forum that, to bring peace to the province where more than 2,400 people have died in political violence since 1969, they might settle for something less than a united Ireland.

title: REPAIRING CRACKS IN PLASTER
description: HOMEOWNERS are often frustrated by cracks in ceilings or walls that keep coming back - no matter how carefully the crack is cut out, filled with patching plaster or spackling compound and then primed before painting.

title: Anne Ruvane Marries Thomas Hyatt
description: Anne Julie Ruvane, an associate in the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, was married yesterday to Thomas Karl Hyatt, an associate in the law firm of Schuster & King, also in Washington. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: SYRIAN MEETS BEIRUT LEADER ON ARMY DEPLOYMENT
description: Vice President Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria conferred today with President Amin Gemayel and senior Moslem and Christian officials on plans to deploy the Lebanese Army in the Beirut area and along the coastal road all the way to the Israeli lines in southern Lebanon.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
A BIG DROP IN 3D-QUARTER GROWTH
description: Growth in the third quarter slowed markedly to 1.9 percent, the lowest since the recession ended and a figure that analysts say brings the economy closer to a new recession. The slowdown has been steeper than most expected, as the economy continues to foil prediction attempts: the preliminary figure for the quarter had been 2.7 percent, and even pessimistic economists had expected it to be above 2 percent. Among the few who had warned of such sluggishness in the economy were advisers to Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic candidate for President. Their predictions had been dismissed as overly grim by the Reagan Administration.

title: Miss Schambach Weds in Virginia
description: Winifred Scott Schambach, a daughter of Mary West Tyree Schambach of Lexington, Va., and the late William James Schambach of Shrub Oak, N.Y., was married in the Lee Chapel on the Washington and Lee University campus in Lexington yesterday to James Robert Leva, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Leva of Johnstown, Pa. The Rev. Dr. David W. Sprunt, a Presbyterian minister and chaplain at the university, performed the ceremony.

description: As grand designs go, this one soared:

description: -regulated tenants in New York City's tight, high-priced apartment market often are confused about the right of relatives to succeed to their apartments after they leave.

description: Security forces ambushed a flotilla of six boats carrying about 60 guerrillas today and headed off a new attack by Tamil separatists on a police station in eastern Sri Lanka, officials said.

description: THE death last week of the states's first heart-transplant recipient demonstrated that it is ''unrealistic'' to expect all heart-transplant patients to survive, said Dr. John Fenn, chief of staff at Yale-New Haven Hospital, where the transplant was performed.

title: DEPOT, 99, STRUGGLES FOR 100
description: DRIVING south on Wantagh Avenue below the suggested speed limit, one still might pass by the original Wantagh railroad station without realizing it. The 99-year-old cream and chocolate-colored Victorian edifice lies nestled alongside a wooded section of the hamlet, and in recent years its inconspicuous presence has in itself created some problems affecting its very survival.

title: TOPICS
description: DEAR Santa, The catalogues are arriving at my house, and I have been devouring their contents avidly. Each one contains so many fantastic items, items that I can barely live without.

title: ATLANTIC CITY HEARS TALE OF A MAYOR AND THE MOB
description: When New Jersey voters were debating in 1976 whether to permit casino gambling in Atlantic City, many opponents said they feared that organized crime might muscle its way into control of the industry. Nonetheless, casinos were approved in a referendum, strict regulations were established, and there have been no allegations of organized crime gaining control or skimming revenues since the first casino opened in 1978.

title:
CAMERA;
PICTURES TAKEN IN SUBWAYS CHRONICLE THE CITY
description: Niklas Deak is a freelance photographer. The New York City subways offer a great variety of subjects for an observant photographer to capture the essence of the city. A permit is necessary and there is usually no problem in getting one for any legitimate reason.

title: NEW SERVICE MATCHES ELDERLY WITH HOMES FOR FOSTER CARE
description: Jeanette Vaughan is in the matchmaking business. She finds foster homes for ailing older people.

title: Ruth Morgan Cortner Becomes Bride
description: Ruth Morgan Cortner, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jean A. Cortner of Narberth, Pa., and John Hammond Reynolds, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester M. Reynolds of Oxford, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. Howard Friend performed the ceremony at the Gladwyne (Pa.)

title: THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat Succeeds In Convening His 'Parliament'
description: Yasir Arafat proved last week that he still has loyal supporters in the splintered Palestine Liberation Organization. He opened the long-postponed meeting of the group's ''parliament in exile'' in Amman, Jordan, despite catcalls from Syria, which questioned the validity of his declared quorum of 261 delegates.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a technical error, a picture today on page 3 of The Guide, section 2A, is captioned incorrectly. It shows Rock Hudson in ''The Vegas Strip War,'' an NBC-TV movie that will be broadcast this evening at 8.

title: PARMESAN CHEESE HAS MANY USES BUT SEEK THE REAL THING
description: PARMESAN is a cheese that people assume is from Italy, but it is often made elsewhere. The term is also used to discribe dishes that are not necessarily made with Parmesan cheese. It is time to unravel this confusion.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
HIGH ROLLERS IN THE BINGO HALL
description: COMPULSIVE gambling is a rapidly growing social problem in New Jersey, one that has intensified since lotteries and casinos were legalized.

title: Collette Steg Is Bride Of John Davis Kellogg
description: Collette Renee Steg of New York, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald F. Steg of Jamestown, N.Y., and John Davis Kellogg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Kellogg of Dorset, Vt. were married yesterday. The Rev. John T. Horne performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Lakewood, N.Y.

title: Stacy Phillips to Wed a Fellow Lawyer
description: Stacy Donna Phillips and Craig S. Bloomgarden, both lawyers, plan to be married in April, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Phillips of New York, have announced.

title: No Recovery for the Neediest As New York City prepares for the holiday season of feasting and good cheer, the plight of its homeless grows worse. The weather turns cold, and people with nowhere else to go flood into city shelters in record numbers. Children of homeless families, hoping for places in crowded hotels, end up spending the night on welfare office floors. Any thoughts of 10-speed bicycles or Cabbage Patch dolls are pushed aside by needs of basic survival - a warm room, a decent meal, a comfortable bed.
description: Nor are the homeless the only discordant elements in the general environment of economic recovery and affluence. The unemployed, the poor, the ill, all look forward to the holiday season with despair.

title: URUGUAY TO PICK CIVILIAN LEADER IN ELECTION TODAY, FIRST SINCE '71
description: Uruguayans are scheduled to vote Sunday for a civilian Government to end 11 years of repressive military rule.

title: RIVER TOWNS SEEK TO PRESERVE SCENIC QUALITY
description: ''WE do not live in Hastings-on-Hudson. We live in a place called Hastings-Near-Hudson,'' explained John Fox, a member of the Hastings Planning Board, speaking before a conference on scenic quality in the lower Hudson River Valley. Relating his experience as a board member - a ''greenhorn'' as he described himself - Mr. Fox told of the board's struggle with a plan for waterfront development in the village. Although the views of the Palisades from Hastings are some of the best on the river, there is no public access to the Hudson.

title: LOBBYIST SPENDING FELL AS END OF CONGRESS NEARED
description: A group fighting cuts in Social Security and Medicare nearly tripled its spending last summer at a time when many other lobbyists on Capitol Hill were reducing their outlays as Congress headed for adjournment.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'SIMON BOCCANEGRA'
description: Of all the mature Verdi operas, ''Simon Boccanegra'' is the hardest to come to grips with, both for performers and audiences. It has never taken the place in the standard repertory that by rights it should, although it contains some of the most powerful music the composer ever wrote. There are just too many drab stretches along the way. However, despite its unremitting gloom, the opera grows on one and a respectable performance such as the Metropolitan Opera put on Friday night always seems to win over a few new converts.

title: Memories of Matthew - Forever 16
description: The wind just changed - you could literally see the cold front in the sky as the temperature dropped. I think of Matthew with the fresh earth over him, dried leaves of autumn through which we walked, blowing all around.

title: NEW APPROACH IN INDIAN JEWELRY
description: American Indian jewelry was all the rage in the 1960's, when hippies who could afford it wore Indian belt buckles and turquoise beads. In 1980 the fashion world again picked up the look briefly. But there have long been collectors of fine Indian jewelry and crafts who don't care about fads. They appreciate the beauty of top-quality turquoise beads and the intrinsic worth of a finely wrought silver bracelet. And they will pay thousands for the work of outstanding artisans.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
J.F.K.'S DEATH: PEARL HARBOR FOR ANOTHER GENERATION
description: FOR my parents' generation it was Pearl Harbor. Forty-three years later, they still recall with a clarity usually reserved for wedding days and the births of first children exactly where they were the moment news of the attack reached them. In that instant, the Depression seemed to end, taking with it their innocence, propelling them suddenly beyond the warm kitchens and familiar streets of youth into a dangerous and unfamiliar world.

title: THE WORLD ; Food to EthiopiaIs Still Short
description: Food from the United States and other Western countries, sometimes transported on Soviet planes, was reaching hundreds of thousands of famished Ethiopians last week. But relief officials warned that many more, especially in remote or war- ravaged parts of the country, were still in danger.

title: Jersey Boardwalk Fire Ruins a Roller Coaster
description: A fire on an amusement pier yesterday afternoon in the seaside resort of Wildwood, N.J., destroyed a roller coaster and damaged two other rides. It was the fourth serious fire on the Cape May County community's boardwalk in as many years.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
NEW EFFORT NEEDED ON NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: THIS fall weekend is one of my favorites. Along the road the leaves are gaudy in the sunlight. The town road crew has already planted tall wooden stakes on the sides of the road. Soon it will be winter and the stakes will guide the snowplows along their way. Patra, our 3-year-old Labrador retriever, bounds along, attached to me by her long leather leash. The road is a narrow country road, bordered on one side by the lake and the other by small ''camps,'' as summer places are sometimes called in upstate New York.

He was one of Alfred Stieglitz's pre-World War I Pictorialists, published in Camera Work in 1906, 1907 and 1910, exhibited at ''291'' in 1908.

title: DEATH AND MADNESS IN DEVONSHIRE
description: IN September 1975, Robbie, Frances and Alan Luxton, elderly siblings, were found shot to death on the grounds of West Chapple, the killings sparked a flurry of attention in the London scandal sheets, and sent shock waves through the placid countryside around West Chapple. The last local members of a family that could be traced back to the 12th century, the Luxtons were seen by their neighbors in the village of Winkleigh as reclusive anachronisms, seemingly unaware that the world had changed since the 19th century. Their farm was archaic, and wih the exception of Frances, who was occasionally glimpsed huddled over tombstones in dark churchyards, the Luxtons almost never left its grounds. With the discovery of their bodies, each shot at close range in the head, rumors began to circulate - of suicide pacts, family curses and incestuous relations between Robbie, the eldest Luxton, and his sister. And though the case was officially resolved and closed, the dark questions it raised about the family have never been put to rest.

title: ONE BURN VICTIM EXTENDS AN ENCOURAGING HAND TO ANOTHER
A Broken Gear Box Strands 380 People Aboard a Ski Lift
description: Three hundred eighty skiers were stranded for up to five hours Friday when a broken gear box halted a ski lift on Mount Pluto, and 300 more were forced to wait on the slopes, a resort official said.

title: Paris to Give Managua $1.73 Million in Aid
description: France has agreed to give about $1.73 million in aid to Nicaragua, the third largest recipient of French aid in Latin America.

title: WHERE'S THAT PROMISED NEW WORLD OF CABLE?
description: The scenario could be entitled ''The Dream Deferred - Once Again.'' The promise of cable's programming abundance raised some hope among viewers that the producers of American cable fare would try more often to match the quality of such imported gems as ''Brideshead Revisited'' and ''Berlin Alexanderplatz.'' Yet, the production record of the nation's biggest pay-cable operator, Home Box Office, which supposedly has been leading the way for the rest of the industry, has been discouragingly dismal.

description: A caption on page 106 of the issue of Nov. 18 misspelled the name of a Roman Catholic priest in a Harvard Divinity School prayer group. He is the Rev. Henri Nouwen.

description: A state appellate court has overturned a lower court's order requiring two Egg Harbor Township policemen to have their sense of smell tested. The officers had reported smelling marijuana in a car they had stopped.

description: WEST TRENTON CUTTING bits of colored construction paper and gluing them together to make shapes represented a challenge for 16-year-old Kelly Dragun, who is deaf and legally blind.

description: Variety on Display At Benefit Boutiques Shopping, always a movable feast in this preholiday season, is softened by live music at no charge and international food selections are sold at one location this week, while at other boutiques the concentration is on variety.

description: Heatherten, the highweight and favorite, raced to a 6 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $119,000 Ladies Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct.

title: U.S. REBUFFS STATE ON DRG SYSTEM

title: Coyote Question Answered But Problem Stays Unsolved
description: Place two hungry coyotes, two lambs and a llama in one cage and the odds are that the lambs will be safe, according to a University of Wyoming study.

title: SOME TEXANS NEED WATER MORE THAN OIL
description: Once again, a drought has ended in Texas, this one the worst since the 1950's. Recent torrential rains broke a two-year dry spell that burned crops, caused some farmers and ranchers to give up or go under and forced others to sell off their breeding stock.

description: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY has acquired and intends to build dormitories on two Lower East Side properties that were the center of a dispute between community groups and a developer who had planned to build two transient hotels.

title: THE LEADING EDGE
description: Michael Berryhill, a freelance writer, lives in Houston. DUSK ON THE AIRCRAFT CARRIER Constellation, making 13 knots into a light wind 80 miles off the California coast. Scuds of cloud 800 to 2,000 feet high shade the purple twilight. The red light of a following frigate glows just at the edge of a horizon that is about to disappear for the half-dozen pilots stacked in a holding pattern 25 miles behind the Connie. The Navy is waiting for darkness so its flyers can practice what has long been the most dangerous task in aviation: night carrier landings. Some of the aviators on the U.S.S. Constellation are making their first such touchdowns. Making them successfully is the final, decisive test in the long, expensive process of preparing a United States Navy fighter pilot for war.

title: 126 MORE POLES LEAVE FERRYBOAT IN WEST GERMANY
description: The border police said today that 126 more Polish tourists on a cruise to West Germany had abandoned a ferryboat with the apparent intention of seeking political asylum.

title: ARAFAT EXPECTED TO REJECT JORDAN PEACE PLAN
description: King Hussein's call for a Middle East peace initiative based on United Nations Resolution 242 has little chance of winning approval from Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian sources and Western diplomats said here today.

title: DAY CARE: MOTHER'S POSITIVE VIEW
description: All the undergraduates I talked to wanted to have a full-blast career as well as a family,'' Sandra Scarr was saying about her recent visit to Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts. ''And so I asked them, 'How do you combine those things?' And they didn't have a clue. They knew that there might be a problem, but they didn't know its magnitude. And they certainly didn't know the solutions.''

title: TOPICS ; Afloat in New YorkMacy's first marched its Thanksgiving Day parade down Broadway in 1924 as a holiday event to engage its ''family'' of employees. The kinship now extends to millions who watch along the parade route or on television across the country.
description: In 1924, according to The Times, Santa arrived at Macy's newly expanded Herald Square store ''with a retinue of clowns, freaks, animals and floats.'' Today's star attractions are the giant balloons that first appeared in 1927 when an air-filled Felix the Cat rode on a float. This year's feline was a helium-filled Garfield, awesome, but inanimate.

As for the Islanders, who breezed to a 6-3 victory over Bowman's Buffalo Sabres at Nassau Coliseum, they wait for nothing these days.

title: ROCKETS LOSE TO MAVERICKS
description: Rolando Blackman's 26 points led five Mavericks in double figures as Dallas defeated the Houston Rockets, 113-95, tonight in an emotionally charged National Basketball Association game that included five technical fouls and three ejections.

title: TEL AVIV, SHOWCASE OF MODERNISM, IS LOOKING FRAYED
description: The first thought that comes to mind upon seeing the panels of ''White City: International Style Architecture in Israel,'' the exhibition currently at the Jewish Museum, is that suddenly one knows why Tel Aviv is such a dreary city: it is full of modern architecture. Tel Aviv is more completely built up with the austere, stark forms of the International Style than any city in Europe or the United States. It is a place in which the revolution Modernism sought was won, where modern architecture as far back as the 1930's was not the radical style, as it was then in the United States, but the established one. And it is one of the dullest urban environments anywhere.

title: Sudan Troops Kill 8 Rebels
description: Sudanese soldiers killed eight rebels in a clash last week, according to a report today in the daily newspaper El Sahafa. A group of rebels entered western Kordofan Province from neighboring Ethiopia by way of the Upper Nile, the paper said.

title: SAVING THE GREAT 'SAILS' OF L.I.
description: PARALLELING the movement to develop unspoiled land and modernize industries on the East End are efforts by local citizens and officials to preserve remnants of the area's history. One effort under way is the repair, sometimes requiring extensive renovation, of East End windmills. Two of them, the Hook Mill and the Wainscott Mill, both in the Town of East Hampton, are undergoing repairs scheduled to be completed in the spring.

The game, played before 4,000 spectators at C. W. Post College in Greenvale, was Garden City's first loss this season.

title: MORE ON 'BELTING' IN THE OPERA HOUSE
description: As anyone familiar with the territory would anticipate, a recent article in this space discussing the transfer of ''Sweeney Todd'' from the Broadway stage to the opera house drew a rush of comment, all of it fascinating, much of it informed and some of it quite erudite. I pointed out the difficulty that the City Opera's well-trained voices had in projecting the words and music of Stephen Sondheim's score, even though amplified. It was a phenomenon owing, I thought, to a basic incompatibility in vocal techniques and traditions between the opera house and the musical theater.

title: 8 More Deaths Reported In European Storms
description: Storms sweeping Europe took 12 more lives today, bringing the total death toll to 14 as hurricane-force winds ripped roofs off houses, flooded roads and blocked highways with fallen trees.

title: A Musical Theater Breakthrough
description: Stephen Sondheim brings an intellectualism to the musical theater that is challenging and refreshing (''A Musical Theater Breakthrough,'' by Frank Rich, Oct. 21).

title: THE REGION ; Blame in theBumpurs Case
description: Although Mayor Koch said last week that New York City accepts responsibility for the shooting of Eleanor Bumpurs, many blacks remained unconvinced that city officials had shown sufficient remorse over her death or that similar tragedies could be avoided in the future.

title: Margaret Stickles Married to Kenneth Monaghan
description: At St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church in East Rockaway, L.I., yesterday Margaret M. Stickles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Stickles of Lynbrook, L.I., was married to Kenneth J. Monaghan, the son of Jessine M. Monaghan of Garden City, L.I., and the late Frank A. Monaghan of New York. The Rev. Jay Madasci performed the ceremony.

title: Abigail Kaplan Wed in Bethesda
description: The marriage of Abigail Kaplan to Michael G. McKenna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. McKenna of Hamilton, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Z. Kaplan, parents of the bride, in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Harold White, a chaplain at Georgetown University, performed the ceremony.

description: IT has been three decades since autumn Saturdays have generated this much excitement at the university that Thomas Jefferson founded in 1819, in tree-lined surroundings that still conjure visions of the local gentry on horseback for a leisurely afternoon gallop.

title: Watson Leading In 4-Man Golf
description: Tom Watson won all the money, $120,000, in today's opening nine holes of the Skins Game with Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Gary Player.

title: FATE OF A POND: IS DREDGING NECESSARY?
description: THROUGH the windows of their respective North Haven village homes, Mary Ann McLaughlin and Carol Williams can watch the late afternoon sun turn to slate gray the surface of Great Pond, disturbed occasionally by an egret slicing gracefully through the water. It is a picture, they say, of beauty and harmony; of a tranquillity, they say, that must be preserved.

title: TWO HOLIDAY SHOWS IN BERGEN COUNTY
description: TWO holiday crafts markets that traditionally claim the first weekend in December will open this week in Bergen County.

title: ON A NEW ISSUE AND PHILATELIC PEDIGREES
description: With virtually no prior notice to the public, let alone stamp collectors, the United States Postal Service issued last month, a 20-cent commemorative stamp honoring Hispanic Americans. A closed first day of issue ceremony was conducted at the White House Rose Garden last month before an audience of about 300 persons who were predominately servicemen in uniform. The speakers were President Ronald Reagan, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Postmaster General William F. Bolger.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Setback forAntismut LawIn Indianapolis
description: Pornography is a billion-dollar growth industry, with entrepreneurs quick to move into new markets and to take advantage of new technology. Sexually explicit materials long ago became a profitable staple of the corner drug store, and sales of pornographic videocassettes are booming.

title: Whitman Upsets Sachem for Title
description: Kirk Murphy hauled in his second touchdown pass of the game with only 26 seconds remaining yesterday as Whitman (8-1-1) captured the Division I championship with a surprising 17-14 victory over Sachem (8-2).

title: HAWTHORNE'S SECRET An Un-Told Tale. By Philip Young. 184 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. %15.95
description: ACCORDING to Julia Hawthorne, who looked Herman Melville up while researching his biography of his famous father, the author of 'Moby-Dick' believed that 'there were some secret in my father's life which has never been revealed,' one that 'accounted for the gloomy passages in his books.' Hawthorne's pious son had no use for Melville, whom he evidently considered a kind of crackpot, and still less for Melville's biographical theory. 'The closet had no skeleton in it,' is his verdict on his father.

title: THE WORLD ; Separatists SplitIn Quebec
description: The election of the pro-independence Parti Quebecois in Canada's second most populous province in 1976 created an uproar among English-speaking Canadians, who feared the breakup of their federation. Last week the party itself seemed to be breaking up as five provincial ministers resigned in revolt against Quebec Premier Rene Levesque.

These statistics, reported last week by New York State's public- employee health plan, made perhaps the most compelling case yet for second opinions as the treatment of choice for rising medical costs.

description: De Soto officials were visiting a suburb of Mexico City to set up ''sister city'' ties when natural gas explosions shook the area Tuesday. Shocked at the devastation, which resulted in more than 300 deaths, the officials returned home determined to help their new friends.

description: A legislative study has recommended scrapping the system that allows towns to decide how much money welfare recipients may collect. Instead, the report suggested that the state set up schedules for payments.

title: HEATED RACE UNFOLDS IN MT. VERNON
description: MOUNT VERNON THE death four weeks ago of Mayor Thomas E. Sharpe Jr. has touched off one of the most controversial and dramatic political battles this city has seen since 1976, when the death of Mayor August Petrillo sparked an embittered political fight that divided the city along racial lines and created political animosities that have lingered to this day.

title: CHARTING A COURSE TOWARD 1988
description: As the dust settles in the wake of the Presidential election, there will be a great deal of self- analysis among Democrats and, increasingly, among Republicans as they also begin to chart a course toward 1988. In this phase of re-examination, American political life is not alone. Having spent the first half of 1984 in Europe, I can attest that the search for new political directions is endemic throughout the Atlantic world.

title:
ART;
DIVERSE SHOW OPENS GALLERY
description: THE occasion for a diverse group show at Manchester Community College's Newspace Gallery is the inauguration of that gallery. For 16 years, art at the college was exhibited in something called the Stairwell Gallery, but the new quarters are considerably larger than what is implied by a stairwell. They are very bright and accessible, too, in the college's new Frederick Lowe Building.

title: TO MODERNIZE, THE ARMY IS BRINGING BACK LIGHT INFANTRY
description: In the 18th and 19th centuries, light infantry usually referred to units of soldiers who used rifles rather than smoothbore muskets, marched faster than their ''heavy'' comrades and were more likely to fight from cover than to hurl themselves against the enemy in close quarters.

title: CELEBRATING A HARVEST
description: Roger B. Swain is science editor of Horticulture magazine and author of ''Field Days: Journal of an Itinerant Biologist'' (Scribner's).

title: HIGH-VOLTAGE LINE IN STATE APPROVED
description: The State Public Service Commission has concluded that a high-voltage power line cutting through the Catskills should be built. The 345-kilovolt line would transfer cheap Canadian hydropower to the New York City area.

title: INTEREST GROWS IN STREILIZATION
description: STERILIZATION has surpassed the birth control pill as the most common form of contraception in the United States, according to a recently published study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute. Although exact figures are not available for Long Island, Planned Parenthood offices in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties report that inquiries about sterilization procedures have increased noticeably over the last year.

The Rev. Wolodymyr Bazylevsky performed the ceremony.

title: Grocery Chains Are Fined In L.I. Price-Fixing Case
description: A Federal judge has ordered four supermarket chains that pleaded no contest to price-fixing charges to pay $830,000 in fines. The judge, Francis X. Altimari of District Court, suggested Friday that they could pay part of the fine by donating food for the needy.

title: 'SANDWICHING IN' RETIREMENT ADVICE
description: ''IT'S all right to start living. To tell them all we won't be home for Thanksgiving.'' Midway through a discussion of ''The Challenges of the Sandwich Generation,'' Adele Miller of Jericho got the message. And the 11 other men and women who had gathered in a classroom at the C. W. Post Center in Brookville for the last session of their five-part Pre-Retirement Planning Workshop nodded in assent.

title: Carrie Wolleman a Bride
description: Carrie Wolleman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wolleman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Stein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Stein of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Irving Kaslow performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

description: ON one side of a motor parkway in Hauppauge is Gasho, a reproduction of a 12th- century Japanese farmhouse. Directly opposite, parked at the entrance of another restaurant, is an authentic railroad caboose. What a curious mix of cultures.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Mindlin of Pittsburgh and West Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jayne Mindlin, to Christopher Chase, a son of Robin Chase Kuhn of New York and the late Gordon Chase of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: ON THE BURDENS SPORTS CAN CREATE
description: a function shared with British monarchs and American Presidents - is to symbolize and articulate the cherished beliefs and values of a society. It is not surprising, then, that Hunter College's president, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, extolled the virtues of sports and the beneficial consequences that will follow from ''expanding the athletic opportunities for students of both sexes.'' (''Sports: Active Ingredient in the Pursuit of Discipline,'' The New York Times, Nov. 11.) But, as is usually the case with such ritual celebrations of traditional activities, social and cultural realities are resolutely overlooked.

description: GROUND has already been broken in Westport for a new public library, an issue that had bitterly divided the town like none in years.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER ; DISCOUNTS FOR OLDER PEOPLE
description: Sooner or later the travel industry was sure to recognize the bonanza at hand. It is a bonanza of older Americans - more and more of them each year - able and eager to travel. The 1980 census counted 25.5 million age 65 or older - roughly 10 percent of the total population. The American Association of Retired Persons, their largest organization, counts more than 17 million people at least 50 years old in its 3,300 chapters and says membership is growing by about 5,000 a day .

title: SHOREHAM SCORES HIGH ON 'READINESS REVIEW'
description: FOR years Shoreham's opponents have complained about the adequacy of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's supervision. When the commission staff gave the plant its blessing earlier this month, it did not satisfy the critics who want an independent review of the reactor's safety, but it did demonstrate the commission's determination to avoid repeating some of the most troubling incidents to befall the reactor industry in recent years.

title: LOW-COST AUDIO EXCELLENCE

title: World Lift Mark Set
description: Naim Suleymanov of Bulgaria set a world record today in the 132-pound category by lifting 314 pounds at an international weight lifting competition. Suleymanov's lift came on his third attempt. On his second attempt he lifted 310 pounds to better the previous world mark of 309 pounds set by a countryman, Stefan Topurov.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; 'AGNES OF GOD': LOFTY IDEAS
description: JOHN PIELMEIER'S problematic play ''Agnes of God,'' currently at the Arena Players Second Stage Theater, depends heavily on acting and directing and stagecraft to gloss over its otherwise obvious flaws. Given the right combination in the collaborative process, this drama about a young nun accused of murdering her newborn has proved capable of engrossing an audience. Without those elements, the improbable plot seems fatuous.

title: CITY SOFT-SELL
description: The New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry will be doing some Big Apple-polishing with its guide, ''New York: A City of Neighborhoods,'' to be published next month.

title: NEW ROLE EYED FOR OLD HOUSE
description: THE historic I. U. Willets house off Shelter Rock Road in North Hills is now in the initial phase of a two-part study conducted by Guy Ladd Frost, an architect with 20 years of experience in restoring old buildings. The two-story white frame farmhouse, along with the four acres on which it stands, was deeded to the village by its most recent owner, Allan V. Rose, a developer who seeks permision from the village to build condominium townhouses on the remaining 127 acres that once harbored the Willets Farm and more recently the Links Golf Club.

description: The descendants of a woman who was buried in a suburban cemetery in 1929 have been awarded $44,000 by a jury in Common Pleas Court because her remains were found last year in a dirt pile. The jury also awarded $12,000 in lawyers' fees.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE AND ROBBINS/THARP
description: An old favorite returned to the repertory looking eternally youthful, and a newer work showed signs of growing old gracefully at the New York City Ballet's performance Thursday night in the New York State Theater.

title: Chevrolet's Trio Challenge Imports
description: GENERAL Motors has been doing some interesting things lately. First, there was the corporation's inner split into equal primacies, one for small cars - basically Chevrolet and Pontiac - and one for the traditionally bigger cars of Oldsmobile, Buick and Cadillac. Then there was the decision to join with Toyota in building a car in California.

description: SERVICEMEN returning from in a fi World War II wanted more out of life than their old jobs in Danbury's dying hat factories. This, coupled with crippling strikes in the 1950's, forced the city into re-evaluating its future.

title: 3 SOMALI SOLDIERS SAID TO HIJACK A JET TO ETHIOPIA
description: A Somali jetliner carrying 130 people was hijacked Saturday by three armed Somali soldiers who beat the pilot and wounded a crew member in a midair shootout, Ethiopian officials said.

description: Spencer Tillman scored two second-half touchdowns today as Oklahoma came from behind in the third period to beat Oklahoma State, 24-14, and gain a berth in the Orange Bowl.

title: Bobsledding Canceled
description: High winds and driving rain forced officials to cancel two runs of the season's first World Cup four-man bobsled competition today. The competition will be decided by the two runs scheduled for Sunday.

title: HIGH-FLYING FURS
description: WOMEN ARE IN the mood to buy furs, the nation's retailers report. And not just any furs, but luxury furs. Quality furs. Furs that are high on workmanship, high on tailoring and high on the bank account. ''That's why Galanos furs are selling so well,'' says Jack Cohen, the fur buyer at Bergdorf Goodman. ''They are great quality.'' .

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Bion Yu-Ting Tsang is a young cellist of remarkable gifts. Mr. Tsang, who is 17 years old, studied with Ardyth Alton, Channing Robbins and the late Leonard Rose; he has appeared as a soloist with the Atlanta Symphony and the New York Philharmonic, among other orchestras, and is currently a Harvard University freshman. Last Sunday afternoon, he made his New York solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: U.S. Role in Honduras
description: I read Gordon Mott's interesting article, ''Honduras: Key to U.S. Role in Central America'' (Oct. 14). Some of his interpretations and statistics, however, caused me to wince, just as he apparently winced as United States Airlift Command planes took off from Toncontin airport.

title: THOUSANDS MOURN CHICAGO PREP STAR
description: They turned out by the thousands today for Ben (Benjy) Wilson, not to cheer him but to mourn his death.

title: Beauty Pageant Gets An Entry in Protest
description: The student newspaper of the Georgia College at Milledgeville has entered a piece of beef roast in the Miss Georgia College scholarship pageant to protest rules governing the behavior of contestants.

title: Minnesotan Upsets Wendy Turnbull
description: Ann Henricksson of Mahtomedi, Minn., ranked 100th in the world, stunned third-seeded Wendy Turnbull of Australia today and advanced to a meeting with Martina Navratilova in the final of the $150,000 Family Circle New South Wales Women's Open tennis championships at White City.

title: U.N. CHIEF TO HEAR WOMEN'S JOB COMPLAINTS
description: The Secretary General of the United Nations is scheduled to meet again Monday with representatives of a women's rights group in an attempt to end practices that many women employed here say are discriminatory and undermine the organization's commitment to job equality.

title: THE NATION ; The CongressMakes ReadyTo Regroup
description: The ideological divides of the 97th Congress were reflected in a number of ways, including entymological rubrics such as boll weevils, gypsy moths. Nomenclature for the 99th, which will formally convene in January, has not yet been derived. But as the legislators journeyed to Washington for organizing meetings and leadership elections this week and next, distinct swarms were forming.

title: WRITER FOR THE TROUBLED YOUNG
description: AT this time of year, when a child shows up at the school nurse's office with regularity on Monday morning, chances are he is suffering from more than just an early winter cold.

title: Robber Slays Student
description: A high school student has been shot to death while trying to recover purses a gunman took from three young women, including the victim's girlfriend, according to the police.

title: STUDY CITES SHIFT IN POWER PLANTS
description: Hundreds of small electric plants, built largely by individuals or businesses, are springing up around the country, challenging the basic structure of the electric utility industry, according to a study released yesterday by a Washington research concern.

title: Suburbanite Responds To City Dweller
description: I have read Howard Schneider's article (''The City Vis- a-Vis the Island,'' Opinion Page, Oct. 28) and for the first time in my life am moved to write a letter in response to a publication. He wishes for a ''long overdue dialogue between city and suburb.'' So be it.

title: JUDITH JAMISON IN A NEW ROLE
description: Judith Jamison was one of the genuine stars of the day during her 15 years with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which she left in 1980. She was an anomaly among dancers, so tall and big and bold that only Mr. Ailey figured out how to use her. And in his dances, she took over the stage space with her first step into it, dancing with an unassuming warmth and generosity that teased the razzle-dazzle of it all. Who can forget the moment she glided onto the stage in ''Revelations,'' white umbrella held aloft and rippling in the air she stirred? Or the way those pumping knees churned her skirt into froth in ''Cry''?

title: YULE TREE DECOR YEAR-ROUNDPROJECT
description: -day arts and crafts juried event on Cape Cod each August, Polly Reilly's hand-painted, original Christmas tree ornaments excite a goodly share of attention.

title: A WEEK TO ENJOY LOCAL TROVE
description: ''AFINE genius in his own country,'' wrote Benjamin Franklin in his Almanac, ''is like gold in the mine,'' but fortunately things are a little better in our own county: Westchester residents seem much more ready to enjoy the cultural riches of our resident artists, and a number of golden opportunities to do so await your attendance this week.

title: Jackson and the Constitution
