title: Mary Burns Weds George Bucknall
description: Mary Bridget Burns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Valentine Burns of Naples, Fla., was married there yesterday to George Stafford Bucknall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stafford Bucknall of Greenwich, Conn., and Tannersville, N.Y. The Rev. Gordon Mann performed the ceremony at Trinity-by-the-Cove Episcopal Church.

title:
DINING OUT;
A PLACE FOR UNUSUAL CHINESE FARE
description: ON weekend evenings, prospective diners crowd together in the small vestibule of Paul Ma's China Kitchen or in the adjoining food shop to wait for tables. At this unpretentious storefront restaurant, no reservations are taken. Those who wait know their patience will be rewarded by cooking that is deliciously unique and a welcome change from ubiquitous Hunan-Sichuan food.

title: U.S.C. STOPPED BY IRISH
description: Although a driving rainstorm turned the playing field in the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum into a large mud puddle today, the result of the game couldn't have been sunnier for Notre Dame.

title: VENICE PREMIERE IN 1857
description: ''Simon Boccanegra,'' the 21st of Verdi's 28 operas, failed at its Venice premiere in 1857. La Scala heard his revision of the score, with a remodeled libretto by Arrigo Boito, in 1881, when the starry cast included Victor Maurel, Francesco Tamagno and Edouard de Reszke.

title: HOW SENATORS VIEW THE SENATE: WHAT HAS CHANGED AND WHAT IT MEANS
description: Following are views of the United States Senate, and how it functions, from some of its members:

title: Headen to Start
description: Andy Headen will start at left (strong-side) outside linebacker for the Giants against the Kansas City Chiefs here Sunday, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said today.

title: RELIGION AND POLITICS MIX POORLY FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Not since John F. Kennedy ran for President in 1960 has religion been as much a part of political discourse as it was in the 1984 campaign. Bishops, ministers, rabbis - and candidates - talked about abortion and the separation of church and state. Religion even figured in television commercials. Serious intellectual issues were often seriously discussed, but the serious political issue was votes. Appeals by both parties were carefully aimed at particular religious faiths.

title: DOUBTS IN THE DELIVERY ROOM
description: Philip Taubman's article was not a surprise to me at all.

title:
GARDENING;
TAKE CARE WITH THE AMARYLLIS BULB
description: ONE of the showiest of flowering bulbs for indoor forcing is the amaryllis. It can be relied on to produce clusters of as many as four six- to eight-inch flowers atop a single flowering stem that may reach two feet or more in height. More properly called Hippeastrum, the amaryllis that is commonly planted is of hybrid origin and is not found in the wild.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE STATE MUST MONITOR THE EFFECT OF CASINOS ON OTHER BUSINESSES
description: THE New Jersey Casino Control Commission predicts that there eventually will be an increase from 10 to at least 18 gambling casinos in Atlantic City.

title: SMALL TEST FOR SHOREHAM IS A MILESTONE FOR LILCO
description: THE debate over the Shoreham nuclear power plant

title: JERSEY COMMISSION REPORTS A 2.7% RISE IN CASINO WINNINGS
description: Winnings at Atlantic City's casinos rose 2.7 percent last month over the same period a year earlier, according to the state's Casino Control Commission.

title: LOVE MAKES A MOVIE COMEBACK
description: If the film is called 'Falling in Love,'' and

title: WHEN THE TALE GETS LOST IN THE TELLING
description: A great deal goes on in ''Secret Pastures,'' a new dance work by Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane. At the same time, not much goes on at all. A story is suggested but never told completely. Relationships are outlined but never filled in. Dancers move nonstop, but they dance within a predictably circumscribed range of movement. All this is presumably deliberate. Mr. Jones and Mr. Zane are part of what could be called the new Neither-Nor generation of experimental choreographers.

title: Sports of The Times; The Shooting of Ben Wilson
description: A magazine, ''Hoop Basketball Yearbook/ '85,'' arrived in the mail not long ago. It details the coming season from the pros to the colleges to the high schools. On page 86, it lists ''High School's Hottest Prospects.'' One of them was ''6-8 Ben Wilson of Chicago Simeon HS,'' a 185-pound senior forward who was ''being recruited by most of the nation's powers.''

title: HEADLINERS ; Who's Estranged?
description: Michael Reagan , the adopted son of Ronald Reagan and his first wife, Jane Wyman, said he didn't know he was estranged from his father until Nancy Reagan said it to a reporter in an interview that was published last week. He said he was ''shocked'' and ''hurt'' by the First Lady's assessment.

title: NEWLY STABLE CHANA BEGINS SHOWING SIGNS OF PROSPERITY
description: Flight Lieut. Jerry John Rawlings, who has ruled this West African country for almost three years as a proponent of third world revolution and liberation, is now seeking Western financing for a solidly capitalist recovery plan.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN A STAR BOARDER RETURNS
description: ONE day in the spring of my 24th year, I called home and said: ''Mom, would it be O.K. if I spent the next couple of months at home while I looked for a job in New York?''

title: GREEK LEADER GIVES VIEWS ON RELATIONS WITH UNITED STATES
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou says his Government is following a moderate policy toward the United States and does not want a confrontation with it. But he says he will continue to pursue an independent foreign policy even if this displeases other Western nations.

title: YALE'S CLASS OF '37 CHRONICLED IN BOOK
description: A HISTORY of the Yale Class of 1937 is chronicled through the life stories of some of its members in a two-volume book by John W. Field of Fairfield.

title: Priest Freed in Murder Case
description: The Rev. Cristian Briales, a Jesuit priest charged with the murder of a 4-year-old boy, was released from prison today after an investigating judge ruled there was no evidence to support the charge. Two other priests were set free by the police on Friday after being held 72 hours. The three priests are working in the parish of a poor neighborhood in the outskirts of Seville where the body of Francisco Reyes Moreno was found on Oct. 29.

title: Seance on a Wet Afternoon
description: Starring Kim Stanley and Richard Attenborough; written and directed by Bryan Forbes, 1964 VidAmerica 111 minutes. $59.95

title: YOU'RE FIRED, SO YOU BUY A FERRET
description: William Kotzwinkle's novels include the recent ''Queen of Swords'' and the forthcoming ''Seduction in Berlin.'' BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG CITY

title: CEREMONY IN TEXAS, FANTASY IN ARIZONA
description: San Antonio Celebrates Las Posadas

title: Bus Tours
description: To the Editor:

title: S. CAROLINA GAINS GATOR BOWL
description: A 1-yard run by the quarterback, Mike Hold, with 54 seconds left and Scott Hagler's second-chance extra point capped a dramatic rally and lifted South Carolina to a 22-21 victory over arch-rival Clemson today.

title: CAT DOLLS GET IN COSTUME FOR HOLIDAY SHOW
description: -TALE felines add an air of fantasy to this year's holiday exhibit at the Gunn Historical Museum in Washington. There, 20 miniature cats, standing upright and clothed in elaborate, turn-of-the-century costumes, are displayed in a not-so-traditional Victorian Christmas celebration.

title: HOLLY 'CAPITAL' BUSY
description: MILLVILLE THE Christmas season, says the man who runs one of America's two specialty nurseries dealing exclusively in holly, seems to begin earlier and earlier every year.

title: DOUBTS IN THE DELIVERY ROOM
description: Philip Taubman was quite correct in stating that it is ''preferable if the mother and child could get through the birth without being heavily drugged.'' However, it should also be noted that a prolonged and painful labor and delivery are detrimental to both mother and child: the mother is exhausted, and the pain she experiences causes her both to hyperventilate and to stimulate her sympathetic nervous system.

title: CENTENNIaL OF AN UNCOMMON COMPOSER
description: Donna K. Anderson, professor of music at SUNY-Cortland, owns a large collection of Griffes manuscripts and memorabilia.

title: CONNECTICUT AGENCY IS ADDING AIR FILTERS TO WASTE PLANT PLAN
description: The Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, prodded by Gov. William A. O'Neill, will install expensive air-pollution filters when it builds its planned garbage-to-energy plant here rather than waiting to see if it can meet air- quality standards without them.

title: OPERA IS SCHEDULED IN ABUNDANCE
description: THANKSGIVING may be only a memory, but there is one more piece of Thanksgiving music on the schedule: Ralph Vaughan Williams's beautiful ''Song of Thanksgiving,'' which will be performed on Friday and Saturday evenings at 8:15 by the Trinity College Choir, under Gerald Moshell. The rest of the evening's program, subtitled ''Songs of Exaltation,'' is equally fascinating, with the Poulenc ''Gloria'' and the finale to Wagner's ''Meistersinger'' alongside the rarely encountered ''Hymn to France'' by Berlioz. For more information, call 527-8062.

title: GULF CITIES VIE FOR LUCRATIVE NEW NAVY BASE
description: Sixteen Gulf Coast cities, including seven Texas ports, have gone all out to impress Navy officials who are studying possible sites for a new base that could mean a bonanza in jobs and business.

title: THE 'SOVIET PRINCESS'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW THE INSTITUTIONS RULE THE MARKET
description: Harold J. Folz, a retired vending machine operator living in Hallandale, Fla., is fed up with the stock market. ''I find it very speculative,'' he said. ''It flies all over. You think it's hitting bottom, and it goes down more. To my mind, it's crapshooting.''

title: SURVIVAL HINTS
description: BECAUSE OF THE rapidly increasing population and breakdown of just about everything, Americans require far more survival information than used to be the case. I am old enough to remember when the only advice you needed to survive quite happily could be summed up in three sentences:

title: RECOVERY IS FADING AT A CRUCIAL TIME
description: WASHINGTON GLOW to gloom, mandate to stalemate: in the brief passage since Election Day, the economy has intruded into the battle over budgets and taxes, increasing the force of some arguments and deflating others. Only last week, a new set of what some in the capital call ''complexifiers'' were introduced into the Administration's economic policy deliberations.

title: GOLDCREST: NEW STAR OF BRITISH FILM
description: LONDONIn an industry where the leading enterprises often belong to famous

title: REINVIGORATED NAVY WAR COLLEGE ATTRACTS WOULD-BE ADMIRALS
description: The Naval War College, the Navy's senior educational institute, is experiencing a resurgence of intellectual vigor after years of being spurned by officers who thought it unnecessary for operations at sea or promotions in rank.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FAKES: IT CAN HAPPEN TO ANYONE
description: RUMSON ''TOO True to Be Good,'' a provocative hour-long run through the subject of fakes, forgeries and reproductions in the field of American antiques, was the subject of a talk given here recently by Charles F. Hummel, deputy director for collections at the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum in Wilmington, Del.

title: LATE DEVIL GOALS BEAT PENGUINS, 5-3
description: Rollie Melanson, in his first game as a North Star since being acquired from the Islanders last Monday, made three key saves in the third period and Craig Hartsburg scored 3 minutes 35 seconds into overtime to give Minnesota a 5-4 victory Friday night over the Devils.

title: HAWKS DEFEAT NETS, 101-99
description: For the second straight game, the Nets suffered a costly collapse in the final minutes, and lost tonight to the Atlanta Hawks, 101-99.

title: Arming for Arms Control
description: If words mean anything, President Reagan's clearest new mandate is to seek an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union. And if new signs of Soviet interest are genuine, Mr. Reagan and Secretary of State Shultz are now well positioned to pursue the quest. But their desire for agreement does not yet equip them to achieve it. Besides finally engaging the Russians in a serious way, they need finally to discipline their own ranks.

title: HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR ILL CHILDREN
description: JACKSON TO Alice Weber, art is synonymous with life. The 85-year- old resident of this Ocean County community has won many awards for her crafts, and could easily keep busy making gifts for her eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren (two more great-grandchildren are on their way).

title: Eileen Dolan Is Bride Of Joseph H. Staley 3d
description: Eileen Patrice Dolan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Dolan of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Joseph Hardin Staley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Staley Jr. of Dallas, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Tobin performed the ceremony at the Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: A SHORTCUT TO THE HEART OF COMPLEX PROBLEMS
description: THERE are times when

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MAJOR credit cards are now being accepted at most of the state's 36 general hospitals, according to Albert F. May , spokesman for the Connecticut Hospital Association.

title: LIPPER HAS TO RESIGN IF HE RUNS, KOCH SAYS
description: Kenneth Lipper would have to resign as Deputy Mayor and as a board member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority if he decided to run for public office, according to Mayor Koch.

title: THE NATION ; Roundup Nets3,309 Fugitives
description: The arm of the law had reached into eight East Coast states to capture 3,309 fugitives by the end of a 10- week manhunt Monday. By Tuesday, half of them had trickled through the courts' fingers.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE LURE OF A BUCKS COUNTYINN
description: NESTLED at the foot of a hill on an unspoiled country lane in Bucks County, Pa., a charming old inn beckons once again. The Carversville Inn, about 10 minutes northwest of New Hope, was reopened four months ago by its chef-owner, Michel Faure, and his wife, Barbara. The opening followed extensive renovations in which the new owners were careful to retain the simple, enchanting atmosphere of the building's early-19th-century origins.

title: THE INTELLIGENTSIA IN THE FIRES OF STALINISM
description: Anatole Shub, program officer of the United States Board for International Broadcasting, is a former Moscow correspondent and author of ''An Empire Loses Hope.'' THE BURN

title: THE REGION ; Governor SeeksTo End Bid-Lock
description: Long Island's stalled state highway construction program got a shove from behind last week as Governor Cuomo temporarily abandoned the competitive bidding process and asked for negotiated contracts in one set of projects.

title: INSURGENCY ADDS TO MOZAMBIQUE'S PROBLEMS
description: Buffeted by rebellion and drained by famine and bankruptcy, Mozambique's Marxist Government reigns in this capital and other cities but is usually unable to impose its authority in the rest of the country.

title:
GARDENING;
TAKE CARE WITH THE AMARYLLIS BULB
description: ONE of the showiest of flowering bulbs for indoor forcing is the amaryllis. It can be relied on to produce clusters of as many as four six- to eight-inch flowers atop a single flowering stem that may reach two feet or more in height. More properly called Hippeastrum, the amaryllis that is commonly planted is of hybrid origin and is not found in the wild.

title: Miss Morris And Analyst Are Married
description: The marriage of Constance Anne Morris, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John McLean Morris of Woodbridge, Conn., to Peter Mathies Jarowey 2d took place yesterday at the First Church of Christ, Congregational, in Woodbridge. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Jarowey of Hamden, Conn.

title: Pitt Sends Penn St. To Fifth Loss, 31-11
description: John Congemi, a junior who missed half the season with an ankle injury, passed for three first-half touchdowns as Pitt rose from the ashes of its worst season since 1972 to upset Penn State, 31-11, today in the 84th meeting of these intrastate rivals.

title: THE NATION ; Aging ChemicalArms Buildup
description: Although the United States stopped making chemical weapons 16 years ago, they pose a growing threat today. The Army's huge chemical arsenal, 90 percent obsolete, has begun to deteriorate.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE DIARIES OF JANE SOMERS, by Doris Lessing. (Vintage, $6.95.) Doris Lessing published two novels this year and last under the pen name Jane Somers. The author of more than 25 books, Miss Lessing wanted to highlight difficulties faced by unknown writers, to encourage them and to fool reviewers. The novels are ''The Diary of a Good Neighbour'' and ''If The Old Could. . . .'' Both are now in ''The Diaries of Jane Somers.'' Our reviewer, Caroline Seebohm, wrote of ''If The Old Could . . .'' that ''the problems of older women and sex, of loneliness and of the generation gap are all central to this novel's theme. . . . this is an extremely courageous attempt (to deal with these subjects), and Jane Somers is a courageous writer.'' IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL, by Amos Oz. (Vintage, $5.95.) Amos Oz, the Israeli novelist, toured his country in 1982 interviewing fellow Israelis - including Sephardic Jews, West Bank settlers and Arabs. ''In the Land of Israel,'' translated by Maurie Goldberg-Bartura, is ''stunning'' and ''brilliantly controlled, a careful if galloping report by an artist wearing a journalist's mask, who portrays his country through conversations,'' Roger Rosenblatt said in The Book Review last year. ''The extraordinary dialogues (Mr. Oz) wrote from these encounters first appeared in the socialist newspaper Davar. The voices are not types.''

title: FOR ART, NOT PROFIT
description: Bruce Weber is a freelance writer and critic who lives in New York. THE PUSHCART PRIZE, IX: BEST OF THE SMALL PRESSES

title: BYPASSED BY DEVELOPMENT, ORLANDO EYES REVIVAL
description: Booming growth in Orange County has come at the expense of downtown Orlando, the area that was once the hub of the county's commercial and social activity.

title: RECORD 52 BY KING HELP KNICKS WIN
description: It was show time at Madison Square Garden last night, and Bernard King was the show.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
MAKING THE BEST OF FLU
description: EVEN though I am healthy, at least once a year I am knocked out by a Golden Glove flu bug. Instead of fretting over the inconvenience of this illness, I have learned to take advantage of the time out.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: There was a time when nonhuman species in science fiction typically resembled creatures out of nightmares, both in their disgusting physical attributes (bug-like, slimy, smelly and so on) and in their implacable hostility to homo sapiens. Three recent novels illustrate how profoundly sf aliens have changed - becoming more alien and less nightmarish. Almost as a corollary, it is the human beings, trying to adapt to environments outside the solar system, who seems increasingly ''alien.''

title: Another Move
description: To the Editor:

title: PLEASANTVILLE FALLS TO DOBBS FERRY
description: Dobbs Ferry rolled to a 21-0 victory over Pleasantville yesterday, giving the Eagles their third consecutive Section 1 Class C bowl championship.

title: Elephants Kill an Indonesian
description: A herd of wild elephants rampaged through a village in northern Indonesia, trampling to death a farmer who tried to defend his land by slashing one of them with a knife, news reports said today. The Jakarta Post said the herd had destroyed large areas of cropland and damaged 14 villages since early November in Syamtalira Bayu on the island of Sumatra.

title: THE REGION ; No NonsenseOn No Smoking
description: Eddies swirled in the smoke-filled rooms of New Jersey last week as legislators and lobbyists contemplated six bills that would regulate smoking in most of the state's public areas.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL GROUP DISMISSES ONE OF ITS TOP LEADERS
description: The directors of the largest Nicaraguan rebel force have expelled from their ranks a top leader who had openly discussed and was critical of the Central Intelligence Agency's covert aid to the anti-Santinista group.

title: SCIENCE PARK PLANS EXPANSION
description: SCIENCE PARK is hardly typical of the sprawling suburban industrial park. Its 80 acres sit in a former manufacturing complex in the midst of one of New Haven's poorest neighborhoods.

title: THREE SPOTS FOR LUNCH IN FAIRFIELD
description: ALMOST every town has an informal eatery where local residents drop by for a casual, usually inexpensive lunch. One of the frustrations for the infrequent visitor to a town is knowing where such a place exists. Such information is invaluable to anyone in search of a good, modest lunch in cheerful but not fancy surroundings.

title: WITH ITS CROONERS AND TOASTERS, REGGAE IS THRIVING
description: Jamaica is just 475 miles off the Florida coast. But for Americans who want to keep up with Jamaican reggae, it can seem much farther away. Reggae has rock and soul roots, and has become a continuing influence on all pop sung in English, but since the death of Bob Marley it has been relegated once again to the zone of exotica. Singles - which make the reggae market so volatile in Jamaica and Britain - are either imported directly from Jamaica or not heard at all, and American record buyers are offered reggae albums only when it's convenient to issue them. Through the vagaries of international rights negotiations, the delay between a Jamaican release and an American one can range from weeks to years, so it's difficult to get an overview of reggae as it evolves.

title: Costly Injury
description: John McEnroe 's abrupt withdrawal from the Australian Open because of a wrist injury has touched off an intense recruiting effort by tournament officials that could cost McEnroe a $200,000 prize he thought he had already won. The officials have been trying to persuade Jimmy Connors to take McEnroe's place in the tournament, which begins tomorrow, and if Connors accepts and wins the tournament, he would displace McEnroe as the top point-getter on the 1984 Grand Prix circuit and earn the first-place bonus of $600,000.

title: AN ORCHID EXPERT MAKES IT SOUND EASY;
description: Charles Marden Fitch is the author of ''All About Orchids'' and grows hundred of plants in his home.

title: TREASURES OF JEWISH FOLK ART
description: A pair of fierce-eyed Torah ark lions would be right at home on a carrousel. A patchwork quilt stitched of satin and velvet by Adolph Schermer boasts an extraordinary square of the Star of David framing the Stars and Stripes. And a Hanukkah lamp is a priceless conception made up of Woolworth store finds. Its base is wrapped in miniature American flags and its lights are eight souvenir bronzes of the Statue of Liberty with pink plastic birthday candleholders embellishing their torches.

title: IN SEARCH OF A CENTRAL AMERICAN POLICY
description: James Chace is an editor of The New York Times Book Review and author of ''Endless War: How We Got Involved in Central America and What Can Be Done.''

title: PORT AUTHORITY PAYS RENT INCREASE TO NEWARK
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has paid Newark an additional $11.5 million in rent for Newark International Airport and Port Newark.

title: COHALAN HAS THEM GUESSING ON FUTURE
description: WHILE Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell is saying he will seek a third term next year, his neighbor, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan, is responding to widespread reports that he will not even finish his second term, which expires at the end of 1987.

title: ERITREANS ASK SEPARATE AID, SAYING REBEL AREAS GET LITTLE
description: An appeal has been made for food and other aid for 1.5 million people in the rebellious Ethiopian province of Eritrea, where famine has been aggravated by civil war.

title: HORRORS OF WAR IN BRONZE
description: MICHAEL SHACHAM lives in Basking Ridge now. But in 1967 and again in 1973, he was in the Israeli Army and once, when his unit ambushed the enemy, he had to kill several men as they leaped from the back of a truck.

title: One Texas Quintuplet Dies
description: Quintuplets were born Friday to the wife of a Greek air force officer but one died a few hours after the birth, a United States Air Force spokesman said. The other four, born 14 weeks premature, remained in critical condition, the spokesman, Sgt. Karl Gruhlkey said. He said he did not know whether the mother, who was reported well, had taken fertility drugs.

title: THE HIGH COST OF OBEYING FACADE-REPAIRS LAW
description: ALTHOUGH frustrated residents

title: GHENA DIMITROVA: A DIVA DISCOVERED
description: Paul Hofmann, a former foreign correspondent for The Times, is the author of ''O Vatican: A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See'' (Congdon & Weed).

title: Amy Margolin Is Wed To Robert J. Sommer
description: The marriage of Amy Matika Margolin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Margolin of Larchmont, N.Y., to Robert J. Sommer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. K. Joel Sommer of Larchmont and Truro, Mass., took place yesterday in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club.

title: Island Recieves Lighthouse In Exchange for Bird Habitat
description: Block Island is getting title to Old Granitesides, a historic lighthouse that marked Long Island Sound, in exchange for a conservation easement on 20 acres of an important migratory bird habitat.

title: CUTBACKS HAVE A TELLING EFFECT ON SHLETER FOR ELDERLY
description: THE first generation of federally assisted

title: FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST OPENS 73D APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens its 73d annual appeal today on behalf of the poor, the distressed, the hungry and the homeless in the New York metropolitan area.

title: New Antenna Is Fixed Atop the Empire State
description: The Empire State Building was a bit taller yesterday, its shrinking process having been completed. But it was more a tale of adventure than a riddle.

title: CASINO AIDE ASSAILS PROMOTION PROPOSAL
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE chairman of the Atlantic City Casino Association has assailed proposed legislation that would compel the gambling industry to pay to promote other resorts and a proposal by the liquor industry that it share in the slot-machine business.

title: Pakistani City Expels Unmarried Afghans
description: About 10,000 unmarried Afghan refugees have been expelled from Peshawar, capital of Pakistan's North-West Frontier province, and 5,000 more will be expelled next month, an official said today.

title: Miss Silber Bride Of State Senator
description: Christine Silber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Silber of Amityville, L.I., was married yesterday to Martin Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Connor of Mercerville, N.J. The Rev. Anthony Failla celebrated the nuptial mass and Deacon William Mitchell, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''Testament'' should be even more chilling on television than it was on the large screen. When it inaugurates the fourth season of PBS's ''American Playhouse'' series this Monday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, Lynne Littman's film about a nuclear holocaust will benefit from the change of scale.

title: PREPAID MEANS LESS PAID IN MEDICAL PLANS
description: Jacob Ganfer, a retired cab driver and an involuntary expert on hospitals, has just returned home from his latest stay at Illinois Masonic Medical Center on Chicago's North Side. ''I'm their best customer,'' he said with a you-better-believe-it air. After previous hospital visits, including two for heart bypass surgery, the 67-year-old Mr. Ganfer said he learned to ''fight tooth and nail'' to correct billing errors. This time, however, there will be no bill. He is one of thousands of Chicagoans who have recently joined a health maintenance organization, or H.M.O. With incentives from Washington and competitive pressures changing the thinking of many doctors and hospitals, these prepaid medical plans are booming. In Illinois, for example, where many in the medical community formerly resisted the concept, membership has risen by 49 percent in the last year alone.

title: A PARTY OF ACCESS?
description: Like many another concerned Democrat, Lieut. Gov. Michael Daniel

title: Female Globetrotter?
description: The Harlem Globetrotters, the crack basketball team that began life 58 years ago with a mostly black cast, is out to make some new social history. Dick Palmer, the president of the team, said it had begun a nationwide search for the team's first female player. ''The pre-eminence of female athletes in the summer Olympic Games and in N.C.A.A. competitions has led to the team's decision,'' he said, ''While the average height of female players may put them at a disadvantage, we feel the talent of some of the best will enable them to compete fully and effectively against the top male athletes.''

title: STAMFORD HISTORICAL SOCIETY GAINS NEW HOME AND STATUS
description: A BEQUEST of $1.2 million dollars, accompanied by a large, important collection of period furniture worth an additional $500,000, has catapulted the Stamford Historical Society into ''the big time in a most remarkable way,'' said Janet Jainschigg, president of the Connecticut League of Historical Societies, of which Stamford is a long-standing member.

title: U.S. AND NORTH KOREA TRADE CHARGES ON DMZ CLASH
description: United States and North Korean military officers met today in the Korean demilitarized zone and blamed each other for the exchange of gunfire at Panmunjom on Friday that left four soldiers dead and as many as six others wounded.

title: POLITICAL SPENDING CURB PROPOSED FOR JERSEY
description: Assembly Speaker Alan J. Karcher says he will press for enactment of a $50,000 spending limit on Assembly campaigns in time for the races next year, when all 80 Assembly seats are up for election.

title: HEADLINERS ; From Cuba With Loathing When
description: Jose Luis Llovia Menendez , a high-ranking member of the Castro Government, decided to defect in 1981, he found it a lot easier to get out of Cuba than into the United States. Officials at the American Embassies in Montreal and Venezuela refused to give him a visa because they didn't believe he was who he said he was.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HITCHCOCKK'S 'FANCY CHAIRS'
description: IN 1818, after four years as an apprentice to the cabinetmaker

title: Dave Johnson's Computer Feeds Mets
description: DAVE JOHNSON reports that he is ready to start feeding ''a few new programs'' into his computer to give the Mets the early edge for the 1985 season. But he says that he doesn't need the computer to advise him on trades: The Mets don't need any, at least not for their starting lineup.

title: TAKING A BATH
description: A SATISFYING SOAK IN A WARM bath soothes muscles, relaxes the body and stimulates circulation. And at the end of a stressful day, it can act as an effective soporific.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Heading 'em OffAt the Impasse
description: Setting up temporary roadblocks to catch drunken drivers is constitutional, according to New York State's highest court.

title: THE HOUSE THAT BANKING BUILT
description: When Joel R. Wells Jr., joined the top management team at Sun Banks Inc. in 1975, he paid what he thought would be ''just a social call'' on Harry V. Keefe Jr., head of the stock research firm of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Mr. Keefe, however, was not about to pass up a chance to learn more about the troubles then afflicting the Florida bank holding company.

title: WOMEN WHO SAY WHAT THEY MEAN
description: Patricia Hampl's most recent books are ''Resort and Other Poems'' and the prose memoir ''A Romantic Education.'' MERMAIDS IN THE BASEMENT

title: Miss Loomis Has Nuptials
description: At the First Church in Windsor, Conn., yesterday Rebecca Cairns Loomis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Kingsley Loomis of Windsor, was married to DeWitt Montgomery Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Waddell Smith of Mountain Lakes, N.J. The Rev. F. Van Gorder Parker and the Rev. Duane J. Estes, Congregtional ministers, performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;
STIRRING SHAPES IN AFRICAN METALWORK
description: ''AFRICAN Metal Implements: Weapons, Tools and Regalia,'' currently at the Hillwood Art Gallery on Long Island University's C. W. Post campus, is a fascinating exhibition that adds significantly to our knowledge of tribal art. This first survey of the subject to be offered in the metropolitan area has as its nucleus the collection of two Long Islanders, Claire and Frederick Mebel.

title: 'TABOO IN REVUE' FEATURES THE EFFORTS OF 3 LONG ISLANDERS
description: -fire'' musical: a song-and-dance version of the life of Helen Keller, to be titled ''Oh, Helen!''

title: WIESENTHAL DRAWS CROWD IN BEDFORD
description: THERE were some initial fears that his age and the demands of a compact and somewhat frenetic schedule would tire him and that the evening's lecture before a crowd of more than 800 people would prove too taxing.

title: CAN GENERALS WAGING WAR BE WOUNDED BY THE PRESS?
description: Until now, most of those who have made libel law in this country have been overshadowed by the cases that bear their names. L.B. Sullivan, for instance, is far less familiar than New York Times v. Sullivan, the landmark Supreme Court decision he spawned. This is changing, however, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, where two of the most prominent figures in recent military history, William C. Westmoreland and Ariel Sharon, are waging warfare of a different sort: multimillion-dollar libel suits against big news organizations.

title: Pamela McKniff Weds
description: Pamela Ann Marie McKniff, a caterer, was married yesterday to Dr. Jack L. Feinberg, a professor of physics at the University of Southern California. Rabbi Don Singer and the Rev. Charles Ara, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at La Venta Inn in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. The bride is a daughter of John Thomas McKniff 2d of Covina, Calif., and the late Mary M. McKniff. The bridegroom is the son of Chief Judge Wilfred Feinberg of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cicruit and Mrs. Feinberg of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: AUGUSTANA BEATS UNION FOR 23 IN ROW
description: It was a rematch of last season's Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl game, and the outcome was the same with Augustana winning, 23-6, today over Union of Schenectady, N.Y., in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III semifinal.

title: Joan M. Shea Married To John D. McKinney
description: Joan Marie Shea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur James Shea of Memphis, was married there yesterday to John David McKinney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ewing McKinney of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. William Klieser performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception.

title: B.Y.U. Extends Streak to 23
description: Lakei Heimuli ran for two touchdowns and Vai Sikahemi added two more today to give Brigham Young a 38-13 victory over Utah State.

title: Texas Upset From S.W.C. Lead, 24-10
description: Coach Fred Akers said that he had never seen his Texas team play as badly this season as it played today in the 24-10 upset loss to Baylor that knocked the Longhorns out of the Southwest Conference lead.

title: HE'S COTTONING UP TO HIS NEW JOB
description: '' IT was the most fun, exciting business I'd ever seen,'' said Joseph J. O'Neill of North Massapequa, recalling his introduction in the mid-1960's to commodities trading.

title: Power-Line Issue Is Still Unresolved
description: A FEW days ago, those who have been fighting a proposal by the Power Authority of the State of New York to run a portion of a high-voltage line through the western end of the Catskill State Park were elated when the state's six-member Public Service Commission voted unanimously that an alternate route skirting the park to the west should be used.

title: ROCKEFELLER ARCHIVES: A PORTRAIT OF A FAMILY
description: THE unassuming white sign at the corner of Lake Road and Dayton Avenue in Pocantico Hills pointing to the ''Archives Entrance'' around the corner does not suggest to the visitor that a 32-room stone mansion set on 24 rolling acres awaits. The house - known as Hillcrest - was built in 1961 by Martha Baird Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s second wife, but was never occupied by her. At her death in 1971, the property went to the Rockefeller Brothers Fund.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday concerning activist clergymen, the location of the Rev. Vernon A. Shannon's St. Catherine's African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church was incorrectly reported. It is in New Rochelle.

title: THE REGION ; A Tax MeasureAll New YorkersCan Love
description: A cut in state personal income taxes seemed sufficiently assured to help inspire thankfulness in New Yorkers last week. It also, like Thanksgiving itself, inspired some greed.

title: RANGERS ROUTED BY NORDIQUES, 8-3
description: The Quebec Nordiques scored four goals early in the second period for a 6-0 lead and then coasted to an 8-3 triumph over the Rangers tonight.

title: LINDA RONSTADT REACHES FOR AN OPERATIC HIGH NOTE
description: For Linda Ronstadt, ''La Boh eme'' is a tenuous stopover on the way from from a life she no longer wants to a destination still unknown. Rock's brilliant queen of the 1970's is 38 years old as 1985 approaches, and on the eve of her formal debut as Puccini's Mimi at the Public Theater, she seems alone in a world she really doesn't know and for which her past has only partly prepared her - ''too old to rock and roll,'' as Jethro Tull once sang, ''and too young to die.''

title: BUYERS OF INSURANCE MUST BE TOLD OF ALL THEIR OPTIONS, COURT RULES
description: Insurance agents have a duty to explain fully to all their customers all the options available, according to a ruling by the Appellate Division of Superior Court.

title: BEST SELLERS Nov. 25, 1984
description: Fiction*1 15 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 26 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *3

title: Susan Cavanagh Bride in New Haven
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church on the Green in New Haven yesterday, Susan Elizabeth Cavanagh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Cavanagh of Hamden, Conn., was married to George Urban Wyper, a son of Florence U. Wyper of West Hartford, Conn., and James Wyper Jr. of Hartford. The Rev. Andrew F. Fiddler performed the ceremony.

title: BRIGHTON IS REHABILITATING ITS BLIGHTED AREA
description: JUST up from the beautiful boardwalk and

title: THE END-OF-THE-WORLD SCENARIOS
description: All of those currently debating whether a nuclear war would be followed by a catastrophic ''nuclear winter'' agree on one thing - that their scientific conclusions have important political consequences. And they are happy to point them out. Nuclear winter presents ''a real danger of the extinction of humanity,'' Carl Sagan has written in the journal Foreign Affairs. Therefore, we must move ''as rapidly as possible to reduce the global nuclear arsenals below levels that could conceivably cause the kind of climatic catastrophe and cascading biological devastation predicted by the new studies.''

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: On Volunteer Needs Of the Red Cross It was interesting to note in the article, ''Some Opportunities for the Volunteer'' (Oct. 23), that no mention was made of the American Red Cross.

title: Saints Activate Elliott
description: For today's game against San Francisco, the New Orleans Saints have activated Tony Elliott , the nose tackle who was given clearance to play earlier this week by the league. Elliott, who spent four weeks in a drug rehabilitation center during the 1983 season, was waived July 13 after being arrested and booked a day earlier on charges of forgery and issuing worthless checks.

title: Schiro Tops Course Mark Cathy Schiro, a 17-year-old senior at Dover High School in New
description: Hampshire, set a course record in the 5,000 meters and led a group of

title: MING MNEMONICS
description: THE MEMORY PALACE OF MATTEO RICCI

title: Radio Cabs Needn't Be Yellow It's 5 P.M. on a weekday in midtown Manhattan, and though dozens of cabs with empty back seats are in sight, none are for hire. Every one is lit with a blinking sign, ''On radio call.''
description: A familiar tale? Some 2,000 taxis - about 1 in 6 - belong to radio groups, which permit them to charge a premium over the price on the meter. But that service could be provided equally well by other cars, freeing the yellow ''medallion'' taxis for street hails.

title: GOOD ART KNOWS WHEN TO SHUT UP
description: WASHINGTON

title: 'JOE PALOOKA' HANGING UP HIS GLOVES AT 54
description: -BARRE, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI) - ''Joe Palooka,'' whose exploits in and out of the boxing ring entertained readers for 54 years, retired today and headed back to his Pennsylvania hometown.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MIAMI
description: JON NORDHEIMER is chief of the Miami bureau of The Times. Miami's heyday as a tourist destination, with some notable exceptions, is well behind it. Many visitors still stream through the airport on their way to a cruise ship or to other parts of Florida, but the Miami Beach hotel strip now relies primarily on cut-rate package tours and conventions, and visitors to the City of Miami are more likely to be traveling on business than for pleasure. The city's role as a financial hub and link to Caribbean and Latin American markets has grown tremendously over the last decade, and at least half of the passengers arriving by plane are business travelers. For them, Miami has become a more inviting place than it was when it only offered sun and sand, and it is certainly a good place to mix business and pleasure in winter, for there's nothing like closing a deal and returning home with a suntan.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday about peace centers in the county, a word was omitted in reporting the remarks of Dr. Peri Faithorn. the sentence should have read: ''In my practice, I'm aware of many people who are not consciously concerned with nuclear war who are having more and more dreams of a nuclear holocaust.'' In the same article, the first name of Dr. Adma d'Heurle was mispelled.

title: PARIS SPEEDS SELF-RULE FOR SOUTH PACIFIC ISLAND
description: France, in an attempt to halt a wave of violence in New Caledonia, announced today that it was speeding up the self-determination process for its South Pacific territory and said this could lead to its independence.

title: DISCOVERING THE OTHER YOSEMITE
description: LYNN ROSELLINI, formerly a correspondent for The New York Times, is a writer based in Washington, D.C.

title: Draft Evasion
description: Most Swedish men between the ages of 17 and 28 are subject to a military draft, but not, it turns out, if they are world-class tennis players. It seems the law applies only to residents of Sweden, and according to one Swedish official, tournament professionals routinely avoid military service either by arranging to be in foreign tournaments when the draft notices are sent out or by moving out of the country altogether.

title: L.I.R.R. EYES A 'TROLLEY' LINE FOR OYSTER BAY
description: A YEAR-LONG study may literally turn the Long Island Rail Road in a different direction. With evidence of dwindling ridership on the Oyster Bay branch, the railroad is considering several proposals, including the establishment of a north- south light rail trolley-type line, the first on the Island. It would run from Oyster Bay to Mineola, necessitating an added transfer for commuters, but at the same time possibly creating a new travel mode for thousands of other Long Islanders, according to a railroad spokesman, Don Malone.

title: COMMUNICATION GAP
description: Accidents at the bridge- table, like the products of H.J.Heinz, come in 57 varieties. In almost all cases the source of the trouble is immediately obvious. A player who makes an insufficient bid, or leads out of turn, or exposes a card, does not need to explain what has happened. Sometimes it is easy to diagnose the problem: A player who opens one no- trump, announcing 16-18 points, and then produces a 20-point dummy, has clearly had a miscalculation.

title: SUSPENDED POLICE OFFICER RETURNS TO JOB
description: MOUNT KISCO

title: RIDING HIGH IN THE MIDDLE WEST
description: NOEL PERRIN, whose most recent book is ''Third Person Rural: Further Essays of a Sometime Farmer,'' teaches American literature at Dartmouth.

title: HUNDREDS SEEK CURES IN RADIOACTIVE MINES
description: People from all over the world, many of them lame or bent, come here hoping for a miracle but content to accept whatever relief nature, their prayers or their minds might afford.

title: Self-Management ; And Bookkeeping

title: A 'Matter of Law'
description: When Bernice Lane was sentenced in 1977 after being convicted of selling 2.9 ounces of heroin, the judge said he would have imposed a ''substantially lesser'' term if possible. But under New York State's drug laws, the sentence for her first conviction was mandatory: 15 years to life in prison.

title: DON'T BLAME THE SCREENWRITER WHEN THE GLUE IS MISSING
description: It seems to me high time that we

title: CUTTING ACID RAIN WOULD AID 2 UPSTATE LAKES, STUDY FINDS
description: A study sponsored by private utilities finds that reducing acid rain would clearly benefit at least one deadened lake in the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York, although not enough to restore a flourishing fish population.

title: ALBANY, WITH CUOMO'S SUPPORT, TO CONSIDER RAISES FOR OFFICIALS
description: Legislative leaders in Albany have asked Governor Cuomo to support salary increases for state legislators, judges and commissioners, and for the governor and the three other officials elected statewide.

title: Demolition Is Delayed At New Orleans Fair Site
description: The demolition of buildings on the site of the 1984 World Fair has been delayed by a Federal bankruptcy judge who wants to find out if the structures could be used to raise money to pay off fair contractors.

title: LANE TRAVELED CIRCUITOUS ROUTE TO JETS' SECONDARY
description: Skip Lane of Westport, Conn., the son of Paul Lane, the longtime coach of Staples High School there, is playing for the Jets these days. He does not play often, but he is present and accounted for.

title: WELFARE OFFICE BECOMES A HOME OF LAST RESORT
description: THE number of homeless

PRIMARIES, FAST TRACKS AND OTHER PLACES WHERE YUPPIES PLAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Miriam W. Payne Is Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Leon M. Payne of Houston of the engagement of her daughter, Miriam Wilson Payne, to Charles Horry Prioleau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Means Prioleau of Darien, Conn. The wedding is to take place Jan. 12.

title: FEAR NOT THE NAME, ONLY THE PLAY
description: BEFORE a recent performance of ''Rainsnakes'' at the Long Wharf Theater Stage II in New Haven, a subscriber asked at the box office, with trepidation, whether there were any snakes on stage. His waiting wife, he said, was afraid to come inside.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
INTERNATIONAL SHOW HIGHLIGHTS BUSY SCHEDULE
description: A veritable banquet of coin- related activities is scheduled for coin collectors in and around New York in the next two weeks.

title: A DOCUMENTARY IN PRAISE OF A MEMORABLE FIRST LADY
description: Television biographies, like those in print, always start with a problem: what to leave in and what to take out. The television problem is different in kind, however, because television is visual; seeing is not the same as reading, and film, unexplained and unexplicated, may not mean very much by itself. At the same time, the worst possible way to do a television biography, or even a reminiscence, is to have a lot of people commenting on, or recalling,the sub ject. Talking heads can deaden even the liveliest film, and a documentary can use them only with care. ''We Remember Eleanor,'' a one-hour documentary produced by WNEW- TV, uses them with great care, and the result is a modest triumph. The intelligent, even moving, work will be shown on Channel 5 at 9 tonight.

title: THE RE-EDUCATION OF A 'STINKING INTELLECTUAL'
description: Judith Shapiro is the co-author, with Liang Heng, of ''Son of the Revolution'' and ''Intellectual Freedom in China After Mao.'' SIX CHAPTERS FROM MY LIFE ''DOWNUNDER''

title: G.M. REJECTS A PLEA BY FEDERAL AGENCY FOR RECALL OF X-CARS
description: The General Motors Corporation has rejected a Government request that it recall its 1.1 million 1980 X-cars.

title: MOSLEMS MAKING THEIR MARK IN OHIO
description: When Barbara Loder looks out her bedroom window across the flat Ohio fields, she sees a gleaming white brick mosque, a $3 million structure rising alongside cornstalks and barns.

title: Citing Pretoria Ties, Yale Curbs Portfolio
description: Yale University's governing board has voted to stop investing in three companies doing business in South Africa, saying they have failed to comply with a fair employment code.

title: JERSEY TESTS A POLYESTER REEF AS LURE FOR OCEAN CREATURES
description: Strips of polyester netting attached to concrete blocks and empty plastic milk jugs form an unusual breeding ground for sea life in an experiment that began this week four miles off New Jersey's coast.

title: JERSEY TO SUE 7 COUNTIES OVER LATE LANDFILL PLANS
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection plans to file suit next week against seven counties that it says have failed to submit acceptable plans for disposing of solid waste, according to a department spokesman.

title: Miss Gillin Weds Wesley Lang Jr.
description: Mary Margaret Gillin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Matthew Gillin of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Wesley Warren Lang Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lang of Garden City, L.I., were married yesterday in Villanova, Pa. Auxiliary Bishop Francis B. Schulte of Philadelphia performed the ceremony at St. Thomas of Villanova Roman Catholic Church.

description: Featuring George Carlin Vestron Video 59 minutes. $59.95

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SHIRLEY KAYE, supervisor of Newark's municipal telephone systems, has been on the job for 42 years and often thinks about retiring. But, she says, that would be tantamount to living a life of poverty.

title: NEW JERSYANS
description: RUSSELL PETERSON never thought he would end up in jail. ''That was my last choice,'' he said. ''I never had a police record in my life, only traffic tickets.''

title: FAREWELL TO A BEARD
description: is an assistant metropolitan editor of The New York Times.

title: BASKING IN THE MAJORITY
description: HARTFORD FOR Philip S. Robertson, the most surprising thing about shifting from the minority to the majority party in the State Senate has been the telephone calls.

title: MANUFACTURING SIMPLICITY, JUST IN TIME
description: Following are excerpts from ''Japanese Manufacturing Techniques, Nine Hidden Lessons in Simplicity,'' by Richard J. Schonberger, published by The Free Press.

title: YALE STUDENT'S SENIOR PROJECT WAS A 5-WEEK 'SELF' PORTRAIT
description: To fulfill the requirement of a senior project, most Yale University students research and write lengthy papers, create art portfolios or direct plays.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; City to Sell Bonds to Pay Paralyzed Policeman
description: The City Council has resorted to a bond sale so that South Tucson, which once faced bankruptcy, can pay a $3 million court settlement to an injured former policeman.

title: Jennifer Eckrich Becomes Bride Of James Gregg
description: Jennifer Louise Eckrich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Eckrich of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to James Gordon Gregg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Gregg of Bernardville, N.J. The Rev. Francis Virgulak, assisted by the Rev. William Donovan, performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Noroton, Conn.

title: Alfred J. Yardley Jr., 44, Dies; Chairman of Jenkins Canada
description: Alfred J. Yardley Jr., chairman of the board of Jenkins Canada of Lachine, Quebec, died Thursday at his home after a long illness. He was 44 years old and lived on Middle Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: Arthur Hatzopoulos Weds Susan Sanford in Tenafly
description: Susan Sanford, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James R. Sanford of Bellport, L.I., was married yesterday to Arthur Hatzopoulos, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine Hatzopoulos of Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. Socrates Tsamutalis performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Paula Schwed Bride Of Matthew C. Quinn
description: Paula Ann Schwed, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Schwed of Fort Pierce, Fla., was married yesterday to Matthew Coleman Quinn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Quinn of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Gavigan performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: AFFORDABLE BERGEN CONDOMINIUMS
description: -unit town-house development in Englewood two years ago, Ananda S. C. DeSilva set out to prove a point.

title: RESTLESS SOUL OF A ROCK-HARD LINEBACKER
description: Last spring, 4-year-old Aja Carson put down her doll and looked up to the bear of a man sitting opposite her.

title:
GARDENING;
TAKE CARE WITH THE AMARYLLIS BULB
description: ONE of the showiest of flowering bulbs for indoor forcing is the amaryllis. It can be relied on to produce clusters of as many as four six- to eight-inch flowers atop a single flowering stem that may reach two feet or more in height. More properly called Hippeastrum, the amaryllis that is commonly planted is of hybrid origin and is not found in the wild.

title: DIX HILLS ZONING RIFT GROWS
description: THE parties to a typical suburban zoning controversy are often a business seeking a zoning change and a group of homeowners demanding that things stay as they are. But in a dispute in Dix Hills, the roles have been reversed: homeowners are seeking the zoning change while a business fights to keep the status quo.

title: No Headline
description: A directory in the Fall Survey of Education on Nov. 11, listing services for parents of the learning-disabled, gave an incorrect telephone number for the New Jersey branch of the Orton Dyslexia Society. Its number is (201) 328-1512.

title: ALL THE BUSINESS BOOKS YOU'LL EVER NEED
description: ''The Good Book Guide for Business,'' from the publishers of The Good Book Guide and The Economist. Harper & Row, N.Y. 317 pages, $20

title: 'GUYS AND DOLLS' IN MILLBURN
description: MILLBURN ONE CAN go on about whether ''Guys and Dolls'' is the best Broadway musical ever, or just one of the top two or three. With recent stagings in Britain's National Theater and the Guthrie in Minneapolis, the show's status as a classic is as established as the floating crap game it celebrates.

title: BECOMING A WRITER WAS SUCCESS ENOUGH
description: SAROYAN

title: SENATE DEPLORES DISARRAY IN NEW CHAMBER OF EQUALS
description: The United States Senate was created as a legislative aristocracy whose members' six-year terms would insulate them from passing political passions. In the view of many senators, however, it has degenerated into a raucous town meeting, focusing on narrow issues of the moment rather than the broad policy decisions envisioned by the founding fathers.

title: Connecticut Reports A Better Bond Rating
description: The State Treasurer, Henry E. Parker, said this week that the state's bond rating had been upgraded from AA- minus to AA by Standard & Poor's Corporation, one of two rating agencies for state securities.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: Joiner Goes for Mark
description: For someone who started out as a defensive back, Charlie Joiner has caught a lot of passes over the years, so many, in fact, that if the 37-year- old Charger receiver catches five more when San Diego plays the Steelers in Pittsburgh this afternoon, he will set a National Football League record. Joiner has already caught 645 passes, including 49 this season.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Not often does life provide an opportunity to go from the sublime to the ridiculous as rapidly as this week, when two of 1983's better movies - ''Silkwood'' and ''To Be or Not to Be'' - come to cable for the first time.

title: A MUSICAL THEATER BREAKTHROUGH
description: Frank Rich's article on Stephen Sondheim and ''Sunday in the Park With George'' seemed like nothing more than a rationalization for a show that is musically, visually, intellectually and emotionally one-dimensional.

title: Correction
description: In a review in the Children's Book Issue (Nov. 11), the title of a book by Grace Hechinger was given incorrectly. It is titled ''How to Raise a Street Smart Child.''

title: FROM CAMEMBERT TO SEAFOOD
description: PATRICIA WELLS, restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune, is the author of ''The Food Lover's Guide to Paris'' (Workman).

title: TOMORROW marks a tragic anniversary for the Grucci family of Bellport
description: It was a year ago that a chain of explosions destroyed the family's fireworks plant, killing James Grucci and his second cousin, Donna Gruber. The blasts also injured 24 neighbors and damaged more than a hundred homes in the immediate area.

title: Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARP TAKING PART OF FORD PLANT SITE
description: When the Ford Motor Company locked the gates of its Mahwah, N.J., assembly plant four years ago, throwing 3,350 people out of work, the strength of Japanese car imports, no doubt, had a hand in turning the key.

title: LOCAL LEADERS SEEK CHANGES IN BOND FORMULA
description: County and local government leaders are at odds with Governor Cuomo over how to share the sale of $2.6 billion worth of industrial development bonds in the next fiscal year.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: AS many will attest, finding the right house in Westchester is no easy feat. And even then, problems can arise. The Westchester Children's Association, a White Plains-based nonprofit agency founded in 1923 to promote the welfare of children, discovered that last April when its attempt to open the county's first emergency shelter for homeless and runaway youths was thwarted. Although the association had found a suitable location in White Plains, the City Council there would not grant it a special zoning permit.

title: Barbara G. Apple Is Minnesota Bride
description: Barbara Gale Apple, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Apple of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to William R. Sullivan, a son of Donna Sullivan of Alexandria, Va., and the late Col. William G. Sullivan, U.S.A. Judge Eugene Menenko of the Hennepin County District Court performed the ceremony at the Lafayette Club in Minnetonka Beach, Minn.

title: THE WORLD ; Salvador FailsA Rights Test
description: Bringing to justice those who murdered two American advisers on land reform has long been considered a test, particularly in the United States Congress, of El Salvador's determination to end human rights abuses. Last week, the Salvadoran Supreme Court halted all proceedings against Lieut. Isidro Lopez Sibrian, who, according to two men convicted of carrying out the 1981 murders, had issued the orders and furnished the weapons.

title: TELEMANN RIDES A RISING TIDE OF POPULARITY
description: The roller-coaster reputation of Georg Philipp Telemann over three centuries ended with critical and popular favor, which is today reflected in the constant release of recordings of his music. Considered the leading German musician in the first half of the 18th century, when Bach was also active, he lost status after his death. The vast amount of music he produced came to be regarded as trivial. No one could write that much, it was said, and produce serious results. A reevaluation of his music, beginning in the first quarter of this century, brought critical admiration and respect, and in the rising tide of popularity for Baroque music has found a wide audience today.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
A LIFE AT 50: BALANCING THE SEESAW
description: THIS has been a big year for 50th birthdays. I was invited to three surprise parties for friends' 50ths, gave a fourth for my husband's, and flew to Mexico City to celebrate a fifth. (I must have misplaced my invitations to Gloria Steinem's 50th birthday bash and to Shirley MacLaine's, Jane Byrne's and Van Cliburn's.) Nineteen Thirty-Four was a vintage year! My own 50th did not exactly make the social columns, but more about that later.

title: ALBANIA OPENING ITS DOOR TO BONN
description: In a year that has seen Albania move gradually toward expanding relations with other European countries, the Albanian Government is making slow progress in improving relations with West Germany, according to Western diplomats.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
HOW A BOOK CHANGED INTEL'S WAYS
description: About a year ago, while traveling

title: Iran's Premier Accuses Red Cross of Spying
description: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi said today that the International Committee of the Red Cross must change its policy before it will be allowed to operate further in Iran.

title: VENEZUELA FOCUS AT UCONN
description: CONNECTICUT and Venezuela are more than 2,000 miles and a hemisphere apart but a group of people in each place is trying to bridge that distance.

title: '37 AIR RIDDLE: SIBERIAN LAKE YIELDS A CLUE
description: A Soviet search party in central Siberia says it may have found the remains of a plane and crew that vanished in 1937 on a celebrated pioneering flight across the Arctic from Moscow to Fairbanks, Alaska.

title: WHEN GARDEN WAS THE PLACE FOR BASKETBALL WISE
description: ''MEETCHA under the Marquee at the Garden'' was the signal for a night of sports excitement. It was a graceful Art Deco theater-type marquee on the west side of Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th streets. The four teams in that night's doubleheader would be lettered on its sides, and the match- ups were magical: St. John's-Utah, C.C.N.Y.-Bradley. Or L.I.U.-Oklahoma A & M, N.Y.U.-Holy Cross. Or C.C.N.Y.-N.Y.U., Manhattan-St. John's. The marquee announced the best college games in the country. And capacity crowds of more than 18,000 would gather.

title: 'Brights Lights, Big City'
description: A young man works for a New York magazine in the Department of Factual Verification, where facts are tracked ''through dusty volumes, along skeins of microfilm, across transcontinental telephone cables, till they prove good or are exposed as error.'' Factual error cannot appear in this magazine, and it sure sounds like The New Yorker, though it is never named in Jay McInerney's first novel, ''Brights Lights, Big City.'' In any event, our hero does not fit in. ''Should you call up the president of the Polar Explorers and ask if it's true that someone was wearing a headdress made out of walrus skin?'' asks the narrator, who uses present-tense verbs and second-person pronouns, presumably apostrophizing himself. ''Does it matter?''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A CASE FOR NOT HAVING HAMSTERS
description: THIS is the story of the day Hermione the hamster died. It was a cold day in November. The kids had been home from school a half hour or so. They were watching ''Popeye'' on Channel 5.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
TOWARD GREATER U.S. COMPETITIVENESS
description: While there is much debate over whether taxes do or do not need to be increased to reduce the deficit, almost everyone in Washington, on Wall Street and in the academic community agrees that basic reforms are needed. The goals are to promote simplicity, equity, savings and investment.

title: A Hug Is Good for You, Women's Group Says
description: A women's group has found a force for raising money while promoting an activity that is said to relieve physical and emotional problems. The force is hugging.

title: Club for Homosexuals Loses Appeal on Membership List
description: Government officials may require a social club to disclose its list of members, even if most are homosexual, when it applies for a liquor license, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled Friday.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: STATE officials, legislators, aides and lobbyists say the Legislature has been so inundated by environmental bills that the public often does not get legal notification of required hearings.

title:
GARDENING;
TAKE CARE WITH THE AMARYLLIS BULB
description: ONE of the showiest of flowering bulbs for indoor forcing is the amaryllis. It can be relied on to produce clusters of as many as four six- to eight-inch flowers atop a single flowering stem that may reach two feet or more in height. More properly called Hippeastrum, the amaryllis that is commonly planted is of hybrid origin and is not found in the wild.

title: EXPERTS SAY JOB BIAS AGAINST WOMEN PERSISTS
description: Despite years of progress in the workplace, American women still face job discrimination so deep and pervasive that it will be years before they begin to approach parity with male workers, experts say.

title: DEMOCRACY GAINS IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA
description: UNDER flawed conditions, Uruguay is holding elections today for a president and congress. If everything goes according to schedule, civilians will assume power in March after more than 11 years of military rule.

title: POLICE CHECK REPORT THAT OFFICER PASSED FILE TO CRIME FIGURE
description: Law-enforcement authorities are investigating whether a New York City police detective passed copies of a confidential file to a member of the Gambino crime organization who was convicted last month on Federal charges of distributing heroin, police officials said yesterday.

title: Boston Mystery
description: Returning to the Harvard Graduate School of Design after spending Thanksgiving at her home in Glen Ridge, N.J., Joan Webster got off the air shuttle at Logan International Airport in Boston, picked up her luggage and disappeared.

title: HERO FOSSIL HUNTERS
description: Donald E. Savage is a professor of paleontology at the University of California at Berkeley. DISCOVERERS OF THE LOST WORLD

title: Jersey Suspends 14 Car Examiners
description: Fourteen examiners at the state's Eatontown motor vehicle inspection station have been suspended without pay after an investigation found that almost half of them there were approving cars in violation of regulations, officials said.

title: THE REGION ; Man Kills Relative And Is Shot Dead
description: The police shot and killed a 28- year-old man after he killed his adoptive grandfather and critically wounded his adoptive grandmother because they planned to sell their house and move to Florida, authorities said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1984 International Ground for compromise with Moscow will be sought by the United States in preliminary arms-control talks between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Secretary Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva on Jan. 7-8. Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, said the United States was prepared to ''flexible and constructive'' in the negotiations. (Page A1, Column 6.) A Philippines Communist insurgency is growing rapidly, largely because people have begun to accept its presence, Filipino officials say. The insurgency is strongest on the big southern island of Mindanao. A gun-toting Wild West atmosphere prevails there. Law and order is often lacking and, according to human rights groups, abuses by the Philippine military are frequent. (A1:5.)

title: Bathing in Space
description: Life in space is not all glamorous exploits, like recapturing errant

title: Nurses Lose Case on Theory Of Comparing Pay to Men's
description: A hearing officer has rejected a claim by 75 public health nurses that they were victims of discrimination because their wages are lower than those of physician's assistants, who are male.

title: Economic Freedom Is Swedish Issue
description: Sweden's official unemployment rate is under 3.5 percent and both the industrial and service sectors of the economy are thriving. Why, then, is Olof Palme's ruling Social Democratic Party trailing its nonsocialist opposition in the public opinion polls as Sweden starts on the road to next September's elections?

title: Japan Railways: Sleek, but Troubled
description: For a change, the Japanese are grousing about their prized railroad system almost the way New Yorkers do about the subways.

title: Crabs, Fresh from China
description: Even by crab standards these are

title: Army to Enforce Beirut Plan
description: The Lebanese Army issued orders today for troops to begin enforcing a security plan for Beirut by dismantling militia barricades and taking up positions in predominantly Moslem West Beirut. At Suk al Gharb, nine miles east of Beirut, two civilians were killed as troops fought with Druse militiamen in neighboring villages with mortars and rocket-propelled grenades.

title: Debt Issues
description: * A.R.A Manufacturing Co. filed for an offering of 45,000 units through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as the sole underwriter.

title: Advertising; In Pursuit of Accounts
description: IN many areas advertising augments the work of salespeople. In

title: Tarantara Wins Aqueduct Feature
description: Rena-Kim Stable's Tarantara rallied in the middle of the track yesterday to score a hard fought victory in the $76,900 Sport Page Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct.

title: NORTH CAROLINA RALLIES TO BEAT FORDHAM
description: Brad Daugherty scored a career- high 22 points and Dave Popson added a career-best 14 points as North Carolina rallied from a first-half deficit for an 81-65 college basketball victory over Fordham today.

title: OLYMPIC PROPOSAL REJECTED
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation has rejected a request from organizers of the 1988 Seoul Olympics to transfer some athletic events to morning schedules to accommodate television.

title: Indiana Neighbors Join In 'Prayer for Healing'
description: About 600 people gathered at William J. Schroeder's church tonight to join in a ''prayer for healing'' for the second recipient of a permanent artificial heart.

title: REPORT ASSAILS COLLEGE FAILURES IN HUMANITIES
description: American colleges and universities are failing to give students ''an adequate education in the culture and civilization of which they are members,'' a panel convened by the National Endowment for the Humanities asserted yesterday.

title: Iranian Oil Cited in Price Downturn
description: International oil traders and others will be keeping an anxious eye on the spot crude market Monday to assess Friday's collapse of oil prices in Europe.

title: STUDENT PROTESTS GROWING IN SEOUL
description: Anti-Government protests by South Korean college students have surged in recent weeks, with demonstrators adopting increasingly bolder tactics in an attempt to force confrontations with authorities.

title: MEETING THE CHALLENGE ON DEFICITS
description: Are you worried about the Federal deficit? If you're not, you should be.

title: An 8-Footer For $240,000
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. Through the years, Jack Nicklaus has had a reputation not only as the best golfer in history but also as the best pressure putter. If you had to choose a golfer to make an 8-footer for your life, other touring pros often joked, you would want the Golden Bear putting for you. Neither his life nor anybody else's was at stake yesterday on the 18th green at Desert Highlands in the Skins Game, only $240,000 was at stake - but Jack Nicklaus made an 8-footer.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: JOBS NOW OUTNUMBER WORKERS IN THE BOSTON AREA
description: Bloomingdale's employees get a bounty for bringing in new workers. A discount department store offers day care to entice young mothers to work. The airwaves vibrate with advertisements promising employment with good benefits.

title: IN ISRAEL, THE GOVERNMENT IS THE ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPETITION IS WHAT THE CABLE INDUSTRY NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida's Storm Ends, Leaving Damage Behind
description: Winds and seas along the east coast of Florida subsided today, ending a three-day storm that gouged beaches and caused millions of dollars in damage along the hundreds of miles of shoreline from St. Augustine to Palm Beach.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MYSTERY BLUES Two detectives investigate the disappearance and possible murder of a trumpet player. It can be revealed without spoiling the play that the detectives themselves die but keep walking around. It is only one of the mysteries in ''Suicide in B Flat,'' the second of three ''jazz plays'' written by Sam Shepard in the late 1960's and early 70's and being revived as ''Shepard Sets'' at La Mama Annex, 74A East Fourth Street, west of Second Avenue.

title: Lenore Matson Is Married To Comptroller in Florida
description: Lenore Matson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Matson of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Marquez, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Marquez of Miami. Judge Norman Gerstein of the Dade County Court performed the ceremony at the Coral Gables (Fla.)

title: COLD-BLOODED PLAY GAVE KARPOV HIS 5TH VICTORY
description: Precise, cold-blooded end-game play brought victory to the world chess champion, 33-year-old Anatoly Karpov, in the 27th game of the title match in Moscow on Saturday. He now leads the 21-year-old challenger, Gary Kasparov, 5-0, and needs only one more victory to complete a successful title defense.

title: DANCE: NINA MARTIN PRESENTS 'COPYRIGHT'
description: What's new? That question kept being asked in ''Copyright,'' the bitterly amusing dance-theater work that Nina Martin presented Saturday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. The answer each of the characters she created gave to the question appeared to be ''I'm new. You'd better believe me. And you'd better applaud me.''

title: Race Broken Up By Spectators
description: Organizers called off the fifth annual Canillejas road race today after a spectator had pushed over a runner who was leading, and other spectators had prevented another runner from reaching the finish line.

title: CITY TRIES TO KEEP YOUNG MOTHERS IN SCHOOL
description: New York City and its school system, trying to prevent teen-age girls from leaving school to care for their out-of-wedlock babies, are now financing day-care centers for young mothers in 17 high schools.

title: Cronkite Look-Alike
description: Former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, now a

title: BOWLS WON'T SETTLE NO. 1 COLLEGE SPOT;
description: This curious and sometimes exciting 116th college football season will wind down with a record 36 teams in 18 bowl games from Dec. 15 to Jan. 1. The lengthy final act may result in no more conclusive a decision about the No. 1 team in the nation than there was in the first season, 1869, when two games were played and Princeton and Rutgers split them.

title: THE GROWTH RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON It was 1970, and the economy was

title: Tariff Group Meets Today
description: The governing body for world trade opens an annual meeting of its 90 contracting parties Monday under a cloud of despondency over its failure to stem growing protectionism.

title: TRIVIAL PRESIDENTIAL PURSUITS
description: The answer was Ronald Reagan, but what was the question?

title: Meridian Bancorp Capital Notes Set
description: Meridian Bancorp, based in Reading, Pa., is offering $75 million of floating rate subordinated capital notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.20 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Navratilova Runs Her Streak to 70
description: Martina Navratilova routed unseeded Ann Henricksson, 6-1, 6-1, today in the final of the $150,000 Family Circle New South Wales tennis championships.

title: Weapons Search Stalls Train Traffic
description: A Philadelphia-to-Boston Amtrak train with 500 passengers aboard was halted at New Haven for 90 minutes yesterday as authorities searched unsuccessfully for four men believed to be carrying weapons.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1984

title: Leonard S. Baker, 54, Dies; Won a Pulitzer Prize in 1979
description: Leonard S. Baker, a writer whose book, ''Days of Sorrow and Pain: Leo Baeck and the Berlin Jews,'' won the 1979 Pulitzer Prize for biography, died of cancer Friday in George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 54 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Kodak's New Manager For Communication Bid
description: With the Eastman Kodak Company's announcement last week that it planned to enter the telecommunications market, the brainchild of Lester G. Miller was born.

title: CARDINALS DOWN EAGLES ON A FIELD GOAL
description: Neil O'Donoghue kicked a 44-yard field goal with eight seconds left today to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 17-16 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: IT'S NO JOKE TO BE A HUMOR CONSULTANT TO INDUSTRY
description: What does a fellow from Queens do with a master's in communications, a reputation as a theorist on language behavior, a law degree and a second place on ''The Gong Show'' with a trained plant act? Why, move to San Francisco and set up shop as a humor consultant to industry.

title: SALVADOR TALKS TO BE HELD FRIDAY
description: Government and leftist rebel representatives will meet in El Salvador for a second round of peace talks on Friday, the country's Roman Catholic Archbishop announced today.

title: C.I.A. IS LESS THAN TOP-NOTCH IN AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: FEWER WOMEN HEAD PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: It could be called ''The Case of the Vanishing Headmistress,'' but in the view of many of the women involved in running private secondary schools there is no mystery at all. When a drop in enrollment began to pinch private schools' finances in the late 1960's, many noncoeducational schools merged with others or became coeducational. In the ensuing years, boards of trustees at school after school, including many that enroll only girls, have named men to their top positions in the belief that men cope best with the problems of recruitment, administration and fund-raising.

title: Results Mixed for Tool Orders
description: United States machine tool orders, a gauge of business plans to increase production, rose 40 percent in October, to $283.5 million, from $202.6 million a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported yesterday. But the figure was down nine-tenths of 1 percent from September's level of $286.2 million.

title: JMB ADDS DEVELOPER TO ITS REAL ESTATE ROLES
description: When Neil G. Bluhm, president of the JMB Realty Corporation, is asked to appraise the nearly square block of vacant land across from his company's headquarters on Chicago's exclusive North Michigan Avenue, he smiles and calls it ''just a hunk of dirt right now.''

title: wo Generations of Fans
description: The older man was astonished when
