title: Ceil Cleveland Is Wed to J. K. Footlick
description: Ceil Cleveland, the senior public affairs officer for Columbia University development and editor in chief of Columbia, the university magazine, was married yesterday to Jerrold K. Footlick, a senior editor of Newsweek magazine and managing editor of Newsweek on Campus. Judge Sol M. Wachtler of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the Coffee House Club.

title: U.S. CALLED READY TO BE 'FLEXIBLE' AT TALKS ON ARMS
description: President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, said today that the United States was prepared to be ''flexible and constructive'' in arms- control talks with the Soviet Union.

title: COTTON-DUST PLAN WAS DROPPED
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR LOCAL TALENT, NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: The metropolitan area has long been fertile territory for out-of-town college basketball recruiters. The helpless local coaches could only hope loneliness and disenchantment would force some talented players to transfer back to a school in the New York area. Many did.

title: IN THE HELL OF A NAIROBI SLUM, A PRIEST OFFERS HOPE
description: A few miles and an eternity from here sprawls the Mathare Valley, a place where poverty would be a step up and despair expands its definition.

title: BRONCOS BEATEN BY 27-24
description: A combination of excellence and luck enabled the Seattle Seahawks to end their long chase of the Denver Broncos today.

title: FILIPINO INSURGERNCY IS REPORTED TO GROW IN ALL 73 PROVINCES
description: A Communist insurgency is growing rapidly throughout the Philippines, in part because people have begun to accept its presence, Filipino officials and foreign diplomats say.

title: Basques Claim Role in Blast
description: The French Basque separatist group Iparretarak claimed responsibility today for planting a bomb that partially destroyed a newly constructed police station on the French side of the Pyrenee Mountains.

title: HOSPITAL EXECUTIVES CONSIDER OPERATION 'WISE INVESTMENT'
description: It is one of the largest for-profit health-care companies in the country, but until this weekend Humana Inc. was not widely known except in the cities where it operates its hospitals.

title: Royal Heroine Wins on Coast
description: Royal Heroine stalked front- running Sabin for a mile before cutting loose in the stretch to score a one- length victory today in the $200,000 Matriarch Stakes for fillies and mares on the turf at Hollywood Park.

title: U.S. Embassy in Lisbon Attacked With Grenades
description: Four grenades exploded today at the United States Embassy here, damaging three cars but causing no casualties.

title: Thomas Ruppert, 35; Cleared of Yonkers Fire
description: Thomas Alfred Ruppert, whose conviction for setting a fire in 1965 that killed 12 people at the Yonkers Jewish Community Center was overturned on appeal, died Friday at the Jersey City Medical Center in Jersey City. He was 35 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: INDIA POLITICS: THE SUN SETS ON OLD WAYS
description: D. K. Borooah, a veteran of India's struggle for independence, was sitting down for egg-and- tomato sandwiches as the sun set behind his veranda a few days ago.

title: Tradition Hits Homer
description: The struggle involved some of the biggest names in baseball, the stakes were high and both sides sent impressive lineups to the plate. But when the dust settled in Federal Court in Manhattan last week, the challengers had been routed and a venerable baseball tradition had been declared safe.

title: BIPARTISAN PANEL URGED FOR DEFICIT
description: Municipal leaders, worried that cities would suffer from efforts by the Reagan Administration to reduce the Federal deficit, today endorsed a proposal to turn the problem over to a national bipartisan commission for study.

title: PROFESSIONALS BLAMED FOR VEHICLE THEFT RISE
description: So many professional criminals have taken up stealing automobiles that the chance of recovering a stolen vehicle has declined to little better than 50-50, a Federal study reported today.

title: C.I.A. COMPLAINT RAISES FIRST AMENDMENT ISSUE
description: NewsAnalysis

title: JOINER SETS RECORD, BUTSTEELERS ROMP
description: Mark Malone riddled San Diego's secondary for four scoring passes, three to John Stallworth, and ran for a touchdown as the Pittsburgh Steelers routed the error-prone San Diego Chargers, 52-24, today.

title: BLUE LAWS, LANGUAGE AND COFFEE
description: In the South, more than elsewhere in the nation, local and state governments have continued to uphold and defend ''blue laws,'' ordinances dating to the 18th century that bar certain kinds of commerce on Sundays.

title: Mitterrand Announces Chernenko Might Visit
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, is to visit Paris next year, ''events permitting.''

title: FOURSOME IS MAKING A BID TO EQUAL 45-YEAR-OLD MARK
description: An East Coast foursome was making a strong effort on the final day of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon to match a 45-year-old record.

title: DANCE: TAGLIONI IN ART
description: ''Mademoiselle Taglioni is not a dancer, she is the embodiment of dancing.'' So wrote the French Romantic poet, Theophile Gautier, about Marie Taglioni, the 19th century's most famous ballerina and the original ''Sylphide.''

title: Gary Seem Weds Miss Scancarelli
description: Lauren Elise Scancarelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Lawrence Scancarelli of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary Sammis Seem, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Seem of Oakmont, Pa. The Rev. Harry Aufiero performed the Congregational ceremony at the Bronxville (N.Y.) Field Club.

title: AUDIO DISK PLAYERS COMING OF AGE
description: Sharply declining prices and a new portable model made by the Sony Corporation have brought the compact audio disk player, which has done only moderately well since it was introduced in the United States in 1983, into the consumer mainstream.

title: CHILE TO REQUIRE FOREIGNERS TO PLEDGE TO OBEY LAW
description: The Government moved today to crack down on foreigners who take part in political activity, issuing a decree that non-Chileans must sign an oath to obey Chile's laws and Constitution.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 26, 1984: MONDAY Amer ExpressNorthwest AirlinesBell South CorpRio Grande IndusConn Natural GasWatkins-JohnsonDetroit Edison

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Fletcher National Bank, Indianapolis, has elected Jerry J. Roberts senior vice president and manager of the Consumer Services Group.

title: Aftershock Felt on Coast
description: An aftershock shook the Sierra Nevada today in the same area where a strong earthquake Friday caused rockslides. No damage or injuries were reported after this morning's quake, which was centered 25 miles northeast of Lake Crowley in the Mammoth Lakes area.

title: Learning To Swim
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. When Zeke Mowatt came to the Giants as a free agent out of Florida State in 1983, he was a tight end who didn't want to catch passes. This is like a duck that doesn't like to swim. He'll waddle, but he'd rather not paddle. In each case, though, the job requires more.

title: THEATER SEEKING NEW HOME
description: The Theater for the New City - one of the oldest avant-garde troupes in New York - is being squeezed out of its longtime home in the East Village by a rent increase of more than 300 percent. And, as of now, the theater has nowhere to move after an agreement with its landlord expires in March.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES, 1-0
description: Hartwick had just one serious scoring threat against Columbia yesterday, but that was enough for a 1-0 victory in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: GOVERNOR TELLS ALBANY CHURCH OF DUTY TO POOR
description: The First Church in Albany has stood on the banks of the Hudson here since 1642, when it was organized by Dutch settlers. In the three and a half centuries since, it has established many traditions, and one of them is inviting laymen to preach.

title: OPERA: 'CLEMENZA'
description: Four singers who have entered the Metropolitan Opera's ''Clemenza di Tito'' cast over the past weeks appeared together for the first and (as the schedule stands) only time Saturday evening. That is a shame, since each one was a distinct improvement over the opening-night roster that is to return when the opera reappears in January.

title: Dr. Susan Tarnofsky Weds R. J. Grossman
description: Dr. Susan B. Tarnofsky, a dentist at the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center of New Jersey in Jersey City, and Robert J. Grossman, a rating officer for Standard & Poor's Corporation in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Stanley Asekoff performed the ceremony at the Short Hills in Millburn, N.J.

title: INTERSTATE PUCH BY BIG BANKS
description: As William E. Dick sees it, the future of American banking is now being charted here, well removed from the money centers of Manhattan.

title: SURGEONS IMPLANT MECHANICAL PUMP TO REPLACE HEART
description: A 17- member surgical team today removed the diseased heart of a 52-year-old man and replaced it with a plastic-and- metal pump.

title: ; WHERE A VOTER CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Jets vs Dolphins, at Miami. Miami has clinched the American Conference Eastern Division title and a spot in the playoffs.

title: Computerizing the Senate
description: Later than many institutions - but sooner, at least, than the House of Representatives - the Senate is being computerized. Three companies - Honeywell, Data General and Prime - have won the right to compete for the right to automate the senators' offices.

title: CONSOLATIONS ARE RICH
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N.H. My goal, in addition to bagging a deer, on our first day of hunting in this remote wilderness area in northeastern New Hampshire, was to have a look at Lamb Valley Pond, but I accomplished neither.

title: Dear Readers
description: When The New Republic celebrates its 70th birthday at a black-tie fete at the National Portrait Gallery tomorrow, two of the most important if not most recognizable guests will be Dr. Park White of St. Louis, who is 93 years old,, and Herman M. Wessel of Elkins Park, Pa., who is 86. In advance of the observance, the weekly magazine sought out its longest continuing subscribers and came up with Dr. White, who began in 1917 while he was secretary of the Harvard Socialist Club, and Mr. Wessel, whose subscription dates from 1919.

title: ISLANDERS ROLLING WITH TROTTIER BACK
description: Back when the Islanders looked more like an expansion franchise than former champions - all of two weeks ago - their problems were mounting.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;
Dentists and Drills
description: Oblivious to the terror such a scene

title: 2 LATE GIANT SCORES STUN CHIEFS
description: With little more than 9 minutes remaining in the game today, the Kansas City Chiefs completed their third touchdown pass and took a 27-14 lead over the Giants. Many of the 74,383 spectators at Giants Stadium, confident the Giants were finished, headed for the exits.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Black Voters Look to the Future
description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson set out a year ago in pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination, he sought a ''rainbow coalition'' of many groups to press the claims of the poorest Americans. But at heart his campaign was an exhortation, and inspiration, for blacks to use the political system to advance their interests. His slogan that ''hands that once picked cotton can pick a President'' evoked a new surge of black pride, at least in the primary season. Election Day finally found blacks again the most loyal of all the traditional Democratic constituencies - and thus uniquely buried by Ronald Reagan's landslide victory.

title: Dr. Janet Levick Weds Dr. Jonathan Gordon
description: Dr. Janet S. Levick, a fellow in hematology and oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and Dr. Jonathan D. Gordon, chief psychologist at the Holley Child Care and Development Center in Hackensack, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Marshall J. Maltzman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El in Wynnewood, Pa., assisted by the bridegroom's father, Rabbi Morton L. Gordon.

title: SONG: ELLY AMELING PERFORMS DEBUSSY
description: Elly Ameling, heiress to Elisabeth Schumann and Victoria de los Angeles as a charmer and consoler in song, sang as her attentive audience knew she would sing at a sold-out Tully Hall yesterday afternoon.

title: Beagle Channel Treaty Approved in Argentina
description: Argentines today approved a treaty with Chile to end a century of conflict over the Beagle Channel, a strategic and potentially oil-rich waterway at the tip of South America.

title: Lynn, Ray Return to Jets
description: The Jets will get two starters back from their injured secondary, but will lose a starting wide receiver and a linebacker when they face the Dolphins on Monday night.

title: Futures/Options; Analysts See Sugar Deficit
description: IN the eyes of a chartist, swings in world sugar

title: E.E.C. Prices Advance 0.8%
description: Consumer prices in the 10 nations of the European Economic Community rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in October from the previous month, the community's statistical service said Friday. That compared with increases of five-tenths of 1 percent in September and four-tenths of 1 percent in August.

title: 26 in Congress Urge Vatican Ties With Israel
description: A group of 26 Jewish and Roman Catholic members of the House of Representatives issued a letter today calling on the Vatican to recognize Israel.

title: 'DYNASTY' CREATORS JUMP TO DEFEND IT
description: When the Carringtons on ''Dynasty'' argue about lust or finance - which is often - they usually yell, threaten or throw each other in the pool. When Columbia University faculty members and students met the program's creators, Esther and Richard Shapiro, last week to discuss the place of ''Dynasty'' in American life, nobody got wet, but they argued nevertheless, in tones appropriate to the program.

title: NEW DROPS IN INTEREST RATES SEEN
description: Further interest rate declines, to coincide with weak economic data to be announced this week and later this year, are quite likely, some economists said over the weekend.

title: IS NEW YORK CITY'S INCINERATOR PLAN A HEALTH THREAT?
description: Can New York City burn the more than 22,000 tons of garbage it produces each day without polluting the air with chemicals that are believed to promote cancer?

title: JUBILANT URUGUAYANS ELECT CIVILIAN LEADERS
description: Uruguay held general elections today for the first time in 13 years, recovering a democratic tradition that had long distinguished the country within Latin America.

title: ROLE PLAYED BY 'SIDE BAR' CONFERENCE IN CBS TRIAL
description: A. FARBER

title: A Dealer for Harvester Awaits Sale to Tenneco
description: For weeks Robert P. Corley, an International Harvester Company farm equipment dealer near Decatur in central Illinois, has heard rumors about the impending sale of Harvester's agricultural equipment division to Tenneco Inc.

title: Washington Watch; Suggestions On Competition
description: WASHINGTON IN the summer of 1983, the Democratic candidates for President talked a lot about ''industrial policy'' solutions to the ills of flagging businesses and the growing pains of new ones. Republicans said the whole idea reeked of central planning. Even so, Mr. Reagan established a President's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness, which bore a certain euphemistic kinship to the Democrats' terminology.

title: Montreal Blast Kills 4; Dynamite Is Suspected
description: A predawn explosion today in a 21-story building killed 4 men, wounded 8 people and wrecked 8 apartments, the police reported.

title: HELP FOR KING HELPS KNICKS
description: A pattern for victory appears to have emerged in the Knicks' five- game winning streak. The ingredients include a big game from Bernard King, a helping hand offensively from one or maybe two other Knicks and good defense, the chief characteristic of Hubie Brown's coaching.

title: Star War Shootists
description: Critics of President Reagan's plan to build an intercontinental defense system in space will wheel out their heavy artillery today.

title: SOMALI JET HIJACKERS SET A NEW DEADLINE
description: Three hijackers holding 108 hostages aboard a Somali Airlines plane here tonight set a new deadline for Somalia to free a group of political prisoners. Otherwise, they said, they will blow up the plane.

title: ACCORD OFFERED ON DOCUMENTS IN SHARON CASE
description: Israel's Attorney General, Yitzhak Zamir, said today that he was trying to work out an arrangement in which someone acceptable to Ariel Sharon and Time magazine would inspect secret Israeli documents and use them to answer questions posed by a New York court in Mr. Sharon's $50 million libel suit against Time.

title: Give A.T.& T. Some Room on Rates Like other public utilities
description: A.T.& T.'s long-distance phone rates are regulated to insure that its virtual monopoly does not generate excessive profits. But unlike other utilities, the company does compete directly with unregulated companies providing some of the same services.

title: Rockland to Join Indian Point Drill
description: For the first time in two years, Rockland County will participate Wednesday in a Federal drill of emergency- response plans for the counties neighboring the Indian Point nuclear- power plants.

title: Dr. Joanne E. Foodim Wed to Robert Forbes
description: The Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dr. Joanne Ellen Foodim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Foodim of Northport, L.I., to Robert Pierce Forbes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. A. Crosby Forbes of Cambridge, Mass. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: F.D.U. ADVANCES
description: Fairleigh Dickinson, which suffered its only regular season defeat at the hands of Penn State Sept. 21, avenged that loss today with a 1-0 victory in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: Full Slate of U.S. Offerings Planned
description: The Treasury has scheduled a full slate of auctions this week to provide it with short-term money to cover low points in its cash balance and to help finance the Federal budget deficit.

title: FUTURE DOCTORS DEBATE ROLES IN A NUCLEAR AGE
description: A medical student made some informal inquiries at the emergency rooms of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center recently, to find out how it would respond to what doctors there call the final epidemic: a nuclear war.

title: BETTER USES FOR THAT $800 MILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: Added Post for Wang
description: Frederick A. Wang, 34 years old, has been named to the additional post of treasurer of Wang Laboratories Inc. Mr. Wang, who remains executive vice president and chief development officer, will report to Harry H. S. Chou, vice chairman and chief financial officer. Mr. Wang is the son of An Wang, the chairman, chief executive and founder. The Wang family owns 40 percent of the computer company, which is based in Lowell, Mass.

title: WHEN LAW PARTNERS SPLIT UP
description: A law partnership is a fragile entity - especially when one or more of the partners wants out. Suddenly, all the ties of common ownership, shared values and trust that have bound the partners for years may unravel in the face of conflicting claims.

title: RICHARDSON GETS OLD SPARK BACK
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: THE ADULT CHILDREN OF DIVORCE
description: THE youngest child is off at college; the older ones are preoccupied with their independent lives. Why, then, are they all so upset to hear that their parents are getting a divorce?

title: KOCH AND HIS AIDES
description: News Analysis

title: MITTERRAND CRITICIZED OVER PACIFIC ISLE
description: Separatists on the French island of New Caledonia announced that they had created a provisional government today, prompting a denunciation of the Mitterrand Government by five former Gaullist Prime Ministers.

title: EXPLOSION IN LOUISIANA KILLS 5
description: At least five people were killed and 21 injured when a natural gas pipeline that was under repair exploded today, the State Police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Hint in Four Languages
description: ''Tips are part of our salary. Be

title: A TOP ITALIAN WRITER IS MAKING INROADS IN U.S.
description: Asked whether he had spent much time at Mount Holyoke College earlier this month, where he was awarded an honorary degree, Italo Calvino, the Italian writer, replied softly, ''No, I arrived just for the coronation.''

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many teams did Leo Durocher manage in the major leagues and how successful were they? Where does he rank among managers in victories?

title: DANCE: PETER MARTIN'S 'SCHUBERTIAD'
description: ''The tried and the true'' has never been the New York City Ballet's motto. And even many of its familiar works can be seen as still-experimental commentaries upon the past.

title: U.S. VOTES NO AT WORLD BANK MORE OFTEN UNDER REAGAN
description: Representatives of 21 countries were sitting around the oval mahogany table in the 12th-floor boardroom of the World Bank's headquarters on Nov. 2. They were considering a staff proposal to lend $130 million to Colombia's state- owned Ecopetrol oil enterprise for development of the Casabe field in central Colombia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; At 79, a Budding Career
description: Before going to Los Angeles for the

title: THE OPERA: 'ORLANDO'
description: At Carnegie Hall last night, a major event and a major audience success: the opening of the Handel Opera Festival with ''Orlando,'' in what may be the first uncut professional performance of any Handel opera in New York. It was, if not quite a triumph all round artistically, a vivid and inspiring effort, worth a hundred bullseyes at easier targets - both because it clears a path for possible triumphs to come and because it expands our understanding of a composer whose greatness is unchallenged but (in this facet of his work) too nearly unexamined.

title: 30 Revelers Die in Turkey
description: Thirty people were killed and 24 injured today when a truck and a passenger bus carrying wedding revelers home collided head-on in north central Turkey, the state-run Turkish radio reported. The newlyweds were among the dead in the accident near Ilgaz, 90 miles north of Ankara in Cankiri province, according to the semiofficial Anatolia press agency.

title: STARVATION ACROSS AFRICA
description: Most attention is being riveted on the shocking starvation and death in Ethiopia. But Angola, Chad, Mozambique and a growing list of other African countries are not far behind, because years of drought and civil strife have exhausted both the land and its people. There are at least 24 African countries that the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization list as suffering from food shortages.

title: HIGH TRAFFIC DEATH RATE IN HOUSTON IS DROPPING
description: For six years, America's fourth largest city has led the nation in traffic deaths among cities of a million people or more.

title: FORDHAM PLANS HOUSING FOR ELDERLY IN BRONX
description: It was an abandoned parcel of land on a plot next to the Rose Hill Campus of Fordham University in the Bronx. It had become an eyesore and a health hazard, with tons of garbage illegally dumped there over the last five years.

title: MARION FRESCHL
description: Marion Szekely Freschl, voice teacher to opera singers such as Marian Anderson, Shirley Verrett, Camilla Williams and Brenda Lewis, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital after a heart attack.

title: Tributes to Auerbach
description: Basketballs are hardly alien objects at the Boston Garden, but the ones that have popped up around the arena this season are not quite regulation National Basketball Association models. They're the right size and the right color, and from a distance they look authentic enough, but there's one key difference. They're not made of leather, but of sheet metal. They aren't basketballs at all, but special donation boxes for the new Red Auerbach Foundation, which has been formed to honor the longtime Celtic coach and executive, and raise money for youth development in the area.

title: Reactor Unit Shut Down By Problem in a Test
description: A malfunctioning generator caused a reactor to shut down automatically as the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant continued operational tests, officials said today.

title: TOLEDO PLAN INCLUEDE ASSESSING TENURED TEACHERS
description: Last year the pupils in Lynn Burns's fourth-grade class were found to be reading a third- grade book, and school administrators feared that her reading program was deficient.

title: Redskins Romp, Tie for First
description: Charley Brown, Keith Griffin and Art Monk were key players today for the Washington Redskins, who routed the Buffalo Bills, 41-14. John Riggins left with a stiff back after three carries in the first period, the third one good for a touchdown, the 106th in his long career.

title: Presidential Warm-Ups
description: A prevalent political theory has it that Presidential campaigning has become so demanding that a candidate should resign from public office and avoid serious private employment for a year or two before the election, concentrating all efforts on convention delegates and then on electoral votes.

title: ABROAD AT HOME ; POLITICS IN COURT
description: Something strange is happening

title: MET OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'BARBIERE'
description: Were it not for the presence of Kathleen Battle, Saturday afternoon's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' at the Metropolitan Opera would have been one of the house's drabber second-cast performances. As Rossini's Rosina, however, Miss Battle was splendid.

title: BUSINESS GROWTH BRINGS HOTEL BOOM TO SUBURBS
description: When Ralph Widner, an expert on urban problem- solving, flew in from Ohio six years ago to address a business group, his hosts were unable to find a hotel room here for him. So he stayed in New Haven, a 45-minute drive away.

title: PETE JOHNSON, A CASTOFF, FINDS THE GOAL LINE WITH DOLPHINS
description: MIAMI Half a dozen times a game, someone taps Pete Johnson on the shoulder pad and says, ''Score us a touchdown.'' Funny thing is, Johnson has quite a record of delivering.

title: Ethel K. Schwabacher Dies; Artist, Writer, Rights Activist
description: Ethel K. Schwabacher, a painter, writer and civil rights activist, died of a heart attack yesterday in her home. She was 81 myears old and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Ball 4 for Craig
description: When it's been a disastrous, dissension-ridden season in which the players have spent the summer at one another's throats, the owner has been popping off at the manager and the manager has been popping back, nothing can be more riveting than one of those gossipy, day-by-day, feud-by- feud accounts of a baseball campaign gone wrong.

title: By Drew Middleton;
description: TOO SECRET TOO LONG. By Chapman

title: How Much Disclosure?
description: How are the Federal financial disclosure laws working? Do they guard against conflicts of interest among public officials or pry too much into their affairs? Some answers may come soon from the ethics committees of the House and Senate.

title: POLES VOW TO CONTINUE SLAIN PRIEST'S MASSES
description: At least 25,000 people braved a biting wind to celebrate mass tonight at the parish church of the pro-Solidarity priest who was abducted and slain last month, apparently by Government security men.

title: NORDIQUES STOP RANGERS IN OVERTIME
description: It took a closed-door meeting the night before to open up the emotions of the Rangers, to enliven their spirits, and lift their game last night. But it will take more than that to bring them back to winning hockey.

title: BOSTON BANK NAMES BROOKE CHAIRMAN
description: The Boston Bank of Commerce said Edward W. Brooke, a former Republican Senator from Massachusetts, had been named chairman.

title: SENATE'S NEW BREED SHUNS NOVICE ROLE
description: Bob Kasten, a Wisconsin Republican, typifies the changing character of the 98 men and 2 women in today's Senate.

title: DEFIANT PASTOR SENDS A SECOND SERMON FROM JAIL
description: Parishioners of the Trinity Lutheran Church today heard a second sermon sent from the jail cell of their defiant pastor, jailed as a result of a dispute with their bishop.

title: A New Poll on Volcker
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the New York brokerage, will release the results of a poll today reporting on how 163 financial executives believe Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is doing his job. The survey also asked the executives who they would select to replace Mr. Volcker if he leaves, and, in quite a different question, who they believed the President would appoint among 10 high-visibility possibilities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A student can obtain a bachelor's degree from 75 percent of all American colleges and universities without having studied European history, from 72 percent without having studied American literature or history and from 86 percent without having studied the civilizations of classical Greece and Rome.'' - William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. (A20:1.)

title: Hinckley Writes Newsweek Seeking Trade with Sakharov
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot President Reagan in 1981, proposed in comments published today that he be exchanged for Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident who is in internal exile in Gorky.

title: MUSIC: BACH AT THE Y
description: Who are we to say how Bach's B minor Mass should be sung and played? This grand liturgical summation of Christian polyphony - a Latin mass written by a devout Lutheran - fits neither Roman Catholic procedure nor that of Bach's own church and may not have been intended to be performed at all.

title: Lisa Sue Presser Is Wed
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday Lisa Sue Presser and David Hillel Goldberg, third-year students at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University, were married by Rabbi Pinchas Teitz, assisted by Rabbis Eleazer Mayer Teitz and Yakov Hilsenrath. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Presser of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Goldberg of Metuchen, N.J. The bride graduated from Brooklyn College. The bridegroom, an alumnus of Rutgers University, received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University.

title: Partygoers Critically Ill After Drinking Lye
description: -SALEM, N.C., Nov. 25 (AP) - Three people who mistook a corrosive liquid for wine were in critical condition today with internal injuries, including one whose esophagus and stomach had to be removed, officials said.

title: 'WOMAN OF SUBSTANCE'
description: The six-hour dramatization of ''A Woman of Substance,'' which is being spread over three Mondays on WPIX/ Channel 11 beginning tonight at 8 o'clock, is one of those epic sagas that seem to have been made for television. The novel by Barbara Taylor Bradford, on the best-seller lists for just under a year, tells the rags-to- riches story of Emma Harte, who went from being a servant for a Yorkshire squire to owning one of the biggest business conglomerates in the world. Revenge, ambition and power, complicated with an assortment of sexual entanglements - the formula is written in stone.

title: Market Place; Skittish Stocks And Tax Law
description: LAST Monday, when the stock market was being

title: Fund Adds an Award For Reporting on City
description: The Fund for the City of New York has announced the winners of its annual public service awards and the establishment of the Peter Kihss Award for outstanding reporting on the New York City government.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Randolph C. Harrison, Retired Bank Official
description: Randolph Carter Harrison, a retired senior vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company of New York, died Saturday at the Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Martin M. Rosen, 65; Banker and Financier
description: Martin M. Rosen, founder and chairman of the First Washington Securities Corporation and former chief operating officer of the World Bank's private investment affiliate, died Friday of cancer. He was 65.

title: Iran Presses Charge Of Red Cross Spying
description: Iran published documents today that it said supported its accusations against the International Committee of the Red Cross of espionage and of violating its traditional neutrality.

title: Margaret Mead Hall For American Museum
description: The Margaret Mead Hall of Pacific Peoples will open at the American Museum of Natural History on Dec. 14 as a permanent exhibition of some 1,500 artifacts illustrating the cultural activities of the peoples of Pacific Islands.

title: BOOKS: AN ANTI-FASCIST;
description: THAT AWFUL MESS ON VIA MERULANA. By Carlo Emilio Gadda. Translated from the Italian by William

title: Miss Halle Wed in Jersey To Gary Maitland, Lawyer
description: Janice Halle, the daughter of Ruth Halle of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and the late Walter Halle, was married yesterday to Gary Maitland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Maitland of Englewood Cliffs. Rabbi Benjamin Weinbach performed the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Zedek in West New York, N.J.

title: BIG EAST REMAINS SHADOWED BY A LACK OF BALANCE
description: In five years of operation, the Big

title: ITALIAN CHIEF VOWS TO FIGHT MAFIA 'TO THE END'
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, bolstered by the victory of his five-party coalition Government in a crucial parliamentary vote this weekend, vowed here today to lead the fight against organized crime ''to the end.''

title: ARCHDIOCESE CHALLENGES KOCH'S ORDER ON HIRING
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, in a broad attack on Mayor Koch's authority, have asked an appeals court to strike down an executive order barring discrimination because of race, creed, age, sex or handicap.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $405,000 on the sale of assets.

title: Addendum
description: * Better Homes and Gardens magazine is increasing its ad rates 7.25 percent with the March issue.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-11.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CANADIENS' LAFLEUR REITRES AS PLAYER
description: Guy Lafleur, whose explosive speed and deft scoring touch made him a superstar with the Montreal Canadiens, announced his retirement today.

title: Two Rexnord Officials Promoted to Key Posts
description: Rexnord Inc. announced yesterday that its board had approved two top management assignments in anticipation of the retirement of Robert V. Krikorian, the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: Almost $2 Billion in Navy Ship Pacts Awarded
description: The Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr., today announced the award of nearly $2 billion worth of contracts to six East Coast and Gulf Coast shipyards for 10 warships after competitive bidding that he said cut $243 million from initially estimated costs.

title: Analysis Industry Gears Up
description: Now that there is the clear prospect of eight Reagan years instead of four, the Washington analysis industry is surer of what it has to analyze and it is beginning to hum again. One of the first organizations to start scrutinizing the Reagan administrations, the old one and the coming one, will be the American Enterprise Institute.

title: Walgreen Plans
description: The Walgreen Company plans to open 100 drugstores and 10 free-standing Wag's restaurants in 1985, the company said in its annual report.

title: Topics ; Seasons' Meetings ; Heavy WeatherSuddenly the crowds in New York City seem double what they were last month. But it's not the tourists and shoppers who make the difference. It's the coats. Cities like Minneapolis and Buffalo have room for people whose size is doubled in winter. But in this landscape of density, the Winter Coat looms very large. Sometimes it's filled with down, and therefore the size of a large barrel. Sometimes it's made of a lot of tweed or camel's hair and is called a greatcoat. Sometimes it's made of fur, in which case it's seldom seen on the subway.
description: The Winter Coat makes shopping difficult. The other day, a camel's hair polo coat encountered a down cocoon in a bookstore aisle.

title: Herman & Rosner Co-Founder to Quit
description: Charles Rosner, 40 years old, who co-founded Herman & Rosner Enterprises in 1978, is leaving the company on Friday after a disagreement with his partner, Harvey Herman, 50, ''on how to do things.''

title: WESTERN STUDY GROUP CALLS FOR LESS RELIANCE ON NUCLEAR DETERRENCE
description: A group of Western public figures issued a report today that said that although nuclear deterrence had so far preserved the overall peace, it was essential to reduce Western reliance on nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: RESOLUTIONS TO CURB U.S. DEFICIT ARE URGED FOR MAYOR'S APPROVAL
description: Two resolutions on the Reagan Administration's efforts to curb the Federal deficit were recommended today by a key policymaking committee of the National League of Cities for approval by delegates to the group's annual convention.

title: Karpov Postpones 28th Game of Match
description: Anatoly Karpov postponed the 28th game of the world chess championship match today, two days after winning his fifth game against his challenger, Gary Kasparov.

title: CELLULAR PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOREANS BEAM WITH OPTIMISM OVER OLYMPIC PROGRESS
description: South Korea's most important sports official said yesterday that Soviet sports authorities indicated they were ready to talk with South Korea about participating in the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul.

title: Carter Opens Forum on Early Deaths
description: Former President Jimmy Carter convened a meeting of health experts today to discuss ways of preventing premature deaths.

title: Torres Will Head State Commission
description: Jose Torres, the former world-champion boxer, will be named chairman of the State Athletic Commission, top aides to Governor Cuomo confirmed today.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: COURT TO RULE ON TEXAS ZONING BAN FOR RETARDED
description: It is a nice small-town neighborhood with solid, working-class people. And it is a nice old house, with fresh beige paint and a broad, inviting porch.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Judge Rules on Bulls
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Marvin Fishman, a Milwaukee real- estate developer who won a $12 million antitrust judgment last June against the owners of the Chicago Bulls, isn't eligible for $4.5 million in punitive damages.

title: Taiwan Trade Curbs
description: The Taiwan Government should remove its non-tariff trade barriers as a major step toward narrowing its growing trade surplus with the United States, according to Harry Thayer, head of the American Institute in Taiwan. Mr. Thayer said on Sunday that Taiwan should allow American companies to expand beyond their current limited role of providing such services as banking, insurance and advertising.

title: BEST OF SPRING: THE SIMPLE AMERICAN LOOK
description: It is known as the American look, at least among foreign visitors to this country. It involves clean, spare clothes that look comfortable to wear and are nonrestrictive. Many of the best designs of the new spring season fit neatly under its umbrella. They are lean, pared down and casual, even if they are planned for evening. These are basic ingredients of American style.

title: SHARON ADMITS PANEL GAVE HIM 'MARK OF CAIN'
description: Ariel Sharon testified yesterday that he once said an Israeli commission had put ''the mark of Cain'' on him.

title: Security Pacific Issuing Notes The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million of
description: two-year extendible notes with

title: PRENTICE ACCEPTS $71 BID BY G.& W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries and Prentice-Hall Inc. announced jointly yesterday that they had agreed to merge, creating the nation's largest book publisher. The agreement followed an offer by Gulf and Western to increase its previously rejected $70- a-share offer by $1 a share.

title: A STERN FORUM FOR A BUDDING ENTREPRENEUR
description: MICHAEL BERGELSON admitted that he had no inventory, no sales force and no customers. But if he had $1.4 million, he was telling a recent gathering at the Harvard Business School Club in New York, his nascent company would have profits of $1.7 million on $16.5 million in sales in three years.

title: Asian Series at La Mama
description: La Mama's Third World Institute of Theater Arts Studies will present an Asian perspective of traditional and contemporary music, dance, ritual and poetry from Korea, Japan, Indonesia, India, China and the Philippines Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday and next Monday. The program on Friday and Saturday is an interpretation in music and dance by Agapito (Butz) Aquino of the writings and poetry of his brother, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the assassinated Philippine opposition leader. Information: 475-7710.

title: Shopping for a Coach
description: Terry Bledsoe, the general manager of the Buffalo Bills, who have won only once in the National Football League this season, had little to say about a report that the team is shopping among the college ranks for a replacement for Coach Kay Stephenson. A report in The Buffalo News said that Don James of Washington had turned down an offer to replace Stephenson, and that the Bills were now trying to get Mike White of Illinois.

title: Florida Federal
description: Florida Federal Savings and Loan Association said it had agreed to buy six branch offices in Florida from Freedom Savings and Loan Association.

title: Bonneville Broke Pacts, Judge Rules
description: The Bonneville Power Administration breached its agreement with four private utilities when it recommended the mothballing of a Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear project, a Federal judge ruled today, ordering a trial to determine whether the utilities will be owed up to $800 million in damages.

title: Financier, 85, Goes to Jail
description: C. Arnholt Smith, the 85-year-old financier who once headed a $2 billion corporate empire, began serving a one- year jail term today for grand theft, entering the back door of the county jail to avoid reporters.

title: By John Gross;
description: FATE KEEPS ON HAPPENING. Adventures of Lorelei Lee and Other Writings. By Anita Loos. Edited by Ray

title: Maine Studies Seabrook Role
description: Maine utilities should be ordered to pull out of the Seabrook nuclear power project unless a financial bailout is completed in five weeks, examiners for a state regulatory agency recommended.

title: Javits Enters Hospital Suffering Chest Pains
description: Jacob K. Javits, the retired four-term United States Senator from New York, was admitted to New York Hospital yesterday complaining of chest pains. Mr. Javits, who is 80 years old, was listed in stable condition and was ''resting comfortably,'' according to Jed Golden, a hospital spokesman. Mr. Javits suffers from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, which gradually destroys a person's control of his muscles. Mr. Javits was elected to the House of Representatives in 1946 and was re-elected three times. In 1954, Mr. Javits defeated Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to become State Attorney General.

title: 2 Utilities Plan To Buy Back Debt
description: Announcements by the New York Telephone Company and the Southern California Edison Company of plans to purchase some of their own bonds at prices well above face value have helped raise the quoted prices for other issues of high interest rate bonds, according to specialists in the corporate bond market.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said 1983 sales figures have been adjusted to reclassify freight revenue from selling and general expenses.

title: THE OPERA: 'ORLANDO,' WITH MARILYN HORNE
description: AT Carnegie Hall Sunday night, a major event and a major audience success: the opening of the Handel Opera Festival with ''Orlando,'' in what may be the first uncut professional performance of any Handel opera in New York. It was, if not quite a triumph all round artistically, a vivid and inspiring effort, worth a hundred bullseyes scored on easier targets - both because it clears a path for possible triumphs to come and because it expands our understanding of a composer whose greatness is unchallenged but (in this facet of his work) too nearly unexamined by the public.

title: Descendant of Wagner To Direct Royal Opera
description: Britain's Royal Opera today named a descendant of the German composer Richard Wagner to the new post of opera director.

title: BANK EXPANSION LIMITS ARE PLANNED BY F.D.I.C.
description: Acknowledging that issues of states' rights were involved, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it was moving to restrict banks from going into new lines of business under authority recently granted by some states.

title: WHY VOTING IS LIKE SINGING IN CHURCH
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRIAN PRESIDENT'S BROTHER ENDS HIS 'EXILE'
description: The Syrian President's younger brother, whose departure from this country five months ago, apparently into exile, prompted speculation about a major struggle for power, returned here today from Paris.

title: TRADE PACT WITH INDIA REPORTED
description: The United States and India have tentatively reached a trade agreement that would allow India greater access to American high technology exports, a State Department official said tonight.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1984.

title: Saints' Mecom Sets a Price NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26
description: John Mecom, frustrated at the New Orleans

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY PLANS MAJOR SPENDING SHIFT
description: The New York City Transit Authority proposed sweeping changes in its $6.3 billion rebuilding plan yesterday, calling for more money to buy new buses and overhaul subway cars.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks , at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. The Knicks try to extend their five- game winning streak in the first meeting between the teams this year; last season they lost four of five games to Atlanta.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON MAKING NUCLEAR WAR LESS LIKELY
description: Following are excerpts from a report, ''Managing East-West Conflict,'' made public today by the Aspen Institute International Group:

title: TOKYO PHONE FIASCO: SMILES WITHOUT THE SERVICE
description: The telephones are ringing again in Setagaya.

title: PARAGUAY PLEDGES TO HUNT FOR NAZI
description: A delegation that traveled to Paraguay seeking information and publicity in a hunt for the Nazi fugitive Josef Mengele reported yesterday that officials still denied knowing the whereabouts of the notorious Auschwitz doctor but had pledged to search for him.

title: THE WORLD OF BATS: SCIENTISTS UNCLOAK THE MYTHS
description: THE dark world of bats has long been hidden from humans, surrounded by myth, fear and ignorance. But scientists have recently begun to discover that the world's only flying mammal is a much more sophisticated and benign creature than previously believed.

title: Interest Rates Rise Modestly
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as investors and traders were unsure about the extent to which the Federal Reserve will promote lower interest rates in the future.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 4 percent stock dividend paid in December.

title: Same Face, New Team
description: University of New Mexico officials received a surprise when the Lobos opened their basketball season last Friday against Morgan State: Larry Hubbard, who had been kicked off the 1979 Lobo team, was starting as a freshman for Morgan State.

title: GENERAL AND CBS LAWYER CLASH ON ENEMY DATA
description: A. FARBER

title: COLUMBIA DATA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 48 AT EVERS COLLEGE LOSE FEDERAL AID
description: Forty-eight students at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn have had their Federal aid rescinded because they were ineligible academically, a spokesman for the City University of New York said yesterday.

title: Reagan to Give Medal For Slain Congressman
description: President Reagan will present a Congressional medal Thursday to the family of Leo J. Ryan, the Congressman from California slain in Guyana in 1979, the White House said today.

title: Who's No. 1?
description: Only two days after the official announcement of college football's bowl matchups, the jockeying over which bowl, if any, will produce the No. 1 team has begun. Ignoring Brigham Young's 12-0 record and No. 1 ranking in the news-service polls, Orange Bowl officials have proclaimed their Jan. 1 matchup in Miami between Oklahoma (9-1-1) and Washington (10-1) as the one for the No. 1 rating.

title: Hijackers Delay Decision On Fate of Somali Plane
description: The hijackers of a Somali Airlines plane said today that they would wait until Tuesday before deciding whether to carry out their threat to blow up the plane and kill the 108 passengers on board.

title: THE RESEARCH ROAD TO BABY FAE AND BEYOND
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS SEEKING RECEIVER
description: In the victory Sunday over the Kansas City Chiefs, the Giants lost a player, Phil McConkey, who must be replaced quickly as the team drives for the playoffs.

title: A HARBRINGER OF A DISKLESS FUTURE?
description: BY now most people are aware of the two disk types commonly called floppy and hard. Disks and disk drives are so basic to personal computing that it is pretty difficult to glance through any magazine or book on the subject without getting at least some awareness of them. Where the novice is likely to stumble over disks, however, is on meeting the diskless disk for the first time.

title: CONGRESSMAN AND RIGHTS LEADER ARRESTED AT SOUTH AFRICAN EMBASSY
description: Representative Charles Hayes of Illinois and the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference were arrested this afternoon after refusing to leave the South African Embassy here, the authorities said.

title: 2 Named in Crime Spree Plead Guilty in Abduction
description: A couple linked by the authorities to slayings and assaults in six Middle Western states pleaded guilty today to Federal kidnapping charges in Ohio, while in Indiana they were charged them with killing a 7-year-old girl.

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
COMPOSER DREW UPON POEM, ARIOSTO'S 'ORLANDO FURIOSO'
description: ''Orlando,'' the 30th of Handel's 40- odd operas, is based on ''Orlando Furioso,'' an epic poem written in 1516 by Ludovico Ariosto. Many other composers have drawn upon the poem for operatic material, among them Domenico Scarlatti, Steffani and Vivaldi.

title: Backman Asking For Number Zero
description: After a season in which he finally established himself as the regular second baseman for the Mets with a .280 batting average and seven game- winning hits, Wally Backman obviously feels a bit more secure.

title: FARM GROUP BOYCOTTING CAMPBELL PUTS FOCUS ON FINANCIAL CONCERNS
description: The six-year campaign of the Farm Labor Organizing Committee to win collective bargaining rights with the Campbell Soup Company is taking a new turn.

title: Jailed Pastor Balks At Hearing by Ministers
description: A jailed Lutheran pastor, temporarily suspended as a minister for his militant stance in a labor dispute, refused to answer questions today at a hearing called to consider whether he should be permanently defrocked.

title: Strong Aftershock on Coast
description: An earthquake beneath the Sierra Nevada this morning was the largest aftershock since a quake in the area last Friday, seismologists reported. The tremor at 8:21 A.M. registered 5.0 on the Richter scale, a measure of energy released, and was centered near Mammoth Mountain. Friday's quake registered 5.7.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: ONE UNION CHIEF IDENTIFIES WITH THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, reached under his desk and pushed a button. The draperies that cover one wall of his office whisked back to expose a panoramic view of the Capitol.

title: On the Air
description: Dan Dierdorf, a Pro Bowl selection from the St. Louis Cardinals for 6 of the 13 seasons he was an offensive lineman in the National Football League, has not been lounging around the house since he retired at the end of last season.

title: THE EFFECT OF SONIC BOOMS ON NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Poor Poverty Law
description: Congress being out of session, it's time again for the Reagan White House to try stacking the Legal Services Corporation with board members hostile to the program Congress set up to provide legal help to the poor.

title: FORTUNE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: British Coal Mine Strike
description: An end to Britain's long-running coal miners' strike would increase the nation's economic growth to 3.25 percent in 1985, up from the 2.5 percent predicted for 1984, the Confederation of British Industry said today. It said growth could be lower than 3.25 percent if the miners' strike continued, or if world economic growth declined sharply.

title: WORLD COURT STEP POSES TEST FOR U.S.
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the World Court's ruling that it had jurisdiction to decide Nicaragua's lawsuit against the United States would force Washington to consider whether to boycott further proceedings.

title: OILMEN JOIN WITH ECOLOGISTS
description: The oil industry has taken many of the environment's riches over the last 50 years, but on this curving wisp of sand in the Gulf of Mexico some of them are being given back.

title: EDWARDS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $173,000 for the quarter and $809,000 for the year.

title: Slow Signings
description: The major leagues haven't played a baseball game for six weeks, but they nevertheless have managed to set a record. None of the 56 players who went through the Nov. 8 free-agent draft has signed a contract, which means this is the latest teams have gone in the nine years of free agency without signing any players.

title: Back on Court
description: Eddie Wilkins, the rookie forward, has been reactivated by the Knicks, who put the center Bill Cartwright back on the injury list. Wilkins missed 15 games after spraining his right ankle on opening night. Cartwright's 4-year-old son, Justin, underwent heart surgery in Sacramento, Calif., and officials at Sutter Memorial Hospital there said the operation went well. . . . Bernard King of the Knicks, who averaged 40.8 points a game in leading the Knicks to a 4-0 record last week and scored a career- high 52 against the Pacers Saturday, was named the N.B.A. player of the week yesterday.

title: LETTER TO PRESIDENT IS FOCUS OF SUIT ON LIBEL
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a citizen's private letter to the President, criticizing a potential Federal officeholder, can ever give rise to a suit for libel.

title: Beethoven, It Seems, Was Very Left-Faced
description: Beethoven probably never knew it but he was left-faced.

title: Holmes Says It Again
description: Boxers have said it often, and now Larry Holmes has said it again: His next fight is his last. ''I'm going to fight David Bey and quit,'' the unbeaten 35-year-old heavyweight champion said yesterday of the planned International Boxing Federation title match. Holmes would not rule out a possible bout against the light-heavyweight champion, Michael Spinks, but said, ''I don't see the fight going on.''

title: SIGNERS OF THE ASPEN STUDY
description: Following are the Western public figures who signed the report of the Aspen Institute International Group, which was made public today:

title: JAPANESE TO MANUFACTURE TRANSIT CARS IN YONKERS
description: The Port Authority has signed a contract with two Japanese companies to build 95 new air-conditioned cars for use on the Trans-Hudson rail line and to renovate 248 existing cars, Governor Cuomo announced today.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $607,746 for the quarter and 9 months from an insurance claim.

title: Oil Prices Are Sharply Lower
description: Oil prices yesterday plummeted to their lowest levels in weeks as two more refiners cut the price they would pay for crude oil and traders worried about continued warm weather, overproduction by oil exporters and a potential further price cut by Norway.

title: People
description: * Sid Liebenson has been promoted to senior vice president and director of marketing services at Kobs & Brady Advertising, Chicago.

title: POLYPLASTEX UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. RESTORES FULL TIES WITH IRAQ BUT CITES NEUTRALITY IN GULF WAR
description: The United States and Iraq announced today that they had agreed to restore formal diplomatic relations.

title: Steel Output Drops 5.3% By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.463
description: million tons in the week ended

title: Accounts
description: * Extrom Communications Corp. to AC&R Advertising.

title: Hearts and Technology
description: Only 10 days after Baby Fae's, another medical spectacular is under way in a Louisville hospital. William Schroeder has become the second patient to receive a mechanical heart. His progress, like Barney Clark's last year, will be a human drama, but also an experiment.

title: A GATT Call For Patience
description: Member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, opening their annual assembly today, were urged to avoid ''witch doctor'' cures for the problems of world commerce.

title: LEBANESE ARMY DEPLOYS MORE TROOPS TO CONTROL BEIRUT AREA
description: The Lebanese Army moved to consolidate fully its control of the capital and its suburbs today.

title: ST. FRANCIS WINS IN VALVANO'S DEBUT
description: Bobby Valvano made a successful debut as coach of St. Francis College last night as the Terriers, behind Tim Brisco and Chris Phillips, defeated William Paterson College, 69-64, at the Terriers' Physical Education Center in Brooklyn.

title: ROCK: DEL-FUEGOS QUARTET
description: -Fuegos treat rock as house party music - raucous, unpolished and full of moxie. At Irving Plaza Friday, the Boston-based quartet tossed off one three-minute song after another - pausing barely long enough for dancers to catch their breath - that mixed and matched 1950's and 60's rock.

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: WORLD COURT ACTS TO OVERRULE U.S. IN NICARAGUA CASE
description: The World Court ruled today that it had jurisdiction to hear a case brought by Nicaragua that is aimed at declaring the United States an aggressor country.

title: SINKING SLABS OF SEA FLOOR MAY CAUSE SHIFTS IN EARTH'S CRUST
description: ONE of the most basic unanswered questions in earth science is what keeps the great plates of the earth's crust constantly in motion?

title: NEW PLAN SEEKS AVIATION SAFETY ON THE GROUND
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is expected to announce new steps this week to help reduce the danger of aircraft collisions on the ground, which is emerging as one of the airline industry's major worries.

title: Indiana Sheriff Bars Evictions in Steel Area
description: A sheriff says he has ordered his department not to evict any residents whose homes are foreclosed on this winter, citing high unemployment in an area dependent on the steel industry for jobs.

title: Stakes Disclosed By Boesky Group
description: Ivan Boesky, a New York investor, and a group of companies he controls told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had purchased a stake in Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and raised their stake in ARA Services Inc. Mr. Boesky said the group had bought 1,153,400 common shares, or 9 percent of D.L.J., at prices ranging from $28.50 to $29.64 a share. The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has made a tender offer of $30 each for D.L.J.'s shares.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Cordelia B. Robertson, A Director of Charities
description: Cordelia Biddle Robertson, a leading figure in New York City's charitable and philanthropic activities in the 1950's and 1960's, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: Drug Runner Gets Life Term
description: A former bail bondsman accused of leading a wide-ranging cocaine ring was sentenced in Federal District Court today to life in prison without parole and fined $425,000. The bondsman, Harold Rosenthal, 53 years old, was convicted last month in connection with a smuggling operation that prosecutors said brought five tons of cocaine into the United States in 14 months. He was sentenced by Judge G. Ernest Tidwell.

title: Floral Account Moves
description: The 800-Flowers organization, which is on its way to becoming a national flowers-by-phone operation, has given its advertising account to its Dallas neighbor, the Bloom Agency. The assignment was made a few days after the client had dismissed Chiat/Day's New York office, which had had the assignment for a few months. The account reportedly will bill $12 million.

title: Disease Awareness Week
description: President Reagan today proclaimed this week National Epidermolysis Bullosa Awareness Week. The term means a group of ailments in which skin blisters after minimal injury or pressure.

title: UNESCO AIDE SEES THREAT TO THE U.N.
description: An official of Unesco said today that decisions by the United States and Britain to withdraw from the agency were politically motivated and could mark the beginning of the end of the United Nations system.

title: LLOYD GAINS EASILY IN AUSTRALIAN OPEN
description: Chris Evert- Lloyd, playing her first match in more than three weeks, trounced Kim Shaefer, 6-0, 6-2, today to advance to the second round of the $1.28 million Australian Open Tennis Championships.

title: Patriots Assisting Teams Into Playoffs
description: The New England Patriots lead the National Football League in the dubious category of putting the most teams in the playoffs. When they lost to the Dallas Cowboys on Thanksgiving Day, the Patriots enabled the Miami Dolphins to clinch the Eastern Division of the American Conference and the Denver Broncos to clinch at least an American Conference wild- card berth.

title: DMZ DEFECTOR SAYS HE ACTED FREELY
description: A Soviet defector said today that he had acted of his ''own free will'' when he bolted from North Korea into South Korean territory, touching off a fatal gun battle here in the heart of the demilitarized zone.

title: RETIRED NEW YORK ARCHITECT
description: Morris Ketchum Jr., a retired New York City architect and a former president of the American Institute of Architects, died last Thursday at his home in Newtown, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: POLISH LABOR CHIEFS MEET TO FORM FEDERATION
description: In a move that appeared to reflect their yearning for the sort of credibility once enjoyed by Solidarity, more than a thousand leaders of Government-sponsored unions met over the weekend to form their own federation.

title: SUPPORT THE PEACE EFFORT OF NICARAGUA'S INDIANS
description: The debate about armaments in Nicaragua has obscured news of an important development that holds out hope for a peaceful settlement of the three-year war that has ravaged the Atlantic Coast region of that country. In recent weeks, the Indian peoples of Nicaragua, under the leadership of Brooklyn Rivera, have begun to talk about making peace with the Sandinistas. This peace effort deserves Reagan Administration support.

title: British Aide Is Slain in India
description: A British diplomat was shot and killed by one or more unidentified attackers as he walked to work in Bombay today, according to the British High Commission here, the equivalent of an embassy. Percy Norris, 56 years old, Britain's Deputy High Commissioner in Bombay, was shot in the head and the heart, a spokesman said. He was pronounced dead at a hospital.

title: MITTERRAND ARRIVES IN SYRIA FOR A 3-DAY STATE VISIT
description: President Francois Mitterrand arrived for a three-day state visit to Syria today and within hours heard a stern and uncompromising statement on the Israeli- Arab conflict from President Hafez al- Assad.

title: WHERE THE LIBERALS WENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Pipeline Ruling Backed
description: The Supreme Court refused today to set aside a ruling that forces a Federal energy agency to tighten control over oil pipeline charges to protect consumers. The Justices, without comment, rejected pipeline company arguments that an appeals court exceeded its authority in ordering the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to revise its pricing guidelines.

title: Bridge: 4 Teams Tie for First PlaceIn Reisinger Board-a-Match
description: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship ended here late Sunday night in an unprecedented four-way tie between squads led by Bill Root of Boca Raton, Fla., Fred Stewart of Accord, N.Y., Sam Stayman of New York and Jim Robison of Los Angeles.

title: ADRIAN HOLZMEISTER
description: The Rev. Adrian Holzmeister, chaplain of the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y., a Roman Catholic hospice for cancer patients maintained by the Dominican Sisters of Hawthorne, died of a stroke there Nov. 20.

title: CAPITOL AIR IS FACING CHAPTER 11
description: Capitol Air, which suspended its flights Sunday night, is facing a petition filed by four employees that it be involuntarily put under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: James D. Bernstein, 37, Dies; A Partner at Goldman, Sachs
description: James D. Bernstein, a partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, investment bankers and brokers, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DANCE

title: DEATH PENALTY ASSAILED BY FLORIDA CHURCH LEADERS
description: Leaders of 13 major Christian denominations in Florida today issued a joint statement condemning the death penalty as counterproductive and immoral.

title: Market Place; Bell Regionals Hold Up Well
description: THE seven Bell regional holding companies

title: Japan Protests to Soviet On Airspace Violations
description: The Japanese Government said today that it had protested to the Soviet Union over what it called repeated violations of Japanese airspace by Soviet bombers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Uruguay knew poverty, but it never before knew misery. Now we face a problem of generalized misery.

title: BERRY INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,072,000 for the quarter and $8,359,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,887,000 for the quarter and $4,372,000 for the 9 months.

title: ENDOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in July 1983.

title: UNIWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cabby Who Insisted On 4A Is Fined $500
description: George Street, who locked a passenger in his taxi for 30 minutes because she was 4 cents short on a fare, has been ordered to pay a $500 fine.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC AND DANIEL BARENBOIM
description: PIANISTS may argue into the night over which of the two Brahms piano concertos is the more fearsome monster, but one thing is certain: either one can eat a soloist alive and leave only a few fingerbones behind as evidence of the struggle. Daniel Barenboim chose to avoid all argument last night at Avery Fisher Hall. He played both the brutal, trill-obsessed D minor and the deceptively warmer B-flat on the same New York Philharmonic program, in a performance to benefit the orchestra's Pension Fund.

title: Topics ; Seasons' Meetings ; Games Nations Play
description: The annual economic summit meetings of Western leaders don't accomplish much, but it's worthwhile nonetheless for them to spend a few days each year getting to know each other. Next year's meeting, in Bonn, will have another purpose - political symbolism.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income

title: URUAGUAY ELECTS CENTRIST AS PRESIDENT
description: A centrist politician who played a key role in persuading Uruguay's military regime to leave office has been elected to head the country's first civilian Government in 11 years.

title: I.B.M GIVES 'QUICK AS A FLASH' NEW MEANING
description: SCIENTISTS at the International Business Machines Corporation have generated light pulses so short that as many of them could be crowded into a single second as there are seconds in 30 million years. They are said to be the shortest produced to date and should have a variety of applications in observing high-speed reactions of molecules, atoms and electrons.

title: Chase Sets Expansion In London
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation plans to purchase two large brokerage partnerships here - Simon & Coates and Laurie, Milbank & Company - as soon as the London Stock Exchange changes its regulations to allow it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Kenneth Duchac, president of the

title: FAST PACE FOR A SLOW RECEIVER
description: The ball was floating through the

title: THE NATIONALITY ISSUE
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia

title: A Fan Mandate
description: ''Coaches, writers and broadcasters, and some newspapers have their own college football polls, but how about the general public?'' said Donn Bernstein, ABC-TV's college football media director, yesterday.

title: Tree-Trimming
description: The ceremonial decorating of the

title: Track Group Bans 6
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation has confirmed lifetime bans on six athletes, including the Soviet distance star, Tatyana Kazankina, for drug-related infractions.

title: HEART IMPLANT PATIENT 'LOOKING SUPER' AFTER A COMPLICATION
description: William J. Schroeder, who bled massively into his chest Sunday only hours after becoming the second person to receive a permanent artificial heart, today was described by his doctors as ''looking super.''

title: Aid for Elderly's Meals
description: Baloney springs to mind when politics and gastronomy collide. But a few politicians got together in the kitchen yesterday to whip up an Italian lunch and raised more than $50,000 for Citymeals-on-Wheels.

title: AUTOPSY FINDS BUMPURS WAS HIT BY TWO BLASTS
description: An autopsy on a Bronx woman who was fatally shot by the police in an eviction dispute indicates that she was hit by two shotgun blasts, not one, as originally reported by police officials.

title: FREQUENT MOVES AFFECT SCHOOLWORK
description: WHEN school began in September, Public School 62 in the South Bronx had 463 pupils. In the next seven weeks, 201 more pupils were admitted and 88 left. If this school year is anything like the past, and it looks like it will be, P.S. 62 will experience a turnover rate of more than 70 percent by June.

title: For Accuracy on Menus
description: If the vegetable you are eating is referred to on the menu as an Idaho potato and the fish is called a Nova Scotia salmon, then according to a proposed city law, the items would have to be from Idaho and Nova Scotia or the restaurateur would face a fine.

title: Generation Gap
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, made a

title: CBS BUYS INTO SPORTS CHANNELS
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire for $57 million various interests in four regional pay cable sports channels operated by the Sportschannel, which is jointly owned by the Washington Post Company and Cablevision's Rainbow Program Enterprises.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Top Management Shifted at Kellogg
description: The Kellogg Company yesterday announced promotions, effective Jan. 1, for three top-level executives. Walter T. Redmond, Kellogg's 60- year-old president, has been appointed vice chairman and chief administrative officer.

title: AP REPORTER CHARGED ANEW
description: A reporter for The Associated Press said today that the Government had charged him with sedition, a crime that carries a maximum sentence of life in prison and a fine.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 3
Avon Purchase
description: Avon Products Inc. said its Mallinckrodt Inc. division had purchased Tronomed International Inc. and its associated companies for more than $14 million. Tronomed, which has offices in Costa Mesa and Carlsbad, Calif., produces disposable medical devices for intra-arterial blood pressure monitoring. The company will have sales of more than $11 million this year, Avon said.

title: FRONTIER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a gain of $9,724,000 from the sale of a loan portfolio. d-The company went public in October 1984 and did not report share earnings for the year-ago 9 months.

title: REPARATIONS TO NAZI VICTIMS HELD NOT AFFECTING U.S. AID
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that reparations paid by the West German Government to victims of the Holocaust may not be counted as income in determining the victims' eligibility for United States Government disability benefits.

title: 'HEROES AND SIDEKICKS,' SPECIAL TONIGHT ON CBS
description: ''HEROES and Sidekicks - Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,'' the CBS special on Channel 2 at 8 tonight, is really about two things: movie heroes and their pals, and the glories of the Stephen Spielberg-George Lucas film. The connection between the two is that the swashbuckling archeologist Indiana Jones has a sidekick, and that this is in the great Hollywood tradition. In fact, it seems to be the apotheosis of the tradition.

title: SPARKMAN PRODUCING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRIME RATE CUT TO 11 1/2% FROM 11 3/4%
description: Led by Citibank, several large banks reduced their prime lending rates yesterday to 11 1/2 percent, from 11 3/4 percent.

title: DUST COVERS USEFUL WHEN GRIT ABOUNDS
description: IF there is going to be a computer

title: Ms. Advertorial Insert
description: All-About-Travel Guide for Women will be the title of an advertorial insert to be carried in Ms. magazine in the April and October issues. The ads, priced at $10,700 for a four-color page and $7,960 for black-and-white, will entitle the advertiser to a mention in the advertorial material and also to 500 free copies of the insert.

title: ABC SAYS C.I.A. SEEKS TO SUPRESS REPORTING
description: ABC News said yesterday that a complaint filed against the network by the Central Intelligence Agency was ''an unprecedented effort by a Government agency'' to suppress reporting and ''raises serious and disturbing First Amendment concerns.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Autoclave Engineers Inc., Erie, Pa., said it had acquired all of the shares outstanding of Unit Instruments Inc. of Orange, Calif., for $9.8 million.

title: L.I. School Official Sentenced in Theft
description: Nassau County's highest-ranking public-school official was sentenced to five years' probation today after he pleaded guilty to a charge of using a school credit card for personal benefit.

title: Texas Women Upset Georgia
description: Gay Hemphill and Fran Harris led a patient Texas attack as the No. 3-ranked Lady Longhorns upset No. 1 Georgia, 83-69, in women's basketball tonight.

title: Zeta Laboratories
description: International Signal and Control Group P.L.C. said it intended to acquire Zeta Laboratories Inc. for about $35 million and 600,000 new International Signal shares valued at $2 million. Zeta, based in Santa Clara, Calif., produces microwave subsystems and parts for defense electronic communications. It is a subsidiary of the Computer and Communications Technology Corporation.

title: U.S. Restores Full Ties With Iraq But Cites Neutrality in Gulf War
description: WASHINGTON--The United States and Iraq announced today that they had agreed to restore formal diplomatic relations.

title: FRANCHISEIT CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-There are no results for the previous year because the company went public in June.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1984 International The United States faces a trial before the World Court. The Justices voted 15 to 1 against United States arguments that they had no jurisdiction in the dispute and then decided unanimously in favor of Nicaragua's request to try the United States as an aggressor nation. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The World Court's ruling that it had jurisdiction to decide Nicaragua's lawsuit against the United States will force Washington to consider whether to boycott further proceedings in the case, Reagan Administration officials said. (A1:5.)

title: KEY IMAGE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: INDUSTRIAL SOLID STATE CONROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONSUMERS DISTRIBUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net income

title: Japanese Steel Exports
description: Japan exported 2.87 million metric tons of steel in October, up 1.7 percent from the previous month and eight-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today. The trade group said October's weak growth was the result of restraint in steel shipments to the United States.

title: 3 Diverse Selections For Ad Hall of Fame
description: A former agency head, the ad director of a major package goods company and a marketing educator have all been elected to the Advertising Hall of Fame of the American Advertising Federation.

title: RESTORING SANITY TO INTEREST RATES
description: With very little public comment, interstate banking is quietly entering the business landscape. As it grows, interstate banking will exacerbate the already catastrophic effects of interest-rate deregulation, assuring that interest rates remain at historic highs.
