Yet, most economists and Washington officials continue to blame Federal deficits for high interest rates, not recognizing that deregulation of interest rates - and the resultant competition among banks for depositors - is the real culprit.

title: Understudy Replaces Injured Derek Jacobi
description: Derek Jacobi, currently starring in the Royal Shakespeare Company's productions of ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' and ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' at the Gershwin Theater, has been sidelined until Friday night with a cracked rib.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Raytheon Company received an $88.3 million Army contract for engineering services for the Patriot missile production program, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said the Remington Arms Company had been given Army contracts totaling $61.2 million to operate Government- owned, contractor-operated facilities in Independence, Mo. The Air Force gave Avco Everett Research Laboratory Inc. $53.1 million for a high- power laser program to include development and design.

title: Group to Buy Billboard Inc. Billboard Publications Inc.
description: said it had agreed to be acquired by Boston Ventures

title: FILM OF 'FATAL VISION' HELPS BOOK TOP LIST
description: Spurred by the combination of a prime-time television mini-series and a widely reported legal effort to stop it, ''Fatal Vision'' - Joe McGinniss's book about a surgeon and former Green Beret captain convicted of the brutal slaying of his wife and two small daughters - has returned to the No. 1 spot as a paperback best- seller.

title: Veronis, Suhler Offers Ad Agency Study
description: Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment banking firm specializing in the communications field, is releasing a study on the financial side of the ad agency business, or at least the small publicly held segment.

description: Some of the most fascinating

US MEDICAL ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable figures were not available because the company was operating as general partnerships.

description: b-After a loss on investments of $298,000.

title: 'YE HAVE ENTERED INTO THEIR LABOR'
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUTERS' MILEAGE STUDIED
description: American commuters traveled an average round trip of 22.4 miles to work each day in 1983, with cars and trucks the overwhelming choice for transportation, according to a survey by the Hertz Corporation.

title: HEALTH CARE AS BUSINESS
description: Doctors said William J. Schroeder, who received an artificial heart, was ''looking super.'' Page C4.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: G.E.-Wuxi Pact
description: The General Electric Company said it had signed an agreement with the Wuxi Electrical Apparatus Company that would lead to the establishment of a network to sell G.E. programmable controllers in China. G.E. said Wuxi would set up eight regional offices to distribute and market the controller units, which employ microcomputers to control industrial machines and processes.

title: FOR SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS PANEL, MORE PARTISANSHIP AND LESS INFLUENCE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, once the crown jewel of prestige and the focus for national policy debates, has almost become just another committee.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
WOODHEAD, DANIEL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 29
Comings and Goings
description: Aaron Krickstein and Michelle Torres will be honored as Tennis magazine's male and female rookies of the year, with Corey Pavin and Marta Figueras-Dotti as Golf Digest's rookies of the year. The awards will be presented at a luncheon Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria. . . . . . . Virgil Hill , an Olympic boxing silver medalist, was convicted of being a minor in possession of alcohol but had his sentence deferred on the condition he deliver speeches to students at five local schools. . . . The Devils yesterday recalled Rich Chernomaz and goaltender Hannu Kamppuri from the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League.

title: NUMEREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Scott Paper Deal
description: Scott Paper International Inc. of London, a subsidiary of the Scott Paper Company, said it had agreed to acquire Productos Sanitarios e Higienicos Sancel S.A., a producer of sanitary tissue paper products in Spain. Terms were not disclosed. Scott already owns 92 percent of Gureola-Scott S.A., another Spanish maker of sanitary tissue products.

title: PEACEMAKER FOR URUAGUAY
description: In the last 11 years, while thousands of Uruguyans were jailed and tens of thousands more were forced into exile, Julio Maria Sanguinetti avoided a confrontation with the military regime, convinced that it could be coaxed - but never forced - out of office. Mr. Sanguinetti's election Sunday in Uruguay's first presidential elections since 1971 provided vindication of this strategy: two outspoken political leaders were banned as candidates, but the dictatorship should end on March 1.

title: APPLIED COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'A TOUCH OF SCANDAL,' WITH ANGIE DICKINSON
description: SOME films seem to proceed on the premise that, given a juicy core, the audience will buy anything. ''A Touch of Scandal,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, plays like a story board gone berserk. Motives are obviously considered secondary, and things just happen, creating the unsettling impression that great chunks of the production have been snipped out at random.

title: IN ADIRONDACKS, TIME TO HARVEST CHRISTMAS TREES BEARING PROFITS
description: Roger Barber does not shout ''Timber-r-r!''

title: MORE ALCOHOL, LESS MILK N U.S. CONSUMERS' DIET
description: Americans are drinking more alcoholic beverages than milk, but soft drinks are the most popular of all, according to a report by the Agriculture Department.

title: CANCER SURVIVAL RATE PROGRESS IS REPORTED, BUT SKEPTICS OBJECT
description: The National Cancer Institute reported today that survival rates for cancer victims continued to improve slightly during the last decade, but skeptical members of a high-level advisory board suggested that even this seeming improvement may present a falsely optimistic picture of how the war on cancer is going.

title: F.D.U. Home For Hartwick Fairleigh Dickinson of Teaneck, N.J., ranked third in the
description: nation, will play at home

title: LOWER TAX FOR INDIVIDUALS ASKED;VAST BUDGET CUTTING IS PROPOSED; PLAN FOR 1988 OUTLINES REDUCTIONS IN OUTLAYS NEARING $100 BILLION
description: A working group is to present President Reagan with a ''Draconian'' plan Wednesday to cut spending by about $100 billion in 1988, reducing the projected deficit to about $100 billion for that fiscal year, top Administration officials said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Sears Roebuck & Company is offering $300 million of 11 7/8 percent debentures at a price of 99.78 to yield 11.89 percent to maturity through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Beating Swords Into Lemons In June 1982, while losing a single aircraft, the Israeli Air Force destroyed 19 Syrian missile sites in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, as well as 79 Syrian MIG's. That feat of arms holds a lesson to make the United States Defense Department blush.
description: The Pentagon likes to attribute Israeli victories to high technology obtained from the Pentagon. Actually, intensive training and skillful tactics are the main explanations. But technology did play an important role in defeating the Syrian missile sites. The Israelis used pilotless aircraft to provoke the Syrians into switching on their missile radars, then mapped and jammed their frequencies and attacked them safely with other aircraft.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Chile Vows to Uphold Order During Protests
description: A Chilean official said today that the Government would take all necessary measures, including an early curfew, to maintain ''order and tranquillity'' during anti-Government protests called for Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Player's Appeal Denied by Court
description: Albert (Truck) Butts, considered a top rebounder, lost a bid in Federal court today for a temporary restraining order that would have allowed him to play tonight in La Salle's basketball opener against Monmouth.

title: Opposition Party Figure Is Slain in Zimbabwe
description: A senior member of Zimbabwe's main opposition party was shot and killed Sunday near his home in the southern region of Matabeleland, a Government spokesman said today.

title: CITY U. COLLEGES RAISING MONEY ON THEIR OWN
description: Hunter College will begin a major fund-raising drive today, the first of its 114-year history. The $3 million campaign, though modest, reflects a new determination by the colleges of the City University to search more aggressively for private donors.

title: BLAST AT EMBASSY IN COLUMBIA
description: A bomb exploded under a car near the United States Embassy today, killing a woman and wounding six men, including two embassy employees. Police blamed drug traffickers for the blast.

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a gain of $1,022,510 on the sale of real estate Corrected from the editions of Saturday, Nov. 17.

title: Sylvan N. Goldman, 86, Dies; Inventor of the Shopping Cart
description: Sylvan N. Goldman, inventor of the shopping cart and a multimillionaire philanthropist, died at his home here Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: President Is Named At UNC
description: UNC Resources Inc. announced yesterday that Dan A. Colussy, an airline executive for the last 12 years and a member of the company's board since 1981, had been named president and chief executive effective Jan. 1.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (CALIF)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DO 'FREUDIAN SLIPS' BETRAY A DARKER, HIDDEN MEANING?
description: FREUDIAN slips are in trouble. A new body of psychological research now suggests that they are generally not ''Freudian'' at all: that for the most part they do not, as the old master would have us believe, bespeak some hidden message from the unconscious.

title: F.B.I. Agent Is Wounded
description: Law-enforcement officers searched the Mount Hood area Sunday for a gunman who had wounded an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a shootout.

title: Power Failure
description: A power outage caused by a faulty circuit threw sections of the Meadowlands race track into momentary darkness tonight and delayed the running of thoroughbred races about 25 minutes, a track spokeswoman said. The outage occurred between the first and second races, at about 8:10 P.M., said Carol Hodes. Emergency generators kicked on seconds after the power loss and patrons were not left in darkness, she said. Full power was restored at 8:35 P.M.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: NOTHING, or almost nothing, was more in the New York mind last week than shopping. So, the day after Thanksgiving, traditionally the biggest shopping day of the year, New Yorkers hungry for bargains surged through the stores. Whether or not they

title: CONCERT: ARMENIAN SONGS AND DANCES PERFORMED
description: ''PICTURES OF ARMENIA: The Songs and Dances of a Distant Land'' was the title that the Antranig Dance Ensemble and Hayasdan Choral Group gave to their program on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Yet what this warmhearted and exuberant presentation managed to do was to make Armenia seem not so distant, after all.

title: A DINNER RAISES $2 MILLION MORE FOR CUOMO RACE
description: Governor Cuomo collected more than $2 million at a black-tie fund-raising dinner last night, with friends and former foes contributing to a re-election campaign that Mr. Cuomo has yet to announce.

title: Barbara de Portago Wed to J. H. Grant
description: Barbara de Portago, the daughter of Mrs. Gerald Van der Kemp of Washington, Paris and New York, and Henrick von Schlubach of Hamburg, West Germany, was married yesterday to Jason Harrison Grant of Philadelphia, London and New York, the son of the late Ada S. Greenfield and the late G. Gregory Grant, both of Philadelphia. Justice Stanley Parness of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the National Academy of Design in New York.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
West Hollywood Council Cheered in Rent Rollback
description: The City Council of this newly incorporated city was cheered Sunday by several hundred elderly residents as members announced a proposed rent rollback at a get-acquainted meeting.

title: Speakerhood Meditation
description: If and when Speaker Thomas P.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. filed for a proposed public offering of $25 million of subordinated debentures due 1999 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: LEARNING TO BE WELCOME OVERSEAS
description: If you are an official of the Agency for International Development going abroad to dispense advice and money to some struggling country, before you go you will be put through a short but intensive course in ''cross-culture communications.'' Under this term, The agency teaches how to win foreign friends and avoid losing them while giving them something.

title: Transactions
description: Released Rick Leach, designated hitter, to the Syracuse Chiefs of the Class AAA International League.

title: 'YE HAVE ENTERED INTO THEIR LABOR'
description: To the Editor:

title: IDENTITY SWITCH MARKS CRASH SURVIVOR 'DEAD'
description: A 16-year-old girl, disfigured in a car accident, awoke from a coma Saturday to find she had been mistakenly identified as a girl who died in the wreck.

title: Irma Turtle Aided By Memorable Name
description: Irma Turtle finds that she is immediately memorable thanks to the name. And that happens to be handy when one has gone into business for oneself, as she has.

title: A FOOTBALL LEGEND IN 4 DAYS
description: It is only a footnote to history now,

title: TOP THREE AMERICAN AUTOMAKERS RECALL 4 MILLION VEHICLES
description: The nation's three largest automobile manufacturers today announced they were recalling more than four million automobiles to inspect and repair potential safety defects.

title: Texas Air Bids For Stock in Unit
description: The Texas Air Corporation said it had proposed to acquire the minority interest outstanding in New York Airlines, using common stock of the Continental Air Lines Corporation and a new issue of Texas Air subordinated debt.

title: 7 Jersey Counties Sued Over Waste
description: The state filed a court complaint today against seven county governments charging that they had failed to develop garbage-disposal plans as required by the state's Solid Waste Management Act of 1975.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1984

title: Brake Lines Cut On School Buses
description: Air lines on the brakes of all 40 school buses in the Clarkstown school district were discovered cut early today, forcing several thousand students to get rides or walk to class, officials said.

title: U.S. SHIP WAS SET FOR LEBANON RAID
description: The United States ordered an aircraft carrier this month to prepare for a retaliatory strike against terrorists in Lebanon, an Administration official said tonight.

title: MARCOS, 'UP AND ABOUT,' ENDS SECLUSION
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos met today with Cabinet ministers and members of the National Assembly for the first time since he went into seclusion for health reasons on Nov. 14.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
CHERNENKO SAYS HE WILL CONSIDER ALL ARMS STEPS
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko said today that the Soviet Union was prepared to search for the ''most radical'' solutions to the arms race at talks with the United States scheduled for January.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Cattle Prices Mixed; Hogs and Bellies Down
description: Cattle futures prices were mixed while hogs and pork bellies were lower at the close of trading today on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
P.E.N. Awards Given To 2 Publishing Figures
description: Robert Gottlieb, the president and editor-in-chief of Alfred A. Knopf, and Jonathan Galassi, senior editor at Random House, were honored last night for their contributions to publishing by P.E.N., the international writers' organization, whose acronym represents its membership of ''poets, playwrights, essayists, editors and novelists.''

title: Advertising; Dailey Is Added By Mattel
description: MATTEL INC., the country's largest toy company, having studied the West Coast agency scene, has decided on using Dailey & Associates as its second agency. The specific assignment will be for the Hot Wheels brand of toy racing cars, as well as a new product.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
GEORGE S. VECSEY
description: George S. Vecsey, who wrote broadcast news for The Associated Press for 30 years, died Friday at his home in Holliswood, Queens. He was 75 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 27, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LOWER TAX FOR INDIVIDUALS ASKED;VAST BUDGET CUTTING IS PROPOSED; REAGAN GETS TREASURY BLUEPRINT FOR RISES IN COMPANY PAYMENTS
description: The Treasury Department recommended a tax plan to President Reagan today that would generally lower the taxes paid by individuals but would raise the taxes paid by corporations, according to Administration officials.

title: JAMES A. FARMER
description: James A. Farmer, retired general solicitor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a former assistant United States attorney, died Nov. 16 at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Bethel, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: 16 Families Left Homeless by Fire
description: Sixteen families were left homeless yesterday by a fire that spread through three buildings here, officials said.

title: ACTION, NOT JUST WORDS, BEING URGED FOR REFORM
description: ''HOW long do you think the window of interest in the schools will stay open?'' Howard Mehlinger, dean of Indiana University's School of Education, asked in discussing the public mood. He answered his own question: not much longer unless talk about reforms is followed quickly by credible action.

title: Floyd Worthington, 76, Dies; Baritone and Voice Teacher
description: Floyd Worthington, a classical baritone, died Saturday of congestive heart failure at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 76.

title: AN URBAN TALE OF LIFE ON THE EDGE
description: THE homeless have been sheltered, the hungry fed and the personable counselor writes her night-shift report in the orange notebook. She says the young mother whose husband put her out is to become a nurse's aide and that a good home has been found for the baby. She isn't sure what's to become of the alcoholic mother.

title: Plan for Union Sq. IsBackedbyPanel
description: The city's Planning Commission yesterday approved a special zoning district to encourage and guide the revitalization of Union Square in Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Natural Resources Co., Detroit, has elected Steve Bandrowsky, president and chief operating officer of its trucking unit, ANA Freight System, to the additional post of chief executive officer of that unit.

title: Debt Meeting On Yugoslavia GENEVA, Nov. 26 (AP) -
description: Sixteen creditor nations today

title: WEISFIELDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split March 8, 1984.

title: STOCKS FALL DESPITE PRIME RATE CUT
description: The stock market fell moderately yesterday despite a cut in the prime rate by several large banks.

description: The sign says ''Giants Stadium,''

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 3 GROUPS JOINTLY COMMISSION PIANO CONCERTO FROM ZWILICH
description: Carnegie Hall, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and the American Symphony Orchestra League have joined forces to commission a piano concerto from Ellen Taaffe Zwilich, it was announced yesterday.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $276,000 for the quarter and $5,099,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $382,000 for the quarter and $3,047,000 for the 9 months. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $197,000 for the quarter and $88,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $575,000 for the quarter and 1,358,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations from the sale of certain assets of the company's retail shoe stores.

title: HARVESTER TO SELL FARM UNIT
description: The International Harvester Company - the descendant of a company founded by Cyrus McCormick, who invented the reaper in 1831 - announced today that it would abandon its farm equipment business by selling the money- losing division to Tenneco Inc. for $430 million.

title: E.E.C. Fines 5 Companies
description: The executive commission of the European Economic Community today charged five chemical companies with conspiring to fix prices and supplies of three products for 19 years.

BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Delaware Hopes to End Use of Bond Certificates
description: The State of Delaware is continuing to press for the sale of its tax-exempt bonds through a book-entry system that would avoid the expense of issuing bonds in printed form.

title: TEXACO WRITING OFF $765 MILLION
description: Texaco Inc., in a huge financial housecleaning reflecting weaker conditions in the oil industry, said yesterday that it would reduce the value it places on certain of its assets by $765 million. That amount will be charged against earnings in the fourth quarter, producing a loss for the period.

title: HERITAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $234,000 for the quarter and $498,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $207,000 for the quarter and $315,000 for the 6 months.

title: Borough Hall Fire Damages Offices
description: A fire damaged the offices of the Queens District Attorney's narcotics and rackets bureau in Borough Hall late Sunday, and a spokesman for the District Attorney said yesterday that it was believed to be arson.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Photographer At Operation
description: Weeks before the implantation of an artificial heart at Humana Heart Institute International in Louisville, Ky., the institution hired a former newspaper photographer, William Strode, to take pictures throughout the operation and for a brief period afterward. The institution prepared Mr. Strode for the job by sending him to the University of Utah, where he could watch the hearts implanted in animals. His photos have been distributed to the press.

title: Lull in Debate on Schools
description: It was billed as a debate and it was

title: MUSBURGER WEIGHS OFFER FROM ABC
description: Billy Packer was back in his element last Saturday, on the tradition-polished basketball court of Indiana University's Assembly Hall. The expert analyst on CBS's college basketball broadcasts, which began the new season Saturday with Louisville at Indiana, Packer had Frank Glieber as his play-by-play sidekick - this time. But the identity of Packer's permanent partner remains undecided, and is being debated at the moment in Miami and New York.

title: JETS ELIMINATED BY MIAMI, 28-17
description: Dan Marino, the Dolphins' remarkable second-year quarterback, was prevented from throwing long passes tonight. So he threw four short touchdowns instead.

title: Business and the LawState ; Controls On Takeovers
description: ANDREW SIGLER, chairman of Champion International and spokesman for the Business Roundtable, says the current rash of acquisitions is so far-reaching that only a handful of corporations are not vulnerable to hostile takeovers. ''I would say if you could list a dozen, that would be a lot,'' he said.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest third quarter include a gain equal to 4 cents a share from the sale of a Florida motel.

title: Truck Crash Stalls Traffic in Queens
description: A dump truck that overturned after striking an overhead road sign on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway tied up traffic at rush hour yesterday evening and forced the closing of the expressway in the area of Woodside, Queens.

title: People
description: * Harry Rubicam named promotion director of Discover magazine.

title: REDEFINED JUSTICE AND JUSTICES ON THE COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: 'BARTOK,' A 1981 BIOGRAPHY, ON CABLE
description: THE Arts and Entertainment service, one of those channels that comes with no extra premium as part of a basic cable hookup, offers one of the more curious of television's programming mixes. Full-length operas and drama productions one night, BBC situation comedies the next - it can all be quite disconcerting and, for the alert viewer, surprisingly rewarding. Tonight at 9, for instance, can be found ''Bartok,'' a detailed and illuminating 1981 biography of the great composer. It was made by Curtis W. Davis, now an A & E vice president, with financial backing from, among others, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Hungary's Magyar Television and Mafilm.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Lovely War ('84 Skirmish)

title: Landry Will Be Back
description: Tom Landry , saying it was time ''to lay to rest all the rumors'' about his retirement, announced that he would return as head coach of the Dallas Cowboys next season. ''I guess I'll be around for a couple of years at least,'' said the 60-year-old Landry, the only coach in the franchise's 25 years.

title: A BARGAINING CHIP
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's tax proposal is being regarded here as less a plan for enactment than a bargaining chip in what is certain to be a prolonged battle with Congress and thousands of special interests over changes in the nation's tax system. Mr. Regan allowed as much today at the news conference announcing the plan. ''This thing was written on a word processor,'' he said. ''It can be changed.'' He said it was the Treasury's proposal, not the President's, and indeed President Reagan seemed to be keeping his distance from the study he ordered last January but saw for the first time only on Monday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE books offered here in this annual gift roundup are not necessarily of the coffee-table variety: though some are beautiful, others are highly practical or simply amusingly offbeat. What they have in common is that if the reviewer did not already possess them, he would long for them most greedily.

title: WESTMORELAND-CBS TRIAL: A RUNNING BATTLE OVER STATISTICS AND CREDIBILITY
description: Like the Vietnam War itself, the Westmoreland-CBS libel trial has been mired in a running battle over statistics, particularly with regard to estimates of enemy strength in South Vietnam in the year before the Tet offensive of January 1968. But this week, perhaps more than at any time during the eight-week- old trial in Federal Court in Manhattan, the paper war has been moved to the front line in what appears to be a major - and unanticipated - engagement between Gen. William C. Westmoreland and David Boies, the CBS lawyer who is cross-examining the 70-year-old general in his $120 million suit against the network.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 28, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BLIGHTED LIVES IN CANADA: AGENT ORANGE ACCUSED
description: An awkward amphibious vehicle called a muskeg, used for weed spraying, is central to this story.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Pennsylvania Power Sells Mortgage Bonds
description: In its first bond offering since April, the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company yesterday offered at competitive bid $125 million worth of 30- year first mortgage bonds, due Dec. 1, 2014.

title: Grapplers Hotline
description: To the many pieces of special information available over the telephone to New Yorkers - time, weather, Lottery information, sports results, one-minute fairy tales, jokes and prayers - add a wrestling hotline.

description: Corporation unit has named

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
2 in Family Get Posts With Wrather Corp.
description: The Wrather Corporation, a combination of oil, entertainment and real estate businesses, announced yesterday that Christopher Wrather had been elected president and chief executive.

title: Helms and Hawkins
description: The possibility that Senator

title: VW Narrows 9-Month Loss WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Nov. 27 (AP) - Volkswagen said today that it had
description: slashed its multimillion-dollar

title: Councilman Mugged On Fact-Finding Trip
description: City Councilman Ed Schwartz, riding one of the city's trolleys to see what the average commuter goes through, was mugged Monday at a transit stop near his home.

title: BANK OF MONTREAL (CALIFORNIA) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results include operations of Harris Bankcorp Inc. since its acquisition on Sept. 4. The Bank of Montreal is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: 500-BED HOSTEL PROPOSED FOR AMSTERDAM AVE. LANDMARK
description: A landmark building on Amsterdam Avenue that once housed widows of Revolutionary War veterans would become a low-cost hostel for overnight travelers under a proposal filed with the city yesterday.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The results for the year-earlier period were restated for acquisition of Rax of Florida Inc. on a pooling-of- interests basis Aug. 7.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: The latest quarter includes a non- recurring charge related to termination of a license agreement.

title: Freighter With Potash Foundering in Pacific
description: Water gushed through a small hole in the bow of a 482-foot freighter, threatening to sink the vessel in stormy Pacific seas today 180 miles off the northern California coast, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Kennedy on South Africa
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy attacked the Reagan Administration's policies on South Africa at the African-American Institute's 30th anniversary dinner last night.

title: NOV. 11-20 AUTO SALES IMPROVED SHARP 28.8%
description: Automobile sales improved sharply in the Nov. 11- 20 period, the manufacturers reported here today. Sales by the six major companies jumped 28.8 percent in mid- November from the period last year.

title: U.S. Warns France on Trade Issue
description: A Reagan Administration trade official today accused the French Government of blocking an American effort to reduce trade subsidies and warned of retaliation early next year if France does not change its attitude.

title: HEART RECIPIENT, 'FEELING GOOD,' REQUESTS A BEER
description: William J. Schroeder, the second recipient of a permanent artificial heart, breathed on his own today and asked for a can of beer. His doctors said his new heart was working ''beautifully.''

title: Canada's 1985 Outlook
description: Canada's top forecasters agree with Finance Minister Michael Wilson that its economy will grow 4.2 percent this year and 2.4 percent in 1985, the Conference Board of Canada said today after a survey of 17 economists.

title: Computerland Chooses Foote, Cone & Belding
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, has picked up the Computerland Corporation account, which could bill as much as $15 million in the United States. And it will also be working for the client in Canada, Britain, France, West Germany, Japan, Australia and China.

title: REFINING THE ART OF SELLING BY MAIL
description: SOME consumers are receiving as many as 60 catalogues this month in what may be the greatest single outpouring from one of the country's most lucrative industries, the mail-order business. Last year, the national mail-order market was $44.5 billion, up from $39 billion the previous year, according to Edward J. Pfeiffer, vice president of the Direct Mail Marketing Association, a New York-based trade group with 2,200 company members in the United States and 37 other countries.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS SEE OBSTACLES FOR REAGAN
description: When Congress convenes in January, Republicans will hold the same 53-to-47 majority in the Senate they had in 1981, when they were a driving force behind President Reagan's dramatic legislative successes.

title: Test for Dioxin Set to Start At Army Base Scouts Used
description: Tests for dioxin at a military base where thousands of Boy Scouts camped for their 1981 Jamboree will begin later this week, a spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency said.

title: Job Needs Of Small Businesses
description: A WHILE ago, Dr. Henry M. Levin, a professor at Stanford University, advanced the startling theory that in the future not many jobs would become available in the high-technology industries, certainly not as many as job counselors had been predicting.

title: TEXT OF SUMMARY REPORT ON FUNDAMENTAL SIMPLIFICATION
description: Following is the text of the summary provided today by the Treasury Department of its Report on Fundamental Tax Simplication and Reform:

title: U.S., STAY IN UNESCO
description: Until last week, America was alone in its unyielding resolve to withdraw from Unesco at the end of 1984. Now Britain threatens to do so, in a year's time. Since Britain joined the other Common Market countries in praising Unesco's reform efforts only two months ago, one can assume the British press was on to something in accusing the Government of knuckling under to American pressure.

title: VIOLENT DEATH RATE CITED AS U.S. HEALTH CONCERN
description: More than 50,000 Americans are murdered or commit suicide annually, and this poses a major public health problem, according to current and former officials with the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: Marriott Is Expanding Scali, McCabe's Tasks
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct, which has been working for the Marriott Corporation for a year, will now be working for Marriott Lifecare, residences for the elderly that the corporation is now building. Billings will be more than $1 million.

title: Bridge:Play Is Set to Start Tonight At Club Level for New Title
description: Entirely new national championships are very rare indeed, but for residents of New York City and Long Island one will begin tonight. It is a division of the Grand National Teams restricted to players with fewer than 500 master points. The official title is ''Flight B,'' but ''Little National Teams'' would seem appropriate.

title: JAZZ: AKIYOSHI'S BAND PERFORMING AT LUSH LIFE
description: TOCHIKO AKIYOSHI'S New York Jazz Orchestra, which has been playing Monday nights since early fall at Lush Life, has arrived at a fine point of development as a result of a steady series of performances there and the good acoustics of the club. On Monday evening the band was heard in a challenging situation that stressed the solidity of its growth.

title: GIBRALTAR TALKS DUE BY FEBRUARY
description: Britain and Spain announced today that they would hold new talks on the future of Gibraltar, including the possible end of British sovereignty, by mid-February as part of an agreement to reopen the border between Spain and Gibraltar.

title: FERRONICS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Chief Resigns At Florafax
description: Florafax International Inc. announced today that its chairman and chief executive, Joseph H. Hale, had resigned.

title: 'Supergirl' 1st at Box Office
description: For the third consecutive week a newcomer led the 10 top box-office parade as ''Supergirl'' - a woebegone off- shoot of the successful ''Superman'' trilogy - posted $7.7 million in its first five days.

title: F.B.I. HOLDS 6 IN KIDNAPPING OF MOON AIDE
description: Six men have been arrested on charges that they kidnapped a leader of the Unification Church in Manhattan in September and tortured him until he agreed to pay a $1 million ransom, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: INDIRA GANDHI VIEWED POWER AS A MEANS TO NECESSARY GOALS
description: To the Editor:

title: VIEW OF SCHIZOPHRENIA ON 'THE BRAIN'
description: ''THE BRAIN,'' just possibly the best series of its kind ever done on television, looks tonight at schizophrenia. Strictly speaking, the series stretches its mandate to do this - the physiology of the mental illness is shadowy and only dimly understood - but the episode, ''Madness,'' is rewarding. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: IVAL GOODMAN
description: Ival Goodman, a Cincinnati Reds right fielder who played on two pennant-winning clubs and was a National League all-star, died Sunday at Jewish Hospital.

title: U.S. Accused Over Trade
description: Developing countries today accused the United States of violating its free trade commitments and attempting to sabotage the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade by pushing issues outside the scope of the international trade forum.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'd like a can of beer.'' - William J. Schroeder, artificial heart recipient. ( B7:1.)

title: DANCING PANCAKES AND OTHER FOLK FARE
description: MOST dancers live on diet cola, yogurt and junk food. But Dan Wagoner, dancer and choreographer, is an exception. He eats like a 19th-century farmer: Indian pudding, succotash, buckwheat cakes and Southern fried chicken are the sort of dishes he likes, and he cooks many of them in the fireplace.

title: RESTAURANT WINE 'CELLARS': SOME UNTRADITIONAL LOCATIONS
description: IF you decide to splurge on a bottle of 1966 Ch^ateau Lafite Rothschild when dining at Lut ece,

title: PARENTS TELL CITY PANEL OF FEARS AND ANGER OVER SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: Their children are often taught on the far side of the building, they said, and eat their lunch in a separate corner of the cafeteria. Some of their children have severe physical handicaps, others have learning disabilities and some were assigned to special education classes because they were slow to learn or presented discipline problems.

title: RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a tax loss of $59,000. c-Net loss d-After a tax credit of $3,105,000. The company said the 1984 figures include the sale of three Canadian subsidiaries in May, July, and August.

title: SCREEN: 'CASE IS CLOSED'
description: MRINAL SEN'S ''Case Is Closed'' begins by introducing a middle-class Calcutta couple who are flirting with the idea of hiring a young servant. Soon thereafter, a lower- class boy of about 11, not much older than their own son, enters the couple's employ. The film, which opens today at the Film Forum, is about the aftermath of an accident that occurs some months later. The servant dies, apparently of carbon monoxide poisoning, while sleeping in a windowless kitchen on an especially cold night. He was supposed to have slept in an unheated cubbyhole under a stairwell.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for a call-in survey to be conducted Saturday by ABC-TV. Those who think Brigham Young University is the No. 1 college football team in the country may call (900) 720-0070.

title: SHOESTRING MOVIES AS AN ART
description: What can a film maker do with a million dollars? In Hollywood - where the average movie costs $12 million - a million dollars will buy one star, a few sets, or two weeks of shooting at a fancy location.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about an injury suffered by the actor Derek Jacobi misidentified the play to which he will return on Friday. It is ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' at the Gershwin Theater.

title: Democrats on the Move
description: Ann F. Lewis, who has been political director of the Democratic National Committee since 1981, is leaving the committee to become national director of Americans for Democratic Action. Her departure will give the new party chairman, to be chosen in January, a key staff position to fill as part of an expected rebuilding operation.

title: DROP REPORTED IN CITY WELFARE ROLLS
description: Welfare rolls in New York City have begun to drop, and a report issued by the State Comptroller's office yesterday predicted that the decline would continue.

title: Persian Gulf Nations Open Annual Parley
description: The leaders of Saudi Arabia and the five Persian Gulf nations that make up the Gulf Cooperation Council opened the group's fifth annual meeting today. The conference is expected to focus on improving coordination among the members' military forces and regional security.

title: IN BURGUNDY, CHEESE AND CONTEMPLATION
description: CITEAUX, France

title: MAJOR STEPS IN THE WESTWAY PROJECT
description: Following are key developments in the Westway project since it was proposed more than a decade ago: 1971 - Wateredge, the forerunner of Westway, is proposed by two members of the State Urban Development Corporation. The early plan includes creation of 700 acres of new land between the Battery and 72d Street. 1973 - An elevated section of the West Side Highway collapses under the weight of a dump truck sent to repair a deck.

title: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK GUERRILLA BASES 20 MILES EAST OF BEIRUT, KILLING 7
description: Israeli Air Force jets attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases in eastern Lebanon today, and 7 people were reported killed and 10 wounded.

title: How Tax Rates Would Change
ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

Sports Seminars Open The sixth annual Sport Summit, a three-day international symposium for people involved in sports-related businesses opened yesterday at the World Trade Center. Governor Cuomo gave the welcoming
description: address. Representatives were on hand to give their pitch for everything

title: Talman Elects New Officers CHICAGO, Nov. 27 - The
description: board of the Talman Home

title: On Judges Paid Less Than Clerks
description: The 1,100 judges who staff New York's courts have been prosecuting a case of their own. They are paid too little, they say, in some cases less than their clerks. They make a good case, and even Governor Cuomo now seems grudgingly to accept it. Likewise, state legislators and the state's top four elected officials are overdue for a pay raise, and the special session of the Legislature, to start Tuesday, will be the time to act accordingly.

title: 3 EJECTED
description: The Devils defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 3-2, tonight in a game marked by 27 penalties and the ejection of three players, including Ron Low, the Devil goalie, for fighting.

title: IF TAX SYSTEM IS OVERHAULED
description: ASSUMING that the Treasury's plan for overhauling the Federal income tax system is adopted in essentially its proposed form by President Reagan and Congress - which, at this point, is a risky assumption - what would be the effects on business and the economy?

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
BUSINESS COMMUNITY REACTS WITH APPREHENSION
description: Although the Treasury Department's tax proposals are aimed at smoothing out inequities in the nation's tax system, concern was mounting in the business community yesterday that the plan, if enacted, would deal a sharp blow to the economy.

title: ROOTS OF LOS LOBOS ALBUM IN MUSIC OF DECADES
description: THE first album by Los Lobos, ''How Will the Wolf Survive?,'' ought to stir up a few parties this winter. The band from East Los Angeles, which performs tomorrow at the Ritz, digs into three decades' worth of music - blues, rhythm-and-blues, folk-rock, country and Tex-Mex norteno music - like the ultimate sock-hop band. ''We're not nostalgic,'' said Louie Perez, the group's drummer. ''We make contemporary music with a deep foundation.''

title: Sharp Criticism From Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday sharply criticized the Treasury Department's proposal to disallow Federal deductions for the payment of state and local taxes.

title: Omark-Blount Merger Set Omark Industries, a leading
description: maker of the chains used in

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SOME WESTERNERS PUT HOPE IN IDEA FROM AFRICA
description: After decades of ruinous overgrazing of a fragile land, Westerners are testing a profoundly different way to use the range.

title: Power Failure No Threat
description: A short power failure today at Humana Hospital Audubon, where William J. Schroeder is recuperating, did not threaten the machinery keeping him alive, Dr. Allan Lansing said. In the two to three minutes that the power failed, the machine pumping air into Mr. Schroeder's implanted mechanical heart did not waiver, Dr. Lansing said, adding that the emergency power system came on immediately.

title: CRIME PANEL TOLD OF COCAINE ABUSE
description: Cocaine abuse has reached epidemic proportions and one of every 10 Americans has tried the drug at least once, witnesses before the President's Commission on Organized Crime said today .

title: PLAY CLOSED AFTER 'CRUCIBLE' DISPUTE
description: A leading experimental theater group has closed its production ''L.S.D.,'' apparently ending the controversy surrounding the show's use of a 20-minute segment from Arthur Miller's ''Crucible.''

title: SERVED AS ENVOY TO TRINIDAD
description: Dr. Melvin H. Evans, the United States Ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago, died this morning in St. Croix, V. I., after suffering a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: SHANLEY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $683,170 from debt restructuring of a subsidiary. The latest quarter and 9 months figures include the July 1 acquisition of its Quick Fill subsidiary.

title: THEATER: PAN ASIAN'S 'STATE WITHOUT GRACE'
description: LINDA Kalayaan Faigao's ''State Without Grace,'' a new play at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, is a multigenerational study of a family in disharmony. The setting is a city in the Philippines, but the situation transcends geographical and ethnic boundaries. Both the play and the playwright are marked by their potential.

title: PLOT IS REPORTED ON A U.S. EMBASSY
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Italian and American agents had foiled a possible plan by a group of Lebanese to bomb the United States Embassy in Rome.

title: NOXIOUS WHITE CLOUD FROM JERSEY DRIFTS TO STATEN I. AND LEAVES 32 ILL
description: A white cloud of noxious fumes drifting from New Jersey over the Arthur Kill made at least 32 people ill yesterday on the Staten Island side of the Goethals Bridge.

title: CONCORD COMPUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: MARIA BENITEZ AND JOSE GRECO
description: THE Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company opened last night at the Joyce Theater with Jose Greco as guest artist - an event that comes as something of a surprise in that Mr. Greco, now 65 years old, supposedly gave his farewell performance in New York in 1979.

title: INTERSECTIONS ARE NO PLACE FOR INNOCENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Angola Proposes Timetable For Pullout by 20,000 Cubans
description: Angola proposed a three-year timetable today for the withdrawal of 20,000 Cuban troops from its territory as part of a settlement for South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.

title: A.T.&T.'S ADS GET TOUGHER
description: A.T.&T., the company long known for its warm and friendly ads, has decided to ''reach out and touch someone'' - its competitors - with some stinging ads.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
Warner-Lambert Elects New Chief
description: The Warner-Lambert Company announced that Joseph D. Williams, president and chief operating officer of the drug and consumer products company, had been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He will succeed Ward S. Hagan, 64 years old, who will remain chairman of the board.

title: EX-C.I.A. EMPLOYEE HELD AS CZECH SPY
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday arrested a former Central Intelligence Agency contract employee in New York and accused him of having infiltrated the agency to channel national security information to the Czechoslovak intelligence service.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Officer at De Beers Announces Retirement
description: Harry Oppenheimer, one of South Africa's most prominent business executives and reputedly one of the world's 10 richest individuals, announced that he is retiring as head of the diamond conglomerate, De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd.

title: Connecticut Bonds Offered
description: In the municipal market, Connecticut offered $100 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.

title: Macy's Chief Cites Sluggish Season
description: Consumer buying is sluggish thus far in the holiday season, Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive officer of R.H. Macy & Company, said yesterday. The first four days of Christmas shopping have been ''marginally disappointing to us,'' he told the company's annual meeting.

title: Tulane Drops Coach
description: Tulane University yesterday dismissed its football coach, Wally English , whose teams were 7-15 during a two-year tenure. Athletic Director Hindman Wall refused to discuss the reasons for English's termination but continually referred to a university statement citing ''broad, irreconcilable policy differences between English and the Tulane administration.''

title: Braniff Approval
description: The Justice Department said today that it had found no antitrust violations in Braniff Inc.'s proposed sale of nine gates at the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport to American Airlines for about $20 million. Charles F. Rule, Deputy Assistant Attorney General, said the two companies were notified last Friday that the Government had decided to refrain from challenging the deal. But he noted that the department would continue to monitor competitive conditions at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport.

title: 4 West Germans Expelled by Rumania
description: Rumania has expelled four members of the West Germany Embassy staff in Bucharest in retaliation for Bonn's expulsion of five Rumanian diplomats, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: TWO SHARE TOP OFFICE AT K.& E.
description: KENYON & ECKHARDT, which has been without a president since April, still does not have one as such, but it does have a new office of the president occupied by two vice chairmen, Stephen O. Frankfurt, 52 years old, and Ronald DeLuca, 60. Both happen to be Pratt Institute alumni who started in the business as art directors.

title: Employee Petition At Capitol Air
description: John A. Catsimatidis, the vice chairman of Capitol Air Inc., said that so many employees had joined a petition to keep the company under protection of Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws that management might not challenge the petition.

title: HOW PLAN WAS PUT TOGETHER
description: The Treasury's package of tax recommendations is the product of a painstaking and sometimes fractious team that labored much of the year.

title: FLYERS EXTEND UNBEATEN STREAK TO 10
description: Lindsay Carson had a goal and an assist as the Philadelphia Flyers, scoring three goals within the first five minutes of play, downed the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 4-2.

title: BUNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
OPEC OUTPUT SAID TO EXCEED QUOTA
description: Oil production of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is exceeding the daily limit set last month, raising doubts that the group can keep its official prices from falling, oil analysts said yesterday.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a capital gain of $632,987 from the disposition of an unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: LEGISLATIVE LEADERS ARE WARY
description: Congressional leaders, while generally praising the tax simplification plan presented by the Treasury Department, said today that any proposal would require strong lobbying from President Reagan to have any chance of passage.

title: TORRES'S WORLDS ARE UNITED
description: Jose Luis (Chegui) Torres, a former world boxing champion whose No. 1 ambition is ''to write a great novel,'' was sworn in yesterday by Governor Cuomo as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, and there were enough of his friends present for the television cameras to produce a ''This Is Your Life'' episode.

title: CBS AHEAD IN RATINGS DESPITE A POOR WEEK
description: With the November ratings sweeps nearing an end, CBS's prime-time entertainment appears to be close to clinching a win among the three networks despite last week's first third- place finish in four years.

title: CROWN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Talking Turkey
description: This postscript to Thanksgiving

title: ALABAMA PRISONS FOUND IMPROVED
description: Lawyers for Alabama prison inmates and the State Correction Department took another step today toward resolving a 13-year-old lawsuit involving prison conditions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: UNFOLDING A LIFE Isaac Bashevis Singer, the writer and master teller of stories about Jewish life in Europe and America, is 80 years old this year, and what better reason for an exhibition that reviews his life in document and photograph at the place dedicated to Yiddish, the language of this Nobel Prize winner? The show lines the halls of two floors of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street (535-6700).

title: STAGE: 'SHORT EYES,' BY PINERO, IN REVIVAL
description: FOR the Second Stage revival of Miguel Pinero's ''Short Eyes,'' David Jenkins has designed a wraparound set that envelops the audience in the clammy, cinder-block environment of a New York House of Detention. And, after a while, we really do feel that we're in jail. By the time the inmates erupt in an irrational cataclysm of vigilante violence, the audience is squirming uncontrollably, afraid to watch the bloodletting and yet unwilling to look away. When the play ends a while later, a theatergoer may be torn between a desire to applaud and the urge to rush home for a cleansing shower.

title: MOTHER SUSPECTED SURVIVOR MIGHT NOT BE HER DAUGHTER
description: Colleen Lake says she suspected the truth, that the injured girl who lay comatose in a hospital bed for two weeks after an automobile accident was not her daughter. But Mrs. Lake pushed those thoughts aside.

title: CHASE CUTS PRIME RATE TO 11 1/4%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank leapfrogged over other major banks yesterday and lowered its prime lending rate half a percentage point, to 11 1/4 percent.

title: IONA TOPS HOFSTRA IN OPENER, 80-72
description: In its home opener tonight, more notable for who was missing than who played, Iona defeated Hofstra, 80-72, before 2,427 fans.

title: ; INTERSECTIONS ARE NO PLACE FOR INNOCENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said that the Omega Optical Co., which was acquired in August, contributed about $8 million to first quarter sales and broke even in the quarter.

title: KOCH URGES DELAY IN CONFIRMING LIPPER FOR A SPOT ON M.T.A. BOARD
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had asked the State Legislature to postpone a confirmation vote on his deputy, Kenneth Lipper, as a member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board of directors.

title: Bill to Limit Inquiries Stopped by McGinley
description: A bill to strip the Department of Investigation of its power to initiate inquiries without the authorization of the Mayor or the City Council was withdrawn yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alpha Microsystems, Irvine, Calif., said it had completed the acquisition of the assets and service contracts of Paragon Computer Services Inc. and Computer Service Network Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Ferry Across the Hudson
description: Surveying the kingdom of Manhattan as if he could conquer it from his imperial barge, Arthur E. Imperatore journeyed across the Hudson yesterday from New Jersey.

title: Fruits of Victory Turn a Bit Sour
description: Winning the first Olympic marathon for women was sweetly satisfying for Joan Benoit, but the 27-year- old champion has not much enjoyed the celebrity and demands on her time that resulted from her stirring triumph.

title: RECITAL: FRANK WIENS
description: FRANK WIENS, a pianist who made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night, studied at the University of Michigan and has taken prizes in the North American Young Artists Competition and the Southwest Pianists Foundation Competition. He is currently a resident artist at the Conservatory of Music of the University of the Pacific.

title: Reductions For Most People
description: The majority of taxpayers would find their tax bills reduced under the Treasury Department's tax simplification plan, which taxes corporations more heavily in order to provide additional relief for individuals.

title: Changes at Northwest
description: M.J. Lapensky, chairman and chief executive of Northwest Airlines Inc., said that he would give up the chief executive's position, effective Jan. 1.

title: Seller of Legal Forms Spared Jail in Florida
description: Rosemary Furman, a legal secretary whose do-it-yourself legal forms made her a popular hero, was spared today from serving 30 days in jail for refusing to stop giving legal advice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1984

title: SOVIET SAYS '85 ARMS OUTLAY IS UP BY 12% TO KEEP MILITARY BALANCE
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was raising its military budget next year by 12 percent, to a new high, to maintain a strategic balance with the West.

title: REPORT BACKS INCREASE IN RURAL SPEED LIMITS
description: A Federal panel today strongly endorsed the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit for most highways in the nation. But it also said that on rural parts of the Interstate system higher speed limits could have strong benefits without a ''proportional impact on safety.''

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
SULCUS COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OFFICES ARE REPLACING PRESSES IN DAILY NEWS BUILDING
description: The presses and equipment for printing millions of copies of The Daily News have been removed from the newspaper's 54- year-old landmark building on 42d Street at Second Avenue, and the 175,000 square feet where they were used is being converted into commercial office space.

title: SURVIVAL IN THE FAST LANE
description: ''I would suggest,'' Bob Kousoulos says calmly to his driving student, Jules, ''that you do something soon with the brakes. It is a red light, Jules. ''Jules, the brakes!''

title: CHINA TIMES CEASES U.S. PUBLICATIONS
description: The China Times, considered the most influential Chinese-language newspaper in the United States, has ceased publication.

title: CHILEANS, DEFYING ARMY, STAGE PROTESTS
description: Government troops patrolled the streets of this capital today as Chileans held brief demonstrations in more than half a dozen locations to protest against the 11-year rule of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: CHRISTMAS GIFTS FOR CHILDREN
description: 1.*Lightweight Tricycle

title: PERCY MILLER JR., 85, A FORMER LEGISLATOR AND MAYOR IN JERSEY
description: Percy A. Miller Jr., a former New Jersey State Assemblyman and a former Mayor of Irvington, N.J., died Sunday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 85 years old and had lived in Stuart for about 20 years.

title: Thomson-CSF, Hewlett in Deal
description: Hewlett-Packard France and Thomson- CSF Telephone said they had signed an agreement to provide a system for integrating office and data telecommunications equipment.

title: Maryland Judge Ousted As Forger of a Writ
description: Maryland's highest court on Monday ordered the immediate removal of a judge accused of forging another judge's signature.

title: Driver's Preference
description: Shopper to driver of bus headed down Fifth Avenue: ''Do you go to Macy's?''

title: YOUTH IS ON TRIAL IN FATAL BEATING IN VIDEO ARCADE
description: An 18-year-old youth yesterday went on trial for murder, charged as one of two attackers in the beating death of a student on the East Side last Jan. 1.

title: A POSITIONING OF PORTFOLIOS
description: LAST February, when some Wall Street strategists kept forecasting a ''second leg'' for the

title: Namath's Line
description: Joe Namath, the former Jet quarterback and erstwhile pantyhose purveyor, was in town yesterday peddling his latest wares, a special Joe Namath signature line of men's underwear.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: GRIMOD DE LA REYNIERE, who was born in Paris in 1758 and was considered the greatest gastronome of his age, once said: ''Everything in a pig is good. What ingratitude has permitted its name to become a term of opprobrium?''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ron Jaworski , the Philadelphia Eagle quarterback, who suffered a broken left leg and torn ankle liga? ments Sunday, underwent successful surgery yesterday. . . . A groin injury likely will keep Dan Fouts , the Chargers' quarterback, out of the lineup next Monday night, when San Diego is host to the Chicago Bears. . . . The Los Angeles Rams have placed the rookie tight end Chris Faulkner on their reserve-nonfootball illness list. Faulkner has been admitted to Centinela Hospital in nearby Inglewood where he will undergo tests for possible chemical dependency.

title: SCOTTS SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $3,000 relating to an adjustment of a tax benefit. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $4,000 and a tax credit of $23,000. d-After a tax credit of $32,000 and an extraordinary gain of $197,000 from an adjustment of accelerated debt payment. e-After income from discontinued operations of $384,000 and an extraordinary gain of $476,000 from an adjustment of accelerated debt payment.

title: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. PLANS TO DOUBLE SUPPLY OF ARMS TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: United States officials say $280 million has been earmarked in covert military aid for the Afghan insurgents this fiscal year, more than doubling the aid in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

title: INSIDER TRADING CHARGED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a Citibank vice president and several other people and companies today of using illegally obtained advance knowledge that McGraw- Hill Inc. planned to buy Monchik- Weber Corporation, a computer systems marketing company.

title: NAVRATILOVA LIFTS A STREAK TO 71
description: Martina Navratilova, aiming to win her seventh consecutive Grand Slam tournament, trounced Yvonne Vermaak of South Africa, 6-1, 6-1, to advance today to the second round of the $1.28 million Australian Open tennis tournament.

title: Letter: On Environmental Hazards Toxic Dumps and Cancer Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMB SUSPECTED IN SALVADORAN CRASH
description: A helicopter crash that killed the Salvadoran Army's leading combat commander last month was probably caused by a bomb and not by mechanical failure or leftist rebel gunfire as originally reported, according to military officials here who are close to an investigation of the crash.

title: Northrop Outlay
description: The Northrop Corporation said it expects to invest about $150 million in developmental work in its F-20 Tiger Shark program this year. Northrop said it was developing the plane with its own funds in response to the Government's stated need for a high-performance fighter. The F-20 program's financial impact on Northrop was not expected to be significantly different in 1985 than in 1984, the company said.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 27
Ken O'Brien's Bloodhound
description: Perhaps someday Ken O'Brien,

title: CONYERS ARRESTED IN RACIAL PROTEST
description: Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan was arrested today outside the South African Embassy in the latest in a series of marches protesting that country's racial policies.

title: Big Cocaine Shipment Is Captured in Arizona
description: The police seized 1,500 pounds of high-grade cocaine worth an estimated $1 billion Monday after a vacationing detective spotted fresh airplane tracks at an abandoned World War II airstrip, the authorities said today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Knicks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. This is the first meeting of the season between the cross-river rivals, who split six games last season.

title: FIVE SENATORS IN TIGHT RACE TO BE CHOSEN REPUBLICAN LEADER TODAY
description: Five Republican Senators were locked today in an extremely tight battle to be chosen majority leader in an election Wednesday, and Capitol Hill analysts agreed that any one could win.

title: Kean Signs Bill For a Youth Corps
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today to set up a Volunteer Youth Corps to recruit, train and employ young people to rehabilitate housing and public property in urban centers.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
S & K FAMOUS BRANDS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 27
KOCH HONORS 6 IN THE ARTS WITH AWARDS
description: Mayor Koch honored six New Yorkers for their lifetime achievements in the arts yesterday in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion.

title: CATERED PARTIES: NOW IN ALL SIZES
description: THE party season is under way. From now through Christmas and New Year's, in what New Yorkers like to think is the most party-giving city in the Western world, this is the season for festivities of all descriptions.

title: SISTER MARY CROSS
description: Sister Mary Francilda Cross of the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul, a retired teacher and administrator in Roman Catholic elementary schools in Manhattan and the Bronx, died Nov. 17 at the Convent of Mary the Queen in Yonkers.

title: Home Mortgage Bonds Marketed
description: The Georgia Residential Finance Authority offered $65 million of home ownership mortgage bonds, with serial maturities ranging from 1986 to 1989 and a ''put'' bond maturing in 2004.

title: NEW CRIME FIGHT BEGINS IN DETROIT
description: With a rise in violent crimes adding to Detroit's longstanding image problems, Mayor Coleman A. Young held a symposium today on ways ''to bring this crime wave to a screeching halt.''

title: OF SEX, BUSINESS AND THE CENTURY CLUB
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLISHERS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $27,000 for the quarter and $14,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: THE COMMON CRUELTY
description: Even those who loved me were

title: SOVIET PLUGS CASPIAN LEAK, THEN RESTORES IT
description: In 1980, the Soviet Union tampered with nature by building a dike to plug a leak in the Caspian Sea. Now, four years later, unforeseen ecological effects have forced it to build an aqueduct to restore the leak.

title: Setback for Horner
description: Bob Horner , the Atlanta Braves' third baseman who missed most of the 1984 season with a broken wrist, may be facing surgery he had hoped to avoid. According to the Braves, when the cast was removed from Horner's right wrist on Monday and X-rays were taken, the team phsyician, Dr. Robert Wells , found that the fracture had not healed properly. Dr. Wells said there was an abnormality that could limit the flexibility of the wrist and affect blood flow. The finding, which came just a month after Horner had been told he would not need a bone graft, raised the possibility that the slugger might now need the surgery.

title: Police Detective Is Suspended
description: A city police detective was suspended without pay yesterday after being accused of passing confidential intelligence reports to a convicted heroin trafficker who was identified as a member of the Sicilian Mafia.

title: Shcharansky Is Moved Back to a Labor Camp
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky has completed his second three-year stretch in prison and has been returned to a labor camp, his family reported today.

title: BRIEFS ; Debt
description: * A.R.A. Manufacturing Co. of Delaware filed for an offering of 45,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 in sinking fund debentures due in 1996 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Joffrey Ballet Receives $150,000 Grant for Tour
description: The Joffrey Ballet's annual national tour was awarded a grant of $150,000 by Philip Morris Inc., part of a cumulative grant of $375,000 given the ballet company during its four year association with Philip Morris.

title: Nestle Confident On Carnation Tie
description: Officials of the huge Swiss food manufacturer Nestle S.A. said that they were confident United States regulatory authorities would allow the company to complete its $3 billion acquisition of the Carnation Company of Los Angeles.

title: Of Moses and the Hudson
description: When the Broadway Association honored the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday for helping improve the Times Square neighborhood, lunch took on a biblical tone.

title: A DEEP FRYER-STEAMER
description: THERE are two requirements for successful frying: clean oil and proper temperature. For home cooks, clean oil is no problem, but the temperature business can be vexing. It is best dealt with by using a frying thermometer and regularly checking the oil.

title: MEXICO SAYS I.B.M. PLANT IS PERMISSIBLE
description: Top Mexican Government officials said tonight that the International Business Machines Corporation would be permitted to build a wholly owned plant for microcomputers in Mexico, on the condition that it use 50 percent Mexican-made components.

title: Discouraging Words for Flutie
description: Success breeds attention, and Doug Flutie of Boston College had his share of both even before that amazing pass last Friday that beat Miami in the Orange Bowl. Who knows? By now Flutie may be the best-known athlete in the country.

title: Rev. Seward Hiltner, 74, Dies;Taught at Princeton Seminary
description: The Rev. Dr. Seward Hiltner, a Presbyterian minister who was a leader in the field of pastoral care and a former professor at the Princeton Theological Seminary, died Nov. 19 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock distribution paid in September.

title: LATEST IN OIL DRILLING PLATFORMS
description: As one nestles down on the North Sea's newest oil production platform following a two- hour helicopter flight from Aberdeen, Scotland, the platform differs little to the untutored eye from its neighbors dotting the horizon here in the productive East Shetlands basin.

title: First-Place Fines
description: In a recent compilation by Sports Industry News of the largest fines in sports history, the ''winners'' were the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association, who were assessed $400,000 by the office of the commissioner for illegally signing Julius Erving in 1975.

title: STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHINA'S MARKET REFORMS
description: A leap into the unknown is the only accurate way to describe the economic reforms announced in China last month. But based upon a trip to four large Chinese cities earlier this month, I am convinced that the Chinese leaders intend to make a permanent change in their system of state socialism.

title: EX-MAYOR, AT TRIAL, ENTERS A GUILTY PLEA IN ATLANTIC CITY CASE
description: Former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City pleaded guilty today to a single count of extortion, abruptly ending his trial after the Federal jury had heard only two witnesses.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
ENERGETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No comparable results were reported for the year-ago 9 months because Energetics Inc. had no operations prior to the consummation of its exchange off which closed at the end of March 1983.

title: VITALITY UNLIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITISH DIPLOMAT IN INDIA IS SLAIN ON WAY TO HIS OFFICE IN BOMBAY
description: The British Deputy High Commissioner for western India was shot and killed today by two unidentified assailants as he was being driven to his office in downtown Bombay, the police said.

title: BEVIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary net loss of $133,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: DISABLED WOMEN MEET ROLE MODELS
description: WHEN Harilyn Rousso, who has cerebral palsy, was growing up, she had virtually no contact with other disabled people. ''I attended a regular school so I just didn't know anyone else who was disabled, and disability was then shrouded in secrecy and stigma,'' Miss Rousso said, addressing an audience composed almost entirely of disabled women. ''So it never occurred to me that there could be interesting, smart, attractive, witty and successful disabled people.''

title: U.S. DELAYS RELEASE OF REPORT ON SOVIET ARMS COMPLIANCE
description: White House officials said today that they had decided to put off the release of a new report until next February on purported Soviet arms-control violations that was scheduled to be made public on Saturday.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a currency adjustment loss of $310,000. c-After a loss of $4,595,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SUICIDE AS AN ACT OF VIOLENCE IS ON THE RISE
description: To the Editor:

title: First Executive
description: An investment group controlled by the Belzberg brothers of Canada told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the First Executive Corporation common stock to about 3.5 million shares, or 7.3 percent of the total outstanding. The group said it bought an additional 500,000 shares on Nov. 20 in the open market. First Executive is a life insurance holding company.

title: O'BRIEN WILL START AGAIN FOR THE JETS
description: Pat Ryan said today that he was disappointed to learn he would not start against the Giants next Sunday. He contended that he was healthy enough to play.

title: JACOBS'S AVCO STAKE LIFTED TO OVER 12%
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, has increased his ownership of the Avco Corporation to slightly more than 12 percent and has asked the company to consider an unspecified ''transaction'' that he said would pay Avco shareholders a premium above the current market value of Avco stock.

title: Full Brandenburg Set at Y
description: All six of J. S. Bach's Brandenburg Concertos will be performed by Gerard Schwarz leading the Y Chamber Symphony at the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The complete set will be heard Dec. 27 and Dec. 29 at 8 P.M., Dec. 30 at 3 P.M. and Dec. 31 at 8 P.M. Tickets are $13.50 to $17.50, except for the Dec. 31 concert, at which champagne will be served; tickets for that concert are $17.50 to $22.50. Seats are available through the box office (427- 6000) or through Chargit (944-9300).

title: Dow Rises by 7.84 as Volume Spurts
description: Stock prices mostly rose yesterday in accelerated trading, apparently fueled in part by the Treasury's announcement of its tax proposals.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was 1945, soon after V-E Day, and aboard

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Automatic Data Processing Inc. has named John M. Gaven president of the Financial Services division.

title: Drug Runner Gets Life Term
description: A former bail bondsman accused of leading a wide-ranging cocaine ring was sentenced in Federal District Court Monday to life in prison without parole and fined $425,000. The bondsman, Harold Rosenthal, 53 years old, was convicted last month in connection with a smuggling operation that prosecutors said brought five tons of cocaine into the United States in 14 months. He was sentenced by Judge G. Ernest Tidwell.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANIES WOULD PAY MORE
description: The Treasury's proposals for tax simplification, if enacted into law, would result in one of the largest tax increases in decades for businesses.

title: Transactions
description: Named Greg Riddoch director of minor league clubs. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Named Joe Klein special assistant to the general manager.

title: Thousands of Filipinos Honor Aquino at Rally
description: Thousands of Filipinos paid tribute to the slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. today.

title: DUTCH COURT ACTS ON 'RIGHT TO DIE'
description: The Netherlands Supreme Court asked an appeals court today to take another look at the case of a doctor who gave a fatal dose of curare to an elderly patient who had begged to die. Many here said they believed the request could result in a landmark case on the issue of euthanasia.

title: Ohio Toxic Dump Open With New State Rules
description: Toxic wastes again can be trucked into the Cecos International hazardous-waste landfill because the state has approved its reopening under strict new regulations.

title: Failure to Post a Flag Cited in Train Crash
description: The crew of a commuter train that backed into another train and injured 150 people, failed to use a flag man to watch for other traffic, a preliminary report says.

title: The Deficit Behind All That Smoke
description: Look at all the balls up in the air in Washington . . . or are they trial balloons? . . . or just smoke? The Treasury is proposing a vast tax reform plan. The Budget Office offers a list of spending cuts in popular programs. There's enough controversy here for four more years and then some. But is this all the economic program Mr. Reagan has in mind? These ideas are interesting, perhaps even meritorious, but they evade the central issue: how to curb the Federal deficit.

title: ON MATTERS OF TRADE, A STYLIZED GIVE AND TAKE
description: A periodic ritual of international pressure and response, played against the growing United States foreign trade deficit, is once again under way in the nation's capital.

title: MUSIC: COLLECTIVE, SOUNDS OF BRAZIL
description: AN Indian violinist, a British keyboardist and percussionists from Brazil and India joined forces as the Collective for two nights at Sounds of Brazil. The best part of Monday's early set was the give-and-take of noises and rhythms between Nana Vasconcelos on drum machine, shakers and Brazilian berimbau (musical bow), Trilok Gurtu on temple blocks, cymbal and Indian tabla drums, and both on congas and assorted rattles and bells.

title: ALL 108 ON HIJACKED JET ARE FREED IN ETHIOPIA
description: The hijackers of a Somali airliner seized on Saturday released their 108 hostages unharmed today and were given the choice of political asylum or safe passage to a country of their choice by Ethiopia.

title: POP-SOUL: AT BOTTOM LINE, GLENN JONES, GOSPEL SINGER
