description: -year-old gospel singer from Jacksonville, Fla., who appeared at the Bottom Line on Monday, is a promising young singer in a pop- soul ballad tradition whose mannerisms have been codified by Luther Vandross, James Ingram, Jeffrey Osborne, and Kashif, among others. These singers have redefined the pop- soul love song as a tense, polished expression of romantic longing.

title: SPARROW CAPS RALLY BY KNICKS
description: Rory Sparrow, who had been struggling offensively the entire game, hit a 13-foot jumper with five seconds left to give the Knicks a 97-96 come-from- behind victory over the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: 5TH GRADERS LEARN TO MANAGE STRESS
description: Fifth graders in this South Shore town have turned out strongly for a course in stress management, with 30 signing up for the eight available places. They are taught how to deal with problems ranging from quarreling parents to the threat of nuclear war.

title: SHARON, COMPLETING HIS TESTIMONY, SAYS TIME ARTICLE CREATED 'HATRED'
description: Ariel Sharon completed his testimony yesterday by declaring that a Time magazine article had created ''a new wave of hatred'' against him.

title: ARMY PREPARES FOR MCCALLUM
description: Napoleon McCallum, Navy's premier running back who suffered a broken foot in the second game of this season, was supposed to be finished with football because of the injury. He is now listed as a doubtful starter against Army on Saturday in Philadelphia.

title: CROWLEY, MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
American Express $100 Million Issue
description: The American Express Credit Corporation offered $100 million worth of senior notes.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Bond Prices Change Slightly
description: Bond prices were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday.

title: Altman Sale Set
description: The Altman Foundation said that, as expected, it had signed a definitive agreement to sell B. Altman & Company to a group of five investors. No purchase price was given, although retail trade reports have estimated it at about $115 million. The investors are Earle W. Kazis, Maurice S. Taprin, Peter L. Malkin, Morton L. Olshan and Sanford J. Zimmerman. Mr. Kazis, Mr. Taprin and Mr. Olshan are New York real estate developers; Mr. Malkin is a member of the Manhattan law firm of Wien, Malkin & Bettex, and Mr. Zimmerman is a former chairman of Abraham & Straus and chairman of Cohoes Specialty Stores Ltd., in Cohoes, N.Y.

title: Books: A Life of Music
description: EDWARD ELGAR: A Creative Life. By

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1984 International The foiling of a terrorist plot to bomb the United States Embassy in Rome was reported by Administration officials. Italian authorities said they believed the suspects were linked with Islamic Holy War, which has claimed responsibility for bombing American installations in Lebanon. Rome's Police Chief, Marcello Monarca, said that seven Lebanese were arrested Saturday near Rome and that one had a detailed map of the embassy containing notes on supposed ''weak points.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) Increased aid to Afghan rebels is planned by the Reagan Administration, according to American officials. They said that about $280 million in covert military aid had been earmarked for the guerrillas in this fiscal year, more than doubling the aid provided last year. (A1:3-4.)

title: Likely New Head For Times Sq. Project
description: The probable new head of the nearly

title: WINE TALK
description: The American wine scene is in disarray. The grand design of five years ago, which had consumption, doubled since the 1960's, doubling again before the turn of the century, is an embarrassment. The talk of ''a wine-drinking nation'' has subsided in the face of general public indifference. Antialcohol groups are on the attack, and the industry, weighted down by archaic laws and fragmented by internal discord, has yet to fashion any serious sort of defense.

title: Fernando Corena, 67; Met Bass for 25 Years
description: Fernando Corena, who sang bass at the Metropolitan Opera for 25 seasons, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Lugano, Switzerland. He was 67 years old.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: North Korea Calls Off Talks With the South
description: In the first diplomatic fallout from the gun battle last week at Panmunjom, North Korea today called off economic talks with South Korea that were scheduled for next week.

title: Algerian Official in Syria
description: The Algerian Foreign Minister, Ahmed Taleb Ibrahemi, arrived here today and was received at the airport by Yasin Rajjuh, the Syrian Information Minister. The purpose of the visit, which coincides with a state visit by President Francois Mitterrand, was not known.

title: THE HIGH COST OF BEING A SOLDIER OF CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE arrival of chilly and sometimes inclement weather spells an end to outdoor exercise for many Americans. To help stay in shape until spring invites them out again, some look to health clubs, Y's and other indoor facilities.

title: ARMY DETERMINES BUILDING WESTWAY COULD HARM BASS
description: Building Westway would have a ''perceptible'' but ''minor'' impact on the striped bass that spend winters in the Hudson River and ''will not threaten'' their survival, the Army Corps of Engineers has concluded.

title: USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $21,000 for the 9 months.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1.3 million from discontinued business costs for the quarter and year. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,621,000 from an exchange of stock for debentures. d-Includes a $4.3 million charge from divestitures and plant consolidations, a $2.2 million gain from reduction in LIFO reserves and a gain of $2.6 million from an income tax adjustment, all for the quarter and year periods.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific National Corporation said its plan to acquire the minority shares of the Hong Kong- based Bank of Canton had been approved by the Supreme Court in Canton. Security Pacific already owns 69 percent of the bank. The company said the acquisition of the remaining 31 percent was valued at $46 million.

title: TIPPING THE BALANCE
description: WASHINGTON The Democrats are back in Washington, flirting with a bum idea.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
REAGAN SON HOPES TO SETTLE DISPUTE
description: President Reagan's son Michael said today that he wanted to sit down with his father and settle their differences ''outside the press'' so that ''Dad can get on with negotiating with the Russians.''

title: 327 Face Charges Of Fare Evasion
description: Transit police making a sweep of 23 subway stations in central Brooklyn yesterday arrested 327 people for fare evasion, including a man wanted for murder.

title: 2 Are Admonished On C.I.A. Project
description: Two Rutgers University professors were admonished yesterday by school officials who said they had failed to adhere to university guidelines while doing a research project for the Central Intelligence Agency and should have better informed a class in American foreign policy that its term papers would be part of the research.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include pretax charges of $2.9 million for the quarter and $8.1 million for the year.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on Oct. 19.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Muslim Rights Upheld InFrisksinStatePrison
description: The top court in the state today ruled that it would be a violation of a male Muslim prison inmate's constitutional rights, in most cases, to be pat-searched by a female guard.

title: L.I.U.-Fordham Reset for Tonight
description: Long Island University's basketball team, scheduled to oppose Fordham in the Rams' home opener last night, arrived more than one hour late at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx because of a traffic accident on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway that caused a three-hour delay.

title: Winds and Snow Strike The Pacific Northwest By The Associated Press
description: A blizzard with winds up to 90 miles an hour lashed parts of the Pacific Northwest yesterday, leaving up to 16 inches of snow, knocking out power to thousands of homes and closing interstate highways.

title: Don't Duck Our Day in Court
description: Sixteen judges of the World Court, including judges from America, Britain, France and West Germany, have now asked the United States to respond to Nicaragua's charges of aggression. The reaction in Washington has been not only ''disappointment'' but a threat to ignore and perhaps even to denounce the Court. The Administration had better think hard before taking such rash action.

title: Calling a Chair a Chair
description: Frank Mankiewicz, the former

title: Cracking Hickory Nuts
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Sample City Family Would Face Tax Rise
description: One New York City family with a combined annual salary of $80,000, studied as an example, would pay an additional $623 in Federal income tax for 1984, if the Treasury Department tax proposals had been in effect this year.

title: Pretax Profit Up for Bayer
description: Bayer A.G., the West German chemical group, said today that its pretax profit surged 62 percent in the first nine months of 1984, to 2.2 billion marks, or $719 million, from 1.36 billion marks a year earlier. The company did not divulge net profit or revenue figures.

title: Israeli Court Considers Witness in Sharon Suit
description: The Supreme Court in Jerusalem today ordered Israel's Attorney General to show cause in 15 days why Minister of Police Haim Bar Lev should not give evidence about former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon's character in his libel suit against Time magazine.

title: SUIT IS FILED TO BAR POSSIBLE HARM TO EARTH'S PROTECTIVE OZONE LAYER
description: An environmental group sued today to force the Government to curb emissions of chlorofluorocarbons into the atmosphere, asserting that the danger that they would deplete the earth's protective ozone layer was ''greater than previously thought.''

title: MORGAN KEEGAN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TREASURY OFFERS SWEEPING REVISION OF U.S. TAX SYSTEM
description: The Treasury Department today presented its proposal to restructure the nation's tax system in a way that would affect the income taxes paid by nearly every person and company in America.

title: Western Union Omits Its Dividends
description: The board of the Western Union Corporation, faced with cancellation of a bank credit line and the need to conserve cash, today voted to eliminate the next cash dividends on the company's common and preferred shares.

title: Coast Reactor Restarted
description: The Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant's reactor No. 1, shut by a malfunction last week, has resumed operating at 30 percent of capacity, officials said today. The 1.1 million-kilowatt-capacity reactor was running at 9 percent of capacity at the start of the day Monday, but operators raised this to 30 percent by 4:30 P.M., according to a Pacific Gas and Electric Company spokesman.

title: Editor From New York Goes to Ireland Digest
description: The traditional dream of the big city newspaperman who has spent a lifetime meeting unremitting daily deadlines has been the editorship of a small-town weekly. Martin O'Shea, after spending a majority of his 50 years in the man-eating New York milieu, is giving it a try, but with a twist.

title: Long Ends Holdout
description: One of the National Basketball Association's leading holdouts has come to terms with his team, and another may be close. The Detroit Pistons said that John Long , their free-agent guard, had agreed to terms and would be in uniform tonight against Portland.

title: Direct Broadcast
description: The Direct Broadcast Satellite Corporation, a privately owned company in Bethesda, Md., said it had signed a contract with European Arianespace for the launching of two satellites in 1987 and 1988 for about $90 million.

title: LTV Asset Shift
description: The LTV Corporation said that all of the assets of the company's Gadsden, Ala., steel plant had been transferred to a new company, the Gulf States Steel Corporation.

title: FOR LUNCH, A LOCAL TASTE OF GIVERNY
description: Even on the coldest, grayest day, there is a warm, tropical paradise here within a two-minute walk of the Capitol, a place of dazzling colors, dizzying scents and tranquil walkways that provides a sylvan respite from the fulminations and partisan jousts that occupy so many members of Congress.

title: A GASTRONOMIC WALK INSPIRED BY TOKLAS
description: BELLEY, France

title: Memorial for George Barrett
description: A mass of remembrance for George W. Barrett, a reporter, a war correspondent and an assistant metropolitan editor during a 43-year career at The New York Times, will be offered at 2 P.M. next Monday at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street. Mr. Barrett died of complications from Parkinson's disease Nov. 20 at the age of 71.

title: Synthetic Fuels Appointments WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -
description: President Reagan appointed

title: CBS ADDS A PROGRAM ON SUNDAY
description: CBS, in attempt to shore up its traditionally powerful Sunday evening schedule, is pulling out what it calls one of its strongest reserves, a new adventure comedy called ''Crazy Like a Fox.'' The program, about a father-and-son detective team, is the network's first season-replacement series this year.

title: Center of Attention
description: Bill Walsh , coach of the San Francisco 49ers and a close friend of Mike White , coach at the University of Illinois, said he expected White to be a coach in the National Football League next season. White was offensive line coach for Walsh's 49ers in 1978 and 1979.

title: DEMOCRACY IN FLOWER
description: In the late 1970's, 13 of Latin America's 20 republics were governed by generals, Haiti was ruled by a family dynasty and a Communist dictator was in power in Cuba. Democracy, long preferred by inhabitants of the region, seemed headed for extinction. Then suddenly the trend changed. On Sunday Uruguay became the eighth Latin American country to elect a civilian President since 1980 and Brazil and Guatemala should follow suit next year. Today only Chile, Paraguay and Haiti are still firmly in the grip of rightist dictators.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: How to Keep Mothers in School Every year 14,000 unmarried teen-age New York City girls bear children. Most are high school dropouts, which means that the only jobs they can get pay poorly and seldom offer fringes like health insurance. The more feasible and realistic option is usually welfare.
description: The majority say they'd like to get off welfare, and eventually some do. But because they have less schooling, they earn less than half the income of women who delay childbearing till their 20's.

title: THE MUSEUM OF AIR AND SPACE AND SUPERLATIVES
description: No longer satisfied with calling itself the ''most popular'' tourist attraction in the world, the National Air and Space Museum is launching even more superlatives these days.

title: PINOCHET FOILS OPPOSITION STRIKE CALL IN CHILE
description: President Augusto Pinochet's hard-line tactics undercut the opposition's call today for a national strike to protest against the 11-year-old military Government and the state of siege it imposed three weeks ago.

title: Advertisement at Tiffany
description: Another prominent Fifth Avenue

title: PROF. CUOMO GIVES PUBLIC SHORT LESSON IN BUDGETING
description: A parade of people - advocates for an alcoholic treatment center short of money in Schenectady, a hospital threatened with service cuts in Corinth, a toxic waste site in Guilderland - took their problems to Governor Cuomo today.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $108,495 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: CHINA TURNS TO PRIVATE MEDICINE TO HEAL SYSTEM
description: Each weekday morning when the traditional Chinese pharmacy on Zhangye Road opens, Kong Xianghe sits at a small desk inside the door and waits for customers to consult him about their ailments before buying the fragrant herbal medicines.

title: NETS END KNICK STREAK
description: The Nets learned some time ago about life without one of their most critical players. The Knicks learned that painful lesson tonight.

title: CONSIDER A U.S. SALES TAX
description: Both polls and politicians tell us that Americans want Federal deficits reduced, income tax rates cut and a fairer and simpler tax system. We can achieve these goals in 1985 but not with the modified flat tax plans - like that offered this week by the Treasury Department - that are now in vogue.

title: UEBERROTH TERMS TV KEY BASEBALL PROBLEM
description: Fans throughout the country may benefit from television superstations that carry hundreds of major league games, but Commissioner Peter Ueberroth zeroed in on those stations yesterday as one of the problems from which baseball suffers most.

title: TRP ENERGY SENSORS INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
PHILIP MORRIS TO TAKE BIG MILLER WRITE-DOWN
description: Philip Morris Inc. said yesterday that it would write down the value of its Miller Brewing Company's new $450 million brewery in Trenton, Ohio. The move would reduce fourth- quarter earnings by an estimated $140 million.

title: U.S. Magistrate Refuses Bail For Suspected Nazi Criminal
description: A suspected Nazi war criminal, Andrija Artukovic, accused of involvement in the murders of more than 700,000 people in Yugoslavia in World War II, was ordered held without bail Tuesday pending a hearing on his extradition to his homeland.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Work Ethic
description: Eddie Lee Ivery , a running back for the Green Bay Packers, reported to Brown County Jail in Wisconsin yesterday to serve a 10-day sentence for a traffic ticket but will be allowed to play in Sunday's game against Tampa Bay. Under a state work-release law, county authorities said, he can leave jail for employment purposes and will be allowed to practice with the team daily. He was sentenced for driving with a revoked license, having pleaded no contest in October. . . . Curtis Dickey , a running back for the Indianapolis Colts, accepted a plea bargain in Municipal Court in Indianapolis and will participate in a domestic couseling program after his estranged wife had charged him with battery stemming from an argument at her apartment last weekend.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes sales of Winkelman Stores Inc. of $19,265,281 for the quarter and $63,450,275 for the 9 months. Winkelman Stores' operations have been consolidated since Nov. 1, 1983, and prior to that, they were reported on the equity method. Sales of Miller-Wohl Co. of $67,761,000 are included in the latest quarter and sales of $90,287,000 in the latest 9 months. Miller-Wohl has been consolidated effective June 3.

title: REAGAN GETS '88 BUDGET WITH $235 BILLION IN CUTS
description: President Reagan's top budget and economic advisers today presented him with a plan to reduce projected Federal spending by about $235 billion over three years, according to Administration officials.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPECTACULAR IN BROOKLYN A spectacle that opens today in Brooklyn smacks more of a Max Reinhart epic than something that could fit in a church, but the production of ''Carmina Burana,'' with trimmings, will indeed be housed in the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, in Brooklyn Heights at Clinton and Montague Streets.

title: Ex-Chairman of Ashton Named President of Ziff
description: David C. Cole, who late last month abruptly resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Ashton-Tate Inc., one of the nation's leading computer software companies, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the Ziff Corporation, which has extensive holdings in information companies and computer publications.

title: Transactions
description: Named Terry Crowley batting coach. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Appointed Art Stewart director of scouting. MONTREAL (NL) - Named Larry Bearnarth pitching coach, Rick Renick hitting coach and Ron Hansen first-base coach.

title: PEOPLE PLAYED DURING ARCADE KILLING
description: Patrons continued playing video games while an 18-year-old student was being beaten to death in an East Side arcade last January, witnesses testified yesterday.

title: SECOND CAREERS AS DEVELOPERS
description: THREE years ago Nancy Chaffetz worked as a lawyer with Shearman & Sterling, a Wall Street law firm, and Leslie Hartley Wolff sold municipal bond funds, also on Wall Street. Both women, however, gave up their successful careers to develop residential real estate in Brooklyn.

title: International Incident
description: The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field, decided yesterday to take its international counterpart to arbitration for the reinstatement of Renaldo Nehemiah and Willie Gault .

title: RICKY BELL, 29, DIES AFTER 2-YEAR ILLNESS
description: Ricky Bell, an outstanding running back at Southern California who played six years in the National Football League, died yesterday at age 29 in a hospital in Inglewood, Calif., not far from his Los Angeles home. Doctors attributed his death to cardiac arrest caused by illnesses from which he had been suffering for two years.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Treasury Plan Is a Best Seller
description: Publication of the Treasury Department's plan for revising the income tax system set off a lively scramble by lawyers, lobbyists, accountants and other Washington operatives.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $9,105,000 for the quarter and $9,291,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $586,000 for the quarter and $1,233,000 for the 6 months.

title: A STUDENT DESIGN FOR EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Stayman Adds to His Titles With Triumph in Reisinger
description: Two of the records established by the remarkable climax to the Reisinger Board-a-Match team championship Sunday night were rather obvious.

title: Celebrities at Court
description: The courtroom drama of Ariel

title: Talks Set as a Deadline NearsforCartingStrike
description: The 400 companies in New York City that remove commercial garbage and their 2,000 unionized employees remained far apart yesterday on key issues in their contract dispute. The union has threatened to strike at 12:01 A.M. Saturday if the issues are not resolved.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mary Decker , the track star, will be married Jan. 1 in Eugene, Ore. to a British discus thrower, Richard Slaney . . . . Felipe Alou , a former major league outfielder and a coach with the Montreal Expos last season, was named manager of the Indianapolis Indians of the American Association, the Expos' top farm team. . . . Joe Washington , the speedy running back of the Redskins, was activated for tonight's game against the Vikings after being sidelined since the fifth week of the season with a sprained knee.

title: Killer Flees in Virginia Prison
description: An inmate serving life sentences for killing a banker and a policeman in a 1972 robbery attempt walked past a corrections officer tonight and out the front door of a prison, the authorities said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Big Reorganization Reported by Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday announced a major reorganization that effectively places full operational control of its day-to-day activities in the hands of Thomas G. Labrecque, Chase's president and chief operating officer since 1981.

title: Bank Rates Down Again
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts have declined for the fourth consecutive week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. The Monitor's national index of money market accounts fell to 9.14 percent, from 9.30 percent, in the week ended yesterday as the index of six-month C.D.'s declined to 9.60 percent from 9.88 percent.

title: Rail Warehouse Gutted by Fire
description: A fire gutted a two-block-long N.J. Transit warehouse this morning, destroying $5 million of equipment, vehicles and materials, officials said.

title: ECONOMISTS PRAISE MUCH OF TAX PLAN
description: Economists reacted favorably yesterday to this week's proposal by the Treasury for revamping the income tax system, but the reasons behind their enthusiasm varied widely, depending on their business affiliations and ideologies.

title: CHINAGLIA REACHES A GOAL AS AN OWNER
description: When he was only 23 years old and a relatively new star on the Italian soccer scene, Giorgio Chinaglia marched into the office of the president of his team, Lazio of Rome, with a check in his hand, asking to invest in the club and to be made a vice president.

title: The Republicans' Good Soldier ''If you ask people around the Senate who's been the most effective Republican Senator in this Administration, you're sure to get two answers,'' says Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause. ''One is Howard Baker and the other is Bob Dole.'' That being so, it's time to applaud Senate Republicans twice.
description: Senator Baker deserves bipartisan credit for the job he has done as the outgoing majority leader. And Senator Dole deserves the honor his Republican colleagues paid him yesterday by electing him leader as they installed one centrist after another in their front ranks.

title: RUCKELSHAUS RESIGNING POST AS CHIEF OF THE E.P.A.
description: The White House announced tonight that William D. Ruckelshaus was resigning as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, a post he assumed in the spring of 1983 when the agency was deep in crisis.

title: Funds for Curbing Drunken Drivers
description: Governor Kean announced today that 25 police departments in the state would receive $212,386 in Federal grants to crack down on drunken drivers.

title: United Ties Planes To Labor Pact
description: Richard J. Ferris, the chairman and chief executive of United Airlines, said the airline would buy more planes if a proposal it has sent its pilot union leads to a labor agreement. United, a unit of UAL Inc., has been in negotiations with the union for 10 months.

title: Stone & Adler Chief
description: As rumbles have had it for more than a month, Richard V. Colligan will be the next chairman and chief executive of Stone & Adler, Chicago direct marketing agency. He will replace Gerald Wood, who resigned. Mr. Colligan, who is 33 years old, has been president since 1981 of Benton & Bowles Direct and before that was with Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline since 1974. Wunderman, like Stone & Adler, is part of the Young & Rubicam Direct Marketing Group.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of the actress Sudie Bond on Nov. 12 misidentified the author of ''The Sandbox,'' a play in which she appeared. The playwright was Edward Albee.

title: SYMPHONY: PHILADELPHIANS
description: JORGE BOLET was the star of the Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night, appearing as soloist in Franck's Symphonic Variations for Piano and Orchestra and Weber's Konzertst"uck for the same combination. As connoisseurs of piano-playing are well aware, Mr. Bolet has a deft keyboard technique equaled by few performers on the concert stage today.

title: Long-Distance Phone Message
description: Since becoming a tennis professional in 1981, Ann Henricksson has had little to boast about. Although she was ranked No. 1 in women's singles among amateurs under 21 in 1980, her serve-and-volley game did not prosper in the pros.

title: Peignoir at the Barbizon
description: Neighbors must have wondered

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Football
description: Minnesota Vikings vs. Washington Redskins, at Minneapolis. A victory here would allow the Redskins to break the logjam at the top of the National Conference's Eastern Division by moving half a game ahead of the Giants and Dallas, if only briefly.

title: Comment by Iranian Angers Israeli at U.N.
description: The Iranian representative to the United Nations, Said Rajaie-Khorassani, said today that ''the final solution of the problem of the Middle East'' would be to replace Israel with a Palestinian state.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MENNONITES ORGANIZING TO HELP FARM BRETHREN
description: Their songs were hymns of joy, the words praise for their God as the giver of harvests.

title: STAGE: SHEPARD'S 'SUICIDE IN B FLAT'
description: or a murder - has taken place and two bumbling detectives, rejects for the role of Sam Spade, trip over blind leads and false accusations. Sam Shepard's ''Suicide in B Flat,'' in revival at La Mama Annex, is a comedy-mystery, a jazz caper that operates, to use the author's words, ''under the influence of macabre overtones.''

title: MR. STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $17,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the year.

title: BROKERS SKEPTICAL OF TAX PLAN
description: The Treasury Department's tax simplification plan was greeted with skepticism today by officials of the securities industry, who said it not only threatened their business but also could hurt the stock market's ability to raise capital for smaller corporations.

title: The New Nuggets
description: When Vince Boryla became president of the Denver Nuggets in May, he called the team a .500 ball club without hope in the draft and ''not much of trading value except Kiki Vandeweghe and Alex English.''

title: POLL FINDS WIDE SUPPORT FOR 55-M.P.H. LIMIT
description: A decade after its enactment, the Federal traffic law mandating a national speed limit of 55 miles an hour retains broad popular support around the country, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Reagan Endorses Limited Intelsat Competition
description: President Reagan today formally endorsed the idea of competition by privately owned satellite communications companies with Intelsat, the international consortium. But the endorsement was hedged with restrictions that might limit the competitors to 15 percent of Intelsat's business.

title: Beatrice to Sell Food Service Unit
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its food service equipment business for $116 million to Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a New York-based investment banking firm specializing in buyouts.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Commandant's Instruction 6110.1A.

title: Arafat Retracts His Offer to Quit
description: Cheering supporters carried Yasir Arafat on their shoulders to the rostrum at the Palestine National Council meeting today where he retracted a day-old offer to resign as chairman.

title: Mistler Rejoins Giants
description: Last August, the night after the Giants' last exhibition game, John Mistler and Phil McConkey, wide receivers and good friends, had dinner together. The next day, when the Giants made their final roster cuts, they kept McConkey and dropped Mistler.

title: BLOCK, H & R INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Yamani Sees Oil Price Spurt
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister predicted today that there would be a strong rise in oil prices over the winter and said some OPEC nations were exceeding production limits.

title: Eyes on the Deputy
description: Conservative Republicans have given up their effort to have Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, replace Robert C. McFarlane as national security adviser because President Reagan wants him to stay on. But they may have their sights set on another target: Mr. McFarlane's deputy, Rear Adm.

title: Wilander Triumphs
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden overcame a slow start to defeat David Mustard of New Zealand in the second round of the $1.28 million Australian Open championships today.

title: Kissinger the Liberal
description: When former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger rose to speak Tuesday night at a dinner marking the 70th anniversary of the weekly magazine The New Republic, his audience included many liberally oriented politicians and journalists. As if to reassure the audience that he had something politically in common with them, Mr. Kissinger introduced himself as ''a member of an extinct species, a Rockefeller Republican.''

title: MISSION FOR NAVY'S SENIORS
description: Mark Stevens was explaining what it meant to be a senior and co-captain for Navy. A few days before the opener against North Carolina, Stevens said, a classmate who did not play football told him: ''Good luck against Carolina. But remember, beat Army. That's what counts.''

title: Norwest Program Set in Wyoming
description: The Norwest Corporation, the Minneapolis-based bank holding company, said a Wyoming bank holding company had agreed to be the first financial institution to join in Norwest's new Alliance banking program.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said net income during the latest quarter includes a favorable adjustment of $70,000 to its tax rate, related to its domestic international sales corporation.

title: Japan Output Rises
description: Production at Japan's factories and mines rose 11.7 percent in October from a year earlier, up from a 12-month rise of 8.6 percent in September, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the ministry said, industrial and mining production gained 2.9 percent from September. Production in October was bolstered by increased output in the electronic, transportation and general equipment sectors, a ministry official said.

title: FRANCE ARRESTS A SEPARATIST LEADER IN GUADELOUPE
description: French authorities said today that they had arrested a man in Guadeloupe they described as the leader of a banned separatist group that has claimed responsibility for about 60 bomb attacks in the French Caribbean.

title: N.H.L. to Review Report on Fight
description: The National Hockey League will not take action against the three players ejected for fighting in Tuesday night's game between the Devils and the Minnesota North Stars until it reviews the referee's report.

title: FRENCH BACK SYRIA IN LEBANESE ROLE
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France said today that he welcomed Syria's efforts to end the conflict in Lebanon.

title: PAY TV FOR '92 OLYMPICS SEEN
description: A leading television expert predicted yesterday that the 1988 Olympic Games, to be held in Calgary, Alberta, and Seoul, South Korea, would be the last in which commercial television provides free live coverage to the United States.

title: Water at Cartier
description: A Santa Claus-red flannel drape

title: WHERE TO FIND SPACES
description: -STORAGE companies rent

title: Mennonites: Their Origin
description: The Mennonites organized in the Reformation in the 16th century after a split with Martin Luther and John Calvin over such issues as pacifism and the separation of church and state.

title: Ameritech Sees Rise in Spending
description: Ameritech said its capital spending in 1985 was expected to reach $1.88 billion, up from $1.6 billion this year. William L. Weiss, Ameritech's chairman and chief executive officer, told securities analysts in New York that nearly half of the total was planned for the fiber optic and digital facilities.

title: THE BIG CHILL
description: BOSTON The United States Department of

title: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
HERITAGE WISCONSIN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $548,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of minority interests in two banks.

title: Florida Killer Receives A Stay of Execution
description: A man condemned to die in Florida's electric chair for killing two police officers won an indefinite stay of execution today from a Federal appeals court.

title: GANDHI MAKES FEW CHANGES IN PARTY TICKETS
description: As the first phase of India's national election draws to a close and the campaign is about to begin in earnest, it has become apparent that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has made no sweeping changes in the character of his Congress-I Party ticket.

title: A GRAB BAG OF CRAFT FAIRS
description: Antiques, handmade dreidls, ceramics and ethnic jewelry are among the many items on exhibition and for sale around the city and in White Plains for the holidays.

title: Ecuador, U.S. In Agreement
description: The United States has reached an agreement with Ecuador over a contentious aspect of investors' rights that may result in new investment by Americans in that country, Ecuadorean and American officials said yesterday.

title: Signature Sales
description: Bobby Shantz, the left-handed pitcher who captured the American League's most valuable player award in 1952 when he won 24 games for the Philadelphia Athletics, never again approached that brilliance in the remaining 12 years of his major league career. But he did appear in the World Series twice with the Yankees before retiring in 1964.

title: Market Place; Fund Leader's Unusual Views
description: JOHN M. TEMPLETON, whose mutual fund

title: Blast Rocks Uganda Capital
description: An explosion rocked the Ugandan capital today, the fourth in a week, sending thousands of people fleeing in panic, witnesses said. The blast, believed caused by a bomb, hit an area of southwest Kampala where there have been three explosions in the last week. It was not known if there were any casualties today, the witnesses said.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $804,000 for the 9 months, a loss of $7,231,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations, provisions of $2.5 million for the quarter and $5 million for the 9 months for nonrecurring charges and other reserves and a gain of $3,643,000 for the 9 months from the sale of Keuffel & Esser headquarters building in Morristown, N.J. c-After a loss of $101,000 for the quarter and income of $1,097,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, a charge of $5,182,000 for the quarter related mainly to the company's Keuffel & Esser operations and tax credits of $948,000 for the quarter and $2,888,000 for the 9 months.

title: CHESS GAME ENDS IN DRAW ON 25TH MOVE
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw after 25 moves today in the 28th game of their world chess championship match.

title: DEPENDENCE ON AID IS VILLAIN
description: Infant bellies swollen by want and pale deserts haunted by thin- cloaked people and dead cattle: In Africa, the images seem to recur, cyclical emblems of dispair that bring stirrings of guilt to outsiders and then are forgotten until the next tragedy in a distant world.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES OFF SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, as short-term rates fell slightly and note and bond yields rose.

title: Gathering Satellites
description: After years of study and delay on the issue, the Joint Chiefs of Staff are expected to recommend to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger that all satellite operations of the Air Force and the Navy be placed under a single command.

title: AN OCCASION, NOT A RIVALRY
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: SUIT FILED ON ACID RAIN IN WEST
description: The Environmental Defense Fund brought suit in a Federal District Court today to force two copper smelters in Arizona to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions. The group said the smelters were a major contributor to acid rain that the group says is threatening thousands of high- altitude lakes and streams in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Pair of Sneakers Leads to a Burglar
description: A Freeport burglar who removed his sneakers to avoid making noise was convicted today of breaking into a house on Pearsall Avenue in Freeport last July.

title: Morocco and Guerrillas Report Fierce Fighting
description: Morocco and its Polisario guerrilla foes reported fierce fighting in the Western Sahara today that left scores of dead and wounded.

title: DOLE WINS BATTLE TO BE G.O.P. LEADER IN THE NEW SENATE
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas was elected majority leader of the Senate today, defeating Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska by three votes in the final round of a tense and hard-fought contest.

title: ANTONY CHANDRIS, SHIPOWNER Antony J. Chandris, a leader in Greek shipping, died Monday of cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.
description: The head of Chandris Lines and a former president of the Greek Shipowners' Union, Mr. Chandris had a merchant fleet of 39 vessels, one of Greece's largest. He was a founding member of Intercargo, an international organization that represents owners of dry-cargo ships.

title: METHADONE OFFICIALS EXPECT LITTLE IMPACT
description: The directors of two large New York drug treatment programs said yesterday that Federal approval of naltrexone would prove important for a relatively small number of heroin addicts but would probably have little impact on their methadone maintenance programs.

title: United Jersey In Heritage Bid
description: The Heritage Bancorporation of Jamesburg, N.J., said it had received an unsolicited merger proposal from United Jersey Banks yesterday, a day after an appeals court blocked a bid by the giant Mellon Bank Corporation to acquire Heritage for $175 million.

title: DANCE: MARK MORRIS AT BROOKLYN ACADEMY
description: -performers in New York who would dare to come out on the stage dressed in a loincloth for a 20-minute solo that draws upon the exotic vocabulary of Indian dance. But Mark Morris did, on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Lepercq Space, where he and the Mark Morris Dance Group are performing through Sunday as part of the Academy's Next Wave Festival.

title: WRITER SAYS SHARON KNEW OF PLANS FOR MASSACRE
description: A correspondent for Time magazine testified yesterday that Ariel Sharon knew there would be a massacre of Palestinians in Lebanon and did nothing to stop it.

title: SMUCKER, J.M. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DEMOCRATS FROM NEW YORK DIFFER ON EFFECT OF TREASURY'S TAX PLAN
description: Advisers sent President Reagan a deficit-reducing plan that would cut many domestic programs. Page D21.

title: JESUIT WAS A LEADING THEOLOGIAN
description: The Rev. Bernard J. F. Lonergan, a Jesuit philosopher and theologian whose ideas have had major impact on Roman Catholic thought, died Monday at the Jesuit Infirmary in Pickering, Ont., from multiple ailments over two years. He was 79 years old.

title: F.C.C. Extends Airfone Permit CHICAGO, Nov. 28 - Airfone
description: Inc. said today that it had received a one-year extension

title: Sound Compromise on Housing Under pressure from New York City legislators who believe that temporary tax concessions to stimulate new construction are no longer needed in mid-Manhattan, the Koch administration has come up with a sound compromise that deserves Board of Estimate support.
description: With moderate-income housing in desperately short supply, it's understandable that legislators might question the need for partial tax exemptions for builders of apartment houses where rents reach $600 or more per room per month.

title: Japanese Car Export View
description: Japanese auto industry leaders today told Keijiro Murata, the newly appointed International Trade and Industry Minister, that Japan should not extend its ''voluntary'' restraints on car exports to the United States after the current agreement expires next March.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 13
LEGISLATURE WANTS PLAN FROM CUOMO ON M.T.A
description: For the first time in years, the State Legislature has told the Governor that it is up to him to take the lead in dealing with the chronic deficits of the New York metropolitan region's subways, buses and commuter rail lines.

title: RESERVE HELPS FORDHAM DEFEAT L.I.U.
description: Joe Franco, a substitute, contributed 14 points and Tony McIntosh, the captain, had 21 as Fordham defeated Long Island, 78-67, last night at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx. The game was originally scheduled for Tuesday night, but the Blackbirds were caught in a three-hour traffic jam, causing the postponement.

title: State of Emergency in Peru
description: Peru declared a national state of emergency today to preserve order during a 24-hour general strike called for Thursday. A published decree said key constitutional rights would be suspended for 30 days. Shortly after the declaration, dockworkers voted to close the country's 15 ports as part of the strike.

title: CHILDREN ARE A THIRD-WORLD RESOURCE
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL IS SHOWN DEVICES FOR USE WITH DISTURBED
description: The police yesterday demonstrated several nonlethal devices, including a robot that sprays Chemical Mace, to be used in restraining emotionally disturbed people.

title: Pass the Prayer Book
description: As the Office of Management and Budget sent its drastic budget cut proposals to the White House yesterday, a sign at the agency seemed to express the O.M.B. mood. The neatly printed sign, on the door of Room 243 in the Executive Office Building, which is the office of Fred Upton, a Deputy Assistant for Legislative Affairs, says: ''Office of Constant Crisis. AMEN.''

title: PINNACLE PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Speculum Musicae Opens
description: The Speculum Musicae will open its 14th season Dec. 12, at 8 P.M. at McMillin Theater, Broadway at 116th Street.

title: Taiwan Foreign Trade
description: Taiwan's two-way foreign trade should reach a record $52 billion this year, up 14.28 percent from last year, a Government official said today. Vincent Siew, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said the booming trade was due to the economic recovery in the United States. The United States is Taiwan's largest export market.

title: GEN. HANS SPEIDEL, WHO PLOTTED TO KILL HITLER
description: Hans Speidel, a scholarly German general whose role in the conspiracy to assassinate Adolf Hitler eased the path toward a key NATO command 13 years later, died yesterday at his home in West Germany. He was 87 years old and lived in Bad Honnef.

title: INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $11,000 for the latest year and $8,000 for the previous year.

title: IF GIFT WRAPPING GETS OUT OF HAND
description: Some people are all thumbs when it comes to gift wrapping. Bows won't tie neatly, or the paper bulges in odd places. Others, with gifts in hand, find the wrapping process too time- consuming for their busy lives. For those who need help in gift wrapping there are professional services that can do the wrapping and in some cases even arrange for delivery.

title: LTV, Sumitomo In Joint Venture
description: The LTV Steel Company said it plans a joint venture with Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd. of Japan to build a $130 million galvanizing line at LTV's Cleveland works.

title: U.S. EXPRESSES CONCERN ON CHILE
description: The Reagan Administration expressed growing concern today over what it called a cycle of ''terrorism, repression and protest'' in Chile.

title: TEST SERVICE ACCEPTS SAFEGUARDS AGAINST BIAS
description: The Educational Testing Service said today that it had agreed to adopt safeguards to avoid racial discrimination in tests used to license insurance agents in Illinois.

title: City Investing Sued by Tamco
description: Tamco Enterprises Inc., rebuffed in two attempts to buy part of the City Investing Company, said it was suing the company in Delaware Chancery Court to enjoin a Dec. 12 special stockholder meeting and to prevent the sale of three subsidiaries unless put to a shareholder vote.

title: U.S. SAYS 6 SOVIET ARMS SHIPS HEAD FOR NICARAGUA
description: The White House said today that six Soviet ships were on their way to Nicaragua with more arms.

title: Europeans Plan Retaliation for Steel Import Ban
description: The Common Market said today that it would retaliate against President Reagan's decision to ban imports of European steel pipe for the remainder of this year.

title: FRANK WEEDEN, 91, A LEADER IN FOUNDING 'THIRD MARKET'
description: Frank Weeden, a retired investment banker who was a leader in the development of the over-the-counter trading in issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, or the ''third market,'' died Tuesday at his home in Alameda, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bankers Trust Co. has elected George A. Boronkay, James G. Hellmuth, R. Philipp Mayer, Thomas H. O'Brien and Timothy T. Yates senior vice presidents.

title: State Savings Bank Losses
description: Losses reported by state-chartered savings banks in New York State more than doubled in the third quarter, to $47.8 million, from $20.9 million in the second quarter, according to figures released yesterday by the state banking deparment.

title: OVERSIZE PHONES: VISUAL HELP
description: -large pushbuttons, numbers and letters can be a big help to the blind or sight-impaired. Webcor makes the Jumbo Button telephone with buttons that measure an inch and a half square, considerably larger than the standard ones, on a base that is 7 1/2 by 8 inches. The lettering on the buttons, which is raised, comes in blue on a white background or orange or brown on an ivory background.

title: Westmoreland Case Set to Resume Today
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the former commander of American forces in Vietnam, is expected to resume his testimony this morning in his libel trial against CBS in Federal Court in Manhatttan.

title: Technology; Plastic Engine In Racing Car
description: Why plastic over metal? ''Weight is the primary thing,'' Mr. Holtzberg said. ''It's also quieter and doesn't rust, but the key element for Detroit would be reduced manufacturing time over the process involved in making metal engines.''

title: A SHIFT TOWARD CENTER
description: With Bob Dole as their new majority leader, Senate Republicans have chosen a voice of independence from President Reagan's White House and given Mr. Dole a more visible platform for any run for the party's Presidential nomination in 1988. The longtime Senator from Kansas, who calls himself a moderate conservative, has frequently differed with the President on deficits, taxes and such issues as civil rights. He has taken the lead in promoting bipartisan packages when White House proposals have faltered and Mr. Reagan has hesitated to initiate compromises.

title: MAUREEN REAGAN ENTERS FRAY
description: Maureen Reagan, the President's eldest daughter, said today that her brother Michael Reagan was conducting a ''vendetta'' against Nancy Reagan that had left the President and his wife ''just agonized.''

title: IN A WELSH BORDER HOUSE, THE LEGACY OF THE VICTORIANS
description: MY father was a Welshman, and in 1950, when he retired, he bought Leighton Hall on the borderland between Wales and Shropshire. You will find Leighton on any good-size map, because it has been a manor for centuries and there used to be a fine half-timbered manor house that was already old in the reign of Henry VIII.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 29, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Tower Approved For Union Square
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday unanimously approved the first permit for a new building within the newly created Union Square Zoning District.

title: Jaruzelski Says Slaying Of Priest Hurt Warsaw
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said today that the killing of a pro-Solidarity priest was against the ethics and interests of the Government and ''has done a lot of harm to us.''

title: ACTING STATE JUSTICE IS CENSURED FOR HARASSING A 4-YEAR-OLD BOY
description: An acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan was censured yesterday by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for having repeatedly harassed and threatened a 4-year-old boy during questioning in a divorce proceeding.

description: An American Folk Art Christmas, the

title: HIS PITCH IS HUNGER; HIS MARKET, THE WORLD
description: C. Payne Lucas is a dreamer and a risk- taker.

title: EXXON MAY SELL A DIVISION
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was discussing with other companies the sale of its once-pioneering office systems division.

title: PLAYERS ; BOXER REACHES A CROSSROADS
description: The dream was not supposed to

title: BOOK'S POPULARITY TESTS THE VATICAN
description: Eight months after an American Archbishop complied with a Vatican order to remove his seal of approval from a popular Roman Catholic textbook, ''Christ Among Us,'' the volume continues to sell well at religious bookstores throughout the United States.

title: Productivity Down in U.S.
description: Business productivity in the United States dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, breaking a two-year string of increases and reinforcing recent signs of an economic slowdown, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Recent history has proven that we cannot assume unilaterally the role of the world's defender.

title: Complex in Village Given Support
description: The City Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved the building of a 28-unit, $20 million condominium apartment house in Greenwich Village that had been criticized for not blending with the historic district.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2.3 million for the quarter and the 9 months. c-Including a gain of $23.6 million from the disposal of shares of Reuters Holdings PLC.

title: Advertising; Test Seeks Creative Talent
description: DURING the 1970's, according to the high command of J. Walter Thompson, New York, about 90 percent of all TV commercials produced by the office were seriously copy-tested. In this decade, however, the figure is more like 30 percent, and even in that minority group the test results no longer create the frenetic go or no-go situation that existed a decade ago.

title: STEVENS, J.P. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
MARCHI CHARGES CREDIT AGENCIES UNDERRATE NEW YORK STATE BONDS
description: The chairman of New York State's Senate Finance Committee charged yesterday that credit rating agencies had systematically underrated state bonds, at a cost of more than $100 million a year in extra interest.

title: John Wiley Selling Professional Computing
description: John Wiley & Sons, publisher of technical books and journals, has suspended publication of its first consumer magazine in its 177-year history, and is in the midst of negotiations to sell it.

title: 7 Playwrights Receive Drama League Grants
description: Annual assistance awards of the Drama League of New York have been given to seven playwrights.

title: U.S. WILL NOT DRIFT INTO A LATIN WAR, WEINBERGER SAYS
description: Excerpts from speech, page A5.

title: CONGESTION IN THE SKY
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOPPERS WORLD STORES reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
NEW LEADER OF THE SENATE
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, entered a news conference this afternoon carrying a schnauzer puppy with a large sign around its neck proclaiming ''Leader.'' It was a premature Christmas present for her husband, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who had just been elected majority leader.

title: Ty-D-bol Assigned
description: HBM/Creamer has been named by Knomark Inc., to do advertising for Ty-D-bol toilet bowl cleaner, and Esquire shoe care products. Billings should be about $1 million. The previous agency was Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.

title: RECITAL: THE PIANIST MARGARET LENG
description: THOSE who found their way to the pianist Margaret Leng Tan's Carnegie Recital Hall concert Tuesday night were rewarded with one of the most stimulating musical events of the season. Miss Tan, who combines impeccable technique with a genuine spiritual and intellectual grasp of her repertory, had the splendid audacity to devote her program to the work of two American originals: Charles Tomlinson Griffes and Dane Rudhyar.

title: AROUSING POWERFUL INTERESTS
description: The Treasury proposal released yesterday, which strives to restore fairness, efficiency and simplicity to the tax code by eliminating most tax preferences, is arousing a range of powerful and diverse interests that have benefited from those preferences.

title: HUNGER'S TOLL: A GENERATION OF ETHIOPIANS
description: A few days ago a delegation of American legislators visited Korem, where as many as 40,000 refugees of the Ethiopian famine have migrated in search of food and medical care.

title: THE 'LIPPER FACTOR' SEEN CONFRONTING KOCH WITH MAJOR POLITICAL TROUBLES
description: Political ambition, hardly uncommon in government, has put in a new appearance in the Koch administration. And this time, the ambition is not Mayor Koch's.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Insurance Companies Recycling Old Bonds
description: Amid a heavy supply of new tax-exempt bond issues, securities dealers this week are also recycling nearly $500 million of old bonds previously held by insurance companies.

title: Empire StateBuilding GivenaHaloofLight
description: The top of the Empire State Building turned gold last night as a new lighting system for the 1,454-foot structure was introduced.

title: IMPLANT PATIENT GAINING STRENGTH
description: William J. Schroeder swallowed fruit juices, hot wheat cereal and a milkshake today, but he still craved for a beer as his doctors said he was growing stronger and his body was continuing to make a natural adjustment to his mechanical heart.

title: Risdon Closing
description: The Risdon Corporation has announced it will close its Waterbury plant Friday, citing declining business and an antiquated plant as the reasons. The Waterbury plant, where safety and straight pins are manufactured for the sewing trade, employed 65 people, Joseph A. Zimmermann, Risdon's president, said. He said the company had decided to close the plant rather than spend about $3 million to renovate it.

title: Pass the Sunscreen
description: Martin Kaplan, who was chief speech writer for Walter F.Mondale's Presidential campaign, is on an extended vacation, now on his way to England after getting tanned in the Caribbean. He may not be writing, but he indicated in a chat the other night in a Georgetown restaurant that he was still in search of aphorism. ''You never want to make a decision about your life without a good tan,'' he said.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $26,000 and a loss of $219,000 on the disposal of discontomued operations. c-Net loss including income of $391,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $13,708,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: COLOR TO ORDER FOR CHILDREN'S ROOMS
description: THEY started their company because they were both parents of small children and couldn't find what they considered ''nice children's furniture.''

title: THE LAST-DAY RUSH TO BUY TELECOM
description: Thousands of Britons jammed banks today to sign up for shares of British Telecom on the last day of the largest stock sale in history.

title: Cubs Sign Eckersley
description: Dennis Eckersley , one of the Cubs' four free-agent pitchers, has signed a new contract with the team that will pay him nearly $2.5 million over the next three seasons. ''We are very happy that Dennis has made the commitment to come back to Chicago,'' said Dallas Green , the general manager.

title: U.N. Backs a New Mandate For Golan Heights Observers
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the life of the 10-year-old United Nations observer force in the Golan Heights for six more months.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1984 International Hunger threatens 35 million Africans as drought has spread in large areas of the continent over the last three years. Well-intentioned relief agencies are being criticized by African Governments that point out that saving people from famine without finding a key to increasing food production puts too much pressure on fragile land. The land dies, they say, while dependency on outsiders increases. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) United States military forces will not be drawn gradually into combat in Central America, according to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. But, he said, if forces are committed anywhere, it must be with the clear intention of victory. (A1:3.)

title: HOUSE PLANT PESTS
description: WHERE do they come from? A favorite house plant starts to look straggly. Its leaves turn yellow. Blooming stops.

title: U.S. Is Helping Bring Deported Woman Back
description: Immigration officials said today that they were working to bring back to the United States a pregnant Filipino deported to Manila 12 days ago, and the woman's husband hopes to have her home by Christmas.

title: KNOCKING 'EM FLAT
description: WASHINGTON By electing Bob Dole Senate majority leader, Senate Republicans also chose to put a genuine maverick in charge of their most powerful committee: Bob Packwood of Oregon is chairman of Finance.

title: 'PARTNERS IN CRIME,' AGATHA CRISTIE ON PBS
description: WITH the hustle and bustle of the holiday season getting under way in earnest, drooping shoppers may be looking for something silly in the way of harmless diversion. ''Partners in Crime,'' beginning tonight at 9 on WNET/13 as part of public television's ''Mystery!'' series, is very silly indeed. Its efforts to be lighthearted will leave you either slightly giddy or mildly irritated, depending on your tolerance for terribly sophisticated, flapper-era Britons.

title: Turner Will Sell Cable Music Channel to MTV
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its fledgling Cable Music Channel to MTV Networks Inc. for $1 million.

title: CHINA'S TRANSLATOR GENERAL OF THE AMERICAN PAST
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIEND SAYS SPY SUSPECT 'HATED COMMUNISTS'
description: To his friends and neighbors in the luxury apartment building on the Upper East Side, Karl F. Koecher was a militant anti-Communist refugee from Czechoslovakia, a sharp-tempered debater who vigorously supported conservative causes.

title: DELLUMS ARRESTED IN ONGOING SOUTH AFRICAN PROTEST
description: Three black leaders, including Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat, and a vice president of the United Automobile Workers union, were arrested today at the South African Embassy as protests continued against that country's policies of racial segregation.

title: IPC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $1,055,000 associated with a nonrecurring payment of $1,675,000 related to the favorable settlement of a long-term manufacturing agreement.

title: BOLIVIANS MARCH AS NATIONWIDE STRIKE BEGINS
description: The police fired tear gas today to halt marchers near the presidential palace on the first day of a nationwide strike.

title: New Zealand Opposition Drops Muldoon as Chief
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, Nov. 29 (Reuters) - Sir Robert Muldoon, who was Prime Minister for nine years until he was swept from power in an election last July, was ousted today as leader of the National Party.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.75** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SURVEY FINDS HOMEWORK AVERAGE IS OVER HOUR FOR EACH SCHOOL DAY
description: America's children average just over an hour of homework each school day, but girls do more than boys and students at private schools do more than double the work of those in public schools, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ATLANTIC CITY BRIBERY TRIAL
description: For former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City, pleading guilty in mid-trial Tuesday meant he could check out of the ''Silber Hilton'' and return home until sentencing Jan. 7.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PERIODIC TABLE. By Primo Levi. Translated From the Italian by Raymond Rosenthal. 233 pages. Schocken Books. $16.95.

title: BERNARD KALB NAMED TO POST AT STATE DEPT.
description: Bernard Kalb, a widely traveled foreign correspondent for television and newspapers who covered the State Department for the last eight years, was named today as the department's next spokesman.

title: Man Says His Charges Of Sex Abuse Were False
description: A man who pleaded guilty to sex charges and agreed to testify against 24 other people charged with sexually abusing children now says he was lying when he implicated the others, according to a broadcast report.

title: Delaware Bonds Use Book Entry
description: Delaware yesterday became the first state to sell long-term bonds that will be available to investors only in book-entry form, with no printed bond certificates.

title: PROGRAM OFFERS A LIFT TO FLEDGLING DIRECTORS
description: ''I kind of thought that once you got your M.F.A. from Yale, the theater world would open up and things would get started,'' says Jim Peskin, a young director. ''That hasn't been the case at all. The number of theaters that are willing to let a young, untried director walk onto their main stage and do something are few and far between.''

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POP: JOHN WAITE AT THE RITZ
description: -songwriter who recently scored a No. 1 hit with ''Missing You,'' straddles the line between what used to be called progressive rock and the music-hall flavored pop-rock of British stars like Elton John and Leo Sayer. Mr. Waite, who performed at the Ritz on Tuesday, is a gaunt, Pierrot-like figure with a waxen face, a mop of reddish hair and a strained, thin vocal delivery that is at once urgent and lacking in color.

title: Rock Concert Halted When Floor Collapses
description: A concert by the British rock group Frankie Goes to Hollywood was halted at a downtown theater Saturday night when the floor beneath the stage collapsed under the weight of the audience, authorities said.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Space for Baby
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: FRANCE PRESERVES A FORGOTTEN SOUND
description: THIS is a tale of two tenors, and they are not Luciano Pavarotti and Placido Domingo. Earlier this fall, the New York City Opera offered Leo Delibes's faded but still sometimes charming ''Lakme.'' (If ''Lakme'' is known at all, it is for its title role, and most particularly for Lily Pons, her silvery soprano and her bare navel.)

title: HOME IMPOVEMENT
description: -improvement products that have been made with the latest materials or improved by space-age technology are often much more versatile than older models. They make excellent gifts for people who like to do their own repairs. Here are some examples:

title: RANGERS DEFEATED BY CAPITALS
description: A grinding night that saw few compelling offensive rushes by the Rangers ended with controversy and frustration as they lost, 2-1, to the Washington Capitals last night at Madison Square Garden. It was their seventh loss in eight games.

title: Kentucky Race Certified
description: The State Board of Elections Tuesday certified A. M. McConnell, a Republican, as winner of the Nov. 6 race for the United States Senate by 5,809 votes over the Democratic incumbent, Walter D. Huddleston.

title: Wien Shuts Down
description: Wien Air Alaska Inc. said it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws and immediately canceled all flight operations. The carrier's president, James J. Flood, said that the company had hoped to avoid the action, but that ''recent occurrences have made it impossible to proceed without the protection of the bankruptcy court.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture in Business Day yesterday, with an article about R. H. Macy & Company, was reproduced in mirror- image; as a result, the caption misidentified two company officials. Edward S. Finkelstein, the chairman, was at left and Mark S. Handler, the president, at right.

title: BANK OF AMERICA AND OTHERS CUT PRIME TO 11 1/4%
description: The Bank of America and several other major banks cut their prime interest rates to 11 1/4 percent yesterday, following the Chase Manhattan Bank's move, made Tuesday. Analysts said other banks were likely to follow soon.

title: ISLANDERS STOPPED BY FLAMES
description: The Islanders opened a four-game trip tonight, riding a seven-game unbeaten streak and looking for only their third victory away from home. But their streak was snapped in a 5-2 loss to the Calgary Flames and their road record stood at a dismal 2-7-1.

title: Debt
description: * Arkansas Power and Light Co. is offering $100 million of 14 1/8 percent bonds due 2014 at 99 1/2 to yield 14.20 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Disney to Buy Back 10.4% of Its Shares
description: Walt Disney Productions has authorized the repurchase of more than 10 percent of its stock, the entertainment and real estate concern said today. However, Erwin Okun, Disney's spokesman, said the company had no plans to buy out any specific shareholders, adding that officials ''simply consider it an attractive investment at this time.''

title: CITY DWELLERS 'RENT AN ATTIC' AT MINI-STORAGE FACILITIES
description: REVA ROSS, an East Side advertising copywriter, uses her space to store childhood mementos: a hula hoop, a Barbie doll and a collection of Nancy Drew novels. Steve Linn, a SoHo sculptor, uses his space to store his masterwork, a 3,000- pound, lifesize wooden truck cab entitled ''Six Days on the Road and I'm Gonna See My Baby Tonight.'' Bibi June, a dancer fresh from San Francisco and without a New York apartment, uses her space to store possessions between tours of Europe and the Caribbean.

title: TENTATIVE PACT REPORTED ON PAPERS' WAR ROLE
description: The Defense Department and two leading newspaper associations have reached tentative agreement that newspapers should cover future military operations to the maximum extent possible, according to letters recording that agreement.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Aeronca Inc., an aircraft structural assemblies concern based in Charlotte, N.C., said it had acquired Compositair Inc., a closely held company based in Newbury Park, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1984

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COURT LIMITS ACTIVITY IN HOMOSEXUAL BATHHOUSES IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Bathhouses catering to male homosexuals, closed last month in an attempt to control the spread of AIDS, may reopen under strict limitations on sexual behavior, a Superior Court judge ruled today.

title: DRUG SMUGGLERS SAY HARD PART IS WHAT TO DO WITH MONEY
description: Several longtime drug traffickers drew a vivid picture today of just how easy it is to smuggle marijuana, cocaine and other drugs into the United States.

title: ONCE-A-YEAR OPPORTUNITY TO SLEEP AN EXTRA HOUR ON AMTRAK
description: To the Editor:

title: Big-Format Ads For Doctors Only
description: When you hear that the 13-30 Corporation of Knoxville, Tenn., has created its first advertising medium for professional advertising to physicians, you will probably guess that, given the history of its talented management, it will be something different.

title: LT EX-PRESIDENTS MAKE DEBATE RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: CHEVRON PLANS TO CLOSE GULF'S HEADQUARTERS
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that it intends to close the Pittsburgh headquarters of the Gulf Corporation as part of its plan to streamline and consolidate operations once its $13.2 billion acquisition of Gulf is approved by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: GOULD ART COLLECTION TO BE AUCTIONED
description: Two hundred art works, including Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings and drawings by Van Gogh, Gauguin, Toulouse-Lautrec, Cezanne, Degas and Monet, from a private collection that have not been viewed by the public for decades, will be exhibited and auctioned at Sotheby's in New York in late April.

title: Dining at Beth Abraham
description: How about holding a benefit without

title: STUDY FINDS AIR CONTROLLERS DISCONTENTED WITH SUPERIORS
description: Air traffic controllers, although happy about their pay and job security, are still complaining about the way their superiors treat them, according to an internal survey made public today by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Celtics Beat Rockets, 110-100
description: The Boston Celtics, fueled by Larry Bird's 23 points, took the lead for the first time with 5:54 left in the third quarter and then sped to a 110-100 victory over Houston tonight, handing the Rockets their first home loss of the season.

title: REAGAN'S REACTION A PART OF STRATEGY
description: President Reagan's seemingly cool reception of the Treasury Department's tax proposal Tuesday was designed to protect him from the pressures of interests opposing particular parts of the package that would overhaul the nation's tax system, Administration officials said today.

title: The Central Flaw in Tax Reform The Treasury has now trumped both Republican and Democratic tax reformers in Congress. After a year's labor it has designed a sophisticated, indeed elegant version of the ''flat'' tax - a fairer and more efficient levy that would strictly limit deductions but greatly reduce tax rates.
description: The Treasury's plan is so sweeping and complicated, and written with so little attention to the politics of tax reform, that it may turn out to be only an academic exercise. But it deserves center stage in any reform debate, not least because it dramatizes the difficulty of trying to simplify Federal taxes without streamlining the rest of the Federal economic system.

title: MOCK ACCIDENT AT NUCLEAR UNIT STAGED FOR DRILL
description: The State Power Authority simulated a major accident at its Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor this morning.

title: FOR EL SALVADOR, TALKS PLUS ELECTIONS
description: I am writing from El Salvador, from somewhere between San Salvador and La Palma, on the eve of the second round of talks between the Government and the opposition. After 15 years of clandestine revolutionary life, I look with great hope down the road begun at the first round of talks in La Palma. To pursue that road will take determination and realism on both sides, but it could indeed lead to peace - real peace with liberty and justice.

title: JEFFERSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3 ROB PHONE COMPANY OF $900,000 CASH PAYROLL
description: Three men robbed a New York Telephone Company office in lower Manhattan of more than $900,000 in $100, $50 and $20 bills late yesterday afternoon,

title: 2 SIDES IN SALVADOR TO MEET AGAIN FRIDAY
description: Salvadoran Government and rebel officials will meet at a Roman Catholic Church retreat near the capital of San Salvador for a second round of peace talks on Friday, church and rebel spokesmen said today.

title: Reagan and Thatcher To Meet in December
description: President Reagan will confer with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at the Camp David retreat in Maryland on Dec. 22.

title: DEMOCRATS PORE OVER THE RESULTS AND DISCUSS SOME NEW FORMULAS
description: A group of leading Democrats pondered the future of their party today in a rambling symposium that heavily emphasized post-mortems on the rout of Walter F. Mondale on Nov. 6.

title: ITALY HUNTING A NEW SUSPECT IN REPORTED PLOT ON EMBASSY
description: The Italian police are searching for another suspect in a reported plot to bomb the United States Embassy here.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A 1930'S WINTER IS FORECAST: MILD IN EAST, COLDER IN WEST
description: The coming winter is likely to resemble those of a half-century ago, with relatively mild weather in the East and cold in the Western mountains, the National Weather Service said today.

title: New Money Funds Weekly Two of the nation's top chroniclers of consumer interest
description: rates said yesterday that they

title: ALL THROUGH THE HOUSE: A CHRISTMAS GIFT SAMPLER
description: FROM basics to baubles, the selection of Christmas gifts for the home offers an appealing variety of choices. There are objects and furnishings to suit many different tastes, interests and price ranges. To begin with, there are seasonal choices such as a cozy teapot or an elegant wine cooler, always welcome additions to the china closet. A number of traditional holiday items have taken on imaginative twists. For example, a set of French candles in the shape of classical columns might be just right for up-to-the-minute post-modernists.

title: BOMBAY SLAYING: ARAB LINK SEEN
description: British press reports today linked the assassination of a high-ranking British diplomat in India with the attempted slaying in London two years ago of Israel's ambassador by a Palestinian terror group.

title: Lord Howard Is Dead at 64;Former Chairman of the BBC
description: Lord Howard, former chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation and owner of Castle Howard, setting for the television series ''Brideshead Revisited,'' died Tuesday at his family home.

title: ARMAND HAMMER WILL MEET CHERNENKO ON U.S. RELATIONS
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko has asked Armand Hammer, the American industrialist, to go to Moscow for a discussion of Soviet-American relations, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW CAST OF G.O.P. LEADERS IN SENATE
description: John H. Chafee

title: Computer Research Center To Be Built by the Pentagon
description: The Defense Department announced Tuesday that it was establishing a Supercomputer Research Center to explore ''significantly different approaches'' to developing future computers.

title: On Resuscitation
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MUSIC: SOLISTI ORCHESTRA
description: THE Solisti New York Chamber Orchestra played a concert that refused to catch fire Monday evening at Carnegie Hall. The players are first-rate, and a soloist who usually strikes a spark (Frederica von Stade) was on hand, but Ransom Wilson's vaguely elegant conducting did little to differentiate one measure from the next, and almost nothing to create dramatic continuity and excitement.

title: TVI ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
