description: Because of a technical error, an article about Doug Flutie in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday misstated an assessment by Jim Valek, vice president of the New Jersey Generals. He described Flutie, the Boston College quarterback, as a ''very exciting guy'' who would have no trouble playing professional football.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS OF WEINBERGER
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of an address by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger to the National Press Club today, as made available by the Defense Department:

title: Penn Gets U.S. Citizenship
description: President Reagan today conferred honorary citizenship on William Penn, the Quaker who founded Pennsylvania, and his wife, Hannah.

title: HERS
description: WHEN our first child, Timothy, was born six years ago, my husband and I, thinking that we could provide stability and security for this tiny person we had made, began behaving in all sorts of odd ways. For example, we bought life insurance.

title: F.D.A. ANNOUNCES NEW DRUG TO BLOCK CRAVING FOR HEROIN
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug that it said blocks an addict's craving for heroin without creating a new addiction.

title: DOW OFF 14.80
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in slower trading, reflecting concern over the Treasury's tax proposals and the slowing economy, as well as weakness in the bond market.

title: Unitary Tax Suits Filed
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said today that it would join Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain in legal action seeking to declare the unitary method of taxation unconstitutional in the United States. Alcan said the two companies had filed separate but similar actions against the State of California in United States District Court in Chicago. The suits seek to end California's practice of using a company's worldwide income as a base for calculating a local subsidiary's tax.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Modest Proposal for the Homeless
description: Many of New York's homeless are incapacitated by emotional or physical ailments, but many others suffer from nothing more than a dearth of space. That shortage is a largely man-made disaster in a city that emerged from World War II with a large inventory of decent, relatively new and cheap apartment houses. Thousands of additional New York homes have been built since World War II, while the population has been shrinking. The present shortage therefore means that vast quantities of decent homes have been destroyed, abandoned or allowed to deteriorate.

title: SHULTZ AND WEINBERGER: DISPUTING USE OF FORCE
description: The Secretary of State, George P. Shultz, and the Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, have long had muted disagreements within the councils of Government over the uses of military power. The differences have been more subtle than pronounced and, so far as anyone on the outside has seen, debated in careful argument rather than explosive dispute.

title: ART: MODERN WORKS OF AMERICAN INDANS
description: WE'RE a long way from the days when Indians were encouraged by well- meaning patrons to produce a hide-and-feathers school of work that was merchandised as ''tribal'' art. Though still an identifiable ethnic minority, Native Americans, as they are now often referred to, are, by and large, as diverse in their cultural outlook as Americans in general and no longer feel dutiful about making art that reflects their Indian heritage.

title: APARTHEID PROTEST TAKES PAGE FROM 60'S HISTORY
description: Each day this week members of Congress, noted black leaders and union officials have gone to the South African Embassy here to be arrested in protests much like the civil rights sit-ins of the 1960's.

title: KOSSUTH M. WILLIAMSON
description: Dr. Kossuth M. Williamson, who taught economics at Wesleyan University for 39 years, died Tuesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: FLUKE, JOHN MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including a tax adjustment gain of $4,566,000, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: Money Fund Assets Climb
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds continued their surge, rising $2.76 billion, to $208.04 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: HONDURANS OPEN TO A NEW U.S. BASE
description: Senior Honduran officials offered today to allow the United States to build a permanent military base in their country.

title: PARLAN PLANS A SERIES OF CONCERTS WITH SHEPP
description: HORACE PARLAN, an American jazz pianist who has been living in Denmark for the last 12 years, flew into town Monday and will fly back to Denmark next Tuesday. His brief visit has two purposes: One is to play in the United States for only the second time since he left in 1972, a six- day engagement with the saxophonist Archie Shepp at Sweet Basil that runs through Sunday evening. The other is to pick up a grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Arts to do a series of concerts with Mr. Shepp in which they will present the history of black music.

title: I.B.M. DEAL WITH STORAGE REPORTED
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has ordered a large number of data storage systems from the Storage Technology Corporation, according to sources in the industry. Storage Technology, a rival manufacturer, recently sought bankruptcy protection in part because of its inability to compete with I.B.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Once we went down toward that operating room, I was relieved because I felt that my husband was fading away from me, and now I feel I have him back again and that I have another chance.'' - Margaret Schroeder. (A1:1.)

title: 'GOD'S BROKER' AUTHOR REFUSES TO PRODUCE NOTES
description: Antoni Gronowicz, author of ''God's Broker,'' a biography of Pope John Paul II that was withdrawn from book stores after its publisher termed it ''fraudulent,'' yesterday defied a Federal judicial order in Philadelphia to produce all notes, travel records, correspondence and photographs collected while writing it.

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO BACK A FREEZE IN OVERALL BUDGET
description: President Reagan tentatively decided today to freeze overall spending in the 1986 budget at the current level, according to Administration officials.

title: Financial Corp. Wants Knapp Payment Back
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it was going to court to force its former chairman and chief executive, Charles W. Knapp, to return the $2 million payment he received hours before he resigned last Aug. 28.

title: Environmental Protection, Paralyzed William Ruckelshaus healed the Environmental Protection Agency that Anne Burford shattered because he was trusted on all sides. In his too-brief tenure he restored the professionalism and quality he had given the agency as its first Administrator. Yet one of his frustrations in office was that the E.P.A.'s Administrator is trusted too little.
description: Congress has shaped environmental laws in a way that ''assumes they will not be administered fairly,'' he complained last week. By allowing the E.P.A. too little discretion, the laws stifle progress in protecting the environment.

title: SENATE UNIT IS TOLD OF SEX TOURS
description: A worldwide network of child pornographers promotes such activities as child sex tours and auctions, with few efforts by governments to stop them, a Senate panel was told today.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT is usually an auspicious sign in an ethnic restaurant to see at least one customer hyperventilating while waving a hand in front of his mouth. I usually walk over to the table and, when the customer catches his breath, ask what he is eating. I make sure to order it.

title: Park Avenue Alight
description: Park Avenue will be alive with light and music on Sunday, when the annual tree-lighting and caroling ceremony begins at 7 P.M. Trees from 53d to 79th Streets will twinkle with lights, and carolers will gather at the Brick Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street. The lights will be on nightly from 5 P.M. to 1 A.M.

title: Southland Plans Cutback at Citgo
description: The Southland Corporation said it plans to lay off 700 employees and reduce production by 46 percent by year-end at its Citgo Petroleum Corporation refinery here because of deteriorating market conditions. Sam J. Susser, president of Citgo, said the reduction would reduce crude oil production at the refinery to 140,000 barrels a day from an average 1984 rate of 258,000 barrels a day, and would cut the work force of 1,500 to about 800.

title: CHILE EXPELS U.P.I. REPORTER OVER A DISPATCH
description: The Government today expelled a United Press International reporter, charging that he had filed a ''false dispatch.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob MacMillan , the 12-year National Hockey League veteran who was obtained by the Chicago Black Hawks from the Devils last summer, has been placed on waivers. . . . Jack McKinney , who resigned from the head-coahing job of the Kansas City Kings earlier this month, has been named a full-time scout for them. . . . Ronnie Lester , the guard cut by the Chicago Bulls, has signed with the Los Angeles Lakers. He takes the roster spot vacated by Earl Jones , who is sidelined by a sprained ankle. . . . Howard Slusher , agent for 6-foot-10-inch Joe Barry Carrol , says he has rejected the Golden State Warriors' final contract offer to Carrol.

title: Tomy Toys Business To West Coast Agency
description: Keye-Donna-Pearlstein of Los Angeles, one of four finalists when DYR won the Tomy Toys account in the summer of 1983, has just got a piece of the business.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
ART: ROMARE BEARDEN, 'RITUALS OF THE OBEAH'
description: ROMARE BEARDEN'S gift for storytelling deepens with time. In front of his collages and watercolors of black American life, there is a sense of an artist so at ease with his craft that his lines and colors lead him not only into his personal and cultural experience but also through it, to a human strata that is shared by everyone. Bearden's musicians, farm workers and street people are reminders that the language of Cubism and Abstract Expressionism can be put in the service of just about any narrative goals, no matter how rudimentary or exotic.

title: Slow Comeback
description: Best Decision won Monday's seventh race at Aqueduct at odds of 9-2. Only nine months earlier, the 4-year- old filly underwent surgery that gave her longer odds of ever making it to the winner's circle again.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE only thing about ''The Cotton Club'' more monumental than the film's well- publicized production troubles is its advertising campaign, which began early this month. The first television spots for the film were broadcast on Nov. 7, ''almost not early enough,'' according to Orion's executive vice president of advertising and publicity, Charles Glenn. Competition among Christmas movies is expected to be particularly fierce this year, and Mr. Glenn acknowledges there is less built-in audience awareness of ''The Cotton Club'' than of some of its rivals. ''But I think we can build it into a very honest want-to-see,'' he said.

title: GENERAL DISPUTES QUOTE IN CBS TRIAL
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland and a lawyer for CBS argued yesterday over one of the most memorable phrases of the Vietnam War, with the lawyer suggesting that the general had misled Washington into believing there was ''light at the end of tunnel'' in 1967 and the general saying he had not used that expression.

title: TASTE OF LIFE ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: A child's voice guides a tour down Essex Street between Canal and Grand. 'In just two city blocks,' the voice says, 'there is one Chinese laundry, five Jewish religious article stores, two pickle stands, one fruit stand.'

title: Uphill Climb
description: In six years as a tennis pro, Andres Gomez has steadily but quietly improved to the point where he is ranked fifth on the Association of Tennis Professionals computer and fourth in the Volvo Grand Prix tour standing.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $5.6 million gain from the reversal of the tax provision previously recorded against income earned by the company's domestic international sales corporation. c-Net loss Gearhart said that Geosource Inc., acquired recently, contributed $79.3 million to revenue for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Mazda Plant In U.S. Is Seen DETROIT, Nov. 29 - The
description: Mazda Motor Company is expected to announce on Friday

title: Sterilizer Suits
description: The American Sterilizer Company said five additional lawsuits had been filed by shareholders against the company, First Boston Inc., Kelso & Company and certain other defendants in connection with a tender offer for American Sterilizer.

title: DOCTORS DO A LITERARY AUTOPSY ON HESTER PRYNNE'S LOVER
description: It was 134 years ago that Nathaniel Hawthorne did away with the Rev. Arthur Dimmesdale at the end of his classic tale ''The Scarlet Letter.''

title: Volcker Sees Fed Flexibility
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last night that with inflation apparently under control, the Fed has more room to maneuver in governing monetary policy.

title: FOR ANIMALS AND ART, A PAIR OF ELEGANT PARTIES
description: Bob Hope played Carnegie Hall at long last, the city's zoos reaped $500,000, the Museum of Modern Art dedicated a new gallery and the United States Secretary of Agriculture put on a pigtailed Willy Nelson headdress and sang country-western songs. It all happened Wednesday night, and the limousine crowd was out in force.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Metromedia Offering To Raise $1.3 Billion
description: The Metromedia Broadcasting Corporation is offering four debt issues to raise about $1.3 billion to repay bank debt incurred in the leveraged buyout of Metromedia by its senior management earlier this year.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $36.7 million for the quarter and year.

title: Loophole on Liability SeeninSeatBeltLaw
description: Insurance companies may balk at paying liability claims in full for New York motorists who have an accident while not wearing seat belts after the state's new seat belt law takes effect Saturday, according to industry experts.

title: LILLY PULITZER INC.'S CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY FILING
description: The designer and sportswear company owned by Lilly Pulitzer Rousseau, the Palm Beach socialite, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a credit of $3,474,910 representing net proceeds from life insurance.

title: NEGOTIATE A BAN ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: Though arms control talks with the Soviet Union are scheduled for January, the Administration's sudden interest in restraining the arms race will not easily translate into a good treaty. If President Reagan wants to achieve a lasting arms accord, he should begin where both countries left off - with space weapons - and he must start with a cogent negotiating strategy.

title: POETS' GROUP PRESERVES LINK TO SICILY
description: A people Become poor and enslaved When they are robbed of the tongue Left them by their ancestors: They are lost forever . . . . - From ''Language and Dialect''

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pipe Falls Killing Worker
description: A construction worker was killed on a West 34th Street sidewalk yesterday when a section of pipe fell from the office building in which he was working and struck his head.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
BRIEFS ;  Debt
description: * Allied Corp. is issuing 10 billion yen of 6 3/4 percent seven-year Eurobonds, at par, through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. There are about 245 yen to the dollar.

title: 84 of 99 Political Bans Lifted in South Korea
description: President Chun Doo Hwan lifted a political ban on 84 people today, three months before scheduled National Assembly elections, but left 15 better-known dissidents on a four-year- old blacklist.

title: THE IMPROBABLE POLES
description: WARSAW Poland never ceases to produce the improbable, if not the simply impossible.

title: Tribute to a Printmaker
description: ''Art in Print: A Tribute to Robert Blackburn,'' an exhibition of 45 works by 20 artists, opens today at the New York Public Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue at 135th Street.

title: WRITER'S 'ANALYSIS' FORMED KEY PART OF SHARON ARTICLE
description: A Time magazine correspondent testified yesterday that a key part of a disputed article about Ariel Sharon was based on ''my evaluation - my analysis.''

title: BRAZIL'S BLACK UNDERCLASS: ALMOST HALF A NATION
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1984 International The discharge of a Salvadoran officer accused of organizing the 1981 murders of two United States labor advisers and the head of the country's land redistribution program has been ordered, according to a close aide of President Jose Napoleon Duarte. Mr. Duarte ordered the discharge to be immediate and without pension. It is believed to be the first time a Salvadoran army officer accused of human rights violations has been dismissed. (Page A1, Column 3.) 770 Poles have jumped ship this year from the ferry Rogalin in ports in West Germany, the only Western door still ajar for Poles. Some of the Poles call it a flight from economic misery, corruption, political oppression and fear. (A3:1-3.)

title: JON HENDRICKS SINGING TONGUE-TWISTING TUNES
description: JON HENDRICKS, a jazz singer best known for his rapid-fire, tongue-twisting lyrics to the tunes of Count Basie and other famous instrumentalists, is making a rare weeklong appearance through Sunday at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village.

title: McGraw Realigns Into Units
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that it was realigning its major operations into market-oriented business units, and it named two new corporate executive vice presidents. The structural changes and the appointments are effective Jan. 1.

title: BABY HELD HOSTAGE RESCUED
description: A woman killed her 3-year-old son and her infant nephew yesterday after holding them hostage in a South Bronx apartment.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Arrests for Spying
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was investigating its handling of the arrests of an accused Czechoslovakian spy and his wife in Manhattan, amid allegations by the man's lawyer that they were interrogated improperly.

title: LIGHT OPERA GROUP STAGES 'YEOMEN'
description: ''We treat operetta with tender loving care instead of camping it up with our tongues in our cheeks,'' said Ronald Noll, musical director of the Village Light Opera Group, as the company prepared for the opening production of its 50th anniversary season, Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Yeomen of the Guard.''

title: Indian Music and Jazz
description: The Alternative Museum, 17 White Street (966-4444), will present jazz and Indian music this weekend.

title: ONCE AGAIN, WAX RECORDS
description: In this age of electronic sound, two young phonograph buffs are swimming against the stream of sonic progress.

title: JUDGE RESTRICTS BOSTON'S SEWERS TO CLEAR HARBOR
description: A state judge today barred new commercial connections to the aged sewer system that serves Boston and 42 other cities and towns, dumping tons of raw sewage into the harbor.

title: Economic Scene; Ambivalence On Tax Plan
description: THE Treasury Department's report to the

title: California Ballot Issue Thrown Out by Judge
description: A Superior Court judge today declared unconstitutional a statewide ballot question approved by voters in June that cut the Legislature's budget 30 percent and changed its internal rules in favor of the Republicans.

title: Ex-IBH Head Found Guilty
description: Horst-Dieter Esch, the former chairman of IBH Holding A.G., the giant construction machine group whose collapse last year was at the heart of a bank crisis here, was convicted of fraud today by a court in Hanau, in Bavaria, and sentenced to three and a half years in jail.

title: Coast Nuclear Unit Down
description: Operators at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant worked today to restore power to the generator of Unit No. 1, which automatically shut down Wednesday for the second time in less than a week because of a malfunction. A spokesman said the unit, with a rated full capacity of 1.1 million kilowatts, shut off because there was too much water in the steam generator.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Thefts Reported At a City Hospital
description: Thousands of dollars worth of property may have been stolen from unused buildings at the city-run Sea View Hospital and Home on Staten Island, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Monkey on Space Flight In 1959 Dies at 27
description: Miss Baker, the tiny squirrel monkey that 25 years ago became one of the first two animals to go into space for the United States, died today of kidney failure, officials said.

title: Suit to Halt Hunting In U.S. Refuges Filed
description: The Humane Society of the United States, in a bid to halt a ''repugnant'' practice, filed suit today to stop sport hunting in Federal wildlife refuges.

title: GRAY STILL DOGGED BY SOME CHARGES
description: Ten days after issuing a brief statement that appeared to clear Harry J. Gray, chairman of the United Technologies Corporation, of allegations that he electronically bugged the conversations of other senior executives, directors of the company are preparing a report on other charges against Mr. Gray.

title: GIBRALTAR'S NEIGHBORS JOYFUL AS BARRIERS TUMBLE
description: Here in the lee of the Rock, on the Spanish side of the border beneath the powerfully upward thrusting mountain that is the British territory of Gibraltar, human concerns won over nationalism.

title: MATURE CITRUS TREES SHOW CANKER SIGNS, FLORIDA OFFICIALS SAY
description: Citrus canker has been discovered for the first time among mature trees in Florida, agricultural officials said today. A growers' group said there was no real cause for alarm.

title: A NICARAGUAN INDIAN LEADER CRITICIZES RIVAL REBEL GROUPS
description: A Nicaraguan Indian leader says an effort to unite two factions of the Miskito Indians has stalled because of pressure from rival insurgent groups.

title: S & K FAMOUS BRANDS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 27
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CHESS: DIFFERENT START BUT FAMILIAR END
description: Gary Kasparov made a big change in his opening repertory and also produced a small-scale innovation leading to a positional pawn sacrifice in the 28th game of the world championship chess match Wednesday, but it was a gesture without force. Anatoly Karpov, the 33-year-old titleholder, had no trouble achieving a draw with the black pieces.

title: ENVIROMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No results available because the company had completed its initial public offering in September.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The clubs meet for the second time this season. In the first encounter, Mike Gminski, filling in for the injured Darryl Dawkins, hit a 16-foot jumper at the buzzer for a 118-117 New Jersey victory.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUBLISHING: THE JEWS IN CHINA
description: THE author's tour of distant cities is an established part of publishing, but Sidney Shapiro, a Brooklyn-born graduate of St. John's Law School, would seem to have carried it to extremes. In order to promote his latest book, he has come all the way from China.

title: 26 Get 10 Days to Reply To Aquino Charges
description: The Philippine armed forces chief, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, and 25 other people were asked today to show cause why they should not be charged with the murder of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: MARK MORRIS, A NEW FORCE IN DANCE WORLD, HURTLES ON STAGE
description: THERE is a rehearsal going on at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Lepercq Space. Ten dancers rock and crawl like delicate beasts, tenderly exalted by the Vivaldi ''Gloria,'' to which they move. Minuscule beneath the high ceiling, the dancers ebb to the sides, leaving a void filled with light. There is a crash as the choreographer hurtles onto the stage for a solo, his long, curly hair flying and one hand reaching to tug an earring. A startled member of the stage crew jumps. Affectionate laughter bubbles from the wings. Mark Morris has returned.

title: YALE STRIKERS VOTE TO RETURN TO WORK
description: Striking clerical and technical workers at Yale University voted tonight to return to work Dec. 4 with their contract dispute unresolved. Their union said they might walk out again if an agreement were not reached by Jan. 18.

title: Money Under the Door
description: Please accept this anonymous

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATING KILLING BY POLICE IN EVICTION
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has started a civil-rights investigation into the fatal shooting by a city police officer of a 66-year-old woman who resisted eviction from her Bronx apartment last month.

title: Indians Post for Bavasi
description: The Cleveland Indians may still be looking for a new owner, but the club has found a young man with an old baseball name to take over as president and chief operating officer when 74-year-old Gabe Paul retires Jan. 1. He is Peter Bavasi , 42, who has been operating a consulting service in Tampa, Fla., since resigning in 1981 as the chief front-office executive of the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: CARMEN'S UNION GETS READY FOR A STRIKE AGAINST L.I.R.R.
description: Members of the Carmen's Union made preparations early this morning for a 6 A.M. strike against the Long Island Rail Road that the railroad said could shut down service for the line's 175,000 riders.

title: Jazz Meets Jazz
description: ''Afro-American Jazz Meets Afro- Cuban Jazz'' will be presented Sunday by the Caribbean Cultural Center. The concert will feature the pianist Randy Weston, who has lived in Africa, and the Cuban trumpeter- arranger Mario Bauza, who helped invent Afro-Cuban jazz with the Machito orchestra in the 1940's. Mr. Weston will lead a 12-piece band, and Mr. Bauza will perform with some of the city's top young Latin-jazz musicians, including the keyboardist Jorge Dalto, the saxophonist Paquito d'Rivera and the drummer Ignacio Borrell.

title: KRIEG JUSTIFIES SEAHAWK'S FAITH IN HIM
description: The Seattle Seahawks were so satisfied with the performance of their quarterbacks last season that during the off-season they tried to sign Warren Moon.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1984
description: The Economy

title: SPY CASE FIGURE ON COAST SAYS SHE AIDED F.B.I.
description: A Russian emigre accused of spying for the Soviet Union said Wednesday that she had been an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and had had sexual liaison with two bureau agents, including the man charged as her co-conspirator, Richard W. Miller.

title: AFTER A LONG REST, SPINKS LOOKS TO A FEBRUARY TITLE DEFENSE
description: Slowly, the stars are coming out again. Michael Spinks, inactive since outpointing Eddie Davis last Feb. 25, appears headed for a Feb. 23 defense of his light-heavyweight title against David Sears of Howard Beach, Queens.

title: ERNST, E.C. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A FILM ON L.I. TURNS EXURBIA INTO SUBURBIA
description: To make a movie about suburban life, the film makers left the suburbs and came here.

title: VAN BREDA KOLFF GOES HOME AGAIN
description: Strangers live in the two-story frame house at the corner of McCartney and High Streets, the first home Butch van Breda Kolff's children knew. The bar down the block, where the coach and his cronies played quoits in the basement, is now a student pizza parlor, but a minor heart problem has curtailed van Breda Kolff's drinking, so that's probably just as well.

title: Posts Are Filled By Biederman, Burson
description: Other companies in communications - Biederman & Company and Burson-Marsteller - had major personnel announcements to make.

title: PANEL PROPOSES SWEEPING CHANGES IN SENATE RULES
description: A special Senate committee recommended sweeping changes today in the way Senators organize themselves and consider legislation.

title: Heckscher on La Guardia
description: August Heckscher, former Parks

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
Wall St. Sales Abuses Feared
description: A Government regulatory official said today that efforts by securities firms to cope with tough times may be fostering practices harmful to the investing public.

title: 7 New Orleans Officers Charged in Man's Death
description: Seven police officers were indicted today by a Orleans Parish grand jury on charges of negligent homicide in the death of a man who died struggling against arrest.

title: CENTRUST OFFERS EUROBOND ISSUE
description: Centrust Savings and Loan Association, a $3.6 billion Florida chartered savings and loan formerly known as the Dade Savings and Loan ASsociation, is offering $1.2 billion face amount of zero coupon collateralized Eurobonds due in 25 years at a price of 5,995, or $59.95 per $1,000 bond, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities. The idfference between the purchase price and the face value equals a semiannual yeild of 11.58 percent.

title: Comsat Venture
description: The Comsat General Corporation said it had agreed to form a partnership with Hi-Net Communications Inc. to construct a network for distribution of video programming via satellite to 1,500 Holiday Inns across the country in an investment worth up to $35 million. Services provided by the new network would include Showtime, Cable News Network programming and a pay-per-view package of recently released movies, concerts and special events, said Scott Chase, a Comsat spokesman. Hi-Net Communications is a subsidiary of Holiday Inns Inc.

title: Lloyd Looks Out For No. 1,000
description: If Chris Evert Lloyd wins her third- round match against Pascale Paradis of France tomorrow in the Australian Open at Melbourne, it will mark the 1,000th singles victory of her career. If she reaches that plateau, officials of the Women's Tennis Association and the Virginia Slims tour plan to present the 29-year-old champion with a cake bearing 1,000 candles at courtside.

title: GOODHEART-WILLCOX CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WORK AT HOME GIVES NEW LIFE TO THE SWEATSHOP
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING ; Alors! No W.C.'s?
description: The United States and France

title: Nystrom Gains in Australia
description: Third-seeded Joakim Nystrom of Sweden defeated Colin Dowdeswell of Britain, 6-4, 6-2, 6-4, today to advance to the third round of the $1.28 million Australian Open Tennis Championships at Kooyong.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months nets included a gain of $84,000 from change in estimated depreciation.

title: LEBANON AND ISRAEL TRADE CHARGES ON TALKS
description: Israel and Lebanon, meeting for the sixth round of troop-withdrawal talks here, blamed each other today for the slow pace of the negotiations.

title: STUDENT LOAN OVERDUE? UNCLE SAM WANTS YOU
description: Overdue student loans. Inadvertent overpayments to veterans and Social Security recipients. Nonpayment of Small Business Administration disaster loans. Crop and mortgage insurance delinquencies. Defaults on loans from the Rural Electrification Administration.

title: D H HOLMES CO., LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including gains of $720,000 for the quarter and $1,616,000 for the 9 months from the sale of investment properties. c-The company broke even. d-Including a gain of $1,121,000 from the sale of investment properties.

title: GASTINEAU DRWAS THE MOST ATTENTION, EVEN BEFORE THE GAME
description: He is the most famous sack-producer in recent football history. But Mark Gastineau has only one sack in the last three games and a total of one other tackle the last two games.

title: U.S. MOVES TO BAR LEAKS ON ARMS TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration, in advance of high-level Soviet-American talks on arms control, has introduced an extraordinarily stringent policy to prevent unauthorized disclosures to the press or to other Government officials, State Department officials said today.

title: FOLKS RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Errant Torpedo Exploded
description: Navy demolition experts, using plastic explosives triggered by remote control, today blew up a torpedo after it was snared by a fishing trawler in Rhode Island Sound. A Navy spokesman said the torpedo had probably been a test warhead dating to World War II, when Narragansett Bay was a center for torpedo production and testing. The torpedo was rigged with a floatation device, packed with eight pounds of plastic explosives and detonated by remote control somewhere off Point Judith.

title: Coke Sweetener
description: Coca- Cola USA said it would begin using Nutrasweet as the only sweetener in Diet Coke. Brian G. Dyson, senior vice president of the Coca-Cola Company and president of Coca-Cola USA, said using 100 percent Nutrasweet would cost more than blending with saccharin, and the extra cost would be ''shared with our bottlers on an equitable basis.'' Despite the switch to 100 percent Nutrasweet in Diet Coke, the company said it remains committed to the multi-sweetener concept for other soft drinks.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: The company said year-ago 9 months figures include results of operations of the company when it was operated as a division of Atlan- Tol Industries.

title: GERMAN BANKER ON LEAVE FOR TRIAL
description: Hans Friderichs, accused of accepting $122,000 in payments from the Flick industrial conglomerate while he was Economics Minister of West Germany, will step aside at the end of December as head of the Dresdner Bank, the country's second-largest bank.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and year nets include a credit of $700,000, or 14 cents a share, resulting from adjustment of charges recorded in fiscal 1982 in connection with planned changes in the company's method of product distribution, and a credit of $600,000, or 12 cents a share, for a reduction in vacation pay liability resulting from renegotiation of a labor contract.

title: FROM BARB TO QUIP, DOLE LEADS WITH HIS WITH
description: Senator Bob Dole, the Senate's new majority leader, leads with his wit.

title: SHOOTING TOWARD A MOVING GOAL
description: It seems like sound, if somewhat

title: 6 NATIONS TO FORM JOINT GULF FORCE
description: The leaders of Saudi Arabia and five Persian Gulf nations announced tonight that they had agreed to establish a rapid deployment force to help defend themselves against external military threats.

title: Head of Indian Bureau Quits
description: Kenneth L. Smith has submitted his resignation as director of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, the Interior Department announced today. Mr. Smith, A Wasco Indian from Oregon's Warm Springs Reservation, is the first Indian with a reservation background to direct the bureau. The resignation becomes effective Dec. 7.

title: CORRECTION
description: Dispatches from Boston on Sept. 20 and Oct. 30 about the Massachusetts Senate campaign misstated the role of John F. Kerry, now a Senator- elect, in Vietnam Veterans Against the War. He was a leader and spokesman of the organization in the early 1970's, but he was not a founder. The group was formed in 1967.

title: Change at Boston U.
description: After winning 55 games in 8 seasons, more victories than achieved by any other coach in Boston University's 77-year football history, Rick Taylor decided it was time to turn the job over to a younger man. So the 43- year-old Taylor, who will continue to serve as the school's athletic director, has stepped aside and handed the coaching job to Steve Stetson , a 33- year-old former assistant at Boston University and New Hampshire who had been head coach at Hamilton since 1982. . . . Darryl Rogers will apparently be returning for his sixth season as head coach at Arizona State despite the opposition of important alumni boosters. The school's president, J. Russell Nelson , indicated at the annual football awards dinner that Rogers's contract, which expires in January, would be renewed. . . . Coach Bobby Ross of Maryland, who had been considered the leading candidate to take over at Missouri, said he planned instead to stay with the Terps, in part because Missouri had postponed a decision on its coaching vacancy until mid-December.

title: Western Union
description: The troubled Western Union Corporation said that it was negotiating with its unions for wage and benefit concessions reportedly worth $35 million. Separately, Western Union said it would sell its E.F. Johnson Company cellular mobile phone subsidiary.

title: Abzug on Abzug
description: Bella Abzug delivered the inaugural

title: Advertising; Seat Belt Campaign And Law
description: THE people producing advertising to educate the public about

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: A leading figure in British contemporary music, John McCabe, is in town wearing two hats - composer and pianist. His ''Rainforest,'' commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, will receive its premiere performances at Tully Hall tonight at 8 and Sunday at 5 P.M. And, in the same concerts, he will join Joseph Swensen in Mozart's piano and violin sonata in A (K.525). Performers of ''Rainforest'' will include the Emerson String Quartet and Charles Wadsworth, piano; Leslie Parnas, cello; Paula Robison, flute; Gervase de Peyer, clarinet, and Richard Fitz, glockenspiel. Also on the program are two Bach preludes and fugues arranged by Peter Maxwell Davies for flute, clarinet, viola, cello, marimba and harpsichord. Tickets: $15. To charge: 874- 6770. 53 PRIZE FILM AT THE MODERN

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has named Kenneth I. Chenault senior vice president and general manager of the Merchandise Services division of the American Express Travel Related Services Co., and Daniel S. D'Agostino senior vice president and general manager-money order and payment products for the same unit.

title: Diner's Journal
description: JOHN'S PIZZERIA at 278 Bleecker Street, where customers queue outside the door nightly for some of the best brick oven pizzas and calzones in town, has opened an uptown branch. The new restaurant, called John's of Bleecker Street, at 408 East 64th Street, is a large and spiffy establishment as pizzerias go. It has colorful paintings, potted plants, wooden booths and gold tablecloths. Pete Castellotti, the owner, plans to open an outdoor cafe in the summer.

title: CUOMO DISTRIBUTION OF CAMPAIGN-STYLE FLIER
description: Governor Cuomo today ordered his staff to stop distributing a campaign-style pamphlet listing the accomplishments of his administration.

title: CATERPILLAR TO SHIFT MORE WORK ABROAD
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced today that it would reduce its tractor manufacturing operations in the United States and concentrate more of them overseas.

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: The New Nixon
description: The new portrait of Richard M.

title: Dough on a Stick
description: From a thumbnail-sized lump of

title: ACTIVIST'S CHURCH IS TO BE DISSOLVED
description: Members of a Clairton, Pa., church whose pastor has been dismissed for his militant stand in a labor dispute were notified today by Lutheran officials that the church will be temporarily closed and the congregation dissolved.

title: DEL WILLIAMS
description: Del Williams, a former star offensive guard at Florida State University and with the New Orleans Saints, died Wednesday at age 39 of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the illness known as Lou Gehrig's disease. Williams was a third-round choice of the Saints in the team's first National Football League draft, in 1967, and became a starter in his rookie season. He played in New Orleans until the Saints released him in 1973, then spent a year with the World Football League team in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acro Energy Corp., Elk Grove, Calif., said it plans to offer to repurchase shares of its common stock held by owners of 99 or fewer shares.

title: AUCTIONS
description: FOUR sales of Judaica next week at New York's top auction houses - three at Sotheby's and one at Christie's - will offer hundreds of selections of 12th- through 20th-century Hebrew books, manuscripts and art works worth more than $6 million. The auctions are being held at a time when prices for Judaica are soaring, and when a court action is still pending regarding the legality of a sale of Judaica at Sotheby's in June.

title: ART: BRONZES AND DRAWINGS BY SAINT-GAUDENS
description: THE Parks Department is cleaning and refurbishing all the Augustus Saint-Gaudens monuments in the city but, most likely, only the pigeons and a few observant passers-by will notice. Others can either tour the sites, which are in Brooklyn as well as Manhattan, or they can visit the Houghton Gallery at Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, which is currently given over to a show about Saint-Gaudens (1848-1907).

title: STAR WARS WON'T FLY
description: Even in the face of the deficit crisis

title: Greek Music and Dance
description: An evening of Pontic Greek music and dance is planned tonight at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street.

title: Pete Dawkins Remembers
description: Tomorrow afternoon and evening,

title: TAX PLAN CREDIT IMPLIES SHIFT TO ASSIST HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: Buried in the Treasury's tax simplification proposal, amid recommendations to repeal dozens of business tax incentives, is a sentence advocating the continuation, on a modified basis, of a 25 percent credit for research and development.

title: No Time for Blues
description: Ever since it became known that John Mecom was ready to sell the Saints, there have been fears in New Orleans, particularly among officials of the Louisiana Superdome Commission, that a new owner might move the team out of the city, leaving the Superdome without a prime tenant. Now Mecom has confirmed that the club is on the market, for $75 million, and he just may have a buyer who can meet his price and be counted on to to keep the team in New Orleans: the family that owns the company that manages the Superdome for the State of Louisiana.

title: CUOMO SEEKING EXTENSION OF TAX TO MAINTAIN PRESENT TRANSIT FARES
description: Governor Cuomo today asked the Legislature to extend for another two years a corporate tax surcharge that subsidizes subways, buses and commuter railroads in the metropolitan region.

title: Esterline Plans
description: The Esterline Corporation said it had signed an agreement to acquire the assets and business of Hollis Automation Inc. for $17 million plus the assumption of bank debt of about $8 million. Hollis makes automated equipment used in the soldering and cleaning of printed circuit boards and related applications.

title: DUARTE DISMISSES SALVADOR OFFICER
description: A Salvadoran Army officer accused of organizing the 1981 killings of two United States labor advisers and the head of the country's land redistribution program has been ordered discharged from the army without pension, according to a close aide of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: A BLURRING OF BOUNDARIES BETWEEN TWO CITY AREAS
description: Defining the exact border between Manhattan neighborhoods such as Yorkville and the Upper East Side can be a tricky business, complicated by history, local pride, real estate values and wishful thinking.

title: Dining Out Guide: Winter Casseroles
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BON TEMPS ROULER, 59 Reade Street

title: Ogilvy and Doremus Making Acquisitions
description: Both Ogilvy & Mather and Doremus & Company, a subsidiary of BBDO International, are involved in acquisition machinations that came to light yesterday.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MID-STATE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (OCALA, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are from Jan. 20, 1983 to Sept. 30, 1983 since the company converted to a stock form on Jan. 20.

title: 3,500 TO 4,500 LIBYANS ARE REPORTED STILL IN CHAD
description: A Western analyst here asserted today that Libya still had 3,500 to 4,500 troops in Chad despite Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's assertion this week that all of his forces had left the country.

title: REDSKINS TRIUMPH TO LEAD DIVISION
description: Joe Theismann passed for two touchdowns and the Washington Redskins scored twice on fumble recoveries to take sole possession of first place in the National Conference East with 31- 17 victory over the Minnesota Vikings tonight.

title: Bankruptcy Law Upheld
description: A 1984 law governing Federal bankruptcy courts withstood its first major legal challenge today when United States District Judge Robert H. Schnacke ruled that the nation's 232 bankruptcy judges are legally in office.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: A SPECIALIST IN SONGS OF STAGE
description: Jimmy Lyon, a pianist who was the accompanist for the singer Mabel Mercer for eight years and who was noted as a performer of the music of Cole Porter, Jerome Kern, Richard Rodgers and other composers for the musical theater, died as a result of cancer Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Paramus, N.J.

title: A TROUBLE-SHOOTER FOR THE E.P.A.
description: After a brief presentation before a group of scientists earlier this year, Lee M. Thomas was asked to say a few words about himself. Was he a lawyer, someone in the audience asked, or an engineer or environmental specialist?

title: ROBOT RIGHTS IS A GROWTH MOVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: LINDA RONSTADT IN PUCCINNI'S 'LA BOHEME'
description: It's not consumption that's killing Linda Ronstadt's Mimi in the New York Shakespeare Festival's crazy- quilt production of ''La Boh eme'' - it's abject fear. From the moment she first knocks on the door of the poet Rodolfo's Parisian garret, Miss Ronstadt seems tentative and shaky, and the panic rarely subsides thereafter. Whatever else is to be said about this performer, she's no fool and no coward. One can tell at a glance that Miss Ronstadt herself knows that she's not at home with Puccini - and one can only admire the bravery that allows her to forge ahead anyway, reason be damned.

title: BEAUMONT PROPOSES A JULLIARD LINK
description: The new leadership of the Vivian Beaumont Theater yesterday pledged itself to an ''artistic purpose,'' to a link with the Juilliard School, to the establishment of an endowment fund and to the appointment of an artistic manager with an ''earned reputation.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: Schocken Books. $15.95. For Maurice Valency, who is 81 years old and has been known as a drama critic, playwright and producer, this is a first novel. It is a novel set in the past - the period sketched here is the 1930's - but it is the past not so much recaptured or strenuously searched for, as remembered through the mild and dissolving lens of nostalgia.

title: Mead to Sell Unit
description: The Mead Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Mead Money Management division to current management of the division through a new company, Flagship Resources Inc.

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, an aerospace contractor, said it would begin a phased three-week shutdown of its aluminum smelter at The Dalles, Ore., after efforts to sell it failed.

title: TONIGHT, 'MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING'
description: ABOUT a year behind schedule - not bad for such a mammoth project - the BBC's undertaking of ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' 37 of them, enters its final season tonight at 9 on Channel 13 with ''Much Ado About Nothing.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Inland Steel Names A New President
description: Robert J. Darnall has been elected president of the Inland Steel Company, the nation's fourth-largest steelmaker, succeeding Frank W. Luerssen, who will continue as chairman and chief executive.

title: INCREASE IN AIDS CASES REPORTED
description: The number of AIDS cases reported in the United States is continuing to climb at a fairly steady rate, the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported yesterday in their weekly morbidity and mortality report.

title: FILM: 'CHINA 9, LIBERTY 37,' AT THALIA
description: THE laconic, supremely masculine style that has made Monte Hellman's films (including ''The Shooting,'' ''Ride in the Whirlwind'' and ''Two- Lane Blacktop'') such cult favorites is very well represented by Mr. Hellman's ''China 9, Liberty 37,'' which was made in 1978 and opens today at the Thalia. A Spanish-Italian co-production, it takes place in a charred- looking Spanish landscape meant to represent the American West.

title: Market Place; Tax Plan May Aid Publisher
description: WHEN the Treasury Department introduced its tax simplification plan on Tuesday, it created uncertainty among many investors, according to analysts, and thus has helped unsettle a stock market that was already worried about the slowing economy, disappointing corporate profits and the huge budget deficit.

title: Knicks' King Still Out
description: Bernard King , the National Basketball Association's top scorer, remained at home nursing a painful groin pull yesterday as his Knick teammates flew to Milwaukee for a game tonight against the Bucks. Dr. Norman Scott , the Knicks' team doctor, was unsure if King would be able to play tomorrow night against the Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden.

title: RESEARCHER FINDS CHROMOSOME WEAK SPOTS
description: The discovery of 51 previously unknown weak spots on human chromosomes was reported yesterday by a research team at the University of Minnesota.

title: Lybrand, S.E.C. Settle
description: Coopers & Lybrand and M. Bruce Cohen, a partner in the accounting firm's Philadelphia office, have settled a disciplinary proceeding brought against them by the Securities and Exchange Commission in July, the commission announced today. The firm had been accused of ''unethical or improper professional conduct'' in audits of Digilog Inc., a computer company based in Montgomeryville, Pa.

title: Conrail Steps Criticized
description: Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole has challenged the propriety of lobbying activities and expenditures by the management of Conrail to promote a plan for the sale of the carrier.

title: Seal in the Lobby
description: ''Go and do thou likewise,'' reads

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in October 1984.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN COMPOSERS GROUP
description: THE American Composers Orchestra opened its ninth season last night at Alice Tully Hall with an eclectic program of 20th-century music that consisted of two recent works bracketed by familiar older ones by Charles Griffes and Aaron Copland. As usual, the orchestra played everything alertly and conscientiously, under the baton of one of its founders, Dennis Russell Davies, a conductor to whom no modern score seems to present any problem. He is one of those rare leaders who combine technical precision with an ability to phrase freely and to make clear the musical point, if any should exist.

title: BROADWAY
description: TOM O'HORGAN, the man responsible in good part for giving the world ''Hair'' and ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' has come up with what he hopes will be a method of avoiding multimillion-dollar Broadway and Off- Broadway disasters. Mr. O'Horgan has been working on his plan for some time, but his recent involvement with ''The Three Musketeers,'' which closed almost before it opened, convinced him of the necessity of working in what he calls ''a four- or five-stage development process.''

title: Rates Up on Money Growth
description: Short-term interest rates rose a tenth of a percentage point yesterday, with most of the increase coming after the Federal Reserve announced a huge $6.7 billion increase in the M-1 measure of the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Nov. 19.

title: TOO MANY SHEPARDS CALLING ONE FLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: OPENING GALA BY ALVIN AILEY TROUPE
description: AS usual, it was an unusual opening gala by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Grace Bumbry, an international opera star, not only lent her dazzling presence Wednesday night at the City Center, but also sang.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Nov. 30, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Fox Talks On Studio Reported
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, beset by an $89.7 million loss for its latest year, is negotiating to sell its 50 percent interest in a film studio to Mary Tyler Moore Enterprises, a source said today.

title: Electrolux Plants
description: The Electrolux Corporation, one of the nation's leading vacuum manufacturers, said it would close its manufacturing plant in Greenwich and a tool room in Norwalk on May 31, 1985, with a loss of 830 jobs. Manufacturing operations at the two plants will be transferred to other locations, according to Roger Loeffelbein, group vice president for human resources. The 51-year-old, two-story plant in Greenwich had an outdated design and was too old for renovations, the company said when it announced tentative plans to close the plant on Nov. 13.

title: ACKERLY JOINS BIDDING AT REGISTER AND TRIBUNE
description: A third offer was made yesterday for the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, escalating a bidding war touched off earlier this month. And media industry analysts said another bid may be made soon.

title: LABOR STRATEGY NEXT TIME
description: The pundits have been telling us that organized labor's election strategy - to back a candidate early and stay the course - was a terrible flop, as if the ''union bosses'' formed up shoulder-to-shoulder and, on the count of three, shot themselves in the foot. And eight of 10 columnists go on to say that these ''bosses'' have lost touch with the rank-and-file.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $47,435 for the quarter and $104,299 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $122,958 for the quarter and $529,077 for the 9 months. The company said results for the latest quarter includes $4,484,000, or 67 cents a share, from a change in the tax law.

title: Cleaner Taxes Washington is suddenly seized again with tax reform. There are three plans, one from the Treasury and two from Congress, all designed to spread the tax load more evenly. None deal with the most crucial need, to raise new revenue, and each angers interest groups, by closing old loopholes. As a result no reform at all may occur. But when three distinctly different sponsors come up with a similar conclusion, it's worth examining even if it's wishful. What's up?
description: The current catchword is fairness. The modern income tax originated with the same motto, in a 19th-century populist protest against raising revenues solely from sales taxes and tariffs. The fairness of taxing income is now well established. The unfairness lies in the many exceptions the tax code makes for different types of income.

title: 300 Reported Arrested In Peruvian Strike
description: The police clashed with demonstrators in several cities today, injuring dozens and arresting more than 300 during a nationwide strike called to protest the Government's economic policies, union leaders said.

title: THE VEENING HOURS
description: ''BUT

title: St. John's to Open Tonight
description: St. Bonaventure, St. Francis and Lafayette will attempt to do this weekend what no other team except St. John's has ever done: win the Lapchick Memorial Tournament that kicks off the Redmen's basketball season.

title: ROAD CONTRACTORS FOUND TO BE EVADING ANTI-BIAS LAW
description: The State Transportation Department has disqualified almost a fourth of the 200 companies doing roadwork as minority-group or women's enterprises after an investigation concluded that many were fronts for white male owners.

title: Prices Rise in Sweden
description: Swedish producer prices rose four- tenths of 1 percent in October from September and 8 percent from a year earlier, Statistics Sweden said today.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $532,000 for the quarter and $874,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $295,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the termination of a pension plan. c-Including tax credits of $699,000 for the quarter and $1,142,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $600,000 for the 9 months from the termination of a pension plan.

title: IMPLANT SURGEONS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The House Ear Institute and the 3M Company said that the following surgeons in New York were currently implanting the hearing device that approved today:

title: Bonanno Son Faces Charge
description: Joseph C. Bonanno Jr., the son of the reputed crime figure, and his wife have been released on bond after being indicted in what Federal officials said was a cocaine conspiracy. Mr. Bonanno, 39 years old, and his wife, Karen, 38, were arraigned Wednesday before a Federal magistrate in San Jose according to an assistant United States attorney, Michael Lasater.

title: N.B.A. Roll Call
description: U.C.L.A.'s domination of college basketball ended in 1975 with the Bruins' 10th National Collegiate Athletic Association championship in 12 years. Even so, the Bruins still have more representatives than any other college in the National Basketball Association.

title: SONG: CHEEK IN SCHUBERT
description: Reaction to Schubert's ''Winterreise'' is bound to be extremely personal and difficult of explication. John Cheek sang the great cycle at the 92d Street Y Tuesday, accompanied by James Levine. Mr. Cheek is a serious artist, with a good voice; Mr. Levine is a brilliant pianist; each had thoughts about the songs.

title: OFF BROADWAY, BIG SEASON ON SMALL STAGES
description: A THEATRICAL panorama of the miraculous world of Hieronymus Bosch complete with such unearthly delights as an aerial ballet; a musical-comedy version of modern Japanese history; the teeming, rawboned landscape of the Klondike Gold Rush - this weekend New York's small stages are filled with spectacle, melding sound, movement and music.

title: ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $80,000 for the quarter and $257,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gain of $1,374,000 from sale of stock. d-After a gain from discontinued operations of $163,000.

title: REAGAN INAUGURATION TO BE LOW-KEY AFFAIR
description: The festivities surrounding Ronald Reagan's second inauguration as President will emphasize events for his young supporters rather than the lavish trappings and black-tie activities that accompanied his inauguration in 1981.

title: Women's League Curtails Season
description: The Women's American Basketball Association announced today it was ending its season two weeks early for half of the six teams and closing the league office in Columbus, Ohio, because of financial difficulities.

title: Rutgers Downs Rider, 77-73, in Opener
description: John Battle scored 27 points to lead Rutgers to a 77-73 victory over Rider tonight in the season-opener for both teams.

title: Rhymes With Waking Up
description: Two of the fiercest combatants of

title: MAN IS ARRESTED IN AUTHOR'S SLAYING, THEN FREED DALY CITY, Calif., Nov. 29 (UPI) - A California man who was arrested two days ago in connection with the slaying of a Chinese author, was released today when prosecutors said there was not enough evidence to hold him.
description: Three members of a Taiwan street gang were still being sought for the murder of Henry Liu, 52 years old, at his Daly City home Oct. 15.

title: Pepsi-Cola Plans New Queens Plant
description: Mayor Koch, Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin joined officials of the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of New York yesterday to announce officially the relocation of the company's plant in Long Island City, Queens, to the borough's College Point Corporate Park.

title: CHIEF OF LTV STEEL WILL RETIRE
description: E. Bradley Jones, the 57-year-old chairman and chief executive of the LTV Steel Company, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, surprised the industry today when he announced he would retire at the end of the year.

title: MICROMEDICAL DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no year-ago results because the company commenced operations in September 1983.

title: Cr eche at Metropolitan
description: The 21st Christmas tree and baroque cr eche display will go on view tomorrow in the medieval sculpture hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. The display, which features a decorated 20-foot blue spruce and an assortment of carved Neapolitan cr eche figures, will be on display through Jan. 6.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GARBAGE PROBLEM IS BIGGER THAN RECYCLING
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile-Argentina Pact On Frontier Is Signed
description: Chile and Argentina signed a Vatican-mediated treaty today, settling their dispute over the Beagle Channel in Tierra del Fuego.

title: Coleman Quartet
description: The tenor saxophonist George Coleman is leading a quartet through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Agca Said to Write Of Threats by Soviet
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II, has written to a Turkish newspaper saying he was threatened by Soviet and Bulgarian secret services, the newspaper said today.

title: DAKOTA WATER PROJECT REVISED BY U.S. PANEL
description: A special commission has tentatively approved a revision of a $1.2 billion North Dakota water project that would eliminate two reservoirs and cut in half the amount of land that would be irrigated.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MORE ROOM FOR A KNIFE SHOW
description: The New York international custom-knife show will be held at

title: DREW NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $243,000 for the quarter and $785,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: A METROMEDIA OFFERING TO RAISE $1.3 BILLION
description: The Metromedia Broadcasting Corporation is offering four debt issues to raise about $1.3 billion to repay bank debt incurred in the leveraged buyout of Metromedia by its senior management earlier this year.

title: DARIO FO PLAYS END RUN
description: ''Accidental Death of An Anarchist'' will close with tomorrow night's performance at the Belasco Theater. The play opened Nov. 15 and ran for 20 performances. It was written by Dario Fo and starred Jonathan Pryce.

title: THE SCREEN: 'SKI COUNTRY'
description: ''WARREN MILLER'S SKI COUNTRY'' is a travelogue strictly for ski enthusiasts, none of whom could possibly be as enthusiastic as Mr. Miller himself. The mastermind behind a ski magazine and 34 other films on the subject (with titles like ''Sno Wonder''), Mr. Miller peppers his soundtrack with gung-ho hyperbole, inviting the viewer to ''steal a brainful of thrills.''

title: TRYING MULTILATERAL DIPLOMACY IN THE AMERICAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kohl Comes to Town
description: The Chancellor of West Germany, Helmut Kohl, today becomes the first foreign head of state to pay his respects to President Reagan and congratulate him on winning a second term. But some diplomats here are not ecstatic about the timing of the state visit and are skeptical that it will materially strengthen relations between the two nations.

title: TAKING A STAND AGAINST STANDING FOR THE PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE
description: The morning began typically at Randolph High School. At 7:45 o'clock, the assistant principal, Richard Power, played a battered 45-r.p.m record of the Philadelphia Orchestra playing ''The Star Spangled Banner'' over the public address system and recited the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.

title: END 11-YEAR SLUMP
description: The Devils won at the Spectrum for the first time in their history tonight when Aaron Broten had two goals in the third period to beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-1.

title: POLISH SHIPS SEEN AS LAST OPEN EXIT
description: Docked safely in from the choppy Baltic Sea, the sleek white Rogalin, a 7,500-ton ferry, looks like it was designed for the rich and the privileged. But this year, 770 Poles, most of them with good proletarian credentials, have used the Polish luxury vessel to flee to freedom.

title: HEART PATIENT BRIEFLY LEAVES BED
description: William J. Schroeder got out of bed today and walked a few steps to a chair for the first time since he became the second recipient of a permanent artificial heart. He also drank three-quarters of the can of beer that he craved.

title: Bridge:16 Winners in the Reisinger Have a Right to Feel Lucky
description: The finale of the Reisinger Board- a-Match team championship in San Diego Sunday was perhaps the most remarkable in the history of the event: A tie between four four-man teams with an uncommonly low winning score.

title: Dow Declines 11.93, to 1,193.46
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday for the second consecutive session after a Government report indicated that the economy was continuing to slacken.

title: MUSIC: NOEL COWARD TUNES ADDED TO JULIE WILSON REVUE
description: JULIE Wilson opened her fourth engagement in New York within a year this week. During 1984 she has done a Cole Porter program and a Stephen Sondheim program at Michael's Pub, a Rodgers and Hart program at the Cafe Carlyle and now, in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, she has added No"el Coward to her list.

title: Computer Magazine Acquires Another
description: Professional Computing magazine, started by John Wiley & Sons, is being acquired by Computer Communications in Camden, Me., for an undisclosed sum. The Maine company, two years old, already publishes Portable 100 for owners of Tandy 100 computers, and Epson World for owners of the Epson machine.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.7%
description: The Government index that is intended to predict the course of the economy fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, its third decline in the last five months, the Commerce Department reported today. Until this choppy period began, the index had increased 21 months in a row.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1984

title: SCHOENBERG: THE COMPOSER AS ARTIST
description: ''ARNOLD SCHOENBERG'S VIENNA'' is the name of an exhibition at the Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street. Though bulked out with paintings and drawings by Gustav Klimt, Oskar Kokoschka and Egon Schiele, it derives both its title and its primary interest from the inclusion of more than 30 paintings and drawings by one of the great composers of the 20th century. It has the further merit of introducing some paintings and drawings by Richard Gerstl (1883-1908), the painter who killed himself after Anton Webern had persuaded him to end his association with Schoenberg's first wife.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES TOXIC WASTE CHIEF TO HEAD THE E.P.A.
description: The official in charge of toxic waste programs in the Environmental Protection Agency will succeed William D. Ruckelshaus as the agency's Administrator, President Reagan announced today.

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DETROIT LETS TOP DOWN AGAIN
description: When the Chrysler Corporation revived the convertible after a six-year absence in 1982, the car was regarded by many in the auto industry as little more than a novelty, an attention-getting attempt by a failing company.

title: GRAND JURY STUDIES GIRL'S CHARGES OF ABDUCTION BY 3 POLICE OFFICERS
description: A Queens grand jury has begun looking into allegations by a 16-year-old girl that three plainclothes police officers abducted her and that two of them forced her to perform sexual acts before releasing her.

title: P.L.O. PARLAY: ARAFAT SURVIVED, BUT NOW WHAT?
description: The single important fact about the 17th session of the Palestine National Council, the Palestinian parliament in exile, is that it took place. When the session ended late Thursday night after nearly a week, the question that remained was: Where does Yasir Arafat go from here? By virtue of the fact that he managed to hold the meeting, Mr. Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman and longtime survivor of Arab politics, managed to survive again, outmaneuvering the Syrian-backed rebel factions of the P.L.O.

title: Continental Group To Sell Florida Gas
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation of Texas said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Florida Gas Transmission Company and its 4,300- mile natural gas system from the Continental Group for about $800 million. Florida Gas is the only natural gas supplier in most of the state.
